SIEGE PERSISTS IN SARAJEVO
For all the welcome relief of the cease-fire, which marked its first month on Wednesday, war-shattered Sarajevo is still under siege. All normal commerce and communication is cut off and nearly all of the food comes on U.N. aid flights. A1
 

GENERAL AFFIRMS U.S. BOSNIA ROLE
The top U.S. military officer today reaffirmed Washington's commitment to send as many as 25,000 troops to help enforce a total cease-fire in Bosnia, but he acknowledged that the Administration lacks public support to do so. A12
 
ISRAELIS INSPECT MASSACRE SITE
Walking past coiled firemen's hoses that had been used to wash away blood, members of an Israeli inquiry board went into the Cave of the Patriarchs and traced the path of the Jewish settler who massacred Muslim worshipers. A3
 
EUROPEAN CRITICS ASSAILED
Mickey Kantor, the U.S. trade representative, assailed European governments for criticizing Washington's policy with Japan. D1
 
NIXON ANGERS YELTSIN
President Boris N. Yeltsin abruptly canceled a meeting next week with Richard M. Nixon, saying he was "deeply, personally offended" by the former President's visits with top Russian opposition leaders. A5

The U.S. has devised a novel means to verify the dismantlement of warheads and the Pentagon wants to propose it to Moscow, senior Pentagon officials said. A6

PUB-DATE: March 10, 1994

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 2924 words

HEADLINE: Low Pay and Closed Doors Confront Young Job Seekers

SERIES: Staying Afloat: Work in the 90's -- First of four articles.

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo.

 BODY:
Andrew Flenoy has ironed his white shirt until there are sharp creases down the sleeves. His hands are folded in his lap, his back is ramrod straight, and his feet jiggle nervously as he begins his fifth job interview in as many weeks -- this one at Sprint, the long-distance telephone company that is Kansas City's largest private employer.
Mr. Flenoy, 21, comes across as nervous and sweetly sincere as he tells the interviewer how much he wants the $17,274-a-year job selling long-distance service. 
 Mr. Flenoy, a high school graduate who completed a year-and-a-half training course at a business trade school, is scrambling for a foothold in a work world that has turned inside out. Even in an economy that has created three million new jobs in the last three years, career positions -- the old-fashioned jobs offering benefits, vacation and room for advancement -- are increasingly hard to come by.
 
Hard Reality
 For millions of people across the country, young and old, economists' predictions of the late 1980's have now hardened into the reality of daily life. While there are still plenty of good jobs for computer engineers, nurses and others whose skills fit the changing economy, other workers have had to reconcile themselves to a job market that has little use for them.
The recovery started almost three years ago in this heartland metropolis of 1.6 million people. In its demographic makeup and economic indicators, Kansas City closely mirrors the national average -- and these days, it is an exemplar of the profound changes that have transformed the American workplace for young workers like Mr. Flenoy, including these:
*Once-reliable employers like T.W.A. and Sears have dumped workers, and executives with master's degrees remain as vulnerable to layoffs as production-line assemblers. The unskilled castoffs of shrinking industries, used to earning $20 an hour, are finding that the new labor market offers them no more than $6. Many now work two or three jobs, without matching their former salary or benefits.
*Temporary jobs are at their highest levels ever. There are 24.4 million part-time and temporary workers, representing 22 percent of employed Americans. In Overland Park, Kan., a well-off suburb of Kansas City, one branch office of Manpower Inc., a large temporary employment agency, filled out 4,500 W-2 forms in 1993 for employees who had worked anywhere from a day to a full year -- 30 percent more than the previous year.
*For some skilled workers, the increasing flexibility of the work world is a boon, allowing them to change jobs at will, work when and how much they want, and earn more as employers compete for them. This group includes not only the computer engineers and other bastions of the changing economy, but also electricians and other blue-collar workers whose skills remain in demand.
*With the layoffs of so many men whose paychecks once kept the family afloat, women are not merely bolstering household incomes -- their salaries have become essential to maintaining a tenuous grasp on a middle-class life style. And even though women streamed into the work force during the 1980's, the median household income in Kansas City was $31,637 in 1980 but had slipped to $31,613 by 1990.
While the public's perceptions of the national economy may have improved in recent months, Americans' insecurity about their own jobs is substantial and widespread, according to The New York Times Poll. Two-fifths of the work force voiced worry that during the next two years they might be laid off or forced to take pay cuts. And in the last two years, 24 percent said that in the last two years they have personally experienced layoffs, pay cuts or reductions in hours, according to the poll, taken in mid-February.
For economists and workers alike, the big question is whether the recovery will eventually spur the creation of plenty of good new jobs. Some experts say that is bound to happen, now that the explosive growth of temporary jobs has flattened.
But others say the American work force has undergone such basic structural changes that many high-paying jobs -- from factory foremen to office supervisors and professionals -- are gone for good.
 
Their Market
Amid a Recovery, More Layoffs
 Whatever the future, the "downsizings" and "rightsizings" that began in the recession are continuing, as the largest companies here, as elsewhere, keep pruning payrolls in 100- and 1,000-worker sweeps.
Last year, Sears Roebuck here closed a distribution center, leaving more than a thousand people jobless. Other companies have also shrunk their work forces, including Marion Merrell Dow, a pharmaceutical company; Allied Signal Inc., which makes nuclear bomb parts here; Hallmark Cards, renowned around town as a benevolent employer; Colgate-Palmolive and A.T.& T.
Even a young, growing company like Sprint, with 9,000 local workers and 50,400 nationwide, had a round of layoffs in August, cutting 1,000 workers nationwide, 120 of them in the Kansas City. Overall, the telecommunications industry laid off 60,000 workers in the country last year.
Certainly some businesses are adding full-time, well-paying jobs with good benefits. Twentieth Century Services Inc., a mutual fund company here, has seen its work force grow from fewer than 300 eight years ago, to 1,900 now, and there are plans to add 300 to 400 this year.
Transamerica Life Insurance and Annuity Company of Los Angeles is moving 500 jobs here, and hundreds of small businesses are picking up abandoned workers and keeping the unemployment rate down to 5.4 percent last year, below the national average of 6.8 percent. And at least one employer, Ford, is adding people to its 4,000-worker plant to make the new Contour and Mercury Mystique, the successors to the Ford Tempo and Mercury Topaz.
But new jobs are not coming on stream the way they did after previous recessions. Frank Lenk, the senior economist at the Mid-America Regional Council here, calculates that in the three years since the last recession ended, the Kansas City region has gained about 20,000 jobs -- compared with 93,000 jobs created after the previous downturn in the early 1980's.
 
Their Jobs
$6 an Hour, 7 Days a Week
 To their bitter disappointment, Mr. Flenoy and most other young workers are finding that "McJobs" -- jobs that pay $6 an hour or less, and offer little in the way of a career path -- are about the only openings around.
"It just seems really difficult for my generation," said Mr. Flenoy, the oldest of six children in a rural Arkansas family.
Data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics confirm that impression: in the last decade, the average wage has fallen 5 percent, adjusted for inflation. And median full-time weekly earnings for those aged 20 to 24, expressed in 1982 dollars, dropped to $199 in 1993, from $215 in 1989.
As a placement director at the University of Missouri-Kansas City, Maria Manuel has watched graduates with high expectations struggle in the job market. "Almost everyone is having a hard time finding jobs," she said. "Some of them go out there thinking they should be able to find something paying $25,000 a year, and we have to tell them $17,000 is probably more like it."
There are some young people, those who have specialized skills in fields like nursing or auto mechanics, who have employers clamoring for their services.
Jason Walters, who like Mr. Flenoy is 21, has had no trouble finding his way in the work world. He began working on cars as a sophomore in high school, for $5 an hour. These days, after getting a degree in automotive technology at Longview Community College, he is earning $9 an hour, and planning to be married in May.
"I love my work, and I feel pretty secure in it," said Mr. Walter, who works at Cooper's Automotive. "There are plenty of jobs for me. I know because I see how hard it is for them to hire anybody here. But my dad is a fair wrench-turner, and I always knew I wanted to be a mechanic. I didn't run around with the in crowd in high school; I just worked on cars all the time."
But most others have a string of disappointments to recount. Some are mailing dozens of resumes a month, and getting nothing but form-letter rejections. Others wonder why, with more education than their parents, they still cannot find work anywhere near as stable or well-paying as their parents have.
 
Internship Pays Off
 Reese Isbell is one of the luckier ones: He found work he liked just a month after graduating from the University of Missouri-Kansas City in 1992.
But these days, even lucky young people are likely to land in part-time jobs, if not internships or temporary assignments.
"I had an internship my last semester of college, working 20 hours a week in the public affairs office at Planned Parenthood, and I really liked it," said Mr. Isbell, who was a sociology major. "My father couldn't believe I would have any trouble getting a job when I graduated. He thought there would be all kinds of people recruiting me. But there weren't. I went to a temporary agency, and got a data entry job, but I hated it so much that I quit after two days."
So Mr. Isbell leapt at the chance for a paid job at Planned Parenthood -- still 20 hours a week, but now earning $8 an hour. To make ends meet, he also took a $7-an-hour weekend job as an admitting clerk at a hospital, a position he has kept even as the Planned Parenthood job expanded to 30 hours, and soon, to full time.
"I'm working seven days a week but I know I'm really lucky, and it wouldn't have happened without the internship," said Mr. Isbell, 23. "My father is a computer programmer, which used to be a shoo-in, but a couple years ago he lost his job and was out there pounding the pavement at the age of 40."
 
Their Prospects
When College Is Not Enough
 "Reality Bites," the current movie about twentysomethings, reflected young workers' profound uneasiness about their job prospects. The heroine graduates as valedictorian of her college class, then is promptly dismissed from a television job where she had been warned that she could be replaced by an unpaid intern. Her boyfriend has been dismissed from 12 jobs, and, she says, is "on the inside track to Nowheresville, U.S.A."
Her mother urges her to get a job at a burger place. Her best friend tries to recruit her to work at the Gap -- and is offended when she says she is not interested. And when she applies for media jobs, she is rejected as overqualified at one, underqualified at the next.
"It all sounded very familiar," said Dan Wulf, a graduate of Wesleyan University in Connecticut who came to Kansas City a year and a half ago to set up a summer program for children. He now works as a secretary at the University of Kansas Medical Center during the week, and at Kinko's copy center from 2 P.M. to 11 P.M. on weekends. On Sunday mornings, he teaches Hebrew school.
He and Mr. Isbell have both concluded that to get more challenging jobs -- and avoid seven-day workweeks -- they will have to go to graduate school.
"We're getting more college graduates than we are college-level jobs," said Dan Hecker, an economist for the labor statistics bureau. "About 20 percent of the college graduates end up in non-college-level jobs."
The number of college graduates working as street vendors or door-to-door-salespeople grew from 57,000 in 1983 to 75,000 in 1990, the last year the statistics were compiled, according to the bureau. In the same period, the number of truck or bus drivers with college degrees grew from 99,000 to 166,000.
 
From Carhop to Paralegal
 For those without college degrees, the struggle for a good job is even tougher: Renda Rush married at 17 and had her first child the following year. She began working as a carhop at Sonic Drive-In two years later and stayed there -- with breaks for the birth of two more children -- until the end of 1992.
"What started me thinking was seeing a lot of high school girls, home for the summer, working at Sonic," said Ms. Rush, now 26. "Then in the fall, they'd go on to college, or whatever, and I'd still be there. And I finally thought, they're moving on and I've been here five years, I've got kids, and I'll be left behind forever if I don't do something about it."
Ms. Rush went back to school, choosing a two-year paralegal training program at Penn Valley Community College. And she is on her way to a career: She started as a receptionist at a personal-injury lawyer's office, but is now doing paralegal work too.
Ms. Rush, who earned $4.85 an hour at Sonic, earns $7 an hour, with the understanding that her pay will rise when she gets her degree later this year.
 
Their Fallback
A Generation Of Temps
 In the recession, many employers, here and elsewhere, tried to keep their costs low by increasing their use of part-timers and temporaries, who work only during busy periods and usually get no benefits.
According to data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, employment with temporary agencies accounted for 15 percent of the new jobs created last year and 26 percent the year before -- compared with less than 3 percent of the new jobs created in 1989.
In dozens of interviews with young workers in Kansas City, temping seemed to be an almost universal experience: Mr. Wulf had a weeklong job in a real-estate office through a temporary agency; Mr. Isbell had his data-entry job, and Mr. Flenoy did a market-research project surveying theater-goers.
And for some young people it becomes a way of life. For a year and half now, Cabrenna Clark, 24, has been working for Kelly Services, a temporary employment agency, earning about $6 an hour, plus some overtime. But every six months, she sends out a round of resumes for the business jobs she covets.
"I work every day, and there always seems to be another assignment when one ends," said Ms. Clark, who has completed a year and a half of college and plans to return later this year. "I've had a couple places call me back as a temp. But it seems like right now, people are more interested in working with temps than hiring for permanent jobs."
Ms. Clark said her parents, both civil servants -- her mother working for the state, her father for the Federal Government -- tell her she is wasting her time working as a temp.
"I don't think they understand how hard the job market is," she said. "If you're in Kansas City, and you're not in medicine or telecommunications or the military, you can just forget it. Temping is what I can do right now. "
 
Their Disappointments
Another Day, Another Interview
 For Mr. Flenoy, what started as a temporary job has become more permanent than he ever intended. He was hired as a temporary dishwasher at Myron Green, a Kansas City company that runs cafeterias and catering in offices and schools. After 90 days, he was offered a permanent dishwashing job, for $5.50 an hour, then was quickly promoted to cafeteria line server ($5.75), grill cook ($6.00) and catering manager ($6.25).
Mr. Flenoy, the first in the family to go beyond a high school education, has come tantalizingly close to several good permanent jobs in the last two months. He was almost hired as a secretary-administrator for a church, and was one of the two final candidates for a corporate data-entry job.
But the Sprint job was the one he coveted, both because it paid more than the others, and because the company offers a generous benefit plan including tuition reimbursement that Mr. Flenoy hoped to use to further his education.
At the interview at Sprint, Mr. Flenoy began to relax as the recruiter, Mary Reiter, worked through her list of printed questions, asking him to talk about a time he tried hard and failed, a time he was too persistent, how he knows if he has done a good job. Ms. Reiter smiled encouragingly as Mr. Flenoy told about making a special effort to arrange a beautiful food tray, and thinking he had done a spectacular job -- until he heard the customers' reactions.
"Normally in interviews when they ask questions, I'm completely blank, but this time it just flowed along," Mr. Flenoy said after the interview.
 
Thinking of New Towns
 But a good interview was not enough: on Sprint's multiple-choice telemarketing aptitude exam, Mr. Flenoy scored too low to win another interview. So for the time being, he must stay at the food-service job.
"I'll do it as long as I have to," Mr. Flenoy said one recent morning, as he took a break from arranging a taco-bar luncheon. "But I really want some kind of business job. My resolution for 1994 is that if nothing comes along, I'll relocate and start from scratch somewhere else."
Mr. Flenoy said he knew from the time he was in high school that he wanted to leave Marianna, Ark., where his only job prospect seemed to be packing cotton or farming. He always wanted a career in business. After a semester at a community college, he moved to Kansas City, where he had relatives, attending Wright Business School in the mornings and working in the evenings.
Now he is tired of the burgundy and black uniform he must wear, and of the sense that he works every day from 6 A.M. to 2 P.M. just to earn enough money so that he can come back and work some more the next day.
But he does not tell his family how disheartened he is. He does not want to discourage his younger siblings.
"I'm trying my best to be very, very positive for them," he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Markets
To help the millions of Americans who own municipal bonds, the Government issued new rules intended to make it easier to track the bonds' value. [Page A1.]
Stocks advanced modestly on moderate trading. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.69 points, to 3,853.41. [D6.] 
 Bond prices got a much needed lift from the Fed's Beige Book report, rebounding from their lows for the day. [D16.]
Wheat prices fell after President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia said his country would not import grains this year. [D15.] The dollar rose against the yen. [D15.]
 
The Economy
The Federal National Mortgage Association is planning new rules to make home ownership easier for lower-income Americans, people involved in the effort said. [D1.]
Even in an economy that has created three million jobs in the last three years, whether a person has a good position depends not on economic cycles but on factors beyond anyone's control. [A1.]
The nation's economy expanded moderately early this year, the Federal Reserve reported. [D2.]
 
International
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, denounced European governments for criticizing Washington's toughened trade policy with Japan. His language was caustic. [D1.]
 
Companies
As an independent corporate director, retired Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., a former Chief of Naval Operations, has become a shareholder ally in board rooms. [D1.]
Since Virgin Records was sold to Thorn EMI two years ago, Ken Berry, its chairman and chief executive, has tried to blend its freewheeling culture with Thorn's corporate atmosphere. [D1.]
A Federal bankruptcy judge ruled invalid a claim of more than $92 million against the American corporation that owned The Daily News of New York when it was controlled by Robert Maxwell. [D1.]
Martin Marietta may have agreed to pay cash for Grumman to avoid a bidding war with Northrop, S.E.C. filings suggest. [D1.]
Fleet Financial Group is expected to lay off more than 10 percent of its work force, analysts said. [D3.]
Texas Instruments introduced a powerful new computer chip that will process video, images and audio on a single chip. [D3.]
Kellogg, the nation's largest maker of breakfast cereal, will produce a new line under Conagra's Healthy Choice brand. [D3.]
General Motors is in a new venture to test the commercialization of a relatively new kind of electric-vehicle battery. [D4.]
Raytheon announced a one-time $250 million charge for its first quarter and a plan to cut 4,400 jobs. [D4.]
Tommy Hilfiger, the men's sportswear company, shuffled its top management to prepare for a move into women's apparel. [D4.]
Many staff members of Lear's magazine expect to hear today that the magazine is closing. [D20.]
 
Today's Columns
The idea that nations are in perpetual competition may be comforting, but some economists call the view both wrong and dangerous. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
An upturn in the heavy equipment sector raises the prospects of Titan Wheel International even higher. Market Place. [D6.]
The United Negro College Fund is changing its longtime "A mind is a terrible thing to waste" campaign. Advertising. [D19.]

HEADLINE: U.S. Sees Hypocrisy On Trade

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's top trade negotiator today denounced the Europeans for criticizing toughened American policies toward Japan. He said the policy was already showing signs of progress, with word that Japan was close to agreeing to increase Motorola's access to the lucrative Japanese cellular-telephone market.
The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said the apparent Japanese willingness to open more of its market to Motorola "could be a portent of things to come and is a movement in the right direction" with regard to other major trade disputes with Tokyo. 
 In a speech at a trade conference here sponsored by the Economic Strategy Institute, Mr. Kantor vented some of the Clinton Administration's bitterness over what it views as dishonest and sanctimonious criticism by European officials of Washington's get-tough policy with Japan, at a time when the Europeans are quietly using some of the same tactics to protect their own manufacturers.
 
'Sit on the Sidelines'
 "The Europeans are always delighted when they can hold our coats and we can go out and get our noses bloody," Mr. Kantor asserted. "What we don't look for is criticism from those who sit on the sidelines and who are not willing to get into the game."
United States officials were particularly peeved at Peter Sutherland, Director General of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, for remarks he made in New York last week that seemed critical of some American trade tactics in opening Japanese markets, suggesting that they were close to "managed trade."
Mr. Sutherland, who heads the Geneva-based organization that governs world trade, never specifically mentioned the United States, but American officials said they had no doubt as to whom he was talking about.
 
Spirit of GATT Accord
 They privately communicated their anger to him and to members of the European Union, who were warning that the American quest for numerical indicators to determine whether Japan's markets were being opened violated the free-trade spirit of the recent world trade accord.
"It's interesting that there have been some voices in the union that have said our approach is managed trade," Mr. Kantor said today. "First of all, I'm not sure what managed trade is. Is managed trade when you have a voluntary restraint on automobiles and trucks at 16 percent in Europe, including transplant production? Naw, that wouldn't be managed trade, would it? No, because the Europeans did it."
The audience of economists and business people from around the world laughed. Senior Administration officials said that Mr. Kantor's contempt for European criticism was shared by President Clinton.
"Now when they do it," Mr. Kantor said, "that's protecting their markets and making sure it's fair. When we do it -- the largest open market in the world, who led Bretton Woods and GATT, have kept their markets open since the Second World War, who've led global growth, who have a President who made sure there was an Uruguay Round, who made sure there was a Nafta, who made sure we're trying to open up Japanese markets -- that's not good enough."
He referred to the role played by the United States in forming the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank at a conference in Bretton Woods. N.H., half a century ago; to the global trade talks that concluded in December, and to the North American Free Trade Agreement, the pact widely known as Nafta.
 
Just What Is 'European Culture?'
 The Europeans, Mr. Kantor continued, "have a broadcast directive which says you have to have at least 50 percent European content on television to protect European culture."
"Well, it's interesting. Are we protecting British culture, or Portuguese or German? I'm trying to figure out what European culture is. So every time the United States wants to go out there and make sure we lead global growth or we try to open markets, and the Europeans believe they sort of can come in in our wake, they don't want to stand with us. Every time it's in their interest, of course, to engage in behavior which is not opening their markets, that's justified."
Turning to American complaints that Japan has obstructed the import of Motorola cellular telephones, Mr. Kantor said, "I can report to you this morning that there is movement in the Motorola case."
The Motorola dispute is based on an American complaint that Japan has not fulfilled a 1989 agreement to insure that Motorola is not locked out of the lucrative Tokyo-Nagoya cellular phone market, an area as large as the market from Washington to Boston. Motorola has been allowed to compete freely outside this area, and has earned about a 50 percent market share elsewhere. But in Tokyo, because of restrictions imposed by the Japanese Government to help Japanese companies, Motorola has only a small fraction of the market.
Last month, the Clinton Administration set a deadline of March 17 for Japan to open its market further to Motorola or face the prospect of punitive tariffs on hundreds of millions of dollars worth of Japanese exports to the United States.
American negotiators say that in the talks being conducted in Tokyo, the Japanese Government and phone companies have signaled a willingness to build the base stations and install the switching equipment, by a specified date, that would make it possible for Motorola to compete fairly in Tokyo. The complicated deal has not yet been nailed down.
[Motorola and its Japanese partner have roughly agreed on a plan under which the Japanese company, Nippon Idou Tsushin, would build more relay stations by March 1996 to expand services for Motorola-type phones in the Tokyo-Nagoya region, The Associated Press reported on Thursday, quoting the Japan Broadcasting Corporation.]
 
Optimism at Chrysler
 In another industry where trade tensions between the world's two largest economies might be eased, Chrysler said in Detroit today that it expected Japan to allow it to increase exports of its popular Jeep Cherokee. Some Japanese auto companies have also signaled a willingness to purchase more parts from the United States.
"It should not escape any of our attention," Mr. Kantor said, "that this progress comes after the President said no to a cosmetic agreement that would paper over the differences in the framework talks, and it comes after the reinstitution of Super 301," the legal provision revived by Mr. Clinton that gives him the authority to quickly impose strong trade sanctions against a nation that is imposing unfair trade restrictions.
"It gives us some reason to believe that the Japanese, knowing the ball is in their court, will come back with something," Mr. Kantor added.

HEADLINE: The Nation's Economy Has Moderate Growth

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
Despite the harsh winter in the East and Midwest and the earthquake in California, the nation's economy "expanded moderately" early this year, the Federal Reserve reported today.
Most respondents to the latest Fed survey of regional business conditions said the little disruption that had resulted from the weather and earthquake would be temporary, and activity would rebound later in the year. And, they added, the economic growth was producing little inflationary pressure. 
 The survey, which was concluded on Feb. 24, was conducted by the Fed's 12 regional banks for a March 22 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the central bank's panel that sets monetary policy.
After its meetings on Feb. 3 and 4, the Fed nudged the Federal funds rate up to 3.25 percent, from 3 percent, in what analysts said was a move to stem any inflationary spiral before it got started.
 
Higher Rates Expected
 Some analysts maintain the central bank will probably raise rates further as the year progresses. The Federal funds rate is what banks charge each other for short-term loans.
The survey found manufacturing activity increasing in most regions, with the biggest strength coming from automotive and construction-related sectors.
"Durable goods and construction account for most of the advance throughout the nation," the survey found, although Cleveland and San Francisco reported that military and aerospace were damping their economies.
Although bad weather depressed retail sales in some areas, other regions reported consumer spending rose steadily.
 
Merchants Optimistic
 "Almost all district reports suggest that merchants expect solid sales growth in coming months," the survey found.
"Real estate markets continue to improve, despite severe winter weather in many districts," the summary said. "Residential sales activity is strong or growing in over half the districts, and three-quarters observed positive developments in construction.
"The Los Angeles earthquake will increase demand for residential repair services over the next six to 12 months, and freeway repair will push into 1995."
"Over all, only limited price pressures are reported," the survey found. "Prices of building materials, selected metals and some chemicals are said to be rising, but prices of manufactured products and consumer goods generally are not experiencing upward pressure."

HEADLINE: U.S. Remarks Over Kashmir Anger Indians

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, March 9

 BODY:
India has reacted with anger to recent statements by the Clinton Administration over possible abuses of human rights in the Government's efforts to put down a rebellion in Kashmir.
American officials say there has been no change in United States policy on the issue, which calls for India and Pakistan to settle their long dispute over Kashmir in talks. Nevertheless, Indian officials charge that the Administration statements amount to a shift toward support for Pakistan's claim to the territory. 
 Newspaper headlines here regularly accuse Washington of new attempts at "interference" in a domestic issue, and Indian leaders say that relations with Washington are at a low point.
 
Statement on Kashmir
 Among the comments that have riled New Delhi was a statement last month by President Clinton while accepting the credentials of Maleeha Lodhi, Pakistan's new Ambassador to the United States, that the United States shared Pakistan's "concerns on the abuse of human rights in Kashmir."
Kashmir is India's only state with a Muslim majority and has been coveted by Pakistan since Britain partitioned the subcontinent in 1947. Since then India and Pakistan have gone to war twice in Kashmir, and India charges that Pakistan is now fomenting the rebellion among Muslims.
Beyond the anxieties relating to the remarks about Kashmir, senior Indian officials are angry over the Clinton Administration's failure to send an ambassador to New Delhi. The post has been vacant for more than a year.
Senior officials in Washington have said recently that Mr. Clinton will move soon to nominate former Representative Stephen J. Solarz, a Brooklyn Democrat who is well-known here, and generally liked among senior Indian officials, from his tenure as chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Asian and Pacific Affairs.
For now, the practical effects of the Indian Government's unhappiness seem minimal, although Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao has shelved plans to visit Washington soon.
But in a sign of the sour mood, some of the country's best-known politicians have won desk-thumping ovations in Parliament for speeches accusing the United States of sinister motives in Kashmir, with some charging that Washington wants an independent Kashmir for use as a military base.
To officials in the United States Embassy here, the issue seems overdrawn. They say that remarks by President Clinton and by the Administration's senior official dealing full time with issues on the Indian subcontinent, Robin Raphel, have not changed United States policy on Kashmir.
 
The U.S. Position
 In essence, the United States position calls for India and Pakistan to settle the dispute over the divided territory, taking into account the wishes of the predominantly Muslim population.
India has become less critical of Western influence and has stepped up its drive to introduce reforms that have unleashed powerful market forces. Last year, new investments by large American companies, including A.T. & T., Coca-Cola and General Electric, pushed American investments here to more than $1 billion, more than all American investment since 1947.
Trade topped $7 billion, the highest ever, and kept the United States as India's largest trade partner.
 
10,000 Deaths
 Indian officials acknowledge improvements in economic ties, but say that those are outweighed by the risks inherent in American pronouncements on Kashmir. Since 1990, the two-thirds of Kashmir ruled by India has been convulsed by a Muslim uprising.
At least 10,000 people have died, mostly Muslim civilians. International human rights groups have supported accusations by Muslims of atrocities by Indian security forces, and the Indian Government has suspended the elected government in the state, substituting direct rule from New Delhi.
The Indian reaction had been primed by remarks in Washington by Ms. Raphel, who was named last fall to the newly created post of Assistant Secretary of State for South Asian Affairs.
At a briefing in October, Ms. Raphel was quoted as saying the United Statesregarded the Indian-controlled part of Kashmir as "disputed territory."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Pakistan Loses a Plea
 GENEVA, March 9 (AP) -- Pakistan lost a hard-fought bid today to send a United Nations team to investigate allegations of rights abuses in Kashmir. After finding itself isolated in the United Nations Human Rights Commission, Pakistan dropped a resolution condemning "gross and consistent violations" in the territory.
Iran led an appeal by more than a dozen countries to persuade its Islamic ally not to push for a vote, citing India's readiness "to facilitate a visit by a group of ambassadors from Muslim countries to Jammu and Kashmir."
To stave off a vote, India agreed to let the Red Cross visit detainees in Kashmir.
The Indian Foreign Minister, Dinesh Singh, said in a statement today, "We are grateful to countries like Iran which have prevailed on Pakistan to see reason."
Pakistan's delegate, Iqbal Akhund, reluctantly said he would drop the proposal. But he later said Pakistan had not formally withdrawn the resolution.
"It is not a bilateral issue," he said. "If large numbers of people are being killed, it's no more bilateral than Sarajevo."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Are Lifted By the Fed's Beige Book

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve's "beige book" report painted a portrait yesterday of a moderately expanding economy, not the robust one that many market participants had feared. As a result, bond prices bounced off their lows of the day.
Traders said the market, which has been concerned about further Fed moves to force up rates, has been jittery since the last rate increase. Yesterday was no exception, as investors and traders were prepared to read the report for signs of price pressures and possibly building inflation that could prompt the central bank to push short-term interest rates higher. 
 The Fed's beige book, which describes business conditions in each of the Federal Reserve's 12 regional districts, is used to brief members of the Fed's Open Market Committee when they meet periodically to set monetary policy. The committee is scheduled to meet March 22.
 
Long Bond's Price Up
 In yesterday's session, the price of the Treasury's 30-year bond went from trading down about 3/16 point to rise 11/32 , reaching a price of 9222/32 and yielding 6.83 percent late in the day. It was a decline of three basis points from Tuesday. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percent.
John Ryding, a senior economist at Bear, Stearns & Company, said that with traders fearing discomforting inflation comments, the market sold off to new high-yield levels before the release of the beige book.
He also noted that the market, which had initially opened up 1/4 point in price on the long end, was down about the time the news services carried a comment from a Federal Reserve governor, John P. LaWare. The Dow Jones News Service quoted him as having said he did not expect a repeat of last year, in which the economy slowed significantly in the first quarter after surging in late 1992.
"Anytime you get comments from Fed officials in a market that is trending down, it seems to bring out selling," one head trader said.
 
Fed Governors Comment
 Mr. LaWare's comments were the second by a Fed governor to move the bond market. On Tuesday, the market responded positively to remarks in a speech by Lawrence B. Lindsey, another Fed governor, that short-term interest rates would remain at "three something." The Fed later dismissed the comment as a joke, and the market saw a selloff.
Mr. Ryding said, "Over all, the beige report was pretty much in line with judgments about the economy." When the report reached traders, it produced a short-covering rally in the bond market, he added.
"We're not expecting strong pressure on consumer prices yet," Mr. Ryding said. "Right now the market is more concerned with input prices at the wholesale level."
Mr. Ryding believes price pressures will push inflation into the area of 3.5 percent, or a little more, later in the year, when the inflation numbers finally do appear in consumer prices. For that, he said: "We think the Fed will have to take the Federal funds rate to 4 percent later to get to a more neutral position. At the same time bond yields will go up to 7.25 percent on the long end."
 
Short Positions Squeezed
 Yesterday's report did not give the market momentum for a rally, but instead squeezed the short positions, Mr. Ryding said.
Retail sales will be the big number this week, and economists expect the figures to give the market some momentum.
But next week is another matter. The market is likely to see a lot of volatility, as several economic reports are released that could move the Fed into some action if the numbers are too unsettling.
Next week's data include business inventories and the Atlanta regional Fed index of manufacturing activity, the producer prices, industrial production, consumer prices and housing starts.
Some market watchers are expecting essentially lower prices and higher yields before setting the basis for a sustained rally in the market.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
On Macho Trade Issues, Economists Turn Chauvinist

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
IT'S still war out there, only the terms of battle have changed.
A decade ago the object was to get the Russians out of Afghanistan and keep them out of Europe. Now the enemy is Japan and a dozen mini-Japan's ready to suck us dry of advanced technology and good jobs. . . . 
 The idea that nations are in perpetual competition is intuitive and, in a perverse way, comforting: Americans, after all have always done best when they face a common enemy. But in the view of Paul Krugman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, "the obsession with international competitiveness is both wrong and dangerous."
Mr. Krugman is hardly alone in his concern. "There's just not much intellectual dispute" that competitiveness is a phony issue, concurs Barry Bosworth, an economist at the Brookings Institution and an official in the Carter Administration. Unlike many of his colleagues who have confined their misgivings to the seminar room, however, Mr. Krugman is now openly challenging the popular wisdom. And those who read his provocative new book, "Peddling Prosperity" (Norton) or his undiplomatic article in the current issue of Foreign Affairs magazine may indeed wonder whether the economists have let the country down by playing footsie with the chauvinists.
People compete and businesses compete. National economies are made up of people and businesses. Why, then, is it wrong to think that economies also compete?
The simplest explanation, Mr. Krugman suggests, is that even in a world of relatively open trade, most of what Americans consume is made in America. Thus living standards are largely determined by the productivity of American farms, factories and offices.
Trade might still have a disproportionate (if hard to predict) impact on the success or failure of high-technology, high-profile industries. Indeed, Mr. Krugman is one of the intellectual parents of "strategic trade theory," which amounts to a clever catalogue of ways in which being first or most aggressive in world markets might yield benefits beyond those generated simply by producing cheaply and well. If, for example, there is room for only one efficient manufacturer of jumbo jets in the world, the first company off the mark (Boeing) will reap an exceptionally high return.
But the numbers just don't justify the concern with strategic factors in trade. Mr. Krugman calculates that America's global advantage in technology and marketing between 1959 and 1973 -- America's gain in terms of trade with other economies -- raised the average annual growth of living standards from 1.85 percent to 1.87 percent. That may have been enough to determine the fate of a business here and there, but is hardly worth the current fuss.
Then, too, there is the question of who actually reaps the rewards from successful strategic trade initiatives. Contrary to intuition, trickle-down in the form of better jobs or lower prices for American consumers may be small or even negative. "If General Motors does well in global markets at the expense of foreign producers, it doesn't help me particularly," Mr. Bosworth said.
Why, then, have economists who know better been slow to take issue with the Clinton Administration's posturing on trade in high-technology products? For that matter, why has the Administration itself, which is loaded with economic talent, been inclined to go ballistic with the Japanese on who sells the most cellular phones in Tokyo and who builds the new airport in Osaka?
Mr. Krugman's answer is a "mixture of hope and fear." The hope part is that the belief that political hormones stimulated by talk of competition can be channeled to virtuous ends such as investment in education, higher savings and elimination of parasitic Government subsidies. The fear part is the age-old worry about telling the emperor he has no clothes.
Van Doorn Ooms, research director of the Committee for Economic Development, adds a realpolitik explanation for the silence of the economic doves. Posturing with Japan may in the end do little harm since the alliance is so firmly rooted in mutual self-interest. And it might even do some good if it goads Japan to stimulate its way out of recession or to open its markets more rapidly. Don't forget, too, that the macho talk may serve Mr. Clinton's interests by robbing Republicans of their traditional political advantage as the tough guys on foreign policy.
But the hope that the White House "may get it right for the wrong reasons" doesn't allay Mr. Ooms's concern that confrontation with Japan will damage the alliance that has guarded the political stability of the Pacific for a half-century. Nor does it satisfy Paul Romer, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley, who has long championed the idea of selective government aid in science and technology as a means of increasing productivity.
"The Clinton Administration may end up damaging the case for sophisticated intervention," he said. "This could set back progress toward better growth policy for years."

HEADLINE: Gov. Weld Will Run Again

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 9

 BODY:
Gov. William F. Weld announced today that he would seek re-election, asserting that Massachusetts would revert to "the terrible misguided mistakes of the past" if the Democrats regained the Governor's office.
Mr. Weld, elected in 1990 after a bitter contest with his Democratic opponent, John N. Silber, the president of Boston University, is the first Republican Governor of Massachusetts in nearly two decades. 
 With the cooperation of the Democratic-controlled Legislature, he dealt with a large budget deficit that had caused the state's bond rating to fall to one step above "junk" status.
Mr. Weld, a former United States attorney, called for tougher measures to fight crime, including sending violent criminals to prison for life after three convictions. He also pushed for tax cuts, term limits and a welfare overhaul emphasizing jobs.
Mr. Weld, 49, is considered likely to win re-election, although Democratic contenders say they plan to hold him accountable for the state's still-sputtering economy.
"Where are the jobs?" asked one Democratic hopeful, State Representative Mark Roosevelt of Boston. " His economic record has been abysmal."
Another Democrat seeking his party's nomination in the Sept. 20 primary is State Senator Michael Barrett of Cambridge.

HEADLINE: Rally in Capital Protests a Rise In Smoking Tax

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
Granted, this sounds peculiar. But to protest President Clinton's plans for financing his proposed overhaul of the health care system, some of the nation's biggest tobacco companies virtually stopped making cigarettes today.
Instead, they shuttered their factories and bused their employees -- and tobacco farmers, leaf processors, cigarette-carton makers and a throng of other industry workers -- to Washington and the biggest pro-cigarette rally in political annals. 
 From 16,000 to 20,000 demonstrators gathered on the frigid, sodden Ellipse to denounce Mr. Clinton's proposal to finance his health care plan with a 75-cent increase in the Federal excise tax on cigarettes, to 99 cents from 24 cents a pack.
Later, they marched past the White House. And later still, they stormed Congress, divvying up an 800,000-signature anti-tax petition according to the hometowns of its signers, and dropped off relevant pages at many of the 535 legislators' Capitol Hill offices.
 
Plan to Raise $56.6 Billion
 The White House says the tax would raise an additional $56.6 billion through the year 2000 to help finance a system of guaranteed health insurance for the entire population. The cigarette industry, and its workers, said today that the tax increase would throw 274,000 people out of work and strangle the economy, or at least that of tobacco states. The estimate is from an analysis by the Tobacco Institute, the industry's lobbying arm.
"You kill tobacco, you kill the whole East Coast," Leon Harris, 51, a worker at a Greenville, N.C., company that cleans and chops up tobacco leaves for cigarette makers, said as he huddled under a thick jacket at the rally today. The industry's many critics argue that it is cigarettes that do the killing. By the Surgeon General's latest estimate, 419,000 people died in 1990 from cancer, heart disease and respiratory ailments caused directly by smoking.
Smoking deaths and illnesses cost the economy about $65 billion a year in lost workdays and medical expenses, the Government estimates.
The vast crowd of protesters, clustered under a Washington Monument looming behind them like a huge unfiltered Camel, would have nothing of that today. They wore Winston rain slickers and Marlboro hats and Salem and Vantage windbreakers. They waved plastic cigarettes big as baseball bats, handed out bumper stickers reading "I smoke and I vote," and wore buttons labeled "Tobacco pays my bills."
To a man, and woman, they maintained that the $48 billion-a-year tobacco industry already pays more than its share of taxes, and that a threefold increase in the tax is little more than a Federal attempt to stub out an industry that individual smokers -- 50 million adults, at last count -- believe they have a right to patronize.
"It's jobs, man," said Jonas Grant, 45, a leaf processor at the Philip Morris U.S.A. plant outside Richmond. "Seventy-five cents a pack is too much."
"We've been taxed enough," said Terry Jernigan, a payroll clerk at a P. Lorillard Company cigarette plant in Greensboro, N.C., who was selling buttons at the rally. "Cigarettes don't cause any more disease than anything else. Let's talk about alcohol. Let's talk about mind-altering drugs. Let's put a tax on the pollution from these cars, and all the other things that make people sick."
"More people drink than smoke," Mr. Harris said, adding that he no longer smoked. "I had some lung problems, a long time ago. I quit before I had any more."
Maura Ellis, a spokeswoman for the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, said the notion of a protest first arose last May, when about 1,500 Reynolds workers drove to the capital to protest what was then being billed as a $2-a-pack tax increase. That June, she said, they formed the Tobacco Action Coalition, now a group of about 2,000 tobacco workers and smokers who, she said, organized today's rally.
With some help, of course: Lorillard's Greensboro factory and Philip Morris's Richmond plant, which by itself makes 500 million cigarettes a day, were all but idle today. Fully 7,000 of Richmond's 9,000 Philip Morris workers boarded buses before sunrise to attend the rally.
At the big and mostly deserted Reynolds plant in Winston-Salem, N.C., it was a day for cleaning and routine maintenance, Ms. Ellis said.
But smoking opponents are not getting the backhanded victory of a dip in the nation's cigarette supply. A Philip Morris official said production would be increased on other days to make up the shortfall. "Our manufacturing planning team made the necessary adjustments to see that before or after, we could continue to meet our customers' demand," said Jay S. Poole, the company's director of government and community relations.
Attendance at the rally was voluntary for most, if not all the workers, but many, including Philip Morris employees, were paid a day's wages for their appearance and bused to the capital at company expense.
Whether it all will make any difference in Congress is not clear. Political sentiment has drifted steadily and quickly against smoking in recent years, even in some tobacco-growing states. Maryland officials announced on Tuesday that the state had labeled smoking an occupational hazard and planned to ban cigarettes entirely from all workplaces in 60 days.
 
A Beleaguered Industry
 The industry has been battered this winter by a barrage of Federal attacks on smoking, including suggestions by the Food and Drug Administration that it will seek to regulate cigarettes for the first time as an addictive drug.
One Republican legislator and a former tobacco grower, Senator Lauch Faircloth of North Carolina, predicted in an interview today that any health plan approved by the Congress would contain a far smaller smokers' tax, if any at all. And it is true that tobacco-state lawmakers, many with years of seniority, hold enormous political power in Congress.
But Mr. Clinton's proposal so far seems to have the support of the two lawmakers who count: Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, who heads the Senate Finance Committee. Their panels are drafting the health-care legislation that will eventually come to votes on the House and Senate floors.
Indeed, the industry's battle in the Finance Committee, if anything, is even tougher after the rally. Among those trapped in traffic jams when the cigarette marchers shut down Pennsylvania Avenue today was Mr. Moynihan, who was late to an appointment at the White House.

HEADLINE: U.S. Aides Report Compromise on Sea Mining

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
After more than a decade of opposing the Law of the Sea treaty as hostile to free enterprise, United States officials said today that Washington would probably sign the treaty this summer, now that they have negotiated major changes.
Washington's backing would greatly strengthen the treaty, which governs the world's oceans. It is scheduled to take effect this November, having been ratified by the required 60 nations among the 159 that signed it. 
 The Reagan Administration heatedly denounced the treaty in December 1982, saying it would sabotage private enterprise by requiring companies that mine the seabeds to pay hefty royalties to help third-world countries that could not afford to do such mining.
But Clinton Administration officials said today that they were close to signing the agreement, the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, after intensive talks with third-world nations won their agreement to make it less onerous for mining companies.
For example, the companies would pay far lower royalties and would not be required to turn over their mining technologies to competitors from poorer countries. And production limits on mining companies would be removed.
One potential complication is that the revisions must now be submitted to the countries that signed the original document. But United States and United Nations officials say this should not be a problem.
Noting that many third-world nations are no longer as opposed to free markets as they were a decade ago, a State Department official involved in the negotiations said, "The international community has agreed that we need to take a more market-oriented approach to the whole subject."
Under the treaty, all nations would have full sovereignty over the seas within 12 miles of the shore. But in an important provision for the United States and other military powers, the treaty grants airplanes and ocean vessels the right to pass over straits.
The treaty would give nations control over fishing rights and oil- and gas-exploration rights within 200 miles of their shores.
The treaty could not go into effect until 60 nations ratified it. In November, Guyana became the 60th to sign.
 
A Long Dispute
 The treaty has fueled disputes between rich and poor nations because of its underlying premise -- that the oceans and the sea bed are part of the "common heritage of mankind" that must be shared through "a just and equitable economic order."
The treaty called for a global mining consortium that would enable poorer countries to compete with industrial nations. The money this consortium collected -- partly from royalties paid by mining companies -- was to be distributed to poor nations. United States officials said today that as part of the recent talks, the consortium would lose much of the royalties.
"We already have virtual agreement on all substantive issues," said Satya Nandan, a United Nations negotiator. He voiced optimism that the industrial nations that have not signed -- the United States, Britain and Germany -- would do so soon.
One State Department official said he was confident the treaty would win two-thirds backing in the Senate.

HEADLINE: Whitman, in Office, Still Campaigns;
Governor Tries to Build Support as a Fight Over Cuts Looms

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 8

 BODY:
After seven weeks in office, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman is showing every sign that she intends to maintain the kind of high public visibility that she displayed on the campaign trail.
While the capital has fixated on the politics of the 5 percent income tax cut signed into law on Monday, Governor Whitman has often forsaken the State House and the company of the Republican legislative majority. Instead, she has conducted an almost daily round of public appearances in the state, showing a sunny personality and communicating a stern political message to the public. 
 One day recently, it was a street soccer match at St. Benedict's Prep in Newark to mark New Jersey's role in this summer's World Cup soccer competition. At a boat yard in New Gretna, on the Jersey Shore, she sold tax cuts as an elixir for business investment. Opening a conference on Women's History Month at Rowan College, at the south end of the state, the Governor called for more women to take their places in public life.
 
First Major Battle
 If Governor Whitman is acting as if her victorious campaign over Jim Florio has never ended, it may be because she knows that her first real fight is still to come. It begins on March 15, when she must divulge how she intends to pay for her $243 million tax reduction and for the $1.2 billion in additional cuts she has promised to enact over the next two years, as well as the immediate problem of a $1.5 billion built-in deficit.
The base of public support that Governor Whitman is building may become crucial when she begins apportioning the pain of budget cuts in less than a week, said Neil Upmeyer, head of the Center for Analysis of Public Issues, a policy-study organization based in Princeton.
"We always complain about the difficulty of communicating with the voters in New Jersey, and she has apparently concluded that that is how she will succeed, by touching every base in the state," Mr. Upmeyer said. "That was always Florio's problem. When things got tough for him, he didn't have any political capital to fall back on."
It may be working. A poll by The Star-Ledger and the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University found that more than a third of the public knows something about the town meetings and call-in shows that the Governor has used to sell her message that New Jersey's tax-heavy, highly regulated economy must be changed.
Meanwhile, in Trenton, where Mrs. Whitman holds one or two news conferences a day, the Governor only on Friday filled out her Cabinet by choosing a Labor Commissioner. Numerous sub-Cabinet positions remain unfilled.
 
A Small Inner Group
 As for paying for her tax cuts, Mrs. Whitman only hints that it will be painful. How painful even her allies, the leaders of the Republican majorities in the Assembly and Senate, have been kept guessing.
Indeed, Governor Whitman's public appearances, with the opportunities to communicate directly with voters, contrast with her neglect of her nominal allies, the Legislature's Republican majority. She ignored their maneuvers to find jobs for their friends in her Cabinet, and she has so far spurned their pleas for a sense of how her budget will affect their constituents.
"She keeps very close counsel with a very small group of people, but I think it's too early to say that this is wrong, because it gives her a lot of freedom," said Stephen Salmore, a political science professor at Rutgers who is also a Republican campaign consultant.
Those insiders are by all accounts within the same circle of family and old friends who helped guide her to an improbable victory last fall: her husband, John; Malcolm S. Forbes Jr., the publisher; Hazel Frank Gluck, a lobbyist, and Judith Shaw, her chief of staff and Ms. Gluck's former partner.
No one in her administration has yet suggested how the Governor will handle other problems soon to come to roost on her desk; they include a court-ordered reformulation of state aid to local schools that adds $400 million annually in aid to city systems; payment of some $900 million to motorists with claims against a state-backed auto insurance pool and a court-ordered solution to overcrowding in state prisons.
 
A Meeting With Senators
 When some senators publicly balked at the Governor's policy of cutting taxes before specifying ways to make up the lost revenues, the Governor's office obligingly invited the Senate Appropriations Committee down to the Governor's wood-paneled office for a chat.
No, the senators felt constrained to object: As an equal branch of government, the Legislature expected the governor to come to it. Governor Whitman and her Treasurer, Brian W. Clymer, readily agreed, and at the meeting two Thursdays ago the senators expected to have their fears of budget chaos put to rest.
"That's not what happened," said Senator Dick LaRossa, a Republican who represents Trenton and is a member of the budget-writing committee. "They did not say, 'No, that's the case, don't worry about it.' They did not say, 'Here's how we're going to do it.' They just acknowledged our concerns and said the budget process itself is where all those issues will be resolved."
The lawmakers know that could leave them fighting among themselves over allocating the pain of the budget cuts. Donald T. DiFrancesco, the Republican Senate President, with evident frustration, issued his own declaration that school and municipal aid will not be cut under the Governor's budget, whatever it turns out to be.
Senator LaRossa, with many worried state workers among his constituents, refused to vote for the cuts and abstained. The measure passed easily on Thursday.
 
Making Promises
 Sometimes the Governor herself succumbs to the temptation to promise money she may not have. In a weeklong inspection of the state's juvenile justice system last month, she called for earlier intervention for troubled youth, more drug treatment and more follow-up on released juveniles. She has promised to keep public higher education affordable, but warned that state aid to colleges will be cut. She has criticized the mandatory sentencing that has jammed the state prisons but endorsed life sentences for felons convicted of three violent crimes.
As the state's first female governor, Mrs. Whitman also displays a rugged feminist streak. She is particularly conscious of her role as a model for girls.
"She feels very strongly about it," said Ms. Gluck, her friend. "When people come to say hello, and they bring their daughters with them to see the first female governor of the state, she feels she has a responsibility that goes beyond just being Governor."
The question of roles came up not long ago when Mrs. Whitman invited the State House reporters to tea. "You're not actually going to serve us, are you?" asked one reporter, fumbling for small talk.
"You wouldn't even ask that if she weren't a woman," one of the Governor's aides rejoined.
Under her breath, the Governor muttered, "That about goes to the heart of it."

HEADLINE: Fannie Mae Seeks to Ease Home Buying

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
The organization that stands behind many of the nation's mortgages is taking broad steps to make home ownership easier for lower-income Americans, particularly recent immigrants and minorities, people involved in the effort said today.
Under the new rules, banks would have more flexibility in lending to people who already owe a considerable amount of money or who cannot afford a down payment equal to 20 percent of the price of a home, the people said.
 
Tuesday Announcement
 The change is to be announced on Tuesday by the Federal National Mortgage Association, popularly known as Fannie Mae. Officials at Fannie Mae would not comment on the plan. 
 President Clinton is tentatively scheduled to attend the announcement. The Administration is urging that loans be more broadly available to poor and lower-middle-income Americans.
In addition to changing its guidelines, Fannie Mae plans a national educational campaign that will seek to teach recent immigrants and minorities how to obtain mortgages. The campaign will be aimed particularly at immigrants in a dozen "gateway" cities where the percentage of home ownership has been declining.
The long-term goal is to broaden the economic and ethnic diversity of homeowners. About 70 percent of white households now own their homes, compared with 40 percent of black and Hispanic households.
 
Two Million Excluded
 Mortgage experts have estimated that up to two million American households are excluded from buying homes now because of conservative mortgage lending standards. These include Americans with minor blemishes on their credit records, for such things as changing jobs repeatedly or failing to pay utility bills on time. Most mortgage experts assume that even people who fall behind on other bills will struggle to make mortgage payments lest they lose their homes.
"Mortgage-lending criteria have been very conservative, and we have a lot of people who should be creditworthy and have been cut out," said Thomas H. Stanton, a former Fannie Mae lawyer.
It is not clear how many of these households might be covered immediately by Fannie Mae's changes in mortgage guidelines.
Fannie Mae and the much smaller Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, better known as Freddie Mac, are publicly traded enterprises that were created by the Federal Government to help provide more money for mortgages. They have issued or guaranteed securities made up of about $1 trillion worth of mortgages bought from lenders.
Freddie Mac loosened its guidelines for low-income mortgages a few weeks ago. But Deepak Bhargava, the legislative director of the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now, a New Orleans-based group of affordable housing advocates, said that Freddie Mac's guidelines remained more restrictive than Fannie Mae's.
Next week's changes in Fannie Mae's guidelines will probably widen the gap between the two institutions' policies, Mr. Bhargava said. Freddie Mac officials did not return phone calls made to their homes and office this evening.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Realty Appraisal Shift
 WASHINGTON, March 9 (By Bloomberg Business News) -- The Federal Reserve loosened lending regulations today on bank holding companies by requiring fewer appraisals of property involved in real estate loans.
The rules exempt banks from conducting a real estate appraisal for loans of $250,000 or less, raising the threshold from the previous $100,000.
Appraisals on some loans are required by the 1989 Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act, though Congress gave Federal banking agencies the power to set a threshold to exempt smaller loans from the requirements.
Three banking regulators -- the Fed, the Office of Thrift Supervision and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency -- proposed raising the threshold to $250,000 last June. The Fed is the only agency so far to approve the proposal.
In its proposal, the Fed staff said raising the threshold would increase the availability of credit and ease the regulatory burden on banks without endangering the safety and soundness of the banking industry.

HEADLINE: Stocks Advance on Fed Economic Report

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Probably surprising even itself, the stock market chose to believe the Federal Reserve Board yesterday when the central bank reported that in January and February the American economy was moderately robust, yet showed no signs of inflation.
The Fed's message cheered the bond markets and thus helped the stock market to rally, but just barely and in only moderate trading. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.69 points, to 3,853.41. Still, the rise was significant since stocks seemed to be heading downward after lackluster sessions Monday and Tuesday. And today's session may build on yesterday's small rally if traders continue to take good news on inflation at face value. 
 The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, also helped. He said yesterday that the United States and Japan were close to an agreement on the fractious issue of Motorola's entering the Japanese cellular telephone market. Many economists would see that development as a major signal of improving trade relations with Japan that would reduce American inflationary pressures.
 
 
Tentative Reactions
 But the tiny creep upward for stocks was an indication of how tentatively traders react to good news about inflation. Traders have spent weeks talking themselves into believing that the Fed is about to raise short-term interest rates a second time, thus hurting both stocks and bonds. The Fed raised short-term rates one-quarter of a percentage point on Feb. 4.
The stock market has been largely driven by the bond market, stock traders say. The yield on the benchmark 30-year bond has risen more than half a point since Feb. 2 and two-thirds of a point since Jan. 12.
"Bonds have a very, very strong influence on stocks and now the nervous money has been taken out of the market," Thomas Gallagher, a senior officer in the equity trading department of Oppenheimer & Company, said. "Everybody who wants to sell bonds has sold them."
The New York Stock Exchange composite index gained 0.30 point, to 258.78, on volume of 309.8 million shares. But declining stocks outnumbered advancing stocks by 1,098 to 1,034. The American Stock Exchange market value index declined 0.89 point, to 466.79.
The broader Standard & Poor's 500 index advanced 1.18 points, to 467.06, while the Nasdaq composite index rose 0.93 point, to 793.05.
Yesterday, the Fed reported the good inflation news around noon in its so-called beige book survey of economic conditions, but it took many stock traders more than 90 minutes to digest the news.
The S.& P. 500 and the Nasdaq index did not rise convincingly until shortly after 1:30 P.M. The Dow did not rally in earnest until 3 P.M.
 
 
Computer Trading Program
 By then, a huge computer-driven trading program was beginning to affect prices, according to Birinyi Associates, a Greenwich, Conn., equity research firm that tracks such program trading. A computer buy program involving as many as three million shares was executed around 2:28 P.M., Philip H. Smyth, a Birinyi analyst, said. He estimated the buy program lifted the Dow by eight points yesterday.
Such computer programs often affect the Dow industrials because the programs involve the nearly simultaneous purchase of 50 stocks culled from the S.& P. 500 and which include most, if not all, of the 30 Dow component stocks. The programs are set to buy or sell, most recently on how traders bet on short-term interest rates.
Whose computer program affected trading will not be known until stock brokerage firms release their trading records weeks or months from now.
The most active stock yesterday was Telefonos de Mexico, whose American depository receipts fell 1 7/8, to 65 1/8, on volume of six million shares. Each A.D.R. represents 20 ordinary common shares.
Telmex is such a large stock that it is often used by portfolio managers as a proxy for the Mexican stock market.
