HEADLINE: Inflexible Structure Hinders the Power Authority

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
More than 50 years ago, Gov. Alfred E. Smith envisioned a state power authority that would harness the energy of Niagara Falls and the St. Lawrence River and bring the blessings of electricity to homes, farms and small factories around the state, no matter how remote.
It worked well for a long time, but not lately. 
 The New York Power Authority, which boasts of being the largest state-owned public power agency in the nation and of saving New Yorkers hundreds of millions of dollars a year on electricity, is in trouble, and some customers are wondering if it saves them anything at all.
For years, for example, utilities and industries have coveted contracts with the authority. But at the end of this month, Consolidated Edison will let one such contract lapse because Con Ed believes it can get power elsewhere for less.
The authority's largest customer, New York City, is also looking into buying power elsewhere to save money.
The underlying problem is that recession has cut the demand for power just as independent power producers are bringing new plants on line, creating a glut of electricity and the collapse of prices. That leaves the authority selling power, supposedly cut-rate, at prices higher than some private companies. For now, the authority is able to sell its power, and balance its books, but if it cannot continue to, there is a possibility that taxpayers will have to make up the difference.
 
Management Problems Cited
 In a view echoed by many, Lindsay P. Audin, the manager of energy conservation at Columbia University, said that all utilities in New York face that problem right now. The Power Authority's difficulties, he said, are compounded by "serious management problems that put its other difficulties into a higher profile."
Its biggest management problem is that its nuclear power plants run fitfully or not at all; Indian Point 3, in Buchanan has now been closed for a year because of bad management, but it is still running up high maintenance and payroll expenses.
The authority's hydroelectric plants work as well as ever, and since they are mostly paid for, their power is very cheap. But critics say that the system of distributing power -- fashioned years ago -- has greatly favored some upstate communities and offered large subsidies to some industries while leaving downstate communities paying some of the highest rates in the nation.
Many of the authority's other problems stem not from Governor Smith's concept of electrification and economic development, which was signed into law by Gov. Franklin D. Roosevelt, but by a later idea approved by Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller when the state used the Authority to rescue Con Edison, which had overbuilt.
Two decades ago the authority bought from Con Edison the Indian Point 3 nuclear plant and a conventional plant in Queens, then called Astoria 6 and later renamed for Charles Poletti. Those plants are two sources of trouble now, because their generating costs are not competitive and because the authority can not blend their expensive power with its cheaper power.
S. David Freeman, who became president and chief executive of the authority on March 1, is to talk about the authority's problems and how to solve them at a news conference this morning.
 
A Major Producer
 Whatever the authority does it is likely to be felt around the state; the agency is a whale in the state's power pool, boasting that it supplies one-quarter of the electricity used in the state. Part of the power it distributes is bought from Hydro-Quebec for Con Edison. But the authority's own generating stations are huge, and its transmission lines stretch 14,000 miles. The authority is the lifeblood of scores of upstate industries. Through about 150 contracts for cheap power, it provided what amounts to operating subsidies to companies that employ a lot of people or are in high-technology fields that offer the promise of growth. It can do this with power from old dams.
And, the authority provides cheap power to residences upstate. Critics said the cheap power offers no incentive for residents to conserve or for industry to modernize and use less.
"Every time you use one of those cheap kilowatt-hours, somebody else, who is the last person on line, has to pay the highest price," said B. Robert Piller, executive director of the Public Utility Law Project, a public interest law firm based in Albany that represents low-income utility consumers.
In 1984 Mr. Pillar studied the contracts and the size of the subsidy per job saved; in some cases, he said, it was $60,000 or $70,000. If the state had sold the power at market rates, he said, surely it could have used $70,000 to create more than one job.
The system of allocations has since become more rational, said Mr. Pillar, but it is still "outright unsound." But he and other analysts say that many of the allocations are mired in politics and unlikely to change.
John Dyson, who was chairman of the authority from 1979 until 1985 and is now a Deputy Mayor of New York City, said, "The politics is that these industries located in the Niagara Frontier and Massena because of the promise of this power, and to change it now unemploys large numbers of people."
 
Restless Customers
 Meanwhile, downstate governmental customers, including the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the New York City Housing Authority and various local governments, are supposed to be getting moderately-priced power, under an unusual deal struck 20 years ago in which the Power Authority took over Indian Point 3 and the conventional plant in Astoria. Along with the plants, the Power Authority also got Con Ed's governmental customers, which was essential to the authority because it could not finance the purchase with tax-free bonds unless the power went to public agencies.
But now the authority is having trouble keeping those customers satisfied, because they pay more for their bulk purchases than utilities do on the open market.
"The situation is not a very happy one," said Mr. Freeman. "We're going to have to hustle."
The authority has already cut its staff by 400 full-time positions, to about 3,400. Last year the authority promised its New York City-area customers a rate freeze through 1996, but that has not been enough to keep all of them happy.
Some problems are largely outside the authority's control.
"Right now, because of low fuel cost and low interest rates, new plants can generate power cheaper than the Power Authority's average cost," said Ashokh Gupta, a senior energy analyst at the Natural Resources Defense Council and a former staff member at the city's Department of Telecommunications and Energy.
According to Mr. Freeman, with surplus capacity, some suppliers are happy to offer power to the general market at anything above the cost of their fuel, and right now fuel costs are very low.
Mr. Freeman said that one of his tasks would be to determine what would happen if he wanted to retire some power plants. The Power Authority has an unusual structure, with bonds tied to individual projects, so it is not clear how the bonds would be paid off. The authority paid more than $600 million for the plants, and has invested additional amounts, especially at Indian Point 3.
This structure, Mr. Freeman said in an interview, makes the authority "an economist's dream but a manager's nightmare." An economist could tell quickly, he said, which plants are competitive and which are not, because their power is marketed individually. But any other utility, he said, could blend its high- and low-priced sources together, producing an average price that is still quite reasonable. The power authority, however, because of the laws that established it, must sell power from each project at prices that reflect the cost of that project.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises Against Yen, Buoyed by Hopes on Trade

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen yesterday, buoyed by new hopes for possible easing of the trade frictions between the United States and Japan.
The dollar received early help after the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said progress had been made in a cellular phone dispute with Japan. He said an agreement, which has yet to be announced, would bode well for future trade relations. 
 "We got a decent move up in the dollar, triggered by Kantor's comments," said Jim Phoenix, foreign exchange dealer for the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce.
The dollar rose to 105.80 yen in late New York trading, from 105.30 yen on Tuesday.
Mr. Kantor's comments came on the heels of the move by President Clinton last week to reinstate his authority under a measure known as Super 301 authority, which would enable him to impose strong trade sanctions quickly.
 
Deal 'Looks Possible'
 "A cellular phone deal looks possible and would smooth over some of the ill will between the two countries," Mr. Phoenix said. "It looks like a move in the right direction and Kantor's comments provided an opportunity to buy dollars against yen."
But the dollar remained in a slump against the German mark and other major currencies after the Bundesbank shaved its repurchase rate just three basis points, to 5.94 percent.
Dealers said the dollar fell as the Bundesbank's move made it less likely that German interest rates would drop this year.
"The dollar's having difficulty penetrating the upside due to concerns about German rates going higher," one dealer said.
The dollar eased to 1.7070 German marks in late New York trading, from 1.7148 marks on Tuesday. In London, it fell to 1.7084 marks, from 1.7185 on Tuesday.
Gold prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the most active April gold contract gained $2.40, to $380.10 an ounce.
The dollar barely moved on the Federal Reserve's "beige book" report on American business conditions. The beige book, which Fed officials use as a basis for periodic discussions on money and credit policy, said the economy was growing and that consumer prices were steady.

HEADLINE: BASKETBALL;
Rutgers and West Virginia Are Invited to Join Big East

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN 

 BODY:
The Big East invited Rutgers and West Virginia to become full-time members yesterday in a compromise that expanded the basketball conference to 12 schools and averted a split that had threatened its future.
After voting down proposals of expansion to 13 or 14 members, which could have added Temple and Virginia Tech to the basketball league, the presidents of the 10 Big East schools approved the two-team expansion by a vote of 7-3, the minimum required under conference regulations. 
 The Rev. Donald J. Harrington, the president of St. John's and newly elected chairman of the conference presidents, said that the new members would join the basketball league no earlier than the 1995-96 season, in part not to disrupt next season's schedules. The Big East will retain a one-division format, with teams playing each of the other members at least once and in some cases twice.
After weeks of discussion, in a process that Mike Tranghese, the Big East commissioner, considered the most serious crisis in the league's 15-year history, Big East presidents preserved the conference by establishing equality between the interests of members that play Division I-A football and those that do not. That balance helped secure the decisive support of St. John's, the only school voting in favor of expansion that does not play major-college football and is not contemplating a move to that level.
"There was a strong, strong sense, from football as well as basketball schools, that we wanted to do everything we could to keep the Big East together," the Rev. Harrington said last night. "We wanted to see if we could preserve this."
By adding Rutgers, which had reportedly discussed the possibility of joining the Big Ten, the Big East prevents that league from establishing a presence in the New York market. The Atlantic 10 will lose Rutgers and West Virginia, but keep Temple.
The complex discussions leading to yesterday's decision, made during a meeting in midtown Manhattan, resulted from a problem not faced by older, more traditional conferences. The Big East, which sponsors 10 men's sports and nine women's sports, became divided by dramatic differences in the levels of commitment to football. Such a dichotomy existed from its beginnings in 1979 and intensified when the conference added Miami in 1990 and established a football league the following year.
Four of the league's full-time members -- Boston College, Miami, Pittsburgh and Syracuse -- had threatened to combine with the four football-only members -- Rutgers, West Virginia, Temple and Virginia Tech -- to form a separate all-sports league if expansion was not approved. They had negotiated a five-year, $65 million contract with CBS that takes effect in 1996.
Their departure would have forced the schools without major football programs -- Connecticut, Georgetown, St. John's, Seton Hall, Providence and Villanova -- to reestablish their identity in a scaled-down Big East, possibly with the addition of Notre Dame. As discussions dragged on -- through a Feb. 25 meeting in Boston in which the presidents were unable to arrive at a conclusion -- the destructive threat of a potential imbalance became clear. The basketball schools feared that a 14-team league, with eight schools playing Division I-A football, would create a perpetual 8-6 vote favoring football interests.
 
A Two-Step Solution
 Two actions by the presidents helped solve the problem. They voted to change the minimum number of votes for approval in the future from two-thirds of the membership to three-fourths. The presidents also secured the support of Connecticut and Villanova by determining that members could elevate their football programs to the I-A level by declaring an intention by 1998 and meeting N.C.A.A. requirements for participation at that level by 2002.
That provided Villanova and Connecticut, which have both considered upgrading their programs to the I-A level, an opportunity to join the conference's football membership after a reasonable amount of time to prepare for that step. Those two votes, combined with those of Boston College, Miami, Pittsburgh and Syracuse, left the expansion proponents one vote short of approval.
St. John's became a decisive factor in the compromise when the Rev. Harrington determined, after a series of meetings with university officials, that the preservation of the league would be in the school's best interests if a balance between football and basketball interests could be achieved.
The Rev. Harrington said the compromise of a 12-team league was first raised when the presidents initially met in Boston. "Some, perhaps legitimately, believe football and basketball cannot coexist," he said.
St. John's did not support the proposal to expand to 14 because of the imbalance favoring football and the logistical problems a basketball league of that size would have created. Once that proposal failed, the major football schools were left with an economic decision.
Tranghese said a departure from the league would have required each school to make a withdrawal payment of at least $1 million and forfeit a share of conference revenue from the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament, a total that could exceed $5 million after the 1994 tournament.

HEADLINE: To 3 R's, Some Add Emotions

BYLINE: By DANIEL GOLEMAN 

 BODY:
ANGER, disgust, fear, joy -- a kaleidoscope of feelings washes over the faces of a class of fifth graders at the Troup Middle School in New Haven. Locked in concentration, they are mimicking the expressions on faces pictured on a handout about the specific facial-muscle recipes for each emotion. It's an exercise in empathy: they practice the expressions and talk about the feelings that go with the face. 
 While this may seem a rudimentary lesson in emotional literacy, it is one that some children fail: schoolyard fighters, researchers find, typically interpret benign expressions as hostile and, so, react to provocation where none was intended.
While there have long been courses in values and moral development, or programs warning against perils like pregnancy and drugs, there have only recently been any meant solely to foster emotional abilities like empathy, impulse control and social problem solving.
"People are clamoring for violence prevention," said Tim Shriver, a pioneer in the emotional education movement who directs the social development program for the New Haven schools, which the Troup pupils are following. "We had a war on drugs, and before that, one on teen pregnancy." Saying the nation doesn't need any more such "wars," he added, "What we need is to build basic competencies in kids that work for all these specific battles and leave them with essential skills for living."
A University of Vermont study released in December found that the last two decades had seen a steady and sometimes precipitous climb nationwide in rates of violence and problems ranging from depression and anxiety to disobedience, vandalism and violence among children of all economic levels.
Thomas Achenbach, who directed the study, and other experts on family life point to a range of causes, including a drop in the time parents spend with their children because of work and other pressures, and a rise in the number of single-parent homes. As a result, children spend more time on their own, looking to other children rather than to adults for basic emotional lessons, like caring about how other people feel.
For the last 12 years, Mr. Shriver has been a fixture at Hillhouse High School, a sprawling 1950's building in a dying neighborhood of New Haven -- an area where many schoolchildren live in poverty, a number have parents with AIDS or are themselves infected, and shootings are routine. In this decaying urban core, Mr. Shriver has spearheaded a citywide effort to increase the social and emotional skills that children need more than ever to navigate the perils they face on their journey to adulthood.
For five years now, the 18,000 students in New Haven's 45 public schools have been studying such essentials for life as how to handle their grief and anger, how to negotiate rather than fight and how to cooperate in the classroom, on the playground and at home.
The curriculum, developed by a team of New Haven educators and Yale University psychologists, starts in kindergarten and continues through high school.
The specifics vary depending on the emotional lessons children are able to learn at a particular age. For example, when children start school, social emotions like jealousy and pride come to the fore, while in later grades, friendship skills are of crucial importance. The idea is to offer every child emotional coaching, which otherwise, parents, even in stable families, may or may not have provided effectively.
Some education experts, while acknowledging the urgency of the problems, balk at the new courses.
"There is an urgent need to create a climate of civility in schools," said Dr. Ernest Boyer, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching and the Commissioner of Education under President Jimmy Carter. "But I don't think we should assume every problem needs a separate course instead of weaving it into existing ones. The curriculum is getting stretched beyond belief."
Recognizing the problem, the life skills curriculum -- like many other such programs -- is partly folded into existing courses like physical education and history. But teachers also say they do not mind the added topics, because of the effect on their classroom itself.
"I find the life skills course helps me deal with confrontations and handling problems that come up with my students," said Joyce Andrews, the Troup School fifth-grade teacher whose class was studying facial expressions.
Based on comparisons with students who have not received the programs, there is evidence that there are measurable benefits from the handful of existing emotional education programs -- not just in New Haven, but in hundreds of other schools from Seattle to the Bronx. The benefits include, for instance, a 34 percent drop in suspensions in the New Haven schools, a more congenial classroom atmosphere, fewer fights and disruptiveness, and an increase in children's ability to think before they act and to pay attention and learn.
Perhaps more telling is the recent tale of a sixth grader at Troup who passed her social development teacher a note about her best friend, an eighth grader who was planning suicide because she was pregnant. The girl said she did this because she knew the teacher cared.
Encouraged by the solid signs of success, Mr. Shriver, 34, has taken a decisive step: last month, he established the Center for the Advancement of Emotional and Social Learning at Yale to help teachers and school administrators across the nation who want to set up similar programs.
"Many educators are waking up to the fact that it's not enough just to suspend kids for fighting," Mr. Shriver said. "That it's better to improve the relationship between teachers and students to prevent dropouts and that all students need a solid core of emotional skills in life."
The center will act as a national clearinghouse of information not only about the New Haven program, Mr. Shriver said, but also about a spectrum of similar programs.
The fledgling movement has emerged in part from the wreckage of earlier classroom efforts aimed at isolated problems, with violence prevention being the cause of the moment. A five-year study commissioned by the W. T. Grant Foundation weighed measures of the problems the programs were supposed to prevent, like drug abuse. It concluded that some programs were worthless, and that those that worked best included a broader and prolonged training in basic emotional skills like impulse control and solving conflicts.
Schools are increasingly seen as one bastion that can help take up the slack in socializing the young, and the center is a tacit recognition of the need to expand the mandate of schools beyond academic skills.
Mr. Shriver's center is housed in the Yale Child Studies Center, which has incubated other influential programs in education. Notable among them is the successful model for schools of Dr. James Comer, which seeks to improve the climate of schools through teams of parents, educators and community leaders.
Mr. Shriver is himself a disciple of Dr. Comer, a psychiatrist; in keeping with the Comer approach, the emotional education course is matched with a range of complementary after-school programs. One, for example, recruits adults as mentors for schoolchildren who are foundering.
"A student may confide to his mentor that he's thinking of running away from home because he fights with his mother," Mr. Shriver said. "The mentor can say, 'Why don't you stop first and think of some alternative ways to deal with this, like you've been learning in class?'
"One thing is clear: the proving ground for social problem solving is the cafeteria, the streets or home."

HEADLINE: Mr. Stark's Race Backward

 BODY:
Representative Pete Stark, a California Democrat, heads the House subcommittee in charge of Medicare. So it comes as no surprise that his idea of health-care reform is to shove as many Americans as possible into Medicare, making him czar over an industry almost as large as the Italian economy.
But while Medicare-for-all might be the right prescription for Mr. Stark, it is the wrong reform for the rest of us. Medicare has demonstrably failed to control costs and provide first-rate care. Building reform on the Medicare model would send health care careering in the wrong direction. 
 Mr. Stark would open Medicare -- the Government plan that pays hospital and doctor bills for the elderly -- to the uninsured of any age. The new program, which he calls Medicare Part C, would charge premiums to cover its costs. That is unlike existing Medicare, which charges enrollees only 10 percent of their medical cost (a fact that explains the program's popularity among the elderly).
Mr. Stark rejects the reforms of Mr. Clinton and Representative Jim Cooper of Tennessee, which are designed to control costs by forcing large health plans to compete against one another. He would, instead, attempt to control costs by slapping price controls on doctors and hospitals. That is the system that Medicare uses now. And it fails. Medicare costs spiral out of control because while Washington can control prices, it cannot control volume -- how many office visits, tests and procedures doctors provide patients.
The Stark plan is dismayingly backward-looking. Price controls, he proposes, would be based on how much Americans have spent in the past on individual health services. But in a system in which, as studies show, perhaps one-third of expenditures are wasted, such a calculation would lock in bad practice.
Medicare's fee-for-service coverage, which reimburses doctors for nearly anything they do, rewards doctors and hospitals for providing unneeded procedures. In attempting to control that problem, Washington has been forced to impose incomprehensibly complex regulations. The result is a system that does not constrain costs and drives providers toward procedures that patients do not need but that involve risk.
A better way to achieve high-quality, affordable health care is the creation of integrated networks of doctors and hospitals that are paid a fixed annual fee for taking care of enrollees. That way doctors have incentive to keep patients healthy, with ample doses of preventive care, and to weed out unwarranted procedures. That is the approach adopted by Mr. Clinton and Mr. Cooper. Mr. Stark wants to push health care back to the past.

HEADLINE: U.S. TIGHTENS RULES TO HELP INVESTORS IN MUNICIPAL BONDS

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
In an effort to help the millions of Americans who own municipal bonds, the Federal Government issued new rules today intended to make it easier for them to keep track of the value of their bonds, which are often a major part of their life savings.
American households own $488 billion worth of municipal bonds directly and an additional $414 billion through mutual funds and other investment vehicles, making individuals by far the dominant investors in the $1.2 trillion market. Investors increasingly choose these securities because they do not have to pay taxes on the interest they receive. Over the last 10 years, individual ownership has jumped to nearly 75 percent of the market from less than 45 percent. 
 But buyers of tax-exempt municipal bonds sold by large cities like New York or tiny agencies like the Sterling Independent School District No. 3 in Oklahoma have had no assurance that they could learn about important financial developments: a ballooning budget deficit, for example, or the missing of an interest payment. Either development would make the bonds much less valuable.
 
Notification of Trouble
 Under the proposal issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, state and local governments and authorities would have to issue annual financial reports after the initial sale of a new bond, some of which do not mature for 30 years. There is currently no such disclosure requirement.
In addition, governments that sell bonds would also have to notify investors if they run into the kind of financial trouble, like a lower credit rating, that could instantly undermine the value of the tax-exempt bonds investors own.
Though these new regulations remain far less strict than those governing corporations that sell stocks and bonds to the public, they mark a radical change in the huge, lightly regulated tax-exempt bond market, which has been rocked by political and financial scandals in the last few years.
 
Role in Most Mishaps
 "It's been hard for investors to evaluate individual issues, given the quality of disclosure," said John Markese, research director for the American Association of Individual Investors. The S.E.C. plan could prevent the problem, he said, "where you buy a bond and 20 years later a default or a ratings change hits the individual out of the blue."
As new investors move billions of their dollars into municipal bonds, directly and through mutual funds, the S.E.C. chairman, Arthur Levitt Jr., said, "it becomes particularly imperative that this vital constituency understand what they are buying and what they are paying for."
S.E.C. officials say inadequate disclosure of financial data has played a big role in most municipal bond market mishaps since the New York City fiscal crisis in the 1970's. These include the largest tax-exempt bond default ever, by the Washington Public Power Supply System, as well as a series of small defaults by nursing homes across the country.
The S.E.C. is also concerned that investors with information about problems in a bond issue have taken advantage of the lack of generally available data "and unloaded the bonds on unsuspecting retail investors," said Richard Y. Roberts, the S.E.C. commissioner who has been a leading critic of municipal market practices.
The problem is particularly acute in the case of issues that governments sell on behalf of private companies to generate economic development or promote local projects like hospitals and nursing homes, said Richard A. Ciccarone, senior vice president of Kemper Securities in Chicago.
"Though these situations are in the minority rather than the majority, they are common enough to be concerned about," he said. Last year, for example, holders of an $8.6 million issue sold by the Bartlesville, Okla., Industrial Development Authority saw the price of their bonds fall, but the authority refused to release any information that would explain the decline. Bondholders were left worrying that the project might default on the bonds and are still in the dark, Mr. Ciccarone said.
The proposed disclosure rules are one of two big changes being made in the operation of the municipal bond market. The other is a broad restriction on political contributions from the municipal industry to local and state officials in an effort to win lucrative contracts to underwrite, or sell, municipal bonds.
The municipal industry has already put into effect a voluntary ban on such contributions. And a Government rule backing up this ban, supported by the S.E.C., is expected to go into effect this spring.
In general, governments should be able to comply with the new disclosure rules without much trouble, said Jeffrey L. Esser, executive director of the Government Finance Officers Association in Chicago. Many already produce annual audited financial statements, which the new regulations will require, he said.
As for the requirement that governments tell investors about material problems like defaults on interest payments or a finding that bonds are not tax-exempt, Mr. Esser said, "those happen rarely to any issuer" and should be reported.
 
Costlier for Governments
 The trade organization for the mutual fund industry, the Investment Company Institute, said its members support efforts to improve the information available about municipal bonds. Fund managers, who are now the largest buyers of tax-exempt securities, say better disclosure will help them value bonds properly and protect fund shareholders.
While large issuers like New York City, which was the biggest seller of bonds last year, probably will not feel much effect from the new regulations, they may have more impact on taxpayers in smaller cities and towns, which may find it more expensive to borrow the money they need to buy school buses, fix sewers and build bridges because of the cost of periodic financial disclosure. "This will materially increase the cost of issuance for small issuers," warned Leo C. O'Neill, the president of Standard & Poor's ratings group.
Mr. O'Neill said the new increased disclosure would not have much effect on his firm, which now rates about 80 percent of the municipal bonds outstanding. But, he added, "it will be an additional incentive for the governments and may make things a little easier for us: we may not have to keep sending out all those letters" requesting financial updates.
Although government and market participants were reluctant to endorse the S.E.C. plan today because they had not seen the details, they had been closely involved in the writing of the proposal.
"We are encouraged that the S.E.C. proposed rule amendments reflects many of the ideas contained in a statement we issued jointly with the Government Finance Officers Association and other issuer and industry groups last December," said Heather Ruth, the president of the Public Securities Association, which represents municipal bond dealers.
 
Industry Changes Attitude
 What Mrs. Ruth did not say in her statement was that the praise for the S.E.C. move reflected a change in attitude of the industry, which had been generally opposed to such new disclosure requirements as recently as last year.
Congress has never given the S.E.C. direct power over state and local governments, which sell municipal bonds. The agency will instead enforce the new rules using its power over investment firms.
Investment banks will no longer be able to sell new bonds for local and state governments if the issuers do not agree to provide investors with continuing financial information by sending audited annual reports to a central depository. Governments must agree to inform a registry at once if they have a serious, material problem, like failing to make an interest payment.
In an effort to insure that investors get the benefit of the newly required disclosure, brokers will be barred from recommending bonds outstanding to clients unless they have reviewed the most recent financial data available.
 
Final Version in 4 Months
 The commission will not adopt a final version of these requirements for four months, giving investors, government officials, bond dealers and others time to comment on the plan. But Mr. Levitt made it clear that the changes would go into effect. As of now, these rules will apply only to bonds sold in the future.
"To a significant degree, the debt markets operate based upon traditions, many are going to view these proposals as disruptive since they call for a change in traditional practices," Mr. Levitt said. "I intend to pay close attention to the comments. But, over time, I believe that these innovations will be viewed as anything but disruptive."
In an additional measure to bolster investor protection, the S.E.C. plans to require bond dealers to inform buyers if a bond is not rated by an independent agency. Brokers will also have to disclose in many cases how much of a profit -- or markup -- they are charging customers when bonds are traded. Mr. Levitt said he feared that many investors were like his mother, who did not realize that she was paying a markup. Because she was told she did not have to pay a commission on the transaction, Mr. Levitt said she thought she was getting a bargain.
The least onerous of the new regulations are steps the S.E.C. says governments can take to make it easier for them to defend themselves against accusations of securities fraud in the future. These steps, which are suggested but not required, include disclosing potential conflicts of interest and financial ties among government officials and brokerage firm executives that sell their bonds.
The new disclosure regulations will probably exempt governments that have sold less than $3 million of bonds in the last four years and have less than $10 million outstanding. But the S.E.C. may modify or limit that exemption because many of the bond issues that have burned investors in recent years have been small deals done for nursing homes and hospitals.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 19, 1994, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a front-page article on March 10 about new financial disclosure rules for the municipal bond market misstated the position of the Public Securities Association. The association, which represents municipal bond dealers, has supported the need for issuers of bonds to report regularly on their financial status after the initial sale of the bonds.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A Corporate Hybrid of New Cereals

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
The Kellogg Company, the nation's largest maker of breakfast cereal, said yesterday that it had agreed to produce a new line under the Healthy Choice brand name in a licensing deal with Conagra Inc.
The arrangement is a first for both companies. Kellogg has never licensed a cereal brand from another company, nor has Conagra let another company use its Healthy Choice name. Financial terms of the joint venture were not disclosed. 
 "It's very unusual," said Lawrence Adelman, a food analyst for Dean Witter. The alliance creates some potential economic advantages for both companies, but whether it pays off with consumers will take longer to determine, he said.
Kellogg's shares, which had risen 87.5 cents Tuesday in anticipation of the announcement, fell $1 yesterday, to $48.25 on the New York Stock Exchange.
"The hype was not justified," Mr. Adelman said.
Conagra shares rose to $28, up 75 cents, also on the Big Board.
 
Out of Space
 Conagra has 300 products under the Healthy Choice label, including soups, frozen dinners and ice cream, but only egg substitutes in the breakfast area. The brand line, which was started six years ago, accounted for $1 billion of Conagra's $21 billion in sales last year. But the company, which is based in Omaha, does not have the manufacturing capacity for all its Healthy Choice products, many of which are made in plants of private-label producers.
The alliance with Kellogg gives Conagra a relatively inexpensive means to broaden its product line. "The cereal business is very capital-intensive from a start-up basis," Mr. Adelman said.
Kellogg has an opportunity to bolster its 37 percent share of the $8 billion cereal business by adding three varieties to the 45 brands it produces. "They will get a jump-start because of the brand name," Mr. Adelman said.
Karen MacLeod, a spokeswoman for Kellogg, said, "This will bring the Healthy Choice consumer into the breakfast category."
The cereal, which will have the green Healthy Choice packaging along with the red Kellogg name, will be available in June for $2.50 to $3.50 a box, in sizes ranging from 11.5 ounces to 16.5 ounces. It will come in three varieties: flakes, squares and multigrain clusters. Consumers gave the cereal high scores in taste tests, Ms. MacLeod said.
The cereal is to be marketed to adults, who can already choose from shelves full of rival brands, like Nabisco Shredded Wheat, General Mills' Total and General Foods' Fruit & Fiber.

HEADLINE: 7 Chinese Intellectuals Appeal For End to Political Repression

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 10

 BODY:
Challenging the Government's latest crackdown on dissidents, seven leading scientists and intellectuals appealed in writing today to President Jiang Zemin for an end to repression of free speech and for the release of all political prisoners.
The appeal, which coincided with the opening session of the National People's Congress, was made available to Western journalists a day before Secretary of State Warren Christopher is to begin an official visit. It is believed to be the first petition to the Chinese Government on human rights from a group of eminent intellectuals since the crackdown on the Tiananmen Square demonstrations in 1989.
 
Arrests Are Protested
 The group said it was protesting the arrests and intimidation of dissidents during the last week in advance of Mr. Christopher's visit and the opening of the Chinese congress. 
 "We appeal to the authorities to bravely end our country's history of punishing people for their ideas, speech and writing, and release all those imprisoned because of their ideas and speech," said the petition, signed by seven intellectuals. The group was led by Xu Liangying, a 74-year-old historian of the Academy of Sciences who helped translate Albert Einstein's collected works into Chinese.
"People of insight, who are concerned with the fate of the nation and who are dedicated to our country's modernization, feel shocked and at the same time upset and worried," the statement said, adding, "To talk about modernization without mentioning human rights is like climbing a tree to catch a fish." [Text of appeal, page A10.]
The tone and spirit of the statement recalled the popular movement that rose in the winter of 1989 and gathered momentum that spring, first among intellectuals, then among students and workers. Their protests in favor of democracy paralyzed Beijing and seized international attention for weeks until the movement was crushed by tanks and machine-gun fire in Tiananmen Square on June 4, 1989.
 
Petition Mailed to Officials
 Mr. Xu said he mailed the petition today to President Jiang and to Qiao Shi, chairman of the National People's Congress, or parliament. Official Chinese news organizations have not yet reported the appeal, but its existence is likely to become widely known here through foreign radio broadcasts beamed to China.
Providing a copy of the petition to The New York Times, Professor Xu asked that it be conveyed to Mr. Christopher and expressed a desire to meet with him during his three-day visit, which begins on Friday.
Mr. Christopher, speaking during his visit to Tokyo, sought to play down expectations that he might meet with Chinese dissidents, saying he had no "plans to do so at the present time." [Page A10.]
The other signers were Ding Zilin and Jiang Peikun, philosophy professors whose son was killed during the military crackdown four years ago; Shao Yanxiang, a poet; the writer Zhang Kangkang; Liu Liao, a physicist; and Professor Xu's wife, Wang Laili, a historian.
All are well known and command great respect in Chinese society, which prizes its intellectuals.
Professor Xu's reputation among the Chinese is also based on his long service to the Communist Party, the persecution he suffered after criticizing Mao Zedong's purges and finally, his break with Marxism.
Rehabilitated in the late 1970's after Deng Xiaoping came to power, he formed a alliance with other intellectuals and reignited what became known as the "science and democracy" movement.
In an interview in his apartment in Beijing's university district, Professor Xu sharply criticized China's leadership for zeroing in on the youthful leaders of a reinvigorated democracy movement this winter in Beijing and Shanghai.
"They are being detained or arrested only because of their speech," he said. "It is the responsibility of us senior intellectuals to defend them."
More pointedly, he said the petition showed "that the Chinese people have not died out; not everyone in China is dead. There are still some people who can petition for human rights."
President Clinton has warned China that it could lose its preferential trade status with the United States this June if it does not take concrete steps to improve its human rights policy.
 
Rights Campaign Planned
 In another challenge apparently linked to Mr. Christopher's imminent arrival, Wang Dan, a former student leader who has been detained twice in the last week, announced in an open letter to China's Parliament that he would begin a "legal and open" campaign to investigate human rights abuses in China.
"I will, on my own identity, conduct detailed investigations on some specific cases involving human rights," Mr. Wang said in a statement faxed to offices of Western news agencies.
"I don't avoid mentioning human rights issues," he said. "My opinions differ in many respects from the authorities but I don't want to impose my views on the Government. I only hope the Government could abide by the law when enforcing laws and truly safeguard the rights of the citizens, including those detained."
The statements are among the most vigorous and open challenges to the Communist Party's suppression of free speech in recent years. They were issued on a day when Prime Minister Li Peng, addressing the opening session of the National People's Congress, declared that "social stability" -- a code word for political repression -- would remain an "indispensible prerequisite" for economic development.
 
Signs of Defiance
 Around the capital, there were other signs of defiance.
Wei Jingsheng, the country's most prominent dissident, who left the capital last weekend after 30 hours of detention and interrogation, called other members of the dissident community today and told them to expect a "great event" during Mr. Christopher's visit.
Mr. Wei has been staying at a hotel in Tianjin since he was released last by security agents Saturday. He told security officials he was leaving Beijing for health reasons.
There has been wide speculation that American officials and Mr. Wei were making preparations for a meeting since Feb. 27, when Mr. Wei met for 90 minutes with the State Department's top human rights official, John Shattuck.
Beijing's diplomatic quarter seemed to be braced for a bruising exchange between Mr. Christopher and President Jiang, who has assured a series of American officials in recent months that China planned to take steps "within the framework of its laws" to respond to President Clinton's demand for "significant progress" on rights.
China has yet to deliver on the pledge, and some diplomats believe that any concessions from the Politburo will come in the final weeks or perhaps days before the June 3 deadline Mr. Clinton has effectively set.
For now Mr. Christopher's high-profile visit, his first to Beijing as Secretary of State, has given China's dissidents their greatest opportunity since 1989 to resurface and submit a new set of demands for civil rights and democracy to a Politburo accustomed to quieting its critics.
Professor Xu's credibility cannot easily be shaken by the authorities. He and Mr. Qiao, now one of the most powerful members of the Politburo, were part of the Communist underground together in southern China during the 1940's.
He received a prestigious academic appointment after the Communist victory in 1949, but his criticism of Mao's purge of intellectuals in the summer of 1957 led to 20 years of political persecution.
 
Letters Are Confiscated
 The New York-based group Human Rights in China said that security agents confiscated letters carried by one of its founders, Li Xiaorong, at Shanghai's international airport.
[Early Friday morning, the police in Shanghai detained Wang Fuchen, 39, the Secretary General of the Shanghai-based Association for Human Rights, Reuters reported.]
Ms. Li reported that the agents had seized a letter from Professor Xu that she was carrying back to New York. It appealed for financial aid to the families of students wounded during the Tiananmen Square crackdown.
Also confiscated, the group said, were a personal letter from Mr. Wei to Liu Qing, the director of the human rights group, and a letter from Xu Wenli, a democracy campaigner released from prison last year, to a French magazine.

HEADLINE: U.S. TO ALLOW SALE OF THE TECHNOLOGY FOR SPY SATELLITES

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration announced today that it would allow companies to market sophisticated spy satellite technology to commercial customers around the world.
The decision marks a big change from the comparatively strict limits now imposed on satellite-imaging systems, and it caps more than a year of intense debate among the Commerce Department, the Pentagon and Government intelligence agencies. 
 The move, which could attract business worth hundreds of millions of dollars to American industry, also marks one of the clearest examples so far of the Administration's intention to emphasize commercial and economic priorities over more traditional cold war-era concerns about national security.
 
 
Change Raises Concern
 Some security experts questioned the decision to allow wider access to a technology that has been described as one of the most powerful tools in America's espionage arsenal. But others said that the technology was already becoming available in other countries and that American companies should be allowed to profit from the trend.
Under the new policy, American companies will be allowed to build and operate for-profit satellite systems that can photograph objects on the ground as small as one square yard, smaller than a subcompact car or a hot-dog stand.
Several American companies, among them the Lockheed Corporation, are hoping to set up satellite-imaging services for customers around the world. As envisioned by Lockheed, customers would be able to transmit instructions directly to the satellite, which would turn its cameras to the desired location and then beam the images back to the ground. Such customers might include oil and mining companies and environmental researchers, who want to map the precise characteristics of large swaths of land.
 
'A New Era'
 Administration officials said companies would also have greater freedom to export entire satellite systems to foreign countries, though such sales will still require State Department approval.
"This is 1994," David J. Barram, Deputy Secretary of Commerce, said in an interview today. "This is a new era. We believe national security and economic security are intertwined. In order to have national security, you have to have vibrant and competitive industries that are allowed to do what they do best."
But some experts warned that the decision could severely compromise national security by letting hostile countries use America's own spy technology to obtain detailed images of sensitive military installations in the United States or to plan military activities elsewhere in the world.
"The main customers for these systems will be the intelligence agencies of other countries," predicted John Pike, director of space policy at the Federation of American Scientists, a nonprofit group devoted to science and public policy. "They have fairly strong safeguards here. But in practice it is going to be difficult to prevent North Korea or Iraq from using a front company to gain spy satellite photos in the same way they acquired nuclear and chemical missile technology."
Numerous companies already market commercial satellite images, which can be used for mapping, geologic surveys and even agricultural purposes, like remote monitoring of cattle herds.
 
 
Best Current System
 But currently, the most sophisticated of these services is offered by Spot Image, a French company, and it cannot produce photographs showing land areas smaller than about 10 yards in diameter. And while the Spot system is being upgraded, it will still be unable to view areas smaller than five yards.
Lockheed and other American companies have been arguing for permission to operate systems that could depict objects about a square yard in size, a request that had been resisted by the Central Intelligence Agency and National Security Agency.
 Despite the agencies' concerns, Administration officials said today that they fully intended to approve requests like those of Lockheed, and went on to argue that the higher-resolution images are essential if any significant commercial market is to be formed. The Commerce Department says that remote-sensing services, as they are known, currently make up a $400 million market worldwide; the market is expected to grow to about $2 billion by the year 2000.
Besides Lockheed, two other American companies have sought permission to operate high-resolution satellite-imaging services. One is the Orbital Sciences Corporation, a small rocket and satellite company based in Dulles, Va. The other is World View Inc., a start-up company in Livermore, Calif.
Administration officials said that while the companies intended to adopt the precise technology that has long been used on Government spy satellites, the new policy included a number of safeguards to prevent the technology from falling into the wrong hands.
As happens now, the Commerce Department must still approve each application to operate a commercial satellite surveillance system or to sell such a system within the United States -- or to market the services around the world. Sales of such equipment outside the country, however, will be subject to the export-control procedures already in place for products that have military applications, which means that each sale must be approved by the State Department and that sales to hostile countries will likely be blocked. But under the new policy, the Government would be much more likely to approve spy satellite exports.
 To prevent the misuse of satellite data sold by the new commercial services, the Government said the companies would have to maintain a record of every job the satellite had been instructed to carry out. Moreover, the satellites cannot scramble their transmissions with coding technology that the Government cannot decipher. An oil company could protect its business secrets - for example, by transmitting its exploration photos in scrambled form -- but the Government would have the right to decode them.
 
 
Government Intervention
 In addition, the new policy leaves room for the Government to shut down a satellite system during what an Administration statement described as "periods when national security or international obligations and/or foreign policies may be compromised." But industry officials who support the new policy said they had been assured by Commerce Department officials that the country would need to be in a "Persian Gulf situation" before it began shutting down systems.
Executives at companies that have pressed for more liberal rules said the new policy gave them virtually everything they wanted.
"We are very pleased that the Administration put together such a forward-thinking policy that allows the application of defense technology for commercial purposes," said Brian Dailey, vice president at the Washington office of Lockheed.
Gilbert Rye, corporate vice president at Orbital Sciences, echoed that view. "It's an outstanding development," he said.
 Today's decision was supported, at least in public, by the Defense Department and other agencies concerned with national security issues, despite earlier resistance. Two Central Intelligence Agency officials were present at a news briefing for reporters today, though they did not make any comments.
Some longtime national security experts said the new policy made sense, given the proliferation of satellite imaging technology around the world. "Inevitably, we're going to see a proliferation of systems, publicly available throughout the world, with this capability," said Martin Faga, who served under President Bush as director of the National Reconnaissance Office, the highly secret agency that builds spy satellites.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Offer by Northrop For Grumman Tops Martin Marietta Bid

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
In what appeared to set off a bidding war, the Northrop Corporation offered late yesterday to purchase the Grumman Corporation, the Long Island warplane manufacturer, for $60 a share, or $2.04 billion. The Northrop offer came three days after the Martin Marietta Corporation announced that it would purchase Grumman for $55 a share.
The battle for Grumman underscores two aspects of weapons making in the post-cold war era. One is that Pentagon spending for weapons and research, projected at $88 billion this year, is still a very good business for the half-dozen or so manufacturers that survive as major military contractors. The other is that no matter which company -- Northrop or Martin Marietta -- wins Grumman, the new, merged concern will close plants and cut staff. 
 "We certainly need to rationalize the business as the defense market shrinks," Kent Kresa, chairman of Northrop, said in an interview, using a euphemism to refer to cost-cutting, largely by eliminating duplicate operations. But his emphasis yesterday was on preserving Grumman. He said that if the merger went through, the new company would be named the Northrop-Grumman Corporation "to preserve the proud heritage of the Grumman name."
The issue of another reduction in Grumman's staff -- already down to 18,000 from 33,000 in 1987 -- seems likely to play a bigger role in this takeover battle than in previous ones involving military contractors. Grumman employees own a third of the company's stock, and this stake is managed by representatives of the workers. They will have to decide whether to tender their shares to Martin Marietta or to Northrop. Presumably they would take job security, as well as money, into consideration.
Whoever wins the bidding, the acquisition of Grumman would be the ninth major merger of two military contractors since 1990, when the cold war was clearly ending and big cutbacks in Pentagon spending for new weapons were getting under way. Martin Marietta has been the most aggressive in acquiring other companies and if it gets Grumman, it would emerge as the nation's largest aerospace-electronics concern. The Grumman bid is Northrop's first attempt at a major acquisition.
Martin Marietta had announced on Monday an offer of $55 a share, or $1.9 billion. The directors of Grumman and Martin Marietta had approved this offer, which came after Grumman in February had broken off talks with Northrop. The Northrop offer ups the ante by $5 a share. Northrop said that it would acquire the shares by drawing on a new credit of $2.8 billion that it had obtained from Chase Manhattan Bank and Chemical Bank.
The extra $760 million in financing beyond the $2.04 billion that Northrop offered yesterday suggested that the California-based company was prepared to go higher if Martin Marietta increased its bid, although Mr. Kresa, during a telephone news conference, declined to say how the extra financing would be used. Wall Street also anticipated a bidding war. Grumman's stock price rose by $6.75 a share, to $61.75, after the Northrop offer was announced. The New York Stock Exchange had already closed, but trading was still open in California.
 
 
'Read the Tea Leaves'
 Asked during the telephone news conference whether $60 a share would be Northrop's top bid, Richard Waugh, Northrop's chief financial officer, said: "I cannot comment on this. Read the tea leaves."
Mr. Kresa insisted that Northrop and Grumman fit easily together. Northrop, he noted, makes bombers, notably the B-2, while Grumman makes surveillance aircraft, mainly the Navy E-2C Hawkeye. Its most famous plane, the F-14 Tomcat jet fighter, is no longer manufactured, but the Pentagon pays Grumman millions of dollars to rebuild F-14's, primarily by hollowing out the airframes and installing new electronic gear.
"Northrop and Martin Marietta both want to get into this niche rebuilding business, which is lucrative, at a time when Pentagon spending on new weapons is shrinking," said Greg Bischak, executive director of the National Commission for Economic Conversion, a Washington research and lobby group. Mr. Waugh of Northrop described the aircraft rebuilding at Grumman as "a very sizeable piece of business."
The armed services spend $13 billion a year on rebuilding aircraft and other weaponry and also on the maintenance depots now operated by the Army, Navy and Air Force to overhaul weaponry. Military contractors are lobbying to shift this maintenance work from the armed services to themselves -- an additional source of revenue that would enhance the Grumman acquisition for Northrop or Martin Marietta.
 
 
Electronic Gear
 Both Northrop and Grumman also make various types of electronic gear, and it is in this area that plant closings and layoffs might occur, although Northrop executives insisted during the telephone news conference that a Northrop-Grumman merger, at $60 a share, would make money without any cutbacks. They said none was immediately planned.
Northrop, which is based in Los Angeles, now employs 30,000 people while Grumman's 18,000 workers are mostly on Long Island, near its Bethpage headquarters. Martin Marietta, based in Bethesda, Md., is mainly a manufacturer of space equipment and electronics, including various missile systems.
An hour or so after Northrop's announcement, Martin Marietta said in an angry press release that "the attack by Northrop degrades the entire character of the rational consolidation taking place within the United States' national security industrial base." The press release added that Martin Marietta "will respond to Northrop's action in an appropriate manner at the appropriate time."
Grumman had been seeking a buyer, and a spokesman said last night that the company was studying the proposal from Northrop. Mr. Kresa, in a letter to Renso L. Caporali, chairman of Grumman, announcing Northrop's offer, noted that Northrop and Grumman had been in discussions in January and February, but then Grumman abruptly excluded Northrop, without explanation.
"As early as Feb. 16, your representative asked Martin Marietta but not us to submit their highest and best offer," Mr. Kresa wrote. "We never received such a request. Never, in the entire process were we advised that you were in negotiations with another party, that a decision had been made to sell Grumman, or that we should submit our highest and best bid."
Mr. Kresa said that Northrop had told Grumman, in late February, that it was ready to pay $50 a share, if invited to bid. "At a certain point, we were told they were no longer for sale," Mr. Kresa said.
Grumman did not comment on Mr. Kresa's remarks.
Northrop said that its tender offer for Grumman shares would begin on Monday morning, although Martin Marietta might raise the bidding before then. Northrop stock ended up 62.5 cents on the New York Stock Exchange, closing yesterday at $41.25, and Martin Marietta stock gained 50 cents to close at $46.50.

HEADLINE: Family Struggles to Make Do After Fall From Middle Class

SERIES: Staying Afloat: Work in the 90's -- Second of four articles.

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo.

 BODY:
With two cars in the garage and a swing set in the backyard, Craig Miller and his family fell easily into the suburban rhythms of Johnson County.
He was a sheet-metal worker for T.W.A. His middle-class status was stamped on the pay stub: $15.65 an hour. And the shopping mall clerks didn't care if the paying customer wore steel-toe boots or tasseled loafers. 
 But the airline was troubled, and it laid off Mr. Miller off in the summer of 1992. When he began to search for another job, he quickly learned the market value of a blue-collar worker with a strong back and a good work ethic but few special skills: about $5 an hour.
Mr. Miller, a 37-year-old father of four, now works behind the counter in a McDonald's, hustling orders for Quarter Pounders and chicken fajitas and deferring to teen-age customers with "Yes, sir" and "Thank you, ma'am."
Mr. Miller also drives a school bus. And on the side he has started a small business, changing furnace filters. He printed up cards for the venture, "Sani-Max," but there hasn't been much demand for his service.
For the last eight years his wife, Susan, 34, has worked part time as a stock clerk at Toys "R" Us at night, when her husband can watch the children. She recently got a raise and now makes $5.95 an hour.
In most ways, the nation's economy seems to be racing ahead, evident here in the spiffy shops of Country Club Plaza and the big new crop of $200,000 houses sprouting in the corn fields on the outskirts of town.
 
New Jobs, but Not Enough
 Throughout the country, some two million new jobs were created last year. But for people like Craig and Susan Miller, who lack college degrees as well as coveted skills, the statistics on an increasing number of jobs offer little comfort.
"Sure, we've got four of them," Mr. Miller said, managing a chuckle. "So what? So you can work like a dog for $5 an hour."
In nearly three years since the 1990-91 recession, employers nationwide have taken on three million workers, but that is less than half as many as they hired after the 1981-82 recession. And many of the new jobs are part time or temporary.
At the same time, the number of manufacturing jobs has fallen 8.3 percent from 1989 through February 1994. Tens of thousands of jobs have moved abroad; advances in technology have taken others.
As the Millers gaze into the future from their brick-and-frame house in Overland Park, Kan., they see an employment landscape shaped like a barbell. At one end are bankers and lawyers and accountants exulting in the high-flying stock market; at the other end are countermen at fast-food franchises and clerks at big discount stores struggling to pay the bills. The solid, working-class middle ground, where the Millers once stood, has meanwhile grown narrow -- and slippery.
Counting all their part-time jobs, the Millers will make about $18,000 this year, less than half what Mr. Miller earned as a union sheet-metal worker. They have found the fall difficult to fathom, and even harder to accept. They could probably qualify for food stamps but refuse to consider applying.
"We're middle-class people," Mr. Miller said. "It's just that we have a lower-class income."
 
The Daily Routine
 The work day starts in darkness. Mr. Miller, an Army veteran, crawls out of bed about 6 A.M., careful not to wake his youngest child, 3-year-old Amanda, who shares her parent's bedroom. By 7 A.M. he is behind the wheel of a school bus, stopping and going along tree-lined suburban streets of Overland Park. He will do it again in the late afternoon. The daily pay is $35, no benefits.
After completing the morning bus route, he stops back at his house to change into his blue McDonald's uniform with his "Craig" nameplate pinned onto it. His restaurant job starts at 9:30 A.M., in a strip mall on Highway 69.
The pay in a fast-food restaurant is low, but the work is relentless. Customers are often lined up six deep. Mr. Miller, a man who once fixed dents in the fuselages of jets and felt pride in his craft whenever a plane soared overhead, darts between the counter and the food pickup shelf, back and forth, a hundred times a day, careful not to misfill an order.
In the slower moments, he comes around the counter, dips a mop in a bucket and drags it across the floor. With the customers, he always tries to wear a polite smile, but he doesn't always meet their eyes.
"I still have some pride, you know," he said. "But what am I going to do? I think the needs of my children are a little more important than my ego."
When he took the job, Mr. Miller expected to be the oldest worker at McDonald's. He was surprised to find several people past 30.
Still wearing the McDonald's uniform, he climbs back in the school bus at 2:30 P.M. for the afternoon run. About 5, he arrives home.
Dinner is served right away, often pasta with ground turkey. The Millers never buy beef anymore.
Just before 6, Mrs. Miller leaves for her job, six hours of bending and lifting to stock the shelves with toys. It will be midnight by the time she returns home. She also works one day a week at the same McDonald's as her husband.
 
Battle With Bills
 Every time the telephone rings, the Millers instinctively fear that a bill collector is calling. They are $3,000 behind in medical bills. Mrs. Miller's part-time job provides health benefits, with the company paying 80 percent of medical bills and the employee 20 percent. But with four children, even paying just 20 percent adds up. And one child recently had surgery.
When a bill collector got huffy on the phone the other day, Mrs. Miller told him wearily, "Oh, get in line."
The couple buy one newspaper a week, for the food coupons, and only one light burns in the house at a time. When a child forgets to flip off the switch, Mrs. Miller chides gently: "Have you got stock in the electric company? Well, neither do I."
Not so long ago, such worries would have seemed absurd. The Millers were saving so they could exchange their rented house for one of their own. At backyard barbecues and church picnics they moved comfortably in a social circle that included college graduates, people who wore suits to work and were therefore deemed "professional" but who often earned no more than the Millers.
When a child in school boasted of a parent who was a doctor or a lawyer, 7-year-old Peter Miller was known to reply, "My daddy can fix planes so they can fly high in the sky."
A quarter century ago, Mr. Miller remembers feeling the same kind of pride in his own blue-collar father. But the rules and rewards were simple then: if a man wasn't afraid to sweat, he could succeed.
Mr. Miller had watched his father make good on the bargain, a factory worker who provided a two-story house, a decent savings account and summer vacations to the California redwoods and Yellowstone National Park.
 
'I Miss It a Lot'
 That was the kind of life that Mr. Miller had always planned for his own family. But now there doesn't seem to be much point in even talking about it.
"Oh, yeah, I miss it a lot," he said, referring to the old job, and perhaps to the old rules.
He clings to the hope that the fortunes of T.W.A. will improve and that the company will then re-call him and others who were laid off.
One recent evening, Mr. Miller pulled out some old work tools, grasping them in hands that are now much smoother, and explained the purpose of each.
On the floor next to the sofa was a two-year-old airline magazine, with a cover article titled, "How to make good landings." On the wall, an art print carried a quote from Isaiah: "We grope for the wall like the blind."
Mr. Miller doesn't care to talk much about McDonald's. He sat in the living room with a visitor for two hours one evening, never taking off the jacket that covered his McDonald's shirt. Finally, for a brief moment, he unsnapped the buttons to reveal the uniform.
"There, you see it," he said, with a blush of embarrassment and perhaps a glint of rage. Then he closed the jacket again.
 
Sad Stories Abound
 Now and then, Mr. Miller checks with some of his old buddies from the T.W.A. hangar, men who used to talk about rushing yardage and batting averages on coffee breaks. Now they share rumors about the latest threatened corporate "downsizing."
One of the men, Joe Tomczuk, could not find a job that paid more than $6 an hour. He moved back home with his parents, at age 39, and wondered if he should abandon the hope of ever getting married and starting a family.
"Women are just like me; they want security," Mr. Tomczuk said. "What are they going to see in me?"
Another former colleague is now a janitor in a school. Others seem to have disappeared.
In the months after T.W.A. laid off several hundred workers like Mr. Miller, some marriages collapsed. Alcohol took a toll. And union officials say perhaps a dozen men peered into the bleakness of the future and committed suicide.
Mr. Miller said some friends had encouraged him to move to a city where good blue-collar jobs were more plentiful. But where was that? Even at his father's old factory, in Muscatine, Iowa, a ketchup plant, technology was phasing out workers.
 
Keeping Up for the Children
 But moving is simply not an option. The Millers' eldest child, 11-year-old Jeremiah, has severe learning disabilities but has been making significant progress, which his parents credit to the top-notch teachers at the affluent Blue Valley School District. The couple will not consider risking Jeremiah's future in a mediocre school; nor are they willing to put him through the emotional strain of starting over in strange surroundings even if the schools were superior.
"We try not to tell the kids too much," Mr. Miller said. "This belongs on our shoulders, not theirs."
But some things are difficult to avoid. Not long ago, Jeremiah asked if he could take his friends to a restaurant for his birthday, a custom with many children at his school.
"We'll have to talk about that," Mr. Miller told the boy.
Mrs. Miller glanced toward the children and shook her head.
"I hope they choose their careers carefully," she said later. "Everything is geared to the college people anymore. If your job isn't sitting in front of a computer, watch out."
Mrs. Miller said she and her husband should have seen the writing on the wall. But when times were good, they seemed like they would last forever. Now she has scant hope that those days will ever return.
"For people like us," she said, "I'm afraid the good times are gone for good."

HEADLINE: After Skipping President's Talk, Giuliani Meets Clinton in Private

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
After several days of suspense over whether Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York would manage to clear his schedule for a meeting with President Clinton, the two met yesterday at the Sheraton New York Hotel and talked mainly about law enforcement and the President's crime bill.
Speaking to reporters after the meeting, Mr. Giuliani said he never had any intention of slighting the President by declining an invitation to attend a talk-show-style get-together on community policing and national service at Brooklyn College earlier in the day. 
 "It was a very positive meeting," Mr. Giuliani said, adding that the two had talked for about 40 minutes. (The White House said it was 20 minutes.) "The President and I had a lot of time to discuss the economy, our gun strategy. We talked about policing and some lighthearted conversation, joking around. But these are the things you keep private."
Specifically, the Mayor said he asked Mr. Clinton for more details on his crime bill. "I think what has to happen in the crafting of this legislation is that we need to get more specific on the amount of aid being given, how long that aid is going to last," he said. "By making positive suggestions, maybe we can make it better legislation."
 
'It Wasn't a Snub'
 The two-hour meeting at Brooklyn College, a discussion of President Clinton's national service program and community policing, was attended by leading New York public officials, including the City Public Advocate, Mark J. Green; the City Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi; the Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden; Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, and the State Attorney General, G. Oliver Koppell.
Mr. Giuliani said the President told him he was not disappointed that the Mayor had not attended the Brooklyn College event.
"He was very upbeat," the Mayor said. "Things move very fast and there can be misimpressions. This has been made into something other than what it was. It wasn't a snub. The President understood it."
The White House, too, said the meeting had been cordial. But some people who met with the President later said that Mr. Clinton seemed uncertain why the Mayor did not accept his invitation to attend the Brooklyn College function. "He was puzzled," said the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone. "But he doesn't believe there was an intentional slight. Certainly the President will not deny anything to the city because of it."
Mr. Clinton also met with former Mayor David N. Dinkins in private. In addition, he met with more than 50 leading Democratic officials, fund-raisers and prominent New Yorkers at the Sheraton, including the former Manhattan Borough President, Percy E. Sutton, the developer Donald Trump and the State Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver.
 
'They've Got to Work With Us'
 On Wednesday, Mr. Giuliani said he had decided not to attend the Brooklyn College gathering, explaining that it did not "seem like the format for the most substantive discussion." He added, "It's really a format like 'Donahue' or 'Oprah.' " Mr. Giuliani had told reporters that he had a busy schedule and that he had conveyed to the White House that he had some free time in the late afternoon, if the President wanted to meet then.
One senior Giuliani official made it clear that the Mayor did not want to participate in a public event that the official said would be little more than a photo opportunity. "Rudy's a fighter for New York," said the official, who asked to remain anonymous. "We haven't seen a lot from Washington. They've got to work with us if they want us to cooperate."
The decision to meet in private, far from television cameras and reporters, came late Wednesday night, in a discussion between City Hall and the White House.
Mr. Clinton's appearance at Brooklyn College was interrupted by an unidentified man who walked into the aisle of the auditorium and began screaming at the President, saying he had not worked hard enough to develop treatments for AIDS. The President listened to the man and began chronicling his Administration's initiatives.
But the man continued screaming. "People are dying and you're doing nothing." Finally he was escorted out of the auditorium by security officers. The President continued speaking to the audience, seemingly unfazed by the event, when another man in the audience yelled to Mr. Clinton: "Welcome to Brooklyn."
