HEADLINE: Christopher Unlikely to Meet Dissidents

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 10

 BODY:
Despite wide anticipation among Chinese dissidents that Secretary of State Warren Christopher would meet with them during his three-day visit to Beijing, he said today that he had no plan at the moment to do so.
Mr. Christopher gave no reason for his decision, which he disclosed at a briefing after meeting with Japanese Government leaders today. Asked by a reporter whether he would meet with political dissidents during the visit, his first to China as Secretary of State, he replied, "I don't have any plans to do so at the present time." 
 There has been considerable speculation in China that Mr. Christopher may use what is shaping up as a high-stakes trip to hold a symbolically important meeting with Wei Jingsheng, China's most prominent dissident.
But the State Department spokesman, Michael McCurry, said that such a meeting is unlikely because Mr. Christopher does not want to divert attention from the main purpose of his trip, which is to impress upon the Chinese Government that it must improve its human rights record if the United States is to extend China's preferential trade status in June.
 
Putting Dissidents at Risk
 Mr. Christopher is also concerned that by holding such a meeting, he could put more dissidents at risk, Mr. McCurry added.
Asked whether dissidents who are viewed as potential candidates for a meeting with Mr. Christopher could find themselves at risk, Mr. McCurry said: "It's pretty clear that's what's happening. That's what Wei Jingsheng would conclude."
After John Shattuck, the Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, met with Mr. Wei last week, Mr. Wei was detained for 30 hours and interrogated.
Other senior officials traveling with Mr. Christopher said they had argued that such a meeting could be counterproductive because it could further antagonize the Chinese.
 
America Is a Crucial Market
 The World Bank estimates that preferential low tariffs affect 96 percent of China's exports to the United States. If China's preferential trade status were eliminated, its trade surplus with the United States, which was $18.2 billion last year and could reach $24 billion this year, would dramatically shrink, jeopardizing a cash flow that is crucial for China's expanding economy.
[In an expression of support for Mr. Christopher's difficult mission, 275 members of the House of Representatives signed a letter urging him to press for "substantial progress in human rights and full compliance with the President's executive order outlining conditions for renewal of most-favored-nation trade status."]
The Chinese have not demanded outright that Mr. Christopher refrain from meeting with dissidents, but have expressed their concern more subtly, the American officials said.
"They haven't made any threats; they have expressed a keen interest into what all of his meetings are," said one official. "They have said, 'We consider internal matters should not be part of the dialogue. How we enforce our laws shouldn't be part of the discussions.' "
China's leaders have rejected American pressure to ease political repression, arguing that it amounts to blatant interference in their internal affairs. But in mid-January, the Administration thought it was making some headway when President Jiang Zemin told a Congressional delegation that China was "going to make an effort" to meet American concerns about rights.
 
Planning Has Been Difficult
 Some of Mr. Christopher's senior aides have suggested that he consider canceling some of the meetings his delegation is planning or cut short his trip if it starts off badly.
Mr. McCurry indicated that planning with the Chinese had been so difficult that "they were still arguing about what type of car Christopher would drive in." He added that "some of the meetings are not coming together."
Mr. Christopher is also planning to spend part of Sunday on a sightseeing tour of the capital, but that could be canceled if he does not want to appear too friendly to his hosts.
Among the meetings that could be canceled or cut short are military talks that are to be conducted by Frank G. Wisner, the Under Secretary of Defense for Policy, senior Administration officials said. For now Mr. Wisner, who would be the highest-ranking Pentagon official to visit Beijing since before the 1989 crackdown against the democracy movement, intends to remain in China after Mr. Christopher leaves to discuss ways to upgrade the military relationship between the two countries.
Such links could include cooperative military efforts in peacekeeping, disaster relief and conversion of defense industries.
But Mr. Wisner's visit is also intended to open a channel for human rights discussions with the military establishment, another key constituency of the Chinese leadership, a senior State Department official said.
 
Lecturing Japanese Leaders
 Mr. Christopher spent much of his day in Tokyo lecturing Japanese leaders on the need for them to live up to the specific pledges they made last July to cut their trade surplus with Washington. But he did not engage in serious negotiating and made no headway in convincing the Japanese to take concrete action.
His visit to Beijing promises to be even more difficult because of the recent crackdown on dissidents in Beijing and Shanghai, which has left American policymakers baffled and disturbed.
Other Secretaries of State have learned the hard way that calling on the Chinese does not necessarily produce diplomatic victories.
During a farewell visit to Beijing in the summer of 1988, George P. Shultz was warmly told by Foreign Minister Qian Qichen, "The door of China is forever open to you." But the outgoing Secretary of State failed to convince his Chinese hosts to curb their sales of missiles to the Middle East.
In November 1991, the last time a Secretary of State visited China, James A. Baker 3d ended talks without progress toward easing China's suppression of rights and left the country with the misimpression that the Chinese would adhere to pledges not to export missile technology in violation of an international accord.

HEADLINE: Clinton Offers Plan on Merchant Ships

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
President Clinton today sent Congress a proposal for a 10-year, $1 billion program intended halt the decline of America's merchant fleet.
Administration officials said the money was needed to prevent the extinction of the merchant fleet, which has steadily declined in the last decade because of high labor costs, Government regulations and high taxes. 
 The money would come from increased cargo fees paid by shippers. The legislation would replace the current Federal subsidy program for privately owned vessels sailing under the United States flag. That program has cost the Government an estimated $2 billion over almost two decades.
"This legislation represents an important step forward to assuring America's future as a maritime nation," Mr. Clinton said in a statement. "A modern merchant United States-flag fleet, with skilled U.S. mariners, will provide not only jobs and economic benefits, but also an important sea-lift capability in times of national emergency."
The privately owned merchant fleet in the United States totaled 384 vessels last year, against 573 a decade earlier, according to the Federal Maritime Administration. Last year, Sea-Land Service and American President Lines, the two largest United States merchant fleets, requested Government permission to shift a total of 20 vessels to foreign registries so save operating costs. The requests are pending.
Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and a graduate of the United States Merchant Marine Academy in Kings Point, L.I., who went to sea as a young man, said: "America is perilously close to losing its domestic flag fleet." The nation's maritime unions belong to the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
 
Providing $100 Million a Year
 The legislation would increase cargo fees that all merchant vessels entering United States ports pay the Federal Government by an additional $100 million a year. The Government would use the money to provide $2 million to $2.5 million annually to about 52 merchant ships that could also be used to transport military supplies and equipment. The vessels would have to have crews composed entirely of United States citizens. In addition, ships built in the United would have to be less than 15 years old and foreign-built vessels would have be less than 5 years old.
Representative Gerry Studds, the Massachusetts Democrat who heads the Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries, today introduced the legislation in the House. Last November, the House approved a similar bill by a vote of 347 to 65.
Mr. Clinton's proposal is expected to supplant that legislation. The Senate has been awaiting the Administration's bill.
Mr. Studds called the legislation "a sea change in U.S. policy, and just in the nick of time." He said the legislation was needed to thwart "the absolutely unthinkable prospect of the last remaining superpower on earth without ships flying its flag."
Mr. Clinton's legislation was proposed as the current 20-year subsidy program for the merchant fleet was expiring. The Federal subsidies, which ranged from $250 million to $350 million a year, benefited 81 merchant ships. The current subsidy of $287 million a year declines until all subsidies end in 1997.
Last year Congress approved $50 million for loan guarantees to shipyards and a $30 million subsidy to improve shipbuilding technology.
 
'Simply Unthinkable'
 Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena said, "With the resurgence of U.S. export trade and risk of heightened global trade tensions, it is simply unthinkable that there would be no U.S. merchant marine to carry American cargo. Without a U.S. fleet we would become wholly dependent on other countries. In the fierce competition of the world marketplace, any country forced to rely solely on others to move its goods is vulnerable."
The legislation was hailed by the shipping industry. "It's a great first step," said Peter J. Finnerty, vice president for public affairs of Sea-Land Service, which has 42 United States flag ships, making up the nation's largest maritime fleet. Sea-Land, a subsidiary of the CSX Corporation, also has 43 ships that bear the flags of other nations.
The Administration approach has been opposed by shippers, who would have to pay the higher fees. Shipping fees would increase to 24 cents, from 9 cents, for a net registered ton on vessels entering the United States from a foreign port in the Western hemisphere and to 71 cents, from 27 cents, from other foreign ports. This fee would apply only to the first five times a vessel entered a United States port each year. Net registered tonnage is a ship's total cargo capacity, regardless of the cargo actually on board.
Senator John B. Breaux, the Louisiana Democrat who heads the Merchant Marine Subcommittee of the Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee, said he planned to hold hearings on the bill shortly after the Easter recess. The Senator called the bill "the first complete maritime reform proposal since the days of President Roosevelt.'

HEADLINE: Keep Vows, Christopher Tells Tokyo

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, March 11

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren Christopher accused Tokyo of failing to live up to its promises to President Clinton on opening markets. He reminded them that "great nations keep their commitments."
Mr. Christopher's uncharacteristically strong words, delivered at a tense meeting on Thursday with Japanese leaders, were followed today by further tough remarks prepared for delivery to a senior business group. 
 Both were part of a continuing effort by the Clinton Administration to step up diplomatic pressure on Japan at the same time it is warning of trade sanctions. They came at the first top-level contacts between the two nations since Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa's mission to Washington last month ended in an unprecedented impasse.
In the speech, prepared for delivery to the executive group, the Keizai Doyukai, Mr. Christopher struck at Japan's greatest fear: that the trade tensions could spill over into other aspects of the country's alliance with the United States.
"For the world's two largest economies, agreeing to disagree is not good enough," he said. "We must not allow a situation to persist that might eventually erode public and political support for our overall relationship."
While he praised Prime Minister Hosokawa as a reformer, he made it clear that he was losing patience with the explanations Japan has offered for its slow pace of change.
"We cannot let political deadlock, or bureaucratic inertia, or outdated thinking stand in the way," the Secretary said. And he cited cases in which American competition has aided Japanese consumers by driving down prices, citing price cutting now under way here in personal computers because of the entry of Compaq, Apple and Dell, among others.
It was far from clear, though, that Japanese executives in Mr. Christopher's audience regard that competition, which has greatly cut into some of their profits, as an experiment they are eager to replicate.
On Thursday, Japanese Government officials had appeared unmoved, saying only that by the end of this month they would signal the "direction" of a series of voluntary market openings. In Washington, Mr. Hosokawa held out a somewhat similar prospect, and now, with his coalition Government enmeshed in political insecurity and infighting, officials here say that they do not expect a more specific plan to be ready until the July meeting of the Group of Seven industrial nations.
A senior Japanese official said that Mr. Hosokawa, who had met with Mr. Christopher for an hour Thursday, "made no commitments" beyond expressing a desire to end the tension between the two countries soon.
Mr. Christopher's intense concentration on trade again underscored how dramatically his job has changed in the last year, to the point that a visit here from the Secretary of State has become almost indistinguishable from a visit by the Treasury Secretary or the United States trade representative.
While he spent some time discussing North Korea's nuclear weapons effort and prepared for a lengthy review of Japan's security needs, wherever Mr. Christopher went today, he reminded Japanese officials of their commitment to "significant decreases" in the trade surplus with the United States.
Mr. Clinton's decision last week to reinstate Super 301 provisions of the trade act, giving him the power to quickly impose sanctions against countries whose markets are closed, was never brought up, Japanese and American officials said.
"My presentation to the Japanese leaders today was straightforward and, I believe, candid," Mr. Christopher said a news conference Thursday night. "I said simply that great nations keep their commitments. In making the framework agreement last July, Japan and the United States made commitments. We agreed to cut our deficits and improve our competitiveness," he said, suggesting that the United States had already delivered on its pledges.
Areas of Special Concern
"No one would agree, I think, with the contention that Japan has met its commitments," Mr. Christopher pointedly added.
The accord he mentioned was signed in July by Mr. Clinton and Mr. Hosokawa's predecessor, Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa. It is intended to address areas in which the United States says it needs far greater access to Japanese markets, from public works contracts to autos.
But officials on the two sides got bogged down in a circular debate over how to define "numerical indicators" of progress, with the Japanese accusing the United States of trying to manage trade by insisting on specific results rather than letting market forces work. It was that dispute, among others, that led to the standoff between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Hosokawa, and little has changed since.
Mr. Christopher seemed eager to find a way to defuse the question of numerical targets, which he said had become "a fairly sterile discussion." He seemed to hint, though, that there was flexibility in the American demands, saying the two sides simply had to "find some way to achieve a set of programs that will produce some tangible results."
But he did not say what that would be. Nor was that expected: Winston Lord, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asia, said earlier this week that Mr. Christopher would not be in Tokyo "as a negotiator, because there is nothing to negotiate about."
Yet there have been some signs of modest progress. Over the last two weeks, the American Ambassador here, Walter F. Mondale, has opened a back channel of communication with Japan's most powerful politician, Ichiro Ozawa. Mr. Ozawa, who founded the Japan Renewal Party and serves as the governing coalition's chief strategist, is widely reported to be heading for Washington at the end of the month. It is unclear what message he might bring.
Mr. Christopher had considered using his trip to Asia to visit Vietnam, weeks after the United States lifted its economic embargo. He would have been the first Secretary of State to go there since the end of the Vietnam War. But in an illustration of diplomatic triage, he told reporters on Saturday that Washington had urgent business in Tokyo, and "it is a good time to be in Japan to underscore the President's desire to seek access to the Japanese market."
Despite all the tensions, Mr. Christopher's presence here was barely noted. Japanese television, accustomed to one after another American Cabinet member visiting to complain about trade, showed him only briefly, after reports on the latest scandal in Japan's construction industry and long lines forming to buy scarce bags of domestically produced rice.
Mr. Christopher acknowledged today that many of Japan's Asian neighbors, along with some in Europe, had denounced Washington's tactics in dealing with Japan, apparently fearful that these tactics might be used in dealings with other trade partners.
But he said he thought that governments would applaud the United States if the methods it is using prove successful. Defending the American approach in less colorful language than Mickey Kantor, the trade representative, used in Washington yesterday, Mr. Christopher said, "I think the rest of the trading world will be very relieved and pleased if the United States can take steps that will open the Japanese market."
Mr. Kantor had implied that European critics of the tough American policy toward Japan were dishonest and sanctimonious, and spoke of progress in opening the Japanese market to Motorola cellular phones. Today, a Motorola official, who was not identified by name, said his company and a Japanese concern, I.D.O., had reached a basic agreement that would expand Motorola's access to Japan's cellular-phone market and avert threatened sanctions.
Mr. Christopher, ever the pragmatist, said of America's critics, "I think whatever their position now, the rest of the world will applaud if we can achieve good results."

HEADLINE: Motorola Gaining Access to Japanese Market

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, March 11

 BODY:
Motorola Inc. and a Japanese company have reached a basic agreement that would expand Motorola's access to Japan's cellular telephone market, a Motorola executive said today, in a move that should avert threatened American sanctions against Japan.
The agreement would remove a serious dispute marring trade relations between the United States and Japan. But the cellular telephone issue is separate from a broader dispute over comprehensive trade talks that broke down last month. 
 "There is an agreement between I.D.O. and Motorola," the Motorola official said this morning, referring to the Japanese company.
"It's not signed, sealed and delivered," added the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. But he said a formal announcement of the agreement was expected later today or by Monday.
 
More Signs of a Deal
 Japanese Government officials also indicated that an announcement of an agreement appeared imminent.
Takenori Kanzaki, Japan's Minister of Posts and Telecommunications, said at a news conference this morning, "It's possible a formal agreement will be reached today." He said that if the two companies did reach an agreement, the governments of Japan and the United States would quickly reach their own accord and the threat of sanctions would be removed.
The agreement comes during the visit here of Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who sharply criticized Japan on Thursday and today for failing to honor its trade commitments. Some officials on both sides were scrambling to arrange an announcement of an agreement while Mr. Christopher was still here, so his visit would end on a more positive note.
The United States has accused Japan of violating a 1989 trade agreement that called for Motorola to receive access to the cellular telephone market in the heavily populated corridor of Tokyo to Nagoya.
Washington was planning to publish by next Thursday a list of Japanese products that could be subject to retaliatory tariffs. The threat of sanctions seems to have led to big concessions from the Japanese side.
The root of the dispute is that the Nippon Idou Tsushin Corporation, the company known as I.D.O., which provides cellular phone service in the Tokyo-Nagoya region, has not invested much in building base stations for a system using Motorola technology. Instead, it expanded a cellular system using technology developed by the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation.
Under the new agreement, I.D.O. will invest heavily to build 159 new base stations for the Motorola system over an 18-month period. That would give the Motorola system almost complete geographic coverage of the Tokyo-Nagoya region, making it much more attractive to potential customers.
I.D.O. will also transfer 1.5 megahertz of radio frequencies from the N.T.T.-based system to the Motorola system, meaning there will be more capacity to add channels for the Motorola system and less ability for the N.T.T. system to expand. After the agreement is put into effect, I.D.O. will devote 6.5 megahertz to each system.
 
 
 
The American U.S. Demand
 The United States Government and Motorola have also demanded that the Japanese Government somehow guarantee that the Japanese cellular company will fulfill its obligations under the agreement. Just how this will be done was still being worked out this morning, the Motorola official said. One Japanese official said there could be language to the effect that Japan "recognizes" the agreement between Motorola and I.D.O.
To finance its expansion of the Motorola system, I.D.O. is expected to get assistance from the Toyota Motor Corporation, a large shareholder. Other shareholders include Nissan Motor and the Tokyo Electric Power Corporation. There has also been talk that the Government-controlled Japan Development Bank would make low-interest loans to I.D.O.
The agreement could mean several hundred million dollars in extra sales for Motorola. But I.D.O. has been warning that if it has to build up more capacity for the Motorola system, which uses analog technology, it will be unable to spend as much on newer digital technology. That could hurt some companies, including the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which are trying to sell the digital cellular equipment here.
"If an agreement is made, certainly that will have a good impact on the overall environment," one Japanese trade official said.

HEADLINE: Rates Soar On Selloff In Treasuries

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities plunged yesterday, pushing up the yield on the 30-year bond to 6.95 percent, its highest level in more than nine months.
Long-term interest rates, which move in the opposite direction of bond prices, are now more than a percentage point above the 25-year low reached on Oct. 15 and nearly three-quarters of a point higher than in early February. For the Clinton Administration, which has based its hope for steady economic growth on the lift from low long-term interest rates, the selloff in the bond market must be raising concerns. 
 Some traders sought to explain yesterday's selling by pointing to the uncertainty generated by the investigation into the Whitewater land deal and the political unrest in South Africa, the world's largest gold producer, which pushed up gold prices sharply.
 
 
Fears of Inflation
 But it appears that fear of inflation and uncertainty about when the Federal Reserve may raise short-term interest rates again are still the main reasons for the collapse in the bond market, which began when the Fed raised its short-term interest rate target a quarter-point on Feb. 4.
 Although many market analysts argue that the rise in interest rates has already been more than enough to offset another increase by the Fed, traders and analysts are still uncertain whether the rise has reached its peak. Many economists also argue that fears of inflation are overblown, given the current economic data and the apparent determination of the Fed to resist price increases.
With no fresh data to support the bond market yesterday, investors looked for an excuse to change their investment strategy or sell. Traders said investors who were selling long-term securities turned around and bought short-term Treasury bills, which are less volatile and risky when the market outlook is unclear.
 
 
A Shift to Shorter Maturities
 In late trading, the price of the 30-year bond fell 1 1/2 points, to 917/32 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.95 percent, up from 6.83 percent on Wednesday and the highest since May 1993, when it was 6.98 percent. The rush by some investors to seek the shelter of the shorter maturities lifted the bill market. The three-month bill rate fell 3 basis points, to 3.48 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities Inc., said, "The fact remains that there is simply no demand for Treasuries with investors knowing that the Fed is going to hike interest rates soon."
He said traders and investors, by selling relentlessly last month, had pushed interest rates much higher than what could be justified by the economic outlook. He added that investors might be realizing that the inflation they were concerned about was not a problem for 1994, although it could be an issue in 1995 or beyond.
"We don't know yet if the economy will even be strong enough to produce inflation in those years," Mr. Fine said.
Joseph V. Battipaglia, managing director of Sterling Advisers, said investors were in a selling mood yesterday and were looking for any excuse to sell. But he argued that "everything in market said you should have been a buyer, not a seller."
Mr. Battipaglia said a reference to gold as a gauge of inflation expectations by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, in Congressional testimony last month had made gold a fashionable measure for investors. "And a spike in the price of gold like we had today might spook bond investors," Mr. Battipaglia said.
The gold contract for April delivery jumped $8.10, to $388.20 an ounce, in trading on the Commodity Exchange in New York yesterday.
 "The market is sending a clear message that the Fed has not done enough," Mr. Fine said.
"If the Fed moves quickly, I think the bonds can improve from where they are now. But if the Fed continues to drag its feet, any improvement will be limited because investors are waiting for further tightening by the Fed."
The faster the Fed moves, he said, the more the market will become convinced that the central bank is doing the right thing to stave off inflation in 1995, 1996 and beyond. "If it moves slowly, the Fed will have justified the market's concern that inflation is a problem," he said. The Fed moved at the right time in February, he said, but the increase was not big enough to calm the inflation fears of the bond market.
Some reports that should have helped the market yesterday included the weekly report on initial claims for unemployment benefits for the week that ended on Saturday. The number of Americans filing claims increased by 32,000, to 346,000. Today's report on retail sales for February may draw some attention, traders said, but it is next week's inflation numbers that are more important. The producer price and consumer price indexes for February will be released on Tuesday and Wednesday.
 
China Bonds
 Elsewhere in the debt markets, the Bank of China, a bank owned by the Government of China, received an enthusiastic reception yesterday for an issue of five-year bonds, but an issue of 20-year bonds, the longest yet issued by a Chinese agency, did not do as well.
The $400 million issue of five-year bonds was priced to yield 6.819 percent, or 98 basis points above comparable Treasury securities. The initial sale was completed, and the lead underwriters, Morgan Stanley & Company, allowed the bonds to be traded freely.
The $100 million issue of 20-year bonds, which was priced to yield 8.281 percent, or 135 basis points above comparable Treasury securities, was bid by Morgan Stanley at a 140 basis point spread, a lower price.
Jim Pelgrift, a bond syndicate manager for Morgan Stanley, said some of the 20-year bonds remained to be sold.
Although not formally guaranteed by the Government of China, the bonds were priced as if they were, reflecting the Government's support of the bank.

HEADLINE: Inquiry Faults Weicker On Auto-Emissions Pact

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, March 10

 BODY:
Lobbyists for a company seeking a $150 million state contract influenced the Governor's office, winning the company a second chance after a state commissioner had selected its competitor, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal said today.
Mr. Blumenthal, reporting on his inquiry into the hotly disputed selection of a contractor to operate Connecticut's auto-emissions testing program, said the result was "at the very least, an appearance of unfairness and partiality to the public and to the participants in the process." 
 Mr. Weicker's selection of the program's current operator, Envirotest Systems Corporation of Tucson, Ariz., as the preferred bidder for a new seven-and-half-year contract provoked a dispute in December when it became known that he had rejected the low bidder, a Connecticut company that was the choice of his Motor Vehicles Commissioner, Louis S. Goldberg, and of an evaluation committee Mr. Goldberg had formed to review the bids.
In defending his department's bidding process, Mr. Goldberg suggested to a legislative committee that the Governor's office had had improper contacts with Envirotest lobbyists. Two days later Mr. Weicker dismissed Mr. Goldberg, accusing him of being biased against Envirotest and of misrepresenting his evaluation committee's findings.
In his report today, the Attorney General said that nothing illegal or unethical had been found in the conduct of officials or lobbyists involved in the competition between Envirotest and the evaluation committee's choice for the contract, Environmental Systems Products, or ESP.
Under the state's lobbying law, which applies only to lobbyists trying to influence legislators, Mr. Blumenthal said, "ironically Envirotest's actions and the actions of its representatives did not constitute 'lobbying.' "
 
Based on Financial Strength
 In addition, he said, while Envirotest's lobbying won it a new hearing before the Governor and "set the agenda" for that hearing, it did not influence Mr. Weicker's ultimate choice, which was based on the bidders' financial strength.
But Mr. Blumenthal also concluded that Mr. Weicker made that choice based on inaccurate and incomplete financial data, and he recommended that the Governor reconsider his decision. He also said that Mr. Weicker's accusations against his commissioner had no merit.
The Attorney General praised Mr. Goldberg and the competitive bidding process he established for the testing contract, the largest ever awarded by a state agency. He recommended that the Legislature require a similar process for all large state contracts.
The report said, "The use of a competitive process where none was required by statute was in the best interests of Connecticut's residents, was a sound business practice and was an action which any 'smart shopper' would take."
 
Weicker Comments
 Mr. Weicker defended his actions today. "The Attorney General has concluded that lobbying had no effect on my decision as to an emissions test operator for our state," he said. "Additionally, he found no illegal or unethical conduct on the part of anyone in this administration."
He said he would review the financial data on the companies, as Mr. Blumenthal recommended, but that he would still base his decision on their financial strength. What was the point, he asked, of giving the contract to a company that didn't have the resources to carry it out?
"I cannot afford in tenuous economic times to have a $150 million contract go into weak fiscal hands," Mr. Weicker said. "Not only is it a $150 million contract, but if we don't perform under that contract, the state is subject to $300 million in fines."
The testing program is required in Connecticut and other states to comply with the Federal Clean Air Act.
 
Sees a Bias
 Mr. Weicker also defended his accusations against Mr. Goldberg, saying the commissioner had shown a bias against Envirotest.
"That came out loud and clear in all the discussions I had with the former commissioner," Mr. Weicker said. "I think I'm the best judge of when I can see bias, and that certainly was there, in addition to other remarks he had made to other persons."
Mr. Blumenthal, in a detailed report compiled from interviews with state officials and lobbyists and thousands of documents, suggested that the dispute resulted partly from the circumstances and strategies of Envirotest, an established company, and ESP, a company that had developed new testing technology but was looking for its first big contract.
ESP, wanting to cooperate with Mr. Goldberg's desire for a strictly competitive bidding process, made a decision not to lobby in its own behalf, his report stated. But Envirotest, in danger of losing its contract, decided to lobby heavily, using representatives from the Rev. Jesse Jackson to the head of United Technologies Corporation to the State Treasurer to make its points that it had experience, that it was financially strong, and that it was a minority-owned company.
When Envirotest succeeded in narrowing the competition to the question of financial strength, the report said, the data provided Mr. Weicker by his staff overstated what appeared to be ESP's weaknesses, such as a small amount of cash on hand. Many of those weaknesses, the report said, were simply the characteristics of a start-up company, which would become negligible once ESP had the revenue from the state contract.
Today Mr. Weicker said that he rejected that view of ESP's finances.

HEADLINE: From Coast to Coast, From Affluent to Poor, Poll Shows Anxiety Over Jobs

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. KAGAY 

 BODY:
While Americans perceive that the economy has improved in recent months, their sense of insecurity about their own jobs is substantial and pervasive, with anxiety spread across all geographic regions and through all occupational levels, according to the latest New York Times Poll.
Two-fifths (39 percent) of workers interviewed in the nationwide poll expressed "worry," either a lot or some, that during the next two years they might be laid off, required to work reduced hours or forced to take pay cuts. 
 In the Northeast, 45 percent expressed such concerns, compared with 38 percent in the Midwest, 38 percent in the South and 31 percent in the West.
Forty-eight percent of blue-collar workers said they were nervous about layoffs, reduced hours or wage cuts, and so were 36 percent of those in professional or managerial occupations.
 
Anxiety at All Income Levels
 Forty-four percent of those with household incomes under $30,000 expressed worry, but higher-income respondents were only slightly less insecure. Thirty-six percent in households with income from $30,000 to $50,000 were concerned, as were 34 percent in households with incomes over $50,000. Forty percent of blacks were worried, as were 37 percent of whites.
The nationwide telephone poll was conducted Feb. 15 to 17. The job insecurity questions were asked of 692 adults who were in the work force and whose current or most recent work was for an employer, rather than being self-employed. For that group, the margin of sampling error was plus or minus four percentage points.
Many respondents had reasons to be anxious. A quarter of the work force (24 percent) said they had personally experienced layoffs, reduced hours or cuts in pay in the last two years.
Others observed the problems of people around them: 77 percent said they personally knew someone who had lost his or her job in the last couple of years. And 67 percent said loss of work -- layoffs, jobs moving away or jobs just disappearing -- was a substantial problem facing their communities in general.
When asked to characterize how secure they felt in their jobs, only 29 percent of workers said they felt "completely secure." An additional, 48 percent said "pretty secure," while 14 percent answered "not too secure" and 8 percent said "not secure at all."
 
Need for Extra Jobs
 The poll reflected other ways in which workers have been buffeted by changes in the economy. Nearly two-fifths (39 percent) said that "to try to stay even financially" during the last two years they had had to work overtime or take on extra jobs. Younger workers were especially likely to report this.
Many of these worried workers are trying to improve their job prospects. Two-thirds said they had got some retraining or taken other steps to improve their job skills in the last two years.
Many Americans may need those new skills. Asked to look toward the next 5 or 10 years, only 31 percent saw a "big future" in their line of work. Forty-nine percent said there was "some future," but 13 percent predicted "not much future" and 5 percent saw "no future at all."
Thirty percent said they "sometimes had serious regrets" about choosing the occupations they did, while 66 percent said they were satisfied with their decisions.
When asked to look further ahead, 69 percent said that if they had young children, they would recommend that they find a different line of work. Such a high figure probably reflects the natural wish of parents for a better life for their children as well as pessimism over their jobs.
The poll also revealed some fraying in the relations between employers and workers. Sixty-four percent said most employers show less loyalty to their workers now than in the past. Similarly, 55 percent said most working people today show less loyalty toward their employers than before.
The poll also found that 29 percent of workers received no fringe benefits, while an additional 19 percent received fringe benefits but judged them as only fair or poor.

HEADLINE: Girl, 4, Dies of Drug Dose; Father Is Charged in Death

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
Leah O'Doherty's father was a drug addict who kept methadone in the refrigerator in a Gatorade bottle, the police say. Somehow, Wednesday night, the 4-year-old girl consumed three times the dose of the drug that would have killed an adult, and yesterday morning she was dead.
Her father, Kevin O'Doherty, 26, has been charged with second-degree murder, though investigators have not determined whether the death was accidental or whether Leah was given the drug. Leah's mother, Kelli, 25 -- who the police said was also a drug addict -- has been charged with criminally negligent homicide. 
 The girl died six days after moving back in with her parents in Jackson Heights, Queens; before that she had been staying with her grandparents, the police said.
She was pronounced dead at 7:20 A.M. yesterday at the City Hospital Center at Elmhurst, not quite 12 hours after her father called 911 to report that his daughter was unconscious, said a police spokeswoman, Detective Kim Royster. The police said Mr. O'Doherty did not have a prescription for methadone, which is usually used by heroin addicts to suppress their desire and to allow them to function normally. But some addicts become dependent on the drug.
 
Child Found Unconscious
 Anita Munoz, a neighbor who sometimes saw Leah with her puppy, said the little girl "seemed like a very happy, normal 4-year-old."
"She was very pretty, with long honey-blonde hair," Mrs. Munoz said. "The last time I saw her she was carrying a doll."
It could not be learned yesterday whether the New York City Human Resources Administration had been involved in the child's case.
Neighbors in the building at 87-11 35th Avenue said the police were called to break up a fight in January, three weeks after the couple moved into the fifth-floor apartment. "I heard Kelli saying to Kevin, 'Please don't do it, please don't do it,' like she was begging," said Aurelio Bastidas. Mrs. Munoz said, "Four policemen had to throw him down to the floor."
Officers responding to Mr. O'Doherty's 911 call on Wednesday found Leah unconscious. "The methadone was in a Gatorade bottle in a liquid form," said Sgt. Timothy Dowd of the 115th Precinct Detective Squad. "Based on her blood analysis, the doctors determined that sometime during the night she had three times the lethal dose for an adult."
The investigation showed, Sergeant Dowd said, that Leah had been alone with her father; the mother was out with a friend. "We know the baby spoke to her maternal grandmother around 6 o'clock, about the grandmother coming over the next day," the sergeant said. "So, she was conscious then."
 
Came From North Carolina
 Besides the murder charge, Mr. O'Doherty was also charged with second-degree manslaughter. Second-degree murder can include death resulting from depraved indifference.
The O'Dohertys, Sergeant Dowd said, moved to Queens from Jacksonville, N.C., in 1991. They have been married for five years, he said, and both are unemployed.
"He's not in a methadone program," Sergeant Dowd said. "Sometime recently he purchased it on the street." Detective Royster said drug paraphernalia was found in the apartment. "The father is a methadone abuser and the mother is a heroin addict," she said.
Dr. Beny J. Primm, director of the nonprofit Addiction Research and Treatment Corporation, said the lethal dose of methadone varies according to the tolerance of the addict. An adult dose could range from 30 to 100 milligrams.
"A child would not normally take methadone for any reason," Dr. Primm said. "Even a single adult dose could be lethal if ingested by a child."
A 60-milligram dose of methadone bought on the street usually costs from $10 to $20, Dr. Primm said. About 40,000 people are in methadone programs in the state, he said. "Perhaps he was treating himself, and if our capacity for treatment was expanded, then unquestionably all of these people who are out there buying street methadone could be in a program and would know how to safeguard their medication," Dr. Primm said.

HEADLINE: Power Agency Is Undergoing An Overhaul

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
The new head of the New York Power Authority said yesterday that there was no point in his agency's continued existence if all it did was churn out electricity. And so, in his 10th day on the job, S. David Freeman began a major shakeup, both philosophically and practically, of the largest public power agency outside the Federal Government.
Mr. Freeman said the agency should be pioneering new technologies like the development of electricity from the wind and the sun and leading the nation toward the electrification of its transportation systems. 
 Dealing with the present, Mr. Freeman announced that within 90 days the authority would find cuts of $50 million in its operating budget of $487 million. He said he would cut staff at its nuclear plants despite their recent troubles and possibly close a major generating station in Queens.
Mr. Freeman, a former chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, also said he was deferring a 4 percent pay increase that the authority's board of directors had approved for the authority's 37 top officials. He said he would cut his own salary of $200,000 by 4 percent as well, "to bond with these guys."
 
New Personnel Head
 In addition he eliminated radio advertising and the authority's Washington office, and said the Albany office and the travel budget would be cut back sharply.
Turning to personnel matters, he promised that "we are going to get affirmative about our affirmative action program."
Mr. Freeman said he was embarrassed to learn that there were no blacks among the top 100 of the 3,400 employees of the authority. He announced that he had hired a new personnel director, Deborah Perry Estrin, and said that her addition "nearly doubles" the number of women in top positions.
A spokesman said that none of the actions announced yesterday required approval of the trustees, although Mr. Freeman was keeping them informed.
In unusually blunt talk, Mr. Freeman said that nuclear power was "inherently dangerous" and that the Indian Point plant, which is 35 miles north of midtown Manhattan on the Hudson River, could not be built under today's licensing standards. "I think anybody who is not afraid of nuclear power ought to go to Chernobyl," he said.
In the 1970's, at the T.V.A., Mr. Freeman ordered the cancellation of several nuclear plants under construction, but supervised the completion of others. Yesterday, describing himself as "the last nuclear agnostic," he said that he favored continued operation of Indian Point 3 and the authority's other reactor, James A. FitzPatrick, near Oswego, if it could be done safely and competitively.
"This company cannot run on the basis of losing money on every kilowatt hour and making it up on volume," he said. He also announced that John H. Garrity, resident manager at the plant, who was brought in last April to clean things up, was being replaced by Leslie M. Hill Jr.
 
Operating Plants Jointly
 Mr. Freeman said that perhaps the state's five nuclear-power plants, which are run by four different entities, should be jointly operated, and that perhaps they should compete against one another, with the least efficient being closed. Some power experts have suggested that on that basis the first to go would be Nine Mile Point 1, owned by Niagara Mohawk, in Oswego.
He said the Charles Poletti Power Project, an 825-megawatt generating station that uses oil and natural gas, was so old that it might be obsolete, and needed $20 million to $80 million to comply with the Clean Air Act standards in the coming years. Rebuilding it or mothballing it were both possibilities, he said.
Indian Point 3 and Poletti, then known as Astoria 6, were acquired by the authority from Con Edison for $612 million in 1974, when they were both still under construction.
Mr. Freeman has arrived at a moment of crisis for the authority. The short-term problem is that some of its plants produce power at a price that is too high to sell; Indian Point 3, in fact, has been shut down for more than a year by management problems, while the authority pays 1,000 workers at the site.
In the longer term, the authority needs a new mission; when it was established 53 years ago by Franklin D. Roosevelt it was supposed to help electrify rural areas and to provide competition for investor-owned utilities, and to stimulate economic development. But rural electrification is long complete and Mr. Freeman said yesterday that competition in the wholesale electric market was a fact of life with or without public power. Critics say the authority's economic development program is expensive and ineffectual.
 
Backer of Electric Cars
 Instead, Mr. Freeman said, the authority should concentrate on the environment and electrification of the transportation system.
"We have this terrible problem that everyone's gone to sleep on: we import most of our oil," he said. Unless the United States moves to electric cars, trucks, buses, trains and trolleys, he said, it will "continue to send young men and women to war in the Middle East, or run the risk of having recessions" when oil exports from that region are interrupted.
In his last job, as general manager of the Sacramento Municipal Utility District, Mr. Freeman was a major backer of electric cars and tried to incubate an electric vehicle manufacturing industry there; yesterday he said that he would do the same here.
He also said he would try to move the authority toward windmills and solar electric generation. "If you're just going to make kilowatt hours, and you don't care if it's clean or dirty, or if you back out foreign oil, who needs public power?" he said.

HEADLINE: Cement Prices Under Study

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
Several cement producers and two industry trade associations said today that they had received requests for information from the United States Justice Department as part of an investigation into possible price fixing.
The department's antitrust division is looking into pricing practices in the cement industry nationwide, said Gina Talamona, a Justice Department spokeswoman. She declined to be more specific. 
 The companies reporting that they had received inquiries were the Lafarge Corporation, Holnam Inc., the Medusa Corporation, Lone Star Industries, the Ash Grove Cement Company and Southdown Inc.
John Bermudez, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, said the inquiry arose from average price increases in 1993 of $5 a ton to a current level of $46 to $50 a ton. He said there had been basically no price increases for cement products for 12 years.
The analyst said the cement industry was experiencing a decline in manufacturing capacity and an increase in use to the point where American producers could not meet demand as the economy expanded.
The Portland Cement Association, of Skokie, Ill., also received a request for information on Feb. 28. The association represents 83 percent of the United States' manufacturing capacity. Bruce McIntosh, director of communications for the group, said the American Portland Cement Alliance, of Washington, had also received a request for information.

HEADLINE: Dow Falls 22.79 Points on Slump in Bonds

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
With no good news on inflation to slow or stop its descent, the stock market dropped sharply yesterday. The decline hurt many different kinds of stocks, from Wal-Mart Stores to Ford Motor to Walt Disney, in moderately heavy trading.
Stock traders fumbled for explanations: weak aluminum prices that affected stocks in leading indexes, strong gold prices that exacerbated inflation fears, even a Whitewater rumor that appeared intended to undermine President Clinton. 
 But it was clear that the declining bond market was the major force behind slumping stock prices, with bond yields, which move in the opposite direction from prices, again reaching levels not seen since last summer. The yield of the Treasury's long bond rose to 6.95 percent yesterday. The market for the 30-year bond has closed down in price for 16 of the 25 sessions since the Federal Reserve Board raised short-term interest rates a quarter-point on Feb. 4.
 
 
Anticipating a Rate Increase
 Some analysts speculated that another quarter-point rate increase by the Fed was already reflected in 30-year rates and that rates have thus stabilized, limiting the stock market's decline.
But Rao Chalasani, chief investment strategist for Kemper Securities Inc. in Chicago, said, "If the Fed raises rates more than a quarter- point, then the long bond's yield might even go down and thus help stocks."
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 22.79 points yesterday, to 3,830.62. The broader Standard & Poor's 500 index dropped 3.16 points, to 463.90. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index dropped 3.96 points, to 789.09.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index dropped 1.56 points, to 257.22. Volume was heavy on the Big Board, with 369.4 million shares traded. Declining stocks outnumbered advancing stocks, 1,486 to 688. The American Stock Exchange market value index declined 2.01 points, to 464.78.
Speculation about the Whitewater affair and the course of the special counsel's investigation circulated on trading floors yesterday as some White House aides testified before a grand jury. But most analysts said the speculation had little effect on stock and bond prices.
 
 
Sharp Rise in Gold
 The price of gold, which Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, described recently as an important barometer of inflation, surged yesterday, indicating a rise in inflation fears. It staged its biggest rise since September. Gold for April delivery rose $8.10, to $388.20 an ounce. Some traders cited the drop in bond prices as a reason for the gold rise, but also cited continuing violence in South Africa, whose large gold production might be disrupted.
Aluminum Company of America, one of the 30 stocks that make up the Dow, dropped 1 3/4, to 73 1/8. The world's largest aluminum producer, Alcoa has been a favorite of institutional investors betting that aluminum prices will soon rise following a world glut of the metal. But reports by the London Metal Exchange and others indicated that the glut continued.
International Paper, another Dow component, also fell after executives cautioned Wall Street analysts that their first-quarter earnings estimates were too high. Shares of International Paper fell 2, to 69 1/2.
The two stocks dragged down the Dow by 8.4 points, while 21 other stocks, including General Electric, Sears, Roebuck and Exxon contributed to the rest of the decline.
Intel fell 1 1/2, to 70 1/8, after a rival, Advanced Micro Devices, won a major court victory. A Federal jury cleared Advanced Micro of Intel's claim that Advanced Micro infringed valuable copyrights governing the software critical to Intel computer chips. The ruling will help Advanced Micro sell similar chips and may eventually hurt Intel's sales.
After the market closed, Northrop announced a competing bid for Grumman, the Long Island military contractor. Northrop is offering more than $2 billion, compared with the $1.9 billion offered by Martin Marietta earlier this week. Before the announcement, Northrop rose 5/8, to 41 1/4; Grumman rose 6 3/4, to 61 3/4, and Martin Marietta rose 1/2, to 46 1/2.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts a Broad Drop; Uncertainty on Rates Cited

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply against the German mark and other currencies yesterday amid mounting worries about the Clinton Administration's role in the Whitewater affair.
Adding to the pressures on the dollar was the growing view in the currency markets that the Federal Reserve was unlikely to act soon to push up interest rates further. 
 In late New York trading, the dollar tumbled to 1.6790 marks, from 1.7070 marks on Wednesday. It also fell to 105.30 Japanese yen from 105.80 yen.
The dollar first came under attack in Asian trading overnight, and it was besieged by selling throughout the New York trading session.
 It tumbled on rumors that a Washington-based economic consulting firm was circulating damaging information about the Whitewater real estate affair. The talk rippled through financial markets, pushing bond prices sharply lower and causing stocks to fall in sympathy.
 Win Thin, international economist at MCM Currencywatch, said the Whitewater rumors were not the underlying cause of the dollar's fall but they fed into overall negative sentiment.
 "The market has been very jittery," Mr. Thin said. "There's a lot of uncertainty and this adds to it."
 Much of the selling in Asia took place in reaction to the Federal Reserve's "beige book" report on the nation's economy, which was released Wednesday afternoon. The report described price pressures as mild, dampening recent speculation that the Fed would act soon to tighten monetary policy.
 That prompted selling by many hedge fund managers and other large investors, who had been holding dollars in expectation that higher American interest rates would attract more buyers to the currency.
 Those players have been frustrated with the dollar's inability to make strong gains, dealers said.
 "People had been buying dollars on the dips," said Hillel Waxman, vice president at Bank Leumi Trust Company of New York. "But now they are not bothering. The dollar doesn't seem to have any oomph."
 In New York, the British pound rose to $1.5035, from $1.4925 on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: St. John's Triumphs, But UConn Awaits

BYLINE: By WILLIAM N. WALLACE 

 BODY:
St. John's extended its troubled season by one more game last night. The Redmen defeated Pittsburgh, 80-72, in the Big East tournament, and their reward is a quarterfinal game today against Connecticut, the No. 2 team in the nation according to the polls.
For the first time since 1989, St. John's was playing in the Thursday night doubleheader that opens the tournament at Madison Square Garden, the one matching the seventh through 10th teams in the final standing. 
 In the second game, Seton Hall, the seventh-place team, defeated last- place Miami, 69-51. The Pirates will play second-place Syracuse tonight, and in other games Villanova will meet Providence and Boston College will take on Georgetown.
Pitt gave St. John's a fight, but Miami was feeble against Seton Hall. By halftime, Arturas Karnishovas had as many points for the Pirates, 16, as the entire Miami team. The Hurricanes, losing for the 17th consecutive time, trailed by 35-16 and extended their non-winning record in the Big East to 0-19 this season.
St. John's had finished ninth with a 5-13 record in the conference, and over all it is now 12-16 in its first losing season since 1962-63. The Redmen did a nice job against the eighth-place Panthers, who lost for the ninth time straight time and finished their season with a 13-14 record.
 
Farewell Game for Evans
 The Panthers' leading scorer, Jerry McCullough, did not play because of a hand injury, and it was a farewell for the coach, Paul Evans, whose contract was not extended.
Charles Minlend had another strong performance and was St. John's leading scorer, with 22 points, for the fourth consecutive game. Derek Brown had 16 points, a season high, and Maurice Brown had 10 as the Redmen broke a six-game losing streak, the longest for the school in 75 years.
Derek Brown said: "We didn't have anything to lose because we haven't had a good season. So we came out to just have fun. It's good to get another crack at UConn."
What about Connecticut, a team that trounced St. John's on Saturday in Hartford, 95-80, and beat the Redmen at the Garden on Jan. 15 by 85-81 with Donyell Marshall scoring 42 points for the Huskies?
St. John's Coach Brian Mahoney said: "With their fast break and their shooting ability we'll have our work cut out for us. The problem is we had to spend a lot of energy tonight, and 2 o'clock game time comes pretty quick. So I want to get us back to the hotel as quickly as I can."
Derek Brown added: "We can't rush against their pressure. We have to concentrate on a transition defense and try to limit Donyell to not so many points."
Evans did not think much of St. John's chances against the Huskies. "Anybody's in trouble against them," he said. "They're 20 deep and rank second in the country." For St. John's to win, Evans said, "It's got to be a a fluke, like when Ohio U. beat them. But I don't think those guys are going to bothered by the sun like they were in Hawaii."
The reference was to UConn's defeat, one of only three, to Ohio University in the Christmas vacation tournament on the island of Maui.
 
'They've Been a Problem for Us'
 Seton Hall Coach P. J. Carlesimo was pessimistic, too, about the Pirates' chances against Syracuse. "They've been a problem for us," he said. "The matchups don't work out well for us."
The Orangemen beat the Pirates, 78-74, at the Meadowlands on Jan. 22 and 91-69 at Syracuse on Feb. 23.
Karnishovas, Seton Hall's ace, concluded with 21 points against Miami in a sloppy contest, and Darrell Mims was next with 10. The Pirates (16-11) won easily in spite of shooting only 33.9 percent from the field. Miami (7-20) shot 38.6 percent, 26.3 in the first half, and thus ended a season of misery. "One I wouldn't wish on anybody," said the coach, Leonard Hamilton.
Earlier in the day, Marshall received the Big East player of the year award at a pre-tournament luncheon at the Grand Hyatt Hotel. He led the conference in scoring, averaging 25.7 points per game.
The award for Big East defensive player of the year also went to Marshall by vote of the coaches. "That surprised me," he said.
Only Patrick Ewing of Georgetown, in 1984 and 1985, had received both Big East awards.
The awards piled up for Connecticut. Jim Calhoun was voted Big East coach of the year and Doron Sheffer, the 21-year-old freshman from Israel, was named rookie of the year.
Karnishovas won the award that goes to the best player and student. Karnishovas, an honor student in global economics from Vilnius, Lithuania, graduates in June and hopes for an N.B.A. career.

HEADLINE: Review/Film;
A Bumbler Not Quite Making Ends Meet

 BODY:
"Raining Stones" was shown as part of the 1993 New York Film Festival. Here are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 2. The film opens today at Cinema Village, 22 East 12th Street, Greenwich Village.
Ken Loach, the English film maker, is on a new roll. 
 Like "Riff-Raff," a bitterly comic response to the policies of Britain's Tory Governments, "Raining Stones," his new film, focuses on working-class folk who have somehow failed to benefit from trickle-down economic theories. The setting is a medium-sized city in the north of England where Bob (Bruce Jones), a youngish, balding man who's no better than he should be, is trying to make ends meet in a depressed job market.
When first seen, Bob and his pal Tommy (Ricky Tomlinson) are in a foggy meadow at dawn trying to steal a large, uncooperative sheep. After they have finally caught and trussed the animal, but failed to screw their courage to the point where they might either stick or bash it to death, they deliver it to a friendly butcher. "You said lamb," scoffs the butcher. "This is mutton. You can't give mutton away."
So it goes for Bob through a series of alternately hilarious and melodramatic misadventures in the world of self-help. When he tries to make a little money by going door-to-door cleaning drains, the only person who accepts his services is his pastor, Father Barry (Tom Hickey), a Roman Catholic priest who assumes it's Bob's contribution to the church. Stealing sod from a golf course for a landscape gardener is not much more profitable. A job as a bouncer at a disco lasts one night.
Behind Bob's increasing desperation is the forthcoming first Communion of his daughter, Coleen (Gemma Phoenix). Although both Anne (Julie Brown), his wife, and Father Barry point out that clothes do not make the Communion, Bob remains obsessed with the idea that Coleen must have a new wardrobe costing in the neighborhood of 150 ($224). His is a pride made terrible by poverty.
With a fine screenplay by Jim Allen and the wizardly camera work of Barry Ackroyd, Mr. Loach again shows himself to be in top form. "Raining Stones" is brisk, richly characterized fiction that cuts as deeply and truly as any documentary. The movie slides effortlessly from farce to melodrama.
Mr. Jones, an actor new to me, is splendid in the central role. Though intense and funny, the performance is free of mannerisms. Bob behaves like someone being trailed by a hidden camera.
Mr. Loach is not a fashionable director at the minute. He's an anachronism in a time when even politically committed directors are expected to stand at a distance from their material, in this way to protect their cool. Mr. Loach doesn't worry about that. Yet because he has such command of craft, his films leap beyond politics, beyond genre, to a life in what might be called pure cinema.

TYPE: Review

HEADLINE: Mining Law Change Reduces Tax Revenue

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Gold in Our Hills" by Robert Redford (Op-Ed, Feb. 21) left a misinformed impression that mining has "savaged" the West and that Congressional efforts to rid mining from public lands would create jobs in a region where good jobs are few and far between. 
 Mining opponents, such as Mr. Redford, would actually cost Western states as many as 47,000 jobs and as much as $6.1 billion in lost economic activity, should they prevail in their attempts to place restrictive financial and regulatory constraints on one of the few industries that provide high-paying jobs in even the most remote sections of the West.
To say that the taxpayer "doesn't get a dime for the billions of dollars of minerals extracted" is to ignore the hundreds of millions of dollars mining companies pay in Federal, state and local production and income taxes. A recent study by the accounting organization of Coopers & Lybrand found that the House version of mining law reform legislation would actually cost the Federal Government $422 million annually in lost revenue. The Senate proposal, which has the support of the mining industry, would generate $53 million in Federal revenue annually.
Granted, mining law reformers are correct when they say their environmental cleanup programs would create jobs. But these jobs, by their very nature, would be temporary, pay slightly better than minimum wage and would in no way be able to replace the lost tax contributions that Western state governments, as well as the Federal Government, depend on from mining.
 
JOHN A. KNEBEL
 Pres., American Mining Congress
 Washington, March 1, 1994

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
West in Deal On Russian Oil Refinery

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
The Chevron Corporation and ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd. plan to announce an agreement today to license technology and help upgrade a major oil refinery in Russia.
Chevron would supply the Russians with the licensing and engineering support to build the first hydro-cracker facility using Western technology. ABB Asea Brown Boveri, based in Zurich, is one of the leading builders of refineries. The project, an upgrade of a refinery in Kirishi, about 70 miles southeast of St. Petersburg, is estimated to cost $500 million; the fees awarded to Chevron and Asea Brown Boveri were not disclosed. 
 Hydro-cracking, which converts heavy oil into fuels like diesel, jet fuel and high-octane gasoline, has long been used in the West. It is a highly efficient technology for refining oil.
Laurie Sachleben, a spokeswoman for Chevron, confirmed that the two companies would make an announcement in Russia today, but would not comment further.
 
Some Details Discussed
 Many of the final construction contracts still have to be negotiated, said a person with knowledge of the deal who requested anonymity. Some details of the venture were discussed by Percy Barnevik, the chief executive of ABB Asea Brown Boveri, at a news conference in Copenhagen.
What was left unclear was how the companies would be paid. A major problem for Western companies doing business in Russia is getting paid in currencies or commodities that can be converted or sold in the West.
Russia's oil industry forms the backbone of its exports and is the main way the country obtains Western currencies, which it needs to buy Western products and technology to rebuild its economy.
Russia's production of crude oil has been dropping and most of its refineries are considered backward by Western standards.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Russia Gets an Oil Loan
 WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The United States Export-Import Bank said today it would finance a $245 million loan to the Russian oil industry, its biggest loan to Russia and the first under a $2 billion program to promote oil and natural gas production.
The loan would be made to Permneft, a state-owned company in the district of Perm on the eastern slope of the Ural Mountains. The Export-Import Bank would guarantee the five-year loan from a private bank, which has not been chosen. The money would be used to buy equipment from United States suppliers.

 CORRECTION:
A headline in Business Day yesterday about a Russian oil refinery deal referred incorrectly in some editions to the participation of the Chevron Corporation and the Swiss company ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd. The two companies will be involved with the construction of the refinery; they are not making an investment in it.
In addition, an adjoining article from Redwood City, Calif., about the 3DO Company's game machines erroneously carried a headline from the oil refinery article in some editions. The article should have been headlined "3DO Adds to Builders of Its Games."

HEADLINE: Western Banks To Relieve 40% of Polish Debt

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WARSAW, March 11

 BODY:
After four years of negotiations, Western commercial banks agreed today to a reorganization of Poland's debt that will reduce what the country owes by more than 40 percent and is likely to enhance its economic prospects.
Poland is the fourth-largest debtor among the world's developing countries, ranking after the big Latin American nations that have reached similar debt-reduction agreements -- Brazil, Mexico and Argentina. 
 The Polish deal is the second reached with Western bankers since the collapse of Communism, and it formally ends four years of default by Poland. Last year, Bulgaria received a 50 percent reduction in its outstanding debt.
 
Will Take Time to Achieve
 Bankers and diplomats said it would probably be 1995 before the first positive effects of today's agreement are felt in the Polish economy. Final details of the agreement will not be worked out until September, and the particulars must still be sold to more than 450 banks with loans to Poland.
Whenever the agreement is completed, the Warsaw authorities will be in a position to borrow for big capital projects that are already being designed. These include the renovation of power plants to make them more efficient and the construction of better roads.
Poland's infrastructure is broken down, and this has hindered Western companies with plants here, making it hard for them to set up distribution systems for their products.
Western diplomats here predicted that the agreement would increase the creditor banks' interest in establishing themselves in Poland. Until now, the Polish central bank has declined to issue licenses to foreign banks, hoping to first improve the health of Poland's weak banks.
William Rhodes, vice chairman of Citibank in New York, called today's deal "a very positive event for Poland because it will cut the country's cost of doing international trade and allow it to access the international capital markets when it needs to." Citibank was a member of the negotiating committee.
 
Overdue, an Economist Says
 Tomasz Telma, an economist with Planecon in Washington, a research company that specializes in the economies of Eastern Europe, said: "It is high time this has happened. It will help to reduce the burden of bad debts and open the way for the privatization of Polish banks."
It remains to be seen whether the Polish agreement proves to be as important as those from Latin America over the last five years.
The Latin deals, begun in the Bush Administration under a debt strategy put forward by Secretary of the Treasury Nicholas F. Brady, set the precedent for the granting of debt relief. They proceeded on the realization that the big debtor countries could not afford to pay their obligations under existing terms, and held out the hope that debt relief would stimulate economic growth.
The agreements reached with the Latin Americans were intended to cut outstanding debt burdens by about 35 percent. They were also tied to market-opening moves in the countries, and have helped attract foreign investment.
The Polish deal, which was hammered out in Frankfurt and announced here by Prime Minister Waldemar Pawlak, was hailed by the Warsaw Government and by Western diplomats as a landmark for the Poles.
"This agreement now opens the way for servicing our debt and assures the growth of our economy," Mr. Pawlak said. "This is an event that will have a very important impact on our economic development."
Diplomats in Warsaw said that Poland appeared to have won a significant victory by achieving an overall debt reduction from the banks that appeared more favorable than those under the Brady plan.
According to rough calculations by these diplomats tonight, Poland won a net reduction of $5.9 billion, or about 45 percent. This reduces the total debt from about $13.2 billion to about $7.3 billion. The figures are not final, so the exact reduction is not yet known.
One reason the talks with Poland dragged on so long was the fear by the banks that a precedent set with Poland might force renegotiation of tens of billions of dollars of debts elsewhere.
 
Better Than Brady Deals
 A banker indirectly involved in the Polish negotiations and a veteran of the Latin American deals acknowledged that the overall reduction was larger for Poland. But he also noted that the two sets of deals were very different.
In the Polish deal, for instance, the Government is asking for a relatively small amount of new money as part of the package. The level of new loans, and thus the negotiating leverage for the bankers, was higher in the Latin American negotiations.
According to the World Bank, Poland's total debt, including that from banks and governments, was $48.5 billion at the end of 1992.
In 1991, the Paris Club of Western governments granted Poland a 50 percent reduction in the loans made by the governments, cutting its commitments to sovereign lenders to around $35 billion.
Brazil has a total debt of $121.1 billion. The Brazilians, who have both political and economic problems, are still trying to work out final details of their debt-reduction agreement with the bankers. Brazilian officials are scheduled to meet with the International Monetary Fund next week in an effort to get the endorsements needed.
Mexico owes $113.4 billion, and Argentina, $67.6 billion.
Poland's debt problems arose when its post-Communist Government in 1989 stopped making principal and interest payments on the short- , medium- and long-term loans that its Communist predecessors had taken on in the 1970's to provide housing and other needs for a consumer goods-deprived population.
The failure of Poland to pay back the billions lent by Western banks prevented it from tapping global financial markets for development loans and credits that would move it toward a market economy. Its pariah status on the financial markets had been considered a major inhibitor of its growth.
 
Choices for Banks
 Poland's chief negotiator at the talks, Krzysztof Krowacki, said he was particularly pleased that the banks had agreed to reduce both the total of loans that had to be paid back and the amount of unpaid interest owed. According to one banker, of the $13.2 billion in debt involved in the reductions, a little more than $8 billion consists of old loans and the rest is unpaid interest. Mr. Krowacki said Poland was the first country to win such a concession.
Under the terms of today's agreement -- reached in negotiations with a committee including the Dresdner Bank, Lloyds Bank, the Bank of Tokyo, the Bank of America, Barclays Bank and the Bank of Montreal -- Mr. Krowacki said Poland would pay less than $400 million each year for five years and then $500 million in the following years.
As in other debt-reduction agreements, this one gives banks a choice of how they want to cut Poland's debt obligations. One option cuts the principal owed by 47 percent but leaves the interest rate at market levels. The other leaves the principal owed unchanged but cuts the interest rate well below market levels. The effective debt reduction here is 42 percent.
Poland was one of three formerly Communist countries with heavy indebtedness to the London Club of banks. The others were Bulgaria and Russia, with the Bulgarians having had outstanding debts of $12.1 billion.
