HEADLINE: Job Security That Is Based On Skills, Not the Economy

SERIES: Staying Afloat: Work in the 90's -- Third of four articles.

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KANSAS City, Mo.

 BODY:
A year ago, Terri Welk, a 37-year-old airline worker with a new bachelor's degree in the emerging field of computer-based information systems, sent out a single resume. After an interview two weeks later, she landed a job paying close to $40,000 a year.
Behind these prosaic facts is an adventure story of one woman's escape from the trap doors and falling pillars of the economy of the 1990's. Mrs. Welk may not have struck gold, but she had seen disaster coming and stayed one step ahead. She is a winner in a world of work that for so many has become a world turned upside down.
 
A Night School Route
 Working as a telephone operations manager for Trans World Airlines here in the late 1980's, she watched as the airline began reducing its work force and reorganizing its reservations business. "I started wondering how secure my job really was," she said. 
 So she took classes at night and on Saturdays to earn her degree, and now she helps manage the telecommunications system of Twentieth Century Services, a rising company here that manages mutual funds.
There is no doubt that she made the right decision: since she left T.W.A., her former department has been moved to Atlanta.
Mrs. Welk survived the big-company purges of the last few years, in which the jobs of office clerks and assembly-line workers and middle managers were swallowed by automation and foreign competitors. In the new world of work, experts say, a skill that a worker can sell from employer to employer -- not a lifetime job with one employer -- is what confers security. Today, they say, you are less whom you work for than what you can do.
The experts say that for Americans to make themselves marketable and to stay employed they need computer literacy, a solid grounding in the three R's, apprenticeships for those who do not go on to college, and constant retraining to keep pace with rapidly changing technology and employers' needs.
But the experience of workers here and across the country shows that surviving the current job market also involves some luck. Skills that are in demand in some parts of the country go begging in others. For example, machinists, who are among the highest-skilled industrial workers, have been losing jobs at aerospace companies in Missouri, Connecticut and Southern California. But in Northern California, small and thriving companies in other industries have trouble finding enough machinists.
The value of some skills -- like aerospace engineering and aluminum welding -- has evaporated with cutbacks in the aerospace industry. And the value of other skills, like managing the hazardous wastes of closed military bases, has only recently become apparent.
Across the nation, factory jobs are still disappearing: There were 21 million such jobs, accounting for 23 percent of the work force in 1979, and only 18 million jobs today, accounting for 16 percent of the total. But skilled people like electricians and millwrights can still get factory jobs paying more than $20 an hour.
College graduates -- a quarter of all Americans -- earn 77 percent more than high school graduates, but they are not guaranteed stable employment. The growing emphasis on equipping workers with computers and encouraging them to manage themselves has squeezed out white-collar workers skilled in managing other people and paper flows.
"They were checkers checking the work of checkers," said Rick Lucas, head of the Kansas City office of Drake Beam Morin, which counsels laid-off executives on finding new jobs.
Mrs. Welk took the prescribed road to a fail-safe career by going back to school and acquiring new skills.
 
'A Noneducated Man'
 But the new job market also has room for people like Ron Coleman, 46, a heavy-equipment operator from Kansas City who has not set foot in a classroom since he was 15 years old. He runs a road-working crew that bores water and sewer lines under highways, work that has guaranteed him steady employment through recessions: $15 an hour, good benefits and, for each of the last three years, a $30,000 bonus.
"I'm a noneducated man," Mr. Coleman says. "But I can read dirt."
He and his wife, Linda, a registered nurse, made $90,000 last year, almost twice the national median for two-income families.
Mr. Coleman and Mrs. Welk are the buoyant survivors in today's world of work. Good breaks, like happening to be in a place that covets their skills, have helped a lot. But so has their initiative and grit.
 
<The Welks
Keeping Pace With Change
 One recent morning, Terri Welk was under a desk, pulling out the wires of a telephone, a fax machine and a credit card reader. She was helping to move a department of Twentieth Century Services to larger quarters on the sixth floor of the company's high-rise building in an affluent district south of downtown Kansas City.
"I'm learning about the nuts and bolts," she said. "I used to call, 'Why isn't this working?' My job now is to make it work." In this part of her job, she is like the old-fashioned telephone man.
Some of her day is spent scrolling through data on her computer, trouble-shooting the company's telephone circuits and its answering system, which directs thousands of customers each day to account managers. She programs the telephones and computers that make the company's telecommunications network run.
"Telecommunications is everywhere," she said. "In some capacity, I think I can find a job anywhere."
 
The Price of Automation
 She may be right. Many workers in telecommunications, however, are among the hardest hit in today's economy as automation replaces switchboard operators and telephone repair workers. Last year, 60,000 workers in the telecommunications field were laid off. But even automated telephone systems need workers -- people like Mrs. Welk, who have expertise in operating the technology that makes them run.
Mrs. Welk has worked hard to insure her survival. She first peered into the future of the job market in 1979, when she barely escaped a furlough from her first job as a clerk at T.W.A.'s administrative offices here and she was shifted to another clerical job. "I thought I should to go night school," said Mrs. Welk, who dropped out of college after her sophomore year to get married.
She noticed that T.W.A. was hiring more and more people with data-processing skills, so she took noncredit courses at a community college and was quickly promoted to positions installing software in the company's mainframe computers and managing its voice-mail system.
Then, four years ago, she sensed greater changes afoot as the troubled airline desperately looked for ways to consolidate its operations and save money.
 
A Greater Leap
 This time, she decided, the job market was changing so fast that she had to make a greater leap. With two years of college already completed, she began studying programming and other computer courses at Park College near here, getting up at 5 A.M. to study until she went to work at 8 A.M. Her effort paid off: she graduated summa cum laude three years later and walked into her job at Twentieth Century Services.
"This is the best thing that ever happened to me," she said. "I like doing this, and I think I'll like it for a long, long time."
Her husband, Cary Welk, 39, cannot say the same thing for his job on the assembly line at the Ford Motor Company plant here, where he has worked since 1977.
In these days of booming automobile sales, Mr. Welk is making a lot of money: $18.23 an hour for 40 hours, plus high overtime pay. Each hour on the line, Mr. Welk installs 50 Ford Tempo headliners -- the interior fabric on the roof, the visors and the bracket for the map light. "You can go almost into a trance," he said. "I can go to the Caribbean for 20 minutes."
But it's the uncertainty of the work, not the routine, that gets to him. Robots or lower-wage workers in Mexico, where Ford has a similar plant, could take his job some day. Laid-off, unskilled auto workers here can still find jobs, he said, but they pay only $6 or $7 an hour.
 
Living Well
 Still, he looks at the $1,000 a month he is earning now and at the travails his wife has been through, and says he is willing to run the risk that he and Ford will stay together. From a peak of 5,400 workers at the end of the 1970's, Ford cut back to about 3,000 during the last recession. With his lengthening seniority Mr. Welk has survived the cuts, and with sales surging again the company now has more than 4,000 workers.
The Welks, who have no children, live well in a $100,000, three-bedroom house that was built into the side of a hill on their three semirural acres at the north end of Kansas City. They heat their home with wood that Mr. Welk chops and splits.
On a trailer beside the garage is their 16-foot Hobie Cat boat, which they use most weekends on nearby Smithville Lake. For their 15th anniversary a year ago, they sailed the Virgin Islands for five days on a chartered boat. There is nothing, they say, that they really want except, perhaps, a bigger boat.
 
The Colemans
Hustling Early, Always Learning
 However unsettled the world of work has become, many blue-collar workers still thrive.
Ronald Coleman flunked algebra and dropped out of school in the ninth grade to work on the family farm in Iowa. His girlfriend, Linda Jacobs, got pregnant and dropped out a year later. Today, married 29 for years, the Colemans have the world on a string, sitting in their hot tub, roaring off to rallies with their reproduction 1924 Ford hot rod and their Harley-Davidson motorcycles.
Mr. Coleman is a pipe layer, an occupation much in demand, according to the Labor Department. Hefty and lushly bearded, he is the foreman of a construction crew that bores water and sewer lines under rural highways.
Over the years, he has taught himself to run backhoes, boring machines and bulldozers. He learned welding in his garage with the help of books and tips from his brother-in-law.
 
Trophies of the Good Life
 Most years, Mr. Coleman works 44 to 48 weeks, with time off in bad weather, which is no hardship for him. Besides his $15-an-hour base salary, he has gotten a $30,000 bonus at the end of each of the last three years. His employer, Morris and Company of Marion, Iowa, provides health insurance for him and his wife, even during layoffs, and an ample retirement fund.
His wife, a nurse for 12 years, earns $21 an hour at a local hospital working part time as much or as little as she wants. Their daughter, Lorri, now 29, was so impressed by her mother's success that she is now studying to be a nurse.
In their house, the Colemans display the trophies of their labors. Mounted on the walls of the living room are a wild turkey, a deer's head, a dolphin fish and a hammerhead shark. Mr. Coleman shot the deer and the turkey on his own private game preserve, 100 acres in northeastern Missouri, that he bought two years ago for $21,000.
For all their trophies, toys and comfortable income, the Colemans are fairly frugal. They do not drink, smoke or, aside from the $56,000 remaining on their mortgage, borrow. They live in a working-class subdivision on the northern fringe of Kansas City in a split-foyer house with three bedrooms and two baths.
His work involves driving pipe laterally under highways. With a backhoe, Mr. Coleman and his helpers scour out an oblong pit eight and a half feet deep. "You've got to figure the grade before you dig the pit," he said.
People go to school to learn this work. "You have to know how wide to make your pit to make it safe to work in," he said. "It's like welding. You can read all the books you want on welding. We've sent boys to school for welding. And they still can't do it."
Mr. Coleman started a new project near Des Moines, Iowa, last week after a seven-week winter break
"When I was a kid," Mr. Coleman said, "I learned how to work. I paid attention to what the man was doing. I just paid attention to my job. They found out I was a hustler, so you just move up the ladder."

HEADLINE: Lawmaker's Health Plan Caught in Crossfire

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
For 12 months, Representative Pete Stark took potshots at President Clinton's health plan. He said it was based on "a hope and a prayer and an untested theory." He likened it to a unicorn, "a beautiful animal in fairyland, but unseen on earth."
Now Mr. Stark, a California Democrat who is chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health, is struggling to win votes for his own proposal, which is much different from the President's. And he finds that Democrats and Republicans on his subcommittee are taking potshots at his bill, which would expand Medicare to cover millions of people who have no other source of health insurance. 
 Mr. Stark, who has mocked the Clinton plan and its chief architect, Ira C. Magaziner, has been trying to explain and defend his own plan in three days of subcommittee sessions this week.
It has not been easy.
 
Plan Is Attacked
 On the panel, as in Congress as a whole, any proposal to guarantee universal coverage and control health costs faces a withering barrage of questions from the left, from the right and from unexpected places in between.
"Members are coming from every point of the compass," Mr. Stark observed today. "I do not have the answer to every question."
On the dais of his subcommittee, Mr. Stark is caught between two formidable critics: Nancy L. Johnson, Republican of Connecticut, on one side, and Jim McDermott, Democrat of Washington, on the other.
Mrs. Johnson is often described as a moderate Republican; she supports abortion rights. She has raised questions about Mr. Stark's bill with the persistence of a prosecutor interrogating a witness. She said the bill would disrupt the existing health care market, penalize "high-cost, high-wage states" like Connecticut and inconvenience employers who already offer health benefits to their employees.
"The private sector is reducing health costs at a far more rapid rate than the public sector," she said. But, she asserted, Mr. Stark's proposal would hinder the creative cost-control efforts of many companies and would enroll many of the uninsured in a public program that by her account has done a poor job of controlling costs.
Mr. Stark boasted that his proposal was "much simpler than the Clinton plan." But Mr. McDermott, with a wry, avuncular style, repeatedly pinpointed complex features of Mr. Stark's bill. And he said his own proposal for a "single payer" health program, like the one in Canada, would be much easier to understand and administer.
 
Concern About '2-Tier' System
 Mr. McDermott praised Mr. Stark for trying to find a compromise, but said the bill "institutionalizes a two-tier health care system," with a separate insurance pool for people who are poor or unemployed or cannot obtain private insurance. He said he feared that the proposed Part C of Medicare would be "a waste basket to catch all the problems and failures of the private health insurance system."
By contrast, he said, the single payer plan would create one program for all.
Michael O. Spivey, a lawyer who lobbies for the National Association of Public Hospitals, said Mr. Stark's proposal differed from other bills in that it could conceivably win approval from the subcommittee, the first panel to take up comprehensive health legislation this year.
Mr. Spivey described Mr. Stark's problem this way: "Some members of the subcommittee oppose any health insurance mandate on employers or individuals. Other members want a single payer Government-run system. How do you find a position that attracts support from both extremes?"
In an interview, Mr. Stark said his bill would slow the growth of health spending by authorizing "price controls that are more definitive and stricter than the President's."
Mr. Clinton would control health spending indirectly, by limiting increases in health insurance premiums. Under Mr. Stark's bill, the Government would establish "maximum payment rates" for doctors and hospitals if total private health spending exceeded national goals set by Federal law. The Government would, in effect, regulate private health spending with fee schedules like those devised for Medicare.
Mrs. Johnson asserted: "The Federal role in Mr. Stark's health care plan is far greater than the Federal role in the President's plan. The Government would have the power to impose a Federal fee schedule even on states that stayed within their budget caps."
 
Vow to Fight for Controls
 In response to such complaints, Mr. Stark said, "My bill could work without private-sector price controls." But he said the elimination of such controls from his bill would permit Medicare and other public programs to continue shifting costs to private employers and private insurers. Doctors and hospitals say they routinely increase charges to such private payers because the Government underpays them for treating people under Medicare and Medicaid.
Mr. Stark said he would fight to impose controls on private health spending. It would be "irresponsible, economically devastating, shortsighted and capricious" to delete such controls from the bill, he said. But he said he recognized that some Democrats and many Republicans opposed this part of his proposal.
Hillary Rodham Clinton met on Thursday with House Democrats and urged them to keep pushing health care legislation. Some Republicans have suggested that the inquiry into the Clintons' land deals may reduce Mrs. Clinton's effectiveness as an advocate for the legislation. But Mr. Stark said, "It certainly hasn't affected us here."
Mr. Stark, like Mrs. Clinton, would require employers to help buy health insurance for their employees. But Representative Sander M. Levin, Democrat of Michigan, said Mr. Stark's bill would impose more of a burden on small businesses, because it would not provide them with subsidies or limit their liability.
Mr. Stark said he saw no reason to try to appease small businesses because they would never accept an employer mandate. "That's like trying to feed dog biscuits to a pit bull," he said.

HEADLINE: House, With Little Passion, Passes Clinton Budget

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
After a debate that was genteel by its usual standard of oratorical combat, the House of Representatives voted along party lines today to approve a rough outline for future Federal budgets that is almost precisely what President Clinton was seeking.
It was an utter turnabout from the last major vote of 1993, not four months ago, when scores of House Democrats ignored Presidential pleas and very nearly hacked $90 billion more from Mr. Clinton's spending plans. And it signaled that the deficit-cutting lather that propelled budget politics in Mr. Clinton's first year in office is dead. 
 Representative Timothy J. Penny, the Minnesota Democrat who led efforts to cut Federal spending late last year, said the fervor had "dissipated, both within Congress and across the country." The rising Federal debt seems less menacing this year, he said, in part because low interest rates have kept it from rising as fast as most people had feared.
Today the House voted, 243 to 165, to approve its Federal budget resolution, a spending blueprint that roughly states how much the lawmakers expect major Government agencies to spend in each of the next five years.
 
Republican Plan Defeated
 The plan anticipates spending $1.54 trillion in the fiscal year 1995, which starts next Oct. 1, and a total of $8.5 trillion through the fiscal year 1999. In the fiscal year 1995, discretionary spending -- that is, the spending that is not consumed by mandated programs like Medicare and Social Security -- would total $541 billion, or about $3 billion less than Mr. Clinton requested.
The vote came after House Democrats swatted aside a series of alternative budgets, including a Republican package that would have cut the five-year budget by an extra $147 billion and a proposal by the Congressional Black Caucus to shift $125 billion in military spending to social programs.
The Republican measure, which took up most of today's debate, lost by a vote of 175 to 223. The Black Caucus package was swamped, 81 to 326.
The resolution that prevailed essentially continues into a second year the White House package of tax increases and spending cuts, spread over five years, that Congress narrowly approved last summer.
The resolution would actually reduce next year's discretionary spending by $2.8 billion from 1994 levels -- the first real decline in that budget in 26 years.
 
Debate Without Passion
 The Congressional Budget Office projected in January that that package would lower the annual budget deficit from $223 billion in 1993, when Mr. Clinton took office, to $166 billion in the fiscal year 1996. The annual deficit would rise again after that, reaching $204 billion by the fiscal year 1999, the budget office predicted.
The issue today, as in budget debates last year, was whether the deficit has been cut enough. But unlike last year, the answer was never in doubt, and the passion of those past legislative battles was absent.
The Republicans, led by Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, had come up with an alternative plan with an eye on this year's midterm elections.
The proposal would have cut Federal spending by $266 billion more through 1999, including $55 billion from Medicare and Medicaid, and billions from such areas as student financial aid and grants to cities and counties. But some $120 billion of those savings would have been offset by gifts to voters in the form of a $500-per-child tax credit, a more generous version of the tax-free Individual Retirement Account program and adjustments in the capital gains tax.
The reasoning was simple: "Over the next five years, the Government will have $9 trillion to spend," said Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip. "We think the country is healthier when Americans get to keep their own money."
 
Gift to the Rich Charged
 Democrats called the spending cuts merciless and the tax breaks a Republican gift to the rich. The tax credit for children, for example, would not be available to poor families that owed no taxes but would exist for households with incomes of up to $200,000.
House Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington called that "exceedingly strange."
"If that is the other side's idea of fairness to families, then I am perplexed," he said.
For all that, the vote today binds no one; it merely sets targets for the House Appropriations Committee to meet when its subcommittees begin assembling a more detailed budget later this year.

HEADLINE: Beach Project to Pump Sand and Money

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SEA BRIGHT, N.J., March 11

 BODY:
All those involved in the nation's most expensive beach restoration project, a long-delayed plan to rebuild beaches on New Jersey's severely eroded northern shoreline, refer to the endeavor in monumental terms. But that may be all they agree on.
Work on the initial phase of the enormous project begins this spring with the pumping of millions of cubic yards of sand to create 140-foot wide beaches at Monmouth Beach and Sea Bright. Then pumping operations will continue down the coast to Deal Lake just north of Asbury Park by 1998. 
 That first 12-mile installment alone is the biggest beach restoration project ever authorized by Congress and undertaken by the Army Corps of Engineers.
But it is the ambition of Congress, the Corps and New Jersey politicians to keep the sand pumping all the way down the coast to Seaside Park, altogether 33 miles of beach replenishing that Federal and state officials have likened to the digging of the Panama Canal.
 
Doubts on Costs and Benefits
 The plan has been trumpeted for its potential benefits to shore protection and to the state's $18 billion tourist economy.
But some environmentalists, academics and public advocacy groups question how much the public will benefit from a project expected to cost nearly $300 million in construction and engineering in this decade and conceivably $3 billion over the next half-century for all 33 miles.
The cost for the entire 50 years had been presented to the public as about $1.1 billion. But figures revealed this week by the Corps show that the cost will be $1.029 billion just to restore the first 12 miles of beaches, and keep them renourished as sand is swept away over five decades -- about $80 million a mile in long-term costs.
Long-term costs for 9 more miles of new beaches from Asbury Park to Manasquan Inlet, if financed by Congress and the state, are now estimated by the Corps to total $819 million, or $91 million a mile.
 
Protection or Hopeless Cause?
 "Our projections are that we will protect more capital than we spend on repairing beaches," said Bruce Bergmann, district planning director in the New York office of the Corps. "And there are also the untold environmental costs when the ocean breaches a barrier beach and flows directly into inland bays and rivers."
But D. W. Bennett, executive director of the American Littoral Society, a national coastal environmental group, counters that pumping sand on some vulnerable stretches of coast is like pouring tax dollars into the ocean. "The Atlantic is rising and ultimately will claim portions of the shoreline," he said. Indeed, the ocean has risen and shore sunk a total of one foot in the last century along the Atlantic seaboard, and geologists expect the trend to continue.
Mr. Bennett and others also ask whether supporters of the project have overstated how much the public will be able to use the beaches once they are restored. They especially question the first ones to be enlarged along the narrow strip in the Sea Bright-Monmouth Beach area, where most beaches in the past were the private playgrounds of clubs and summer cottage owners.
On paper, all the beachfront will be public. But in reality, the shortage or absence of public parking lots, toilets, drinking fountains, lifeguards and other amenities could keep the net gain in beach attendance to fewer than 1,500 a day along nearly five miles of brand-new beaches, critics say.
"Access at the Jersey Shore means parking," Mr. Bennett said. "If there's no place to park you don't have access."
Dignitaries tossed the first spadeful of sand in a ceremony on the beach near here last month. That spadeful is to be followed, beginning in May, by the pumping of millions of cubic yards of sand on the northern beaches. After that, pumping and grooming to a height of 12 feet near the seawall will move southward to rebuild beaches hurt by storms in Ocean County. The Federal Government is picking up 65 percent of the initial construction costs and the future replishment costs, and the state and localities will split the rest, said Bernard J. Moore, administrator of engineering and construction in the Department of Environmental Protection and Energy. Most of the state's initial construction share will come from Economic Recovery Act funds.
 
More Funds Every 2 Years
 While there is optimism that the construction phase can be finished in 10 to 15 years, new funds for each stage most be approved as work progresses. The Sea Bright-Monmouth Beach phase, scheduled to be completed by 1996, is already financed. The next stage reaches past Long Branch. Then comes the rest of the county shoreline to the Manasquan Inlet, including the resort towns of Deal, Asbury Park, Belmar and Spring Lake. Congress must reallocate funds every two years.
Should Congress or state officials for some reason balk at providing money for any later stage -- which Army Corps officials say is unlikely -- the beaches rebuilt to that point might be quickly eroded, said Gilbert Nersesian, the Corps' chief district coastal engineer.
Mr. Bergmann was skeptical about support for the project in Ocean County. He said beaches were less sand-starved there and private property owners may be less likely to agree to public-access provisions than their northern neighbors.
Congress has actually appropriated only the first $40.6 million, covering intial construction for two years; a $19.6 million contract has been awarded to Weeks Marine Inc. of Cranford for the first three miles.
 
$1.5 Billion to Replenish
 Thomas Harnedy, the Army Corps project manager, said Thursday that new estimates come to $1.029 billion for the stretch of rebuilt beach extending from Sea Bright to Ocean Township. That estimate includes $88 million for engineering and management, $124 million for actual construction and $817 million for replenishing over the next half century.
A second section, running 9 miles from Asbury Park to Manasquan Inlet, will cost $819 million, Mr. Harnedy estimated. The figure includes $756 million for replenishment over 50 years. No estimate has been made of costs for the contemplated final stage, 12 miles in Ocean County.
The restoration, initially approved by Congress in 1958, languished for decades, hampered by a lack of Federal financing and objections from private property owners and beach clubs. But as powerful recent storms made protection of the shoreline a state political priority, state financing fell into place and the public access questions became more muted.
 
Public, but No Parking
 Still, even some architects of the beach restoration project say that as a practical matter, the new beaches being planned for Sea Bright and Monmouth Beach, two old summer resorts on narrow oceanfront strips just below Sandy Hook, will have only limited public access.
Gateway National Recreation Area on Sandy Hook, just across a short bridge from Sea Bright, has more than six miles of public beaches and 5,000 parking spaces. It still cannot handle the crush of beachgoers on an appealing summer day. On summer weekends, all the parking is taken and park gates are closed by 11 A.M.
Monmouth Beach, with one mile of oceanfront, plans to install only 80 new public parking spaces one block from the beach, according to Mayor Louis P. Sadano. Mayor Charles Rooney Jr. of Sea Bright said the town would eventually add 400 new spaces for cars at its existing public beach near the south end of town.
According to the mayors, Sea Bright will double the size of its lifeguard-protected swimming beach to a 400-foot width and Monmouth Beach will expand to 1,000 feet. In nearly six miles of new beaches, lifeguards will patrol less than one-quarter mile of shoreline, and that is where the only public toilets and drinking fountains will be put.
Two miles of new beaches in Sea Bright will have access paths spaced 2,500 feet apart with virtually no place to park, no public facilities and no lifeguards. Another half-mile is occupied by private beach clubs that were given the right to keep nonmembers off the new sand.
Only 12 public parking spaces exist along the two miles. Local people own the shoulders on both sides of the two-lane road and post "No Standing or Parking" signs along its length.
"My constituents get mad at me," said Mr. Rooney, "but the truth is they want the new beaches but they also want their privacy."
Mr. Bergman said that limited parking and concerns about local traffic bottlenecks would be overcome in part by a state plan to have shuttle buses between "satellite parking" at Sandy Hook and the new beaches. But the state official most intimately involved with the project, Mr. Moore of the Department of Environmental Protection and Energy, said he knew of no plans to bus beachgoers after the Sea Bright part of the construction is completed.
 
No Protection for Public
 Nor did Mayor Sadano. "If the Feds bus bathers down to our beaches they'll have to send lifeguards along with them -- we won't be able to protect them," he said.
Mr. Moore disputed the estimate that 500 or so new parking spaces in Sea Bright and Monmouth Beach would bring in fewer than 1,500 additional beachgoers. People headed for the beach pack four or more to the car, he said, and cars could park on streets in Rumson and neighboring towns, within walking distance. He acknowledged, however, that the distances might be too much for people carrying equipment and babies.
The project's champions, however, say that the beach restorations will not only expand recreational opportunities, especially in oceanfront cities like Long Branch and Asbury Park, where there is little private beach ownership, but that it also will keep the encroaching sea from further damaging the Jersey Shore's multi-billion-dollar tourist industry.
"It's not just that we have beaches along these shores," Mr. Bergman said. "It's the density of population and infrastructure we now have living along this coast that needs protection that only a wide beach can provide," he said, referring to storms.
Edward Lloyd of the Environmental Law Clinic at Rutgers Law School, however, said that in high-hazard areas like Sea Bright, which has a year-round population of only 1,600, it might be less expensive in the long run for the public to buy private property and reroute traffic.
Dr. Stuart Farrell, a coastal engineer at Stockton State College and an authority on the New Jersey coastline, remarked: "The Army Corps can build a beach; there's no question about that. How long it stays there is another story. Some skeptics say six months, tops. My feeling is they will have to go back after three years and replace half of it."
Projected costs, however, are based on replenishment only once every six years, on average.
Mr. Nersesian, the Corps engineer, said the last few years were unusual for the number of winter storms slamming the coast. With calmer periods, repairs might be required only every 10 years or so, he said.
The plan in the Sea Bright area would put more sand beneath the water than on shore. The offshore slope is so steep that engineers must first rebuild a vast expanse of bottom, scraped clean of sediment, before beach-building can begin.
The worry is the new bottom will be unstable and shift in new storms, said Dr. Norman P. Psuty, associate director of the Institute of Marine Sciences at Rutgers University.
He also questioned why Sandy Hook, at the north end of the proposed project, and Island Beach State Park at the southern end, two of the largest public bathing beaches in the region, were not included in the plan, though both areas have suffered extensive beach erosion recently.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

International
 
Western commercial banks agreed to reduce Poland's debts of $13.2 billion by more than 40 percent, substantially enhancing the country's economic prospects. The debt-reduction deal appeared more favorable than those struck by the banks with Latin American countries during talks under the Brady plan. [Page 1.] 

Motorola and a Japanese company reached an agreement to expand Motorola's access to Japan's cellular telephone market, probably averting American sanctions against Japan. [35.]
 
Ukraine's new stock exchange is all dressed up with fancy computers. One problem: There is virtually no financial market yet. Only two stocks are traded for less than an hour a week. [35.]
The Economy
 
Consumer spending bounced back in February from January's freeze and the earthquake in California, reflecting greater confidence, more jobs and growing incomes. Retail sales rose 1.5 percent last month, the Commerce Department said, a gain that was bigger than most economists had expected. [35.]
 
Bank regulators "gagged and possibly coerced" subordinates who sought a criminal inquiry into the failed Arkansas savings and loan at the heart of the Whitewater affair, the top Republican on the House banking committee said. [8.]
 
Companies
 
No midsize military contractor is safe from a takeover, Wall Street analysts say, after Northrop announced a hostile takeover bid for Grumman. Speculation about a takeover boom in the military sector pushed up the stocks of several contractors. [35.]
 
Groupe Videotron and I.B.M. will develop technology for two-way home interactive television services in Quebec. [37.]
 
Viacom took control of Paramount Communications by acquiring more than half its stock for $6.6 billion in cash. Viacom beat out QVC Network in a bidding war for Paramount. [37.]
 
Southwestern Bell is renegotiating the financial terms of its $4.9 billion joint venture with Cox Enterprises, but officials at both companies said the deal was in no danger of collapsing. [37.]
 
Thomas W. Armstrong resigned as the top in-house lawyer for Advanced Micro Devices to "seek other professional opportunities." The move came a day after the company won a crucial copyright-infringement suit involving Intel. [37.]
 
An Oregon auto parts company offers employees bonuses for participating in a self-improvement program that includes reading books and watching videos. [37.]
 
Markets
 
Interest rates of Treasury securities fell sharply, reversing the previous day's surge. In New York, the price of the 30-year bond was 9128/32 , for a yield of 6.90 percent. [35.]
 
Stocks followed bonds again and rallied sharply. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 32.08 points, to 3,862.70. [36.]
 
Sugar and cocoa prices rose sharply as bullish fundamental supply factors pushed up prices for the "soft" commodities. [46.]
 
The dollar finished narrowly mixed against other leading currencies after recovering from an early dip against the German mark that followed a selloff on Thursday. [46.]
 
Your Money
 
Commodity stocks are making a comeback, in part because the companies that make materials like steel and paper and supply metals like copper, aluminum and nickel benefit from higher inflation because they can pass on price increases. [33.]
 
Americans should beware of the consequences, including penalties, of tapping their retirement savings plans early. [33.]
 
Conservative investors with a lot of cash should look at short-term Treasuries, which have an edge over bank deposit rates. [33.]
 
Private mortgage insurance can be a more expensive proposition than many home buyers realize. [34.]

HEADLINE: Stocks Rally Sharply, With the Dow Up 32.08

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Stocks followed bonds again yesterday and rallied sharply. Startled by and then drawn to bond interest rates that almost touched 7 percent, traders began buying bonds again, and stock traders followed by bidding up stocks.
Stocks sensitive to a resurgent economy and interest rates benefited, including United Technologies, Caterpillar, Procter & Gamble and Citicorp. 
 Any concerns about gold, the trade frictions between the United States and Japan or the Whitewater investigation involving President Clinton that may have roiled markets on Thursday receded in the mighty movements of billions of dollars of bonds being bought and sold in worldwide markets.
 
Rate Near 7%
 And stock prices deferred to what bond traders saw on their computer screens: a spike in the yield on the 30-year Government bond shortly after 11:30 A.M. that brought the benchmark interest rate to 6.996 percent. By the end of the day, the yield had settled at 6.9 percent.
"People weren't looking for the yield to go up that high that fast," said Donald W. Kimsey, senior technical analyst for equity trading at Smith Barney Shearson. "So, they said 'that looks good, I'll take that' and they bought. The bears went out to lunch and the bulls pushed prices higher for a couple of hours."
Traders had expected this week to be a volatile one, with few market-moving economic reports. But next week may be particularly volatile with the scheduled release of the Producer Price Index on Tuesday and the Consumer Price Index, the commonly accepted barometer of inflation, on Wednesday.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 32.08 points, to 3,862.70, yesterday and the broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 2.54 points, to 466.44. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 0.11 point, to 789.20.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 1.31 points, on moderate volume of 303.3 million shares. Advancing stocks outnumbered declining by 1,137 to 962. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 1.20 points, to 465.98.
For the week, the Dow Jones industrials moved ahead by 30.40 points.
Gold, a widely watched indicator of inflation sentiment, dropped significantly. Gold for April delivery dropped $2.10, to $386.10 an ounce, after a rise of $8.10 on Thursday.
The dollar dropped slightly against the yen in light trading, probably indicating little in terms of inflation sentiment or the market's concern about interest rates.
The Dow was lifted by 24 of 30 component stocks. Seven stocks rose by a point or more, led by United Technologies, which rose 2, to 69 3/4. Caterpillar, a favorite of institutional investors looking for economically sensitive stocks, rose 1 1/2, to 116 1/2.
Hanson P.L.C.'s American depository receipts were the most actively traded stock issue yesterday, at 25.8 million shares. Hanson rose 1/4, to 20 3/4.
Hanson, a British holding company for a variety of consumer and industrial products, often trades actively when it approaches its ex-dividend date, which is Monday. A current buyer of the issue will not receive a dividend until the next payment is declared.
The second- and third-most-active stocks were Advanced Micro Devices and Intel, respectively. Intel dropped 1 1/2, to 68 5/8, after its rival, Advanced Micro, won a big court victory against Intel on Thursday. Advanced Micro dropped 5/8, to 28 1/4, after rising 6 1/8, to 28 7/8, the day before. Typically, buyers sell stock after a fast rise in price to take profits.
In Tokyo, stocks rose slightly yesterday. The Nikkei average of 225 stocks rose 24.60 points, to 20,115.31.

HEADLINE: Consumer Spending In Rebound

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
Consumer spending bounced back in February from January's freeze and earthquake, reflecting greater confidence, more jobs and growing incomes.
Retail sales rose 1.5 percent last month, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. The gain was bigger than most economists expected and at first raised some fears of inflation among bond investors. 
 But the Government also reported that retail sales were much weaker in January than had been initially thought. They dropped 1.6 percent, not just five-tenths of 1 percent as reported a month ago.
 
Not 'Hog Wild Crazy'
 "It looks like spending is continuing to grow," said David Kelly, senior economist at Lehman Brothers Global Economics in Boston, "but consumers haven't gone hog wild crazy in the first quarter."
Though retail sales figures are volatile and are often revised by large amounts, forecasters and investors closely follow the Government's report on sales because it tracks one-third of all the spending in the economy and thus can be a good indicator of how fast the economy is growing.
The severe winter weather this year has hurt retailers. Construction came to a near standstill in January and was still spotty in February. That showed up in steep declines in stores that sell building materials and supplies. Sales fell 6.6 percent in January and an additional 2 percent in February.
Restaurants and bars also lost considerable business in January, with sales shrinking nearly 5 percent, but they regained 1 percent last month.
 
Auto Sales Increase
 But consumers bought more of just about everything else last month. Sales by auto dealers shot up 3.2 percent in February, confirming earlier reports from Detroit of buying that has been well ahead of last year's pace of 8.7 million cars and light trucks.
Sales of other retailers rose a solid 1 percent last month after falling nearly 2 percent in January. Department stores and clothing stores did especially well. Department store sales rose 1.4 percent, on top of a 1.2 percent jump in January. And sales in clothing stores rebounded 3 percent after falling 3.4 percent in January.
Cabin fever may have sent many formerly snowbound consumers to the shopping malls in February. But consumers are also continuing to feel better, and their uneasiness about job prospects is gradually fading. Although the University of Michigan's index of consumer confidence slipped in February to a reading of 93.2 from 94.3, it is still at the highest level since before the 1990-91 recession.
Indeed, consumer confidence plays an important role in spending decisions for big-ticket items like cars and appliances, and sales of these durable goods were up 2.1 percent in February after a 2.4 percent decline in January. All told, sales of durables goods were 16 percent higher than in February 1993.
Consumers are also in better financial shape. There are 1.8 million more jobs than a year ago. More important, incomes are up. Income after taxes and after adjusting for inflation is up 3.7 percent from last year, nearly as fast as consumer spending.
And the Mortgage Bankers Association reported yesterday that mortgage delinquencies fell to their lowest rate in 20 years. "It is not how much debt consumers have; it's how much easier it is to finance it at low interest rates," Mr. Kelly of Lehman Brothers said.
Higher interest rates -- a full point rise since last October -- could put a damper on spending increases this spring, economists said, if they hold down home buying, which goes hand in hand with purchases of appliances and furniture.
Most economists figure that consumer spending will rise at an annual rate of about 3 percent or 4 percent this winter and spring.

HEADLINE: Cold War's End May Give Life To a Shipyard

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
The Philadelphia Naval Shipyard, which is scheduled to close in 1995, may get an unusual reprieve: new work dismantling Russian warships.
Two Pennsylvania lawmakers, a Senate Intelligence Committee staff member and a senior Russian Foreign Ministry official worked out a proposal this week to keep the shipyard open for 10 years by converting much of the Russian fleet into scrap metal. 
 "This is a real win-win plan," said one lawmaker involved, Representative Curt Weldon, a Republican from Delaware County, outside Philadelphia. "What better way to dismantle the old Russian navy than with American workers?"
 
Hard Currency for Russia
 For Philadelphia, advocates of the proposal say, the plan would allow 1,000 to 3,000 workers to keep their jobs. It would give Russia a market to sell its scrap metal and raise badly needed hard currency to help retool its economy and build housing for thousands of soldiers leaving the Russian military.
It was unclear what effect a lawsuit pending before the United States Supreme Court might have on the proposal. Last week, Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania argued the case in an effort to force the Navy to stop the planned closing of the shipyard in September 1995.
Many details remain to be resolved, but the plan received favorable early reviews this week from Defense Secretary William J. Perry, as well the chairmen of two powerful House committees, Ronald V. Dellums of California and John P. Murtha of Pennsylvania.
Mr. Weldon said Mr. Perry told him he would discuss the matter with Defense Minister Pavel Grachev of Russia when the Secretary visits Moscow next week.
The Pentagon has signed contracts for nearly $800 million to help Russia and the other former Soviet republics eliminate their nuclear and chemical weapons. But this new venture seeks to help both sides derive an economic benefit from dismantling their conventional weapons. It also prevents potentially hostile nations from buying Moscow's sensitive military technology.
Russian officials have responded positively to the plan, which was reported today in The Philadelphia Inquirer. "This project is not only a political gain for both countries, but a social and economic one as well," said Boris Ivanov, Russia's First Secretary for Arms Control and Disarmament, a senior official in the Foreign Ministry.
Dismantling ships is a much different business than building them, and shipping officials consider it one of the most dangerous industrial occupations. Workers are often exposed to asbestos, toxic paint fumes and other hazardous materials. Taiwan and South Korea have been the world leaders in shipbreaking, as the process is called, but much of the work is moving to underdeveloped countries with even lower labor costs.
As part of the arrangement, Russia would be prepared to sell aircraft carriers, cruisers, submarines and several other vessels. Russia has already sold some older submarines and ships to South Korea and Japan for scrap.
American officials said today that the plan's success would hinge on developing a procedure that is environmentally sound and consistent with existing environment regulations, and putting together a profitable business plan.
Any plan would have to cover the costs of buying from 40 to 50 Russian ships, towing them to Philadelphia and scrapping them. Mr. Weldon said scrap steel was selling for from $147 a ton to $800, depending on the kind of metal. "No one will do this unless there's a profit involved," said a senior Senate staff member.
Proponents say a private consortium or the authority established to oversee the reuse of the shipyard after it closes as a United States Navy complex would run the venture. For start-up financing, proponents might seek to tap a $50 million economic conversion fund Congress created for the shipyard or funds from the Nunn-Lugar initiative earmarked to help the former Soviet republics dispose of their nuclear and chemical weapons.
The plan came together over the last few days during a visit by Mr. Ivanov to Washington to discuss with lawmakers arms control issues and the disposition of excess Russian ships and submarines.
Mr. Ivanov met with Gary Sojka, a senior member of the Senate Intelligence Committee staff, who told him the United States objected to Russia selling its sensitive military technology to potentially hostile third world nations. Mr. Ivanov said Russia needed to scrap more than 50 warships and 400 tanks to raise money to help rebuild its economy.
Mr. Weldon has proposed breaking up United States warships at the Philadelphia Naval Yard as a way to keep it open. Mr. Sojka said he remembered the proposal, contacted Mr. Weldon, and along with Mr. Specter, hammered out the proposal.
Mr. Weldon said he would lead a delegation of Philadelphia-area politicians and civic leaders to Moscow in the next few weeks to meet with Mr. Grachev to work out the details. In a letter he gave to Mr. Ivanov to deliver to the Russian Defense Minister, Mr. Weldon said, "It is clearly important to both sides that we nurture cooperative efforts on military conversion and elimination."

GRAPHIC: Photo: American and Russian officials have worked out a plan to keep the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard, which is scheduled to close in 1995, open for 10 years by converting much of the Russian fleet into scrap metal. Workers at the shipyard made repairs on an aircraft carrier last year. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
PRIVATE MANAGEMENT SEEN FOR HOSPITALS
Moving forward with plans to turn over several city hospitals to private management, the Giuliani administration has identified Queens Hospital Center, Elmhurst Hospital Center and Coney Island Hospital as the leading candidates, aides to the Mayor said. Page 1.
 
3D-RATE SERVICE FOR 1ST-CLASS MAIL
Although the United States Postal Service proclaims that nothing keeps its couriers from their appointed rounds, the Bronx has been plunged into a postal crisis in recent months with residents and officials reporting chronic delivery of mail to incorrect addresses and letters mailed to addresses within the city -- even within the Bronx -- taking weeks to arrive. Page 1.
 
PAYMENTS TO CONSULTANT FROZEN
The president of the Health and Hospitals Corporation has suspended payments to a politically well-connected consulting firm whose role in the rebuilding of Kings County Medical Center is being investigated by the city. Page 24.
 
GUN TRACKED IN SHOOTING OF STUDENTS
A drug dealer was arrested in the illegal sale of a handgun that found its way into the possession of Rashid Baz, who is charged in the fatal shooting on the Brooklyn Bridge last week. The authorities said the suspect, Albert Jeanniton, was the first link in a gun trafficking chain that led to Mr. Baz. But they added that they had no evidence that Mr. Jeanniton, 25, knew Mr. Baz or sold him the semiautomatic pistol, and so had no new clues on the motivations for the attack. Page 25.
 
CABBY DEMANDS A HEARING
Piotr Jaworski thinks of himself as a professional and the cab that he drives as his office. That is why he is fighting with the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission over the stereo system in his taxi. "They are telling me to take it out because it is not standard," said the Polish-born driver, who has been operating a cab here for 10 years. "But I did not grow up for 25 years under Communism so that I will just roll over and allow some inspector in New York to dictate how I am supposed to listen to music in my place of business." HEADLINE: Trenton Aide Says Economy Will Stay Flat for Next Year

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 11

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman will not be able to rely on a growing state economy to help close a $2.4 billion gap and to pay for the next installment of her promised income-tax cuts, the State Treasurer said today.
At a briefing on projected revenue for the 1995 fiscal year, Brian W. Clymer, the treasurer, said he had expected better economic news. Instead, he said, the state's economy will remain flat in the coming year, with revenues expected to fall slightly below the $14.8 billion the state expects to receive this year. 
 It is the first time in recent history that revenue projections have fallen from one fiscal year to the other and it complicates Governor Whitman's plan to both balance the budget and to keep on schedule with a promised 30 percent income-tax cut during her first three years in office.
 
'Watch and Wait and See'
 The Governor had hoped that an economic turnaround would mean added revenue from sales and corporate taxes and reduce the need for budget cuts.
But Mr. Clymer said today, "We do want to be conservative and not be overly rosy or optimistic about where this is taking us, so we're going to watch and wait and see."
Mr. Clymer said that based on analyses of current and historical economic trends and factors, revenue for the 1995 budget year, which begins July 1, was expected to be $14.79 billion. He said a corporate tax cut passed in 1993 and the 5 percent cut in the income-tax rate that Governor Whitman signed into law on Monday had flattened what otherwise would have been a slight increase in revenue over 1994.
 
A Political Problem
 While Mr. Clymer said the administration was being conservative, some of the information he provided today was as troubling politically as it was fiscally for the Whitman administration, and Democrats moved swiftly to try to gain political capital from the news.
"During the campaign, Governor Whitman said her three-year, 3-percent tax cut would yield over 400,000 new jobs," said Assemblyman Joseph J. Roberts Jr., the Democratic Minority Budget Officer. "In fact, these revenue projections suggest that the independent economists who criticized the Whitman tax-cut plan last fall were right when they predicted the tax cuts would produce, at best, 10 percent of the jobs that Whitman had promised."
Governor Whitman has said her budget will not cut aid to either municipalities or public schools, or force an increase in property taxes. She has said it will include some form of so-called "one-shot" revenue, a budget gimmick which she derided during the gubernatorial campaign last fall.
Gearing up for the anticipated partisan sparring over the budget, some legislative aides said today that they had been advised to start preparing campaigns pointing out that municipal and basic education aid was untouched.
Those same sources said the administration is considering cutting from education funding the so-called desegregation aid, a nebulous spending category that many school districts have tapped into to bolster their general fund.
 
Merger May Be Considered
 Governor Whitman is also said to be considering a merger of the State Department of Health with the Department of Human Services, a move that would likely lead to the elimination of hundreds of jobs.
The bulk of any tax cut that would be included in her spending plan would go to the middle class, those families earning between $30,000 and $80,000 a year, and would amount to as much as 10 percent, according to some legislative sources. Higher-income taxpayers might see another 5 percent tax cut.
But Governor Whitman, who is to deliver her first budget address on Tuesday, has kept details of her spending plan a closely guarded secret, relying on a tight-knit circle of Cabinet members and advisers that includes Mr. Clymer; the chief counsel, Peter G. Verniero; the acting director of the Office of Budget and Management, Brian Baxter; the chief of Policy and Planning, Jane M. Kenny; and several senior aides. So far, even the Legislative leadership has been kept in the cold on how the Governor intends to balance the budget as required by law, what cuts she might make and if or how big a tax cut she may offer.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mixed at the Close After Recovering vs. Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar finished narrowly mixed against other leading currencies yesterday, after recovering from an early dip against the German mark that followed a selloff Thursday.
Traders said technical factors and a rebound in the American bond market helped the dollar to rebound after it fell as low as 1.6735 marks. In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.6825 marks, up from 1.6820 marks on Thursday. 
 "Both the bond market and the U.S. dollar finally found support they could hang their hats on," said Randolph L. Donney, an analyst at Pegasus Econometric Group.
The firming of bond prices discouraged many investors from bailing out of Treasury securities and selling their dollar proceeds. Such sales had been hurting the value of the currency.
Still, the dollar slipped to 104.95 Japanese yen from 105.30 yen.
Traders said the dollar picked up some support as investors closed out "short" positions before the weekend. Investors with short positions sell a borrowed currency, expecting to repurchase the currency when its price drops and pocket the difference.
But traders said that with investors wondering about another rise in American interest rates and possible fallout from the Whitewater affair, there was no sign the dollar would gain much in value.
"A lot of people are just sitting tight at the moment," said Paul Alley, an associate at the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan Ltd. in New York.
On Thursday, the dollar fell sharply as concerns about the Clinton Administration's political problems in the Whitewater affair spurred additional selling in a currency market already jittery about Federal Reserve policy.
Traders said the market yesterday shrugged off American retail sales figures for February. The unexpectedly strong 1.5 percent increase was offset by a downward revision in January's figures.
In other trading yesterday, gold prices fell after rising overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for April delivery fell $2.10, to $386.10 an ounce. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted spot gold at $385.20 an ounce, down $1.30.
The British pound was quoted in New York at $1.5005, down from $1.5035 on Thursday.
Other dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday rates, included: 1.4215 Swiss francs, up from 1.4155; 5.7243 French francs, down from 5.7315; 1,665 Italian lire, down from 1,666, and 1.3618 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3573.

HEADLINE: MORTGAGES;
Insurance on a Loan Can Be a Costly Item

BYLINE: By Nick Ravo 

 BODY:
AFTER falling out of favor with banks and borrowers in the 1980's, private mortgage insurance has more than tripled in the last three years, spurred by a surge of first-time home buyers.
Borrowers are often required to buy the insurance, which protects the lender in case of a default, if they make a mortgage down payment of less than 20 percent. But home buyers may not realize how much they are paying for the insurance. 
 "Generally, it is very expensive with interest rates approximating those of credit cards," said Paul S. Marshall, a professor at Widener University in Chester, Pa., and an authority in real estate finance.
Premiums depend on the size of the down payment and the length of the mortgage. Generally, the bigger the down payment, the smaller the premium. And premiums are usually lower for fixed-rate and 15-year mortgages than for adjustable-rate mortgages and 30-year loans.
The premium for a mortgage with 10 percent down might be 0.40 percent of the total loan in advance and 0.34 percent each subsequent year until the loan balance falls below 80 percent of the home's sale price.
Thus, someone who puts $10,000 down and borrows $90,000 for a $100,000 home will pay $360 in mortgage insurance initially, and $306 a year, or $25.50 a month, until the loan balance falls below $80,000.
Though the payments seem small, the accrued costs are not trivial, said Marc Eisenson of Elizaville, N.Y., who publishes The Banker's Secret Bulletin, a financial newsletter.
Even if a house's value appreciates 3 percent a year, someone who puts 10 percent down on a $100,000 home will pay $1,278 in mortgage insurance over three years before the mortgage balance falls below $80,000.
As Mr. Eisenson calculates, it is the equivalent of 12 percent interest on the $10,000 that the borrower lacked for a down payment. Here's how. The $1,278 is $426 a year for three years, or a 4.26 percent annual premium for the missing $10,000. Considering that the borrower is already paying an average 7.5 percent mortgage interest, the effective rate on that $10,000 is 12 percent until the equity in the home hits 20 percent. Moreover, mortgage insurance is not tax deductible, while mortgage interest is.
"If you are determined to buy and cannot come up with the full 20 percent, you have to realize that you are paying a very high price to the bank for essentially lending you part of the down payment," Mr. Eisenson said.
Mortgage insurance becomes more expensive, he added, if the home does not appreciate or if the lender requires payments until a home owner has accumulated 25 percent in equity.
Worse, lenders in most states are not required to notify borrowers that they can drop the insurance.
"In a lot of cases, the lenders have to be prompted by the borrowers to remove it," said Brian J. Moloney, a vice president at Consumer Loan Advocates, a nonprofit mortgage auditing firm in Lake Bluff, Ill. "Because removal isn't automatic, you have a lot of people who are carrying it and don't need it since they have enough equity built up."
If the house appreciates in value so that the insurance is no longer needed, the borrower will need to pay for an appraisal to cancel the policy.
 Aside from high costs, mortgage insurance adds a layer of bureaucracy to a lending process already clogged with middlemen and paperwork. Insurers, who are chosen by lenders, may reject a borrower's application after it has been approved by the lender. About 10 to 20 percent of these insurance applications are rejected, according to industry estimates.
"Unless you expect the value of the home to skyrocket, you would be better off waiting until you save up a down payment," Mr. Marshall said.

HEADLINE: Q & A

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane 

 BODY:

Stock Splits
 
Q. When a stock splits 2 for 1, does the share price automatically get cut in half?
LYNN AARON, Manhattan
 
A. Splits are usually announced by corporations after their stock has had a significant run-up in price, in the hope that a lower price will make it more attractive to investors. A 2-for-1 split halves the price of the stock, but doubles the number of shares you own. Frequently stocks rise on such an announcement, but most of the upward price movements from splits are not lasting. 
 "A reverse split would reduce the number of shares and increase the price per share," said John Markese, president of the American Association of Individual Investors. "If you held 500 shares of a $1-per-share stock, after the reverse split, you would have 100 shares of a $5 stock."
 
Annual Percentage Yield
 
Q. I've seen some banks advertise annual percentage yield? What does it mean?
MIKE BERMAN, Jamaica, Queens
 
A. Since last June, banks have been required by the Truth in Savings Act to standardize their deposit account terminology and use the annual percentage yield. This percentage reflects the total amount of interest paid on an account, based on the interest rate and frequency of compounding. Banks are also required to use this figure in advertising so that consumers can more readily compare returns.
"A.P.Y. is not the same as the interest rate," said Kate Barr, senior vice president of the Riverside Bank in Minneapolis. "Interest rate is the annual rate of interest paid on an account and does not reflect compounding."
 
Frozen 401(k) Funds
 
Q. At 70 1/2, how can I receive mandatory distribution from my 401(k) plan, since my funds are frozen because of an investment made by my former employer in a guaranteed investment contract with an insurance company that became insolvent?
HARRY THOMSON, Northport, L.I.
 
A. The Internal Revenue Code generally provides that retirement plans, including 401(k) plans, begin distributing annual benefits no later than April 1 following the year the employee becomes 70 1/2. The minimum distribution is based on the life expectancy of the employee or the combined life expectancy of an employee and a designated beneficiary, typically a spouse. If the distribution is less than the minimum, the participant is subject to a 50 percent excise tax on the difference.
Like yours, some plans that invested in guaranteed investment contracts, or G.I.C.'s, have been unable to make payments because the insurer is in delinquency proceedings.
"If the required payments cannot be made from the G.I.C., and if there are no other sources of funds in the participant's accounts in a plan to make the appropriate payment, the 50 percent excise tax would not apply," said Avery E. Neumark, a partner of Weber Lipshie, a New York accounting firm. "You should note that if and when payments are resumed, there are special makeup provisions."

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Europe Looks Good, but Can Be Volatile

BYLINE: By Carole Gould 

 BODY:
Funds that invest in European equities are mostly quite young. Only 10 of the 28 funds have been around for five years or more, probably because few people wanted to invest in a Europe mired in recession.
But the economic outlook has changed in the last couple of years. The average Europe stock fund gained 25.6 percent last year, compared with a 9.9 percent increase in the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index. 
 The strong performance last year came mainly from declining European interest rates, which still have room to fall. Because European markets tend to lag behind the United States market by about 18 months, the funds look more attractive to some than domestic stock funds, which have already had a good run, said Amy Arnott, an analyst with Morningstar Inc., the fund research company in Chicago.
Because of their narrow focus, the Europe funds are volatile. For example, prices fell in early March when the German central bank made a smaller cut in interest rates than had been anticipated. And a strengthening dollar could hurt funds that are not sufficiently hedged, Ms. Arnott said.

LENGTH: 1554 words

HEADLINE: Iconoclastic and Busy Director: An Innovator or a Provocateur?

BYLINE: By MEL GUSSOW 

 BODY:
As a director, Anne Bogart resolutely probes behind the words, searching for fabric and context. If the play is a classic, she says, she wants to rediscover its "original energy" and learn "what we can see in it as people in the 90's." Each time out, she asks herself, "Who needs to see this, and also who needs to perform it?" In her process, she pans her eye 360 degrees around a play or a playwright.
Ms. Bogart pays a price for her iconoclasm. She has often been involved in controversy, splitting audiences as well as critics. Depending on the point of view, she is either an innovator or a provocateur assaulting a text. 
 In one of her boldest accomplishments, "No Plays No Poetry but Philosophical Reflections Practical Instructions Provocative Prescriptions Opinions and Pointers From a Noted Critic and Playwright," she staged the theories and criticisms of Bertolt Brecht, turning them into a playful, walk-through environment of ideas. The Bogart brand of direction has also given a visceral life to new plays like "In the Eye of the Hurricane," an Eduardo Machado exploration of a Cuban family's reaction to radical political change (presented several seasons ago at the Actors Theater of Louisville in Kentucky).
 
Trilogy Via Collaboration
 This season Ms. Bogart has been a whirlwind of activity, moving from play to play in New York and in regional theater. It is a prolific outpouring from a director who less than four years ago found herself out of work when her brief leadership of the Trinity Repertory in Providence, R.I., came to a sudden end.
The current centerpiece of her directing is a trilogy of plays based on American entertainment of the early part of this century. Drawing upon her interest in popular culture and such influences as Martha Graham and Giorgio Strehler, she has created "American Vaudeville," "Marathon Dancing" and "The Birth of a Nation" (about silent-movie acting). "Marathon Dancing," the first of the plays to be staged in New York, will open tomorrow at the Masonic Hall, 71 West 23d Street, Chelsea, under the aegis of En Garde Arts.
The trilogy, Ms. Bogart said, is an attempt to set the American oral and visual tradition against the European literary tradition. Each work comes out of a collaboration with theater artists; in the case of "Marathon Dancing," with Laura Harrington as writer and Christopher Drobny as music arranger.
For Gregory Boyd, the artistic director of the Alley Theater in Houston, which presented the premiere of "American Vaudeville," Ms. Bogart is at her best directing new plays or "inventing something new" like her trilogy, rather than when trying to reinvent a familiar play.
 
'A Very Angry Play'
 In her unconventional take on "The Women," by Clare Boothe Luce, this 1936 comedy leaped from pre-feminism to post-feminist commentary. "What I tried to do was not just treat it as a bitch fest," she said. She says she considers it "a very angry play" by an "exceedingly angry woman."
While Ms. Bogart is often acknowledged for her theatrical ideas, the execution can fall short of the concept. In his review in The New York Times on Jan. 13, David Richards said the production of "The Women" at Hartford Stage was "frequently surprising, occasionally illuminating and almost never funny." The director, he said, "has such an idiosyncratic vision of the script" that the author's contribution "seems altogether secondary."
This season in New York, Ms. Bogart also directed Regina Taylor's monodrama "Escape From Paradise" at the Circle Repertory Company and will soon take "The Medium" to the New York Theater Workshop.
She conceived and directed the play last summer at the Saratoga, N.Y., international theater institute she founded with Tadashi Suzuki. A collage of the theories of Marshall McLuhan "about how technology is changing our relationships," it is a kind of a companion piece to her "No Plays No Poetry."
That Brechtian collage was revived as the opening play in Ms. Bogart's single Trinity Repertory season. It was followed by a disembodied version of Gorky's "Summerfolk" (low on Gorky and even lacking in samovars) and a striking modernist variation on Brecht's "Baal" (directed by Robert Woodruff but bearing the Bogart stamp).
 
Equivalent of a Resignation
 The Providence experience proved to be part of her regretful past. Facing a severe financial crisis, the board asked for a 25 percent reduction in the budget. When Ms. Bogart refused to go along with the suggested cuts, the board accepted her decision as the equivalent of a resignation. John Howland, who was the chairman in 1990, insisted that it was economics, not art, that provoked the collision.
Richard Jenkins, a veteran company actor and director, was named to take Ms. Bogart's place. A search committee recently chose Oskar Eustis, associate artistic director at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles, as Mr. Jenkins's successor.
Ms. Bogart's departure from Trinity was especially painful because she had grown up in Rhode Island and was inspired to make theater her career by Adrian Hall's Kabuki-style "Macbeth," which she saw at Trinity as a teen-ager.
From the beginning, Ms. Bogart and Trinity may have been a mismatch, or at least untimely. It was her misfortune to succeed Mr. Hall, the founder of the company and its sole director for 25 years. When Russell Baker assumed his role as host of "Masterpiece Theater," he said he would have preferred to be the man who replaced the man who replaced Alistair Cooke. Ms. Bogart might have found less hostility if she had been similarly distanced from Mr. Hall.
In any case, she says she is reluctant to return to her native state. If she went back, she jokes, she would "be lynched."
In retrospect, she says that she learned under fire and she contends that if she were a man she would have had a second season to use what she had learned. She points to the dismissal of JoAnne Akalaitis at the New York Shakespeare Festival and, recently, Josephine Abady at the Cleveland Playhouse as examples of what she considers to be prejudgment of female artistic directors. "You send the girls in to clean house, and then you get rid of them," she said. When it is mentioned that other women, including Mary Robinson, Tanya Berezin and Lynne Meadow, continue to run major theaters, she responds, "God bless them."
 
Eight Stanleys, No Brandos
 Ms. Bogart made her reputation 10 years ago with a revisionist production of "South Pacific" at New York University, setting the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical in a clinic for emotionally disturbed war veterans. In this context, "There Is Nothin' Like a Dame" became a shellshocked battlefront song about male bonding. Naturally, the Hammerstein estate raised an objection.
On another occasion, she directed a production of "A Streetcar Named Desire" with 8 Stanleys and 12 Blanches, one of whom was a man. Even for Ms. Bogart, that "Streetcar" was extreme, but it helped her confront a crucial question: "If you do 'Streetcar,' do you pretend that Marlon Brando never played Stanley?"
Compared with many of her directorial peers, Ms. Bogart regards herself as a collaborator rather than as an auteur. As Mr. Boyd says, during Ms. Bogart's stay at the Alley Theater, she "galvanized the company, unlocking the actors as clowns and dancers" in a play that was about performing. P. J. Benjamin, who plays the emcee in "Marathon Dancing," adds, "In 22 years, I've never had such a freeing experience; she makes you feel safe to make a fool of yourself," and to bring in ideas, in his case a marionette that he may or may not use in performance. Describing her method, he says, "It's like living on stage."
 
Homework Assignments
 Working with her "everything is made into an event," says Paul Zimet, who played a leading role in "No Plays No Poetry." For the Brecht piece, he said, she would give the actors the equivalent of homework assignments, encouraging them to research and develop their roles, "to create your act and bring it in; then she would be critical and appreciative in helping you to shape it." Lyn Austin, who produced some of Ms. Bogart's earlier work, credits her with fearlessness in tackling risky projects. Such forceful characterizations of her directorial personality are jarring when matched with Ms. Bogart's offstage demeanor, which is both composed and self-critical.
Ms. Bogart doesn't begin a piece with preconceived ideas and images. "It's usually in the crisis of a rehearsal that things become clear," she says, adding that her principal concern is with "the relationship between choreography and psychology." What is seen often seems at odds with what is said. For a model, she points to the scene in "Cabaret" in which "a beautiful blond boy stands up and sings 'Tomorrow Belongs to Me.' " While the audience may be seduced by the beauty of the singer and the song, it understands the horrific political implications of the moment.
Even as she diversifies, she plans to continue to scrutinize plays from America's recent theatrical past. These are, she says, "memory capsules of who we are." Repeatedly, she asks herself how she can capture the original energy of a play, and concludes, "The more cultural baggage a play carries, the more I have to go through the back door."
