HEADLINE: Don't Sell Our Spy Technology

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's announcement Thursday that it will allow American companies to market spy satellite technology abroad points to a dangerous weak point in a generally sensible new export control policy.
In seeking to justify the sales, a Commerce Department official offered this glib and expansive explanation: "In order to have national security, you have to have vibrant and competitive industries that are allowed to do what they do best." Such as selling high technology that could end up targeting American troops or military installations? 
 This case is a sad exception to the otherwise sensible approach taken by the Administration in proposing a thorough revision of U.S. export control laws, the first since the cold war ended. If Congress approves the revision, Washington will have struck a balance between the desire of American manufacturers to relax U.S. restrictions and the need to keep militarily useful technology out of hostile hands. But selling high-resolution satellite imaging equipment, which previously could not be licensed for export, threatens to tip that fine balance.
Such sales will make it harder for the Administration to press other governments to adopt tough standards in order to curb the spread of arms -- a challenge made more difficult by the collapse of the common enemy.
The proposed new rules would require government approval to export items like supercomputers and composite materials; they exempt less advanced computers, machine tools, telecommunications equipment and satellite imaging services.
But the Administration went too far in liberalizing sales of satellite imaging technology itself, as well as of sophisticated machine tools and large-rocket technology, which are likely to be put to military use. And it missed a chance to require companies to disclose the sales now exempted from licensing, as well as the identity of ultimate buyers, enabling it to keep track of technology flows.
The U.S. cannot curb worldwide traffic in dangerous technologies on its own, so it needs to form what amounts to a cartel of like-minded states. Otherwise U.S. restraints will erode under pressure from American manufacturers who find themselves at a competitive disadvantage.
An effective cartel is easiest to establish when there are only one or two supplier nations. A desk-top computer has many sellers; the Administration is right to ease restrictions on such products, where it is unlikely to get all other exporting nations to go along. In other cases like supercomputers and high-resolution satellite imaging, however, near-monopoly conditions prevail. Here the Administration needs to set tough export standards and persuade others to follow its lead.
Businesses have been quick -- too quick -- to criticize the restrictions that remain. They have gotten all they should get, and more.
The Administration has not just waived controls on many dual-use exports. It has also established new administrative procedures to expedite licensing decisions, which currently can take 120 days or more. Now, agencies that fail to provide timely objections will be deemed to concur with the Commerce Department, which generally favors exports. The agencies will have to agree on a decision within 90 days or refer the matter to the President. If they fail to meet the deadline, exporters will be allowed to proceed with the sale by default.
Those who complain that the export regulations unfairly discourage trade tend to exaggerate job losses. In 1992 just $24 billion in exports were subject to export controls. Licenses were denied for only a fraction of that, $790 million. In a $6 trillion economy, that does not add up to many jobs.
Still, this Administration, like others, may be tempted to waive restrictions for favored companies. And too often members of Congress engage in special pleading for constituents. There is a need for vigilance at both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue if the U.S. is not to lapse into laissez-faire licensing.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Recycling Has Shown Remarkable Success in Four Short Years

 BODY:
To the Editor:
We disagree with "Recycling Creates More Problems Than It Was Meant to Solve" (letter, March 2) by Mark D. Shantzis, chairman of Hi-Rise Recycling Systems. Recycling is one of several solid waste management solutions. And considering that mainstream recycling has been operating for only about four years, the results are remarkable. 
 Steel cans -- whether empty food, beverage, aerosol or paint cans -- are being recycled at increasing rates across the country. This is due in part to the broad markets for recycled steel cans, used to make a variety of new steel products, and to the country's growing number of efficient recycling programs.
To address several points that Mr. Shantzis makes:
* I don't see where cans, steel or aluminum, are piling up anywhere in the country. Steel cans must be made from recycled steel, like all other steel products. One reason recycling is part of the process is that the industry uses resources efficiently.
* As for the conjecture that consumers have not been encouraged to buy recycled materials, I can tell you as a member of the National Recycling Coalition's Buy Recycled Business Alliance, that efforts have been under way for some time to encourage consumers, businesses and public sector representatives to buy products made with recycled materials. In cases such as steel, the purchaser is always buying recycled.
* As for batch collection of recyclables, communities must design and implement recycling programs to meet their needs, whether mingled, or curb-separated, collection or drop-off collection. Curbside collection with separation at material recycling facilities is an efficient operation, as shown in cities across the country. Steel cans can be magnetically separated from other recyclables.
There is an economic value to diverting materials from municipal solid waste, as well as to using recycled materials as resources for new products. Communities implement programs as they can, and yes, Mr. Shantzis is correct, most are implemented with single-family residences first. But then multifamily dwellings, institutional and office programs may also be implemented.
Such inventions as Mr. Shantzis's computerized system for separating trash in high-rise buildings may help make recycling more efficient. But Mr. Shantzis's attitude could cripple programs that might spawn additional recycling breakthroughs.
It can't happen overnight. Whether it is enhanced collection systems, new material made from old or the steady drum beat of materials like steel being recycled over and over, we must cooperate to forge the way in recycling.
 
WILLIAM M. HEENAN JR.
President, Steel Recycling Inst.
Pittsburgh, March 7, 1994

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES;
Bank Deposits Lack the Luster of Short-Term Treasury Securities

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:
Although banks have raised mortgage rates sharply in recent weeks, the interest rates they pay consumers on deposits have barely moved. For conservative investors with a pot of cash, that means short-term Treasuries now have a substantial edge.
 The annual yield on three-month Treasury bills has soared almost three-tenths of a percentage point, to 3.48 percent, since the Federal Reserve nudged up rates on Feb. 4. Meanwhile, the average annual percentage yield on bank certificates of deposit has inched up six-hundredths of a percentage point, to 2.61 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, North Palm Beach, Fla. A year ago, the returns on these two short-term investments were much closer: 2.95 percent for the T-bill and 2.76 percent for the C.D. 
The gap is unusually wide," said Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist for Chemical Bank. "Banks are not scrambling for consumer deposits right now because loan demand is relatively weak."
 The banks' delayed response is just part of the story. The Treasury market has factored in more than the Fed's quarter-point rise last month in the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans. "There are normally long lags before the rates banks pay on C.D.'s catch up with short-term interest rates," Allen Sinai, chief economist of Lehman Brothers, said. "But now the markets are anticipating more tightening and at least one more increase by the Federal Reserve."
 For the person who wants to invest $10,000, the smallest denomination of a T-bill, Treasuries are certainly the more attractive choice. Treasury securities of other sizes and types are also available at favorable spreads to bank deposits. The yield on a six-month T-bill is 3.76 percent, compared with 2.85 percent for a six-month C.D.; the yield on a one-year T-bill is 4.26 percent, compared with 3.16 percent for a one-year C.D.
 Treasury securities can be purchased at no charge in person or by mail at one of the 37 Federal Reserve banks or branches. Purchases through brokerage firms and banks typically incur a fee of about $50.
 Depending on the Fed's actions, it could take months for the gap to narrow. "Don't hold your breath until C.D. rates take off like a rocket again," warned Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor.

HEADLINE: What if you had a stock exchange and nobody came?

BYLINE: By JILL BARSHAY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine, March 8

 BODY:
For the last two and a half years, Ukraine's market has been dressing up in high-grade new technology. A million dollars' worth of gleaming I.B.M. computers line the rows of the exchange's trading hall, where, in theory, shares can be electronically traded within seconds by modem from any remote village.
An investment of more than $5 million, most of it from France, has transformed a building that once housed a school for Communist Party officials into what might be a cutting-edge bourse, where the technology would be familiar in New York, London or Tokyo. 
 There is a problem, though: so far, there is virtually no financial market. Only two stocks, a shipping company and a bank, are traded on the computerized system for less than an hour each week. Ten or so other stocks trade by hand elsewhere in the building.
 
Narrow Choices Are Widening
 Meager volume is hardly unknown in the fledgling stock markets of Eastern Europe. The stock exchange in Hungary reopened in 1990, 42 years after the Communists closed it, with one listed company, a travel agency. By the end of 1993, there were at least 25 listed shares in Hungary, though a year before that, Budapest was still difficult terrain for stock markets.
A lively exchange in Poland trades in fewer than two dozen stocks. Russia's 57 exchanges now offer more than 1,000 stocks.
Ukraine seems to have deeper problems, which are reflected in its stock market. While Russia's state companies are privatizing at the rate of 900 a month, creating new securities, Ukraine has yet to begin selling its state companies in earnest. The two companies listed on its electronic exchange were privatized by special presidential decree.
Beyond that, start-up private companies in Ukraine are reluctant to go public for fear of having to open their books, because succeeding in business sometimes means dodging or defying layers of rules and regulations left over from the time of the Communist Government.
When President Leonid M. Kravchuk came to see the computerized stock exchange last month, he described it as "a barometer of the national economy," producing an unwitting double-take. In fact, Ukraine is better known these days for its rampant inflation, perilously low currency reserves and unproductive, debt-ridden state factories.
"If we're a barometer of the economy, the Government has a problem," said Valentin V. Oskolsky, the Ukrainian stock exchange's chairman. "We're waiting only for privatization and nothing more."
New attempts to push privatization could yet invigorate the Ukrainian market. Parliament's latest program calls for selling 8,000 state enterprises -- 28 percent of the total -- by the end of this year. President Kravchuk renewed his promises of economic change when he was in Washington last week.
As part of a $30 million proposal by foreign aid donors to make privatization a reality, the United States Agency for International Development will lead an effort to print the privatization certificates for 52 million Ukrainians and establish bidding centers in each of the country's 24 regions, where people can deal in the certificates. But the Government will be under pressure to streamline the bureaucratic process to get a state enterprise ready for sale of shares.
The Ukrainian exchange was set up with a French Government donation of $4.3 million in software and technical assistance in 1991.
 
Disillusioned Frenchman
 "At the time, everybody thought that Ukraine would have a fast development to the market and be the most important country" in the former Soviet region, said Philippe Pegorier, France's commercial counselor here.
"We were very excited and we were betting on the future. But now we are disillusioned. No one thought things would go so badly here -- hyperinflation, no privatization. How is it possible for a stock exchange to work when there is no economic reform?"
Without privatization or other large-scale movement toward a market economy, the Ukrainian stock exchange waits for a trickle of state concerns, like the Ukrrichflot Shipping Company of Odessa, to be sold, one by one, by executive decree.
"It's just a game right now; the sums are so low it's funny," said Dmitri A. Sapunov, one of 40 traders using the electronic hall. "But it's good to practice techniques, to learn how the mechanism works."
 
Dressing for Success
 Mr. Sapunov -- who dresses like someone's idea of slick American stockbroker, in a green suit and flashy silk tie -- represents Comex Inc. Comex started as a small import-export company four years ago and has grown into a conglomerate of 19 concerns, including a brokerage house.
Like some other brokers, Mr. Sapunov is not happy with the electronic system. "There's not a permanent supply and demand," he said. "Often there's only buyers, so you can't count on being able to sell next time at any price."
The 52 brokerage firms trading on the older, noncomputerized stock exchange have resisted switching because some brokers are uncomfortable using computers and prefer bargaining face to face. Beyond the one hour a week when that hall trades its 10 stocks, it is given over to a random antiques or art auction.
The cost of a seat on the Ukrainian exchange, with so little stock trading, has plummeted. Two years ago, Mr. Sapunov said, his company bought a seat for the equivalent of $4,000.
"We thought it made sense for the future," he said. Today, the same seat goes for $1,900.

HEADLINE: Blowback From the Afghan Battlefield

BYLINE: By Tim Weiner; Tim Weiner, a correspondent in the Washington bureau of The Times, has reported on Afghanistan since 1987.

 BODY:
UNDER A RELENTLESS SUN, NOOR AMIN traverses the lunar terrain of Afghanistan. A commander of the Islamic Party, Afghanistan's best-armed and most radical political faction, he has just finished a two-month stint running a military training camp outside the ruined village of Jaji.
Battling the wheel of his four-wheel-drive truck, he drives past miles of poppy fields where boys scrape brown opium into burlap sacks. To the east, inside mud forts in the mountains, laboratories turn the opium into heroin. He crosses the rutted highway running from the Khyber Pass to Kabul, the capital, past checkpoints manned by soldiers of the Islamic Party, their posts adorned with the grim image of their leader, Prime Minister Gulbuddin Hekmatyar. 
 Heading north, he enters a ruined Eden, a natural paradise strewn with man-made disaster. Jade and silver rivers tumble through green valleys where every house, school and mosque is destroyed. Burned-out tanks litter the land like the carcasses of prehistoric beasts. The villages look like archeological sites. Hardly a stone stands upon a stone, save in the graveyards where thousands of slate shards are stabbed into the rocky earth. This is the last great battleground of the cold war, in which the Afghans, backed by the United States Central Intelligence Agency, fought off the Soviet Union in the 1980's.
In the five years since the Soviets withdrew, tens of thousands of Islamic radicals, outcasts, visionaries and gunmen from some 40 nations have come to Afghanistan to learn the lessons of the jihad, the holy war, to train for armed insurrection, to bring the struggle back home.
For nearly a generation, blood and bones were sown into the Afghan dust by the weapons of the superpowers, and now the land bears a harvest of holy war and heroin. The sole field of victory for C.I.A.-backed "freedom fighters" in the 1980's has become an international center for the training and indoctrination of terrorists. The veterans of the jihad have taken their war abroad to Algeria, Azerbaijan, Bangladesh, Bosnia, Burma, China, Egypt, India, Morocco, Pakistan, Sudan, Tadzhikistan, Tunisia, Uzbekistan, Yemen -- and the United States.
"Yes, the whole country is a university for jihad, exactly as they say," Noor Amin declares proudly. He has come home to Asadabad, the ruined capital of Kunar Province, in northeastern Afghanistan. Inside a fortified warren of mud huts, he gently leans his automatic rifle against the wall of his one-room house.
"There are many formal training centers and the Islamic Party has many such schools," like the one near Jaji, he says. "We have had Egyptians, Sudanese, Arabs and other foreigners trained here as assassins."
As in any outlaw culture, guns, drugs and money are interchangeable here. Nonetheless, the unfailing wellspring of cash is the cultivation, sale and processing of opium from fields and labs controlled by rebel commanders. Government estimates vary, but Afghanistan now produces roughly a third of the heroin reaching the United States. Hundreds of tons of opium base are refined into heroin and shipped via Pakistan, Turkey and, increasingly, busy new routes in the Central Asian republics and the Balkans.
The heroin boom is not only predictable but necessary, say Afghan leaders and American officials. It is Afghanistan's only real cash crop, and no outside authority has the influence or muscle to prevent trafficking in what is essentially a lawless country. There is no civil law, no government, no economy -- only guns and drugs and anger.
And that rage is kindled every night in the campfires of the holy warriors. "The jihad, in the opinion of the the United States, was finished when the Communists were defeated," says Noor Amin, draining his tea and dashing the dregs in the dust. "But jihad has no end. It goes on forever."
MOST AFGHANS WANT nothing more than to end the fighting and try to rebuild their prewar lives. But they know that's not going to happen. "For us, Afghanistan is destroyed," says Abdul Haq, a politically moderate mujahedeen commander responsible for the Kabul region during the war. "It is turning to poison, and not only for us but for all others in the world. If you are a terrorist, you can have shelter here, no matter who you are. Day by day, there is the increase of drugs. Maybe one day they will have to send hundreds of thousands of troops to deal with that. And if they step in, they will be stuck. We have a British grave in Afghanistan. We have a Soviet grave. And then we will have an American grave."
In a sense, there are already at least eight American graves.
Afghanistan is where the man accused of assassinating two C.I.A. employees in the agency's driveway disappeared last year after fleeing the United States; where the men convicted of blowing up the World Trade Center, which killed six people, learned strategy and tactics; where the jihad called them and their spiritual leader, Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, the blind Egyptian cleric charged with conspiring to overthrow the United States. Several of those convicted, as well as defendants in another indictment charging a conspiracy to devastate New York with bombs and political assassinations, raised money for or studied jihad with Hekmatyar's forces.
The C.I.A. has a word for this: blowback, a poisonous fallout, borne by political winds, drifting back home from a faraway battlefield.
"It's quite a shock," says Charles G. Cogan, the C.I.A.'s operations chief for the Near East and South Asia from 1979 to 1984. "The hypothesis that the mujahedeen would come to the United States and commit terrorist actions did not enter into our universe of thinking at the time. We were totally preoccupied with the war against the Soviets in Afghanistan. It is a significant unintended consequence."
The point isn't lost on Abdul Haq. "After the collapse of the Soviets, the biggest enemy of the U.S., what they hate the most is drugs and terrorism, yes?" he says. "Afghanistan is now the leader of the world in drugs and terrorism."
ABDULLAH JAN, THE GOVERNOR OF LAGHMAN Province, knocks back his sixth cup of after-dinner tea, pops a Russian candy in his mouth and mulls over the recent history of Afghan-American relations.
"So the C.I.A. says we are the University of Jihad?" He arches an eyebrow and smirks. "Why is the United States afraid? After all, it supported the faculty of this university." So it did, and it did so in one of the least morally ambiguous battles of the cold war.
The villagers of Afghanistan first encountered the wonders of modern technology in the form of Soviet jets, tanks and helicopters. Moscow's military juggernaut killed or maimed perhaps three million Afghans and sent six million fleeing west into Iran or east into Pakistan.
The Afghans took on the infidels. They died in uncounted numbers. They lived on stale bread and tea. They slept on stones in the mountains. And they drove the Soviets out. They fought their holy war with roughly $6 billion in weapons and materiel from the C.I.A., Saudi Arabia and an odd alliance of Iranian weapons procurers, Arab princes, Egyptian politicians and Chinese generals. Together, the Afghans achieved a famous victory. Some say it was the beginning of the end of the Soviet Union.
"But the people of Afghanistan, we have gone from one jail into another jail," says Abdul Hakim Katawazi, commander of the state police under the last king of Afghanistan in the early 1970's.
The prison guards are a God-mad rabble, the foot soldiers of a new Islamic order who received their advanced training in jihad in the military camps that now dot the countryside. Roughly 20 such centers exist in eastern Afghanistan between Kabul and the Khyber Pass, mostly under the control of Hekmatyar and his commanders. The camps have grown up around abandoned villages and battered Soviet military garrisons. Sacks of flour, some purloined from donations by the United States Agency for International Development, are stacked like sandbags in simple huts. Weapons, a good many of them taken from C.I.A.-supplied caches hoarded during the jihad, are plentiful.
In these training centers, the foreigners learn about guerrilla warfare, antiaircraft weapons and rocket-propelled grenades. Much in demand, but too precious to fire in training, is the Stinger antiaircraft missile, supplied by the hundreds to the Afghans by the C.I.A. in the 1980's. An unknown number are missing and unaccounted for; the C.I.A. is spending $65 million trying to buy them back.
The men fly to the bustling frontier town of Peshawar, Pakistan, to the east, riding buses or trucks over the Khyber Pass to Jalalabad, in Afghanistan. The provincial capital serves as a way station for the new arrivals heading for the camps. Here are Palestinians exiled from their native land; cashiered Egyptian army officers; Moroccans, Algerians and Sudanese intent on bringing down their Governments, and from time to time, Americans from New York, Detroit, Chicago and other cities.
The Afghans who lead the training, like Noor Amin, are in high demand wherever radical Islam is at war, for their victory was the first triumph of Islamic warriors over an infidel army since the 16th century. "Their jihad credentials, religious and political, are impeccable," says an American intelligence official. "They beat one of the world's two superpowers and now they're working on the second."
THE DEAN OF THE UNIVERSITY OF JIHAD, Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, represents almost everything Americans hate, fear and misapprehend about radical Islam. The feeling appears to be mutual.
Talking with Hekmatyar is like listening to wind chimes tinkling on the porch of a burning building. A disarmingly feline man, he purses his lips and talks dispassionately of the death of millions. His aim is to build "a true Islamic republic," under his dominion, and he has the will and the weapons to fulfill that dream. If it takes another generation of war, so be it.
"We have already had one and a half million martyrs," Hekmatyar said in a 1992 interview. "We are ready to offer as many to establish a true Islamic republic. We are ready to remain in the mountains for another 14 years."
Unique among the world's Prime Ministers, Hekmatyar has spent the past 22 months firing artillery shells and rockets into the capital of his own country. This act of political sadomasochism began the week the rebels took Kabul from the Soviet-backed regime. The barrage is aimed at the citizens of Kabul, whom Hekmatyar considers to have collaborated with the Soviet occupation, and at the armed forces loyal to Afghanistan's President, Burhanuddin Rabbani. It has killed more than 10,000 Afghans, driven hundreds of thousands into squalid refugee camps, created political chaos and blocked millions of exiles from returning.
Among the refugees is Mohin Ajan, a carpenter by trade, sent fleeing with his wife and seven children by Hekmatyar's missiles. "He rules us by the power of weapons," says Ajan, who lives in a tent amid several thousand other internal exiles on a dusty promontory outside Jalalabad. "He is the king of weapons, not the king of Afghanistan."
Hekmatyar's weapons, the source of his ministry, come mainly from the enormous arsenal sent by the C.I.A.. The United States and its allies gave him more than $1 billion in armaments: tens of thousands of assault rifles and rocket-propelled grenades, millions of rounds of ammunition, hundreds of the deadly accurate Stinger missiles. Hekmatyar put away enough weapons to make war for four more years.
No one doubts he will. Hekmatyar's jihad never ended. When he speaks of a true Islamic republic, he means a land without borders.
BY THE TIME THE SOVIETS LEFT AFGHANISTAN in February 1989, thousands of Afghan-trained volunteers were ready to carry on the war abroad. Thousands more took their place in the camps.
The militants took the torch of the Afghan rebels' holy rage and turned their energies to a greater battle. They saw the 1991 Persian Gulf war as a modern manifestation of the medieval Crusades, the Arab nations supporting the war as corrupt collaborators with Christendom and the United States and the United Nations as imperial knights with smart bombs. Their anger was focused on Arab leaders they saw as American agents, and on America itself.
By 1992, as Kabul fell into chaos at the hands of the holy warriors, posters of Saddam adorned Afghanistan's shops and bazaars, mounted next to heroic pictures of Hekmatyar. As freedom fighter fought freedom fighter over the nation's broken remains, the fire that fueled the jihad began to spread beyond the borders drawn by the 19th-century imperial powers, Russia and the British Raj.
To the north lay Tadzhikistan and Uzbekistan. Tadzhiks and Uzbeks by the millions live in Afghanistan; tens of millions of their Muslim brothers live in the former Soviet republics. Some 20,000 people have died and a half-million have been forced from their homes as Islamic rebels battle the pro-Communist regime still in control of Tadzhikistan. Russia still has thousands of soldiers stationed there, fighting guerrillas on both sides of the Afghan border. The President of Uzbekistan, Islam Karimov, says he expects the rebels to attack his country and Tadzhikistan this spring.
To the east, hundreds of Afghans allied with Hekmatyar have fought in the embattled state of Jammu and Kashmir, a territory disputed since the 1947 partition of India and Pakistan. Thousands have died in the struggle. In China, where Islam has been periodically suppressed, Afghan veterans have fought in two western provinces, Uighur and Xinjiang, where they have armed and trained Chinese Muslim rebels.
To the west, Hekmatyar has sent 500 mujahedeen to fight in Azerbaijan with Iranian forces, according to Haji Abdul Qadr, the Governor of Afghanistan's Nangahar Province. Hundreds of Afghans have fought against Serbs and Croats in Bosnia.
Nowhere have veterans of the Afghan war made a greater impact on society than in Egypt and Algeria. Since 1992, when a junta nullified elections that would have brought Islamic leaders to power in Algeria, more than 2,000 people have died in a continuing campaign of terror and reprisal. The Islamic rebels in Algeria have led a two-year struggle spearheaded by guerrillas who are known collectively as Afghans, regardless of their nationality.
In Egypt, an unending series of assassinations, attacks on Government officials and local insurrections can be traced to the work of al-Gamaa al-Islamia, the Islamic Group. This organization, blamed for the 1981 assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat, established headquarters in exile in Jalalabad and in Peshawar in the mid-1980's. One of the most prominent figures at those new bases was Mohammed Shawki Islambouli, the brother of one of Sadat's assassins. In 1988 and 1990, he played host to Sheik Abdel Rahman, a spiritual leader of the Islamic Group, who struck up a personal and ideological friendship with Hekmatyar.
The Prime Minister reaffirmed his relationship with the sheik in July. As one set of United States authorities weighed deporting the sheik and another prepared an indictment against him, Hekmatyar offered him political asylum in Afghanistan, calling the cleric "a leader of the Islamic nation."
Among the sheik's followers is Mohammed Salameh, a Palestinian who in addition to being convicted in the World Trade Center case, raised money for the mujahedeen in Brooklyn. His roommate in a Jersey City apartment was Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, an Iraqi who fought in Afghanistan and arrived at Kennedy International Airport on a flight from Pakistan in September 1992. On that flight was Ahmad Ajaj, a Palestinian fresh from Afghanistan, whose suitcase bore bomb-making manuals. Ajaj was convicted in the trade center bombing, as was Mahmud Abouhalima, who also raised money for the rebels; friends say he went to Afghanistan to fight. Arrested in Egypt, he allegedly told Egyptian officials -- who may have tortured him -- that the World Trade Center bombing was planned in Afghanistan by veterans of the jihad, with the approval of Iranian intelligence officers and Rahman.
THE FURY OF HEKMATYAR AND HIS DISCIPLES may yet accomplish what Alexander the Great, Genghis Khan, Tamerlane, the armies of the Raj and the tanks and helicopter gunships of the Soviet Union could not. It may destroy Afghanistan.
After 60 centuries, the villages persist amid a lacework of rivers in a wilderness of stones, terraced fields of grain, orchards of apricots and oranges and mulberries. The people there are as strong and as beautiful as any on earth. A great many of those who have survived the war -- commanders, elders, headmen -- are trying, against great odds, to save the surviving villages. They are not terrorists or drug kingpins. They despise Hekmatyar and his eternal jihad.
In the shade of an arbor by the banks of the roaring Kunar River, Haji Rahmat Khan holds court. An ancient man with a long gray beard and glittering eyes, he tells a sad story often told in his province.
"It's a Kunar story, but it's the story of Afghanistan," he says, his hands plucking at his bandolier.
It is the story of Jamillur Rehman, once Hekmatyar's commander in Kunar Province and the most famous of the mujahedeen in these parts. In 1984, he was enticed to leave his command and join forces with well-financed fundamentalists called the Salafis, bankrolled by ultrareligious Saudis.
"He became a rich man," Haji Rahmat Khan says. "He took money from Saudi Arabia. All the Arabians gave him cars, money, everything." The money drew thousands of Arabs to the jihad, and today those men are fighting in Cairo and Khartoum and Algiers. After the Soviet withdrawal, the Salafis battled Hekmatyar's troops. The fighting destroyed most of what remained of Kunar Province. Jamillur Rehman was assassinated two years ago by Hekmatyar's forces.
"Those who killed him were not Russians or Americans," the old man says, his voice rising. "Afghans killed him. Those who killed him wanted the country for themselves. Now Hekmatyar and the rest of our stupid leaders are killing all our brothers, making them die like donkeys, not like heroes. We can't get rid of them -- we'd be killed or jailed.
"We didn't choose these leaders. The United States made Hekmatyar by giving him his weapons. Now we want the United States to shake these leaders and make them stop the killing, to save us from them.
"There is a fire burning in Afghanistan. Now, if there is a fire in my house, and my neighbor won't help put it out, what kind of neighbor is he? Doesn't he understand that his own house may burn?"

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Travel Industry Prepares For a Rush to Vietnam

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WITH the end of United States trade sanctions against Vietnam, the number of Americans traveling there is likely to increase markedly, whether they are motivated by business opportunity, family ties, historical interest or the imponderable attraction of old soldiers to battlefields they cannot forget.
Although it will take months for all the arrangements to fall into place, the travel industry is already planning for the rush. United Airlines and Northwest Airlines have applied for permission to fly from American cities to Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon. United would fly from Los Angeles, Northwest from Detroit via Tokyo. Continental and Delta are also considering providing service. 
 But the American companies cannot sell tickets until the United States and Vietnam work out aviation agreements, which, an official in the United States Transportation Department said, were unlikely to be completed by this summer. Until then, travelers from the United States must fly to some other Asian country, like Bangkok, Taiwan, Hong Kong or Tokyo, and take a foreign airline to Vietnam. Tour operators say they expect a steady increase in business, even though the embargo did not bar Americans from traveling there.
"Adventurous backpackers of the Vietnam and post-Vietnam generations have been going there in droves for the past two years," said Edward Hasbrouk of the Aereo Travel Group in San Francisco, who estimates that most of the tickets his agency sold to Southeast Asia last year were to people planning to spend at least some time in Vietnam.
Even they have had misconceptions about the embargo, he said, often assuming that they had to arrange their flights and visas from Bangkok, not realizing that United States agents could obtain visasfrom Mexico or Canada. (Visas are not yet available in the United States.)
Inner Asia Expeditions of San Francisco, which has been sponsoring tours in Vietnam for a few years, is offering a new trip that takes voyagers down Route 9, a link on the famous Ho Chi Minh trail, across the old demilitarized zone between the north and south, and across the newly opened border into Laos. Typical tours of 8 to 12 days cost from $1,600 to $3,000, not counting air fare.
Gannon Travel of Reston, Va., is another agency developing a specialty in Vietnam, where its parent organization, the Gannon Companies, has permanent offices in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City staffed by Vietnamese and Americans.
Gannon, which also is involved in the construction business in Vietnam, says that a portion of its profits from Vietnam are to be donated to Operation Smile Vietnam, an enterprise that has sponsored medical assistance to Vietnamese children since 1989.
Beginning in April, Gannon will offer day and overnight tours from Hanoi, including bicycle tours, visits to villages, and festival events. The company is also planning to offer a 14-day nationwide tour priced at about $4,000, plus air fare. While travelers can go solo to Vietnam, that approach remains difficult and complicated, especially for those who want to venture far from the former Saigon, a city that still boasts plenty of Western-style hotels and where it is easy to find a car and an English-speaking driver.
There are few first-class hotels outside Saigon, but Heather Smith, who has been to Vietnam twice investigating the trade in endangered species for the Earth Island Institute, a San Francisco environmental group, said she was pleased with the inexpensive hotels she stayed in.
"You can get a great hotel for 10 bucks a night," she said. "In the north they have a hot shower, but in Saigon they don't."
Credit cards issued by American banks cannot yet be used, until the regulatory agencies work out the arrangements. And there may be a charge of up to 5 percent on traveler's checks, which will be cashed in Vietnamese currency that cannot be converted back to dollars. So travelers may want to take as much cash in dollars as possible, bearing in mind the risk of loss or theft. The dollars will be readily accepted.

HEADLINE: IN SHORT: NONFICTION

BYLINE: By Erik Eckholm 

 BODY:

HEALTH CARE
THE ROAD TO REFORM
The Future of Health Care in America.
By Eli Ginzberg with Miriam Ostow.
Free Press, $22.95. 
 Eli Ginzberg, the director of Columbia University's Eisenhower Center for the Conservation of Human Resources, has been writing about the defects and strengths of the American health care system for a long time. "The Road to Reform," written with Miriam Ostow, who is in charge of health policy studies at the Eisenhower Center, is strongest when describing how a sector that involved just 4.5 percent of the gross domestic product in 1950 could absorb more than 14 percent of national spending by 1993. The book's discussions of the Federal Government's postwar role in shaping medical training, and how the Medicare and Medicaid programs transformed hospital financing, bring useful perspective to the often ahistorical debates of the moment. Unfortunately, though, Mr. Ginzberg's insights are often buried in tedious and clumsy prose. He sees President Clinton's proposals as a reasonable starting point toward inevitable change. Closing with a general and unsurprising review of the long-term challenges that will bedevil any national plan, the book sheds little light on the specific hard choices Congress faces this year.
 ERIK ECKHOLM

LENGTH: 2785 words

HEADLINE: Prices at Ebb Tide for Waterfront Property

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
BUFFETED by storms that made insurance tricky to find or difficult to afford and by reassessments that sent property taxes soaring, waterfront properties in many parts of the metropolitan New York region are now being traded at some of the lowest prices in recent history.
"This last recession is the only time I know of when blue-chip real estate did not keep its value," said lyn Hanberg, co-owner of Dunham Ltd. Realtors in Old Lyme, Conn. She said many prime waterfront properties in her part of the Connecticut shoreline had tripled in value during the boom of the mid- to late 1980's and "when they fell, they had that much farther to fall." 
 In Rye, N.Y., Richard De Mato, who has his contemporary waterfront house under contract to sell for $1.6 million, $1.9 million less than he had originally priced it in March 1989, was philosophical. "Dino Ferraris [Ferrari auto models made in the early 70's] used to cost $175,000 -- now they're under $100,000," he said. "Do I ever think waterfront properties will come back up? Sure. When? I don't have any idea."
Agents and others in the real estate industry stress that each town in each county in each state is different, and prices in some beach and waterfront areas -- notably the Hamptons on Long Island -- have been hit less, or have recovered faster, than others.
But there appears to be general agreement among real estate professionals that, in the words of Tina Fredericks, who owns a real estate agency that bears her name in East Hampton, waterfront prices "have hit bottom and are ready to go up."
"I never thought I'd see prices this low," said Charles J. Traina, a sales agent with Zachariae Realty in Manahawkin, on the Jersey Shore, pointing to a ranch house with a dock on a lagoon that once sold for close to $175,000. "When those houses went under $100,000 we couldn't believe it," he said. "And now they're listing them for $80,000, $85,000."
In the shorefront towns of Westbrook and Clinton, Conn., beach bungalows -- fairly large 1920's and 30's clapboard houses on small lots directly on Long Island Sound -- regularly sold for close to half a million dollars at the height of the market. Now many are listed between $350,000 and $399,000 and sell at somewhere between.
In the highest-end markets, waterfront mansions are also selling for substantially less than they were four years ago and even in the Hamptons there are still foreclosure sales. But agents maintain that -- at last -- these properties are now beginning to be shown actively.
"Last week I pulled into the parking lot and actually saw six cars with New York license plates," said Laura Page, of Page-Taft Real Estate in Madison, Conn. "Those people disappeared after the stock market crash and it was like seeing the swallows heading back to Capistrano. I don't know if anybody bought anything that day but it was a ray of hope."
New Jersey realtors are "starting to see a normalcy in the market," according to Robert F. Ferguson Jr., executive vice president of the New Jersey Board of Realtors. "We're not talking about the go-go days of the 80's, but waterfront prices will start to go up," he said. Environmental restrictions, he said, will make new waterfront construction more difficult and thus make existing houses more valuable.
MARIAN FRAKER-GUTIN, president of the Long Island Board of Realtors, said that "prices for waterfront properties are down, interest rates are down and sellers are ready to let them go." Ms. Fraker-Gutin, a broker with Mary Elmore Realty in Merrick, gave the example of a house on South Oyster Bay in Massapequa that was put on the market a year ago at $535,000. "We're just starting to get a little action now," she said, "but we've certainly had a bad time."
About four years ago, she said, the house would have sold quickly for close to $600,000.
Ms. Fraker-Gutin said the problem with selling waterfront homes on Long Island was no longer the recession, but in finding insurance.
"We were recovering nicely when that terrible storm hit, and the insurance problem just threw another fly in the ointment," she said, referring to the Dec. 11, 1992, nor'easter that flooded basements along the New Jersey and Connecticut shorelines, eroded beaches and even wiped out some houses.
"Then there was the threat of another big storm last September," she continued. "That storm never came -- thank God -- but that was one of the reasons why they [insurance companies] started to pull out."
Her comments were echoed by at least a dozen other agents specializing in waterfront property in the tri-state area. Doreen Niggles, of Allan M. Schneider Associates in East Hampton, L.I., said there were "major insurance problems in the Hamptons."
Eric G. Ramsay Jr., who has sold real estate in Bay Shore, L.I., for 35 years, called the insurance situation "really scary." When Bret Saberhagen, the Mets pitcher, bought his $1.275 million waterfront house, Mr. Ramsay said the baseball star tried 40 different insurance companies before one would write a policy, "so you can imagine the trouble any ordinary guy would have."
Few contracts on waterfront houses in his area are complete now without a contingency clause that lets the buyer get out of the contract if he can't find insurance. Asked if lawyers routinely add this clause, Mr. Ramsay repled: "They do if they have a brain."
MARNA VAN DER PLOEG of William Pitt Real Estate in Greenwich, Conn., said the Dec. 11 storm "had a big effect on waterfront property values" because "it made people seriously reconsider buying a waterfront home.
"The first question out of everybody's mouth is: 'Is this house insurable?' I usually answer 'Yes, up to a point -- or well, that depends . . .' Prices have fallen with waterfront properties, but the biggest thing that prevents people buying them and why they're on the market so long is perceived problems with flooding."
A contemporary house on an inlet was appraised by two independent appraisers at $795,000 and $775,000, Ms. van der Ploeg said. It just sold for $635,000. Another Greenwich waterfront house was valued at $859,000 and sold for $697,000, she added, "and this was all after the nor'easter."
Independent insurance agents confirm the problems with finding insurance for waterfront homes.
Tom Archambault, vice president of Archambault Insurance in Chester, Conn., said that after the storm companies tightened their rules on waterfronts and some stopped writing policies on certain types of waterfront properties altogether.
"The Aetna, for instance, rejects all new business for any dwelling within 1,000 feet of the seacoast, bay or sound, or located on a barrier island," he said, reading from the company's new guidelines. "Anything between 1,001 and 2,500 feet that has had catastrophic loss or windstorm damage in the last three years is not eligible."
If a person already owns waterfront property, Aetna will renew his or her policy, he said, but the deductible will be raised to 2 percent of the value if the house is within 1,000 feet of the shore. That makes the deductible on a $200,000 house $4,000, he said.
Other companies will cancel or not renew an existing policy. The policy for one house 1,300 feet from the Long island Sound in South Lyme was canceled by Metropolitan Life because of "increased exposure presented by the dwelling's proximity to tidal water," Mr. Archambault said.
F. Jeffrey Cashman, president of William Pitt Insurance Services in Stamford, said that insurance could be found for waterfront homes but that it was not easy. "Federal flood insurance is available up to $185,000, and Lloyd's of London will pick up any excess," he said, "but obviously that's expensive and is written on a case-by-case basis."
New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have real estate boards and legislators who are addressing the problems and many realtors say relief is in sight.
In New York, the State Insurance Department is creating an Coastal Market Assistance Program, a pool of "10 or 12 insurance companies that will evaluate [waterfront] risks on a rotation basis, so that if there is a big storm no one company will bear the brunt," said John Calagna, an agency spokesman.
In Connecticut, the state's Independent Insurance Agents association is working with the state to establish a similar pool.
Last Dec. 29 the New Jersey Insurance Commissioner instituted a 90-day moratorium on waterfront policy cancellations -- a moratorium the state Legislature is currently considering extending until June 30.
While finding waterfront property insurance has been a problem throughout the region, property-tax reappraisals are a more significant factor in some communities.
Usually the towns that are having the problems are those where a sweeping reappraisal was completed sometime in the late 80's. By the time the property tax bills went out -- usually a year or so after the re-evaluation -- the properties were no longer worth the same.
"Waterfront properties had soared in value," said Pat Jones, who owns the real estate company bearing her name in Madison, Conn., "so they got hit the hardest; the taxes are prohibitive, they're a burden to carry."
A classic shingled beach cottage with columned porch, beaded vertical matchboard paneling and a two-car garage across the street, at 150 Middle Beach Road in Madison, was assessed at a full market value of $833,260, but Ms. Jones said the asking price was now $725,000, down from an initial price of $940,000.
NEARBY, at 16 Middle Beach Road, Sandy Busby of the Maurer Real Estate Company is marketing a 10-room year-round beach house built in 1938 that was extensively remodeled in 1986. The current owners, who paid $1 million for the house in mid-1987, rebuilt the sea wall and put in another bathroom, which they say cost $70,000. They have priced the house at $875,000, which is below the appraised fair market value of $981,000. Taxes on the house have soared, from $3,906.12 in 1986 to $14,566.94 now.
In Old Saybrook, Conn., more than 100 angry property owners who lost appeals before the Board of Tax Review have sued the town over what they claim are unfair 1989 revaluations. Almost half are from the Borough of Fenwick, a posh enclave on Long Island Sound.
Taxes on Beaumaris, an elegant, huge shingle-style Fenwick beach house that had been in the same family since the borough was established at the turn of the century, leapt with the revaluation from $5,649 to $15,543. The house, originally priced at $2.75 million, sold last summer for $1,450,000 after almost three years on the market.
"Families who were paying $4,000 suddenly were presented with a bill for $15,000," said Ward Burian, the co-owner of Dunham Realty in Old Lyme. "They decided to sell."
SIMILAR instances were reported in Essex and the riverfront part of Deep River, he said. Laura Page reported similar increases when Madison had its revaluation and Alix Sara Prince, vice president of Julia B. Fee in Rye, said that the town's waterfront had been appraised at its "overinflated" past values, creating an obstacle to selling waterfront property.
Nevertheless, Ms. Prince insisted that tax assessors, besieged by complaints, often did adjust an assessment after a property was sold if the sale was for less than the assessed fair market value.
In Huntington, L.I., Mary Rice of the Coldwell Banker Sammis brokerage, said that although there had not been a revaluation in Huntington "taxes are thought to be very high, and that creates a problem."
Ms. Rice said that despite the taxes and "some difficulties" in finding insurance, waterfront buyers -- while scarce -- were savvy, cautious customers who knew exactly what they were looking for.
"They're definitely not impulse buyers," said Ms. Rice, who is the sales manager at the Main Street branch. "These people are quite comfortable where they are, but if something comes along they'll make an offer. Every broker here has a few waterfront customers waiting for the perfect house."
She said that there was a time when such customers "would buy anything" but that "they're conservative now."
Because of the lack of pressure to buy, these potential waterfront buyers are known as tough negotiators who will walk away from a house if the price is not to their liking.
Although houses on the Sound in Huntington Bay and Lloyd Harbor almost never sell for under $1 million, Ms. Rice said houses in Asharoken and the McKinley Terrace section of Centerport sold for far less. Houses like the bayfront contemporary in McKinley Terrace now listed for $339,000 would have sold for as much as $400,000 or $425,000 at the height of the market, she said..
"One bayfront house on a narrow lot in Asharoken sold in the low threes and it took forever to go to contract," she said. "One of the issues was whether they could get insurance and they really wrangled over the price, and the seller wouldn't go any lower. It boiled down to the fact that the husband just plain loved it."
The Asharoken section, she explained, is not as accessible as other sections of Huntington. "It's kind of out of the way," she said, "but that's exactly why it appeals to some people."
On the Jersey Shore, Mr. Traina, whose company handles houses in Manahawkin and on Long Beach Island -- the 18-mile-long barrier-beach island across the intracoastal waterway from Manahawkin -- said he offered waterfront houses from $80,000 up to $3 million.
THE six-bedroom modern house at 51D Long Beach Boulevard in Loveladies on Long Beach Island -- one of the area's grandest, with sleek bleached wood, rounded corners and plain round metal railings and with 125 feet of ocean dune frontage -- just sold for $1.3 million. At the height of the market, it would have brought $2 million, the real estate agent said.
In the picturesque town of Bay Head, N.J., about 45 minutes north of Long Beach Island, where much more of the housing stock is of turn-of-the-century vintage than in the Manahawkin area, there is a grand Victorian shingled beach house with a wicker bar sitting on the curved porch.
Three corner fireplaces -- one in the entrance foyer -- sit inside the empty house with the original vertical beaded paneling. The old kitchen is rudimentary and the white trim paint is peeling. Nevertheless, the house appears in good condition and there is relatively new baseboard heat.
The house sold on March 7 for $1.075 million. "During the height of the market, it would have closed for $1.5 to $1.6 million," said Shawn C. Clayton, whose family owns a real estate company that concentrates on the Bay Head-Mantoloking waterfront. Mr. Clayton said that although properties had been hit by the recession, waterfront properties continued to sell.
"We're still getting good numbers," he said, gesturing to a wall of color photographs of properties.
Several of the houses had been substantially reduced. An eight-bedroom white Victorian farmhouse on the open bay in Mantoloking started out eight months ago at $775,000 and is now down to $595,000. A contemporary two-story, six-bedroom oceanfront house began at $1.995 million and is now listed at $1.675 million.
IN Rye, Alix Prince, who has sold four waterfront houses since Christmas, produced a handful of information sheets on houses that had been sold in the mid-1980's and had recently been resold for less.
"In 1990-1991 we had a standoff between buyers and sellers," she said. "The sellers still thought they could get top dollar and the buyers were telling them they couldn't. They're getting more realistic now. It took them a long time to believe that the market had crashed."
The market appears to be recovering more quickly in the Hamptons. According to Frank Zaperach, a real estate agent, waterfront property values that had dropped 20 or 30 percent several years ago, are almost back to the high levels of the mid-80's. His assessment is shared by other realtors there.
Mark Zimmerman, a real estate lawyer who divides his time between East Hampton and Manhattan, said that the Hamptons had recovered faster than other waterfront areas in the region because they attracted "Hollywood, Japanese and European money."
"The celebrities want to be there and the people who want to be where the celebrities are want to be there," he said.
Ms. Niggles, the East Hampton broker, offered another explanation.
"These waterfront houses rent for as much as $300,000 for the summer," she said. "Why would you want to let somebody steal your house at a bargain basement price if you could look ahead to that much income? When waterfront houses aren't selling, the owners will just take them off the market and wait."

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Choosing The Best Mortgage

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS 

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH most of the first-time buyers now flooding the market are choosing fixed-rate mortgages, this may not necessarily be the wisest choice.
True, such mortgages are easier to understand and far more predictable: What you pay at the outset is what you will always pay. But they're certainly not the least exxpensive way to go. 
 Indeed, for anyone likely to move on in a handful of years -- the typical pattern for a first-time homeowner -- there could be major advantages to the vast array of adjustable mortgages now available.
Adjustables are no longer the risky product they were when introduced in the late 70's and early 80's -- a time of volatile interest rates and steep interest charges. Increases can be phased in more gradually and all mortgages have strict limits on how high payments can rise over the life of the loan.
As a result, these mortgages have a special appeal when interest rates are low. If it starts out at 3.5 percent, for example, a lifetime cap of 6 percent (the industry norm) means that the interest rate could never exceed 9.5 percent. So even if interest rates rise as predicted in the coming months they should still make financial sense.
They are particularly useful, for example, to any borrower required to carry private mortgage insurance during the first few years. This normally happens when a down payment is less than 20 percent.
In these situations an adjustable mortgage costs so much less in those early years that it should enable the borrower to pay off principal each month, thereby reaching that 20 percent threshold sooner, noted Marc Eisenson, a partner with Banker's Secret, a mortgage-information publisher in Elizaville, N.Y. As soon as that happens the mortgage insurance can be dropped.
Others who might do well with an adjustable mortgage include transferees with a limited-term assignment and an investor who's buying a "handyman special" for a quick fix-up and turnaround.
There are many different types of adjustables to choose from, each one tailored to a projected length of stay or to cover any lingering fears about the future.
There are adjustables that stay fixed for the first 3, 5 or 7 years, depending upon the borrower's choice; others that allow the borrower to convert to a fixed-rate loan at any time during the first five years with only a nominal administrative charge. Still others offer rock-bottom starting rates in exchange for a willingness to permit an adjustment once each year.
If all of this seems like hype it's worth noting that adjustables have lately become the mortgage of choice for the professionals in the business. And they should know.
Consider Neil Bader, president of Skyscraper Mortgage Corporation, one of the larger mortgage brokers in Manhattan. When he and his wife, Amy, were seeking financing for a vacation home they purchased last July in Stockbridge, Mass., they chose an adjustable for their own $200,000 loan.
The interest rate was 3.8 percent for the first year compared with 7.5 percent for a fixed-rate loan, giving them initial payments of $940 a month instead of $1,398. Even though payments will gradually rise in subsequent years the savings will amount to $8,076 over the first two years alone. "That's a lot of money," said Mr. Bader.
Moreover, the loan carried a cap limiting any increases to 6 percent over the life of the mortgage. So their interest rate could never rise higher than 9.8 percent -- the "worst case scenario," said Mr. Bader.
In other words, in a low interest rate environment, the normal 6 percent lifetime cap on an adjustable rate mortgage means that -- irrespective of what happens to the economy over the next 30 years -- the rate on that particular loan may never rise more than about two points higher than the starting rate for today's fixed-rate mortgages -- about 7.5 percent.
No wonder Marc Eisenson, the mortgage-information publisher, encouraged his brother, Alan, to make a similar move. Alan Eisenson, owner of Just Alan, an upscale gift store in Woodstock, N.Y., has been buying and selling property since the 70's, using fixed-rate mortgages each time.
But when he and his wife, Juliette, and their two children moved to a larger home in the area two years ago they were advised by his brother to instead consider a yearly adjustable, the one with the lowest starting rate. And they have not been disappointed. So far they have never seen an adjustment lift payments to the maximum permitted by their particular contract. "It was a gamble," admits Alan Eisenson. "But sometimes it's worth gambling just a little."
Or take the view of Brett and Sharon Mehlman, a couple in their 20's who have just bought their first home, a two-bedroom co-op on East 87th Street in Manhattan. They don't expect to be in the apartment more than a few years because they plan to have children and move to the suburbs.
Thus they selected a mortgage with a 6.125 percent interest rate that adjusts every three years. The $203,000 they needed in financing is costing $1,233 a month for the first three years. Although it may rise to $1,490 during the second three-year period -- assuming once again the worst case scenario -- this is still only pennies more than the cost of a fixed-rate loan that would have started out at $1,454 a month.
As they also believed that their incomes would increase as time went on, said Mr. Mehlman, it made sense to lighten the burden initially and take a chance on those later years, especially as they may not even be there by then.
Keith Gumbinger, an mortgage analyst with HSH Associates, a mortgage monitoring service in Butler, N.J, figures that it normally takes about five years before an adjustable begins to cost the borrower more than a fixed-rate loan.
Meantime, some sizable savings are being achieved. Mr. Gumbinger gives as an example a $100,000 loan. On a 30-year fixed rate schedule monthly payments would average around $686, given a 7.3 percent interest rate.
By contrast, an adjustable-rate mortgage with 6.3 percent fixed rate for the first five years would only cost $619, a monthly savings of $67. So before any adjustments even started to kick in the savings would amount to $4,020 (67 x 12 x 5).
What kind of adjustables have become the most popular? At Mr. Bader's mortgage agency it's been those that start out with an interest rate of around 5.5 percent and limit adjustments to three-year intervals.
Coupled with a 2 percent cap on each of these adjustment, he said, this means that for at least the first six years the rate will stay under 8 percent, making them highly competitive with a regular 30-year fixed rate loan.
Anyone willing to take on an adjustable with more frequent adjustment periods can probably find a loan that starts out at 3.7 percent, he said. In that case it could take as long as 10 years before you would have paid the bank as much as if you had started out with a fixed-rate loan.
Jenne K. Britell, chief lending officer at Dime Savings Bank of New York, said her first-time buyers liked adjustables that were constant for the first five years, adjusting every year afterwards.
"It gives you the security of a fixed-rate product at a lower rate with five years before you have to worry," she said.

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

'ORLANDO' IN RIDGEFIELD
"Orlando," based on the Virginia Wolff novel that traces the ageless, endless, gender-bending life of the title character, will be shown today at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art at 258 Main Street in Ridgefield.
It will be introduced by Quentin Crisp, the British actor who portrays Queen Elizabeth in the film. Orlando, played by Tilda Swenson, is first encountered as a young nobleman in Elizabethan England, and followed through her amorous adventures to present day London. 
 A reception at 4 P.M. will include a tour of the current art exhibition, and hors d'oeuvres prepared by Johannes Brugger, chef-owner of the historic Inn at Ridgefield. Mr. Crisp's talk and the screening will follow at 5 P.M.
American audiences may be familiar with Quentin Crisp through his autobiography, "The Naked Civil Servant," which was made into an arresting film starring John Hurt.
Tickets are $15, or $10 for students. The number for reservations is 438-4519.
 
ART OF THE ANGLER
 Fishermen impatient for the opening of the season, and art lovers whose season is never ending, will enjoy the new exhibition at the Lyman Allyn Museum in New London. Curated by the director, Elizabeth P. Knowles, "The Lure of Fishing" opens today through May 1, with a selection of paintings and sculpture dedicated to anglers, angling and even some hapless anglees.
Among the historical entries are an Adirondack fishing scene by Winslow Homer, and a handsome black bass by Gurdon Trumbull, loaned by the Fine Arts and Antiques Collection of the Hartford Steam Boiler Inspection and Insurance Company.
The American Museum of Fly Fishing in Manchester, Vermont, has lent works by Ogden Pleissner, an early 20th century member of the Old Lyme art colony; and contemporary fly-fishermen are depicted by several Connecticut artists including Chet Renesen, Lou Bonamarte, Pam Nelson, and Luther Hall. Original prints by Robert Cale are also in the show. The Stonington artist, who died in 1991, developed a technique in which fish became a printing matrix when mixed with inks.
Gallery talks by some of the artists will be given at the opening today from 1 to 5 P.M. The museum is located at 625 Williams Street, open Tuesday through Friday and on Sunday from 1 to 5 P.M.; Saturday from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is $3 for adults, $2 for students and older adults, free for children through the age of 12. The number for more information is 443-2545.
 
GRAY ON ANATOMY
 Spalding Gray will present his monologue, "Gray's Anatomy," at the Norwalk Community-Technical College Theater on Saturday at 8 P.M. Tickets at $25 may be reserved by calling 857-7271.
Taking his title from the medical textbook that bore his name long before he did, he regales the audience with tales of his odyssey around the world, seeking a cure for an eye ailment that defied diagnosis and treatment. At various times he was the patient of a nutritional opthamologist in Poughkeepsie, a New Age healer in a Minnesota sweat lodge, and a psychic in the Philippines who performed strange surgery.
His style, in this and numerous other monologues that he has delivered at the Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center, relies on deadpan delivery of outrageous text. The college is located at 188 Richards Avenue.
 
LOOKING AT NATIONALISM
 The League of Women Voters of Connecticut is celebrating its 25th anniversary. Among the special events on its agenda is a Symposium on International Relations to be presented in cooperation with Yale University at the Yale Law School on Wednesday from 8:30 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. The emphasis will be on Russia and India and the subtitle is "Nationalism: Obstacle or Opportunity?"
Roger Hilsman, professor emeritus of international politics at Columbia University and former Assistant Secretary of State, will open the proceedings with an overview on nationalism, later fielding questions from the audience.
The afternoon session will be led by Philip Oldenburg, a Columbia University professor; and Christine Perney, a doctoral candidate in Soviet studies at Columbia.
A fee of $28 includes a box lunch, morning coffee and a program. Students will be charged $10. The number for reservations or more information is 288-7996.
 
WHEN CHROME WAS KING
 Visitors might recognize their grandmother's chrome coffeepot, platter or bain-marie among the domestic items in the exhibition of Depression Metalware at the Mattatuck Museum, 144 West Main Street in Waterbury.
The array of chrome tableware, lamps, boxes, smoking accessories and other household goods, was manufactured in the 1930's and early 40's by the Chase Brass and Copper Company, which dominated Waterbury's economy for decades.
Advertised in The Saturday Evening Post, Good Housekeeping and House and Garden, the pieces were created by the era's top industrial designers, including Russell Wright, Walter VonNessen and Rockwell Kent. They provided housewives who had to double as cooks and hostesses, with the means of producing a cheaper method of home entertaining -- the self-service buffet.
A slide-lecture on the contents of the exhibit and the social changes wrought by the Depression, will be given by the museum's director, Ann Smith, on Tuesday at 7:30 P.M. Admission is free and the museum is open Tuesday through Saturday from 10 to 5, Sunday from noon to 5. The number for more information is 753-0381.
 
TALKING ABOUT WEATHER
 Appropriate to the Northeast's worst winter in memory, a four-part minicourse on the weather is being offered by the Holland-Brook Nature Center of the Connecticut Audubon Society this month.
"Forecasting Weather, From Folklore to New Technologies" is the title of the first session, to be led by Steve Newman, meteorologist and professor of physics and earth science at Central Connecticut State University, on Wednesday at 7:30.
Mr. Newman will again be in charge on Saturday, when he conducts a tour of the university's weather-tracking equipment in a program called "State of the Art Weather Forecasting." Carpools from the nature center will depart at 9 A.M., or participants may meet the group at the university in New Britain at 10 A.M.
"Weather for Fliers, Farmers and Gardeners" is scheduled on March 23 at 7:30 P.M. at the center. Charlie and Jolly Stephens, veteran seaplaners, will discuss the value of maximizing efficiency and safety through knowledge of prevailing winds, cloud formations, weather trends and seasonal variations.
On the same night Kirk Ducharme, from UConn's Department of Atmospheric Science, will talk about taking advantage of a large body of knowledge about the effects of weather on crops, relevant to preventing damage and destruction.
The final session on March 30 at 7:30 P.M. features Brad Field, meteorologist for WVIT-TV, and Sue Smith, member of the support crew for the 1991 New England Mt. Everest Expedition. The subject will be "Reporting the Weather, Forecasting and Disasters: and Weather for Trekkers." It will be held at the center, 1361 Main Street in Glastonbury. Admission to each program is $10, and the number for more information or to register for any or all sessions is 633-8402. ELEANOR CHARLES

 BROOKLYN

HEADLINE: Hampton, a Town Where Crime Stays on Holiday

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
THE town of Hampton, tucked away in the hills of Eastern Connecticut, is one of the state's lesser-known assets. The small community -- about 25 square miles, about 1,560 people -- still lists agriculture as its principal industry. You have to work to find it on Route 97, a former Indian path known as the Nipmuck Trail that curves and dips through the area.
But Hampton's main street is a scene out of a Currier & Ives lithograph: graceful 18th- and 19th-century homes, some with big attached barns, the Grange Hall, the general store, the Congregational Church with its steeple pointing to the sky. It is a pretty place. It is also -- in an era of drive-by shootings and other random and rampant violence -- the safest town in Connecticut. 
 The Connecticut Conference of Municipalities, which keeps track of the state's 169 towns, discloses in a new report that Hampton has the lowest per-capita crime rate of them all. The report, "Indicators of Need in Connecticut Municipalities," is based on statistics from the calendar year 1992. Crimes included are murder, rape, robbery, aggravated assault, burglary, larceny and motor vehicle theft.
 
Why Hampton, Indeed
 It's no surprise that the state's three biggest cities -- Hartford, New Haven and Bridgeport -- ranked No. 1, No. 2 and No. 3 in crime. But there at the end of the list, ranking 169, was Hampton, a place where crime seems be on holiday. Hartford's crimes -- 21,332 of them -- represented 16 percent of its population. Hampton's crimes -- a total of 9 -- represented considerably less than 1 percent.
Why Hampton?
It is not the smallest of towns; its population is about three times that of Union, Connecticut's most sparsely populated community. Nor is it the richest town, wallowing in money to spend on police and social services. Compared to the affluent enclaves of Fairfield County in Western Connecticut all the towns of Eastern Connecticut's Windham County are poor relatives. And even though Hampton is remote, a deterrent to crime in itself, so also are neighboring towns that have higher crime rates.
To get a line on how the town holds down its crime rate, the man to see is Walter A. Stone, First Selectman, Chief of Police, dairy farmer, self-acknowledged cheapskate when it comes to spending public money, and philosopher in residence.
If Hampton is a scene out of Currier & Ives, Mr. Stone is a character out of a Norman Rockwell painting, tall and spare and with wry opinions on life in the slow zone, on such subjects as getting re-elected or on keeping the town safe.
 
Now, About Spending and All
 Getting re-elected is easy. Just make sure you haven't spent too many dollars and that your town got full benefit from the ones you did spend. Hampton's town office building and its new elementary school are fine examples.
When the town built the elementary school, a brick and stucco structure of style and grace that is meant to last, the old wooden elementary school was converted into a new town office building at minimum cost. And since the basement in the office building wasn't being used, it was rented out to a small private school. That provided money to heat and clean and generally maintain the town offices. "We break even on the town office building," said Mr. Stone happily.
At 64, he is now serving his sixth consecutive two-year term running the town where he was born and where Stones have lived since the middle of the last century. His most recent election, in 1993, was a bit different than usual, however. "I had an opponent," said Mr. Stone. The local Democrats put up Robert McDermott, a retired school teacher, to run against Mr. Stone, a Republican, part of the bait being the opportunity to collect the annual First Selectman's salary of $8,750. Mr. Stone said the campaign was sort of dull: "He didn't say anything and I didn't say anything and I won." That's politicking, Hampton style.
When it comes to preventing crime, Mr. Stone and Hampton are equally low key, and seemingly effective.
While the town has no large industry, said Mr. Stone, it does have many cottage industries, such as a cooking school run out of one home, a lawyer who is also an antiques dealer, a corporate "headhunter" who has his office at home.
"These people are around all the time and they notice people who come into town," said Mr. Stone. "People really watch over each other here. If someone sees a strange car, they'll call me or one of the constables."
The constables, four of them, are elected every two years. "They don't do anything," said Mr. Stone, "but people see their names on the ballot and think they have some power." That's all right with him because it makes citizens feel more comfortable with the constables around.
 
Reining In the Overzealous
 He does not, however, want the constables to get any ideas about enforcement duties, particularly after an unfortunate incident several years ago. A young constable who was also a member of the volunteer fire department, came across a teen-ager riding a dirt bike illegally and gave chase in his fire department car, using the radio to notify anyone in range that he was in hot pursuit of the biker. Right slam on Route 97. Mr. Stone was not amused and told the constable to hand in his badge.
As the official Chief of Police of Hampton, although one without uniform or even a hat, Mr. Stone does have the power of arrest. Not that he plans to use it. On the rare occasion he really wants someone arrested, he calls the State Police barracks in the Danielson borough of Killingly. "They have one trooper who sort of looks after this town and a couple of others," he said. At the moment, though, he didn't have any idea of who the trooper might be because of personnel changes at the State Police barracks.
Mostly, fighting crime in Hampton is a psychological effort. The town has a watch committee that has posted signs all over to notify any bad guys who might decide that Hampton is easy picking that the citizens are on the alert.
When State Police do make an arrest in town, Mr. Stone admits, he tends to learn about it from reading area newspapers. "Usually, it's for fraud, or collecting unemployment compensation while working," the chief said. "I can tell you this, people don't go around beating each other up. That doesn't exist here." A murder in town? "I don't ever remember a murder."
The closest thing to a crime wave in Hampton, said its First Selectman, was last summer when some older boys used to gather at night to shoot baskets at an outdoor court at the grammar school. Somehow, the cover grate of a storm sewer drain had been dropped into the drain, presumably as a prank, and was resting several feet below. Mr. Stone dropped over one night to see the basketball players. One of the players, he said, told him that the cover was off the drain. "I said, 'It better be back on when I come back tomorrow night.' " It was.
 
If It Ain't Broke
 The one thing that mystifies the leader of the safe haven of a town is that people are always trying to change it. Not the people who have lived there all their lives. The newcomers.
"I say to these people, 'Why did you come here?' and they say 'Because we love it here.' So I say 'If you love it, why do you want to change it?' " Some things just don't make sense.
