HEADLINE: Commercial Property/International Design Center;
An Empty Feeling? Try Mixing Uses

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
IT seemed like a really great idea a decade ago: a huge, self-contained furniture mart, just across the East River from Manhattan, full of all the residential furniture anyone could ever want.
Then, when neither buyers nor sellers stormed the doors, Plan B seemed a surefire winner: Fill the showrooms with enough contract furniture -- the industry term for corporate furniture bought in bulk -- to make the place a must-visit destination for anyone outfitting an office. 
 Well, apparently "if you build it, they will come," to slightly misquote "Field of Dreams," works only in movies; they -- designers, architects, decorators, all the potential customers -- stayed away in droves.
Now the two-building, million-square-foot International Design Center in Long Island City is embarking on Plan C: It is trying to become a hybrid place, half furniture center, half business center, where administrative offices coexist with furniture showrooms.
Already it has moved all its furniture tenants into one building, enticing those who had to move with either bigger space or reduced rent. The New York City School Construction Authority has set up offices in the second building.
S.L. Green Real Estate, which was hired by the Bank of New York to manage the troubled center after the bank took control of the property last spring, plans to carve the 320,000 square feet of space left in that building into blocks of 60,000 square feet or so and market them for office use.
"We want people in midtown to view us as an alternative to leaving the city," said Arthur T. Katz, the center's senior vice president of leasing. "But we no longer expect tenants who rely on drop-in traffic. It has to be tenants whose employees come in and stay here until they go home."
Mr. Katz is acknowledging what the center's original conceptualizers did not: From the point of view of the Manhattan-based designers and executives who buy office furniture, the Design Center might as well be in Idaho. The nearest subway stop is a half mile away and the free shuttle buses the center provides to and from the subway didn't make up for the perceived inaccessibility. Nor did the free shuttle service over the traffic-snarled Queensboro Bridge to Third Avenue and 56th Street. Nor the ample on-site parking.
And, as the center's management and its hapless tenants have discovered, emptiness begets emptiness.
"Those customers who do come out here are upset because it feels so empty," said Irving M. Rosen, president of Cumberland Furniture, a Center showroom tenant. "It's like if you are the only customer in an expensive restaurant. Even if the food is good you somehow don't feel like going back."
It is an ignominious end for a project that in the boom times of the 80's held such promise. Back then, Manhattan's Architects & Designers building and its Design and Decorators Building, both on Third Avenue and 58th Street and both considered the places to go for furniture, were not only expensive, they were also full.
Meanwhile, there were these three adjacent factory buildings sitting empty in Long Island City, with big freight elevators that could accommodate furniture. So in the early 1980's New York City officials approached Harvey Schulweis, chairman of Lazard Realty and a general partner in the property, and offered him an enticing package of incentives to turn it into a furnitue center.
MR. SCHULWEIS went first class all the way. He hired the renowned architect I.M. Pei to create a master plan for the proposed design complex and the architects Charles Gwathmey and Robert Siegel to carry out that plan.
What they turned out was two buildings joined by covered bridges each with an enclosed courtyard, attractive and easily navigated staircases and huge corridors that make showroom-hopping easy. (The third factory was not part of the project and is now used primarily by LaGuardia Community College.)
Furniture folks quickly bought into the idea of getting tailor-made showroom space at annual rents of under $20 a square foot, half of what Manhattan space cost. Huge contract furniture companies like Steelcase and Herman Miller took long-term leases for showrooms. And smaller companies, figuring they'd benefit from the traffic that the big ones would generate, quickly followed suit.
By the mid-80's, more than 700,000 of the center's one million rentable feet of showroom space had been leased.
"Everyone expected that if you sold furniture the design center would be the only place to be," said Edward Carr, Steelcase's vice president for corporate services.
Although the leasing activity slackened off toward the decade's end, no one was worried much. Lazard figured it already had enough furniture makers to bring in customers, and it rented some 200,000 square feet of office space to the New York City School Construction Authority.
That prescient move may turn out to be the center's savior. The aftermath of the stock market crash of 1987 put the brakes on almost every corporate expansion plan, and thus on the corporate furniture business.
"Some of our tenants merged, some went bankrupt, some moved out in the middle of the night," Mr. Katz said.
The ones that stayed grew restive, as traffic to their showrooms grew negligible.
"The problem was the recession, but here, when things got slow, everyone blamed the building," said Catherine T. Giliberti, an executive vice president of the Center.
In fact, Manhattan's furniture sellers weren't having an easy time either. But their plight made things worse for the Design Center, not better. As the city went deeper into recession, affordable showroom space became available not only in Manhattan's design buildings but also in several buildings in Midtown south. And the annual rent per square foot for the space dropped to the low $20's or even the high teens, not much more than the Design Center was charging.
TO make matters worse, the city announced it was including a furniture center as part of the Times Square Redevelopment Project. Although that plan has since been tabled, the hoopla that surrounded it put the curse on the idea that, for furniture manufacturers, Long Island City was the place to be.
"Everything out here just ground to a halt," Mr. Katz said.
Today the center's white-tablecloth restaurant is closed due to lack of business, leaving a self-service cafeteria that closes at 4 P.M. as the center's only place to eat. The buildings are only half full, and not all of the current tenants are likely to stay.
Herman Miller, whose lease runs until 1997, has sued the center, saying that letting non-furniture tenants in is a breach of contract and voids their lease. A decision is expected soon.
"In some cities design centers work, in some they don't," said John R. Berry, a Herman Miller vice president. "This one was a disappointment."
Steelcase, whose lease expires in 1999, recently bought 4 Columbus Circle and may consolidate its six New York area showrooms there. Mr. Carr noted that all of Steelcase's New York leases will expire in the next few years and that it was "putting together a long-term strategy" about space; if it does not include the Design Center, many real estate experts say the center is doomed.
"Steelcase moving will probably be the center's coup de grace," warned Richard Maltz, chairman of the Queens real estate firm Greiner-Maltz.
Indeed, the smaller tenants are not certain they can survive if the industry leaders go. Yes, there are some die-hard loyalists, like John Calvano, executive vice president of Levine Calvano Associates, a furniture tenant, who calls the center "a first class facility" and "really conducive" to showrooms.
"Yes, the center has lost momentum," he said, "but if Manhattan rents go up again, it'll recover."
But not all tenants can wait that long.
"I'm between a rock and a hard place," said Mr. Rosen, who is wrestling with whether to renew the lease on Cumberland's 10,000 square feet when it expires in 1996. "I like it here, but I can't survive here alone."

HEADLINE: Why Military Contractors Covet Grumman

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

 BODY:
THE Grumman Corporation, the venerable Long Island military contractor whose future seemed dim, has suddenly emerged as a highly coveted jewel of the weapons industry. As Pentagon spending shrinks, the industry has consolidated, and there are few companies as big as Grumman left to buy -- or as willing to sell to survive.
The Northrop Corporation, a competing weapons maker based in Los Angeles, ignited a bidding war for Grumman last week, making a $2.04 billion offer, or $60 a share, that topped a $1.9 billion bid, or $55 a share, made earlier in the week by the Martin Marietta Corporation. 
 Northrop's bid, which is scheduled to commence tomorrow with a tender offer for Grumman's 33.9 million outstanding shares, raises the ante among weapons companies trying to gain the "critical mass" to survive in a fast contracting industry.
The bidding could go higher, in large part because Northrop, more than Martin Marietta, needs Grumman to keep itself from being taken over. In fact, on Friday, arbitragers were trading Northrop options as if they were in a takeover play.
"My bet is that Northrop will win Grumman in the end because they are hungrier. They need Grumman a lot more than Martin Marietta does," said Jon Kutler, president of Quarterdeck Investment Partners, a Los Angeles-based investment banking firm that specializes in the aerospace and military industries.
"Northrop has to make a decision: Either to exit the business or quickly gain capacity. This is a cornerstone event for them."
Behind the battle for Grumman is a growing recognition by weapons contractors that their industry is retrenching so quickly that they will have to leave markets in which they are marginal participants and acquire businesses in areas they can dominate.
While Martin Marietta has made several acquisitions in recent years, Northrop has made no major ones. And unlike Martin Marietta's, many of Northrop's weapons contracts expire later in the decade.
Since 1985, the Defense Department's budget has declined 64 percent, leaving too many competitors in a dwindling market where, industry experts said, resources are wasted and ultimately also-rans go out of business.
Last week, industry experts and analysts initially said that Martin Marietta's offer of $55 a share was on the high end of what Grumman was worth. But Grumman's shares closed Friday at $64.75, up from around $37, where they were trading a week before Martin Marietta's offer.
That indicates that investors expect the final price for the company to be even higher than Northrop's $60-a-share offer and also raises the possibility that other bidders could join the fray.
Wolfgang H. Demisch, an analyst for BT Securities, said that weapons industry stocks are generally valued at slightly less than 10 times their cash flow and that he had determined several weeks ago that Grumman was worth between $50 and $60 a share using that measure.
Mr. Demisch said weapons firms are valued more cautiously than other major industrial companies because they operate in a declining industry where revenue levels are expected to drop substantially in coming years as weapons programs reach maturity.
But some industry analysts said Grumman might command a price higher than $60 a share based on the company's strong cash flow, its contracts in military electronics programs, commercial aircraft structures and computer information systems and software, and the potential economies of scale achieved through a merger. Of great appeal is Grumman's joint surveillance target attack radar system, or Jstars, which allows the Air Force and Army to broadcast radar images gathered aboard an aircraft to commanders in the field.
Martin Marietta said last week that it has arranged $2.4 billion in financing for its merger with Grumman, a cushion that will allow it to raise its bid to $70 a share. However, Martin Marietta, which had sales of $9.44 billion last year, could bid much higher, depending on how badly it wants Grumman.
Northrop could push its bid to $82 a share, based on its credit line of $2.8 billion. But Northrop's chairman, Kent Kresa, has said repeatedly that the company will not overpay.
Acquiring Grumman is far more important to Northrop than it is to Martin Marietta, which has been among the most aggressive buyers of other weapons businesses. Martin Marietta, based in Bethesda, Md., bought the aerospace electronics division of the General Electric Company in 1992, and last year acquired General Dynamics Corporation's space booster business.
But for Northrop, the acquisition could be a matter of independence. Northrop has failed to make a major acquisition in the all-important military electronics area, which analysts believe shows the most promise for growth. The company needs an acquisition to compensate for a potential drop in its revenues later in the decade. Northrop, which had sales of $5.1 billion last year, makes the B-2 bomber, missiles, military electronics and parts for the F/A-18 jet fighter and the 747 wide body.
The company has said that its annual sales could drop to between $3 billion and $4 billion when the B-2 program ends in the late 1990's.
WHILE Northrop has a significant backlog of weapons business that will keep it afloat through the decade, it has few new contracts in the pipeline. Industry analysts said that by merging with Grumman, Northrop would attain the "critical mass" that it has been seeking in military electronics, commercial aircraft structures, computer and information systems, and airborne surveillance systems.
Northrop officials said that they were under no pressure to complete a major weapons acquisition but that they are doggedly pursuing Grumman because the two companies would have an extraordinary fit.
James G. Roche, Northrop's chief advanced development planning officer, said Grumman is particularly attractive because it has assets in each of three Northrop product areas: military aircraft, airplane sub-assemblies and electronics.
"We want this company because it's a three-fer," Mr. Roche said. "Instead of going out and trying to buy smaller companies that fit into each of these areas, we can get them all in one swoop."
For example, Mr. Roche said that there are great similarities and synergies in the systems integration work that Grumman performs on the Jstars surveillance program and Northrop's B-2 bomber, which is built to avoid detection by enemy radar.
In addition, Mr. Roche said that Northrop's acquisition of Grumman would provide for an orderly transfer of Grumman's expertise in building aircraft from one contractor to another.
With the end of the Navy F-14 Tomcat fighter, Grumman has been closing down its design and manufacturing facilities for tactical aircraft. Northrop, which is a major subcontractor for McDonnell Douglas on the FA-18 and for the Boeing Company on the 747 passenger jet, says that it is better equipped than Martin Marietta to exploit Grumman's aircraft infrastructure. Martin Marietta is no longer in that business.
But Martin Marietta officials also make a good case for synergies that result from a merger with Grumman. With its acquisition of General Electric's aerospace electronics business in 1992, Martin Marietta became the nation's largest military electronics supplier. Grumman would broaden and strengthen Martin Marietta's position.
"Who has the better fit? Right now I'd say it's a tossup and the case can be made in either direction," Mr. Demisch said. "But my guess is that if the real intent here is to shrink the defense base then there would be more rationalization with Martin rather than Northrop."
That would leave Northrop to be swallowed up, which would reduce the size of the industry even more.
No matter who wins Grumman, industry analysts said that there are still plenty of weapons businesses that are ripe for the taking and that the losing bidder could still acquire critical mass through several smaller deals. Among those companies with weapons businesses that are considered likely to be sold: ITT, Raytheon, Harris, E-Systems and Westinghouse.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Norman Augustine of Martin Marietta (left) and Renso Caporali of Grumman after their merger announcement. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Argentina: A Slow, but Rocky, Recovery

BYLINE: By Nathaniel C. Nash 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES

 BODY:
THE second half of 1992 was a time most traders on the Buenos Aires Stock Exchange thought they would never forget, when a soaring equities market, which had been fueled by foreign investor optimism over economic changes here, lost 65 percent of its value in four months.
But last month, as shares on this emerging market once again became the darlings of international mutual fund investors, up more than 20 percent in value for the year, memories appeared to be short. Argentine stocks could do no wrong -- until a series of local and international events caused a selloff. 
 In three days, the exchange's Merval Index plunged almost 20 percent, and the ghost of 1992 returned. There were rumors that Argentina's Economy Minister, Domingo F. Cavallo, the architect of its recovery and its stabilization plan, was about to resign.
Interest rates, which had been low for months, started moving up in response to increases in the United States by the Federal Reserve Board. And foreign institutional investors, who had fueled much of the run-up as Americans poured hundreds of millions of dollars into Latin American mutual funds, started liquidating some of their holdings.
Finally, local investors, who tend to buy heavily on margin and are more prone to speculate on short-term moves, rushed to get out. "Most people are of the opinion that emerging markets only go up and don't come down," said Christopher Ecclestone, a stock analyst and senior partner at Ecclestone Hickey & Company. "The last few days have been pretty traumatic for the investor here."
But stocks have been hard-hit almost throughout Latin America since mid-February, after experiencing big increases in January. The Mexican Stock Exchange, up 15.5 percent in January, has lost 16.8 percent of its value since early February. Chilean stocks, up 22 percent on the year by Feb. 4, have lost 10.5 percent. The Lima Stock Exchange, which was up almost 30 percent in mid-February, has lost 5.4 percent.
The only stock market mostly unaffected thus far is Brazil's, where prices are up 48 percent in dollar terms for the year. Brazilian stocks are less affected because local investors hold a much higher percentage of the stock than do foreigners, making the price less susceptible to outside influence.
Though in Argentina things looked bleak earlier this month, the panic of 1994 may have come to an end, and an abrupt correction may now turn into a slow, rocky recovery, analysts say. Since a 7 percent plunge in the market on March 1, the exchange's Merval index has experienced an uneasy stability. Last week, it fell 3.4 percent, to 603.22 points, down a total of 17.1 percent from its peak of 728 on Feb. 16.
Analysts say 1994 is different from 1992. Argentina is in its fourth year of stable prices; inflation was up 7 percent in 1993, and thus far this year it has been practically at zero. The economy is into its fourth year of expansion, with predicted growth of 6 percent for 1994.
Argentine President Carlos Saul Menem will almost certainly succeed later this year in changing the country's Constitution in such a way as to get himself re-elected in 1995, leading analysts to predict continued stability. They say that before next year's elections, the Menem Government will seek to stimulate the economy even more.
"I have every confidence that the buying will come back in once the market stabilizes a little bit, because there is a lot of interest in Argentina's economic program," said Walter Stoeppelwerth, head of research for Smith New Court in Buenos Aires. "Fundamentally, things look very good," he added.
Economic growth is registering on the quarterly reports of many Argentine companies, with December's corporate profits among the highest on record, analysts say.
And American companies that up to now have participated in the Argentine boom by buying into privatized Government-owned concerns are beginning to look at acquisitions. Nabisco, for example, has announced intentions to buy a $250 million to $300 million stake in one of the country's largest cracker and cookie makers, Terrabusi.
For stock pickers, the emphasis may be changing on the Bolsa. Though the two telephone companies, Telefonica and Telecom, have been the focus of foreign buying for months, as have the privatized Government oil company, YPF, and the largest industrial holding group, Perez Companc, many analysts see just moderate price increases on these stocks for the rest of the year, and have recommended they be put on hold.
Instead, they are focusing on smaller companies that serve two main domestic sectors -- food, underscored by Nabisco's interest in Terrabusi, and construction.
Mr. Stoeppelwerth likes Molinos Rio, a publicly traded unit of the conglomerate Bunge & Born. Molinos has brought in aggressive new management to cut costs and promote new quality brands. He sees profits rising 70 percent this year.
He and others are also pushing the building sector, because for the first time in decades mortgage credit is becoming available to middle-income Argentines. The chief beneficiaries should be two cement companies, Corcemar and Juan Minetti, analysts say.
"Though mortgage rates are still high by international standards, and maturities are short, every day they are coming down," said Augusto Marinozzi, head of research at Mildesa Servicios Bursatiles, a brokerage here. "Argentines have the idea that possessing a home is very good, so this should touch off a major increase in construction."

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
As in the Old Days, Americans Take On More Debt

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
CONSUMERS are borrowing and spending again. Last week, the Government reported that the outstanding total of consumer credit rose $6 billion in February, to $796.1 billion. Over all, the amount that consumers owe is up 7.1 percent over the last year, the most rapid increase since 1989, before the most recent recession.
Auto credit is coming back even more rapidly. Americans now owe $279 billion for cars, an increase of 7.8 percent over the last year. The last time auto credit rose that rapidly, Ronald Reagan was President. 
 That is a sharp turnaround from the early 1990's, when Americans were routinely paying back more debt than they were taking out. That hesitance to borrow was one of the big reasons the initial recovery from the recession was so slow.
Still, the current gains are hardly extraordinary by historical standards. Back in the mid-1980's, when interest rates were low and the economy was growing, double-digit gains in consumer credit were standard and taken for granted.
 FLOYD NORRIS

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Lending Is Easy, But Will They Pay It Back?

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
"CREDIT," as Tom Paine, the American revolutionary, once wrote, "is suspicion asleep."
Nowhere is the snoring louder than in the market for foreign debt. To be sure, there is some evidence that the public is not quite as enthusiastic as the investment bankers, but a lot of it is selling quite well. 
 Last week brought two extraordinary events in the sovereign debt market. First was a $500 million bond issue from the Bank of China, a government-owned operation. Buyers seemed to want the five-year bonds but to be dubious about the 20-year variety. The People's Republic had never before sold bonds of that maturity, and it appears that the decision to sell $100 million of such bonds was based more on what the bank wanted than on what the market demanded. Morgan Stanley, the lead underwriter, acknowledged that not all the bonds had been sold.
The other deal was Turkey's. There, a $1 billion issue that was being marketed by Salomon Brothers and Merrill Lynch supposedly was pulled from them and assigned to CS First Boston, which is said to have promised a lower interest rate. So far, CS First Boston has not announced plans to sell the bonds, and it won't comment on any of this.
Both deals show how eager Wall Street is to do business with governments these days. A decade ago, the very idea of underwriting debt for a country like China would have been laughed at. Now its debt is investment grade, and its 20-year bonds were priced to yield just 1.35 percentage points more than Treasury bonds.
Whatever you might think of Washington, it does have a dollar printing press, which makes it highly likely it will be able to meet its obligations. On the other hand, if the Bank of China were to default, there is no guarantee that Chinese courts would uphold an American judgment ordering it to pay.
The billion dollars raised by the Bank of China, said Huo Tuan Jie, a deputy general manager of the bank, will be used to finance a variety of energy, communications and transportation projects in China. Not the most liquid of investments in a pinch, but these days the words "emerging markets" bring out the greed, not the fear, on Wall Street.
The Chinese deal was sold as Secretary of State Warren Christopher was on his way to China to express concern over human rights abuses and to threaten to remove China's favored treatment as a trading partner unless things improve. The buyers seem to be unconcerned, pointing instead to the bank's solid balance sheet -- audited, as it happens, not by an accounting firm but by the bank's own accounting department.
It was only a few years ago that most of America's large banks took huge losses due to defaults by foreign governments that turned out to be worse credits than expected. But there's no similar danger here. To be sure, banks bought almost half the Bank of China bonds, but not for their own accounts. Instead, they put them in the trust accounts they manage for customers.

HEADLINE: Business Diary: March 6-11

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring 

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Grumman as Cinderella: From Loser to Belle of the Ball
With arms spending way down, the folks at the Pentagon certainly don't want a lot of huge, hobbled weapons makers littering the land, like rusting hulks of old war planes. So it fit their vision nicely last week when Martin Marietta agreed to buy Grumman for $1.9 billion. As its Pentagon contracts dried up, Grumman tried to make it in the real world, but could never quite manage. It can't be that much of a loser, though, because suddenly Northrop got into the act, raising the ante by offering $2.04 billion for it. That's $60 a share, but Grumman stock leapt to $64.75 on Friday -- yes, a bidding war's brewing. What's up? Clearly, even with shrinking budgets, there's still money in high-tech weaponry, and Grumman can be a big plus. But one thing doesn't change: whoever wins, a lot more jobs will disappear at Grumman, Long Island's largest corporate employer. 

 Fleet Goes for Efficiency
Many companies face a hard choice these days: Is it worth creating a brutal efficiency if it means firing thousands of loyal workers? Last week Fleet Financial decided it was. Even though profits have surged, it will cut a surprisingly high 5,500 jobs, more than a quarter of its banking staff; that includes 3,000 layoffs. But will surviving employees put heart and soul into almighty efficiency, or will they wonder if the person who used to be at the next desk is now flipping burgers? The layoffs are "painful," said Terrence Murray, Fleet's chairman, but he insisted the alternative would be to "put even more jobs at risk."
 
Thank You for Not Taxing
The thought of a 75-cent-a-pack increase in cigarette taxes alarms the tobacco industry. So much so, in fact, that on Wednesday some big tobacco companies shut their factories and bused workers to a Washington protest rally. The industry's grim vision: the tax would put 274,000 out of work. "You kill tobacco, you kill the whole East Coast," said one worker. Then there's the Surgeon General's grim vision: 419,000 smoking-related deaths in 1990. And a third view: a study last week in the Journal of the American Medical Association minimizes the impact of a smoking decline, saying cigarette money would be spent elsewhere, creating different jobs.
 
Second Thoughts at British Air
It sounded good: British Airways would pump cash into USAir, each would feed the other's flights, and the partnership would sparkle in a global sunset. But last week British Air, which has already chipped in $400 million for 24 percent of USAir, decided to cool it. It won't invest more -- it had planned $450 million more -- until USAir gets costs down. That pushed USAir, which has lost $1.8 billion since 1988, to go to its unions for more concessions; it may even have to mimic rivals by giving workers equity. One upshot of this falling-out: the United States wants more access to London's Heathrow, but with British Air no longer clamoring for more of USAir, America's lost some bargaining power.
 
Truce for Sculley and Spectrum
John Sculley and Spectrum have made peace, of sorts -- or at least they've calmed down enough to stop throwing things at each other. Mr. Sculley had sued Peter Caserta, Spectrum's chairman, saying Mr. Caserta had lured him aboard by hiding some nasty facts. And Spectrum fired back a lawsuit accusing Mr. Sculley of breach of contract for bailing out. But last week both sides dropped their suits. They wouldn't say why they'd backed off, but one reasonable theory has it that they'll need all their energy to battle class actions from shareholders, who say management inflated the stock price by painting a too-rosy picture of the promise of Spectrum's cellular technology. So, chapter closed, but not this bizarre book.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Satellite Pictures for All
America's got some pretty fancy technology for taking satellite pictures -- it can spot things as small as a few feet wide. The question is, should it be sold abroad? No, say some, giving the old national-security cry -- we can't let the likes of North Korea and Iraq get their hands on it. Nonsense, say others: the stuff's out there, so if we don't sell it, someone else will. Last week, the Administration came down on the side of commerce -- as it often does these days -- and said companies like Lockheed could sell spy satellite technology worldwide. The cold war recedes even further into memory's distant corners.
 
Media Mergers: Canada's Turn
Americans are not the only ones dreaming of multibillion-dollar media mergers, of dominating hot markets like cable television. In Canada last week, there was a media deal worth serious money: $2.5 billion. After five weeks of haggling, Rogers Communications agreed to merge with Maclean Hunter, creating Canada's biggest communications company. Rogers, Canada's largest cable operator, also runs various radio stations and a Toronto television station, while Maclean Hunter, No. 4 in cable, also has broadcasting and publishing interests.
 
Easing Tensions With Japan
The trade tension between the United States and Japan eased a notch last week. Even as Secretary of State Warren Christopher, on a visit to Tokyo, accused Japan of reneging on a broad promise to open its markets, one small but symbolic sticking point may have been worked out. Motorola and a Japanese company, I.D.O., reportedly made a deal that lets Motorola get a piece of Japan's cellular telephone business. Under the agreement, I.D.O. will build base stations that will work with Motorola technology, making Motorola a viable competitor. It could just be enough to head off trade sanctions threatened by the United States -- and who knows what other unpleasantness.
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Inflation? Here! There! Gone.
Bond traders these days must have powerful telescopic sights. They're jumping at imagined inflation so far in the distance that mere mortals couldn't possibly see it. Ever since the Federal Reserve nudged interest rates higher a month ago, rates have soared, with 30-year Treasury bonds yielding a full point more than they did in October. The market had a bad case of the jitters on Thursday, when rates roared to 6.95 percent, sending stock prices down in lockstep. But when the rate brushed up against 7 percent early Friday, traders said, Enough! Rates skidded back down to 6.90 percent, and the Dow charged ahead by 32 points. And inflation? Still not much in sight.
 
Municipal Bonds: The Facts
In recent years, a lot of people have discovered the joys of municipal bonds -- mainly, not paying tax on the interest. Individual investors, directly or through mutual funds, now account for 75 percent of this $1.2 trillion market, up from less than 45 percent a decade ago. But in many cases they've also discovered the horrors: a bond plummets in value when, out of the blue, bad news hits. Too often, in this lightly regulated market, investors don't know what they're buying -- and aren't told of events that affect their investment. The S.E.C. moved to fix this last week, proposing rules to keep investors better informed, like making issuers put out financial reports and disclose troubles. "This vital constituency," said Arthur Levitt Jr., S.E.C. chairman, must "understand what they are buying."
 
Nice 'Tips' for Co-op Managers
Tenants in Manhattan co-ops and condominiums often wonder where their maintenance checks go, and last week they got an unpleasant clue: they discovered that about 10 percent of their money could be vanishing in thin air. After a three-year inquiry, the Manhattan District Attorney's office said managers have regularly taken payoffs from contractors for work in the buildings. It's become routine, investigators said, like tipping the doorman. But these were substantial tips, with some managers said to have gotten as much as $250,000 over five years. As if living in New York weren't expensive enough.
 
Get Your 3-Cent Stamps Ready
Yes, yes, you'd gotten used to 29-cent stamps and all the multiples -- 20 for $5.80, and so on. But look at it this way: the Postal Service let us have an extra year before making us reprogram our postal thinking. By early next year, when the 32-cent rate it proposed last week takes effect, it will have been four years, not the usual three, since the price last rose (from 25 to 29). And that's just a 10 percent rise, not 16. But brace yourself for weeks of fiddling with 3-cent "make-up" stamps to add to those 29's you keep finding, then having a bunch of 3's left over, useless clutter. Why can't they just take the 29's as trade-ins? Car dealers do it. No, too simple. They've got two billion make-up stamps waiting to torment us.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A Navy surveillance plane at a Grumman plant on Long Island in 1992.. (Lois Raimondo for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3311 words

HEADLINE: The Games, Practice; the Money, Real

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: MELBOURNE, Fla.

 BODY:
THE crack of the bat, the chatter of players lazily chasing fly balls in pregame practice, the clamor of fans straining for a glimpse of their favorite slugger -- all that remains the same. But in many other ways, Space Coast Stadium, the 7,500-seat preseason home of the Florida Marlins that opened here last weekend, deliberately breaks with the tradition of spring training as an idyllic anachronism in the big business of professional sports.
An outer-space motif, in keeping with the nearby Kennedy Space Center, includes an 80-foot rocket outside the stadium, twin gantries that bracket the main entrance and a scoreboard that launches a giant baseball after a Marlin home run -- all monuments to the marketing savvy of H. Wayne Huizenga, the entertainment magnate who owns Blockbuster Entertainment as well as the Marlins. The prices are also out of this world for a spring-training stadium: box seats go for $12, compared with $8 charged by the World Series champion Toronto Blue Jays for their best spring-training seats, and there are even luxury suites, for $25,000 apiece a year. 
 Add a generous 20-year lease from Brevard County and land donated for the stadium by a local developer. All this gives the Marlins, an expansion franchise entering its second season, a spring-training arrangement that is regarded with envy by many established clubs.
With envy, and with a desire to do likewise. The other 27 Major League teams, facing player salaries now averaging more than $1 million a year and broadcast revenues that are about to plummet under new cable and television contracts, are themselves moving to milk the 30-odd preseason games for every dollar they can.
Increasingly, for example, they are playing hardball with the towns in Florida and Arizona that covet the wintering tourists that baseball attracts. Playing one town against another, they are winning favorable deals for new stadiums where the amenities approach those of their regular-season parks.
Take the New York Yankees. Eager to get out of Fort Lauderdale Stadium, which the team considers too small and too far from the other teams, the Yankees have spent the last five years looking for a deal, leaving a trail of ill will in their wake. Tampa now appears to be the closest to winning the team, with a deal to build a $17.5 million, 10,000-seat stadium.
The teams are also raising ticket prices to levels double those of just six years ago. They are cutting deals that give their spring-training hosts no share of the money from concessions, parking and advertising in billboards and game programs -- an amount that typically exceeds revenue from ticket sales -- while saddling the towns with debt. They are planning to raise their broadcasting revenue by televising more preseason games. They are scheduling more preseason games in cities outside Florida and Arizona. And they are forming partnerships in real-estate and other business ventures unrelated to baseball.
"Spring training used to be something casual that teams did for six weeks at a fairly low cost, fun but no big deal," said Charles C. Euchner, author of "Playing the Field: Why Sports Teams Move and Cities Fight to Keep Them" and a professor of political science at Holy Cross. "But the astute, aggressive business people who now run the game realize that spring training is one of those things that, if treated like a real business, can be a nice side venture for you."
Not everyone is happy about the new approach. Lower-income fans like local retirees, low-paid workers and children -- the economic backbone of spring training for years -- are being priced out of the market. Their place is being taken by companies that buy seats for their employees and clients and by more affluent out-of-state visitors who regard a $12 box seat for a spring-training game as a bargain compared with regular-season prices. The Marlins have only raised the ante with the introduction of the luxury suites.
"The old-timey spring-training feeling is already gone from a lot of places," Mr. Euchner said. "Most people think of sports as a proletarian activity, but clearly in recent years it's been very consciously directed at an upscale, suburban audience. Joe Lunchbucket can't afford a suite, but a law firm can, so they become the market."
True, revenues from spring training would not even cover the salary of a Barry Bonds or a Bobby Bonilla. Spring training generates only about 2 percent of a team's total revenues, according to Roger Noll, a professor of economics at Stanford University who wrote the book "Government and the Sports Business."
But increasingly the team owners recognize that they can do a lot better in the preseason and are shopping themselves around to Sun Belt communities until they find an attractive bidder.
Executives at many clubs think the Florida Marlins negotiated an ideal deal here in Melbourne, a city of 65,000 halfway up Florida's east coast. The Marlins' 20-year lease gives the team all the revenues generated by ticket sales, concessions, parking and paid advertising at Space Coast Stadium as well as the money from the 11 luxury suites. Brevard County owns the stadium, freeing the Marlins from possible tax obligations.
What is more, the team got the land on which the ballpark is built for nothing. Space Coast Stadium is part of a 65-acre parcel, valued at more than $1 million on the open market, that was donated by the Viera Company, a Central Florida land development company that also installed the necessary roads and utilities. Viera saw the team as an attraction for a planned community that is eventually expected to have 100,000 residents. Similarly, the New York Mets moved from St. Petersburg to Port St. Lucie in 1988 at the behest of the Thomas J. White Development Corporation, which saw the team as an attraction for its planned community.
"We hope that when people are looking at a game, they are also looking at us as a place to buy a second house, retire, or relocate their businesses," said Perry J. Reader, chief operating officer of Viera. "In economic development, things are so competitive that you need every edge you can get."
The Marlins also have an option to be a joint-venture partner with Viera in the development of a shopping center, golf courses or housing on the land around the stadium.
Similarly, an owner of the Boston Red Sox, Haywood Sullivan, became a partner in a $20 million condominium complex going up near the team's new stadium in Fort Myers. (He has since sold his interest in the team). And the Atlanta Braves, which are owned by Ted Turner, are negotiating with Palm Beach County for a new stadium in Jupiter that would be part of a planned community in which the team might also get a stake.
Built for $6.2 million, Space Coast Stadium will be used during the regular season by a minor league team owned by the Marlins. The Marlins also have the right to use the stadium for concerts and other events. The stadium is but a small part of Mr. Huizenga's entertainment empire, which also comprises Blockbuster Video, the Sound Warehouse and Music Plus record-store chains, film and television production companies, the Miami Dolphins football team, the Florida Panthers hockey team and Joe Robbie Stadium in Miami.
BREVARD COUNTY wanted the Marlins for the tourist dollars the team would attract, and county officials like the deal they got. The Marlins agreed to pick up the cost of operating and maintaining the ballpark, and to build their permanent minor league complex next door.
To be sure, "we don't get a cent" of the money the Marlins generate at the stadium, Tom Jenkins, the county administrator, acknowledged. "But we don't have to operate the stadium or subsidize it either." Total debt service on the park amounts to about $650,000 a year, but Mr. Jenkins said the costs of building Space Coast Stadium have "no direct fiscal impact on local residents" because construction was financed by adding a penny to the tax on hotel rooms.
 
The Yankees' Search
 The Yankees, despite their status as the most valuable franchise in baseball, have found the search for a new home difficult. An early candidate was Pasco County, just north of Tampa. After offering the team 100 acres of free land at either of two sites adjacent to Interstate 75, plus a generous financial incentives package and a pledge to build a $15 million stadium, county officials extracted what they describe as an oral commitment from the team to relocate there. But then, for reasons the county administrator, John J. Gallagher, says he still doesn't understand, Yankee management had a change of heart late in 1992 and backed out.
"It left a bitter taste in everybody's mouth when they broke their word," he said. "I learned that with these people, a deal is not done until it's done, and even then it's not done."
But Joseph Molloy, the Yankees' general partner, said there was no deal. "We had a conceptual idea that we needed to finalize," one that the Yankees' lawyers deemed unsatisfactory because of doubts about the county's ability to meet its financial commitments, he said.
THE Yankees soon made it clear that they were seeking a grander and more elaborate deal in Kissimmee, just south of Orlando. The team approached the Osceola County board with a proposal to build both a 12,000-seat stadium and a 30,000-seat concert amphitheater that would be run by the Nederlander Organization, a minority partner in the team. The project would have cost about $50 million, with the bulk of the cost to be borne by local government.
Osceola County passed on the idea. "The economics simply weren't there," said Bill Goaziou, the county manager. "In 30 days you don't get enough out of spring training to pay the interest on a $50 million project."
Of course, it didn't hurt that Drayton McLane, owner of both the Houston Astros, a team that already trains in Kissimmee, and a food-service company that does a lot of business locally, was irritated by the Yankees' gambit. "We weren't pleased with the idea of another team moving into our market," said Tim Bawmann, the Astros' director of Florida operations. "We have invested millions of dollars in Osceola County, and for them to bring the Yankees in would have done nothing but hurt our ability to survive in this market."
Mr. Molloy, the son-in-law of the Yankees' principal owner, George Steinbrenner, said that the "backroom politics" of "a good-old-boy network" contributed to the failure of the proposal. Asked whether he included Mr. McLane in that group, he replied: "No comment."
Rebuffed, the Yankees then looked north across the county line, to Orlando. But to officials there, the Nederlander amphitheater proposal was a deal breaker. "They said, 'Give us the land, we'll put up the facility and keep all the revenues, and you can build the road,' " said Bob Haven, the Orlando city administrator. "It would have walked events straight out of our arena, and besides, we just weren't interested in subsidizing their operation."
Tampa, where Mr. Steinbrenner has long lived and operated his shipbuilding company, had always been in the running. But when Mr. Steinbrenner returned to baseball last spring after a three-year suspension, the city quickly moved to the top of the team's list. Tampa, which has had no spring-training team since the Cincinnati Reds left in 1988, has offered not only to build a 10,000-seat stadium but also to relinquish all revenues from concessions and parking at the Yankees' games.
But the Tampa deal hinges on the city's ability to put together a complicated real estate swap that, because it involves state land, must be approved by the governor and his cabinet. If the issue is not resolved by April 15, either side can walk away from the deal.
 
Others on the Move
 The Yankees are only one of many teams to want more than they have. Over the last decade, half of the 20 teams that play in Florida's Grapefruit League have moved to new towns. The Boston Red Sox, for instance, jumped last year from Winter Haven and its old 4,500-seat park to a vastly more profitable deal at a new 6,800-seat stadium, expandable to 10,000 seats, in downtown Fort Myers. Several teams, including the Baltimore Orioles and Atlanta Braves, are searching for new homes.
In Arizona, where the eight-team Cactus League plays, the situation is similar. The departure of the Cleveland Indians to Florida after the 1992 season and lucrative offers made to the Chicago Cubs, historically the biggest draw in Arizona, came as a wake-up call, said Joe Garagiola Jr., a Phoenix lawyer who is chairman of the Arizona Baseball Commission. The state has responded by imposing a $2.50 surcharge on car rentals in counties where Major League teams train and using that money to improve existing ballparks or build new ones, like the $30 million complex in the Phoenix suburb of Peoria that opened this month and is shared by the San Diego Padres and Seattle Mariners.
"As teams here have seen the new facilities in Florida and what the teams there have, they have told us they need something similar," Mr. Garagiola, son of the well-known sports announcer, said. While no team has threatened to move, he added, "they don't need to say that" to make the message clear.
TEAMS are also generating more revenue by taking their spring-training show to cities outside the traditional circuit, where they can charge prices close to those of the regular season and fill big stadiums. This weekend, for instance, the Toronto Blue Jays and Atlanta Braves, rivals in the 1992 World Series, flew to Toronto for a two-game set at the Skydome, the Blue Jays' regular season home, that is expected to draw 80,000 fans. The Braves, Orioles, Indians, Marlins, Minnesota Twins and Texas Rangers are also scheduled to play exhibition games at their regular-season parks, and other teams will play in Vancouver, New Orleans and Washington.
Because cities in Florida and Arizona are eager to reap the prestige and the perceived economic benefits that come from having a Major League team as a tenant, most stadium rents are quite low: the 30-year deal that the Yankees have tentatively negotiated with Tampa calls for them to pay only $75,000 a year for the first five years, for instance.
Smaller towns in particular seem willing to make concessions. Studies prepared for the Florida Commerce Department and the Arizona Baseball Commission estimated that the six-week season triggers more than $600 million in spending in the two states, most of it in small Florida towns looking to baseball to attract visitors who would normally go only to Orlando or Miami.
"If you look at the trend of spring training over the last 10 years, the teams have gone out of big cities to smaller towns where they function like an anchor in a shopping mall," said Rick Nafe, executive director of the Tampa Sports Authority. "Miami, Orlando and Tampa all let teams go, because they couldn't match the offers of smaller communities for whom spring training is their only tie to professional sports."
 
 
 
IS SPRING TRAINING PROFITABLE?
 DO Major League teams make or lose money on spring training? That's a matter of debate.
The teams themselves say they make no money from the preseason games. "There are no profits in spring training," said John Schuerholz, general manager of the Atlanta Braves. Referring to the new kinds of deals being struck by teams, he added: "You have to have these new deals just to minimize your losses. The function of spring training is to try to bring in as much money as you can so that you limit what you lose."
That claim cannot be verified because the 28 Major League teams historically do not make their income statements public and each uses slightly different accounting methods. But many independent analysts disagree with Mr. Schuerholz. "I think the teams are probably making a lot of money because there is quite a bit of money to be made," said Andrew Zimbalist, a professor of economics at Smith College and the author of "Baseball and Billions: A Probing Look Inside the Big Business of Our National Pastime." "You are selling out most games at ever higher ticket prices, you're getting a healthy chunk of concessions, advertising and parking, and your player salary expenses are virtually nonexistent" because players generally do not receive extra pay for preseason games.
Indeed, a team's revenues during spring training can exceed $2.5 million, depending on the size of the park and the contract each team has with its host city. By contrast, the average operating cost of spring training per team in 1991 was a mere $750,000, according to a study commissioned by the Florida Commerce Department.
 
 
 
YOU'LL NEED A SCORECARD AND A MAP
 Many baseball teams are on the move in Florida, seeking better deals for spring-training stadiums.
 
BALTIMORE ORIOLES: Left Miami in 1990; still searching for greener pastures. Perched first in Sarasota and Bradenton, now in St. Petersburg, sharing quarters with the St. Louis Cardinals.
 
 BOSTON RED SOX: Felt Chain O'Lakes Park in Winter Haven was too small and too old and moved last year to a new stadium in Fort Myers, built at a cost of $22 million to the team's specification.
 
 CINCINNATI REDS: Wanted a better park and a more secure lease than in Tampa, which might have evicted the team for a Major League franchise. But did not want to lose convenience of being part of an eight-team cluster in the Tampa Bay area. Solution: a 1988 move to Plant City, 25 miles to the east.
 
 CLEVELAND INDIANS: Leaving Arizona, planned to move last year to a bigger, newer park in Homestead, Fla., to be closer to the Midwest fan base. But Hurricane Andrew forced the team to Central Florida for a stay that turned out to be permanent when Winter Haven trumped Homestead's offer, and the Indians invoked an "act of God" clause.
 
 FLORIDA MARLINS: Expansion team moved this month to a new stadium in Melbourne.
 
 HOUSTON ASTROS: Left old park in the Cape Canaveral area in 1985 for a new stadium in Kissimmee, near Disney World. Staved off an attempt by the Yankees to invade their turf.
 
 KANSAS CITY ROYALS: Left Fort Myers for Haines City, south of Orlando, in 1988, after Fort Myers officials refused to spend $2 million to upgrade the stadium. Hoped to benefit in the new location from an association with the adjacent Boardwalk and Baseball theme park, but the project fizzled, and the team is said to be looking for a new home.
 
 MINNESOTA TWINS: Left Orlando in 1990 when the city felt their demands had become exorbitant. Found a home in Fort Myers, which was smarting from the departure of the Royals and was willing to spend $18 million to build a stadium.
 
 NEW YORK METS: Tired of playing second fiddle to the Cardinals in St. Petersburg, jumped in 1988 to a new park and a sweetheart of a deal on Florida's Atlantic Coast, setting up shop near the winter home of the owner, Nelson Doubleday, and reinvigorating a rivalry with the Dodgers. In the process, pioneered the now-popular idea of using a baseball team as an anchor of a real estate development and persuaded many New Yorkers to buy retirement or second homes in the area.
 
 NEW YORK YANKEES: Eager to leave Fort Lauderdale, complaining stadium complex is too small. Team has a tentative agreement to move to Tampa, which happens to be where the principal owner, George Steinbrenner, lives and works.
 
 TEXAS RANGERS: Triggered the recent exodus of teams from South Florida by leaving Pompano Beach for Port Charlotte on the Gulf Coast in 1987. Move to fastest-growing county in Florida allowed team to move from under the shadow of the more popular Yankees and Orioles, which themselves later abandoned the Miami area themselves.

HEADLINE: On Reducing Employees' Trips

 BODY:
This is in response to a letter to the New Jersey editor on Feb. 20, regarding the article "New Rules Nudging Companies to Reduce Employee Commuting."
The letter states that drivers who "putt along in line" (drive at 55 m.p.h.) will cause accidents by crossing from the High Occupancy Vehicle (H.O.V.) lane through lanes of speeders to an exit lane, and, further, that increasing the speed limit to 65 m.p.h. would improve traffic flow, fuel economy and safety. 
 Traffic flow is improved if all vehicles travel at the speed limit, but if you are a good driver and allow a safe stopping distance between vehicles, there will be fewer cars on any given part of the highway as the speed limit is increased. Air resistance reduces fuel economy drastically at high speeds, which is why the 55 m.p.h speed limit was introduced in the first place.
Safety is of primary concern, since accidents not only destroy lives and cost billions of dollars, but also are a major cause of fuel waste and pollution when miles of traffic sit and wait to get by the scene.
Don't get rid of the 55 m.p.h. speed limit; enforce it! While patrolling the H.O.V. lane, the police could issue summonses (with serious point value) to anyone observed passing a vehicle traveling at the speed limit.
If you eliminate this passing, you eliminate the excuse everyone uses for speeding. Under these conditions, changing lanes from left to right will still be difficult, but could be done safely using care and courtesy.
 
VINCENT P. LOSGAR
North Arlington

HEADLINE: A Little Postal Perspective, Please

BYLINE: By BARTH HEALEY 

 BODY:
When the cost of mailing a letter rises next spring to 32 cents, as it almost certainly will, postal rates will finally get back to where they were in 1799. That's right, 195 years ago. The increase was proposed on Tuesday by the governors of the United States Postal Service, and was welcomed by all the important lobbying groups that influence rate changes.
 In 1799, when rates varied according to distance, it cost 31 cents to send a letter from Boston to Savannah, for example. And that was real money -- the same price as a pitchfork, a bundle of quill pens or three or four shots of rum in a tavern, according to historians at Old Sturbridge Village in Sturbridge, Mass. 
 The rates had been much higher before establishment of a common currency in the United States. And they rose later, in 1815, when a Boston-to-Savannah letter cost 43 1/2 cents. But as delivery became more efficient, prices tumbled.
 In 1847, when the United States first issued stamps, there were two rates: 5 cents for delivery within 300 miles and 10 cents beyond. (Before stamps, and for many years thereafter, postmasters just wrote the amount paid on the envelope.)
 Then, in 1863, a uniform nationwide delivery charge was set at 3 cents, not to rise again for 95 years, surely a record for holding the line on costs. Indeed, the rate fell further, to 2 cents in 1883. Ther was a 1-cent "war tax" on letters in 1917-19 to help support American troops in World War I, but the basic rate stayed at 2 cents until 1932. BARTH HEALEY

GRAPHIC: Photos: 1756 -- First handstamp in the United States, used between New York and Falmouth, England; 1815 -- Example of postal charge written on envelope by a postmaster (25 1/2 cents for 150 to 300 miles); 1847 -- First U.S. paper stamp; 1919 -- Allied victory stamp; 1973 -- First "Love" stamp.
 
Graph tracks the cost to mail a basic letter since 1799. The figures are not adjusted for inflation.
 A letter used to be a large financial commitment: 31 cents in 1799 was about half a day's wage; 5 cents in 1847 represented 20 minutes' work. Prices became more reasonable in this century: 1919's 3 cent stamp was worth about 3 minutes' work for the average American; 8 cents in 1973 was less than 2 minutes' worth of work. If a first-class stamp goes to 32 cents next year, it will still be the equivalent of less than two minutes' worth of work. (Sources: Linn's World Stamp Almanac; Historical Statistics of the United States)

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
A Decade of Disillusionment in Grenada

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: ST. GEORGE'S, Grenada

 BODY:
NEARLY a decade before the United States began grappling indecisively with what peacekeeping or peacemaking roles it might undertake in the post-cold war world, there was Grenada.
Small and close to home, Grenada was not Somalia or Bosnia. People were not starving or being shelled. But there was political turmoil. An authoritarian and unelected leftist government under Prime Minister Maurice Bishop, who was respected by Grenadans but demonized by the Reagan Administration, was under attack from more radical hard-liners within its own camp backed by the Cubans and Russians. 
 The hard-liners were responsible for the massacre of Mr. Bishop and scores of his supporters on Oct. 19, 1983. Less than a week later, American troops came ashore. Grenadans, shocked by the carnage that consumed what they call The Revolution, welcomed the Americans. Order was restored at little cost to the United States. Mr. Bishop's killers, led by his deputy, Bernard Coard, were imprisoned. The Yankees went home.
What followed illustrates the limits of a peacemaker's role in rebuilding a nation, even a relatively advanced one, where there is a history of parliamentary democracy, an atmosphere of old-fashioned civility, fertile soil, clean drinking water and no slums.
Grenada and its 95,000 people are in political and economic stagnation, by most accounts. Distrust persists between the majority of African descent and the mixed-race or lighter-skinned intellectual and business elite. Aid from the United States, Canada, Britain, France, Taiwan and Japan has not appreciably altered living standards. In short, democratic Grenada has not taken off, except for growth in tourism. Young people are resentful and restless.
"I think that about 40 percent of the people in this country have lost all confidence in politics and politicians," said Randolph Mark, a retired civil servant and amateur historian who a decade ago was part of an interim government responsible for putting Grenada back together again.
 
Wanting to Look Back
 Partly in despair, partly from a need for reconciliation and healing after the disruption of the revolutionary years, Grenadans often seem to look backward for solutions.
All around Grenada there are signs that a virtual cult has grown up around the Bishop legend, though this has not translated into political power. The Maurice Bishop Patriotic Movement has been unable to get more than about 4 percent of votes in national elections. Nevertheless, the new road to the largely Cuban-built airport that so mesmerized the Reagan Administration, which saw it as a potential Soviet-bloc base, is about to be named the Maurice Bishop Highway. (All former prime ministers qualify to have a road named after them.) At the National Museum, young men stand before and sometimes salute Mr. Bishop's photograph in a small corner display devoted to his era.
Alban Daniel, a freelance tour leader, was a teen-ager in the revolution. He remembers how the Cuban-trained militia came for him because he refused to join the army after finishing high school. "They put a gun at each ear, and one pointed up my nose, and I enlisted," he said. "But I got to see the good things in the army. The Cubans taught us a lot. They gave us training and jobs. And in the revolution if you took cocaine you were shot, no trial, no nothing. Drug-taking stopped. Now it's back all over."
Alister Hughes, a writer and publisher of an independent newsletter who was perennially harassed and finally jailed by the left-wing government, says that many young people live on the Bishop legend "because they were somebody in that period." In the swagger that came with a new uniform and a gun or the pride taken in a Cuban higher education, self-esteem rose in a generation with few other outlets. For their parents, a national insurance plan and make-work programs helped cushion a hard life.
Mr. Hughes remembers the shouts of the young people, many no more than schoolchildren, who helped rescue Mr. Bishop from house arrest. As the youths marched through the town, they chanted proudly that they had saved their leader. But hours later, he was recaptured and put to death.
That generation, now disillusioned and leaderless, faces an unemployment rate over 30 percent and as high as 50 percent for the better-educated.
More astonishing to a visitor returning after 10 years is the resurgent political strength of Sir Eric Gairy, who dominated public life from independence in 1974 to the 1979 Bishop-led coup that overthrew his government. As Prime Minister, Sir Eric communed with extraterrestrials and enforced his earthly will through a villainous armed squad known as the Mongoose Gang. His record won converts to Mr. Bishop's radicalizing vision. Now nearly blind and in his 70's, Sir Eric is expected to be a force in the election that the present Prime Minister, Nicholas Braithwaite, must call in the next 12 months. It will be the third democratic election since 1984.
Both Mr. Mark, now a farmer near Grenville, on Grenada'a Atlantic coast, and Mr. Hughes, in his study overflowing with books and papers on a hillside above St. George's' sheltered Caribbean lagoons, suggest that the fascination with the recent past reflects a still unfulfilled Grenadan yearning for identity and purpose. Mr. Hughes has long argued that islands like this, with African, European, Asian and Arawak or Carib Indian influences, should consciously strive to create a distinctive regional culture he calls "Westindian," spelled as one word.
Mr. Mark says that Grenadans need to get to know themselves better first. He pleads for more attention to the collective histories of a people who passed from slavery to plantation drudgery to independence with scant sense of their own worth or ability to set their own priorities. In that atmosphere, a kind of national attitude of dependency, ideological or economic, can persist.
"Generations have come, and generations have gone, and there's no single record of a life story," he said as he brought out a typescript of an unpublished autobiography, "Sixty Years of Struggle to Survive." The story of Mr. Mark's life, begun as a child laborer in the plantations, would resonate widely in the West Indies. "My mother bought our first house for $6," he said. "It was made of swordfish boxes and galvanized metal. It was so small we six couldn't all be in it at the same time."
Mr. Mark, who became an M.B.E. (Member of the British Empire)in 1985, sees a fundamental need for a closer relationship between islanders and the fertile land that could support them, even when export crops like nutmegs and bananas have taken a price battering. But to return to the land means confronting an older, more painful legacy. "The stigma of our past history of slavery is still with us," he said. "Work in agricultural labor is linked to that."
Meanwhile, in the streets where jobless young men hang out, a common reply to the greeting, "How goes it?" is, "Day pon try," which in the local patois means roughly, "I'm still trying." Ten years after the Americans left, the phrase has special meaning.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
West's Fears In Bosnia: 1) Chaos 2) Islam

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

 BODY:
LATE last year, the peace negotiator Lord Owen addressed an issue that has seldom been openly discussed but has rarely been far from European politicians' minds during the Bosnian war. "The European Union," he said, "has no reason to be suspicious or to fear a new Muslim state emerging within Europe. For Europe over the centuries has been enriched by Islam."
The sense of that enrichment, evident from Cordoba in Spain to Sarajevo, has, however, been dimmed by more pressing concerns. Rising Islamic militancy in neighboring Algeria, a steady flow of Muslim immigrants across the Mediterranean from North Africa and explosive racial tensions in cities short of jobs have produced a thinly veiled anxiety in Western Europe over the potential radicalization of a Muslim-led Bosnia. 
 This anxiety, like some ghost of ancient fears of the Terrible Turk against whom Europeans fought for centuries, has been an unspoken subtext throughout the talks on how to end the Bosnian war. For all the horror over the "ethnic cleansing" of Muslims from land that Serbs covet, Europeans have never been ready to fight to preserve a Bosnian state led by Muslims.
"What many in my party fear is the emergence of a kind of Gaza strip in the midst of the Balkans," said Pierre Lellouche, a Gaullist member of the French Parliament. "There's a widespread view that an isolated Muslim entity would not be viable, and that a drift to radical Islamic politics would follow."
Mr. Lellouche spoke after returning from a hectic overnight stay in his constituency in the Paris area, Garges-les-Gonesse, which he described as "Beirut." A night-long riot, involving the burning of more than 20 cars and the destruction of several buildings including a synagogue, shook the area last week following the murder of a 16-year-old Vietnamese boy. When a police sweep followed, hundreds of youths took to the streets in what Mr. Lellouche called "a kind of Parisian intifada."
"Any pretext is good for a riot," the deputy added. "Thirty-eight percent of the people in Garges are either unemployed or on minimum welfare. In this context, what panics us in France is the vision of hundreds of thousands of Algerians fleeing a fundamentalist regime. We wouldn't know where to put them and we wouldn't know how to employ them."
Viewed from the United States, rioting in Paris suburbs and the savage Algerian war between Muslim fundamentalists and the military-backed Government may appear to have little or nothing to do with the plight of the generally secular Slavic Muslims of Bosnia.
But in an anxious, recession-hit continent just across the Mediterranean from an Algerian conflict that has claimed 2,000 lives in two years, the issues have tended to coalesce. Jacques Chirac, the Gaullist leader, has even referred to "les odeurs d'Islam" -- "the whiff of Islam" -- permeating the French urban landscape.
"The Germans, British and French have consistently shared some concern about a Muslim state in Europe," said a State Department official. "I think they feel somewhat reassured by recent developments."
The official is referring to the United States-brokered agreement between Bosnia's Muslims and Croats to set up a federation of semi-autonomous cantons and eventually join this to Croatia in a loose confederation. Because this arrangement is bi-national, "it finesses some of the European concerns," said Marty Sletzinger, a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee staff.
Important questions remain, however. To what extent have the Serbian and then Croatian campaigns of "ethnic cleansing" against the Muslims during almost two years of war radicalized a population that initially identified only slightly, if at all, with Islam? Has the West, by its passivity during the conflict, encouraged precisely the move toward Muslim militancy that it proclaimed to fear? And to what extent has President Alija Izetbegovic's Muslim-based Party of Democratic Action became divided between hard-liners now favoring something close to an Islamic state and others still committed to a secular, multi-ethnic society in Bosnia?
The fact that some drift toward Islamic militancy has occurred in Bosnia, particularly outside Sarajevo, seems clear. After all, whatever arms and money have reached the Muslim-led government forces have tended to come from Muslim countries.
In the area around Travnik in central Bosnia, the scene of bitter fighting last year and the base for many of the Muslim dispossessed driven out of northern and eastern Bosnia by the Serbs, there have been persistent reports of new regulations imposing the use of the veil on women, and resort to Islamic indoctrination in some schools and army brigades. This is also the area where the United Nations has identified several hundred soldiers believed to be from Iran and Afghanistan, who have often shown a particular brutality, as in the recent killing near Vitez of a British aid worker.
 
A Trend Without Depth
 However, the trend appears to be superficial. "These people are Bosnians and Europeans, but the more the fighting goes on, the more the roots of fundamentalism will dig in with a Farrakhan-like indoctrination imported from the outside," said John R. Lampe, director of East European studies at the Woodrow Wilson Center. "My view is that the fundamentalism in Bosnia remains thin and if there's a settlement, it would fade."
Dominique Moisi, the deputy director of the French Institute for International Relations, was less optimistic. "By doing nothing, we have created a self-fulfilling prophecy," he said. "In desperation, the Bosnians have been pushed toward a more radical Islam. The trend is strong and all hope of a multiethnic Bosnian society has been smashed."
The Clinton Administration now hopes to revive the multi-ethnic dream by extending the Muslim-Croat federation to embrace the Serbs. But the Serbs, who control 70 percent of the territory, have fought to be separate and are unlikely to be drawn in. This impasse in turn appears likely to test the divisions within Mr. Izetbegovic's government and army.
Hard-liners, like Vice President Erup Ganic and some of the army commanders in central Bosnia, would certainly oppose letting the Serbs secede, even if they first gave back wide tracts of land. They argue that Muslims have been fighting, above all, for the right to return to all towns seized by the Serbs. But Prime Minister Haris Silajdzic would probably be more ready to compromise in the interest of peace.
Such divisions mirror emergent splits in Bosnian society between secular Europeans and others whom persecution has now driven toward a vision of Islamic society. The faster the war ends, the less likely these splits are to go wider, both within Bosnia and in Europe as a whole. "There is a European interest in having a state in the heart of the continent where Muslims and non-Muslims live together," said a senior White House official. "For concerned Arab countries elsewhere in the world, that would be a powerful symbol."
