LENGTH: 1860 words

HEADLINE: A Winter of Disaster Leaves the Bills to Prove It

BYLINE: By ASHLEY DUNN 

 BODY:
It wasn't a hurricane or an earthquake, but the winter of 1993-94, which is now entering its final full calendar week, has become a disaster of its own sort, leaving a trail of damage, hardship and bitter memories whose effects will be felt for years in the eastern half of the United States.
Spread over three months, the winter has ebbed and flowed, striking with fury one day, only to give way to days of sunshine. Seemingly relentless, the series of 16 snow and ice storms that have battered the East and Southeast are an unconventional disaster, but one that nonetheless ranks among the worst to have hit the country in recent years. 
 Insurers estimate that they will eventually pay over $1 billion for damage caused by the storms, ranking it above the $900 million for the fires in California last October and the $775 million for the Los Angeles riots in 1992.
 
Benefits for Some
 Yet some businesses, whose products and services thrive in harsh weather, have experienced a boom, while still others, which suffered short-term losses from the frigid weather, expect that demand will prove elastic over time, snapping back as the weather becomes more moderate.
John Skorberg, an economist for the Chicagoland Chamber of Commerce, said the cold spell had actually turned out to be positive for some parts of the local economy. "The retailers who sell clothing, batteries and utilities did better than anticipated," he said. "But malls and small retailers who had to rely on foot traffic were hurt."
The meteorological pattern of this winter's storms has been unconventional, experts say.
While the National Weather Service has recorded at least 18 all-time low temperatures, including 21 degrees below zero in Detroit on Jan. 19 and a minus 50 in Amasa, Mich., on Jan. 18, this winter, over all, will not make the record books when it officially ends at 3:28 P.M. on March 20.
"Astronomically, it's the end of winter, but meteorologically, not really," said Joe Venuti, a meteorologist at Pennsylvania State University. "It's not safe to say we've seen the end of snow."
Indeed, a storm blew east across northern New Mexico yesterday, dropping eight inches of snow on the mountains, Mr. Venuti said; it could reach the southeastern states later this week.
Richard Tinker, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service's Climate Analysis Center in Washington, said: "We've seen some of the coldest air that has ever invaded this part of the world. But then you go and look at the averages, and it's cold but nothing unbelievable."
Much the same applies to moisture. Snowfall records were set in several places around the country, like Boston, which recorded a season total of 89.5 inches. While New York City has so far had a season total of 50.3 inches -- the most in 16 years -- that is still far below the record 63.2 inches that fell in the winter of 1947-48. In many other areas, like the Great Lakes region, which has so far had its 25th driest winter in a century, combined rainfall and snowfall is actually below normal.
Taken in total, the storms have gradually exacted an enormous toll that mounted in small and large ways, from the addition of 14 minutes a day for Philadelphia high school students because of snow closures to the temporary loss of power to 1.5 million Pennsylvanians after a January ice storm.
Philadelphia spent $1 million to demolish 209 buildings, most of them unoccupied, that had become safety hazards as a result of storm damage. In New York, the city lost about $6.5 million in parking fines because of the snow. In Mississippi, pecan orchards throughout much of the Delta were devastated by an ice storm. Crop losses there could be as much as $7 million a year for the next five years, said Freddie Rasberry, a horticulturist at Mississippi State University.
 
Sizable Loss
 For many business owners, the days of lost work and dampened sales have built into a sizable loss that some may never recover. "It's been a nightmare," said Gregory M. LoVece, a 40-year-old clam harvester from Blue Point, L.I., who was only able to gather a quarter of his usual harvest. "Our men are running to Florida, the Carolinas, anywhere there is money to be made. You can't work here because the weather conditions are too adverse."
Municipal governments have scrambled to deal with budgets drained by snow-removal costs, and throughout the freeze zone an oppressive sense of desperation has mounted throughout the winter's prolonged assault.
Unlike disasters whose damage is measured in buildings and homes destroyed, most of this winter's damage is in the form of small claims -- broken pipes, damaged roofs and fender benders. "A lot of homes have sustained a little bit of damage, but the cumulative effect is huge," said Steven Goldstein, a spokesman for the New York-based Insurance Information Institute.
 
113 Deaths
 The economic loss from days of canceled work and diminished sales has accumulated over the past three months, and some economists believe it may ultimately exceed the $12 billion to $30 billion wrought by the Los Angeles earthquake two months ago.
At least 113 deaths were linked to the winter weather -- mostly car accidents and heart attacks from shoveling -- surpassing the combined total of last year's Midwestern floods, in which 48 people died, and Hurricane Andrew, in which 56 died two years ago.
Even for regions accustomed to ice and cold, this winter's freezing temperatures were stunning.
In the tiny New Hampshire town of Stewartstown, just a few miles south of the Canadian border, the temperature dropped so low late last month that sections of the town's water pipes froze, effectively cutting the supply to many homes, businesses and municipal buildings, like the grammar school.
 
Spring Around the Corner
 "They say spring is just around the corner, although no one is saying just how long that corner is," said the town's Water Commissioner, Robert Burns, who figured that much of the underground piping could remain frozen solid until late spring.
In Pennsylvania, state officials had to borrow four ice breakers from the Coast Guard to get fuel oil to the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania after the Delaware River froze.
One of the hardest-hit areas was a swathe of southern states struck by a two-day ice storm that began on Feb. 9 and destroyed crops, snapped power lines and left hundreds of thousands of people without electricity.
In Mississippi, total damage to public facilities exceeded $1.3 billion, and 26 counties were declared Federal disaster areas. Ed Jussely, a spokesman for the Mississippi Power and Light Company, said 4,111 miles of power lines had been knocked down by the weight of ice. The cost of repairs could be as high as $100 million, which the company will try to recoup by asking the state to approve a rate increase. "The damage was the same as if it were a hurricane," Mr. Jussely said.
Economic losses throughout the freeze zone were replayed in widely varying ways, from what the Long Island clammers' called a "total washout" to Weight Watchers International Inc. of Jericho, N.Y., which lost 10 percent to 20 percent of its usual customers this winter because they could not reach the company's offices. "A third of our volume is done in the winter season -- it's New Year's resolution time," said a company spokeswoman, Linda Webb Carilli. "We're hoping for a blockbuster spring."
 
Some Manufacturers Humbled
 Some of the biggest manufacturing plants in the country were humbled by the ferocity of the storms, though shutdowns were mostly short.
Roger Lambert, manager of corporate communications for Honda of America's plant in Marysville, Ohio, said production was slowed when workers were unable to reach the plant and the temperature became too low to paint cars in January. The plant, which employs 10,000 workers, lost four work shifts, but eventually made most of that up by adding Saturday shifts.
Many businesses, particularly those associated with snow removal, reaped a windfall from the weather.
John Kiley, owner of Atlantic Atlantic Plow Blade of Hyde Park, Mass., which makes the cutting edges of snow plows, said: "This is our best year ever. I have three salesmen who do a snow dance every morning and pray for snow every night."
At the Chicago-based Cotter and Company, the distribution arm of the nation's 6,500 True Value hardware stores, sales of windshield-washer fluid increased ninefold over last winter, to 450,000 from 50,000, and sales of ice-melting chemicals and rock salt soared, as well. "Sales of birdseed were up 70 percent, too," said a company spokesman, Alex Goff.
Gary Rejebian, speaking for the Illinois Retail Merchants Association, which has 23,000 store members, said: "For the week that the snow hit, sales were down. But over all, retailers have been doing fairly well. Hardware, home-building and lumber were up in February between 5 and 10 percent; shoe sales were up 5 percent."
Communities like Trenton received an unusual bonus when the freezing temperatures were too low for many criminals. Lieut. Joseph Dolina of the Trenton Police said assaults dropped to 204 last month from 239 in February 1993, complaints of drug deals on the street and other drug violations plunged to 206 from 459, and there were no murders, as compared to 2 in February 1993. "Our crime stats did go down due to the cold weather," he said. "People weren't out on the streets."
But the news in most cities was more about busted budgets than busting criminals. The biggest costs fell on communities and government agencies that had to clear roads, repair utilities and fill millions of potholes.
As budgets drained, resources had to be shifted, setting off a fiscal domino effect in many communities that will continue for months and even years.
The city of Manchester, N.H., spent double what it had budgeted for snow removal, getting the money from a citywide recycling project. Now the roads are riddled with potholes, putting off other, scheduled road repairs. "We're going to be paying for all this way past winter," said Tamara Carson, the administrative assistant to the mayor of Manchester.
 
Frigid Pennsylvania
 In central Pennsylvania, State College has had a record 101.7 inches of snow, breaking the record of 98.2 inches. Harrisburg, the state capital, has had 69.7 inches, breaking the record of 60.6 inches set in winter of 1969-70. The city also recorded its lowest temperature in January -- 22 degrees below zero. John Comey of the Pennsylvania Emergency Management Agency said the state has exceeded its entire winter budget for snow removal by $30 million to $40 million.
Jim Eberwine, a forecaster with the National Weather Service in Philadelphia, said: "In other years, we would often get a big snowstorm, but after 12 hours or so we'd dig ourselves out." Gov. Robert P. Casey asked the Federal Government to declare the state's 67 counties disaster areas.
But spring and warmer weather may not end the trauma. Some Midwestern cities and communities face the possibility of renewed flooding from the spring thaw and rains.

CHINA REBUFFS U.S.

HEADLINE: CHINA REJECTS CALL FROM CHRISTOPHER FOR RIGHTS GAINS

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Mar. 12

 BODY:
Chinese officials today flatly rejected Secretary of State Warren Christopher's demand that Beijing improve its human rights performance and warned that stripping China of its trade privileges would backfire.
In a day punctuated by harsh and often acrimonious exchanges, the Chinese also accused the United States of breaking Chinese law by meeting secretly with a leading dissident last month. 
 Mr. Christopher's first visit to China as Secretary of State, initially planned as the culmination of the Administration's six-month-long strategy of intensive high-level engagement with the Chinese, has instead reduced China's chances of winning renewal of trade privileges that expire in June.
 
Internal Affairs Cited
 This took place against a backdrop of heightened American demands for steady and substantive progress on human rights, and in large part they clashed with China's traditional resistance against being told what to do about its internal affairs and with the authorities' desire to maintain strict control as democracy advocates begin to become more assertive.
Mr. Christopher told Foreign Minister Qian Qichen this morning that China's actions toward its citizens, including the recent detention of a number of prominent dissidents, "suggest that China attaches relatively little weight to core human rights issues," the State Department spokesman, Michael McCurry, told reporters.
If that is so, the Secretary added, it "certainly bodes ill" for the chances of renewing the most-favored-nation trade status that gives China lower tariffs than those accorded to most American trading partners.
 
A Rancorous Exchange
 The exchange was so rancorous that as he said goodbye to Mr. Qian after four hours of meetings that extended through lunch, Mr. Christopher made no effort to hide his frustration, saying, "I wish the meeting had been as good as the lunch," Mr. McCurry reported.
In an afternoon meeting, Prime Minister Li Peng seemed to reverse China's earlier pledges this year to try to make progress on human rights.
"China will never accept the U.S. human rights concept," Mr. Li told Mr. Christopher, according to a Foreign Ministry spokesman, Wu Jianmin. "History has already proven that it is futile to apply pressure on China."
Mr. Christopher's aides have acknowledged that they are both shocked and bewildered by the Chinese decision to greet Mr. Christopher's arrival with a sweeping crackdown on dissidents instead of conciliatory gestures on human rights.
But at the same time, it was impossible to judge whether the sudden Chinese belligerency was a tactical rebuff to Mr. Christopher, who has been publicly scolding the Chinese for not making enough progress, or a tough, new overall attitude on human rights. Only a month ago, President Jiang Zemin told American Congressional leaders in very conciliatory tones that China would make an effort to respond to Mr. Clinton's demands.
In taking a tougher line than at any time since the Clinton Administration took office, the Chinese appear willing to gamble that Washington has too much to lose by revoking the trade privileges, a policy they see as driven by anti-China lawmakers in Congress. Both Mr. Qian and Mr. Li warned Mr. Christopher today that the United States would suffer more than China if its trade privileges were revoked.
 
Boast of Self-Sufficiency
 China is nearly self-sufficient economically, Mr. Li boasted, adding that if the United States were to revoke its trade status, "it means the United States would lose its share of the big Chinese market." He said Chinese imports were growing at a rate of 9 percent a year and would reach a trillion dollars by the turn of the century.
But Mr. Christopher, the highest Clinton Administration representative to visit China, told his hosts that reports in China that the United States had already decided to extend preferential trade privileges or would accept only modest improvements in human rights to extend them were "unambiguously wrong," Mr. McCurry quoted Mr. Christopher as saying.
In an extraordinary allegation that prompted a strong response from Mr. Christopher and his aides, the Chinese accused John Shattuck, the Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, of breaking Chinese law by meeting late last month with Wei Jingsheng, China's most prominent dissident, whom Mr. Wu described to reporters as "a criminal on parole."
The official New China News Agency quoted Mr. Qian as telling Mr. Christopher, "A top U.S. Government official came to prepare for Christopher's visit, and in disregard of Chinese laws, the official took actions interfering in China's internal affairs."
 
U.S. Refuses Diplomatic Limits
 In reply, Mr. Christopher was quoted as saying the United States "cannot accept any limits on the ability of its diplomats to meet with foreign citizens."
Although Mr. Christopher chose not to speak publicly today about his first day of meetings, Winston Lord, the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, chastised his hosts. He told reporters that the Chinese assertion that the United States was poisoning the well in advance of Mr. Christopher's visit because of human rights was "really Alice in Wonderland," and "an extraordinary leap of chutzpah."
Mr. Lord, a former Ambassador to China, tried to put the best face on the trip, saying, "Let's hope the next couple of days are better."
But Mr. Christopher's aides conceded in private that any real progress would have to come after the meeting is over.
 
Two and a Half Months Left
 The Chinese still have two and a half months before the Administration must decide whether they have made enough progress in improving their human rights record to warrant annual renewal of their preferential trade privileges. And despite Mr. Christopher's threats to revoke China's trade privileges, the United States has no intention of abandoning its strategy of high-level diplomatic engagement, Mr. Lord told reporters.
Still, there is deep concern on the American side that China may do too little too late in meeting the requirements of a 1993 executive order linking extension of the trade benefits to China's progress on releasing political prisoners, ceasing the jamming of international broadcasts, carrying out the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, protecting Tibet's cultural and religious heritage, permitting the right of emigration and opening Chinese prisons to international relief groups.
The executive order was the result of intensive consultations with Congress, which has pressed for deeper concessions from China on human rights.
In an unusual departure from Chinese hospitality and courtesy, Mr. Wu, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, acknowledged to reporters that the Chinese had suggested that Mr. Christopher postpone his trip because it coincided with the opening of the National People's Congress, but that when the Americans said they could not change their arrangements, "in the end we have accommodated the Secretary."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Foreign Minister Qian Qichen at their talks yesterday in Beijing. Prime Minister Li Peng said, "China will never accept the U.S. human rights concept." (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Hope Starts to Bloom in the Motor City That No Longer Builds Many Cars

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 12

 BODY:
The economic ministers of seven nations convening here on Monday at the invitation of President Clinton will have a chance to see what Detroit residents have known for years: a strong recovery by the automotive industry no longer guarantees boom times for the Motor City.
In fact, only three automobile assembly plants are left in Detroit, where the public sector is the top employer. Second is the health care industry and the auto industry ranks third. 
 For 50 years, the auto makers have been moving plants into the suburbs, then across the nation and around the world. In the area within 40 miles of the city, factory jobs have steadily dropped in relation to total employment since 1952, to 22 percent in 1993 from 51 percent. But while the suburbs continue to boom with new service industry jobs, Detroit never found industries to compensate.
Now, under an energetic new Mayor, Detroit may be poised for a comeback that many local business leaders believe is possible. Their optimism is pervasive although specific solutions are in short supply.
 
Enthusiasm Returns
 "I'm not suggesting I know what the right answer is on how at this point you revitalize the city," said Robert J. Eaton, chairman and chief executive of the Chrysler Corporation. Citing the willingness of the new Mayor to work with business, he said, "I'm more enthusiastic about the city of Detroit than I have been in the past 20 years."
To be sure, the auto makers are still a major economic force in Detroit, and their upturn this year probably accounts for a recent rise in city tax revenues, said David L. Littmann, senior economist for Comerica Bank. But their economic influence is much diminished from the past.
For instance, while the General Motors Corporation employed 26,000 workers in the city in 1984, Mr. Littmann said, it employed only 9,257 by 1990, the last year for which numbers were available. During the same period, jobs at Chrysler dropped from 13,242 to 8,636.
 
Sentimental Reasons
 Still, a strong sentimental tie connects the auto makers to the city they made famous, and they have donated millions to help build parks and maintain museums. Last month, in fact, the General Motors Corporation promised the city two new Cadillacs, one a limousine, principally for Mayor Dennis Archer.
But in that gift there was also a symbolic reminder of the auto companies' shrinking economic presence: The cars are being assembled in Arlington, Tex.
Mr. Archer insists that the city's economy has already diversified beyond the auto industry, and he is seeking out other businesses like the health care industry to continue the process.
But much remains to be done. "The city of Detroit is in need of a direct infusion of help," Mayor Archer said. He often cites a grim list of statistics, including the fact that almost one in every three residents lives below the poverty line, and among children, 46 percent live in poverty.
Nevertheless there are some bright spots for the auto industry, and consequently for the city.
 
Hiring at Chrysler
 The Chrysler Corporation recently announced that it was hiring a third shift for its assembly plant on the East Side, where the popular Jeep Grand Cherokee sport utility vehicles are produced. That decision could result in about 800 new jobs.
But Chrysler also announced in September that it would move its corporate headquarters and 4,500 jobs out of Highland Park, a city of 20,000 almost surrounded by Detroit. The company had previously said it would not leave.
G.M. is now the only auto maker with its headquarters in the city, employing 5,000 people. Ford's headquarters has been in Dearborn, about 15 miles west of the city, since the 1920's.
Despite the surge in car buying, the auto makers have been cautious about hiring. Douglas A. Fraser, a former president of the United Automobile Workers union who is a labor professor at Wayne State University, scoffed at the recent news that the Ford Motor Company planned to hire several hundred new workers at plants outside Detroit.
 
Jobs for Everyone
 "They used to hire that in a day," said Mr. Fraser, a Scottish immigrant who got his first auto job in a DeSoto plant on Detroit's West Side in 1936. "You went up to the employment office, and they felt you, and if you were warm, they hired you." Mr. Fraser has now put his renowned negotiating skills at the service of Mr. Archer, bargaining for wage concessions from the city's police and fire unions.
Detroit's population has paralleled the course of the industry. Between 1910 and 1930, as the automobile roared into the nation's culture, Detroit's population more than tripled, to 1.56 million. But by the early 1950's, the rapid growth of auto jobs peaked and so did the city's population, which had reached almost two million and has since fallen to about half that.
Even while auto making was still booming in Detroit, the very highway system that was part of the industry's success made it possible for workers to migrate away from the city and into the growing suburbs.
"We didn't realize it at the time, but when they built Hudson's Northland that was the death knell," said Norman McRae, a local historian, referring to a shopping mall that opened in the mid-50's a few miles north of the city.
Like many older Detroit residents, Mr. McRae, who is 68, worked in the auto plants in 1950, when they offered regular work at good pay for virtually anyone. He said that as late as the early 1950's, "a black guy or a poor white guy from Tennessee or an immigrant from Poland could come here, and he could get a job."
 
City Courts Business
 Now, Mr. Archer, in hopes of making the city more livable, is working to improve city services like garbage removal. The first new Mayor in 20 years, Mr. Archer is hoping to reduce the municipal budget deficit by cutting waste in purchasing and contracting.
And he is aggressively courting businesses, pointing out that Detroit residents, lacking stores in the city, spend more of their dollars in the suburbs. "This is a retailer's dream," he said.
Mr. Archer's efforts have caused some business leaders to predict a renaissance. "Whoever it is you talk to, bankers or businessmen or whoever, they see this city as turning around," said Art VanElslander, chairman and chief executive of a chain of Michigan furniture stores, Art Van Furniture.
Mr. VanElslander recently bought a hotel in downtown Detroit that has been run by a Federal agency since the savings and loan that owned it failed. Explaining his acquisition, he said, "I see the economy as very upbeat in Detroit, particularly with the new administration."
Some bankers are not so sanguine. "Nothing fundamental has changed, and people have to understand that," said Mr. Littmann of Comerica Bank, who is also president of the Heartland Institute of Michigan, a public policy group. Mr. Littmann said a principal problem was that Detroit's total tax burden is seven to eight times above average for a Michigan municipality. "That would be all right, if the services were commensurate in value with that, but they're not," he said.

HEADLINE: Accord Will Allow U.S. Cellular Phones in Japan

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
Clearing away one of several trade disputes that have roiled relations between the United States and Japan in the last month, President Clinton today announced a detailed agreement to expand American access to the Japanese cellular telephone market.
The agreement calls for one of Japan's main providers of cellular telephone service to invest in additional equipment that would make it easier for people there to use cellular telephones manufactured by Motorola Inc. 
 But the pact does not address the issues that provoked the failure of the trade talks a month ago between President Clinton and Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa of Japan and continue to produce recriminations.
 
Gain for Both, Clinton Says
 In his weekly national radio address, President Clinton presented today's deal as helping both countries.
"This is a big win for everyone," Mr. Clinton said. "Workers in the United States will gain because the agreement means more demand for cellular telephones and related equipment made in America. Japanese consumers win because they'll have access to better service and better technology at better prices. Even Japanese manufacturers may win because of the increased demand for cellular telephones."
The Administration's tactics -- threatening trade sanctions if the Japanese Government did not force a private company there to change its investment plans to suit an American manufacturer -- had drawn a mixed reaction from economists.
Some economists, and many Japanese officials, contended that the Administration was improperly encouraging the Japanese Government to return to its practice of dictating many companies' financial decisions. Other economists, and American officials, said the Japanese Government had allocated cellular telephone frequencies to insure that American-made cellular telephones would not be competitive in the Japanese market.
The President took pains today to emphasize that the cellular telephone deal included specific measures of compliance by the Japanese provider of cellular telephone service, the Nippon Idou Tsushin Corporation, better known as I.D.O.
In broader talks that began last summer at the Tokyo summit meeting and failed at last month's meeting here between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Hosokawa, the United States had tried unsuccessfully to get Japan to agree to numerical targets by which to gauge the progress in opening its markets.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said at a news conference here today, "This agreement validates our results-oriented approach."
But Takenori Kanzaki, the Japanese Minister of Posts and Telecommunications, said in Tokyo that the pact was consistent with Japan's opposition to numerical targets. The pact calls for I.D.O. to accelerate its schedule for deploying cellular telephone relay stations for phones made by Motorola, not to make additional purchases, he said.
Under today's agreement, I.D.O. must expand its network of cellular telephone relay stations to cover more than 95 percent of the heavily populated corridor between Tokyo and Nagoya by the end of 1995, compared with 56 percent coverage now.
As part of its expansion, I.D.O. agreed today to buy 159 extra phone relay stations from Motorola for an undisclosed price, bringing its total to 348. The Japanese company has already built a cellular phone system using phones made in Japan.
Christopher B. Galvin, Motorola's president and chief operating officer, said the agreement would increase Motorola's annual sales in Japan by $300 million a year and provide "hundreds of jobs" for American workers.
The Japanese Government also agreed today to take away a few of the radio frequencies used for phones made in Japan and reallocate them for use with phones made in the United States. The two phone systems are technologically incompatible.
Walter F. Mondale, the United States Ambassador to Japan, said at a press conference there that because a few details of the pact remained to be worked out, the American threat of sanctions would technically be postponed for 30 days rather than lifted entirely. But he predicted that the final details, notably concerning the precise location of the new relay stations, would be settled soon.
Today's pact was technically two agreements, one between I.D.O. and Motorola and the other between Mr. Kantor and Takakaza Kuriyama, the Japanese Ambassador to the United States.
The broader talks are aimed at reducing Japan's overall trade surplus with the rest of the world, which reached $131 billion last year. These talks have initially focused on industries like cars, car parts and insurance.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, preparing for a news conference in Washington, where he said the American-Japanese agreement on cellular telephones "validates our results-oriented approach." He was assisted by Charlene Barshefsky, a deputy. (Kirsten Bremmer for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: More Women Take Low-Wage Jobs Just So Their Families Can Get By

SERIES: Staying Afloat: Work in the 90's - Last of four articles

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo.

 BODY:
Women who once went to work to buy the extras for their families are paying for more and more of the basics, piling job upon job as their husbands' earnings fall.
About 15 million working wives hold well-paid executive or professional jobs, anchoring their families to the middle or upper classes. But far more -- 37 million -- are working for lower wages as clerks and cashiers, nurses' aides and bank tellers, secretaries and maids. Their wages serve as a cushion between welfare and getting by. 
 For the most part, it is the wives and mothers among this huge population of lower-paid women whose husbands' wages have fallen the most and who are becoming the new bulwarks of the family economy. These women take full-time jobs and then go to school to qualify for better ones. Others combine two or more jobs.
Two decades ago, six men for every one woman held more than one job. As of the end of February, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reports, almost 47 percent of the nation's seven million multiple-job holderswere women. Just over half of these women stack a part-time job on top of a full-time one or hold two or more full-time jobs.
 
'Barely Hanging On'
 "The men are feeling desperate and barely hanging on," said Karen Nussbaum, director of the Women's Bureau at the Labor Department. "Women are more likely to have a practical response: 'How do I just get through this?' They go from a secretarial job to a night job at K mart."
Christine Gibbs is typical. Twenty-nine years old and the mother of a 3-year-old girl, she works 19 hours a week at the drive-up window of a shopping center bank during "peak time" afternoon hours.
Peak-time workers make $8.50 to $12 an hour, but the bank does not provide health benefits or pay wages for an eight-hour day. Then on Saturdays, for $200 a month, she cleans the restrooms and offices of another bank.
 
From Promise to Gloom
 When Mrs. Gibbs began working three years ago, her husband, David, now 30, seemed to have a promising future as an auditor of passenger tickets at Trans World Airlines. So the couple built a three-bedroom house for $80,000 in a subdivision about 25 miles north of downtown and bought a second car.
Since then, Mr. Gibbs has survived round upon round of dismissals at T.W.A. He took a 10 percent pay cut last year, and rumors fly daily of yet more dismissals and another pay cut.
While the Gibbses' annual income, slightly less than $40,000, is still above average for the region, the couple are in debt and know their situation is precarious.
"I expected to gain," Mrs. Gibbs said of her decision to go to work. "But it seems we keep going backward."
For decades, workers like Mrs. Gibbs raised the family income. But in inflation-adjusted dollars, the rise in the median family income peaked in 1989 at $38,710. By the end of 1992, the latest year for which the Government has figures, it had slipped to $36,812.
"An important legacy of the last 12 years is even if you know something is wrong, you're helpless to do anything about it," said Ms. Nussbaum of the Labor Department, reflecting on diminishing incomes and disappearing jobs.
 
Marking Time at Best
 Women, who earn 77 percent of what men do, saw their wages rise by 1.4 percent in real dollars from 1987 to 1993, according to a study by the Economic Policy Institute, a labor-supported research organization. But in the same period, the average male worker's pay fell 10 percent.
Three years ago, the parade of women into the workplace seemed to stall, with 53.5 million employed along with 65 million men. But it was only a pause. Since 1990, nearly three million more women have taken jobs, almost twice the number of men.
Two thirds of all part-timers and nearly 60 percent of all temporary workers are women, according to the Labor Department. Lately, many of these jobs have become entrenched. Banks and supermarkets, for example, now hire some workers, mainly women, for part-time shifts.
The average annual pay in the Kansas City area was $25,345 in 1992, the Bureau of Labor Statistics says, close to the national average of $25,903. Typically, the wife's wages lift the family's income to about $35,000. Economists say that amount here allows a modest, middle-class standard of living, covering the cost of a mortgage on a three-bedroom house, two cars, including one with a loan on it, some health insurance and an annual vacation.
 
A State of Mind
 Middle class is partly a state of mind, but in economic terms it is best defined as the mix of income and cost of living that permits families to live independently and have some options.
Eva Pina, a 32-year-old Mexican-born mother of five children, is just barely there. She earns $16,000 a year as a full-time job counselor at a private, nonprofit center for refugees and an additional $5,000 a year working two nights a week and 12 hours on weekends in a supermarket bakery in a tough part of town.
The family of seven needs the money: Ms. Pina's husband, Emeterio Orozco, who speaks no English, earns $6 an hour making commercial dishwashers.
They worry about the monthly $387 mortgage on their sparsely furnished house. "I don't think we can make it on my husband's salary," Ms. Pina said. "I don't want to be on welfare. I know I would get lazy and not improve myself."
 
Trying to Get Ahead
 It was not hard for Ms. Pina to find work. Subsistence jobs, barren of benefits and paying $5 and $6 an hour, go begging because welfare with Medicaid benefits is often a better bet.
To get ahead, women often go to school later than men. Slightly more men than women go to college between the ages of 20 and 24. But among students aged 25 to 54, about 61 percent are women. And once in school, slightly more women than men also hold jobs.
Thelma West, 25, who has four children, juggles a full-time job as a data-entry clerk at an insurance company with psychology courses at a junior college.
Her husband, Tommy, 32, a public works department truck and tractor driver for five years, quit school in the 10th grade. He is reluctant to discuss his pay, but city workers at his level earn about $15,000 a year. To get a better job, he enrolled in a business school to study electronics. But the school folded, and he was left owing $3,500 on his student loan.
 
'That's the Reason'
 After dinner one night at their rented brick rowhouse, Mrs. West dropped on the couch while her 2-year-old, Frances, played nearby. Nodding toward his wife, Mr. West said, "That's the reason we're making it."
One night a week, Mrs. West takes advantage of her college's concession to working students and watches a three-hour class on videotape at home.
Her wages bring the family's income to around $40,000 a year. But after Mr. West's experience with the business school, the family is afraid of debt. They replace their worn furniture piece by piece when they have the cash, and buy food in bulk.
"I doubt that there're many people saying, 'I'm living as I always wanted to live,' " Mrs. West said.
But she does not complain. "Sure, I would like to buy a house in the suburbs," she said. "And right now I'm making preparations for that day. But I don't see us as a certain status. If I was to put us in a category, I would put us as being blessed."
 
Moved From California
 Eva Virji, 54, is looking for a job similar to Mrs. West's. A former loan processor for the Bank of America in Los Angeles, Mrs. Virji practices data processing seven days a week at Johnson County Community College, in suburban Overland Park, Kan.
She left California a year ago to join her husband, Adi, now 52, a chemist and pharmacologist with a doctorate from London University. He had come to Kansas City two years earlier to take a one-year job at a small pharmaceutical company, and his contract was not renewed. Mrs. Virji scoured the region for a job like her previous one, which paid $26,000 a year. But without data-processing skills, she said, the best she could find paid only about $12,500 a year, or $6 an hour.
This month, her $1,400 monthly severance benefit from the Bank of America ran out, and the Virjis are reduced to living on the $800 a month Mrs. Virji collects in workers' compensation for a knee injury.
With her training almost complete, she said she would start looking for work again. She hopes to find a job like Mrs. West's, paying $9 or $10 an hour. But, she said, "If I have to take two jobs, I will."
 
From Raise to Exit
 Like many other men in their 50's who have lost their jobs, Dr. Virji, who was born in India, has found the job market almost impossible to crack. He was laid off from two jobs in Los Angeles before moving to Kansas City; one company eliminated his job two days after giving him a 25 percent raise.
He was let go at the end of his contract in Kansas City, he said, because the drug company was tightening its belt to prepare for the overhaul of the health system.
In Kansas City, he said, "I thought I'd be a big potato in a small field." Instead, employers say he is overqualified for a lower-level position in a laboratory or in a pharmacy, filling prescriptions. "No one will give you a chance to do a lower job," he said. "They say I wouldn't be happy." Taking such comments to heart, Dr. Virji dropped the "Ph.D." from his resume.
Dr. Virji said he would flip hamburgers, but his wife, protective of his self-esteem, won't allow it. "I don't want him to go to McDonald's," she said. "All work has dignity, but I want him to apply for something in his field."

HEADLINE: Temporary Jobs Now Seem Anything But

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo.

 BODY:
During recessions, employers put off the cost of new hiring by paying people extra to work overtime. They also turn to part-time and temporary workers who are rarely paid benefits.
But it has been three years since the economy began rebounding from the last recession, and these arrangements seem to have taken root. Factories nationwide are relying on record levels of overtime, typically four and five hours a week. Ford's 4,350 workers in Kansas City, for example, have been putting in 50-hour weeks for a year and a half. 
 Automobile industry jobs here, most of them at a Ford plant and a General Motors plant, have climbed to 9,100 from 8,200 four years ago, but they are still far below the 15,200 of 1985.
Some economists say that business's reliance on overtime and on "contingent" -- temporary and part-time -- workers should fade as business picks up.
"We're using more of this contingent work force than we ever have before," said Lowell Mayonne, vice president for human resources at Hallmark, which has its headquarters in Kansas City. "We're like all the other lemmings in American industry. When a gimmick comes along, we tend to fall for it. But I suspect American industry will find that there's a certain loss in productivity."
Other executives suspect that the pressure to operate close to the bone will persist because of a more competitive domestic and global economy and because part-time and temporary workers can provide a more efficient way to serve customers when business is brisk.
Richard E. Beyer, head of human resources at Boatmen's First National Bank, Kansas City's biggest bank, said tellers used to have little to do in the mornings when business was light, then worked hard in the afternoons. Enter a new job category: peak-time workers who are hired only for the busiest hours. The trend toward contingent workers has been a boon to temporary agencies that hire job-seekers and send them out on assignments that can last days or months.
Now, however, even the growth in those kinds of last-resort, low-wage jobs may be abating. David Stanley, chairman of Payless Cashways, a 400-store do-it-yourself chain with headquarters here, said that with ever more sophisticated computers, the company needed fewer and fewer workers.
Bill Yarberry, the head of Manpower Inc.'s office in suburban Overland Park, Kan., makes no apologies for flooding the city with short-timers. He says a temporary job is a springboard to a full-time job for 35 percent of his clients, especially the young workers.
In the minds of many people, "flipping hamburgers at McDonald's," has come to symbolize a culture of low wages and lost hope. But there is another side to the stereotype.
"For young people, the jobs teach teamwork, discipline, communications skills -- a lot of things that build a foundation for later in life," said Rebecca Caruso, a spokeswoman for McDonald's. "More than half our senior and middle managers started out working behind the counter, including our president, Ed Rensi." PETER T. KILBORN

HEADLINE: Washington Might Recognize a Bosnian Serb State

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
The United States may be prepared to recognize a state for Bosnian Serbs on part of the territory they now hold in Bosnia and Herzegovina if such recognition would help foster an overall settlement of the war acceptable to the Muslim-led Bosnian Government, Administration officials said this week.
A senior official said that while the Clinton Administration strongly favors preserving Bosnia and Herzegovina intact by persuading the Serbs to join a proposed federation of Muslims and Croats being negotiated by the United States, the eventual acceptance of a Bosnian Serb state could not be ruled out. 
 "We're not excluding recognizing a Bosnian Serb state," said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "If, at some point, the Bosnian Government tells us, 'Look, this is the best chance for our entity,' we'd have to take that into consideration. It could well be that a Bosnian Serb state will emerge and have some relation to Serbia on the other side."
The Serbs, who made up close to one-third of Bosnia's population before the war began nearly two years ago, now hold about 70 percent of the territory of the former Yugoslav republic. In exchange for any eventual recognition, they would clearly have to give up a considerable part of this land to the federation of Croats and Muslims now taking shape.
 
'Very Loose Structure' Seen
 "We've told the Serbs the door is open for them to join the federation, but we assume they do not want to come in," the official said. "So what you could eventually have after hard bargaining on territory is a Bosnian Serb state recognized by the United Nations with confederal ties to Serbia, and a Muslim-Croatian state with confederal ties to Croatia, and then perhaps some very loose overarching structure for the original land mass of Bosnia and Herzegovina."
Asked what structure could link two separate sovereign states in Bosnia, the official suggested a free economic zone and periodic meetings of the presidents and prime ministers.
After several months of diplomatic inertia, the United States has now taken the lead in seeking a settlement for the Balkan war.
In so doing, officials recognize that it has been obliged to abandon the moral high ground for what they consider a level of pragmatism. Still, recognition of a Bosnian Serb state would be vigorously debated because it might appear to reward the aggressor, flout international law and lend permanence to the forced eviction of Muslims from certain towns by Serbs, known as "ethnic cleansing."
 
Readiness Varies
 Several conversations with senior officials of the State Department and the White House suggested differing degrees of readiness to recognize the Bosnian Serbs. None, however, rejected the possibility.
A second official said: "It will be very difficult if the Serbs want to secede. They would have to give more territory than if they remain within a loose union in Bosnia. But our bottom line is that if eventual secession is acceptable to the Bosnian Muslims, then we will support it and commit U.S. troops to the implementation of the agreement."
Asked about recognition of a Bosnian Serb state, a third highly placed official said, "Let's first nail down the Bosnian Muslim-Croat federation and then approach the Serbs and see." He said it was "unlikely but not impossible" that the Serbs would join the federation, "and we must explore this possibility."
In the conversations with the officials, the planned course of American diplomatic efforts over the next few weeks emerges clearly.
 
Muslims and Croats Talk
 First, every effort will be made to conclude negotiations in Vienna between Bosnia's Muslims and Croats on the establishment of a binational federation of semiautonomous cantons that would then be joined to Croatia in a loose confederation. Officials believe that a signing ceremony in Washington between President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia and President Alija Izetbegovic of Bosnia is likely to take place within the next two weeks.
By the time of this signing, the Muslims and Croats will be ready to put their territorial demands jointly to the Serbs.
This "bottom line" on territory would be coordinated with the United States and is certain to involve a demand that the Serbs give up at least 20 percent of the land they now hold. Indeed, in a statement this week, Mr. Izetbegovic said the Muslim-Croat entity would cover 60 percent of Bosnia -- implying that the Serbs would be asked to give up 30 percent.
Negotiations would then begin with the Serbs, the officials said, and would be certain to involve hard bargaining on a number of issues. Still, an official said, "the Muslim-Croat federation will create a better balance of forces in Bosnia, and we believe this is something the Serbs understand."
 
Muslims Oppose Partition
 After several changes of policy over the last year, it seems clear that Mr. Izetbegovic and his Prime Minister, Haris Silajdzic, now favor maintaining the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina intact rather than allowing partition. Their initial position in discussions with the Serbs would therefore be that the Serbs should give up territory while remaining within some loose union in Bosnia.
"What we have in mind," a United States official said, "is that the central government of the whole would be weak, but the Muslim-Croat part would be stronger. The links to Croatia on the outside could be stronger than those to the Serbs within the country of Bosnia. You'd end up with an asymmetrical federation in Bosnia."
On the specific question of territory, two possibilities are being examined. The Muslim-Croat federation might give up some of the isolated Government-held eastern enclaves, like Zepa and Srebrenica, but in return gain a far greater share of a province around Sarajevo, the capital, and complete control of the city itself, which would not be divided.
Alternatively, blurred land corridors might be secured linking all the isolated eastern Muslim enclaves, with acceptance by the Bosnian Muslims and Croats of a lesser share of Sarajevo and its province.
 
No Telegraphing in Advance
 "I don't deny that some people might be thinking about the necessity of giving up the eastern enclaves," an American official said. "If you look at the maps, some more coherent and contiguous state is easier to defend. But we have tried not to telegraph in advance what we would like the Muslim-Croat part to look like."
But all the ideas appear to present enormous, perhaps insurmountable, problems.
The Bosnian Serbs have never said they would give up more than 20 percent of what they hold, and recently their leader, Radovan Karadzic, has retreated from that position, suggesting that the concession may be no larger than 10 percent. The Serbs are committed to holding part of the city of Sarajevo. And having already declared their self-styled independent state on the land they hold, the Serbs have certainly not forsaken their two-year-old fight for independence or the desire to join with Serbia.
"If the Serbs want out, they will have to give more territory, that is clear," a United States official said. "But even then, for Izetbegovic, it may be tough to sell Serb secession to his various constituents, particularly the army, many of whose soldiers have been fighting for the right to go back to their homes."
 
Two Firm Positions
 Two positions do appear firm amid the difficulties. The first is that while a Bosnian Serb state might be acceptable to the United States if the Muslim-led Bosnian Government agreed to it and secured large territorial concessions, Serbia's annexation of Serb-held parts of Bosnia is not.
"We do not want Serbia expanding into 50 percent of Bosnia and Herzegovina," an official said. "There would be real penalties for any Serbian 'anschluss' of the Bosnian Serbs."
The second is that the Muslim-led Bosnian Government would sign an overall agreement only if it is accompanied by a firm commitment from the United States to send troops to enforce the accord.
"For the Bosnians, our presence is crucial," an official said, adding that he thought President Clinton could secure Congressional approval for sending troops even though it would be a hard-fought battle for the President.
Asked if a necessarily imperfect agreement, involving continuing Serbian dominance on land seized by force, could really be policed by the Americans, the official said, "Look, we are working toward what the Bosnian Prime Minister, Haris Silajdzic, has himself called the least unjust of solutions."

HEADLINE: POLAND SEEKS TIES TO EUROPEAN UNION

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WARSAW, March 12

 BODY:
Concerned about resurgent Russian nationalism, Poland has stepped up its efforts to join the European Union with the idea that even partial membership would push it further into the orbit of the West.
The Polish Foreign Minister, Andrzej Olechowski, said at meeting of the union in Brussels this week that Poland would make its application for what he called partial membership next month. If the union agreed, such an arrangement would allow Poland full participation in the union's foreign and security activities, he said. 
 Poland's economic conditions did not yet allow it to work toward economic integration with the union, Mr. Olechowski said. "I'd like to see this happen as soon as possible," he said of the partial membership plan. "Poland would then be preparing for full membership."
Hungary's Minister for International Economic Relations, Endre Juhasz, said at the Brussels meetings that his Government would apply for full membership in the union next month. Poland and Hungary already have association agreements with the European Union, which provide for limited trade and aid.
 
Unease About Moscow
 The surprise moves for closer ties to the European Union by the two formerly Communist bloc countries reflect a continuing unease about Russia, a disquiet that was heightened by the recent Russian involvement in the efforts to end fighting in the former Yugoslavia.
Poland and Hungary are among the countries that have signed up for partial membership in NATO under the "Partnership for Peace" plan, but so has Russia. Some of the former satellite countries of the old Soviet Union fear that Russia is determined to prevent the partnership plan from growing into an alliance with security guarantees. Polish officials, for example, say that by inviting Russia into the partnership Washington insured that the plan would fail to grow into a meaningful grouping.
The Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, appeared to encourage this fear with remarks before the Russian Parliament's foreign policy committee Thursday. He was quoted in the Polish press as saying: "The NATO-mania of the impatient candidates for members of the alliance, similarly as the conception of 'Partnership for Peace,' may only lead to the strengthening of Zhirinovsky's camp, especially if it's accompanied by anti-Russian hysteria." He was referring to Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, the leader of the ultranationalist Liberal Democratic Party, which made a strong showing in Russia's parliamentary elections.
Mr. Kozyrev's comments followed a swing through Eastern Europe earlier this month, which went smoothly in Hungary and the Czech Republic, but was reported in Poland as a cool and truncated visit. Mr. Kozyrev did not meet with President Lech Walesa, for example, or even visit Warsaw.
 
Jaruzelski Interviewed
 In a rare interview published Friday in the Polish newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza, the last Communist leader of Poland, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, underlined the Polish drive for security guarantees from the West and the nature of its difficulties with Russia.
"Almost all political parties in Poland, whether on the right or left, think that the guarantees of our security lie in our close contacts with the West," he said, adding there should also be "co-operation with our eastern neighbors."
Mr. Jaruzelski, who imposed martial law on Poland in 1981, said that some Russian foreign policy makers wanted to keep Eastern Europe away from the West and leave it as a neutral zone, a prospect that many Poles particularly fear.
The former Polish leader said he liked and respected Russia but predicted Russia would remain a "very unstable country" until at least the year 2000.
As well as pushing at the doors of the European Union, Poland and several of the other former Warsaw Pact countries, plan to seek membership in the Western European Union -- a defense alliance of union members that are also part of NATO -- at a meeting of that organization in May.
The May meeting of the Western European Union is scheduled to consider opening the organization to new associate members. Some officials in Brussels, worried about the direction of Russia, have said in the last few weeks that the Eastern Europeans should be offered stronger security assurances than they are likely to get through the "Partnership for Peace" of NATO.

HEADLINE: State Employees Brace for the Budget

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 12

 BODY:
When Gov. Christine Todd Whitman releases her 1995 budget on Tuesday, no group will pore over its numbers more anxiously than New Jersey's state employees.
With a $2.2 billion projected budget gap to close, Whitman administration officials have been hinting that state workers' wages and fringe benefits, accounting for 20 percent of state spending, will be high on the list for budget savings. 
 Possible changes include placing new limits on the state's generous sick-leave rules, curtailing health insurance contributions and delaying contributions to pension programs. In addition, the state may consider forcing local school districts to assume responsibility for their teachers' pensions, which the state now pays, and weakening the current system of compulsory wage arbitration for police and firefighters, which has been blamed for wage increases that run twice the rate of inflation.
If the fears of New Jersey's 61,000 state workers are realized on Tuesday, they will not be alone in their dismay; state employees in New York and Connecticut also face the prospect of being asked to sacrifice during coming labor negotiations.
 
Economy Up, Not Benefits
 In all three states, public workers had hoped that an improving economy might let them make up for the wage freezes and benefits reductions forced on them during hard times. They are finding, however, that tax cuts, not wage increases, are the order of the day.
A few years ago, administrations pointed to falling tax revenues as the reason for holding wages down, trimming benefits and forcing layoffs. Now they argue that taxes must be cut for the states to remain competitive with lower-taxing states in the South and West. And they show every sign of expecting state workers to help pay the price.
Union leaders acknowledge that the wage-squeezing sits well with recession-weary taxpayers.
"The recession has made it politically acceptable to go after public employees," complained Robert Yackel, head of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s state and local workers' federation in New Jersey. "You still have high unemployment out there, people are having to take second jobs to make ends meet, and they see public employees with steady jobs and steady incomes and they get resentful."
Some experts on state fiscal issues say that state payrolls, particularly fringe benefits, deserve to be re-examined in light of new fiscal realities.
 
Sharp Contrast With 1980's
 "I think everything ought to be on the table in states that are in serious fiscal situations, particularly in a state like New Jersey, that does have high personnel spending," said Steven D. Gold, head of the Center for Study of the States at the Rockefeller Institute in Albany.
The change is in sharp contrast to the relative security that public workers enjoyed as a group during the 1980's, when government employee wages at the state and local levels, while still lower than for corresponding jobs in private industry, were increasing at twice the private rate, and when a state job was considered an ironclad guarantee of lifetime job security.
Over the last three years, however, New York, New Jersey and Connecticut each laid off thousands of state employees, and public workers' pay is now rising nationally at a third the rate of private employees.
Most New York and New Jersey state employees have a year to go on their contracts, but labor contracts did not stop either state from saving millions of dollars since 1991 by delaying scheduled pay increases or reducing pension plan contributions.
 
Weicker Wants Wage Freeze
 In Connecticut most labor contracts expire in June, and Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has already signaled that he wants a wage freeze to help the state compensate local governments for eliminating personal property taxes. On Wednesday, he advised the legislature to reject an arbitrator's award of wage increases to state university employees.
"There is no money in the current budget or in the upcoming fiscal year for general wage increases," said Avice A. Meehan, Governor Weicker's spokeswoman.
In New York City, where Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has proposed layoffs and tax cuts, city workers face much the same situation.
To make good on her campaign promise to cut income taxes by 30 percent over three years, Governor Whitman must cut an additional $1.1 billion in state spending, and there are few places other than the state's work force where she can save.
At its current spending level of $15.6 billion, New Jersey's budget also lists about $2.2 billion more in spending than there is money, a gap that has traditionally been closed by fiscal gimmicks and one-time revenues. Mrs. Whitman, who criticized "one shots" during the campaign, has said that she will have to resort to some in her first budget.
 
Local Cuts a Last Resort
 About two-thirds of the state's budget, or $10 billion, goes for public health and welfare costs or is returned to municipalities and school districts. Mrs. Whitman has assured the mayors and school boards that she will cut state aid to schools and localities only as a last resort.
That leaves the $4.6 billion spent annually for state operations, of which about $2 billion pays salaries and $1.1 billion goes for fringe benefits, including $675 million annually for pensions alone.
Over the years, one of the harshest critics of state spending on personnel has been the Public Affairs Research Institute of New Jersey, a private fiscal monitoring organization, whose former head was David Kehler until he became Governor Whitman's deputy associate treasurer. It is taken in Trenton as an article of faith that Mr. Kehler's critiques of state personnel spending policies are now working their way into the new budget.
In the past, the institute's researchers have criticized the fact that New Jersey employees, unlike nearly all other public workers, need not contribute to their health coverage, although they must pay into their pension plans. Many fiscal analysts have also suggested increasing the co-payment that workers make for doctor's visits and for prescription drugs. Each $1 increase in co-payment for drugs would produce $4 million in savings, for example.
 
Criticizing Sick-Leave Cash
 Mr. Kehler has, in the past, also criticized the state's practice of allowing retiring state workers to cash in their unused sick leave for up to $15,000, a policy that costs the state $16 million annually.
The state could also save close to $400 million in pension costs, over the short term, at least, by delaying contributions to pension plans, and leaving it to future governors to make up the financing as needed for retiring workers. New York State tried this approach in 1991, saving about $3 billion since then, but the courts have since struck down the practice.
Public employee wages and benefits are not the only place Governor Whitman may look for savings. She is known to admire fellow Republican governors in Michigan and Massachussetts who have cut or eliminated welfare payments to able-bodied, childless adults, a program that now costs New Jersey $166 million a year.
In addition, the nearly $3 billion in annual Medicaid payments include expenses for services not required by the Federal matching grant program, like eye care, podiatry and chiropractic. State officials have also suggested requiring Medicaid patients to enroll in managed-care programs.

HEADLINE: Businesses Press Lawmakers on Overhaul of Education

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, March 11

 BODY:
The delicate consensus that supports public education is being tested in the Legislative Office Building's hearing rooms as advocates of an ambitious plan to overhaul the schools try to push it to the top of the General Assembly's agenda.
Strongly endorsed by Connecticut's business leaders, the plan takes its lead from President Bush's America 2000 initiative, which called on states to set "world class" standards for their schools to prepare students to compete in a global economy. 
 The plan focuses on educational outcomes rather than on money spent per student or time students spend in class. It would establish strict goals for knowledge and skills deemed necessary for students to learn, then redesign curriculums to help nearly all students reach them.
But business is only one of many groups concerned with education plans that focus on outcomes, , and it has become a target for others with different interests.
Parents who oppose the plan call it a deception, part of a nationwide conspiracy to "dumb down" schools so they produce docile workers molded to meet industry's needs.
 
Teachers Join Attack
 Teachers unions, fearing that business people with little sense of the classroom are unfairly blaming teachers for the shortcomings of schools, have joined the attack. In a newspaper ad this week, the 30,000-member Connecticut Education Association accused business leaders of misleading the public about the plan's goals.
"Business leaders should say what they are really aiming for: schools that will turn out workers who fit their specific needs," the ad stated. "But teachers know there is more to education than preparing for a job."
Standing among the opposition, meanwhile, are supporters of school-choice plans that would give parents money to send their children to private schools, ready to step forward with their proposals if the plan for outcome-based education falters.
At a hearing before the Legislature's Education Committee today, the clash of perspectives was so jarring that members of the Commission on Educational Excellence for Connecticut, which issued a report on which the bill for outcome-based education is based, were shaking their heads at some criticism.
After one mother described the reform package as "radical educational experimentation" aimed at shaping children's "attitudes, beliefs, values and behaviors," Senator Robert L. Genuario, an Education Committee member who also sat on the commission, asked if she could point to any language in the bill that supported her comments.
"I can't imagine myself voting for legislation that would bring about the results that you suggest," he said.
 
'The Mind-Control Aspect'
 Little that the commission members told the Education Committee about the plan mattered, in an atmosphere in which one opponent, coordinating his testimony with another, said matter-of-factly, "I'll address the mind-control aspect."
The commission had been instructed by the Legislature to draft an outcome-based system, opponents say, and so whatever commission members said, they were really talking about outcome-based education. Outcome-based education, as the opponents understand it, is a system meant to teach all children the same things, to foster conformity and to discourage competition.
Senator Kevin B. Sullivan, a committee co-chairman, tried to spike that line of reasoning. He asked Robert D. Kennedy, the chief executive of the Union Carbide Corporation, "How would you respond to the observation that commission members are either liars who don't mean what they say, or fools who don't understand what they mean?"
Mr. Kennedy replied: "Change is threatening to people. Those who oppose education reform -- and you'll hear from them today, and you should listen to them closely -- it's clear what they oppose. It's not clear what they favor."
Still, when the State Commissioner of Education, Vincent Ferrandino, assured the committee, "It's strange to me that a group of businessmen who are concerned about being competitive would even consider the idea of dumbing down standards," someone in the audience hissed a possible motive: "Robots!"
 
Complicating Factors
 Complicating the plan's prospects is the language of professional educators and reformers, which mixes jargon with sweeping generalizations. After more than 18 months of study and discussion by the commission, for example, the plan's bywords -- "All children can learn at high levels" -- are still misunderstood by many people.
To the commission, the phrase means that all children are capable of learning more than public schools now expect of those who are not college-bound. If schools specified what children should know -- the desired outcomes -- they would then be able to figure out how to teach those things to every child.
But to a public well aware that children come in all varieties of intelligence and aptitude, commission members have been slow to explain how such a concept would be carried out in classrooms so that slow children would have as much time as they need, and smarter ones would not be held back.
As a result, critics have been able to mock the idea as unrealistic, or to supply horror stories from elsewhere in the country where the concept was carried out poorly and all children were held to the pace of the slowest.
Lost in the debate is the plan's intention that most children would meet the requirements not at graduation, but by the end of the 10th grade, leaving at least two years -- more for talented students who met the goals sooner -- to pursue their academic interests.
"We don't expect that all students will reach the same level," Mr. Ferrandino said. "Obviously, some will go well beyond the standards."

HEADLINE: Raze the Roof, Fix a Pothole

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KEARNY, N.J., March 9

 BODY:
At 15 snowstorms and counting, this has been Brian H. Howland's best winter ever.
His company, Reclaim Inc., makes a material to fill potholes, so every time the streets thaw and then freeze, there is more demand for his product. But there is more reason to like the bad weather: it generates more supplies of Reclaim's unusual raw material. While other paving supply companies use asphalt, his uses old roofs. 
 "This weather is great, incoming and outgoing," he said. "It's going to develop both markets."
Reclaim, which says it is the only company in its business, uses the old asphalt shingles that roofers remove from houses and commercial buildings. The company, which has one plant here and another in Camden, shreds the shingles, grinds them, mixes them with gravel, throws in a dollop of a secret blend of solvents that helps it all stick together, and cooks it all up into a patching material.
 
All This and Recycling Too
 With a 20-foot tower of roofing debris rising from the mud beneath the Pulaski Skyway, and a clanking steel-clawed auger in the little factory, Reclaim does not look like most people's notion of a "green industry." But it has kept more than a quarter-million tons of discarded roofing material out of New Jersey landfills, cut the demand for oil used to make asphalt, and provided, according to the company and some of its customers, a superior pothole patch, though it is more expensive than the usual mix.
"It works fantastic," said Henry A. Monker, who fills potholes for the Union City Department of Public Works. "It's good stuff," said William F. Bull, the recycling coordinator in the City of Bayonne. "I really believe in the material," said John J. Tarditi Jr., the Mayor of Haddonfield. All three said Reclaim's main product, called Repave, is superior to the current standard material, called cold patch, a tarry gravel that workers shovel into holes and hope stays there.
New York City officials are evaluating Repave, but have not decided to buy. There are test patches at 11th Street and Seventh Avenue in Greenwich Village and on Smith Street near the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn.
 
Scraping the Barrel
 Asphalt roofing tile and asphalt paving material come from the same place: the bottom of the oil barrel. If oil were peaches, asphalt would be the pits. Asphalt is made from the big hydrocarbon molecules that oil refineries can't use in gasoline, heating oil or anything else.
People have thought for a long time about recycling the tile into paving material, but Reclaim, which is based in Tampa, Fla., is the first to make it work. It works in New Jersey because landfill prices are high, so Reclaim does not have to buy its raw material; in fact, it makes truck drivers pay to dump, although less than they would at a landfill.
Along with the economic incentive, Reclaim has benefited from New Jersey's decision to make recycling mandatory for materials in the waste stream for which a recycling system exists. Roofing tile represents about 3 percent of what goes into landfills.
 
Slow to Catch On
 Reclaim is not trying to maximize the amount recycled. If the pile gets too large, it will raise its fee for accepting the material. The constraining factor is the demand for its product, which company officials say is catching on slowly. Mr. Howland said that city purchasing authorities are slow to try new methods of filling potholes.
So production remains low. Most of it is mechanized, but workers still load five-gallon pails and 60-pound plastic bags with a shovel. The product is not yet available in bulk, which is how highway departments usually buy.
The company went public a year ago and trades under the ticker symbol Roof, but has not yet turned a profit.
At Reclaim these days, there is only a dribble of trucks, because few roofers work in the snow. But it will swell to a steady stream come spring.
 
The Remains of a Roof
 This afternoon Cheryl Halper, the owner of Cornell Disposal of Piscataway, pulled up with a 15-cubic-yard dumpster that held the remains of a roof from a house in Hillsboro. She signed a form saying where the material came from, information that will eventually go to Trenton and help determine the size of a bounty that the New Jersey state government pays each town. The form also included a promise by Ms. Halper that there was no asbestos in the load.
She paid $375 to dump the load. Without Reclaim it would have gone to the Somerset County landfill, she said, at a charge of $1,500. She keeps part of the difference, but most is passed along to the roofer, who presumably passes some of the saving to the homeowner.
"Hey, recycling pays," she said.
From the heap near the entrance to Reclaim's 2.5-acre plot here, a payloader carries the tile to "the muncher," a steel box containing an auger, a corkscrew-shaped piece of metal that breaks up the tile and carries it to a conveyor belt. The tile then goes to a "mini muncher," which breaks the material up finer, until it is shredded. A magnet removes roofing nails.
 
No Goo, Please
 According to Mr. Howland, one of Reclaim's special skills is breaking up the tile without heating it through friction. Too much heat turns the asphalt to a useless goo.
Along with asphalt, the muncher also breaks up the backing of the shingles, which is cellulose or fiberglass. Those materials provide fibers that make the patch stronger, he said. That idea is not new; concrete manufacturers have begun adding fibers to strengthen their mix.
Repave is 20 to 30 percent recycled material. The rest is aggregate, the technical name for the fine gravel used in asphalt, and the solvent.
Pound for pound, Repave costs about six times as much as cold patch, mainly because it requires more labor to make. But road departments say the patches last years. Cold patch sometimes lasts but often comes back out of the hole in weeks.
With cold patch, said Mr. Bull of Bayonne, "you wind up in the course of a winter going back three or four, maybe five times, because the stuff doesn't hold." With Repave, he said, "You just go once and you're finished. So the crew gets a chance to do more holes, and catch up with them."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Cheryl Halper, the owner of Cornell Disposal, delivering the remains of a roof from a house in Hillsboro to Reclaim Inc. in Kearny, N.J. Reclaim uses old asphalt roofing tiles to make patching material for potholes. (Sam D'Amico for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Productivity Booms at Workers' Expense

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Sylvia Nasar's article "The American Economy, Back on Top" (Feb. 27) celebrates the current boom but gives short shrift to the disastrous effects on workers and families. Recent gains in productivity were obtained mainly by raising factory output while reducing factory jobs and middle-management jobs. But the painful downsizing has been masked by a vast rise of mostly low-level and low-paid service jobs -- often temporary or part-time work.
Among most groups there are stagnant wage rates, reduced real family incomes, swollen numbers of discouraged workers and limited purchasing power. At the least, we should be expanding our care for the victims of this kind of boom.
 
EDWIN P. REUBENS
Fort Lauderdale, Fla., March 3
 
The writer is professor emeritus in economics at City College of New York.

HEADLINE: Winners, Losers and Bankruptcy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Beware Management Talking Poor" (Wall Street, Feb. 13), Alison Leigh Cowan exposed a slick method to pay certain creditors far more than 100 cents on the dollar in today's large Chapter 11 cases, while sticking other creditors with larger losses.
Peter C. Browning, National Gypsum's former chief executive, and John H. Laeri Jr., the financial adviser to National Gypsum's asbestos committee, contend the column was wrong (Letters, March 6). I represented a committee of bond and trade creditors in the National Gypsum bankruptcy, and I found the column was on target. 
 Initially, National Gypsum proposed a plan requiring new contracts for the top five executives. We believed the plan was based on pushed-down business projections. Mr. Browning did not receive more than his old salary as part of the plan because the court ruled it would not approve his linkage of the new contracts to the plan.
That five of six classes of creditors accepted the plan only shows that creditors don't mind being paid more than in full.
National Gypsum's directors supported the plan that extinguished their stock. That was not surprising given the admission of National Gypsum's financial adviser that he discussed with a director that the least expensive way to reacquire the company could be to buy the reorganized company's stock on a when-issued basis. To claim that the stock initially traded on a when-issued basis at the low level predicted by National Gypsum only shows that the plan worked. Only after that did the company disclose it could increase cash flow $30 million a year by laying off 12 percent of its work force.
National Gypsum's share prices rose from its projection of $12.50 a share, to $45, in less than eight months, and most of the increase occurred after the company disclosed how it was increasing income and while interest rates were rising.
 
MARTIN J. BIENENSTOCK
Manhattan, March 7
 
The writer is a partner in the business reorganization department of the law firm Weil, Gotshal & Manges.
