HEADLINE: AUTO RACING;
Some Rooms With Vrooms On Crowded Nascar Circuit

BYLINE: By JOSEPH SIANO 

 BODY:
If you plan to attend a Winston Cup stock car race and haven't made hotel reservations, you may not want to bother. Simply show up after the final qualifying session of race weekend; several rooms should be available.
More and more teams are going home early from Winston Cup races this season, as the burgeoning success of Nascar's top series has drawn more teams, more sponsors and more promising young drivers. The only problem is, the number of starting positions has stayed the same. 
 That has made it tougher than ever simply to make the starting lineup, which can vary from 37 to 43 cars depending on track length. In years past, a half-dozen or so semi-regulars would fill the few spots at the tail end of a race lineup that the big-time teams left open. As recently as last season, in fact, some races on the tour started fewer than the maximum number of cars allowed.
 
Big Names Missing
 But in qualifying for the four races this year, including the Purolator 500 today in Hampton, Ga., a number of big-name teams and drivers have missed at least one race -- including, last weekend in Richmond, the new team run by Travis Carter, with Hut Stricklin as its driver. And for the last two weekends, Wally Dallenbach, Richard Petty's driver, has gone home early.
The teams that have suffered the most, however, have been the ones whose drivers are rookies on the Winston Cup tour. Of the eight drivers considered contenders for the 1994 rookie of the year, only two -- John Andretti and Jeff Burton -- have qualified for all four races so far. And two others, Rick Carelli and T. W. Taylor, have not made any starting lineup.
"You can't make any mistakes," said Joe Nemechek, another rookie. "When you go out to qualify, you need to have the best tires you can have and the best setup, and the driver cannot make a mistake."
 
Sponsor Not Happy
 Nemechek went home before the Daytona 500, the series' biggest race. That could not have pleased his sponsor. "Well, there definitely was some pressure there," he said. "They're paying money to be on a race car and to get television time."
One driver who looked particularly relieved last weekend in Richmond was Ward Burton, Jeff Burton's brother and fellow Winston Cup rookie. Ward Burton had failed to qualify for the season's first two races, but squeezed into a tight 37-car field at Richmond and made today's lineup.
"Just making this race was almost as emotionally satisfying as winning my last Busch race at Atlanta," Burton said at Richmond, referring to his sendoff last fall from the Busch Grand National series, Nascar's triple-A league.
Because Richmond is a three-quarter-mile oval, the spread between the fastest and slowest qualifying times -- and thus the driver's margin for error -- is much smaller than at longer tracks such as Daytona. The difference between Ted Musgrave's pole-winning lap time at Richmond and that of the slowest qualifier, Bobby Hamilton, was 0.522 seconds.
 
'A Lot of Really Good Cars'
 "It's nothing new to have a lot of cars," said Jeff Burton, recalling how he and his brother arrived at some Busch series races with 40 cars vying for 28 starting spots. "What's new is there's a lot of really good cars. When you send a driver the caliber of Hut Stricklin home, that doesn't speak negatively about the team, it speaks positively about the sport."
Try telling that to your sponsor. Was Ward Burton feeling pressure as he went out to qualify at Richmond? He laughed and said, "Man, I tell you, it's a ton of pressure."
But, he said, even if his sponsor had been sitting in his garage breathing down his neck, he couldn't have driven the car or himself any harder. "I got a clear conscience with that," said Burton. "The only problem is, sometimes that's not good enough."
Richard Childress, team owner for the defending Winston Cup champion Dale Earnhardt knows how damaging it can be if a team with a major sponsor fails to get into a race.
"What happens is, the sponsors bring in a lot of their sales and marketing people, customers or whatever," Childress said. "And they do a big promotion around it. And so if your car's not in the race, it's not a good situation."
You can always make the best of it, though. Danny Sullivan, the unemployed Indy-car champion who is trying to run a handful of Winston Cup races this year, failed to qualify at Rockingham, N.C., and this weekend, and pulled out of Richmond. But the fact that he has not run a Winston Cup race this year did not stop him from having a trailer full of his souvenir merchandise parked outside the Richmond oval, alongside the trailers selling Dale Earnhardt and Bill Elliott souvenirs.

HEADLINE: A Nuclear Deal for North Korea

 BODY:
International inspectors are now scouring North Korea's nuclear sites for signs of any recent diversion of nuclear material to the making of nuclear arms. If they find none, Washington will soon resume talks with Pyongyang on gaining even greater access to determine how much material, if any, it may have diverted before inspections began and whether that was enough to make a bomb.
To win such inspections, President Clinton needs to put together a package of inducements that addresses North Korea's diplomatic, security and economic concerns. He also needs to quiet the loose talk of war in Washington. 
 To that end, he might read a report by the U.S. Institute of Peace, drafted by former officials, some of whom shaped U.S. policy toward Korea in the past. It challenges the view that North Korea's nuclear program has created a military crisis that requires a flexing of American muscle. Such posturing, the report suggests, adds nothing to U.S. negotiating leverage but instead raises doubts in Pyongyang about whether Washington is serious about a deal.
The report's assessment of the military balance indicates that the threat from the North is not growing. Pyongyang's missiles, artillery and rockets have long been able to reach Seoul. But the South is spending twice as much as the North does on defense, while the North's reduced access to oil has degraded its military effectiveness. Further, North Korea's economic setbacks are so serious that Kim Il Sung's dream of reunifying the peninsula has "given way to concern for survival."
The report also raises questions about the North's bomb-making activity. The C.I.A.'s estimate that the North has accumulated enough plutonium for one or two bombs is a "worst-case extrapolation." Moreover, there is "no hard evidence -- only the presumption" that the North has turned whatever plutonium it has into a bomb.
Rigorous inspections of North Korea's nuclear sites could clear up these uncertainties. The North also needs to carry out its 1991 pledge to dismantle its reprocessing plant, and account for any plutonium it may have produced. To coax Pyongyang into these steps, the U.S. should offer incentives to be delivered once the North takes specific actions.
It is essential, for example, that Pyongyang continue its talks with Seoul. The U.S. can then hold out step-by-step diplomatic ties and U.S. backing for aid, investment and trade as inducements for regular inspections. The package would also include a joint U.S.-South Korean offer to reduce forces in the demilitarized zone and take other steps to build mutual confidence if the North reciprocates.
Pyongyang's economy is in disarray. A firm commitment from Mr. Clinton could produce a broad diplomatic bargain that just might work, allowing Pyongyang to extract itself from a nuclear dead end of its own making.

HEADLINE: In America;
What Recovery?

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Joan Rivers lives in Sandy, Ore., a small town in the foothills of Mount Hood, not far from Portland. She's not the comedian, although she's blessed with an abiding and often therapeutic sense of humor. She's a divorced mother of six who is trying to make her way in the treacherous new world of work in the United States.
Ms. Rivers is not impressed with the current economic recovery. The wonders of the resurgent economy are proclaimed most loudly by those with good jobs and no fear of unemployment. Ms. Rivers is a college English instructor who has been unable to find work in her field. She makes ends meet (barely) by selling ice cream and espresso from a converted vacation trailer. 
 In the hierarchy of tough jobs, selling ice cream in Oregon in the winter ranks near the top.
Ms. Rivers tried to get back into teaching full time a few years ago, but couldn't. "At first," she said, "it was a shock to me that I couldn't find work that I was qualified to do. I have my degree and my teaching certificate. I'm a capable person. I have great references from my professors and everything."
Undaunted, she lowered her standards a bit. She was willing to teach high school English.
"Couldn't even get called in for interviews," she said.
She sought work as a teacher's aide. Nothing.
In desperation, Ms. Rivers even tried to go to Guam, "where I had once taught years ago. They were willing to hire me but there were no living accommodations for my kids."
She improvised. "I did some substituting, made beds at a school for the blind, made and sold wreaths at Christmas."
She had a humorous piece published in The Oregonian, and a short story in Mountain Writer's Quarterly.
"I tried to set up my home for elderly care, but that required fire escapes, decking, etc., which I couldn't afford. I started working nights at the dog racing track, selling hot dogs and beer."
One day she looked out the window at her 1972 trailer in the backyard. She saw possibilities. With her brother's help she refurbished the trailer and turned it into a concession stand. She got permission to sell ice cream at a local tourist stop. Business was O.K. during the summer but it virtually collapsed at the end of September, so she invested $2,500 in an espresso machine in the hopes that it would carry her through the winter.
"Well," she asks rhetorically, "am I unemployed? Discouraged? Self-employed? Underemployed? Or off the charts?"
Given her personal experience with the realities of work in the 90's, Ms. Rivers has little patience with official unemployment statistics and rosy economic assessments. "When I read the business page and see all these figures saying the economy is going up and there are more and more jobs available, I'm saying this isn't accurate."
She spoke of several friends who are also having a difficult time with work: "A former building contractor who builds furniture at home. A divorced woman with three kids who picks mushrooms to supplement her waitress income because she can't find a dental hygienist job. A woman working on her doctoral thesis in labor-management relations who works at a 7-Eleven.
"I used to think people who couldn't get jobs were misfits in some way. Maybe that used to be the case. But I see now a lot of vastly underutilized citizenry."
Ms. Rivers is not bitter, does not feel betrayed and, in fact, remains optimistic. But she thinks it's time for a general acknowledgement of the tough state of the economy and a more honest view of the problems of joblessness and underemployment.
She is far from alone. The New York Times profiled a family last week in which the husband and wife are working four jobs that will pay them a total of $18,000 this year. When it was noted that two million new jobs were created last year, the husband quickly put that statistic in perspective. "Sure, we've got four of them," he said. "So what?"
The economy may be improving, which essentially means businesses are doing well. But in the real world of ordinary working Americans, where the unrelenting struggle is to stop the erosion in the standard of living, things are still not looking up.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARKCHESTER;
Caught Between 3 Community Boards

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
Boundaries of the city's community boards, set up in the late 70's, are due for reconsideration under the terms of the City Charter. And in the first wave of what could become a flood of border wars, Westchester Square is trying to redefine itself.
The area -- with a residential section characterized by single-family homes peppered with high-rise buildings and a flourishing commercial section that is also a transportation hub -- is split between Community Boards 9, 10 and 11. Some merchants and other residents there are urging that it be included entirely in either Board 10 or 11 so it would benefit from the unified lobbying of one community board. 
 "As it is now, it's like a patchwork quilt," said Sandi Lusk, president of Westchester Square and Zerega Improvement Inc., one of the groups behind the campaign. "Residents are totally confused."
Alison Gran, president of the Association of Merchants and Business Professionals of Westchester Square Inc., complained that a simple event like a street fair requires the approval of three community boards, two sanitation districts and three police precincts. "This is ridiculous," she said.
Community Board 9 opposes the move; the other two boards simply say they are satisfied with their boundaries.
Under the City Charter, the Mayor must submit a report to the City Council outlining proposed changes in the city's district maps every 10 years. The review was due after the 1990 census but was delayed when the city challenged the results.
Around 1980, when the first review took place, Bronx residents fought off the city's recommendations to change some boundaries, said Veralyne Hamilton, the director of community boards for the Bronx Borough President. The community board functions largely as an advocate for a particular district, but it wields no legal authority.
As residents of Central Park North, Clinton (formerly Hell's Kitchen) and York Avenue (formerly Avenue A) can testify, New York is a city where shifting neighborhood designations often represent social and economic aspirations and differentiations.
But while there are racial and economic differences among the three community boards -- 9 is densely populated and predominantly Hispanic working class; 10 and 11 are largely middle-class Italian, Irish and Jewish -- the leaders of the campaign in Westchester Square insist their motivation is merely practical.
"I'm not changing my address," Ms. Lusk said. "This is not about Community Board 9. It's a matter of geography."
Those geographical divisions were quite clear after a recent snowstorm, when one side of Tremont Avenue, a main thoroughfare, was cleaned immediately, while it took sanitation workers two more days to plow the other side.
But the proposed plan faces an uncertain future. Councilwoman Lucy Cruz, whose district encompasses Westchester Square, said she opposes redrawing the boundaries and that few residents have complained about lack of service.
"They probably get more service because of the interlapping," Ms. Cruz said. GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RED HOOD;
A New Crane to Help Lift Up a Sagging Port

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
One of the last of New York City's bustling ports, the Red Hook Marine Terminal, will gain a refurbished, high-tech crane next week.
In a major feat of marine engineering, the 70-ton, 120-foot-tall crane will be placed on a special rail-track barge and floated about two miles north along Upper New York Bay from the South Brooklyn Marine Terminal in Sunset Park, where it has been perched idly for years. 
 It is the latest in a series of moves to revitalize the faded waterfront terminal, which has suffered through decades of neglect as the shipping industry has shifted from New York to New Jersey, said Chris Ward, senior vice president of the city's Economic Development Corporation. The crane transfer will cost about $500,000.
The city bought the $7 million crane more than eight years ago to shuttle containers, the metal boxes about the size of a rail car in which most cargo is now shipped, at the 39th Street Pier at the South Brooklyn Marine Terminal. But as the huge container ships shifted to high-capacity ports in New Jersey, the terminal focused on bulk freight, primarily cocoa, and the crane was idled.
Councilwoman Joan Griffin McCabe, who represents Sunset Park and Red Hook, said: "Nothing's happening at the South Brooklyn Marine Terminal that would require the use of the crane. It's not as if we're taking anything away from Sunset Park."
The Red Hook terminal generally serves smaller steamship lines that carry containers of lumber and plywood, salt, clothing, radios, television and bulk steel.
In 1992, the terminal's seven berths handled 53,000 containers. But last year the level fell to about 25,000 containers -- an average of four ships a week -- as most of the terminal's clients opted for New Jersey, said Sal F. Catucci, chief executive of American Stevedoring of Elizabeth, N.J. In January, Mr. Catucci's company signed a seven-year lease for the Red Hook terminal with the Port Authority.
"Given the proper equipment, we can get business back to New York Harbor and make Red Hook more attractive," said Mr. Catucci, who has nicknamed the crane Alexander, after his first grandchild.
Mr. Ward said the capacity added by the new crane was expected to attract more ships and provide hundreds of jobs.
In other moves to help the terminal, the city, state and Port Authority spent $3.2 million last year to finance a barge service from New Jersey to Red Hook. The barge, which began running about a year ago, allows customers to receive and deliver on both sides of the Hudson, said Roy Jaeger, assistant director of the port department of the Port Authority. And the authority has dedicated $9 million to revitalize the terminal, including rehabilitating storage sheds, over the next year.
Lou Pernice, secretary-treasurer of the International Longshoremen's Association, said he was not impressed with the first step of the revitalization. He said the crane could bring in a relatively insignificant number of jobs.
"This crane is going to replace something that should have been done some time ago," Mr. Pernice said. "This move will simply help the port become more efficient. I don't think it's going to add anything." LYNETTE HOLLOWAY

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LONG ISLAND CITY;
For the Giants of Retail, the Rules of the Game

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
New York is one of the last frontiers for modern megastores, partly because of zoning restrictions dating back 20 years. Now the Giuliani administration is wrestling with whether to lower those barriers to draw more of the giant stores to the city.
The barriers originated in a 1974 zoning law intended to curb the loss of hundreds of thousands of factory jobs. That law bars stores larger than 10,000 square feet in manufacturing zones, to keep retail development from driving up real estate prices and factory overhead. 
 Inconsistent provisions placed no size limit on hardware, office supply and toy stores -- a loophole that years later gave Home Depot, Staples and Toys 'R' Us entry to the city while other megastores, like Kmart and Loehmann's, were prohibited and had to go through an long appeals process for the chance of a variance.
Despite the law, factory payrolls continued to plunge -- and because of the law, retail commerce also suffered. Store sales in the boroughs outside Manhattan lagged far behind their suburban rivals.
If the city had its fair share of retail, studies indicate, it could gain 50,000 jobs, billions of dollars in sales and hundreds of millions in taxes.
The Dinkins administration last year proposed opening most manufacturing zones to stores of up to 100,000 square feet.
Now Mayor Giuliani faces the issue, with its prickly political, economic and neighborhood implications. Although his administration is viewed as pro-business and free market, Mr. Giuliani as a candidate was cautious on megastores, urging a case-by-case review. That reflected the concerns of small merchants, many of them his supporters, who fear big-store competitors.
Indeed, Queens is now home to several megastore disputes. Home Depot recently opened in South Ozone Park over neighborhood opposition and a fight on its zoning. Now a battle is shaping up over a proposed Pathmark in Astoria.
Some studies suggest that these fears are unfounded, and John S. Dyson, Mr. Giuliani's Deputy Mayor for economic development, agrees. And would more stores would drive out manufacturing jobs? Planners say the demand for retail space would leave ample room for factories.
Mr. Dyson said that he and the city's Planning Director, Joseph B. Rose, hope to complete a proposal for the Mayor soon. The process, including review by the planners, community boards and borough presidents and adoption by the City Council -- could take more than a year.
Mr. Dyson said the change would be well worth it to the city. "It's plain to me that if the big stores don't get built within the city limits," he said, "they will be built outside the city." B.L.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LONG ISLAND CITY;
Northern Boulevard, Megastore Central?

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
Legend has it that Northern Boulevard follows the route of ancient Indian paths. In more recent decades, the thoroughfare has led a more prosaic existence, lined with aging warehouses and factories and a string of automobile dealers. Suddenly in the 1990's, however, it is becoming a major urban retail center.
"It certainly is a hot megastore retail strip, a natural land-use change that the market is dictating," said Jack Rainey, executive director of the Long Island City Business Development Corporation. 
 The latest merchandiser to join the cluster of large stores in the area is Tops, the expanding suburban discount appliance chain. In its first venture into New York City, Tops plans to open a 75,000-square-foot store this fall at 50-01 Northern Boulevard. Its showroom space will match the chain's largest, at its Secaucus branch. The new site is in Long Island City near Woodside, Sunnyside and Astoria.
Kmart could well be the next addition: It is considering moving into the old Ronzoni pasta factory site opposite Tops, a decision that would symbolize the sweeping reversals in the New York economy. After 43 years, Ronzoni shut down the plant last summer and moved to Virginia, a course similar to that followed by many city manufacturers in search of cheaper overhead.
Several major retailers, including Price Club, are said to be considering the site. Kmart appears to be the most serious, although it has not announced its intentions. "A Kmart would do good there," Mr. Delis said, "and it would be an asset to the area."
Pathmark was the area's first major retail pioneer when it built a superstore on the boulevard in 1977. That remained the lone outpost until 1990, when Pergament and Toys 'R' Us opened adjacent stores on nearby 48th Street. Last year the Staples chain opened a branch on Broadway.
Not everyone welcomes the trend. Nearly 20 years ago Julian Wager was arrested in a street blockade against the Pathmark project. Today, as president of the Steinway Merchants Association and chairman of the Commercial Committee of Community Board 1, he is still opposed.
"I am not thrilled by the prospect of these stores going in there," Mr. Wager said. "They don't belong there. The roads and traffic can't deal with it. They cause bottlenecks the likes of which you've never seen."
But Mr. Rainey said, "When Pergament came in, the Sunnyside community's worst fears about traffic were not realized."
Another objection comes from small neighborhood merchants, who say they suffer from the big competitors.
Replied Mr. Rainey, "I don't know if that's the case, but we're bound to find out." BRUCE LAMBERT

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Where Cocoa Is King

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
ON the Sunset Park waterfront, alongside the 110 acres that make up the South Brooklyn Marine Terminal, waters are still and twisted steel piers are burned out and littered with garbage. The streets nearby are deserted, except for the occasional patron sliding into the local topless bar. Empty warehouses stand as ghostly relics of an age when New York boasted one of the busiest ports in the world.
But behind the high wire fences on 39th Street the other day, 100 longshoremen were unloading almost 8,000 tons of Nigerian cocoa from a freighter. As the sun beat on the wharf, 140-pound bags were piling up quickly, 15 feet high, in the half-mile-long warehouse. Soon trains would rumble on the tracks that curve around the warehouse and transport cocoa beans to the factories of Nestle, Hershey and other chocolate makers. 
That so many tons of cocoa beans are stacked up on a Brooklyn dock is a result of a decision the city made to cash in on the growing demand for chocolate. In 1989, New York set up a cocoa port on the 39th Street wharf, which since then has become the nation's third largest port of entry for cocoa -- still far behind Norfolk, Va., but catching up with Philadelphia.
Importers now complain that sometimes there is not enough space to store all the cocoa beans passing through New York. So they are pleased by the city's plans to expand the cocoa port -- either by adding an $11 million warehouse nearby, a proposal by former Mayor David N. Dinkins, or, more modestly, by converting a coffee bean warehouse on 23d Street.
The Giuliani administration will choose one plan in a few weeks, said Chris Ward, senior vice president of the city's Economic Development Corporation. "The city is committed to expanding the cocoa operations," he said. "Cocoa is clearly the growth commodity. It's the underpinning of the rejuvenation of the South Brooklyn Terminal."
Until the early 1960's, when New York City began rolling down its sleeves and buttoning down its collar, it had the world's greatest concentration of cargo piers. Then the city lost most of its shipping to ports in Newark and Elizabeth, which had modern container ship terminals.
A generation ago, New York was actually the leading port of entry for cocoa beans, but high costs and the lack of a warehouse devoted exclusively to cocoa sent beans south. In 1988, before the cocoa port opened, New York City and Albany accounted for 29,613 tons of cocoa, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. By last year, the figure had climbed to 83,346 tons, with New York City taking more than two-thirds of it.
The rise in New York's cocoa imports has been accompanied by a decline in incoming coffee beans. Cocoa imports last year, mostly from West African nations, were nearly 40 percent above the figure for 1989; coffee fell by more than 50 percent. "We see more of an influx of cocoa and a continuing decline in coffee," said Douglas Martocci, president of Continental Terminals, the city's largest warehouse for both commodities.
In part, coffee has slid because Americans drink about 25 percent less than they did three decades ago. But the immediate cause in New York is that coffee brewers, like auto makers and other manufacturers in search of lower costs and low-paid workers, have taken their factories from the East Coast to Southern states. Most notably, in 1992, Maxwell House padlocked its sprawling plant in Hoboken, once the largest coffee producer in the world, and consolidated its East Coast operations in Jacksonville, Fla. Just a year before, Hills Brothers abandoned its plant in Edgewater, N.J., for a plant in Virginia.
With the area's two biggest roasters gone, New York, which ranked second to New Orleans as the nation's top coffee port in 1989, slipped to fourth place last year.
Thus, one of the city's proposals is to transform a coffee storehouse into a cocoa warehouse, adding 300,000 square feet of cocoa storage space. One drawback, city officials say, is that the use of an existing building would do nothing to rejuvenate the waterfront. It would also steal space from coffee, which, though slipping, still accounted for 143,033 tons of imports last year.
Why can't cocoa and coffee co-exist under one roof? The smell of cocoa beans would spoil the coffee, said Gerald Ponsiglione, vice president of Continental Terminals, which leases the cocoa and coffee ports from the city. And cocoa beans are delicate.
Checking a pile of the cocoa bags from Nigeria, Mr. Ponsiglione scooped up a handful of beans, pointing out the spoiled ones with black shells and hardened insides. He said the bag had probably leaned against metal in the vessel, preventing the beans from breathing. "It's especially risky at this time of the year," Mr. Ponsiglione added, "with the beans going suddenly from a warm to a very cold climate."
The city's other plan calls for the construction of the $11 million warehouse next to the cocoa operation on 39th Street. The cost of simply renovating the coffee port would be substantially less, though the city has provided no figures. For the new 250,000-square-foot building, $6 million would come from the state and the rest from the city's capital budget. Among the potential economic spin-offs are 100 jobs to build the warehouse and 80 jobs to operate it, as well as $10 million in tax revenues over 25 years.
"The downside," Mr. Ward said, "is spending $11 million, which might be better allocated on other waterfront projects."
Johann J. Scheu, president of the Cocoa Merchants' Association of America, said that for cocoa importers, a port's efficiency and low rates are more important than its proximity to manufacturers. Referring to Norfolk, he added: "The industry has been somewhat concerned that it was concentrating in only one location." Cocoa importers have urged Philadelphia and New York to modernize their equipment, to compete better with Norfolk. Mr. Scheu pointed to changes between 1992 and 1993: Norfolk lost about 74,000 tons, while New York and Philadelphia gained a combined 89,000 tons.
City officials are hoping for even greater gains. In their dreams, New York will be known as much for cocoa beans as Coco Chanels. "We are committed to capturing the cocoa," Mr. Ward said.

HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK;
Firemen in Waiting

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
FIREFIGHTERS spend most of their time waiting, fidgeting benchwarmers at a game they can only anticipate. While they wait, they make their own beds, scrub their own toilets, polish their truck (they call it an apparatus). In full fire regalia, they take their shiny red truck to the supermarket, then cook feasts together. They drill on techniques, lift weights, watch television and read mountains of Playboys dating back more than a decade.
At Ladder Company 176, in a tattered corner of Brooklyn, firefighters go about their tasks with a camaraderie found in few groups outside the Boy Scouts. (Women are still a rarity, accounting for just 35 of the city's 11,800 firefighters.) In fact, the men like their jobs so much they routinely arrive an hour or so early. 
 Despite the probability that most will be injured at least twice during their careers, the undisputed high point of their day is a fire; Ladder Company 176 puts out some 40 a month (more than most units but less than one just a few miles away, in Crown Heights), and responds to about 30 false alarms as well as sundry emergencies, from a cat up a tree to a domestic dispute to a woman giving birth.
But to firefighters, anything less than a glorious conflagration -- especially an "occupied structural work," a burning building in which people are trapped -- ranks only slightly higher than snarling guard dogs.
"Anything else is like kissing your sister," allowed John T. Vigiano, the company commander, who won a bout with smoke-induced throat cancer a decade ago. "Everything seems to come up two or three notches when there's a good fire. It's like a game."
Despite the heroics, the Fire Department has its critics. One of the most vocal is Raymond D. Horton, president of the watchdog group Citizens Budget Commission, who contends that firefighters misuse their time. He argues that since urban fires are started by people, people can prevent them. And firefighters, whose duties are defined in union contracts, should be busier conducting inspections, enforcing regulation and educating people. "A perfectly functioning Fire Department would go out of business," he says.
Such revolutionary thinking goes against the machismo grain, though Ladder Company 176 now does inspections two half-days a week. "Firefighters don't want to do building inspections; they don't want to do housework," says Captain Vigiano, a 32-year veteran. "They want to go to fires."
A ladder company's function is to find the fire, ventilate the rooms and rescue people trapped inside, while the engine company's job is to actually put out the fire. Ladder Company 176 and Engine Company 233 share a modern firehouse, situated where the neighborhoods of Bedford-Stuyvesant, Bushwick and Brownsville converge, an economically bedraggled area of vacant lots, storefront churches and Chinese takeout places with bulletproof glass.
 9 A.M. A typical day at Ladder Company 176 begins with roll call. Firefighters work a seemingly haphazard pattern of shifts, a schedule adopted after World War II that has never been changed. They do nine-hour tours on two succeeding days, take 48 hours off, work two 15-hour shifts, then take 72 hours off. Each month, they get an additional day off to keep the workweek to 40 hours.
At roll call the ladder company's five firefighters and one officer are assigned duties. One man, the driver, is also expected to coordinate things outside a burning building. Today he is Cornell Horne, an affable Vietnam veteran who is quick to send flowers to a sick colleague. Mike Pagano, a second-generation firefighter known for his physical and emotional strength, is designated the forcible-entry, or irons, man. He uses an ax and other tools to fight his way to a fire while a colleague carries an extingusher. The extinguisher bearer, or can man, will be Jim Mills, a new fireman who radiates enthusiasm. Jack Sweeney, whose father served for more than 35 years, will be in charge of "lateral ventilation," through windows and walls. The roof man, Thomas Farragher, a 12-year veteran, is responsible for "vertical ventilation."
"Very few jobs have as much instant gratification," says Mr. Farragher. "You're there, and you don't leave until it's out."
9:23 A.M. The alarm sounds -- a smooth series of beeps. Then bells ring -- two summon the engine company, three the ladder company and four both. Most often, both go.
A few men slide down two gleaming brass poles from the living quarters, where there is a study, lounge and dormitory for snatching naps in work clothes. The men move briskly, putting on their leather helmets, coats and boots with practiced motions. They don't run, to avoid bumping into one another. The idea is to quicken response time rather than speeding in traffic. Talk is crisp and factual as the men pile into the cab and race toward an apartment building in East New York.
Some motorists pull to the side, but others seem oblivious even to the deafening horn (the department has shifted to European-style electronic sirens, less damaging to hearing than the old-fashioned whine).
At the apartment building, which houses the mentally ill, it turns out a resident threatened to set fire to his neighbor's apartment. The police, who automatically answer fire alarms, take over.
Minutes later, as the truck wends its way back to the firehouse, a beeping is heard. Another alarm, this one in Brownsville. "I can see smoke," says Mr. Horne. The atmosphere is tense, and they strain to see smoke as they approach. A burning mattress has been thrown in an air shaft. The firefighters drag it outside and extinguish it. A skylight is opened to ventilate the shaft. End of job.
10:35 A.M. Next stop is Met Foods. Mr. Horne stays in the truck to monitor the computer, which sounds alarms and provides addresses and any known details (a central computer processes all fire calls in the borough and automatically assigns companies).
The other firefighters, led by Mr. Pagano, today's designated chef, keep in contact with Mr. Horne via radio. At Met Foods they buy five loaves of Italian bread, Goya red kidney beans and other fixings for chili, a Pagano specialty. He attributes his culinary expertise to TV cooking shows and tricks picked up from firefighters.
The men tip their helmets, a department tradition, to female customers as they pass in the aisles. Each man's share for food will be $5.
11:05 A.M. A call comes from a woman who thinks she is breathing toxic fumes. The firefighters and their officer, Lieut. Philip McDonnell, nicknamed the Sheriff, agree the oil burner and chimney in her tenement need to be fixed. They shut off the furnace and begin the paperwork to force the owner to make repairs. He has up to 16 days, which could mean the building will be cold until then.
"The woman probably thought we could just come over and fix it," says Lieutenant McDonnell. "We can't."
12:53 P.M. Mr. Mills, a firefighter for only nine months, pulls the ladders out of the truck and begins washing them. He is quickly joined by the others, who have finished helping Mr. Pagano chop vegetables for chili.
Firefighters must have a high school education and complete an eight-week course. Before joining the department, Mr. Mills was a police officer for eight years, rising to detective in a Brooklyn anti-crime unit. He is critical of police life. "The managers here go into the fires with you," he says. "Police captains sit in their offices. Then they second-guess what you do four days later." A son and nephew of firefighters, he says it is the bonds between comrades he most values. Referring to Mr. Pagano, he says, "When I come to work and he's working, my confidence goes up."
1:30 P.M. Motivated by thoughts of an alarm, the men gobble down huge platters of rice and chili. "It's not good for your stomach, but you get used to it," Mr. Horne says.
The scene -- firefighters gathered at the table, boots and rubber slickers arrayed in neat rows -- fits the children's book stereotype. Except that this company has never favored high-strung Dalmatians, a traditional horse-stable dog that became a firehouse regular when apparatuses were truly horse-powered. The firehouse has been dogless since the even-tempered Snotsy, a former stray, was run over by a car. But there is no shortage of nonhuman companions. There are two boa constrictors, a python, a baby alligator, four chinchillas and a half-dozen tanks of large tropical fish.
2:10 P.M. The company is on its way to shovel snow from around hydrants and inspect them for storm damage. Mr. Horne, puffing a postprandial cigar, flips on the siren. "I want everybody to know I'm coming," he says.
As the engine cruises, the firefighters see sites they have fought big fires. They point to buildings, quizzing one another on how to approach a fire. After 3 P.M., with students dismissed from school, radio activity picks up as children pull alarm boxes: more false alarms to go out on.
4:03 P.M. Captain Vigiano, who is working the night shift, arrives early. Between battles with a stack of paperwork, he recalls growing up in Bedford-Stuyvesant, and how nice it was to walk with his grandmother to a little bakery on Sundays. He learned his trade as the area burned in the late 60's, when arson was common and there were as many as 38 calls a night for Ladder Company 176.
The result, he says, was that firefighters quickly got on-the-job experience. But he doesn't think the job has become easier. Today's double-paned windows delay discovery of fires and make temperatures higher. There are toxic fumes from plastics. Anti-burglary devices complicate firefighting. "We had more work, so we got better," he says. "They don't have the work and face more obstacles."
5 P.M. The first shift ends, but many hang around. Dinner, arroz con pollo, will be served at 7:30 around the handsome wood table the men built themselves.
"If you had a son and you wanted him to be a firefighter," Captain Vigiano says, "this is where you'd want him to learn his trade."
 
Mike Pagano's Firehouse Chili
Total time: 2 1/2 hours
 
5 pounds ground beef
5 pounds hot Italian sausage (links)
4 stalks celery, diced
6 pounds of bell peppers, both red and green, diced
5 pounds of yellow onions, diced
4 28-ounce cans crushed tomatoes
1 tablespoon each basil, oregano and dried red pepper flakes
3 tablespoons cumin
8 tablespoons chili powder.
1. In a large pot over medium heat, cook the beef and sausage until brown. With a spoon, remove excess grease from the pot.
2. Add the celery, peppers, onions, tomatoes and seasonings, and cook over low heat for two hours. If the chili seems too dry at any time during the cooking, add water.
Yield: 17 servings.

HEADLINE: At Work;
The I.B.M. Circle: Still Unbroken

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble 

 BODY:
IN the years of its dominance, the International Business Machines Corporation was a one-of-a-kind behemoth employer, an elite, life-long womb to which only the best and brightest aspired and were granted entry. So it's not surprising that the 150,000-plus employees who did not survive into the company's post-dominance era would be inclined to stay in touch with each other.
That at least is what Alexander Auerbach, a public relations executive who once covered I.B.M. as a financial journalist, figured as he was driving down the Ventura Freeway in Los Angeles one day last year listening to a National Public Radio story on downsizing at the Armonk, N.Y.-based company. As the story came over the air, he hatched the idea of a publication that would provide news, advice and contacts for the thousands of employees who had been and would be nudged and pushed off the I.B.M. plank. "Two exits later, I had a business plan," Mr. Auerbach joked. 
 This month he published the first issue of Out of the Blue, eight pages of items and tidbits designed to keep the company's alumni around the country at one with their cultural roots, and to help them cope with the shock of separation.
Changes in the work force, especially downsizing, have inspired other startup publications. Hunt-Scanlon, the Greenwich, Conn., publisher of an executive search newsletter, has just mailed out the first issue of Workplace America, which tracks numbers on layoffs as well as career and work trends. And other companies have in-house newsletters and magazines that are sometimes sent to former employees.
But I.B.M. is one of the few companies whose former employees could or would support an independent publication.
"I.B.M. had a unique culture. When people worked there, they bought in," said Rick Weiner, Out of the Blue's editor and a 26-year I.B.M. veteran who took early retirement last year when his job in corporate communications was eliminated. "It was a wonderful corporation. It demanded a lot, but it gave a lot. People who were there so long considered themselves as part of an extended family."
The deep, family-like attachments explain some of the difficulties I.B.M. employees have shifting to the outside world. Not only are many of the downsizees past the point in their careers when shifting gears is uncomplicated, but also, as the lead article, on life after I.B.M., notes, in I.B.M. parlance an employee who leaves the company is said to have "left the business."
"The expression implies that there is nothing else in the computer industry, and maybe not much else of real interest in the business world," writes Emily Andren, who left the company in 1992 and is now a freelance writer. The toll that attitude takes on the identities of workers cut loose is evident in the anger, sadness and confusion of some of the former employees whose stories Ms. Andren tells.
The overall tone of the newsletter, on the other hand, is optimistic. The words "Big Blue Meanie" never appear. The approach was chosen deliberately, Mr. Auerbach said, in part because he is not eager to mix it up with the still-wealthy and powerful organization, but also because he has a message to deliver. "People need to focus on tomorrow, not yesterday," he said. "Investing a lot of emotion in what I.B.M. 'coulda-shoulda' done is pretty pointless."
MOREOVER, Mr. Auerbach and Mr. Weiner agree that however painful the layoffs and changes have been for particular individuals, it was necessary to save the company and the 200,000 jobs it will eventually represent. "The company is facing economic reality," Mr. Weiner said. "It's treating people as well as it can."
The newsletter would not hesitate to publish a critical article, he said, but it is not out to throw darts. Indeed, Paul Carroll's gleeful 1993 evisceration of the company, "Big Blues: The Unmaking of I.B.M.," is favorably reviewed, but without dwelling on what looks to many outsiders like ineptitude on a huge scale. Like the newsletter's other writers, the reviewer worked at I.B.M. The first issue also contains an assessment of I.B.M.'s stock prospects; a first-person account of the perils of moving from a New York City suburb to a small island off the North Carolina coast, and a jobs bulletin board.
What happens to the newsletter once I.B.M. has finished its convulsions and has settled into whatever fate its current employees and executives fashion for it? Can it survive the recovery from mourning of former employees who move on emotionally and materially? The I.B.M. alums, many of whom are in their 40's and 50's, are in the prime advice-receiving years. They are thinking, Mr. Auerbach said, about "everything from being in the sandwich generation to preparing for retirement." Because of their backgrounds, brains and general lack of interest in going to seed, they are also a group employers and investors -- more potential subscribers -- are likely to be interested in. So his publication may not last forever, but then, Mr. Auerbach points out, neither did Look or The Saturday Evening Post.
Information on Out of the Blue, which costs $39.95 a year, is available at 800-871-2583 or P.O. Box 56044, Sherman Oaks, Calif. 91413.
 
 
 
THE LAY OF THE LAND FOR LAYOFFS
IT is quite possible that no newsletter will ever fill the gap left by the demise of Workplace Trends, a feisty, fervently pro-employee bimonthly that disappeared when its editor, Dan Lacey, died early last year. Workplace America, the new newsletter from the Hunt-Scanlon Publishing Company in Greenwich, Conn., is considerably more buttoned-down than Workplace Trends, but to some degree it picks up where Mr. Lacey left off. It provides, for example, a tabulation of fourth-quarter layoff announcements, a vivid reminder that the current recovery is a macroeconomic event not of immediate relevance to many workers.
Workplace America's impetus was simple enough: "Because the workplace is changing so much," said Christopher W. Hunt, the newsletter's editor. "Some of the stories we covered aretestimony to that: flextime, harassment and job layoffs." Mr. Hunt plans to publish the newsletter five or six times a year for Hunt-Scanlon's audience of human resources and executive search specialists and job-seekers. For the latter, the daunting list of layoffs may be counter-balanced by another item, entitled "An 'Out of Work' Executive Could Be Your Best Candidate."

HEADLINE: Highlighting Hair, Women's Ultimate Crowning Achievement

BYLINE: By MARJORIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
RAPUNZEL let hers down. Delilah had Samson's cut off. Medusa's was turned to serpents.
"A woman's hair, which completely replenishes itself, is a powerful symbol defined by myth, traditions, modern concepts and media hype, which influences colors, style and care," Dr. Connie Koppelman of Setauket said. "It can signify age, conformity, mourning, rebellion, punishment, servitude and sex appeal. How can the acceptance of a variety of hair styles move society toward the acceptance of a diversity of life styles?" 
 In June, Dr. Koppelman presented a paper to the National Women's Studies Association in Washington on "The Politics of Hair." Her research took a multicultural approach toward hair as a symbol of power and powerlessness. She discussed how, throughout history and cultures, women's hair, especially, had been styled to show beauty, removed to cause humiliation and interpreted as a sign of strength or weakness.
Hair can determine social, economic, intellectual and marital status or religious affiliation.
Dr. Koppelman has degrees in art history, library science and in American history. She became active in the women's movement in 1972 as an intern at the Whitney Museum of American Art, when a critic, Lucy Lippard, became her mentor.
"That was one of the most wonderful experiences of my life," Dr. Koppelman said. "It was during the Conceptual Art movement. I was present at the first all-women's art exhibition in January 1973 in New York City held at the Huntington Hartford Museum near Columbus Circle."
For five years Dr. Koppelman has been an adjunct lecturer in the women's studies program at the State University at Stony Brook, where she directs the programming in March for women's history month.
"I had always been interested in how women were treated in advertising and the emphasis on beauty rather than brains," she said.
She started her research on hair after a presentation by the African studies department on how advertising affects women's hair. "During my research," Dr. Koppelman said, "I began to have some doubts about my own hair. I stopped coloring it and I cut the front shorter, left the back longer, showing my own ambivalence."
When planning the program for this year she teamed with Norma Cohen, executive director of the Smithtown Township Arts Council. The exhibition is an outgrowth of Dr. Koppelman's paper and Ms. Cohen's resources of hundreds of artists and a national advertisement for related art work.
The show, "Hair: The Long and Short of It," includes 89 artists and begins today at the Mills Pond House in St. James with a presentation by Dr. Koppelman.
Michele Brangwen of Bellerose, who performs with the City Ballet of Houston, will discuss hair and its relation to dance. A video that she choreographed and performed, "The Lone Star Dances," will be shown.
A workshop for children is scheduled for March 19.
The exhibition, which runs until April 17, is financed by the State Council on the Humanities and the National Endowment for the Humanities, as well money from L'Oreal.
"We had no idea what kind of response we would get, but we were flooded with enthusiastic artists," Dr. Koppelman said. "We saw the potential that a head of hair has to communicate public messages."
The cultures reflected are as diverse in shape, form, color and texture as hair itself. All the artists were invited to submit statements about their work.
The spiritual power imputed to hair can traced back from the sun. The early settlers of India referred to their solar god as having "the flaming hair," and the Aztecs' God of Declining Day had "abundant hair."
Rhoda Sherbell of Westbury, whose polychromed bronze of Casey Stengel was purchased by the National Portrait Gallery in 1981, and whose bronze of Aaron Copland has been approved for acquisition, is exhibiting a bonded bronze called "Out of Africa, the Legacy."
After extensive travel through Africa "from the Horn to the Cape," Ms. Sherbell said, she found beauty as well as horror in some of the cultural practices. Her sculpture in St. James was created after a visit to east Africa.
"Hair has always reflected the society that it belongs to, and especially in Africa it has different styles and meanings," Ms. Sherbell wrote in her statement. "Heads are covered, veiled, shaved, braided, adorned with medals, painted with animal fat or covered with cowry shells, as in my sculpture, to signify female sexuality and currency. All the designing has to do with the inextricable practice of ancestral and spirit worship from religious rites to the rite of passage."
Because the African cowry shells cannot be taken out of Africa she used shells from the Philippines. The elaborate sculpture makes a statement about how a woman presents herself. "With a head of shells she is an important person in her group," Ms. Sherbell said.
Alex Gardega of Huntington, who attended the School of Visual Arts and the Fashion Institute of Technology, has been etching glass for six years, much of it relating to mythology. Drawn to the subject of Medusa he began experimenting with oil paint and etching on glass to create between the hair and the face "just enough tension between the two."
Mr. Gardega's Medusa poses the question: "What if a woman with a normal face had such awful hair? What if she had classical beauty, how would she be looked at? How much are women today judged by something they have limited control over?"
He chose to paint a peaceful Madonna-like face contrasted by serpent hair, placing her as a victim of the snakes. Perhaps, he said, that would make people look for a deeper meaning.
A monotype print of a kabuki actor and onnagata, Tamasaburo Bando, is a subject for Susan Carter Carter of Port Jefferson, a printmaker who is also an adjunct professor of art at Suffolk Community College. "In kabuki just a few strands of hair out of place can convey distraught emotions," Ms. Carter Carter said. "I elaborate on that and use the hair as a compositional device."
Since a college summer program took her to Tokyo in 1969, Ms. Carter Carter has used Oriental imagery. In 1974, after much debate, Ms. Carter Carter braided for the final time her own 10 years' worth of hair, reaching midthigh. She said her hair had been a source for endless comments, conversations, jokes and wonder, which evoked offers to touch, brush, cut and even purchase it.
After the cutting, she said, "I remember it so warm, like an animal sitting in my lap." Her hair had come to symbolize the embodiment of a whole period in her life, she said.
Twenty years later and inspired by the theme of the exhibition, Ms. Carter Carter has created a reliquary for her braid, "a more noble resting place." It is three feet long.
When Miriam Cassell of Sea Cliff saw the call for slides in the Smithtown Township Arts Council newsletter, she said, "I had been working on an installation piece in celebration of having green hair for 10 years."
The hues in her hair, to match her eyes, added to her natural red hair. "I've been called a piece of walking art," Ms. Cassell said.
Much of her art work is serious and emotional, and her looks provide a balance, a sense of comic relief, she realized. "When you add color to a canvas or to yourself, you really bring joy to other people," she said. The 10 X 7-foot hanging consists of 47 pieces showing different ways of hair coloring, with a screaming green-haired Ms. Cassell in the center.
Ms. Cassell said she always used her body to create art forms. Accompanying "Performance Art" is a book construction. The mannequin with an elaborate headdress holds her artist's statement.
"My hair is my crowning artistic effect," Ms. Cassell said. "People react to my hair as a mirror reflection of who they are. It creates humor, tension, envy, intimidation, shock, anger, curiosity, but never neutrality. People either compliment or criticize, but I take their reactions in stride. My art evolves and envelops me because I know hair today, gone tomorrow."

HEADLINE: Fishermen and Other Residents Rally To Fight Ferryboats as Threat to Way of Life

BYLINE: By ARTHUR Z. KAMIN 

DATELINE: BELFORD

 BODY:
FOR more than 200 years, the resilient fishermen from this tiny Raritan Bay village have battled severe storms at sea and heavy flooding in port. In recent years, they have voiced concerns about overregulation from what they say are too many overlapping state and Federal agencies, as well as water pollution, declining fish stocks and a growing public awareness of the need for safety in eating seafood.
They know they are in a fragile industry. But now the fishermen from the port of Belford, the last major commercial fishing enclave in New Jersey's Bayshore area and a strong economic force in the region, are facing what they call their biggest survival challenge ever: ferryboats and commuters. 
 They have vowed to save the Belford Seafood Cooperative Association's historic fishing sanctuary in Compton's Creek from a $16 million Monmouth County government plan to build a neighboring ferry terminal, a 1,200-car parking lot and other buildings on 40 acres. The co-op says the project "will squeeze us out and destroy us."
The co-op generates about $4 million in sales yearly, including revenue from a retail store here. It provides about 300 jobs and brings about $10 million into the local economy, fishermen say. The Belford-based fleet consists of about 70 vessels.
But Middletown Township's recently elected Mayor, Joseph W. Oxley, who lives in Belford, sees the ferry project and other Bayshore plans as a "major plus for the area" -- one that will, he said, increase property values.
The ferries would make the 18-to-20-nautical-mile trip to Manhattan in 45 minutes. The county says they could complement or perhaps replace ferry service now operating out of Highlands and Atlantic Highlands. About 450 commuters make the trip now each weekday, and a study projects that the number could grow to 1,200 to 1,400 riders by the year 2,000.
The ferry project is one component of a plan to revitalize the Bayshore region, which encompasses nine municipalities in Monmouth County and four in Middlesex County along Raritan and Sandy Hook Bays. It involves a county park, a hiking and biking trail and possibly some private commercial development in the Port Monmouth area. It is unclear whether that project will become a reality.
 
'A Question of Navigation'
 "Fishing boats and ferryboats just don't mix in a narrow channel," contends Richard T. Isaksen, a third-generation fisherman who lives here and owns a 65-foot trawler, the Iasetta, named after the first working boat his father ever had. Mr. Isaken's 17-year-old son, the next generation, is one of his crew on the 100-mile, three-day trips out into the Atlantic Ocean.
"This is a question of navigation, a question of safety." Mr. Isaksen said. "The time has come for us to draw the line. We are going to fight this to the end."
The fishermen say they are alarmed that plans are to bring in three ferryboats into the creek. They say the ingress and the egress at the mouth of the creek are too narrow to allow the safe passage of a 40-foot-wide ferry and a 25-foot-wide fishing boat in the 75-foot-wide channel.
"Just another negotiating tactic on the fishermen," said Henry R. Nicholson, the director of the Monmouth County division of transportation and one of the small army of county employees and hired consultants involved with this and other proposed Bayshore area development projects. "We've been through this before with them." Mr. Nicholson said. "What we are planning will help preserve the fishing industry in Belford, not eliminate it. The fishermen will have to learn to share. Our consultants tell us there is no safety problem."
 
Impact of Traffic Feared
 The fishermen do not agree with that, nor do a group of 135 Belford residents who have formed the rapidly expanding Belford Citizens Association, which fears the impact of the heavy commuter traffic on their narrow streets.
They say their quality of life is at risk and so is the very character of Belford, a section of modest homes on small lots along the north and south sides of Route 36 in Middletown Township, which is Monmouth County's largest municipality with about 68,000 residents. Belford has about 4,500 residents.
"That's typical of the arrogance and the lack of concern we are getting from the county," said Patricia Cusick, who lives with her husband, Thomas, on Main Street, the main pathway for the automobile traffic. The commuters are expected to come from nearby wealthy areas, a source of irritation to the Belford people.
Plans for an access road from Route 36 to the proposed ferry terminal were eliminated after wetlands problems developed. Mrs. Cusick said residents were not informed of the change.
The Cusicks were among the chief organizers of the citizens' group last July, when, they said, hundreds of large dump trucks suddenly started rumbling into Belford, filled to the brim with dirt, to be used to cap an old landfill near the proposed ferry terminal site.
"No one told us a thing," Mrs. Cusick said. "We could not get any answers from the county. Township officials and the police said they knew nothing about it. One day, 240 trucks came in and then left our town. Children were not allowed out. You can see why we seriously question the county's credibility."
Strong political pressures eventually brought the trucking to a halt. The county has now authorized a $55,000 study by its engineer to investigate the possibility of excavating soil from the area surrounding the landfill to be used to cover the landfill. County Administrator Robert J. Collins took the blame for authorizing the trucks' dirt deliveries and apologized to the Belford residents.
"The only bright side to that whole terrible and outrageous episode was that we realized what we were up against and had galvanized the fishermen and the people of Belford into action," said Paul V. Chaballa Jr., a Belford resident who is active in the association. "We don't have all the attorneys and the consultants that they have. But we do have people who are willing to work for what is right."
 
Finding a New Ally
 And now the fishermen and the residents have a new ally in Andrew J. Willner, who keeps an eye on Raritan Bay as the baykeeper for the American Littoral Society's New York-New Jersey harbor program. The society is a national conservation organization based on nearby Sandy Hook.
"The Belford ferry project should be scrapped as rapidly as possible," said Mr. Willner, an environmental advocate. "It doesn't belong there. There are alternative sites for it in the Bayshore if, indeed, another ferry site is needed."
Mr. Willner said the county and its ferry consultants, TAMS, an engineering, architectural and planning firm from Boston, and its New York affiliate, Howard/Stein-Hudson Associates Inc., never contacted him.
"This is a classic example of how people in a traditional community are being impacted by forces from outside the community who know nothing about the community," Mr. Willner said.
 
Planning Board Review
 Another potential supporter of the fishermen's position is Judith H. Stanley, chairwoman of the Middletown Planning Board and also the president of the Monmouth County Conservation Foundation, which is dedicated to preserving open spaces.
Though the ferry project does not need Planning Board approval, it must go before that body for review. Mrs. Stanley said she would study "very, very carefully" its total impact on Belford, which, she added, "has a great deal of history, beauty and charm."
Clyde L. MacKenzie Jr., a fisheries biologist at the James J. Howard Marine Laboratory at Sandy Hook, said, "I hope the fishermen win this one." Mr. MacKenzie, who is the author of a book, "The Fisheries of Raritan Bay," published recently by the Rutgers University Press, added: "It's obvious the people who are proposing this do not know what they are talking about. Ferries and condominiums don't belong in Belford."
 
An Official Willing to Listen
 Representative Frank Pallone Jr., a Democrat from the Sixth Congressional District, of which the Bayshore area is a part, has become what Thomas Schnoor, a fourth-generation fisherman, calls a "savior" for the fishing industry. Mr. Schnoor is the president of the Belford Co-Op, the umbrella organization for its 38 members and 31 independent fishermen.
Mrs. Cusick said Mr. Pallone was the only major elected official willing to listen with a promise to take action to benefit the fishermen and Belford residents.
Ronald Schnoor of Belford, a third-generation fisherman, treasurer of the co-op board and Thomas Schnoor's uncle, said the next step would be to take the ferry issue directly to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman. "It's time someone from Trenton looked at this matter objectively," he said. "We think she will."
Mr. Pallone held a public meeting at a Belford firehouse in February that was attended by more than 200 residents of the area. No one spoke in favor of the ferry project. Mr. Pallone said he would gather further information from the Army Corps of Engineers, which must give or deny approval for the proposed widening and dredging of Compton's Creek.
He also said he would investigate, with the Coast Guard, possible safety hazards in the narrow channel if ferryboats entered those waters in competition with the fishing boats. "I think everything you are saying about safety is absolutely correct," he told the applauding fishermen.
Mrs. Cusick said she was disappointed that County Freeholder Theodore J. Narozanick, who has been in charge of the Bayshore revitalization projects, did not attend.
Later, Mr. Narozanick, for the first time, broke ranks on the county position on the ferry project. "I would not be averse to another engineering study," he said. "Nothing is written in stone. I am a great believer in compromise."
He is expected to be a candidate for re-election in November, as is Mr. Pallone.
 
'They Handled This Badly'
 Patrick W. Parkinson, a former Mayor who is serving his seventh year on the Middletown Township Committee, said it was time for the Belford project to be brought to a halt and for the county to take another approach.
"They handled this badly," he said. "First of all, they never told anybody what was going on. No wonder people are confused."
In addition, Mr. Parkinson said he did not think the ferry ridership projections were accurate. He said businesses were leaving New York, which would mean fewer commuters taking the ferry to work there.
The township's Deputy Mayor, Joan Smith, also a Belford resident, said she stood somewhere between Mayor Oxley and Mr. Parkinson.
"I think the county is taking too strong a position," she said. "This is our township, not theirs. It's time they started to massage this ferry plan to make the fishermen and the Belford people happy."

HEADLINE: New Jersey Q & A: Dr. Henry A. Coleman;
Helping Government Run Efficiently

BYLINE: By ARTHUR Z. KAMIN 

DATELINE: PISCATAWAY

 BODY:
IN one way or another, all of New Jersey's 567 municipalities, 21 counties and the state government itself have been touched -- probably for the better -- by the Center for Government Services at Rutgers University.
It is one of the few departments at the state university that combine teaching, research, continuing education, technical assistance and public service -- all aimed at making local government units operate more professionally and more efficiently. 
 "No question -- we are in the trenches every day with our strong commitment to public service," said Dr. Henry A. Coleman, who took over in September of 1992 as director of the center, which was established in 1950 as the Bureau of Government Research.
Right now, Dr. Coleman is trying to make sure that the center continues to be regarded as a nonpartisan agency, ready to serve municipal governments run by either political party. He was a top policy aide to Gov. Jim Florio on fiscal, budget and housing issues.
"I served as a bureaucrat detailed to Governor Florio's policy office," he said. "I was never asked to do purely political activities during my tenure."
 
Stress on Ethics Courses
 Concerned that several recent corruption and misconduct episodes at the local level in New Jersey "lower the public credibility of all municipal officials," he wants to place even greater stress on center courses that deal with ethics and integrity in government.
Interestingly, his old boss, Mr. Florio, is now at Rutgers as a visiting professor of public policy and administration and will be lecturing at the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy, of which the center is a component.
Dr. Coleman, whose Ph.D. is in economics, lives in Newark. He is known as one of the country's foremost experts in the area of government finance.
With a new Governor, Christine Todd Whitman, in place and her warnings that this is a time for frugality and cost cutting at all levels of government, and with many questions about whether current levels of municipal and school aid will be maintained, the role of the Center for Government Services has taken on an even greater importance, Dr. Coleman said.
 
Concern on Rising Taxes
 "There is a new concern that property taxes will be going up," he said. "Everyone now is looking not only for ways to be leaner but also for ways to be smarter in the delivery of government services. There are some real opportunities ahead for us."
Many mayors, Dr. Coleman said, are coming to realize that state aid is going to be reduced, and they would be happy just to have current municipal aid programs preserved. He agreed with Governor Whitman that there might be areas in municipal and county spending that could be cut, but questioned whether that would be enough to halt tax increases.
"Remember," he said, "when the income tax was enacted in 1976, it was a property tax relief fund. Take away some of that relief, and it can only mean one thing."
The center, at the university's Livingston College campus here, offers 600 courses in 18 areas of local government and has a full-time staff of 30 people and several hundred adjunct faculty members, all experts in their fields. The courses vary from 9 hours to 13 weeks and cost about $35 to $45 an hour.
The students include municipal financial officers, administrators, lawyers, tax assessors and collectors, planning and zoning board members, firefighters, elected officials, purchasing officials and public works personnel.
The center, which Dr. Coleman says is self-supporting, has also provided research and staff assistance to various state government commissions. It also publishes the annual New Jersey Legislative District Data Book, which is loaded with demographic and tax statistics on legislative and Congressional districts and on municipalities.
Q. What is the center's most important function?
A. All of our activities are important, in my view. However, if significant is measured by scale and/or scope of activities, our 600-plus continuing education programs serving more than 20,000 students annually would be seen as most important.
Q. Where does the center get its funds?
A. Center funding derives from several sources. First, we impose fees and charges, akin to tuition, for many of our continuing professional education courses. Next, we have a few ongoing contracts with the state and the Federal Government to provide training for building code and fire-related personnel, respectively.
We do some research and technical assistance under contract, primarily with state agencies and municipal governments. We generate some revenues through the sale of publications, especially the annual Legislative District Data Book. Finally, just less than 15 percent of our operating revenues is provided by Rutgers University.
Q. The center is now a component of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy. What are the benefits that go along with that move?
A. The principal benefit is that we are now part of a larger organization that shares a common mission -- public service. A state university like Rutgers has a threefold mission: to generate knowledge (research); to impart knowledge (teaching), and to use knowledge to improve the quality of life for its citizens (public service).
This last component is often overlooked. The center, along with our sister organizations in the Bloustein School, helps to provide a critical core set of activities in furtherance of the public service mission.
Q. Does New Jersey really need 567 municipalities?
A. I do not know if 567 are needed, but at least at some point in the state's history, that number was preferred. There is no formula that will take in all of the state's characteristics and churn out a "right" number of municipalities. Moreover, increasing or decreasing the number of municipalities will not be a guarantee of greater efficiency or equity in service delivery or financing.
All that we can say is relative to other states of similar population or geographic size, New Jersey has a lot of local governments, and evidence from research and analysis would suggest that some improvements in efficiency and economy would potentially result from regionalization or consolidation.
Q. In that connection, the Florio administration seemed to talk a good game about the consolidation and regionalization of municipal governments and school districts. But the perception is that little happened. What went wrong?
A. Since I do not know very much about what was attempted by Governor Florio, I cannot really say what, if anything, went wrong. Consolidation and regionalization offer the potential for improved service delivery, as well as cost savings.
I think the state should provide, one, more information so that localities know the potential benefits and problems associated with regionalization. Two, technical assistance so that amenable localities have the required "know how" for implementing regionalization, and three, incentives so that municipalities and school districts are induced and not pushed into greater regionalization-consolidation.
Q. How do you view Mrs. Whitman's action to cut income taxes by 5 percent retroactive to Jan. 1, a measure she signed last week?
A. I have somewhat mixed reactions. The tax cuts may help improve the business climate and provide a modest economic stimulus.
On the other hand, part of the benefits to New Jerseyans will be offset through higher Federal taxes -- both because of Federal tax increases and because residence will have fewer state income taxes to deduct against their Federal tax liability. In addition, the loss of state income tax revenues may exasperate existing revenue shortfalls in the state budget.
Q. Mrs. Whitman is also setting up a 12-member economic master plan commission aimed at coming up with a blueprint for the state's economic future. Your reaction?
A. New Jersey is home base for some of the country's best economic analysts. I think it is commendable that the Governor would seek to tap this resource on an ongoing basis. I see no downside to the establishment of such a commission as a source of advice and counsel to the Governor as she grapples with some very difficult issues.
 
 
 
Profile
 Born: Aug. 2, 1949, in Atlanta.
Education: B.A. in economics, 1971, Morehouse College; M.A., 1973, and Ph.D., 1979, in economics, Princeton University.
Career: Executive director, New Jersey State and Local Expenditure and Revenue Policy Commission; assistant director for operations and research, New Jersey Department of Treasury office of state planning; policy adviser, New Jersey Governor's office; director of government finance research, United States Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations; professor of public policy and director of the Center for Government Services at Rutgers University.
Family: Single.
