HEADLINE: Elevating Sales to a Degree Program

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
WHERE do the heads of American corporations come from? Some reach the top position through a company's legal department, others from accounting, but the majority of chief executive officers are former sales executives.
"Sales are the engines that drive companies," said Edward Flanagan, president of the International Association of Sales Professionals, a trade group with a chapter in Westchester. "You only have to examine any corporate financial statement. Up in the left-hand corner are the company's sales figures, listed prominently. 
 "Businesses depend on a productive sales force for their ultimate success. Yet, people in sales suffer from a negative-image problem, even though, according to the Census Bureau, the number of people who make their living in sales has increased 40 percent since 1980, to 14.5 million today. But the general public still believes that sales is not really a profession."
Other than the individual company training that is given to a sales staff, selling has largely been ignored as a profession by the academic community, Mr. Flanagan added.
 
An Aid to Recruiting
 In order to change these perceptions and improve the image of selling, Mr. Flanagan said that 90 members of his group, from such companies as Avon, Nynex and Sony, met last June to develop a national standard of training and certification.
James Carter, chairman of the trade group and vice president of sales at Domino Sugar, put it this way: "We decided that formal academic training, similar to that which exists for accountants, financial planners and social workers, would help the image of our profession and help recruiting and decrease turnover.
"Sales executives are tired of accepting the traditional poor image of our profession. We're tired of not seeing enough good people making sales a career. We are frustrated that our academic institutions don't offer enough sales courses or a certificate or a degree program leading to the bachelor of science and sales."
Now Berkeley College, a two-year college of business with five campuses in the New York City area, is collaborating with the members of the trade group and has developed a professional-sales-degree program, the first of its kind by any college in the nation. The course will be offered to students at Berkeley's Manhattan and White Plains campuses this fall.
Dr. Rose Mary Healy, president of Berkeley College in White Plains, said: "The professional-sales-degree program is a result of an interesting partnership between education and corporate America. It has already been approved by the New York State Board of Regents, and students are now being recruited for the first class in September."
The year-and-a-half program, which will combine formal academic training with practical work experience, "integrates the classroom with the workplace," Dr. Healy said. "The curriculum includes a core of general business education as well as seven required sales courses, and three paid internships will give a student the opportunity to get some practical hands-on skills. Students will graduate with an associate degree in professional sales and will leave with a thorough understanding of business practices and sales strategies."
What is also interesting, Dr. Healy said, is that in conjunction with an advisory board of members of the International Association of Sales Professionals, "students in the program will get a terrific opportunity to form a network of contacts with prospective employers, as the advisory board has pledged to support the internships and also to work with us to provide permanent positions for the graduates. We are in such a good location here: right in the middle of the largest concentration of corporations in the country, many of them involved with the sales-degree program."
Enrollment at Berkeley's Westchester campus, situated on a wooded 10-acre site on West Red Oak Lane just off the Platinum Mile in White Plains, is about 500, of which 140 are housed in Berkeley dormitories and apartments.
"We recruit students from far and wide," Dr. Healy said. "Several come from abroad. These international students are here to learn American business methods." The school, she added, has an interesting history and has changed with the times. "Berkeley was founded in Manhattan in 1931 in the depth of the Depression," she said. "The first class had an enrollment of 12 students, all women."
 
Accredited as a College in 1987
 When the Berkeley School, as it was known for 59 years, opened its first branch in White Plains in 1945, it was still a traditional secretarial training school for women, teaching typing, shorthand and office skills. It was accredited as a college in 1987.
"The enrollment was all female until 1980," Dr. Healy said. "Men now make up about 25 percent of the student body, and we also have many more male faculty members. We have also added courses that attract men specifically, in restaurant and hotel administration, and despite the recession our enrollments have been holding steady. In fact, we are finding enrollments up among older adults who are either upgrading their skills or preparing themselves for entirely new careers."
Dr. Healy said that courses focus on business and added that 92 percent of the graduates find jobs immediately after graduation. "Our graduates are career oriented and in demand," she said. "It's the mid-size companies where most of the jobs are today. We are perhaps best known for teaching support staff. Shorthand has been replaced by training in computers. Administrative assistants, customer-service account reps are the types of jobs graduates start. Many go on up the ladder to successful careers."
 
A Pragmatic Program
 Now that selling is to be taught in an educational atmosphere, Mr. Flanagan said, there will be a better understanding and appreciation of the role of more than 10 million Americans who earn their living in sales.
"Instead of the adversarial relationship that has long existed between academia and the world of work, here is a pragmatic program developed by leading sales professional educators in tandem," he said. "We are very excited about it. It makes good sense. Students will be taught by a team consisting of one member from the Berkeley faculty and the other from our group of professional trainers who make their living training the sales forces of different corporations.
"For students, it means that they can begin their careers in sales as professionals. For companies, it means they have gained a more effective sales work force with less turnover. It's our hope that other colleges throughout the country will adopt the professional sales curriculum."

HEADLINE: Above the Battle at West Point

BYLINE: By LAURA CUNNINGHAM; LAURA CUNNINGHAM is the author of the memoir "Sleeping Arrangements" (NAL/Plume).

 BODY:
MY uncle Len has always marched to the beat of a different drummer, and that beat led him, on a recent weekend, to check in at the Hotel Thayer at West Point for "undisclosed reasons." As a traveler, Len has always cloaked his movements in a fog of mystery to match his actual cloaklike trenchcoat. Len raised me from age 8 and, during my childhood, he would periodically vanish on what he called "secret missions." At 6 feet 6 inches, tiptoeing on his size 13 shoes, Len's personal aura seemed to combine Sam Spade with Len's own lifelong hero, Abraham Lincoln.
"There's a matter of national importance that must command my attention," Len would say as he departed. He was famous, in our family, for his secrecy and style of traveling light. He carried only a manila envelope. Everything else, including his shoes, would be mailed ahead to the "undisclosed location," and then returned in a sturdy metal mailing box that looked as if it might really contain what Len implied were classified materials. When I was 10, I was sure Len was a world-class spy, or some sort of government agent. At some point in my teens, I peeked into the "classified" file and found only a clean change of underwear and rolled socks. I began to suspect he hadn't truly traveled abroad on a matter of international diplomacy but had taken a weekend flyer with his girlfriend. 
 Not all his trips were fictional: When I was 11, Len whisked me off to Castro's Cuba while the walls ran red with blood oaths to Batista. Len hinted he was there to talk to Fidel, but ultimately he admitted, as we stood on a shrapnel-pocked street, that he had transported me to Cuba to give me some perspective on a problem I was having with a fifth grade teacher. His method worked: I forgot all about the fifth grade.
In the decades that followed, I came to realize that most of Len's trips were in his mind. He made Walter Mitty look like a pragmatist. He exaggerated the distances and the significance of his outings: A trip to the Borscht Belt became obliquely referred to as "official business with the Russians." I learned that he was not, after all, a spy, but a senior economist with the state of New York. After his retirement, it appeared that Len had hung up his trenchcoat and manila envelope for good.
Then, suddenly, at 78, shrunken down to 6 foot 4 but still imposing, with a full head of silver hair, Len was on the move again. But why West Point? Why now? Uncle Len was characteristically noncommittal: "It never hurts to be near ramparts." He murmured a few asides regarding global unrest, and packed a manila envelope, mailed his shoes to West Point, and booked himself a room, river-side, with a view of stout castles and the Hudson. He wore an admiralty cap.
Even before he arrived at the Hotel Thayer -- I escorted him up and back -- Len was thrilled with "the protocol." On the phone, the reservations clerk asked: "Is this a military assignment? A P.C.S.?" referring to a Permanent Change of Station.
"That remains to be seen," said Len, taking the American Association of Retired Persons discount rate.
The Hotel Thayer is government-owned and operated, a fortress built of local granite, that has stood stony guard over the United States Military Academy grounds since 1926. Flags and insignia flying in the crisp river breeze, the hotel itself seems to stand at attention for the 440 cadets who march past.
But the Thayer seemed a real departure from Len's usual style: the nap is worn from the elevator rug and any hedonists would flee before reveille. No one will tuck a bedtime chocolate on one's pillow here for a nice nighty-night. In fact, government-employed chambermaids sprint in to snap off the air-conditioning if any guest should depart his room for even a few minutes. On the other hand, there is no room or food tax.
Len implied, as he checked in to his somewhat fortlike room, that his mission was "government-related," but he refused to elaborate. We had lunch in the feudal-style dining room, a lunch that was surprisingly tasty. The chef turned out to be trained at the C.I.A. (Culinary Institute of America)), and the price (about $10 a person) was as fetching as the presentation (fruit salad served in a carved pineapple). The lettuce was buttercrunch, not the dreaded iceberg, but still I wondered: Why West Point? Why the Thayer? Why was Len tipping his admiralty cap to the desk clerks?
As Len recounted the hotel's history, I began to get a glimmer: "George Washington himself chose the location for West Point. He called it 'the key to America.' " Then Len told me of the giant chain Washington had thrown across the river to block a British invasion. Washington himself surely slept on the site, in a tent, to oversee the design of the series of forts and redoubts that became West Point. Three hotels preceded the Thayer, and housed many notables. "General MacArthur's mother stayed here, to be near her son when he was a cadet," said Len.
A more recent roster of the current hotel turned up an intriguing mix: former Presidents (Ike was the first to sleep here, Mamie moved in for the war years), entertainers (Dinah Shore), fighters (Sugar Ray Leonard) and, as they are always referred to at the hotel, "the American Hostages." The hostages checked in for three days in 1981, to recover from their captivity in Iran. All other guests were asked to leave, and the staff was locked in with the hostages, for security reasons. The hostage stay is still vivid to those clerks who remained with them ("We gave them slippers," recalls one hotel employee, "but they were unaccustomed to wearing shoes, and they walked the halls barefoot all night.")
Len loved the story, and he loved the lobby and the halls, too. The desk clerks were more than friendly. When I'd phone, they'd say, "I just saw him wandering through the lobby," and comment on what a nice man and what a knowledgeable history buff.
When I picked up Len at the end of his stay, he told me the highlight of his trip was a privately arranged visit to "The Fortifications Collection" at the West Point Library. I stopped to chat with the chairman of the collection, Col. Roger Ney, retired. Fortification, the art of building and maintaining forts against the threat of siege warfare, was a period with a distinct beginning, middle and end. The end, it turned out, came suddenly, as soon as the enemy could be airborne. Colonel Ney, the author of "The Patton Mind," as well as a resident historian on West Point and the history of fortification, outlined the elaborate system and design that made West Point so impenetrable.
Len loved the fortification collection: "It makes me feel so safe, in retrospect." But he saved the best for last: a visit to the hotel's Presidential Suite. While it is not possible to reserve the Presidential Suite (unless you happen to be the President), it is quite possible to stay in it -- if you check with the desk after 6 P.M. If no Presidents or other notables have checked in, you may indeed, as Len and I did, hotfoot it up to the third floor and the semi-secret suite, just to look around; it
costs $175 a night for non-Presidents.
Len and I entered the four silent rooms. In the living room, there is a black marble fireplace for Presidential chatting. The bedroom features two double beds, and two toilets (one for the President and one for the First Lady), and there is a kitchenette, where a President could have what Len calls "a snackaroo." In the living room, there is a gleaming raft of a desk, rumored to have belonged to F.D.R. I watched Len assume his seat, and dash off a memo, where perhaps F.D.R. once took a note or two.
We concluded what Len called his "fortification vacation" with a hike to Fort Putnam. Len breathed hard on the climb, but he pressed on, and when we reached the summit, we were the only visitors to this restored Revolutionary War ruin. The day was clear. We could see miles along the blue ribboning Hudson. From down below, at the West Point cemetery, came the sad, but oddly soothing sound of taps. The mighty cannon aimed below. It was not just easy, but inevitable to feel transported back in time. And to think of that distant troubled past was somehow to arrive at this afternoon's sense of peace -- certainly the secret of Len's secret missions. On this afternoon, at West Point, we both stood above the battle.

HEADLINE: State Is Rolling Out the Red Carpet for World Cup Soccer

BYLINE: By JOYCE JONES 

 BODY:
GEORGE R. ZOFFINGER recalled sitting in a Portuguese restaurant in Newark in 1990, about to eat a forkful of paella, when Gov. Jim Florio endorsed his idea: bring the World Cup to New Jersey. Mr. Zoffinger, then the State Commerce Commissioner, was given the go-ahead to offer Giants Stadium as a site for World Cup games in 1994, the year the United States would be the host nation.
In 1992, soccer's governing body, the Federation Internationale de Football Association, announced nine American sites for World Cup play, including Giants Stadium. Seven games will be played there, and the organizers say the matches will add up to the largest sporting event ever held in the New York metropolitan area. Over a five-week period beginning on June 18, half a million people are expected to see the games. The finals will be held in Los Angeles. 
 Other numbers indicate the magnitude of the event. It is projected that two billion people will watch the finals via satellite, up from 1.5 billion for the 1990 World Cup in Italy. Such a forecast proved a viable reason for companies to pay $30 million each to be official World Cup sponsors.
Some $800 million in revenue is expected to pour into the New York-New Jersey region, up from the original projection of $400 million. Even the World Cup draw held in December was a boon to the metropolitan area.
The opening game at Giants Stadium pits Ireland against Italy, an event that Mr. Zoffinger, now a co-chairman of the New Jersey World Cup Host Committee, calls "a match made in heaven."
Filling New Jersey's coffers will be an estimated $13 million in sales tax alone. The economic impact on the state has so much riding on it that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman saw an occasion to give her husband, John, a financier, his first official appointment: co-chairman of the New Jersey World Cup Host Committee, along with Mr. Zoffinger. The co-chairmen's posts are unpaid.
Hotels are already booked; restaurants are conjuring up menus to satisfy the taste of those who will cheer on Saudi Arabia and Morocco, two of the teams scheduled to play at the stadium. Car rental companies are swamped with orders, and shopping malls are ready to promote their wares to occupy visitors without soccer tickets who are traveling with ticketholders.
"The World Cup is a showcase for New Jersey, and we are working hard to take advantage of it," said Gerry Kauper, the acting director of the New Jersey division of travel and tourism. "Hotels at resort sites are offering tour packages; those who stay in the hotels will fill area restaurants."
It was at a restaurant frequented by Portuguese soccer fans -- Seabra's Marisqueira, in the Ironbound section of Newark -- that Mr. Zoffinger played out his idea.
The Essex County Sheriff, Armando Fontoura, a founder of the Portuguese-American Congress of New Jersey, recalled the occasion. "We had finished marching in the Portuguese Day parade and were about to eat when loud yelling continually erupted from a crowd gathered around a television," he said. "Governor Florio asked what was all the commotion about, and George explained they were soccer fans watching the World Cup."
Mr. Zoffinger, who is the now the president and chief executive officer of Constellation Bancorp in New Brunswick, reasoned that if Giants Stadium could be a site for the 1994 World Cup, New Jersey with its deep ethnic ties to the sport would enthusiastically support the games, and the state's economy would benefit.
Soccer's proponents backed his prediction. On a Sunday morning last June, an allotment of tickets for the first five games at Giants Stadium went on sale by telephone at 9 A.M. By 11 A.M., the stadium was sold out. Later, the remaining two games also sold out.
From the start of site selection, soccer federation officials never lost sight of the fact that Giants Stadium was the only arena in this country to have been host to more than six million soccer fans as the home of the Cosmos and the scene of the farewell game of the Brazilian soccer star Pele.
Guido Tognoni, a spokesman for the federation at its offices in Switzerland, said that despite the fact that the field at Giants Stadium by soccer standards is short one meter on each side, measuring 66 by 103 meters instead of 68 by 105 meters, "It would have been stupid not play there," he said.
Having toured Giants Stadium, Mr. Tognoni said: "The stadium has several hundred professional people in place; they even have their own security system. Frankly, we never considered not playing at Giants Stadium, if it were offered as a venue site."
The stadium's 76,000-seat capacity may be reduced somewhat for such factors as field requirements and additional space necessary for television coverage.
After the selection, Doug Arnot, executive vice president of World Cup U.S.A. '94, the United States organizing committee, named Charles Stillitano of Westfield, a lawyer with the American Telephone and Telegraph Conmpany, to head the New York-New Jersey preparations for the games.
"I selected Charlie because he is indicative of why the World Cup is in New Jersey," Mr. Arnot said. "He's steeped in soccer history there, understands the ethnic diversity of its fans and has worked for New Jersey youth soccer leagues that have over 120,000 members. Charlie was all-American soccer at Princeton University, and he understands both sides of the game."
Mr. Stillitano, looking for some benchmarks on numbers and dollars, began his assignment by asking Dr. James Litvack, an economics professor at Princeton University, to put together an analysis of the economic impact the seven games would have on the region.
Speaking about his report, Dr. Litvack said: "What was hard to analyze was, What is the spending going to be like of the ticketholders? An 8-year-old and his mother who travels from Princeton to the Meadowlands may buy a soda, a hot dog and pay for parking. But a group of Italians who come here and stay for a month, needing meals and hotels -- that data changes the numbers."
For Rich Fritsky, the Meadowlands Chamber of Commerce president, it is not just about spending money but increasing trade with foreign visitors and their companies. The chamber includes companies like Goya Foods, the Matsushito Electric Corporation and Hartz Mountain Industries.
"It's an unprecedented opportunity for this region to market itself to the world," Mr. Fritsky said. "Unlike other sporting events, people will come and stay for a month. It gives them time to see what makes this area tick from an economic viewpoint."
Smaller companies also see the opportunity to increase their clients. Glasgow and Sons, manufacturers of children's clothing in Perth Amboy, received approval from Time Warner, which licenses products bearing the World Cup insignia, to design a line of children's clothing with the insignia. The outfits, in red, white and blue, are for newborn to age 13 and include sports clothing, jackets, shorts and sweat suits. They are sold in such stores as Kmart, Caldor and Wal-Mart.
When the games begin in June, Assemblyman John A. Rocco of Cherry Hill envisions play on a board game he created, called World Cup Soccer. Reviewed and approved by Time Warner, the game carries the World Cup insignia and will be sold at nine places throughout the country.
A teacher at Rowan College who has used simulation in the classroom, Dr. Rocco has deployed the same technique with the board game. He said it was geared for beginners along with soccer coaches who can use the board to explain strategy.
George Blasko, who has a U-Save Auto Rental franchise in Clifton, even opened another location on Route 17 to be closer to the Meadowlands and has added foreign cars to his inventory.
In addition, he raised his stock of 15 passenger vans to 100. "People will be traveling in groups," he said, adding that it is "better to have 15 people who don't speak English in one vehicle than have groups of five people in three cars getting lost."
Hotels near the Meadowlands have been booked to accommodate groups like journalists and television crews; some 3,000 media people are expected to be accredited for each game. Away from the site, hotels near training camps throughout the state will house teams and their entourages.
The Italian team will work out at the Pingry School in Martinsville and has reserved the entire Somerset Hills Hotel in nearby Warren Township.
Restaurants and pubs are gearing up. Early in the year, Alan Meinster, a co-owner of Marsilio's in the Chambersburg section of Trenton, dubbed New Jersey's Little Italy, offered cooking classes featuring dishes that would appeal to World Cup teams. But his effort is to get the Italian team to visit the area, where, he said, "the food will make them think they are back in Italy."
At Club Cocomo in Lyndhurst, Mario de Paola, a co-owner, who is also the United States Soccer Federation Region 1 director, has booked groups like 500 Canadian tourists for dinner, shuttling them to the stadium and back for cocktails.
Last October, Cryan's Beef and Ale House in South Orange installed a satellite dish so that fans could watch Ireland qualify for the World Cup. Large, signed photographs of the Irish team decorate the walls, and John Cryan, the restaurant's owner, says he has a commitment from the Irish team to dine there.
Even what had been considered a drawback for Giants Stadium, its artificial turf, has turned into a windfall for New Jersey businesses. Under federation rules, soccer may be played only on natural turf.
To meet the requirement, a field of Bermuda grass, currently growing in Virginia, will be installed. Before it is put down, local companies will construct a platform and truck in tons of soil. The loam will make the turf grass at Giants Stadium a rich shade of green, something akin to the color of the money that will flow into the region.

HEADLINE: For Governor's Husband, A World Cup Role

BYLINE: By JOYCE JONES 

 BODY:
WHEN Gov. Christine Todd Whitman named her husband, John, co-chairman of the New Jersey World Cup Host Committee, it was his first official appointment in her administration. Taking the unpaid post was a departure from Mr. Whitman's usual posture of a mate who is highly supportive, but avoids any official roles.
His appointment, he said, "demonstrates to everyone how important the Governor feels the World Cup is to New Jersey and how she wants to know intimately what is going on every step of the way." 
 With Giants Stadium the site for seven World Cup games, including a semifinal, Mr. Whitman said, "billions of people worldwide will see these games played in New Jersey." He added, "As the most direct spokesperson for the state with the foreign dignitaries who will come here, it's Christie's light to shine on everything she possibly can to showcase the great things we have."
 
Sharing a Post
 Mr. Whitman shares the host committee post with George R. Zoffinger, who was appointed to it in 1992 by Jim Florio, then the Governor. Mr. Florio continues as honorary chairman of the committee, which has among its goals "to sell New Jersey to the world."
As for any political ramifications, Mr. Whitman said, "At the end of the day no matter what your political party or what you are trying to accomplish, basically, if the state does not prosper, you are not going to either."
The timing of the World Cup, Mr. Whitman said, ties in with the new administration's long-range planning. Recalling his wife's statement in her inaugural address, "We are open for business," Mr. Whitman said: "Central to the plan for economic recovery is to attract new business to New Jersey. This is a way to get around the economic problems the state has been suffering. Enjoy the World Cup; come away with a new vision of New Jersey as a place to live and work."
Mr. Whitman, 49, who has been a Wall Street financier, started his own consulting concern, Broken Bridge Inc., which in 1992 earned fees of $1.5 million. He said his work on the host committee would not be confined to finances, but was geared to coordination of the activities of the host committee with the Meadowlands operation and the World Cup U.S.A. '94 organizing committee.
 
'Reaching the End'
 "All of the work of these groups has been going along, and now we're reaching the end of the planning process," he said. "What follows is to make sure that everyone knows what everyone else is doing."
While the host committee will be involved in some fund-raising events, Mr. Whitman said, "I will do whatever they ask, but I am not the banker."
During his new assignment, he will remain engaged in running his own company. "Don't regard this appointment as one of a long line of such positions," he said. "This is short term. But if another situation like the World Cup arises and the Governor feels it is important to make her personal interest in it known, she may call upon me again."

HEADLINE: Chinese Puzzle;
After Months of Dialogue on Human Rights, Beijing Takes Harder Line Toward the U.S.

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 13

 BODY:
From the outset, Warren Christopher's first visit here as Secretary of State has been a diplomatic mugging. Today he and his aides were trying to understand why.
But instead of answers, what Mr. Christopher got was a philosphical discussion punctuated by aphorisms in a meeting with President Jiang Zemin: 
 President Jiang: "You can't become a fat man with one big meal."
Rough translation: The Chinese must proceed step by step toward human rights reform, and no amount of force-feeding will speed up the process.
President Jiang: "You have to clash before you become friends."
Rough translation: We bashed you intentionally to put you on the defensive, and now that we have the advantage, we would like to resume our talks.
After six months of broad and deepening dialogue with the Chinese on human rights, one of the most sensitive issues in this society, Mr. Christopher has been treated to a Chinese attitude that an American official described as "in your face."
The Chinese reaction was not altogether surprising, because Beijing had asked Mr. Christopher to delay his visit, hinting that the timing was not good. But his aides said that this trip best accommodated the Secretary's calendar, and that he was insistent on delivering President Clinton's message on human rights. So Beijing relented.
With less than three months to go before Mr. Christopher recommends to President Clinton whether to renew or revoke China's favorable trade status with the United States, the Communist leadership refuses to articulate, by word or deed, how it intends to respond to Mr. Clinton's challenge to make "overall significant progress" on human rights.
What seems certain is that the struggle within the Chinese leadership over how to define human rights for the country's 1.2 billion citizens is very much unresolved. And therefore Mr. Christopher's mission to admonish, scold and cajole Chinese officials seems destined to be resisted.
The state security authorities who rounded up the usual suspects of dissent last week so Mr. Christopher and his aides would not be able to hear their voices have only reinforced China's image of being in a defensive crouch.
Some American officials have said Mr. Christopher's trip was ill timed, because the annual session of the National People's Congress, China's ceremonial Parliament, opened on Thursday, one day before Mr. Christopher arrived. The Secretary's message may have sounded too much like a rebuke to Chinese leaders concerned about losing face before the assembled cadres.
Other officials wondered whether a new hard-line current was in ascendance in the Chinese leadership. With Deng Xiaoping, the paramount leader, appearing to be in frailer health, China's anti-reform octogenarians whom Mr. Deng forced into retirement may be pondering a comeback.
If that is so, President Jiang may be losing some of his political maneuvering room for tough decisions regarding human rights, like accounting for and releasing political prisoners and opening Chinese jails, detention centers and labor reform camps to international inspection.
No Chinese leader can contemplate concessions on that scale without considering whether the hard-liners will regard them as a sign of weakness.
Since January, when President Jiang told a delegation from the United States Congress that China was going to make an effort to improve human rights, his pronouncement has been followed by inaction.
Some American officials are worried that it could be paralysis.
Not since President Richard M. Nixon came to China in 1972 to begin to reopen relations after more than two decades of hostility has there been such a sense that China and the United States are on the cusp. But of what?
The stakes are enormous for both sides. No one in the Clinton Administration, and virtually no one in Congress or in the human rights organizations, actually wants China to lose its status as a favored trading partner.
Such a move would hurt American consumers, whose purchases of a wide range of Chinese products, including inexpensive textiles and toys, have given China a $20 billion trade surplus with the United States.
At the same time, the Chinese have enjoyed the phenomenal economic growth that comes from access to the United States market. Any slowdown risks social unrest.
American corporations, whose regional chiefs today also chided Mr. Christopher over the Administration's human-rights policy, depend on the low cost of Chinese labor. As their investments grow, what they want is stability in American-Chinese relations.
The simplest explanation for this month's clampdown on dissidents, and the hostile reception for Mr. Christopher, may be the most compelling. Many China analysts point out that the fear of chaos is deep within the Chinese leadership. "Stability" has become a code word not only for political repression but also for a "never again" attitude toward the remnants of China's democracy movement.
This winter's human rights dialogue with Washington and the June deadline for Mr. Clinton's trade decision have empowered and emboldened China's dissidents for the first time since the violent crackdown at Tiananmen Square in 1989. So it is not surprising that with the Communists' urgency for control and order, the authorities swiftly detained and intimidated members of the democracy movement and effectively muted them.
 
A Display of Muscle
 The prospect of Mr. Christopher's arrival seemed only to encourage the dissidents further. What better opportunity, one Chinese analyst said, for President Jiang to establish his credentials as a leader tough enough to crack down on dissent, strong enough to lead the country after Mr. Deng is gone?
"The leadership needs to demonstrate that it can run China," the Chinese analyst said. "It needs to demonstrate to itself and to the country that it is strong."
These currents may have converged as Mr. Christopher and his entourage made their way across the Pacific.

HEADLINE: Rebound in Interest Rates May Hinder the Recovery

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Interest rates have climbed by more than a percentage point in five months, and the American economy is beginning to feel the pinch.
The great rush to refinance mortgages at lower rates and lower monthly payments -- a big source of extra cash for consumer spending -- has slowed sharply, the Mortgage Bankers Association reports. Bank loans to individuals and companies are no longer rising. And many families are rushing to buy houses before mortgage rates go any higher, a flurry of activity that probably will not last, some economists say. 
 "All the data about mortgages and lending suggest that the rise in interest rates is beginning to produce the first stages of an economic slowdown -- a mild one, but clearly slower growth," said Nancy R. Lazar, a senior economist at ISI Group, a Wall Street investment house.
Low interest rates had been the cornerstone of the Clinton Administration's strategy to strengthen the economy and drive up employment. And while no one had expected rates to remain as low as they had been last October -- when the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond, a barometer for many important lending rates, fell below 6 percent for the first time in 25 years -- neither had most people expected the rise to be so quick and so strong. On Friday, the yield on the 30-year bond neared 7 percent, and the rates for other loans lasting two years or more have risen in tandem.
 
Surprisingly Quick Rise
 Most of this rise has occurred since early February, when the Federal Reserve, concerned that the robust economy might be inflationary, decided to push up interest rates slightly to inhibit borrowing and spending. Wall Street traders, who have the power through their buying and selling of bonds to make interest rates fluctuate, then pushed up rates more. They responded not so much to expectations of inflation, but to such unsettling issues as the Whitewater investigation involving President Clinton and the Administration's threat of trade sanctions against Japan.
"This extreme nervousness on Wall Street is relatively temporary," said David M. Jones, chief economist of Aubrey G. Lanston, a bond trading firm.
The sudden jump in interest rates bothers Administration officials, though it has not shaken them from their forecast that the national economy will grow 3 percent this year, even if interest rates do not subside. The economy had been growing at twice that rate from July through December, but 3 percent growth will be enough, the officials say, to create jobs at a healthy pace and reduce unemployment.
"Obviously, we would prefer a lower 30-year Treasury bond rate than we are seeing now," said Gene Sperling, deputy assistant to the President for economic policy. "But even if interest rates stayed where they are now, it is still a far more stable and favorable economic environment than we inherited over a year ago."
 
Still Comparatively Low
 On the day of President Clinton's inauguration, the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond was 7.4 percent, Mr. Sperling noted. Even after the recent surge, rates remain quite low compared with their levels during the last 15 years. What is more, many economists argue, the strong economic activity late last year produced a momentum that has offset the rise in interest rates.
"The rising interest rates will dampen the demand for loans and soften the economy in the process, but this is offset by the fact that the economy has been more robust and the recovery more solid than we expected," said Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office.
That view seems to have been confirmed in the weekly surveys of consumer sentiment by the University of Michigan's Consumer Research Center. "There was a time that people were very apprehensive that the country could quickly slip back into recession, and that apprehension is gone now," said Richard T. Curtin, director of the Michigan surveys. "People certainly don't have a blind eye to the problems of the economy, or their own job problems, but they tend to diminish the negative news out there."
That might explain why car and truck sales have not been affected. They continue to boom, although auto loan rates are up half a percentage point, to more than 9 percent on average for a four-year loan. "But if rates stay up, I would expect to see some slowing in sales later this year," said Wynn Van Bussman, an economist for the Chrysler Corporation.
 
Spurred Auto and Housing Sectors
 More than anything else, the Clinton Administration had counted on low interest rates to make the auto industry and home construction boom. These are huge areas of activity, and the expectation was that prosperity in these industries would spread to the rest of the economy, an expectation that seemed to be materializing in the very strong fourth quarter of last year.
Now, the greatest uncertainty is home construction, given that the average rate for a 30-year mortgage has risen by a full percentage point since October, to 7.6 percent. While home sales are strong, home construction has fallen this year, either because of the bad weather or the rising interest rates or both.
"It is going to be awfully difficult to interpret what is happening in housing until the spring," said Lyle Gramley, the chief economist of the Mortgage Bankers Association, who said he believed that construction would remain strong because mortgage rates, even at 7.6 percent, were still relatively low.
The rising interest rates have not touched some areas of the economy. Retail sales were brisk in February, despite the bad weather, the Commerce Department reported on Friday. "For the most part, people are paying the same rates on their charge cards that they always paid," said Joseph Siegel, a vice president of the National Retail Federation. If anything, some credit card rates have fallen as card companies compete for customers.
Home equity loans, a big source of family credit, are also largely untouched, as are the loans that banks make to small companies. Both are tied, in most cases, to the banking industry's prime interest rate. They rise or fall in lock-step with the prime, and it has remained unchanged at 6 percent for more than a year.
 
Corporate Debt Unaffeected
 Similarly, big companies that borrow millions of dollars by issuing long-term bonds or short-term commercial paper, which are i.o.u.'s, report that the rise in interest rates has not affected their borrowing plans. The Colgate-Palmolive Company, for example, is issuing commercial paper at a 3.5 percent rate, compared with 3.25 percent last year. "That is not enough change to make a difference for us," Brian Heidtke, the treasurer of the company, said.
And Colgate-Palmolive has not canceled its plans to sell $250 million of new bonds by the end of April, although the rise in the 30-year barometer Treasury bond rate means the company will have to pay an extra percentage point or so above what the cost would have been last fall.
"In a longer historical context," Mr. Heidtke said, "the present Treasury bond rate of nearly 7 percent is still very reasonable."
Still, many economists predict that the higher rates, if they endure, will eventually pinch the economy, mostly because of their potential impact on vehicle sales and, in particular, home construction.
"Eventually, higher rates mean higher mortgage payments," said David Wyss, research director for DRI/McGraw-Hill, an economic consulting firm. "And that means fewer people buying homes and less home construction."

HEADLINE: Christopher Ends Beijing Talks Citing Modest Gains

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Monday, March 14

 BODY:
Three days of talks between Secretary of State Warren Christopher and China's leaders ended today with Beijing making modest gestures on human rights that had been sought by Washington.
Mr. Christopher's talks, which both sides said were quite blunt, marked the highest-level visit to Beijing since the Clinton Administration took office and had been planned as the high point of the Administration's six-month-long strategy of intensive engagement with the Chinese. 
 By sending home Mr. Christopher with little to show for his first trip to Beijing as Secretary of State, the Chinese instead have complicated their chances of retaining a relatively favorable trade status that expires in June. Under an executive order issued last year, China must make "substantial, overall progress" in human rights to win extension of the trade benefits, which allow Chinese goods to enter the United States with virtually no tariffs.
 
'Clarity' Is Achieved
 "I came to China to try to insure that the Chinese side understands the importance of human rights in the context" of extending trade privileges, Mr. Christopher said at a news conference after a meeting this morning with China's Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen. "I doubt we would have achieved such clarity at least the highest levels without the advantage of this visit."
Mr. Christopher sought to portray his three days of talks in a positive light and his presentation today lacked the rancor and critical tone of remarks made during his first two days here. He said the two nations have begun "to narrow the differences" between them.
Specifically, the Chinese took some modest steps on a number of fronts, Mr. Christopher said.
On the most sensitive issue -- accounting for and releasing political prisoners -- Mr. Christopher said that his team had received "a great deal of information" on 235 specific cases first presented to the Chinese last fall.
John Shattuck, the Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, said afterwards that American officials were still evaluating the information, but that it appeared to be "definitely more than we had before."
And for the first time, the Chinese have pledged to provide detailed information about Tibetan political prisoners, Mr. Christopher said.
The two sides codified, as expected, an agreement reached in principle with Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen in Beijing in January to reopen Chinese prisons to American inspectors to insure that they are not making products for export to the United States.
Throughout their three days of talks, Chinese officials flatly rejected Mr. Christopher's demand that Beijing improve its human rights performance, saying this was interference in their internal affairs.
On Sunday, representatives of some of America's largest corporations told Mr. Christopher that the Administration's policy was undermining American companies trying to take advantage of China's economic expansion.
The frank comments by indignant executives from business giants including A.T.& T., General Electric and Dow Jones preceded Mr. Christopher's 75-minute meeting with President Jiang Zemin, who dismissed the Secretary's demands on human rights as meddling in China's internal affairs.
 
Less Bitter Atmosphere
 Although Sunday's meeting was described by both sides as less rancorous than Saturday's sessions, the two sides continued to talk past each other.
The Chinese are gambling that Washington will suffer too much it if revokes the trade privileges under a policy they see as driven by anti-China lawmakers in Congress.
At a breakfast meeting with the American Chamber of Commerce in Beijing, members said it was misguided to use trade privileges to force changes in human rights policies, telling Mr. Christopher that the best way to improve human rights in China was to open the country to new markets.
But Mr. Christopher rejected this view, urging the organization of some 300 American businesses "to use your influence to convince the Chinese it is in their interest to make at least the limited progress on human rights that we seek."
Mr. Christopher is to head today to Vladivostok to discuss Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Middle East with Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev of Russia.
Mr. Christopher declined to tell reporters whether the Administration would renew China's trade privileges if it had to do so now. When asked in the past, he has routinely replied that China still had not made enough progress to warrant renewal of the trade benefits. But some of his senior aides have suggested that the daily diplomatic temperature-taking was counterproductive, and when asked the question today, Mr. Christopher replied, "I'm really out of that business."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
CUNY'S CRITICS URGE A MORE ACTIVE BOARD
A majority of the members of the City University of New York Board of Trustees are holdovers whose terms of office expired as long ago as 1988. Educators and local officials say this has weakened the leadership of the nation's largest urban university. Herman Badillo, a governor's appointee whose term expired last June, said this was a critical time for the university, which is undergoing sweeping academic consolidation, budget cuts and a changing student population. A vigorous board is needed, he said. B3. 

INSURANCE-FRAUD INVESTIGATION
An investigation into systematic payoffs to apartment-house managers by contractors has been broadened to include fraudulent insurance claims, investigators in the Manhattan District Attorney's office said. Just as work contracts were inflated to pay for kickbacks from contractors to the managers of hundreds of condominium and cooperative apartment buildings, so were some insurance claims, the investigators said. B3.
 
UNION VICTORY IN CHINATOWN
A seven-month lockout in Chinatown's only unionized restaurant ended in victory for the workers, in what union supporters hope will be a historic day for long-suffering and often powerless Asian immigrant employees. But others pointed out that the Silver Palace, where workers joined the Restaurant Workers Union in 1981, remains Chinatown's first and only union restaurant, and that other workers have little power to fight back. B3.
 
THE LIFE AND DEATH OF LEAR'S
Lear's magazine died as it had lived. It was created by Frances Lear, who, after a bitter divorce from the television producer Norman Lear, was at a crossroads. She invented the magazine for a particular reader: herself. She gave the magazine her vision, her energy, her money and her name. She sustained it with her enthusiasm and, when she lost interest, she pulled the plug. D1.
 
A shootout on Staten Island gravely wounded a 2-year-old boy. B4.
 
REGION
 
REPUBLICANS IN HARMONY
They squabble like a dysfunctional family, accusing one another of dark intrigues and impure motives. But when the Republicans seeking to run for governor talk about how to defeat Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, they harmonize like the Vienna Boys Choir. In a year when party leaders are unable to unite behind a standard bearer and plotting primary challenges, at least the would-be candidates, liberal and conservative, seem sweetly attuned to what they think is the winning formula. B2.
 
FIGHT LOOMS ON LAWSUITS
A fight over placing restrictions on the right to sue -- with supporters saying that would reduce frivolous lawsuits, and opponents contending it would shield businesses from paying for legitimate damages -- is shaping up in the New Jersey State Legislature. The drive for making the first changes in seven years in laws regulating civil torts, cases in which an individual sues because of alleged harm received, is part of a national debate that has surfaced across the country. B5.
 
TAKING OVER NEWARK SCHOOLS
Donna Jackson, an unemployed mother of three, has been battling the Newark school system since her daughter Ericka, now 11, was 3 years old. She considers the district corrupt, anti-parent, and largely unconcerned about its students. Yet she passionately opposes the State Department of Education's proposed takeover of the 50,000-student school district, the state's largest. As the department moves closer to the proposed takeover, emotions in Newark are running high. B5.
 
TRANSATLANTIC FLIGHTS CANCELED
The temporary closing of Heathrow and Gatwick Airports in London after a mortar attack on Heathrow led to the cancellation of some flights from London to New York and left hundreds of passengers stranded for hours on both sides of the Atlantic. But airline officials said they did not expect any interruptions in flight service today. Several British Airways planes flying into Heathrow were diverted to other British airports after the attack, disrupting schedules and forcing the cancellation of four flights headed to Kennedy and Newark International airports from London. A10.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The economy is beginning to feel the pinch of rising interest rates, which have climbed more than a percentage point in five months. The rush to refinance mortgages has slowed, and bank loans to individuals and companies are no longer rising. [Page A1.] 
 An American corporation has dislodged a Japanese company from first place in the list of the top 10 companies receiving U.S. patents. I.B.M. took the honors after nearly a decade in which Japanese companies held the top spots. [D1.]
 
International
New high-wage jobs remain scarce in both Europe and the U.S., and many governments are beginning to fear that the shortage may be permanent. To address the challenge of creating jobs in an integrated global marketplace, the Clinton Administration is bringing together in Detroit the finance and labor ministers from the Group of Seven industrial democracies. [D1.]
Representatives of big American corporations told the Secretary of State that U.S. policy on China was undermining companies that are trying to take the lead in China's economic expansion. [A3.]
An agreement to open Japan's cellular phone market achieved virtually everything the Administration had hoped to accomplish in broader trade talks that collapsed last month. Indeed, in establishing some specific goals, it goes beyond managed trade to what might be called micro-managed trade. News Analysis. [D1.]
Japanese consumers have lined up for rice as the press declared a national emergency -- the first serious rice shortage since the 1940's. [A4.]
Political conflict is deepening again across the southern Mexican state of Chiapas, despite Government promises of aid. [A2.]
 
Companies
Xerox is close to reaching a landmark deal to farm out its data processing, narrowing its list of contenders to two. [D3.]
The Virginia Legislature has approved subsidies Walt Disney demanded as a condition for building a history theme park. [A15.]
Wells Fargo Bank will introduce a family of asset-allocation mutual funds in an attempt to reach affluent baby boomers. [D1.]
Sega of America is announcing an add-on cartridge for computers that is intended to sharply increase the performance of Genesis video games while increasing the games' realism. [D4.]
 I.B.M. consolidated five New Jersey branch offices last year, consolidating everything into a steel-walled industrial building where there are no private offices. [B1.]
 
The Media Business
Lear's magazine died as it had lived. As one of a few magazines owned, directed and financed by people wealthy enough to indulge their whims, it was sustained with the enthusiasm of Frances Lear. When she finally lost interest, she pulled the plug. [D1.]
One of public television's prominent stations, WGBH in Boston, is starting a series of toys, games and other products based on popular programs like "Nova" and "This Old House." [D7.]
 A showdown with the cable industry over retransmission rights may provide big benefits for three broadcast networks. [D7.]
The Atlanta Journal and Constitution is offering an ambitious electronic newspaper with a decidedly local approach over the Prodigy computer network. William Glaberson: Press Notes. [D7.]
A campaign supporting a California program promoting abstinence by teen-agers provides a model for marketers seeking to deliver the same message to different audiences. Advertising. [D8.]
 
Today's Columns
A Canadian company has received a patent for a chest-pain analysis kit that works like a home pregnancy test.
Sabra Chartrand: Patents. [D2.]
 The chairman of Daiei, a big Japanese discounter, may be succeeding in a long quest to change retailing. Market Place. [D4.]

HEADLINE: Conservationists Divided Over How to Protect Sea Mammals

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
As Congress revises a law that controls the killing of whales, porpoises and other marine mammals by the fishing industry, the debate among conservationists seems at times more intense than the one among lawmakers.
Groups that together made "save the whales" one of environmentalism's best-known slogans are now divided over how far to accommodate the needs of the fishing industry in a new version of the law, the Marine Mammal Protection Act. 
 The law, enacted in 1972, was meant to prevent the deaths of mammals in fishing nets. In 1988, its central provisions were suspended for five years to allow biologists to study the status of various protected species. But the moratorium will expire on April 1, putting pressure on Congress to revise the law quickly so fishing will not have to be halted in important areas.
 
Dissent Among Advocates
 Some groups, like the Center for Marine Conservation, have endorsed a draft of legislation that is expected to be debated soon by the Senate, while others, like the Defenders of Wildlife, say the proposed measure is unacceptable.
The question, said Nina Young, a spokeswoman for the Center for Marine Conservation, is, "Do you let the fishermen fish for some amount of time under a set of regulations to reduce mammal mortality, or do you not let them fish -- do you close the fishery down?"
"We support what is coming out in the Senate," Ms. Young said. "It does have a very conservative approach for reducing the mortality. It allows them to fish, and to change their behavior over time."
But Christopher Croft, a marine wildlife specialist with Defenders of Wildlife, said that while his organization and dozens of others did not want to halt fishing they considered the latest legislative proposals to be seriously flawed.
"All we are asking is that there be some protection left in the Marine Mammal Protection Act," Mr. Croft said. "We are not asking too much."
 
Tens of Thousands of Deaths
 In the five years that the act has been curtailed, tens of thousands of mammals have died each year in fishing nets. Some species, like the harbor porpoise, have been depleted to a point where their replenishment is in doubt. (In the late 1980's a consumer boycott of canned tuna led the Government to protect dolphins specifically during the marine mammal law's five-year moratorium.)
Now, as Congressional committees dominated by lawmakers from fishing states rush to draft highly technical bills for consideration by the House and Senate, conservation groups are at odds over the proposals.
Last year, some conservation groups negotiated a proposal with the fishing industry that has been incorporated into the legislative draft. The compromise was intended to reduce the killing of mammals, but not necessarily to end it altogether.
It was that proposal that sparked the dispute among conservation groups. And even though they have won important concessions in negotiations that continue, some groups are withholding support from the full legislation.
 
Acceptable Formula
 Senator John Kerry, the Massachusetts Democrat who is managing the Senate bill, met on Friday with environmental groups to discuss a fresh draft. In an interview, he said he had urged them to help him reach a formula acceptable to all sides.
"I told them, 'You have a choice here between trying to constructively come together and reach an agreement on what we can all make work, or you are going to have to ask for the current regime to be prolonged, which gives you no prohibitions and no guarantees,' " Mr. Kerry said. " 'You really have to get into a reality mode.' "
Although the Senator has been working closely with the conservation groups, his state is also the base of much of the New England fishing industry, which is already suffering because of depleted fish stocks and has much at stake in what the marine mammal law will allow.
For example, the types of nets used for catching flounder and cod in the region take a heavy toll on harbor porpoises, a species that is proposed for listing as "threatened" under the Endangered Species Act.
 
Changing Some Practices
 The draft bill that Mr. Kerry is pushing would set a formula for Federal fishing regulators to use when determining the acceptable level for the killing of harbor porpoises, and for how fishing practices would have to change to protect the mammals. It would also change the treatment of species listed under the Endangered Species Act, making it possible in some circumstances to kill them.
A provision of Mr. Kerry's bill and a companion measure being drafted in the House is of particular concern to some conservationists because it will shift the burden of proof from the fishing industry to the Government when deciding whether to allow protected mammals to be killed. The proposal before Congress would give fishermen permits to kill protected mammals unless the Government showed the mammal species would be threatened. Under the old law, the fishing industry had to prove that the species would not be threatened.
The proposals would require changes in fishing practices, like avoiding certain mammals' known migration routes each year. Some conservation groups are even less pleased with the version of the bill being drawn up in the House by the Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee, which is headed by another Massachusetts Democrat, Representative Gerry E. Studds. A subcommittee approved a draft of that legislation on Wednesday.
In a move that did not affect fishing but that infuriated animal-protection advocates, the House subcommittee agreed to allow Americans to import polar bear trophies, a step that would encourage American hunters to shoot the bears in Canada or Russia.
Although animal-protection groups like the Fund for Animals criticized that provision, which was promoted by sport-hunting businesses, some conservationists defended it, saying it would raise the value of a thriving bear population to Canada's Inuit inhabitants, who could sell their bear-hunting licenses to American trophy hunters.
"Providing ongoing economic value to an animal species is the surest way to guarantee its health and perpetuation," said Joseph P. Kalt, a natural resource economist who is faculty chairman of the environment program at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University.

HEADLINE: U.S. Gains On Japan In Patents

BYLINE: By SABRA CHARTRAND, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
For the first time in almost a decade, an American corporation has dislodged a Japanese company from first place in the top-10 list of companies receiving patents in the United States.
While the Japanese still held 6 of the top 10 positions on the list announced last week by the United States Patent and Trademark Office, I.B.M. jumped into first place with 1,085 patents in 1993, up from sixth place in 1992. 
 The annual list from the patent office, which is an agency of the Commerce Department, is closely watched as a barometer of the research, development and innovation undertaken by the creators and manufacturers of technology around the world.
Throughout the 1980's, the list stood as a sharp illustration of how the United States lagged behind Japan in the race for discoveries that lead to new products and services. In fact, Japanese companies have led the list and dominated the top 10 since 1985.
 
Japanese Companies Edged Out
 On the 1993 list, the International Business Machines Corporation was followed by two Japanese companies, the Toshiba Corporation and Canon Inc. But in another shift, the Eastman Kodak Company and the General Electric Company moved into fourth and fifth places, edging out Japanese companies and giving Americans three of the top five spots.
In 1992, four of the top five spots went to Japanese companies, with Canon leading the list. General Electric ranked fourth, and I.B.M. was sixth.
Intellectual-property analysts, patent attorneys and corporate officials believe American companies are rising on the list because they are investing more vigorously in developing competitive high-technology products. And while Americans are seeking greater patent protection for their inventions, a weak economy is leading Japanese inventors to cut back on patenting costs.
 
A Shift in American Economy
 At the same time, the rankings illustrate how the American economy is shifting from a traditional manufacturing base toward technology-based industries like computers and telecommunications.
"One factor is simply the greater value of technology relevant to traditional wealth in the economy," said Herbert C. Wamsley, executive director of the Intellectual Property Owners Association, a trade group representing patent, copyright and trademark holders.
"What we're seeing now is recognition of the value of technology and knowledge-based industries," he continued. "Because of that, businesses have been willing to invest in research and development and to put greater importance on securing the best possible intellectual property rights as a way of protecting knowledge."
Patents provide exclusive ownership for 14 years to inventors of new mechanical, chemical and electrical products or processes. For many industries, a single patent can be more valuable than the deed to a large factory. In 1991, for example, the Polaroid Corporation received $925 million from Eastman Kodak to settle a lengthy patent dispute over Polaroid's instant photography technology.
The United States Government was the overall leader in patents received last year, with 1,165 inventions belonging to various agencies, principal among them the Defense Department.
 
Rethinking Research at I.B.M.
 I.B.M. officials say the sharp downturn in their company's fortunes in recent years forced them to re-evaluate their research priorities as well as their patenting policies.
"This is a shift in the company waking up to the fact that good things don't just naturally happen to I.B.M., and we have to scrap and scrape to succeed," said Marshall Phelps, vice president of intellectual property and licensing for I.B.M.
"There was a time when I.B.M. could afford to do a lot of research for academic interests," he added. But that was before last year, when I.B.M. slashed $1 billion from its research and development budget.
"Those days are over," Mr. Phelps said. "This stuff is practical. It's about where we think the industry will be, what the technology requires, where the products are going."
But Dan Mandresh, an I.B.M. analyst with Merrill Lynch, questioned whether the company can "bring this technology to the bottom line."
"Here they win this patent citation for developmental efforts embarked on several years ago under a management team that is no longer there because it didn't bring results to the bottom line," he said. "Now they're in the first full year of a new management team whose entire focus is cutting expenses. The question is: Where will I.B.M. be on this list three years from now?"
 
A Tool for High Technology
 Mr. Phelps said most of I.B.M.'s patents were for inventions in the areas of multimedia, software, computer networking, microprocessors and information storage devices. "There is no question that an awful lot of these patents reflect a shift in emphasis into technology," he said.
That should please the Clinton Administration, which views the patent system as an important tool for insuring the development and competitiveness of American high-technology industries. Bruce A. Lehman, the Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks, has said that the Administration sees those emerging industries as the source of future high-wage jobs, and that intellectual-property rights are one way for companies to maintain a competitive edge and seek advantage in export markets.
Mr. Lehman has held public hearings on patent harmonization -- efforts to bring Federal patent law into harmony with rules in Canada, Europe and Japan -- and, more important, on the issue of patents for inventions related to computer software.
 
A Crucial Government Effort
 The patents counted in last year's list are for inventions completed two to three years ago, because that is about how long it takes the Government to process the applications. So the Clinton Administration's efforts would have had no effect on these latest rankings.
But a previous Government initiative, during the Reagan Administration, was crucial to American corporate attitudes toward patents. In 1982, Congress established a Federal Circuit Court of Appeals to hear patent infringement suits. Before that, nonspecialist judges in regional courts were often skeptical of the breadth of many patent claims.
"The Federal Circuit brought more unification and certainty to patent law," Mr. Wamsley said, giving companies more confidence in the long-term investment value of patents.
Thomas L. Giannetti, a partner with Fish & Neave, a law firm that specializes in intellectual property, said, "There's a perception that patents are more valuable than they used to be because they get upheld by the courts with greater frequency, and the damages are higher."
"Patents represent investment," he added. "I can't speak to I.B.M., but it all fits together. If patents have greater value, then research has greater value. It becomes a better investment because companies can protect it."

HEADLINE: Michigan Debates Best Tax to Finance Schools

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KALKASKA, Mich., March 12

 BODY:
For weeks, the talk in this rural town surrounded by poplars and pines has centered not on the snow or the spring fishing but on schools and taxes.
This is the town that drew nationwide attention last March by closing its schools three months early when it ran out of money after voters refused to raise taxes. Its decision led to one of the nation's most sweeping proposals to change the way schools are financed. 
 On Tuesday, Michigan residents will vote on a proposal to pay for their schools by increasing the sales tax to 6 percent, from 4 percent, and tripling the state cigarette tax.
In return, they would get sharp reductions in their local property taxes, which now provide most of the support for schools.
But even if the measure is defeated, paying for schools will never be the same. The Michigan Legislature has approved a backup plan to pay for schools by raising the state income tax and trimming property taxes.
Statewide polling shows the sales tax plan has the edge over the income tax plan, and Kalkaska residents say they simply want their schools to stay open.
"Over all, I think the proposal is a more equitable way to finance schools," said Randy Nygren, the owner of a downtown restaurant and the father of two children in schools here. "I'll probably vote for it. It's the least of two evils."
The plan has drawn considerable interest from other states caught in the same mire of school finance -- with debates about the inequities between rich and poor districts, and with property owners facing tax increases each year for what they perceive as declining schools.
 
Support for Sales Tax
 Supporters, including Gov. John M. Engler, said the ballot measure would relieve pressure on taxpayers as well as schools, which are now forced to go to voters every two to three years for a tax increase.
"There is nothing more stable than the property tax," said John Truscott, a spokesman for Governor Engler, a Republican who is running for re-election in November. "But it is unfair to property owners. The sales tax spreads the cost to everyone."
But will sales taxes generate adequate money or schools?
Critics think not. They said the tax was too vulnerable to the ebb and flow of the economy. In recessions, consumers delay buying cars and other big-ticket items that increase revenue from the sales tax, which covers all purchases except food, prescription drugs and heating fuels.
"The proposal is shaky," said Beverly Wilcow, executive director of the Michigan Education Association, which represents 127,000 school employees statewide. "It is not a good plan."
Nonetheless, figures from the Michigan Treasury Department show that since 1985, the sales tax revenue has grown each year, to $3.7 billion in 1993. Property taxes generate significantly more money -- $6.8 billion last year, of which about 70 percent went to education. Income tax revenue was about the same -- $6.9 billion.
Under the ballot measure, the sales tax would increase to 6 cents from 4 cents, generating nearly $1.8 billion next year. The cigarette tax would rise to 75 cents a pack from 25 cents, raising an estimated $350 million a year.
The incentive for voters is a drastic cut in local property taxes, down to $6 on $1,000 of assessed value. In Kalkaska, where the average home is assessed at $44,000 and property owners pay $24 per $1,000 of assessed value, the typical homeowner would pay $264 a year, down from $1,056.
If voters reject the proposal, the Legislature would raise the state income tax rate to 6 percent from 4.6 percent, which would generate $1.8 billion to $2 billion in revenue. Property taxes would also be trimmed under the backup plan, but not nearly as much. Whichever plan is enacted will take effect on May 1.
In either case, statewide money for education would be increased to $10.2 billion, up 5 percent from the current budget.
While statewide polls show the sales tax plan has the edge, the fight has been cantankerous. Michigan Citizens for Fair Taxes, representing the teachers union and the tobacco industry, is spending $3.8 million to fight it.
But in Kalkaska, a town of about 4,300 people in northwestern central Michigan, some residents say the differences between the two plans amounts to very little.
"Either way, we pay," said Rene Niece, a waitress at Judy's Lagoon Saloon who has two children in school.
At Kalkaska High School, where 590 students are enrolled, teachers said they hoped the measure would eliminate the prospect of closing early, which they said has hurt the students. Sam Luedtke, a 17-year-old senior, said that in his math class this year, for instance, the teacher had to start with the concepts that were not covered because of last year's truncated school year.
Another student, Travis Hansen, an 18-year-old senior who now has to pay a $50 fee to play on the basketball team, said, "The proposal would help our schools, but it won't solve all our problems."
Even though Kalkaska's public schools will see per pupil spending increase to $4,200 a year in the next school year from the current $3,800 if the ballot measure is approved, school officials say the district will still be under financial pressure.
"What happens if the sales tax declines one year and there isn't enough money?" asked Doyle Disbrow, the Superintendent of Schools. "What happens then? As a superintendent, I'd like to know where revenue is coming from in the next five years for planning purposes."
It is not an unreasonable request, Mr. Disbrow said. Already, some state officials acknowledge that the state sales tax measure, if approved, might well require supplemental income from other state sources that have yet to be identified.
That is not a prospect that makes Mr. Disbrow feel comfortable about the ballot proposal. "It has all the markings of destruction down the road," he said.
