HEADLINE: Newark vs. Trenton: Fight for a City's Schools

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEWARK, March 9

 BODY:
Having grown up in this city, Donna Jackson knows that Newark can be angry. She says a little constructive anger might be good right now.
Ms. Jackson, an unemployed mother of three, has been battling the Newark school system since her daughter Ericka, now 11, was three years old. She considers the district corrupt, anti-parent, and largely unconcerned about its students. Yet she passionately opposes the State Department of Education's proposed takeover of the schools. 
 "I still believe, firmly believe, that they have no business coming in here," she said. "The bottom line is, state takeover -- and I'll say this forever and a day -- has nothing to do with our children and nothing to do with education."
 
Newark Under Review
 Emotions are running high in this city as the State Department of Education moves closer to a proposed takeover of the 50,000-student school district, the state's largest. A stinging report delivered to the State Education Commissioner last April portrayed Newark as a chronically failing district, damaged by mismanagement and paralyzed by cronyism and political interference. The report led to a final education department review of the district, now under way.
The State's Education Commissioner, Leo Klagholtz, has said he hopes to review the results of the investigation and make a recommendation on the takeover by June. If, after that, the State Board of Education decides to take over the district, it will replace the school board and top administrators.
Meanwhile, people like Ms. Jackson impatiently work the community groups and parent associations of Newark, warning about the dangers of a takeover.
Ms. Jackson, 29, considers herself a community parent, responsible not only for her own three children, but for every Newark schoolchild "and those on the street, too." She is blunt, insistent, often pushy, a squeaky-wheel woman who serves on several parent-teacher associations and volunteers as a go-between for parents embroiled in school battles large and small.
 
'It's Personal to Me'
 Ms. Jackson became involved in the district to assure that her daughter Ericka, who became physically disabled after a playground accident at the age of 3, received special education. Ericka now receives occupational therapy through the schools. Ms. Jackson also has two other children in the district: Matthew, 7 and Rashaun, 12.
"They say it ain't personal, but damn, it's personal to me," Ms. Jackson said. "Because I know that, directly, they have killed our children for over 10 years."
Ms. Jackson's latest support base is the Newark Parental Commission, a group of about two dozen community advocates and parents who came together from other fledgling groups to create what they hope will be a significant voice for the community during the takeover negotiations. The members of the group are sometimes divided over whether a state takeover will make things better or worse, but united by their frustration at the district's failings.
Asking these parents what they think of their schools is asking to hear a torrent of complaints.
Maryam Bey, who is running for the Newark school board, is angry that the district has not met state education standards for more than a decade; that 86 percent of 11th-grade students at Central High failed the math portion of a recent state proficiency test; that Newark officials are, she says, unable or unwilling to halt the deterioration of the schools.
"Those who are not working have to go," she said. "They are destroying children. That's the bottom line."
Jerry Jacobs, a parent with two daughters in the system, said the only improvements made in his daughters' schools have come since the state began the takeover process. He said district officials have proved that they cannot or will not improve the schools.
"This thing is like a cancer," he said. "It's embedded. You have to clean house."
His fifth-grade daughter is a straight-A student, but only because she has been tutored at home, Mr. Jacobs said. He hopes she will land a scholarship at a local private school for next year and be able to leave the Newark schools forever.
But Mr. Jacobs's 14-year-old daughter is struggling at the High School of the Arts, and he bitterly attributes her trouble to the education she received in middle school. His daughter often did not have English textbooks or math workbooks, he said.
"I am sure the state can't do any worse," he said.
During a meeting of the Newark Parental Commission, on a cold night in late February, fewer than 40 people shared the room. But there was anguish for a thousand.
Gordon Mays, an elementary school principal, pleaded with the group to work with a state takeover, instead of against it. He said the group's impassioned demands to control their own schools with minimal interference from either the state or the Newark school board were unrealistic, and he urged the parents to negotiate with state officials for a part in choosing people to run the district during a takeover.
"There is nothing that prevents you from becoming involved now, as opposed to playing the same old game we have for years -- standing outside, objecting to everything, and when the deal goes down we're still on the outside looking in, folks," he said. "Ever since I been in this district the community has never won."
"Please," he said, "for God's sake, become winners this time."
But Rebecca Doggett, the state-appointed auditor general of the Newark school district, who has attended dozens of meetings to explain the proposed takeover and encourage community involvement, said that although some parents agree with Mr. Mays, most do not.
"Very few parents have said, 'Yeah, let the state come in.' They're as afraid of the state as they are of 2 Cedar Street," she said, referring to the address of the Newark school administrative offices.
No amount of reassurance is enough for Ms. Jackson, who believes passionately that state education officials are more interested in jobs and power than in educating Newark children. Widely shared is the suspicion that during a takeover the state would contract with outside vendors for cafeteria and janitorial services and clerical help -- a move that some fear would especially hurt black and Hispanic workers.
"Newark is being turned into a big employment factory where more of us, and by us I mean African-Americans, will just be pushed out of the way," Ms. Jackson said.
Such tensions lie like a veil over the face of the school district. Newark is a predominantly black city, with a small but significant white population, a large Portuguese community and a growing Hispanic presence. In the past, school board members have suggested that the proposed takeover by mostly white state leaders was, in part, racially motivated.
Several Hispanic groups have complained of Hispanic underrepresentation among teachers and administrators. Hispanic students, mostly Puerto Rican, make up 26 percent of the Newark student body. Fourteen percent of district principals and vice principals are Hispanic, according to district figures. Thirty-five percent are white and 52 percent are black.
Roberto Del Rios, acting executive director of Aspira of New Jersey, a Hispanic educational and advocacy group, said one of the district's two Hispanic guidance counselors died last year. The other retired.
Mr. Del Rios said his group's board of directors has not taken a position on a takeover partly because the group receives money from the district, but also because many members are deeply ambivalent. No one is impressed by the state's results in Jersey City and Paterson, the other two districts that have been taken over, he said.
Different people gave different answers to the big question of why more parents are not involved with the school district. Ms. Jackson said many parents are so confused and discouraged, they have given up. Other parents complained that policies like the required five-day advance notice to speak at board meetings discourage involvement.
Ms. Bey said that although some Newark parents have abdicated their responsibility to help educate their children, that fact does not absolve the district of its failures.
"Eventually those parents will come around," she said. "but it's never the majority that makes a change. It's a small minority." So the Newark Parental Commission goes on, handing out fliers, meeting every other Monday night, preaching fiery warnings and hoping, next time, to draw a crowd.
"With all of that money and all of that failure, it's time to kick butt and stop being quiet, and get emotional," Ms. Jackson told the nodding audience at the group's last meeting. "Y'all too quiet for me."

HEADLINE: G.O.P.'s Cuomo Rivals: Shared Views Amid Squabbling

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 13

 BODY:
They squabble like a dysfunctional family, accusing one another of dark intrigues and impure motives. But when the Republicans seeking to run for governor talk about how to defeat Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, they harmonize like the Vienna Boys Choir.
Crime? The six most active candidates advocate the death penalty, which Mr. Cuomo has blocked for 11 years. Taxes? All support deep cuts in the personal income tax and many business taxes. Welfare reform? All would fingerprint welfare recipients and require able-bodied ones to work. Big government? All talk about slashing the state work force, privatizing services and instituting some form of school voucher program. 
 In a year when party leaders are unable to unite behind a standard bearer and plotting primary challenges, at least the would-be candidates, liberal and conservative, seem sweetly attuned to what they think is the winning formula.
"You've got a basic Republican philosophy and they're all running on it," said William D. Powers, the state Republican chairman. "Someone tough on crime, who understands the problems of the economy, who is for less government, not more, who feels that cutting taxes sends a signal to business that New York State is a user-friendly state."
 
Scent of Blood
 But the Republicans' conformity on issues may have less to do with philosophy than the scent of Mr. Cuomo's blood. A recent poll by the Marist Institute for Public Opinion in Poughkeepsie found that voters were most concerned about crime, the economy and taxes. That same poll showed Mr. Cuomo's approval rating at 36 percent, near an all-time low.
And the successes of tax-cutting and tough-on-crime Republicans in last year's New Jersey gubernatorial race and the New York City mayoral race have given those traditional Republican concerns new prominence in the state's political firmament.
"Nothing quite brings unity like the statewide prospect of victory, and that's what we've got this year," said Jay Severin, a Republican political consultant. "The Governor is in trouble on issues that make virtually any Republican candidate a viable candidate."
The six most active Republicans seeking the nomination are J. Patrick Barrett, a former state Republican chairman; Evan G. Galbraith, a former Ambassador to France; Bill Green, a former United States Representative from Manhattan; Herbert London, a college professor; George E. Pataki, a State Senator from Peekskill, and Richard M. Rosenbaum, a former state Republican chairman.
Mr. Pataki and Mr. London are at the heart of a rift within the party. Mr. Pataki is supported by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato while Mr. London is supported by some Republicans close to Ralph J. Marino, the State Senate majority leader.
Several other men have said they might run but have not campaigned for support. They include Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon of Glens Falls and Thomas S. Gulotta, the Nassau County Executive.
 
Ideological Contrasts
 The candidates by no means share similar ideological roots. Mr. Barrett, Mr. Galbraith, Mr. Pataki and Mr. London hail from the party's conservative wing, and all have ties to the anti-tax group, Change-New York. Mr. Green and Mr. Rosenbaum come from the party's liberal wing, once dominated by Nelson A. Rockefeller.
Those differences are clearest on abortion, the one issue that threatens to inject a sour note into the Republican melody. Mr. Barrett and Mr. London hold strongly anti-abortion views, while Mr. Green and Mr. Rosenbaum oppose any restrictions on abortion. Mr. Pataki and Mr. Galbraith say they support abortion rights, but both could support some abortion restrictions.
But on closer examination, several candidates seem to be inching toward a middle ground.
Mr. London argues that while he opposes abortion, United States Supreme Court rulings have made it a protected right that he, as governor, would be required to uphold. But he would support ending Medicaid funds for abortions, requiring parental consent for minors seeking abortions and imposing a 24-hour waiting period.
Mr. Galbraith says that while he is in favor of abortion rights, he would support ending Medicaid funds for abortions. And Mr. Pataki has voted in the Senate against Medicaid-financed abortions and says he would do so again unless women are required to undergo family-planning counseling before receiving abortions.
Republican and Conservative Party leaders also seem determined to accommodate each other to avoid the friction of 1990, when the Conservative Party endorsed Mr. London instead of the Republican candidate, Pierre Rinfret, an abortion-rights supporter. Mr. Rinfret barely finished ahead of Mr. London as Mr. Cuomo easily won a third term.
Both Michael R. Long, the state Conservative Party chairman, and William D. Powers, the state Republican Party chairman, say abortion will not be a "litmus test" for candidates. "I'm not going to allow a single issue to take over our convention," Mr. Powers said.
On a host of other issues, the Republicans are in sync. Though some articulate only the gauzy outlines of programs, they have not hesitated to attack Mr. Cuomo's tax-cutting, welfare and criminal-justice proposals as anemic.
"What Cuomo calls for is boutique tax-cutting," said Mr. Rosenbaum, probably the most cautious of the Republicans on tax cuts.
All six say they would reduce the state's personal income tax, a position Mr. Cuomo opposes. Mr. Galbraith would go the furthest in cutting the top rate almost in half, to 4 from 7.88 percent. All would reduce the state's corporate surcharge more than Mr. Cuomo has proposed, and three -- Mr. Pataki, Mr. London and Mr. Galbraith -- would eliminate it.
 
'Family Concept'
 Mr. Galbraith proposes the most radical overhaul of welfare, saying he would eliminate most payments within two years. "This system has clearly destroyed the family concept in the inner city," he said.
The other candidates propose a range of programs that require welfare recipients to work or set time limits on payments. Mr. London would also reduce payments to unwed mothers who have additional children while on welfare.
As in the past, the Republicans view Mr. Cuomo's adamant opposition to the death penalty as an Achilles' heel, and all hammer at him for having a death-row prisoner in Oklahoma brought to New York to serve a life sentence for another murder. "This is a governor who has been exporting jobs all over the country but importing convicted killers," Mr. Pataki said.
But for the liberal Republicans, supporting capital punishment also seems a way to win conservative cachet. "The Conservatives ought to consider someone like myself who is a conservative on fiscal issues and supports the death penalty," Mr. Green said.
The Republicans contend that Mr. Cuomo's budget and State of the State speech this year indicate how vulnerable he feels on taxes and crime. Mr. Cuomo has called for reducing the state corporate surcharge, phasing out the state hotel tax and reducing or eliminating a number of lesser taxes and fees.
 
Prison Without Parole
 On crime, the Governor has proposed life imprisonment without parole for people convicted of a third felony, a position long favored by the Republicans who control the State Senate but opposed in the Democratic-led Assembly.
Mr. Cuomo has also sounded several other traditionally Republican themes. He wants to encourage more welfare recipients to work and has endorsed, in theory, fingerprinting some recipients to prevent fraud. He has supported giving parents greater choice over which schools they send their children to, though he has stopped short of endorsing a voucher program. And he has endorsed restrictions on product liability suits and a type of shareholder litigation against corporations.
But Mr. Cuomo's aides object to his being portrayed as a recent convert to those positions, particularly tax-cutting. "The real issue is that the Democrats have controlled and cut taxes to their lowest level in 30 years," said Al Gordon, the state Democratic chairman. "And who did they cut it from? The Republicans."

HEADLINE: World's Big Economies Turn to the Jobs Issue

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
When recession pushed up unemployment in all the major industrial democracies a few years ago, the conventional wisdom was that the upturn in the business cycle would solve most of the problem. But now that the upturn has arrived in the United States, and the worst of the recession is over in Europe, new high-wage jobs remain scarce in both places, and many governments are beginning to fear that the shortage may be permanent.
"We used to think that jobs and the economy were the same thing," the United States Secretary of Labor, Robert B. Reich, said. "But we have learned in recent years that the paper economy and the people's economy are not always the same thing." 
 In today's highly integrated global marketplace, he said, economies can grow in size, company profits can soar, a stock market can rise, and yet many people can be unemployed or underemployed -- because capital and technology are now so mobile that they do not always create good jobs in their own backyard. Add to that the emphasis on corporate cutbacks and a lot of people have been left stranded.
"There is now a much greater sensitivity," Mr. Reich said, "that the challenge of creating good jobs must be dealt with on its own terms" and not by relying on economic growth alone.
That sensitivity is the driving force behind the jobs conference being convened by the Clinton Administration in Detroit on Monday, bringing together finance and labor ministers from the Group of Seven industrial democracies.
This will be the first Group of Seven conference ever to include labor ministers. In the past, only finance ministers and heads of state got together, to discuss high diplomacy and the high finance of exchange rates and interest rate management.
But that lofty approach is insufficient to get at the jobs issue now ailing all these nations. In some ways, just as the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is groping to redefine itself and its priorities to stay relevant, so, too, is the Group of Seven.
"Seen from Europe, unemployment is the biggest security problem facing the Western world today, and the G-7 is simply acknowledging that," Dominique Moisi, deputy director of the French Institute for International Relations, said. "Because if we don't find answers to that problem, our entire system will collapse on itself."
Like many such international gatherings, the Detroit meeting will probably do more to highlight the problems than to solve them. American officials say they are not planning any final communique.
But the ministers do hope that the discussions can teach them something about what each of them has done right, and wrong, in confronting the jobs question. To some extent, they may each use the conference to build political cover at home to confront some of the hardest issues -- such as getting workers in Europe to accept fewer benefits so more people will be hired, or persuading Congress to invest more in job training so more teen-agers who are not going to college will have marketable skills.
Many European leaders initially played down the idea of the conference when President Clinton proposed it last summer in Tokyo. But their interest has grown in recent months as continuing unemployment has become the hottest political issue in elections throughout Western Europe, where roughly 19 million people are out of work.
After all, as Mr. Moisi put it, unemployment "is the proof that governments are not effective because they are not finding solutions to the most urgent problems of the day."
"It delegitimizes governments and is a time bomb," he added. "In France there are people already saying we are preparing ourselves for a nice little replay of the revolutionary events of May '68 -- only this time around it won't be young people bored with growth and the affluent society who take to the barricades, but young people desperate to find a place in a system that rejects them."
Among the Group of Seven -- Germany, France, Britain, Japan, Canada, Italy and the United States -- the jobs problem manifests itself differently. Broadly speaking, Europe and Canada have managed to keep wages and benefits rising for their workers, but at the price of relatively high unemployment for many others, who are sustained with generous unemployment insurance.
The United States, which has been out of recession the longest, has managed to create many more jobs than Europe, but only by getting workers to take more low-paying jobs, thereby widening the gap between the highest-paid and lowest-paid workers.
"At heart," Mr. Reich said, "the question before this summit will be: Are we condemned to choose between more jobs but greater inequality and insecurity, as we have in this country, or better jobs, but higher unemployment and a thicker social safety net, as in Europe?"
 
The Gap in Rates
 The numbers tell the story. In the United States the unemployment rate is holding at about 6.5 percent, despite a booming economic recovery, while in Canada and Western Europe, it averages around 11 percent, with Spain topping the list at 23 percent.
These figures do not take into account the large numbers of workers who are soon to be laid off, as the European Union begins to go through some of the cost-cutting that American industries have already endured.
Japan is at a comfortable unemployment level of 2.9 percent. But that does not include many workers who are kept in make-work jobs as part of Japan's lifetime employment policies.
The problem looks somewhat different from a wage perspective. According to the Labor Department, total compensation -- wages, health benefits, vacations -- for the typical American manufacturing worker has declined slightly or remained flat since the mid-1970's, while in Europe and Japan it has increased by 40 percent. Minimum wage levels tend to be higher in Europe, with cost-of-living increases and four-week annual vacations virtually guaranteed. Average manufacturing compensation in Germany is $26 an hour. In America, it is $16.
What the Labor Department calls low-wage noncollege-educated workers and workers from disadvantaged backgrounds have suffered even more in the United States. In the 1980's, their wages fell 15 to 20 percent when adjusted for inflation, while in Europe and Japan these wages rose about 15 to 20 percent.
But on the flip side, between 1973 and 1991, the United States economy created more than 35 million jobs. In the same period, the European Community generated only eight million new jobs, even though it has about one-third more people.
In large part, this is because of Europe's relatively comfortable social safety nets, which have left many workers preferring to stay on welfare rather than take the sort of low-paying jobs accepted by many workers in the United States. In most of the European Union, an unemployed worker can receive close to $1,000 a month indefinitely. In addition, Europe's highly regulated job markets, where it is very difficult to dismiss workers, have left employers wary of creating jobs.
 
The Potential Lessons
 What might the Americans learn from the Europeans and the Japanese at the conference? They both have done a much better job of developing apprenticeship and training programs for those between the ages of 13 to 17 who are not going to college, American officials say. Getting these young people into more skilled jobs is one reason Europe and Japan do not have as wide a wage gap as the United States between skilled an unskilled workers.
From the Americans, the Europeans and Japanese could learn how to make their work forces more flexible by eliminating some job security, encouraging people to relocate and moving toward a social safety net that is more focused on retraining people for new jobs than paying them to stay indefinitely unemployed.
If there is a synthesis that might emerge from Detroit, Mr. Reich said, it is: "We can learn from their educational system; they can learn from our mobility."
But what is not clear, he added, is this: "Can you combine the degree and quality of human capital investment and educational training and apprenticeship programs that we see in Europe and Japan, with the sort of flexible, mobile labor market that we have in this country?"

GRAPHIC: Photos: At a state-run job center in London, Britons waited for assistance. (Neil Libbert for The New York Times); The line at a Berlin unemployment office stretched down the block. (Associated Press) (pg. D6)
 
Graphs: "Job Woes inthe Group of Seven: An Overview"
 As their leaders gather to discuss the economics and politics of employment, the sevenlargest industrial democracies have little in common beyond concern over slow job growth. Here is where each nation stanes.
 
United States
 Plenty of bad jobs. Over the last two decades, the United States has created many more jobs than Western Europe - 35 million - but the bulk of new jobs are low paying, widening the gap between the lowest- and highest-paid workers.
 Failing pay. Of the major economies, only the United States has seenr eal wages fail over the last decade. Total compensation for the average American worker in manufacturing is $16 an hour, less than two-thirds of the $26 an hour a typical German worker gets.
 First to streamline. American industry has been cutting payrolls and closing inefficient operations on a large scale for more than a year, a process European countries have just begun. America's lower unemployment rate makes short-term dislocation easier to tolerate.
 
Canada
 Commodity slump. Canada's resource-based economy was so clobbered by the latest recession that it has yet to replace jobs lost over the past five years. World demand for Canadian exports like lead, zinc, timber and newsprint has not rebounded strongly.
 Reluctance to hire. "Employers are trying to enhance productivity, not create jobs," said Edward Harvey, professor of industrial relations at the University of Toronto. "They're extracating additional productivity from existing workers."
 Public pump priming. The Government's strategy is to jump-start job growth with large spending on public works programs by all levels of government; aid for small business, the principal generator of jobs, and apprenticeship programs for youth. Officials estimate that 300,000 jobs remain unfilled because young people with relevant skills cannot be found for them.
 
Britain
 Credibility. Britain will be the only European nation at the summit enjoying falling unemployment and solid growth, and its free-market approach, often given the cold shoulder in the past, will command an unusual level of respect. But critics say the country has too many part-time or low-paying new jobs.
 Pressure on unions. The goal of London's approach to job creation is "flexible" labor markets, in which employers can hire and fire workers relatively easily and inexpensively. Policies to that end include limits on the strength of unions, deregulation of industry and low interest rates and inflation.
 Against make-work. Prime Minister John Major has argued strongly -- and so far successfully -- against Europe-wide public spending projects to create jobs, which he said would be inflationary and do little to address long-term structural unemployment.
 
FRANCE
 Irreparable harm. The French government would be less alarmed about rising unemployment if it was simply a product of the current recession. But officials worry that one million jobs lost since 1991 may be gone forever. France's economy creates few jobs even when growing, and except for a brief respite in the late 1980's, the number of jobless has been climbing for 25 years.
 Working less for less. The government has proposed cutting minimum wages for young trainees by 20 to 70 percent, but students and labor unions are stiffly opposed. A plan backed by the opposition Socialists to cut the work week from 39 hours to 32, theoretically spreading the same work and pay among more people, is hotly debated.
 Welfare at risk. The heart of France's problem is whether it must reduce the social costs paid by employers -- and shrink the country's generous system of welfare benefits -- in order to stimulate job creation and make its economy more competitive. But it knows that this is politically explosive.
 
ITALY
 Hard to slim down. Half of the economy is in the public sector; politics makes it hard to prune jobs from the vast array of state-run businesses ranging from supermarkets to the national airline. Worker-friendly laws make private-sector layoffs very expensive for employers, requiring a month's severance pay for every year of service. Ravages of recession. Such protections have not kept unemployment from rising sharply since 1992. And official statistics exclude the 500,000 workers temporarily laid off, who receive 80 per cent of their salaries under a long-standing arrangement between employers and the Government.
 Decoupling wages. Unions agreed last year to suspend the "scala mobile", a national tradition insuring that annual salary hikes automatically matched inflation. Wage rises have slowed substantially.
 
GERMANY
 Structural crisis. In Germany and much of western Europe, "the assumption that renewed economic growth will automatically create jobs is no longer valid," says Kurt Biedenkopf, premier of Germany's Saxony state." The German economy is in a structural crisis, shifting away from labor-intensive smokestack industries toward service, software and high-technology. Even strong growth, which is not to be expected, will not create enough new jobs to replace those lost."
 Market rigidity. Germany's labor market is among the most expensive and tightly regulated in the world. The government has made mild moves to loosen it, moving to encourage part-time employment and allowing creation of private employment agencies. The economics minister, Gunter Rexrodt, wants a new category of low-wage jobs for workers with few skills and lower entry-level wages for some jobs.
 
JAPAN
 Feeling vulnerable. With low unemployment and a huge trade surplus, Japan is approaching the jobs conference with some dread. It is sure to be criticized for exporting unemployment, and pressed to expand its economy and open its markets. But Japan shows only the feeblest signs of recovering from a three-year slump.
 Lifetime jobs. Japan chalks up its low unemployment to the tradition of companies retaining employees in bad times. Takeshi Nagano, chairman of the Japan Federation of Employers Associations, said the jobless rate would be 5 to 6 percent if Japanese employers eliminated unneeded jobs the way Westerners do.
 Other ways to trim. Lifetime employment will not be abandoned outright. But companies are cutting staff by attrition, curtailing hiring and "asking" middle managers to retire. Wage growth, already low, is heading lower.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
An untraditional retailer in Japan is on a roll and gains influence.

BYLINE: By James Sterngold 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
ISAO NAKAUCHI is by Japanese standards a frightening revolutionary he wants retailers to be retailers.
Those are fighting words in a country where, in stark contrast to the situation in most industrial countries, manufacturers and not retailers have controlled which products make it to market, how they are sold and how they are priced. Retailers have generally done as they are told. 
 Mr. Nakauchi has been on a decades-long mission to change that, and there are signs that his long struggle may be coming to fruition. He is the chairman and controlling shareholder of Daiei Inc., Japan's largest supermarket chain and retailer, and after a series of mergers the company has developed far more influence over its suppliers.
Helped by the removal of some regulations at the urging of the United States, Daiei has become a big catalyst of change in Japanese retailing.
"They are absolutely right on target in what they are doing," said Mike Allen, the retailing analyst here with Barclays de Zoette Wedd Securities. "Everything they've done for the past year is just what they need to do to bring pricing control into the hands of the retailer. Daiei is out in front."
Daiei (pronounced die-ay) is a big discounter aiming at the lower end of the market, where volumes are huge and margins are thin. Its products range from food to clothing. It even owns a professional baseball team. More recently it has added real estate to its stable of interests.
One problem, if it can be called that, is that Daiei's stock price has been on a tear. It has more than doubled in the last year, to 1,920 yen a share, or about $18.275, at the close on Friday, from 790 yen, or about $7.52, last March. Given the volatile swings of the market, that has been a remarkably robust performance.
But there is concern that the rise may have run its course. Mr. Allen, for instance, said he rated Daiei a "hold." He added that traditionally it had been one of the least efficient retailers, in spite of its aspirations.
He was quick to add: "We still think that in the long term it has the highest potential for appreciation in the retail sector. It is the only retailer that has consistently improved gross margins throughout the recession."
Kaori Hasegawa, the retailing analyst with Salomon Brothers Asia, also has some hesitations. She said almost a quarter of Daiei's assets were devoted to nonretailing businesses like real estate and condominium sales. These companies, she said, had not meshed well with the retailing businesses and had not produced impressive returns.
"I've been wrong on this stock before," she said. "But the rise has been so sharp it concerns me a lot. If their earnings don't meet expectations, there's a real risk of a big drop."
But she said Daiei had made great headway in taking control of its pricing. A good example is its three-decade feud with the country's largest consumer electronics company, the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company.
Mr. Nakauchi battled Matsushita in the early 1960's, when he defied the manufacturer's orders and sought to sell its refrigerators, rice cookers, televisions and other products at discounts. Matsushita, which sells its products here under labels like National and Panasonic, simply cut off Daiei.
But recently Daiei took control of a smaller retail chain, the Chujitsuya Company, which carries Matsushita products. A decade ago, when Daiei made a similar acquisition, Matsushita stopped selling products to the retailer. This time it was big news when Matsushita agreed to keep selling its products to Chujitsuya. Daiei had gained the upper hand.
Daiei was a pioneer in selling products under a private label at cut-rate prices. It has recently forged close relationships with a number of manufacturers and big trading houses as it seeks to circumvent Japan's famously inefficient wholesaling system.
"Once they consolidate all these mergers, they will have even more purchasing power, and that's what they need to keep reducing their costs," Mr. Allen said. "When Daiei talks, the manufacturers finally listen."

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
In 'Marathon Dancing,' Only Anger Is the Victor

BYLINE: By BEN BRANTLEY 

 BODY:
As the film "They Shoot Horses, Don't They" made thunderingly clear 25 years ago, it isn't too hard to find metaphors for the sickness of the American soul in the dance marathons of the Great Depression. A disparate group of desperate, impoverished losers dancing themselves into exhaustion for a monetary prize, a cynical master of ceremonies manipulating them into increasingly humiliating exhibitions and his repeated glib assurances that these plucky demonstrations of perseverance are what the country is all about: the elements seem made for bald American fables of illusion and exploitation.
Audiences who remember the 1969 Sydney Pollack movie may experience an acute sense of deja vu watching "Marathon Dancing," the director Anne Bogart's fiercely cynical, one-note treatment of the same subject. But though the essential themes of the works are similar, Ms. Bogart takes a far more detached, typically Brechtian view of the phenomenon. And while "Marathon Dancing" offers a host of elaborate visual and musical flourishes, it all seems designed to ballast, quite numbingly, a premise that is established very early on. 
 Whereas the movie was essentially character-driven, Ms. Bogart presents her cast as a marionettelike cavalcade of social archetypes, from an embittered chanteuse to an unemployed World War I veteran, who represent a weary spectrum of a society gone sour, resonant with suggestive parallels to America today. And, in keeping with the director's fascination with indigenous American music, the show is built around more than a dozen songs of the time that, in this particular context, take on sinister significance, emphasizing hopelessness and anomie, even when the lyrics percolate with optimism.
Produced by En Garde Arts, a company famous for its site-specific performances, "Marathon Dancing" has been appropriately staged amid the oppressive institutional opulence of the cavernous Masonic Ballroom on West 23d Street. In the course of its roughly 110 minutes, the work follows some 600 hours of the marathon. We are 721 hours into it when the show begins, and the dancers are already showing signs of fatigue, hostility and disenchantment.
Frankie Aragon, the unctuous M.C. (P. J. Benjamin), a satanic variation on Gig Young's character in "They Shoot Horses," struggles to keep audience interest up with hucksterish patter about the contest, "where dreams are made and broken." Worried about dwindling attendance, he strong-arms the contestants into degrading novelty stunts, including a forced wedding.
His roller-skating floor judge, Gus (Steven Goldstein) roves among the dancers, sadistically anticipating their collapses and pointing out to the audience that the marathon's real catharses are provided not by the final victory but by the failures along the way. "Who's gonna die on the floor?" he asks us. "That's what I'm here for. That's what you're here for."
Most of the characters, including a mute female clown who can only howl in grief, are provided with stale monologues that reveal the bleakness of the lives behind them. As written by Laura Harrington, they are familiar tales of the sorts that abounded in the literature of the period: the boxer who delivered a fatal punch to a friend in an exhibition match; the emaciated farmer whose family is starving in a shack; the aging vaudevillian who feels he has no future on the stage. "I used to have a place," he says. "I can't find it. I can't find anything anymore."
Because the speeches are so standard issue, and delivered with such conscious artificiality, we are seldom directly engaged by these characters, which deprives the work of any real emotional momentum. And the organizers' corrupt nature and the concomitant frustration and weariness of the contestants are made so apparent from the earliest scenes that "Marathon Dancing" fails to develop in any substantially surprising ways.
What we are left with, essentially, is a dark cabaret of songs and dances, some of which, though repetitive in their thematic nature, are indeed very effective. The choreography, by Alison Shafer, blends deliberately clumsy conventional ballroom steps with an imploding sense of anger. Ms. Bogart's robotic staging of the mock marathon wedding, with the reluctant bride swathed in cellophane, is a satirical high point. And Christopher Drobny's adaptations for the three-member band are seductively smooth.
In their singing, the largely talented cast covers a variety of period pastiches, from Kristen Flanders's harsh, Kurt Weillian interpretation of "The Boulevard of Broken Dreams" to Matthew Bennett's subversively manic version of "Never Swat a Fly," a whimsical song about not dividing lovers.
The acting, in a confounding diversity of styles, is less successful. But Ms. Flanders, as a Danish idealist, and Jennifer Wiltsie, as a naive newlywed, find a plaintiveness that transcends the dogmatic material. And Frank Raiter, as the old vaudevillian, has a heartbreaking mechanical smile that punctuates even his most fatalistic declarations and says everything about the show-biz tradition he's descended from.
These individual glimmers of warmth are incongruities in an evening that is clearly intended to keep us at a chilly, contemplative distance. Unfortunately, "Marathon Dancing" doesn't give us much that's new to contemplate.
Marathon Dancing
By Laura Harrington; musical adaptation and supervision by Christopher Drobny; conceived and directed by Anne Bogart; choreography by Alison Shafer; musical director, Michael Rice; sets by Kyle Chepulis; costumes by Gabriel Berry; lights by Carol Mullins; sound by Eric Liljestrand; props, Derek Stenborg; dramaturgy, Carol Martin; producer, Anne Hamburger; managing director, Karen Dalzell. Presented by En Garde Arts. At the Grand Ballroom of the Masonic Grand Lodge, 71 West 23d Street, Chelsea.

HEADLINE: Fewer Are Late On Mortgages

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
Americans had an easier time paying their mortgages in late 1993 than at any time in the last 20 years, a banking group says, as homeowners benefited from lower interest rates and the improving economy.
Mortgage delinquencies, or the failure to meet mortgage payments, fell in the last three months of 1993 to the lowest levels since the first quarter of 1973, the Mortgage Bankers Association said Friday. 
 It said the percentage of homeowners who were late in their payments fell 18 basis points, to 4.03 percent, from 4.21 percent in the third quarter. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The bankers group said the survey, which covers about a third of all mortgages on one-to-four-unit residential properties, showed the delinquency rate was down 21 basis points from late 1992.
The Northeast showed the biggest drop in the rate of troubled mortgages, down 35 points, to 4.02 percent.

HEADLINE: The Plot to Recapture Ukraine

 BODY:
Ukraine is an independent country, though many Russians are reluctant to recognize that fact. Hard-line remnants of Russia's military and K.G.B. are eager to recapture it. Their strategy is to stir up civil unrest, beginning in Crimea, which is part of Ukraine. By undermining Ukraine's territorial integrity, hard-liners hope to destroy the republic's independence.
That strategy could lead to civil war and could erode the power of Boris Yeltsin and his fellow reformers in Russia. Obviously, they cannot afford to play along. Obviously, too, Washington needs to help them. 
 Ukraine has a tenuous hold on Crimea. The Soviet Union ceded it from Russia in 1954. But a majority of its population is Russian; many residents are retirees from the Black Sea navy.
Events in Crimea look ominously like the divide-and-conquer strategy Russia's hard-liners followed in Moldova and Georgia, where Russian secessionists, with the complicity of renegades in the military and K.G.B., declared independence and called on Russia to protect them.
Last month, Crimea elected Yuri Meshkov President. Mr. Meshkov, an ethnic Russian and former K.G.B. border guard, won overwhelming support from fellow ethnic Russians in a campaign managed by a reputed covert operative from Moscow, after which he appointed a citizen of Russia Prime Minister. He will soon call for a referendum on Crimean independence and could then call on Russia's army to protect Crimea.
Meanwhile, the breakaway threat in Crimea has energized rabid Ukrainian nationalists, who fear a broader plot to split off eastern Ukraine, with its large Russian population. Most Russians in Ukraine voted for its independence in 1991 -- many in the belief that it would be more prosperous than Russia. Kiev's economic mismanagement is giving them second thoughts.
Some still think of themselves as Soviet citizens; others share regional rather than ethnic identities. But about a quarter have married ethnic Ukrainians and speak Ukrainian. And many Russians in Ukraine do think it a separate country.
That is not true in Russia, where few Russians, even reformers, have reconciled themselves to Ukrainian independence. That strengthens ultranationalists who desire to regain Ukraine, or at least the part where Russians predominate. But controlling Ukraine would require an army of occupation far larger than the one driven out of Afghanistan. Raising such an army would sap Russia's resources, and a functioning draft could not be restored without force.
This step could not be taken without wrecking reform and restoring the old order in Russia. That is exactly what the empire rebuilders want to do, and why Mr. Yeltsin and his reformers would be wrong to cooperate with them on Ukraine.
Washington may be able to help. It can try to mediate disputes. It can encourage the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe to assure minority rights on both sides of the border. It can encourage Ukraine and Russia to undertake joint economic development in heavily Russified eastern Ukraine and nearby Russia. And it can channel U.S. aid for that purpose.
In short, the U.S. can try to get Ukrainians and Russians to concentrate on economic improvement, not ethnic identity, and give them every opportunity to better their common lot in life.

HEADLINE: Cleaning Up the Trash Racket

 BODY:
Trash hauling is a big, competitive business almost everywhere. But in and around New York City, the trash business is just big. Racketeers and ancient family enterprises dominate the trade; consumers and commercial enterprises suffer. Instead of competing, haulers operate in market-allocating cartels while mob enforcers help keep the competition out, robbing the public of efficient, economical service.
This is a well-documented disgrace that deserves far more official attention that it has received. Mark Green, the city's Public Advocate, now advocates changes aimed at introducing price competition into a strangled market. His suggestions deserve the careful attention of Mayor Giuliani, who is a fan of competitive enterprise and built his career fighting racketeers. 
 A recent Justice Department settlement in a Long Island racketeering suit offers a rare glimmer of hope and suggests a useful strategy against mob control of trash-hauling monopolies. It requires eight of the region's largest carters to start competing against one another and to hire auditors to police them from within and report their findings to the courts.
The settlement, to be supervised by a Federal court, is an interim product of five years of Justice Department litigation. The Government has sued more than 140 companies and people, moving against a half-century's accretion of inertia, graft and the occasional violence that inhibits customers from changing haulers.
The settlement mainly affects the interests of Salvatore Avellino Jr., a captain in the Lucchese crime family and the largest residential hauler in Suffolk County. He has pleaded guilty to ordering the murders of two haulers who bucked organized crime and were preparing to testify against gangster companies.
A similar mix of fresh competition, internal policing and outside supervision could help free the city's commercial enterprises -- restaurants, hospitals and thousands of businesses -- from costly bondage to the cartel. One healthy sign is the recent arrival of Browning-Ferris Industries, the nation's second-largest hauler of solid waste, to bid on commercial waste contracts. The company, which says that it is here to stay, has won some business and claims that its bids have dramatically lowered the costs of contracts it did not win.
Mr. Green has introduced legislation in the City Council calling for experimental collection districts where a single low bidder would replace dozens of small haulers who now decline to compete within their protected fiefs.
Mr. Giuliani needs to come up with his own proposals to make trash hauling more honest, perhaps through auditing procedures, and more competitive. He might consider a program to encourage reputable firms to bid or the redrawing of collection areas, as Mr. Green suggests. Without proposals from the Mayor, City Council leaders should move ahead with hearings on the best way to free trash collection from gougers and racketeers.

HEADLINE: At Home Abroad;
'More Of Itself'

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia

 BODY:
When Lyndon Johnson was struggling in the quagmire of Vietnam, he took comfort from his favorite ally in the war: Australia. Australian troops were there from 1966 to 1972, almost to the final American withdrawal.
Next month the Australian Prime Minister, Paul Keating, will fly to Hanoi. His visit is a symbol of the most important trend in this country. Australia is intent on finding a place for itself in Asia. And part of that is a greater willingness to differ with the United States. 
 American Secretaries of State used to visit Canberra and bask in the warmth of agreement and respect. But that was not what Warren Christopher encountered when he was there the other day, on his way to China.
The Australian Foreign Minister, Senator Gareth Evans, told him bluntly that Australia disagreed with President Clinton's invocation of the threat of trade sanctions against Japan. That was managed trade, he said, not multilateral free trade. If it had any effect, it would simply lead to a preference for American goods in Japan -- and hurt Australia and others.
The Government and Australian commentators were equally critical of the Clinton Administration's pressure on China to improve its human rights record by June or lose its most-favored-nation trade status.
Senator Evans told the press after two days of meetings with Secretary Christopher that a U.S. withdrawal of China's M.F.N. status would have "a very adverse impact" on the economy of all Asia. He said it would be especially devastating for Hong Kong but would also hurt Australia.
The sharp disagreement on trade policy -- and on what Australia sees as rough American tactics -- illustrates the change in relationship with the United States. It is a change both political and psychological.
When the British colonies on this island continent came together as Australia in 1901, the new country remained resolutely British -- with a colonial inferiority complex. The Australian writer Thomas Keneally (author of among other books "Schindler's Ark," on which the movie "Schindler's List" is based) remarked recently that Australian culture and society had to recover "from a sense of exile."
After World War II the ties with Britain frayed, no doubt inevitably because of distance and the end of empire. America replaced Britain as the powerful friend, a relationship formalized in the Anzus Treaty.
Australia's eager support of American policy in Vietnam showed the closeness of the relationship -- and probably marked its high point. For Australia like most developed countries has come to see the great issues and potential conflicts in the world as economic rather than military. And Australia's neighbors in Asia are the fastest growing in the world economy.
Until as recently as 25 years ago Australia was formally committed to not being Asian. That was the import of its White Australia policy, barring Asian immigrants. Since the repeal of that law, a flow of Asians has gradually developed. They now make up 4 percent of the population. A Sydney taxi driver said he came here from Canton seven years ago "to do better."
Echoes of America remain. A visiting American has a certain feeling of deja vu: of familiar issues and trends.
Australia's old reputation was as one of the most macho cultures on earth. But the country has a strong women's movement now, and two women are even moving toward the top in politics. There is a sensitivity about gender in language, sometimes to the same absurd degree as in American political correctness. A woman applicant for a university position was criticized recently for referring to someone's "mastery" of a subject.
Sydney has had a gay and lesbian mardi gras for years. Last week's attracted 500,000 onlookers, and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation did an hour's program on the parade. A few politicians complained about the broadcast but most people seemed happy about the event.
Maybe in that respect Australia is more comfortable with diversity than an angry American society is today. In any case there is a distinctiveness about this country now. It is not really a copy of anything. "Australia," Thomas Keneally said, "has become more of itself."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Why Do We Still Play This Dirty Spy Game?;
Terrorism Studies

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Terrorism studies, a think-tank mainstay of the 1970's and 80's, are among the industries that have declined with the end of the cold war. For more than two decades, this was an academic growth industry, sucking huge sums from Federal agencies into such enterprises as the Rand Corporation, George Washington University and the Institute for Foreign Policy Analysis -- represented by Mark D. W. Edington in "Terror Made Easy" (Op-Ed, March 3). 
 Unfortunately, these studies taught us very little, or we were allowed to learn very little from them. The money filtered into them was from agencies whose own operations were usually sub rosa, so the resulting work was usually not publicly available. Such arrangements seriously compromise academic standards, like the free exchange of ideas and open access to data generated by public funds. Now the students of terrorism are suffering from cutbacks.
One thing we did learn during the period of terrorism studies was that these benefactors, the intelligence agencies, were unreliable in their main business: knowing what was going to happen, or probably going to happen, in key places. The collective wisdom of more than $1 trillion spent on intelligence gathering and analysis did not foresee or properly analyze the consequences of any significant event from the Tet offensive to the collapse of the Soviet Union -- let alone the hijacking of an airplane or the taking of hostages here and there.
Now the declining terrorism-studies industry warns us we face new dangers and must beef up our vigilance (and, by implication, our terrorism research budgets). They play off the domestic headlines and call for beefing up what we are just debeefing, and stricter controls on immigration and personal rights.
The facts do get in the way. The incidents Mr. Edington mentions (the World Trade Center bombing, the arrest of suspected Hamas supporters and the Brooklyn Bridge shooting) were solved with conventional policing powers and are being adjudicated through normal legal processes. We have enough knowledge and legal power to handle these things, and we should not be frightened or seduced into going back down the path of expensive and fruitless studies into what cannot be foreseen.
And we should be especially wary of anyone who wants more domestic controls over our movements and rights.
 
MICHAEL KAHAN
Assoc. Professor, Political Science
Brooklyn College, CUNY
Staten Island, March 3, 1994

HEADLINE: Clinton Partner Denies One Allegation

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
As Democrats and Republicans continued bickering on television this morning over whether Congressional hearings should be held on the Whitewater case, Bill and Hillary Clinton's business partner in the Arkansas land venture that gave the case its name said that one main instance of supposed wrongdoing never occurred.
The former partner, James B. McDougal said on the ABC News program "This Week" that "in no way, shape, form or fashion" did any money from a savings and loan he headed go "into a Clinton campaign." 
 Mr. McDougal held a fund-raising event in 1985 to help Mr. Clinton pay off a $50,000 loan that had helped finance his 1984 campaign for re-election as Governor of Arkansas. One matter under investigation by the independent counsel, Robert B. Fiske Jr., is whether any money raised by Mr. McDougal came from the savings and loan, Madison Guaranty. The savings association ultimately collapsed at a cost to the Federal Government of more than $60 million.
 
Mistake by Aides
 Mr. McDougal, his head shaven, sat stiffly before the camera in a high-backed leather chair in his office in Arkansas and complained that the Clintons were refusing to give him corporate records of the Whitewater Development Company that he needed to complete his income taxes.
A White House spokeswoman responded this afternoon that all the records had been turned over to the independent counsel. She said she did not know if the Clintons had kept copies.
Mr. McDougal said he did not believe that the Clintons had committed any crime, but he suggested that material in the records might somehow embarrass them.
The new White House counsel, Lloyd N. Cutler, appeared on all three network interview programs this morning and said that White House aides had made a mistake by discussing the Madison investigation in meetings with officials from the Treasury Department and the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency managing the savings and loan bailout.
But on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," Mr. Cutler said the mistake was "more the appearance of those meetings than anything else."
Between the lines of Mr. Cutler's remarks, one aspect of the White House strategy began to take shape. The White House seems to hope that Mr. Fiske will deal first with the meetings between Treasury Department and White House staff members on Madison Guaranty, as he has said he might, and publish an interim report exonerating Administration officials of wrongdoing on that angle of the case.
Then, they may hope to argue that since nothing wrong has been done since Mr. Clinton became President, Congressional hearings are unnecessary.
Having been named to his position only on Monday, Mr. Cutler said he had not had time to review many relevant documents.
But, he declared: "From everything I have heard, it seems to be clear that no effort was made by any White House people to indicate to the Treasury people what they ought to do, and, indeed, the Treasury and the R.T.C. did not change their position."
Mr. Cutler and the Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, argued that Congressional hearings should not take place until Mr. Fiske had completed his inquiry.
But Senators Bob Dole of Kansas, Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York and William S. Cohen of Maine and Representative Jim Leach of Iowa, all Republicans, maintained that public hearings were necessary to clear the air.
Mr. Cutler insisted that his job was to advise the President in his public duties and that Whitewater matters would be handled by the Clintons' personal lawyer, David Kendall.
 
Possibility of Back Taxes
 Mr. Kendall said in an interview published this week in U.S. News & World Report that the Whitewater investigation might end up showing that the Clintons would have to pay some back taxes.
Mrs. Clinton, in interviews with Time and Newsweek to be published on Monday, said she and the President would pay whatever additional taxes they owed.
In the interviews Mrs. Clinton took an approach often favored by politicians, admitting that mistakes had been made but rarely saying precisely what they were. For example, in the Newsweek interview, she said: "Clearly there were lots of missteps along the way. I'd be the first to say that, and obviously I wish there weren't because this thing has gotten blown so out of proportion.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 15, 1994, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the Whitewater case misstated the source of a report that David Kendall, Bill and Hillary Clinton's lawyer, believed the Clintons might owe some back taxes on their real estate investment in the Ozarks of Arkansas. The report, published this week in U.S. News & World Report, was attributed by the magazine to unidentified "insiders," not to Mr. Kendall.

HEADLINE: Failure to Replace Trustees Weakens CUNY, Critics Say

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN 

 BODY:
The mayor and the governor have not appointed any new trustees of City University for years. The board held only eight regular meetings last year, and just one of the five borough hearings it is supposed to hold every year. And at committee meetings, where most of the work is conducted, there are often only two trustees at the big table.
A majority of members of the City University Board of Trustees are holdovers whose terms of office expired as long ago as 1988, an unprecedented situation that educators and local officials say has weakened the leadership of the nation's largest urban university. 
 Herman Badillo, a governor's appointee whose term expired last June, said the university is at a critical time, undergoing sweeping academic consolidation, budget cuts and a changing student population. A vigorous board, he said, is needed: "The problem now is there is less regard for the City University. The loss of support from the public and from the politicians for CUNY requires a board that is much more active."
Today, according to State Senator Guy J. Velella, Republican of the Bronx, who is a critic of Chancellor W. Ann Reynolds, "Nobody on the board seems to be paying attention."
 
Highly Unusual
 Many state-appointed boards have some holdovers, but it is highly unusual for a majority of members to be serving expired terms, educators and local officials said. "A few expired terms is fairly common," said Tom Ingram, president of the Association of Governing Boards of Universities and Colleges, a nonprofit service organization. "In this case, it sounds like the City University has an unfortunately and inordinately large number of expired terms."
Nonetheless, the State Attorney General's office said, these trustees have full voting powers.
Of the 15 members, 8 are serving expired terms and 2 vacancies have not been filled, leaving only 5 serving out their seven-year terms. The board also includes a faculty representative, who has no voting rights, and a student representative. The mayor has five appointees, with four now serving expired terms, and the governor 10, including the chairman and the vice chairman. Six gubernatorial appointees, including the chairman, are holdovers. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has said he plans to fill all four vacancies in the next few weeks.
 
Setting the Academic Tone
 The trustees, who serve without pay, set policy for the 200,0000-student system. By hiring the chancellor, who runs the university on a day-to-day basis, and overseeing appointment of the system's 18 presidents and three deans, they also set the academic tone for the institution.
The board's current state stands in sharp contrast to its early years as a high-profile and aggressive body. For instance, in 1976, when the state imposed tuition during the city's fiscal crisis, most of the board quit in protest. In 1979 the board split over the selection of the Hunter College president. One faction wanted Donna E. Shalala, now Secretary of Health and Human Services, but the board chairman, Harold Jacobs, wanted another candidate. So the Shalala faction waited until Mr. Jacobs was out of town and approved Dr. Shalala.
But last year attendance at meetings ranged from as few as 7 trustees to as many as 12 -- not counting the student and the faculty representative -- and the board met eight times, one less than the year before.
The chairman of the board, James P. Murphy, said he disagreed that this board was passive compared with past boards. Mr. Murphy served on the board from 1974 to 1976. He was reappointed in 1986, and his term expired in 1992."There's not a shy one in the bunch," he said.
 
No Appointments by Dinkins
 During his term Mayor David N. Dinkins made no appointments, even though four of his five spots opened. Of the governor's 10 appointees, 5 are serving expired terms, including Sylvia Bloom, whose term officially ended in 1988. In addition there is one vacancy, and trustee Stanley Fink will complete his term in June.
Legislators and other critics blame Mr. Dinkins and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo for the inattention to the board. "It is my opinion that the people responsible for appointments should make them in a timely manner," said Assemblyman Edward C. Sullivan, chairman of the Assembly's Higher Education Committee.
But spokesmen for Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Cuomo, both Democrats, blame the majority Republicans in the State Senate for playing politics with the nominations they forward to them.
"It wasn't lack of care," said Lee Blake, who was executive director of the Office of Education Services under Mr. Dinkins. "The appointment process is so complicated. Fighting battles in Albany just took up so much energy."
Senator Velella conceded that the Senate held up two nominations -- one by the Governor, one by Mayor Dinkins -- over dissatisfaction with Dr. Reynolds's direction on two lawsuits against CUNY. The first, by an Italian-American coalition, successfully sought hiring and educational remedies; the other, by Prof. Leonard Jeffries, successfully sought his reinstatement as chairman of the black studies department at City College. The university is appealing both cases.
"I worry that politics have reared their ugly head in the case of CUNY," said Mr. Ingram, of the national association of governing boards. "It suggests the possibility that political leaders may not understand the function of the board of trustees and the world of universities as distinct to the world of politics."
Mayor Giuliani has announced that he is nominating Jerome Berg, a partner in a consulting and developing firm who is involved in community activities on Staten Island, to replace Louis Cenci, whose term expired in 1989. Mr. Giuliani is also said to be considering Ron Jones of Brooklyn, a vice president of the United Federation of Teachers; Lorraine R. Colville of Manhattan, a former faculty member at John Jay College who during the Reagan Administration was the New York regional representative of the United States Education Department, and John W. Peterkin of Queens, a former police officer and security director of New York City Technical College.
 
'As Quickly as We Can'
 The Governor's education assistant, Neil J. Foley, said the Governor was working on his nominees but he could not say when they would be announced.
"The issue with respect to naming people and resubmitting people's names is one of the many, many items that we deal with here and we will deal with it as quickly as we can," Mr. Foley said.
But the sentiment persists among many educators, at CUNY and at other colleges in the state, that Governor Cuomo is less interested in public education than his predecessors beginning with Nelson A. Rockefeller, who created both the State University and City University system.
"Half of the members have terms that have expired," said Kenneth P. Sherrill, a political science professor at Hunter College. "While some of that reflects the Republicans and the Senate holding things up, it also reflects the low priority they, the governor and the mayor, have given to CUNY, and it reflects the low caliber of the appointments."
 
A Prestigious Assignment
 Before the late 1970's, the board -- then called the Board of Higher Education -- was made up of 21 mayoral appointees, and because it was considered a prestigious assignment it attracted pre-eminent figures in the city's civic, academic and diplomatic circles. Previous boards included such people as Harry Carman, a senior dean of engineering at Columbia University, Ordway Tead, a publisher, Federal Judge Simon Rifkin and Emanuel Peori, the head of scientific research for I.B.M.
In 1976, the city's fiscal crisis caused CUNY to run out of money and close its doors for two weeks. The state rescued it, but CUNY was forced to impose tuition for the first time in its 129-year history. Fiscal control was transferred largely to the state, and by 1979 the governor had 10 of the 15 appointments. The Legislature required that each borough be represented on the board.
Since then, many of the appointees have had political ties to the mayor or governor, or to borough presidents, but there are almost no educators.
"The big problem is that there is no one on the board who is competent to judge some academic issues, who is an academic, who is by profession in the university world," Professor Sherrill said. "What this means is that not only does the central administration have an absolute monopoly over the flow of information, but also a monopoly on the interpretation of the information."
But Mr. Murphy, the chairman of the board, said that while today's trustees have different credentials, they are just as capable of making decisions on the academic direction of the university.
"They represent all social and economic needs of the city," he said. "They are not specialists, and we are not meant to be specialists in academic matters."
