HEADLINE: Kohl, Battered in Opinion Polls, Remains Buoyant

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BONN, March 14

 BODY:
Chancellor Helmut Kohl has stood astride Europe for more than 11 years, but if current public opinion polls are accurate forecasts of the Oct. 16 national elections, his domination might be at an end.
If he should topple, it would send shock waves around the Continent and across the Atlantic, since for many of his fellow leaders he has become the very symbol of Germany, and all of his potential successors are little-known abroad. 
 But at 63, Mr. Kohl looks and sounds supremely self-confident. Looking out at the pink cherry blossoms and the daffodils on the Rhine outside his modern third-floor office here on a sparkling spring afternoon, he just smiled and said: "Ever since I can remember, people have been predicting my imminent political demise. Once it made me angry; later it amused me; now I simply ignore it.
"I know just as sure as I look out the window and see spring that the mood has changed. I'm going to win."
Mr. Kohl has had the last laugh on his opponents often enough to indulge in such idiosyncrasies as not giving interviews to newspapers and magazines he does not like, which means a good many of them. He does not even read Der Spiegel, the country's leading news magazine, which proclaimed "The End of the Kohl Era" on its cover in December.
Mr. Kohl has been there before. He seemed headed for electoral defeat in the last national elections in 1990, but was saved by the sudden collapse of the Berlin Wall in 1989 and the unexpected opportunity it offered for German unification. He seized the opportunity with consummate determination and diplomatic skill, and with firm backing from the Bush Administration.
 
Stressing Close Ties With United States
 Today he has the best personal relationship of any European leader with the Clinton Administration. "I am a proven friend of the United States," he said. "My relationship with America is emotional and deep-seated. And I have had extraordinary luck with all recent U.S. Presidents, including a great relationship now with Bill Clinton."
He visited the President in Washington briefly early this year, strengthening his own image in German voters' eyes as America's most trusted ally. He playfully endured Mr. Clinton's ribbing about his size. At one point during the NATO summit in January, Mr. Clinton told Mr. Kohl that he had dreamed that the German leader was a sumo wrestler, a bit of an exaggeration for the Chancellor, Kohl, who may be big, at six feet four and 300 pounds, but not that big.
But with Germany's unemployment rate over 10 percent, with more than four million jobless -- the highest level since the start of the post-World War II economic recovery -- and with Government finances in such a bad state that his opponents have been drawing comparisons to the Weimar Republic, the domestic economy will probably determine his fate.
Here, too, he is all optimism. "The deep recession that we're just coming out of has laid bare economic problems that have been with us for 30 years, so I'm in the unusual position of telling people at campaign rallies that we have to change our ways of doing things," he said.
His opponents do not underrate him. "He is an unbelievably good political fighter -- the best there is when the chips are down," said Dr. Friedbert Pfluger, a member of Parliament and one of his most outspoken critics within his own Christian Democratic ranks.
Nevertheless, a string of 18 state and local elections began with a defeat for Mr. Kohl's party on Sunday in Lower Saxony, despite his own heavy campaign schedule there. "A bitter loss," he conceded today.
 
Mix of Domesticity And United Europe
 Since he first appeared on the national scene in the mid-1970's as premier of the state of Rhineland-Palatinate, his political genius has always been a shrewd mixture of provincial domesticity that puts his countrymen at ease and a deeply felt dedication to European unity that has often reassured Germany's neighbors.
Even his opponents do not question his commitment to Europe, but when domestic and foreign interests clash, Mr. Kohl goes for the votes at home every time.
In 1985, for example, he insisted that President Ronald Reagan visit a German military cemetery in Bitburg, despite a controversy that raged after it turned out that some members of the Nazi Waffen SS military units had been buried there.
Mr. Kohl prevailed on Mr. Reagan to come anyway as a gesture of postwar reconciliation. Some intellectuals and commentators called him ignorant or worse for forcing the issue, but many ordinary Germans thought him patriotic and courageous.
"In Germany, two-thirds of the population was born after Hitler," he said in his office recently. "I see the role of my generation, which is old enough to understand what happened under National Socialism but too young to be blamed for it, as explaining to the younger ones how it was, bearing witness to the good things their parents' generation did as well as the bad -- not denying the past at all."
 
Stand on Borders Worried Neighbors
 At times his strategy has been difficult for foreigners to fathom. While he pressed for German unification, Mr. Kohl resisted several months of international pressure to reassure Poland that a reunified Germany would make no claims on the territory beyond its eastern border that had belonged to it before the war.
He finally did so in March of 1990, after bringing around supporters who had been expelled from those territories to the view that kissing the lost lands goodbye was the price of unity.
He wanted their votes in the national election, and nine months later his party won.
Mr. Kohl has also shaped his foreign policy around German public opinion. It was reticent in the war in the Persian Gulf, where Germany stayed out of the fighting on the grounds that the 1949 constitution allowed only defense of German territory.
But his policy became more assertive as Yugoslavia began to break up. The German Foreign Minister at the time, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, insisted on recognizing Croatia and Slovenia even though some of his European Community partners feared that recognition could set off fierce fighting in neighboring Bosnia. Mr. Kohl, mindful of strong German support for Croatia, went along with Mr. Genscher.
But with the public horrified by two years of bloody fighting in Bosnia and with Germany overwhelmed by refugees, Mr. Kohl has backed peace efforts by his allies.
 
Playing the Card Of World Expertise
 A grave international crisis before next October would probably help Mr. Kohl to use his international experience against his Social Democratic challenger, Rudolf Scharping, one of his successors as Premier of the state of Rhineland-Palatinate. Mr. Scharping, anxious to bolster his own standing abroad, will travel to the United States next month and will be received by President Clinton on April 12, American diplomats said.
But domestic economic problems have cost the Chancellor the considerable support he had in the eastern part of Germany in the last election. And in the west, people like former Chancellor Helmut Schmidt have asked why Mr. Kohl did not make a "blood, sweat and tears" speech in 1990 to warn them that unification would take sacrifice and time.
"I've been wrong about some things since 1990, but who hasn't been?" he answered. "I didn't know in the spring of 1991 that the Soviet Union was about to collapse, but no one else did either."
If the next election were held now, all the recent public opinion polls indicate, the Christian Democrats would win only 32 to 35 percent of the vote, compared with 37 to 41 percent for the Social Democrats.
 
High Wages Blamed For Recession
 With little prospect of economic recovery in sight, Mr. Kohl began telling voters last fall that the problem was not the $100-billion-a-year cost of unifying the country, but wage and welfare benefits that had swollen to such generous levels that German products were unable to compete on world markets.
"Helmut Schmidt had a lot to do with the fact that wages rose throughout the 1970's without much relation to costs," Mr. Kohl said.
But Mr. Kohl did not ask for sacrifice four years ago because people were not ready then, one of his advisers said. "They are ready now," the adviser added.
Mr. Kohl says that the severe recession scared his compatriots out of complacency. "When I talk to them at rallies, they don't drown me out with jeers, they listen to me and applaud afterward," he said. "The Germans will make an economic comeback -- don't you worry about that."
In fact, Mr. Kohl has seldom led public opinion, and instead tends to follow its dictates. When neo-Nazi groups began attacking the foreign asylum-seekers who were pouring into the country in 1992, for instance, the Chancellor resisted invitations to visit Rostock, the site of one of the worst attacks.
"Political tourism," his spokesman, Dieter Vogel, called such demonstrations of sympathy.
"I am a firm opponent of all radicals, left or right -- they are a shame on our country," Mr. Kohl said.
But he did not believe in the power of words to stop the attacks when the Constitution seemed to lay the country open to an unlimited influx of people in search of a better life.
Germans were "overwhelmed," he said. Last summer, the Government and the opposition agreed to change the Constitution to make it more difficult to obtain asylum, and the number of attacks has diminished.
"He underestimated the effect the right-wing attacks had on public opinion abroad," one of his closest aides said. "But he thought that if he joined the public protests it would only make neo-Nazism seem more serious than it really was and strengthen the right-wing splinter parties."
 
Stress on Austerity To Revive Economy
 Both candidates agree that German industry needs to become more competitive, but Mr. Kohl puts more emphasis on belt-tightening. "We cannot secure our country's future by running it like a collective leisure park," he told Parliament last fall. "We must create the necessary conditions for a fundamental turnaround in all branches of our economy."
Under prodding from the central bank and international organizations, he is also trying to turn around government finances, which relied heavily on deficit spending even before the burden of unification.
According to the central bank, total federal Government debt rose from 232.3 billion marks ($134.3 billion) in 1980 to 678.3 billion marks ($392.1 billion) by last November. To slow down the rate of increase, the government cut $12.4 billion from the federal budget last year, but the federal budget deficit was still $17.3 billion greater in 1993 than the year before.
Mr. Kohl has his eye on grander visions, though. "When I go home I visit Mainz, Worms, Speyer -- all cities that have been repeatedly fought over and destroyed in wars," he said. "We're not going to build Europe in a day, but at the end of this century, I expect to live to see the realization of Adenauer's vision of German unification and European unity as two sides of the same coin."

HEADLINE: Europeans Chase the Sun to Brazil's Northeast

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RECIFE, Brazil

 BODY:
Fleeing cold weather and seeking sunshine, Europeans are flocking to the white crystal beaches of Brazil's Northeast, making the region the fastest-growing center for international tourism in South America.
More and more Italians, French, Germans and Spaniards have begun to vacation along the 2,000-mile coast of Brazil's northeastern shoulder, where this continent reaches out toward Europe. 
 International tourist arrivals are expected to reach one million this year, a tenfold increase in just four years. There are weekly flights from most European capitals to Recife and Salvador, the largest cities in this region, yet cities that are essentially unknown to most in the United States.
 
Cheap, Yet Relatively Unknown
 Although a vacation in the Northeast can cost half as much as a holiday in the Caribbean, travelers from the United States are watching the boom from the sidelines. Americans may offer the largest natural market, but no United States airline flies to the Brazilian Northeast. New United States investment is limited so far to half a dozen McDonald's restaurants and two hotels here, a Sheraton and a Best Western. Yet Recife is as close to Miami as to Lisbon.
By contrast, Spanish and Italian investors are contributing heavily to $1 billion of hotel and resort construction under way on the coast. A further $1.3 billion is being invested by the states of the region, with backing from the Inter-American Development Bank, to upgrade roads and sewers to international tourism standards.
"The Caribbean is saturated," said Celso Sterenberg, tourism secretary for Pernambuco state. "The next big tourist development is going to be Brazil's Northeast."
By the end of the decade, Brazilian economists forecast, tourism will be the largest industry in the Northeast, long Brazil's poorest region. The World Travel and Tourism Council, an industry association, predicted in a study last year that "Brazil's tourism industry would grow 2.8 times as fast as Latin American travel and tourism, and more than 160 percent faster than the world average."
But Varig operates only one flight a week from Miami to Fortaleza and Recife. Next month, another big Brazilian carrier, VASP, will inaugurate direct service between Recife and Miami. To win more United States passengers, Varig recently signed a ticketing, baggage and mileage-program partnership with Delta Air Lines.
Isn't there room for more? Only with great care, says Adam G. Carter, director of Brazil Nuts Tours of Fairfield, Conn. An airline route from Miami to Recife "is not going to make it," Mr. Carter said.
"For the mass American market, it has to be New York-Recife, Chicago-Recife."
American tourism to Brazil dropped sharply in the late 1980's after the authorities failed to check street crime against tourists in Rio de Janeiro, the nation's largest port of entry. "The importance of what is happening now in the Northeast is that it will eventually fuel the return of American tourists to Brazil," Mr. Carter said in a telephone interview from the state of Rio do Norte.
A major appeal is Brazil's cost of living, which is inexpensive compared with that in the United States and most of Europe.
"Here you can have a rum drink for 50 cents and a plate of shrimp for $8," said Carlos A. Sodre, executive director of the Northeast Integrated Tourism Commission. "The average foreigner spends $71 a day in Brazil's Northeast. In the Caribbean, he spends $120 to 150 a day."
On Saturday, 53 American tour operators are to come to Recife as part of a group of 500 attending the Brazil National Tourist Mart, a four-day event that has become the largest such trade fair in South America.
"Once we get more American travel agents down here, we will start getting more American tourists," said Mark Birchall, sales director of the Sheraton Petribu Hotel. He estimated that fewer than 2 percent of his guests are now Americans.
The 16-floor Sheraton opened two years ago on a quiet beach here, part of a cautious entry of American hotel chains into the region.
In the last year, Best Western opened a hotel in Recife, and Ramada signed a contract to administer a hotel in the city of Natal. Hyatt is studying a site in Salvador, where the state government has invested $15 million in renovating the colonial urban core.
 
Hotel Space Is Precious
 As the region comes to the end of the Southern Hemisphere summer, hotel managers report that hotel occupancies for January and February reached as high as 90 percent. These occupancy rates are spurring hotel construction up and down the coast.
"In two to three years, Recife will have nine five-star hotels, the same number as Sao Paulo," Mr. Sterenberg predicted, referring to the nation's biggest city. At Recife airport, the Brazilian Government has authorized the region's first duty-free shop.
Americans working here say they see a new, pro-business attitude in northeastern Brazil, a region traditionally dominated by narrow-minded ruling families.
"To get our supply networks going, the state governors flew us around in their helicopters," said Peter Rodenbeck, who manages half the 124 McDonald's restaurants in Brazil. He has opened six McDonald's in northeastern cities over the last 18 months. "Our sales growth in the Northeast was spectacular last year," said Mr. Rodenbeck, who wants to open restaurants in five more regional cities.
 
Too Big for Single Campaign
 With the nine states of the Northeast vying to become a South American Costa Brava, untouched stretches of beach are being promoted with appealing labels: Bahia's "Green Line," Pernambuco's "Golden Coast" and Rio Grande do Norte's "Route of the Sun."
Northeastern states plan to spend $16 million on promotion this year -- five times what the national agency, Embratur, spends to promote the entire country.
"We are a continent-sized country," remarked Mr. Sodre, the Northeast Tourism Commission director. "There is no return in selling Brazil; you have to sell it by region."
Believing that employment from tourism can help lift the region out of poverty, the Inter-American Development Bank is lending $200 million in the start of a decade-long program to finance tourism development in the Northeast.
"If you don't have good sanitation and roads, you might lose the nascent tourism you already have," said David B. Atkinson, the bank's representative for Brazil. "Our objective is to develop infrastructure in tourist areas near population areas. We are not looking at creating enclaves like Cancun."
The bank is lending $750 million to improve roads and sewage around the three largest tourism destinations -- Fortaleza, Recife and Salvador. Fortaleza has a cholera problem, and the bank's loans will help expand sewerage to 80 percent of the city, from 15 percent. And the northeastern states are investing to promote other projects.
State tourism authorities have set a goal of tripling tourist spending in Bahia, to $1.4 billion, by the end of the decade. Links are being added almost monthly: Salvador's international flights have increased to 43 a day, from six a week in 1991.
Forty miles south of Recife airport, Pernambuco state is promoting an ambitious, Cancun-style development called the Costa Dourada, or Golden Coast.

HEADLINE: Saving Lawmaker on Labor Hit List

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CINCINNATI, March 14

 BODY:
It was surprising enough for Vice President Al Gore to break an unspoken White House tradition by taking sides in a bitter primary fight between two party members. But even more surprising was his decision to do so on behalf of a lawmaker who often behaves more like a Republican than a Democrat.
The candidate, Representative David Mann, voted against President Clinton's stimulus package and his budget proposal. He does not much care for the President's remedy for health care. And he thinks Congress should step in and get to the bottom of the Whitewater matter. 
 But Mr. Clinton had promised to help Mr. Mann in exchange for a single vote: the freshman Congressman's decision to support the North American Free Trade Agreement. That vote infuriated Mr. Mann's longtime friends in labor here and in Washington, who helped elect him in 1992.
This year he is their biggest, and so far most vulnerable, target.
 
Alone With Opposition
 "There's a sense of betrayal here," said Richard Walsh, the national political director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. "We're not afraid to punish our enemies."
For all the bullying from labor organizations last year about knocking off the 102 House Democrats who voted for the trade accord, Mr. Mann is the only lawmaker at this point with serious primary opposition.
And even here the opponent was not recruited by labor, but was a popular candidate who had been waiting on the sidelines: State Senator William F. Bowen, who lost to Mr. Mann by only 416 votes in an eight-candidate primary two years ago. Mr. Bowen is a liberal who is counting on all-out support from labor and from black ministers who are influential here to give him an edge this time.
The May 3 primary in Ohio's First Congressional District, which includes most of Cincinnati as well as suburbs on the Indiana border, is shaping up as a case study of what might have been had the threats from labor materialized elsewhere around the country.
 
Party Is Troubled
 Mr. Clinton, who last year commended Mr. Mann for "a very courageous vote," has put the prestige of the White House on the line to defend him. Labor groups, meanwhile, are out to prove that they have not lost all their influence by making an example of Mr. Mann for daring to defy them. As union memberships dwindle, that may be difficult, especially because this district has never had the big industrial union presence of cities like Cleveland and Akron.
The race has troubled Democratic Party officials, who do not like to see two prominent local Democrats attacking each other and leaving an opening for a Republican to win in November. After all, this is far from a liberal district; Mr. Clinton and George Bush each won 43 percent of the vote in 1992. Usually, national political officials steer clear of local primary fights to avoid ending up with a Republican or an embittered Democrat in office.
"Family squabbles are always difficult," said Donald R. Sweitzer, the political director of the Democratic National Committee who has close ties to labor in this state.
Mr. Walsh of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. said Mr. Mann's trade vote was "the last nail in the coffin" because unions were also distressed by his other positions, like his opposition to the Clinton budget and to extending unemployment benefits.
 
'Public and Private Pledges'
 Clarence Frost, the regional director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said his group would mobilize its 27,000 members in the district and bring in help from around the country to run telephone banks, send out mailings and aid in other efforts. "We're going to do everything we can, that's legal, for Senator Bowen," he said.
Vice President Gore insisted that he had no qualms about being the headliner for two fund-raising receptions here on Sunday, which the Mann campaign said raised more than $100,000. "It's not touchy for me at all," he said in an interview. "Both the President and I made public and private pledges to defend those who cast a vote of conscience and were attacked for it. I'm going to honor the pledge."
But in his introduction of the Vice President, Mr. Mann was still keeping his distance. "My vote is not owned by the President," he declared. "My vote is not owned by the Vice President. My vote is not owned by any member of the labor community or any member of the business community. My vote is owned by myself."
When it was his turn at the microphone, Mr. Gore stopped short of endorsing Mr. Mann, or even putting his arm around his shoulder. He was as effusive as he could be in speaking about someone who often bucks the White House. "I can tell you from personal experience and with some regret that David does not vote the way we want him to every time a vote comes up," Mr. Gore said as the crowd burst into applause. "But the American people want a member of Congress to exercise independent judgment."
The Vice President seemed stumped, however, as he searched for common ground on issues other than the trade accord. He ended up devoting several minutes to thanking Mr. Mann for supporting the Brady bill, which imposes a five-day waiting period on handgun purchases. But with the overwhelming backing of House Democrats, that vote was hardly a close call.
Besides Mr. Gore's rescue attempt, Mr. Mann is reaping other rewards for voting for the trade agreement. Before the $125-a-person public event, four local business leaders held a smaller $1,000-a-person reception with the Vice President. In an invitation, the organizers -- the heads of Procter & Gamble, PNC Bank Ohio, the Kroger Company, and Federated Department Stores -- noted that Mr. Mann "stood with us" in voting for the accord. Mr. Mann said that would help offset the $150,000 in labor contributions he expected to lose to Mr. Bowen, a state senator for more than two decades.
Mr. Bowen contends that the corporate support for Mr. Mann demonstrates that the incumbent, a former Mayor of Cincinnati, has turned on working Democrats. :
"I've known David a long time," said Mr. Bowen, 65, explaining why he decided to run. "I supported him. But people who have supported him are shocked and appalled. It's despicable what he has done." The trade vote was but one of his concerns, said Mr. Bowen. sporting a button on his lapel that said, "I'm proud to be union." He added: "The economic stimulus would have meant substantial money for the city of Cincinnati. Then there was his vote against the extension of unemployment compensation. The budget reconciliation bill. His voting record is not representing the district."
Mr. Mann, who is 54, said he had no apologies for favoring the trade accord or any of his stands. He responds to the attacks by declaring himself to be independent-minded. Five times in his announcement speech, Mr. Mann noted that he had acted under "the instructions" of his constituents and no one else.
"All I had to do was vote 'no' on Nafta and none of this would have happened to me," he said in an interview. "My pollster, my consultant, my wife -- every political consultant I have -- told me to vote 'no.' But I'm very proud of my Nafta vote, and I haven't lost a minute's sleep on it. If there's a district in the country that could benefit from Nafta, it's the First District of Ohio."

Mr. Mann's opponent, State Senator Bill Bowen, has won the strong support of labor. On Sunday, Mr. Bowen campaigned in Cincinnati. (Photographs by Mark Lyons for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: SMALL LATIN LANDS FEELING SLIGHTED

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14

 BODY:
Several Central American and Caribbean countries are angrily accusing the Clinton Administration of favoring the big over the small because it is backing the Colombian candidate, rather than his Costa Rican rival, as the next Secretary General of the Organization of American States.
Officials from Costa Rica, whose Foreign Minister, Bernd Niehaus, is running for the post, complain that the United States is being insensitive in favoring the candidate from a large country -- President Cesar Gaviria of Colombia -- when no one from Central America or the Caribbean has headed the O.A.S. since it was founded in 1948. 
 "The O.A.S. shouldn't be in the hands of just the big countries," said Luis Guardia, the Costa Rican representative to the O.A.S., who complained that "when the United States throws its weight behind a candidate that makes a big difference."
 
Defending an Endorsement
 Some Costa Rican officials feel double-crossed, saying that Washington had originally signaled it would back the candidate endorsed by Central America and the Caribbean: Mr. Niehaus.
Harriet C. Babbitt, the United States representative to the O.A.S., vigorously denied the accusations, insisting that in backing President Gaviria for a five-year term, it is merely supporting the candidate it thinks is best.
"We responded to Gaviria because we think he is a very strong candidate," Ms. Babbitt said. "He has been very forward looking in building democratic institutions in a country where it was sometimes dangerous to do so. He's been very forward-looking on economic reform in Colombia and on economic integration in the hemisphere."
It looked as if Mr. Niehaus would win easily until Mr. Gaviria entered the race last month, evidently looking for a job when he steps down as President in August.
Larry Birns, director of the Council on Hemispheric Affairs, a Washington research group, said Washington's embrace of Mr. Gaviria has unnecessarily created bad blood with other countries. "The U.S. has created few friends but an enormous number of enemies in how it has handled this," Mr. Birns said. "If anything, Costa Rica is in better shape than Colombia in terms of economic reform and human rights."
Costa Rican officials say that Mr. Niehaus has the votes to win the election, which will take place on March 27 in Washington.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Amarillo Promises a Profit For American Air's Service

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
After Amarillo, Tex., learned last month that it would be losing jet service from a major airline, it decided to fight the same fate that had befallen dozens of other small cities. So late last week, city officials put up $1 million to guarantee American Airlines a profit on flights between Amarillo and Dallas.
The arrangement is not unique, but is part of an emerging trend among cities to go on the offensive to retain or expand jet service, which can be crucial in attracting new business and maintaining a strong local economy. With several of the largest carriers shrinking capacity and shedding unprofitable routes, many airlines have told city officials in places like like Sioux City, Iowa, and Bismarck, N.D., that they would replace jets with smaller, propeller planes. 
 "The competition among communities to attract new air services is intense and at levels never seen before," said Morris R. Garfinkle, an aviation lawyer in Washington who represented Nashville last year in its unsuccessful bid to establish an air route between Nashville and London.
Other cities that subsidize service from major airlines include Allentown, Pa., and Traverse City, Mich., as well as some ski resorts like Vail, Colo. In all of these cases, the cities worked out their own, often creative terms to convince major airlines not to replace jets with smaller, propeller-driven aircraft.
In Amarillo, city officials said they would give American Airlines up to $1 million during the first six months of service to cover any losses it incurs from serving the market.
American has been using Fokker 100 jets with 96 seats to fly three flights a day to Dallas, and it planned to replace them entirely with turboprop planes from its American Eagle commuter division.
But with the pledge from Amarillo, it will replace the jets with slightly larger planes this summer and drop a few trips on the turboprops to increase ridership on the jet flights.
Southwest Airlines also provides service to Dallas, but Amarillo officials said that service from a carrier like American with a hub airport was a crucial asset in attracting new business to the city. Amarillo also lost last year the only two daily jet flights offered by Delta Air Lines.
The money that would be paid to American by Amarillo would be drawn from funds collected from a city sales tax for economic development programs.
"We see this as an important promotional element to our economic development program," said Michael Bourn, executive director of the Amarillo Economic Development Corporation.
Trans World Airlines and the Lehigh-Northampton Airport Authority in Allentown, Pa. struck a similar agreement last year. To fight the loss of passengers to airports in Newark and Philadelphia, the airport had been searching for ways to add to the roughly 30 daily jet flights it offered last year. So it promised T.W.A. minimum revenues on one-stop flights to St. Louis and Orlando, Fla.
The city terminated the agreement to subsidize trips to Orlando on March 1, but the service to St. Louis continues. Because the city is guaranteeing revenue, it also sets the ticket prices on the two daily flights to St. Louis through Baltimore.
George F. Doughty, executive director of the Lehigh-Northampton Airport Authority, said the city had cut prices drastically on the route.

HEADLINE: House Panel to Vote on a Health Plan Alternative That Doesn't Raise Deficit

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14

 BODY:
A Congressional subcommittee plans to begin voting on Tuesday on an alternative to President Clinton's health care plan that seeks to guarantee health insurance coverage for all Americans without increasing the Federal budget deficit.
The bill, sponsored by Representative Pete Stark, Democrat of California, would require employers to pay at least 80 percent of the insurance premiums for their workers. It would, in addition, impose a new payroll tax on all employers. 
 The votes in the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health, headed by Mr. Stark, would be the first test of comprehensive health care legislation in the 103d Congress.
Mr. Stark's bill would require employers to pay a premium of 96 cents an hour for each adult worker. This is a substantial amount when compared with the minimum wage, now $4.25 an hour. But Mr. Stark said he was confident that his bill would not hurt any businesses, just as he said there was no harm from recent increases in the minimum wage.
 
$2,500-a-Year Premium
 Mr. Stark's bill envisions a premium of $2,500 a year for each adult. The employer would pay $2,000, and the worker $500. These premiums included the cost of insurance for children, if any. Low-income and unemployed people could enroll in a new program, known as Part C of Medicare.
New budget estimates, prepared by the subcommittee staff with the Congressional Budget Office, show that Mr. Stark's bill would spend $35 billion a year on new Medicare benefits, including coverage of prescription drugs. These costs would be offset in part by $23 billion a year of Medicare savings, achieved mainly through stringent new cost controls.
Mr. Stark's bill also calls for $151 billion a year in subsidies and other assistance to low-income people, to help them pay private health insurance premiums. These costs would be partly offset by $139 billion in savings under Medicaid, the existing program for low-income people.
To make up the difference between the new benefits and savings, Mr. Stark proposes $24 billion a year in new revenues, including a payroll tax of 0.8 percent.
These proposals, taken together, would neither increase nor decrease the deficit, Mr. Stark said. The payroll tax was set at the level needed to make sure there would be no net effect on the deficit.
Mr. Stark developed his proposal to avoid several sections of Mr. Clinton's plan that he said lacked support, most notably its requirement that most Americans enroll in regional insurance purchasing cooperatives, or alliances.
The White House has not offered a detailed critique of Mr. Stark's bill, but Administration officials say they are pleased to see Congress take up such legislation after months of hearings and delays. Mr. Stark's bill incorporates many features of the Clinton bill, but to date no committee has taken action on the President's original proposal.
Mr. Stark said he hoped his subcommittee would finish work on the bill by early next week, clearing the way for action by the full Ways and Means Committee. Mr. Stark's panel will consider many amendments, but Mr. Stark said he would insist that every proposed amendment pay for itself, so the deficit would not increase.
Representative Stark's bill would also gradually reduce the growth of Medicare, the Federal insurance program for the elderly and disabled, so it increases no more than the gross domestic product in the year 2000.
Under current law, the Congressional Budget Office says, the Government will spend $290 billion on Medicare in that year. While Mr. Stark's bill would reduce this sum by $23 billion, Mr. Clinton's bill would cut the growth of Medicare more sharply, reducing outlays by a total of $37 billion in 2000.
Mr. Clinton's bill would provide subsidies to employers -- $58 billion in the year 2000 -- to help them buy insurance for workers. Mr. Stark's bill provides no such subsidies.
But he said today that he would be willing to subsidize "incipient and small businesses with low-wage employees and low profits," provided there was a way to pay for the subsidies. One way, he said, might be to collect additional money from "profitable businesses and rich people."
Republicans are expected to propose eliminating much of the Government regulation, some of the cost controls and the employer mandate in Mr. Stark's bill. In an interview, Representative Bill Thomas of California, the ranking Republican on the subcommittee, said: "I don't expect to win. But if we can defeat some things in a bipartisan way, that's progress. In the process of voting on specific amendments, we can create a universe of bipartisan options."
Representative Sam Gibbons, Democrat of Florida, a senior member of the Ways and Means Committee, predicted that the subcommittee would approve a version of Mr. Stark's bill. He said the bill was a practical way to achieve universal health insurance coverage.
Mr. Gibbons said that Mr. Stark's bill was better than Mr. Clinton's proposal because it would allow people to buy insurance through regional purchasing cooperatives, but did not require the use of such alliances. "That's a good move," Mr. Gibbons said, referring to the proposal for voluntary alliances.

HEADLINE: Clinton Offers Job Prescriptions

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 14

 BODY:
President Clinton called on Japan to stimulate its economy more and on Europe to lower its interest rates, as he opened the jobs conference of the world's leading industrial nations today. But he also used the occasion to call for putting a lid on American interest rates.
"I think that since there's no inflation in the economy, interest rates should not continue to go up," he said. 
 Mr. Clinton's remarks were part of an address to the finance, labor and economic ministers from the Group of Seven major industrial democracies about how they must now cooperate in facing their common problem -- unemployment -- in much the way they have cooperated for the last 50 years to defeat Communism, to stand up against Iraqi aggression and to expand the global trading system.
 
Call for a New Outlook
 In effect, Mr. Clinton called on the group to transform itself from an exclusive club of statesmen who gather annually to talk about issues of high finance and high diplomacy into a global employment agency focused on "the challenge of creating a high-wage, high-growth society in mature industrial countries."
The President said that to produce jobs, each of the Group of Seven nations -- Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Canada, Japan and the United States -- must do more to retrain workers, improve productivity and promote a more flexible job market.
Unless the Governments do more to stimulate their economies, he said, there will not be enough jobs, and workers will not be willing to accept the costs they are being asked to bear, whether fewer benefits, relocation or retraining.
"The United States should continue to bring its deficit down," the President said. "Japan should increase domestic demand through more government spending and tax cuts so that its consumers will import more from the rest of the world. And Europe should continue to work for lower interest rates, so that these three things together can spark a new round of worldwide growth, which will create more economic activity and more jobs in European countries, in the United States and Canada and in Japan."
Just in case Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, did not get the subtle hint, Mr. Clinton told reporters when asked if rising interest rates in the United States were choking the recovery: "I don't think we can say that for sure yet. They were bound to go up some after the fourth-quarter growth figure came in. We had the highest growth rate in a decade. But I think that since there's no inflation in the economy, interest rates should not continue to go up. If they moderate and tail off, then we'll be all right."
The yield on 30-year Treasury bonds, which was below 6 percent in October, has hit almost 7 percent recently, following the Federal Reserve's move to raise short-term rates by a quarter of a percentage point last month. The Bundesbank of Germany, which sets the rate trends in Europe, has been lowering its rates but at a pace that Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen says is far too slow to lift Europe out of recession.
American officials have been equally unimpressed with the one-year, $140 billion tax cut introduced in Japan last month, an action Washington believes is too small and too short in duration to produce much of a jump in spending by Japan's consumers. Still, Japanese officials here signaled no willingness to expand their stimulus program.
The German officials at the conference also steadfastly refrained from giving any sign that their nation would follow Mr. Clinton's advice.
The Administration clearly wants to use this job conference to step up the pressure on its partners to stimulate their economies more, and Mr. Clinton more or less told the delegates that the United States had done its part in getting its deficit down and it was now time for them to do more.
The President did get some backing. Italy's Treasury Minister, Piero Barucci, for one, echoed Mr. Clinton's view. He said the Europeans could afford to bring down interest rates even more "without worrying too much about its effects on inflation, which seems anyway under control."
Pascal Lamy, an official representing the European Union, said: "We have no problem with what the President assigned as the main tasks for Japan and Europe. The problem is meeting the conditions for that. We cannot go faster. That is the debate among ourselves. We've been creating the conditions little by little for interest rates to go down."
 
Past 'Embarrassments' Recalled
 Pointing to the foreign officials gathered at the Fox Theater here, Mr. Clinton said: "My fellow Americans, you need to know that they used to meet once a year, and every time they met, for 10 years, the G-7 nations passed a resolution that was, frankly, embarrassing to the United States.
"They did it in very polite language, but they essentially said the global economy cannot grow if America continues to expand its budget deficit. By cutting the deficit by $500 billion, we now have a deficit that is a smaller percentage of our annual income than all but one of our other G-7 nations represented here today. So we are moving in the right direction."
The clear impression Mr. Clinton left was that Germany and Japan still were not in step, or as the President sought to remind them: "One lesson is clear: there is no rich country on earth that can expand its own job base and its incomes unless there is global economic growth."
It may not have been an accident that the Detroit Symphony Orchestra introduced Mr. Clinton by playing not only "Hail to the Chief," but also the "William Tell" Overture -- more widely known as the theme music to "The Lone Ranger."
Besides the President's speech, seminars on unemployment policy were conducted by Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairwoman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers; Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and Mr. Bentsen. One theme for all of them was that the industrial nations must oppose a growing school of thought that views improvements in productivity and technology as dangerous for countries seeking to create and maintain jobs.
The Americans say that while technology may be "job displacing" and force people to learn new skills, it ultimately is not "job replacing," in the sense of shrinking the overall job market.
"We have to restore confidence in people that if they do acquire the skills they need and help their countries move forward, they'll be rewarded not punished," Mr. Clinton said.

HEADLINE: Never Tiring of Talking About Work

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 14

 BODY:
Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich stepped into an elevator with half a dozen fidgety aides and fiddled with the pin on his lapel.
'Hideous!" he concluded as a thousand unseen gears whisked him to the top of the city's towering Renaissance Center. "Lavender and yellow? It must be the flag of some obscure Slavic country." 
 He spun the lavender side to the top. "Last night at dinner some of the ministers had the yellow side up. Some had it down. We couldn't decide what it meant."
 
Enthusiasm for Problems
 So it goes. Talking, not deciding, is the theme of the two-day Group of Seven jobs conference. And Mr. Reich, who is still very much an unreconstituted academic who seems to revel in problems as much as in the policies that grow from them, stepped off the elevator and into a new round of problems, one of which was that he got so distracted talking that he was late for his own staff meeting.
Though his aides have been quick to deny that the jobs conference is Robert Reich's turn in the spotlight, it is a hard notion to ignore. Assigned to a post that has been routinely undervalued by Republican administrations, Mr. Reich is at the center of the Clinton Administration's effort to rethink some basics of social policy, from unemployment benefits to worker retraining to the linkages between welfare and health care.
Now, with unemployment and other jobs issues topping the agendas of many advanced nations, he finds himself center stage in a play he might as well have written. He hardly troubles to conceal the thrill.
"One of the subtexts of this meeting is that for years and years the G-7 has been primarily about finance, about macroeconomics," he said. "It has been financial ministers and central bankers and of course heads of state talking about policy. But issues of jobs, their quantity and quality have become so much at the center of politics in every nation that the labor ministers and others are now playing a larger role."
 
A Focus on Jobs Training
 The first sessions of the conference only underscored that point. "We spent a lot of time talking about training," he said. "And there was a unanimity that we all have got to do a better job in lifelong learning."
Here, in this city of declining hope and gritty determination, the Labor Secretary is in his metier. Sounding the alarm on stagnant social programs and calling for "a whole new way" to approach everything from high school studies to transitions from one job to another, he has rushed from meeting to meeting, squeezing time when he can to take his message to the news media and then pounding at it again and again in private sessions with his peers.
His hand, or at least his advice, seems everywhere behind this conference. He flew to Detroit on Air Force One on Sunday and then went with President Clinton to Focus Hope, a jobs retraining program that he has been showering with praise for months. His distinctive bearded face and quick grin have been on every network news report for days. And his message, if not his distinct style of delivery, was at the core of the President's statements at his formal opening address today.
Having hammered at these themes month by month since his move from Cambridge, Mass., where he taught at Harvard University, to Washington, the Labor Secretary now has more than a score of foreign ministers and about 1,000 reporters in his line of sight. And he is not missing a chance to chant his chant about retraining, retooling American industry and reorienting the approach to joblessness so that workers will not languish on unemployment insurance for months before anyone realizes that their old jobs will not reappear.
 
Plenty in Common
 And here, he is hearing that chant from France to Japan. "The whole point is to share ideas, to share problems," he said. "We need to realize that we really have a lot in common."
Running late this morning for a breakfast with President Clinton and the foreign officials, Mr. Reich paused with one foot aimed toward the coffee urns and the other toward a tape recorder. As aides nudged and quietly cajoled, he spoke at length about a conversation he had with a British official about the long-term unemployed.
Explaining that a British program corroborated his own theories about quickly identifying workers unlikely to return to their old jobs, Mr. Reich leaned forward with enthusiasm. "That's what we've been saying," he said. "But here's the empirical evidence. That's what this meeting is all about."
The issues have driven him since childhood. His family moved from one economically hard-hit city to another as factories closed and businesses contracted, and he lived through the economic convulsions that he would later analyze. That experience, he said over breakfast last month, shaped his notions of economics and of job security. It also shaped his politics.
Now, it may be shaping his social standing, too. When someone pointed out how rarely American financial and labor secretaries have met and worked together, President Clinton's economics adviser, Robert E. Rubin, suggested that the Detroit meeting could be "a socially uplifting thing."
Robert Reich laughed with everyone else. But then asked -- twice -- "For whom?"

HEADLINE: Giuliani Wants Welfare Recipients to Work

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that his administration is considering requiring at least 10,000 people receiving welfare payments to perform jobs like cleaning streets, filling potholes or scrubbing graffiti in exchange for their payments.
Speaking at a news conference in City Hall, the Mayor said the plan is "in the idea stage," adding that it is one of a number of methods being considered to compel able-bodied welfare recipients to go to work. 
 Under the proposal being considered, some people receiving Home Relief Welfare grants would be required to work in jobs in the sanitation, parks or transportation departments. The idea was discussed earlier in the day at a City Council hearing in which John S. Dyson, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, testified that Mr. Giuliani had directed him to come up with such an initiative.
Mr. Dyson said the target of 10,000 recipients "seemed to be a realistic estimate of what the various departments could absorb." He also said that the figure was based on studies indicating that 30 percent of the people on home relief were classified as able-bodied.
He added that the Giuliani administration planned to have the program in place by the summer and that Mr. Giuliani was eager to expand the number of workers over time.
About 221,000 people in New York City receive Home Relief Welfare grants, which are given to poor people who are single or married or to couples with children. Half of the cost of administering the program -- about $700 million -- comes from the state, with the balance provided by the city. Typically, a single home-welfare relief recipient would receive $400 a month while an average couple with one child would receive $700 a month.
As a condition of accepting the payments, recipients are required to do one of several assignments, ranging from searching for a job to being assigned to work for a nonprofit agency. Some counties in the state require recipients to perform street-cleaning jobs, state officials said. In New York City, the Parks Department employs about 900 home-relief recipients, who perform a number of maintenance and clerical tasks.
 
Aiming for 10%

Over all, about 14,000 Home Relief recipients in the city already work for their benefits. In addition, a small proportion of mothers with school-age children who receive Federal welfare benefits are required to enroll in training courses.
Mr. Dyson said that it remained unclear how many hours a week the welfare recipients would be required to work, saying that many details had not yet been decided. But he said that the Giuliani administration was considering requiring recipients to work the number of hours that would cover the amount of their welfare payments, calculated on a basis of what they would receive if they were earning the minimum wage. He said that, when Medicaid and food stamp allocations were included, welfare recipients would most likely work a 40-hour week.
"If we get just 10 percent of these people to work, that would be 20,000 people," Mr. Dyson said, standing next to the Mayor at the news conference. "It would double the number of people doing this work and the city would really begin to look like somebody took care of it."
Putting welfare recipients to work was a major theme of Mr. Giuliani's campaign for mayor last year. But since his inauguration, he has been vague about how and under what conditions he would require some of the city's 1.1 million welfare recipients to work.
Last month, in fact, Mr. Giuliani sought to distance himself from a memorandum written by Mr. Dyson, suggesting that the city's welfare recipients be required to put on green uniforms and clean up highways and parks as a condition of receiving benefits. The Mayor said at the time that the memo -- which was written in mid-December and addressed to Peter J. Powers, Deputy Mayor for Operations -- did not reflect a clearly formed policy of the administration.
While Mr. Giuliani made clear yesterday that Mr. Dyson's proposal was one of several being discussed, he embraced the idea, saying "it would seem to me that is exactly the area where reform should start."
Mr. Dyson, too, made it clear that he had received the go-ahead from Mr. Giuliani to begin crafting a program to get welfare recipients to clean streets, parks and fill the city's estimated 275,000 potholes. "This would give them the experience, the satisfaction of contributing something back to society and make an overall contribution to the way the city looks," Mr. Dyson said.
But the proposal drew criticism from some experts, who complained that the such a program would not prepare people for long-term, full-time employment. Marion Nichols, a researcher for the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a Washington-based group that studies welfare issues, said: "The problem is people do not necessarily get jobs after these programs are completed. It can lead to a job, but it usually doesn't."
Some union officials, on the other hand, charged that the proposal would replace skilled, unionized workers with people compelled to work for low wages.
"It's a crazy idea," said Peter Scarlotos, president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association. Mr. Scarlotos complained that the idea comes at a time when the Giuliani administration has proposed cutting about 1,500 jobs from the city's sanitation workforce of 9,500 people.
"Mr. Dyson wants to put people who are currently employed out of work, so that unemployed persons can take their jobs," Mr. Scarlotos said. "This is just another attack on organized labor and we will not permit our contractual rights to be trampled on."
Norman Siegel, executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, said his organization opposed the idea because "we believe that individuals should not be coerced into employment and this is a form of government coercion." He said that "if the city wants to induce people to work, the city should make work sufficiently attractive."
"We favor the carrot, not the stick," he added.

HEADLINE: Budget Seen Cutting Services Or Increasing Property Taxes

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 14

 BODY:
The levels of state aid in Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's budget brought expressions of disappointment and dismay today from representatives of school boards and municipalities, who predicted that Mrs. Whitman's failure to increase aid will lead to higher property taxes or sharp service cuts.
At the same time, the union that represents 50,000 state and local workers said that Mrs. Whitman has unilaterally reneged on a deal to prefinance pension and cost-of-living increases that was worked out two years ago with the current Republican leaders of the Legislature, former Gov. Jim Florio and state and union actuaries. 
 Frank Belluscio, the spokesman for the New Jersey School Boards Association, said that maintaining current financing levels is a prescription for higher property taxes or program cuts because school districts face annual increases in teachers' salaries and transportation costs, inflation, new debt service and, often, enrollment increases in regular and special education.
 
Possibility of Larger Classes
 "A lot will depend on where the spending cap is for the coming year," he said. If the amount school budgets can increase is set between 5.5 percent and 6.5 percent, then spending will increase to those levels and require increased property taxes, he said. A lower cap could make it necessary to have larger classes and fewer teachers and programs.
"Some people may think you can cut back on the income tax and keep aid levels the same and not see an impact," he said. "Unfortunately, that's not the case."
Donald Testa, president of the New Jersey Education Association, said the Governor's budget proposals would hurt the quality of education and threaten school employees' pensions and retirees' health benefits.
"This budget signals distress for public school students across the state," Mr. Testa said. "It means we may be cheating our students out of the opportunity to compete in the global marketplace." The cuts, he said, could prevent poor urban districts from reaching financing equal to that in affluent suburban districts, as mandated by the New Jersey Supreme Court.
In addition, state employees and teachers will have to pay a 2 percent Social Security tax that had been paid by the state since 1959. The shift will save the state $98 million but "will amount to a pay cut of $400 to $1,000," said Alan Kaufman, the legislative and political coordinator for the Communications Workers of America, which represents state and local government workers.
Brian W. Clymer, the State Treasurer, said that the losses in state aid will be made up in large part by reducing pension costs paid by schools and towns and by passing along planned savings in state health care costs.
State resources being made available to municipalities and schools are virtually the same as last year, he said, with the exception of "a little haircut" of $14 million in desegregation aid -- which he said did not get used for that purpose -- that would no longer go to 26 school districts. Also, 24 large suburban towns will lose $8 million in density aid, which is used to help pay for municipal services.
The combination of reducing pension costs and returning some benefits from health care changes will mean that school districts will receive $4.02 billion in the fiscal year that starts July 1, compared with $4.04 billion in the current year, Mr. Clymer said. Municipalities will receive $1.54 billion, compared with $1.55 billion this year, he said.
Yet William G. Dressel Jr., assistant executive director of the New Jersey State League of Municipalities said there will have to be property tax increases, or cutbacks in municipal services -- or both.
"We haven't received an increase in four years, and we're already operating in a hole," he said.
 
A Certain Degree of Relief
 Mr. Dressel said, however, that he was relieved that there wasn't a larger cutback in state aid, given the size of the budget deficit Mrs. Whitman had to offset.
The final impact on local governments of the changes in aid and in pension and health benefit systems will have to await town-by-town reviews, Mr. Dressel said. "The devil is in the details," he said.
The decision to finance pension obligations on an annual basis instead of prefinancing their costs, said Mr. Kaufman of the Communications Workers of America, calls into question whether promised pension benefits will be available for future retirees.
Slowing cost-of-living payments and reducing the level of financing for employees' pensions until their salaries increase, he said, will result in "astronomical" pension costs in the future that the state may not be able to finance.
"If the Governor is changing the prefunding agreement without having talked to us, then that's not acceptable," Mr. Kaufman said.
The union will appeal to the legislative leaders to stand by their agreement with the union as they review Mrs. Whitman's budget, he said.

HEADLINE: Stocks Tumble In Mexico

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 14

 BODY:
Mexican stocks ended sharply weaker today, hit by uncertainty about the country's political future and heavy selling of Telefonos de Mexico.
The key IPC index of 36 leading shares ended at 2,429.88 after dropping 81.05 points, or 3.23 percent, the third-biggest fall this year. 
 "It was a massacre," said Alvaro de la Macorra, director of capital markets at the brokerage firm Probursa. "There was nothing to push the market higher. The fall went in line with the drop in Telmex in New York." The American depositary receipts, or A.D.R.'s, of Telmex in New York were down 3 1/4, to 62 1/4, in late trading.
Analysts said the market reacted negatively to the announcement of the Chiapas peace envoy, Manuel Camacho, Friday that he was leaving open the possibility that he would run for president in August.
The prospect of a Camacho presidency worries investors who wonder about his commitment to President Salinas's economic changes and how it would affect the 65-year reign of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party.
In the broad market, 98 issues traded, with declines topping advances, 62 to 11.

HEADLINE: Stocks Advance Slightly in Light Trading

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Stocks drifted up yesterday in light trading. Market professionals held back, awaiting inflation news today and tomorrow as the bond market again approached but then pulled back from long-term interest rates of 7 percent.
Companies related to the computer industry, whose share prices have generally risen recently, benefited from the small rally. Computer makers like I.B.M. and the Digital Equipment Corporation, semiconductor companies like Motorola and Intel, as well as software companies like Novell and Oracle, all saw their share prices rise. 
 There was little economic news yesterday to move markets. Trading was therefore light with 260.2 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange changing hands, the second-lowest volume since Feb. 4 when the Federal Reserve Board nudged up short-term interest rates a quarter- point. "It was a very, very quiet day," said Charles Lieberman, director of financial markets research at Chemical Securities.
Yesterday's volume compares with an average daily volume of more than 300 million shares since the Fed rate increase.
The Dow Jones industrial average seesawed widely yesterday, dropping as low as 3,856 shortly after 1 P.M. and then rising to as much as 3,871 shortly after 3 P.M., then dropping once again. The Dow settled at 3,862.98, up 0.28 point.
Since the Jan. 31 peak of 3,978.36, the Dow has fallen more than 115 points, or about 3 percent. Some market professionals believe the Dow is in for a price "correction" of 5 percent or more, or at least 200 points.
The broader Standard & Poor's 500 generally paralleled the blue-chip Dow and rose 0.95 point, to 467.39. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 3.60 points, to 792.80.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.48 point, to 259.01. Advancing stocks outnumbered declining stocks, 1,159 to 949. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 2.08 points, to 468.06.
The Federal Reserve is in a quandary. Both stock and bond market professionals are almost uniformly calling for the Fed to raise interest rates to fight inflation, yet there is little or no evidence of inflation so far. Inflation hurts the long-term value of bonds, thus depressing bond prices, and also raises the borrowing costs of corporations, thus hurting stock prices.
The Labor Department is scheduled to report the February Producer Price Index today.
Telefonos de Mexico's American depository receipts were the most actively traded stock yesterday at 5.6 million shares. Telmex dropped steadily from the beginning of the session, declining 3 1/4, to 62 1/4. One A.D.R. represents 20 ordinary shares.
Telmex stock, because it accounts for one-sixth of the Mexican stock exchange, is often used by portfolio managers as a proxy for Mexican stocks and is thus vulnerable whenever foreign investors become concerned about Mexico.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises Against Yen After Cellular Phone Deal

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen yesterday, after the United States and Japan reached a final agreement over the weekend on a trade dispute involving Japan's cellular telephone market.
It also inched higher against the German mark and several other European currencies. 
 The dollar began rising in overseas trading in reaction to the move by Japan in giving Motorola Inc. greater access to its cellular telephone market, and its surge continued in the United States.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 106.16 Japanese yen, up from 104.95 yen on Friday. It also rose to 1.6893 marks from 1.6842 marks.
The yen surged earlier this year amid worries that a trade war might erupt between the United States and Japan and that American officials would press for a stronger yen as a means of gaining leverage in the dispute.
But the yen's strength has waned recently amid signs that the trade tensions may be cooling off.
 
Bank Ratings in Review
 The yen suffered a further blow in late New York trading trade after the Standard & Poor's Corporation said it had placed the debt ratings of the Bank of Tokyo, the Mitsubishi Bank, the Sanwa Bank and the Sumitomo Bank under review for possible downgrading. The news reinforced worries about the dismal state of the Japanese economy.
The yen's retreat against the mark, however, was the bigger session surprise, said a Bank of Tokyo dealer, Belal Khan.
Mr. Khan said the Japanese currency's cross-rate slide "might be a signal that some of the strength the yen had accumulated is slowly being unwound."
Against the mark, the dollar opened slightly higher and then wandered in a very narrow range, with most dealers casting an eye toward tomorrow, when the Bundesbank will announce if and how much it is cutting its repurchase rate.
Traders are also looking to today's report on February producer prices for signs about inflation.
Gold prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for April delivery, the most active futures contract, gained $1.10, to $387.20 an ounce.
The British pound slipped to $1.4970 in New York, from $1.4999 on Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Friday's quotes, included: 1.4350 Swiss francs, up from 1.4225, 5.7410 French francs, up from 5.7305; $1.3601 (Canadian), down from $1.3619, and 1,671 Italian lire, up from 1,667.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of U.S. Securities Down in Quiet Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities sagged yesterday in very thin and quiet trading as investors and dealers nervously awaited the release of the first of February's key inflation reports today.
Traders said higher bond prices generated by last Friday's rally gave a few dealers, who did not bail out during the sharp declines earlier last week, the opportunity yesterday to sell before the release of the Producer Price Index today and the Feburary Consumer Price Index tomorrow. 
 Many traders and investors worry that the reports, even if they show only moderate increases in inflation, will still prompt more selling because of the uncertainity over when the Federal Reserve will move to raise short-term interest rates for the second time this year.
With the bond market so sensitized by the fear of inflation, it did not take long for trading to take a negative tone yesterday, analysts said. The Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta said that its survey of regional business activity in the Southeast found prices rising, both for raw materials and finished goods.
The February prices-paid index rose to 24.5, from 19.5 in January, while the February index for prices received for finished products rose to 15.8 from 12.1 in January. The bond- price declines after the Atlanta report only helped underscore the market's nervousness ahead of today's release of the producer price report.
The price of the 30-year bond in late trading was down 19/32 , to 919/32 , as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.95 percent, from 6.90 percent on Friday.
 
Focus of Other Data
 Other data the market will be focusing on this week include tomorrow's Consumer Price Index and Thursday's Philadelphia Federal Reserve survey of regional business activity, which many remember precipitated the "pre-emptive" increase in short-term rates last month by the Fed.
Yesterday the market opened to a Barron's article that suggested the Fed had intervened quietly last week to stem the rising long-bond yields, which had reached 7 percent in intraday trading on Friday. Traders said they were not sure if the bond market really believed the article, but prices were up in early trading.
Analysts at MMS International said they doubted the Fed would try to manipulate long rates or defend specific levels. The article was denied later in the morning by a New York Fed spokesman.
With few investors in the market and most on the sidelines, the moves were greatly exaggerated, analysts said. Matthew Alexy, a government trading strategist at CS First Boston, said, "It was real hard to fall in love with anything in this market ahead of the numbers."
Louis Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, said the market appeared to him to be worried that higher energy prices may put pressure on the index today. "But the market is likely to be forgiving if the strength is concentrated in the energy component," Mr. Crandall said.
He said that while the Producer Price Index was a measure of inflationary pressures, many market participants were also aware that the index was more volatile than the Consumer Price Index. "Therefore, strong numbers are less likely to be a surprise to the market," he said.
One reason the Producer Price Index can have less impact is that it does not include prices in the service sector of the economy. The consensus forecast is for an increase of four-tenths of 1 percent in the overall producer index, with a two-tenths of 1 percent rise in the so-called core index, which excludes volatile food and energy prices.
Elsewhere, the Treasury was busy selling $25.2 billion of three- and six-month bills at its regular weekly auction, with the average discount rate up over the previous week.
The average rate for the three-month bill was 3.57 percent, up from 3.52 percent last week and the highest since June 29, 1992, when it was 3.59 percent. For the six-month issue, the average rate was 3.85 percent, up from 3.75 percent last week and the highest rate since June 1, 1992, when it was 3.90 percent.

HEADLINE: Canada Weighs Job Incentives

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 14

 BODY:
Canada may offer tax incentives for companies to hire new workers and may tie unemployment insurance programs to job and skills training, Government officials said today.
Speaking to reporters at the start of the Group of Seven industrial nations jobs conference here, the Canadian Finance Minister, Paul Martin, said the Government must re-examine its tax code to encourage companies to increase employment. 
 "At the present, we have a situation under our tax system that at times of recession companies are encouraged to buy equipment and lay off people, and that's just counterproductive," he said.
"We've got to build in incentives to hire people and to train them. Obviously, the tax act is one way to do that."

HEADLINE: Sally Belfrage Dies; Writer Specializing In Memoirs Was 57

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Sally Belfrage, who wrote nonfiction books about life in an Indian ashram and about the civil rights movement in Mississippi in 1964, died yesterday at Middlesex Hospital in London. She was 57 and lived in London.
The cause was cancer, said her literary agent, Irene Skolnick. 
 Ms. Belfrage (pronounced BELL-fridge) spent a month studying under an Indian spiritual leader to gather material for "Flowers of Emptiness: Reflections on an Ashram" (1981). The book won her praise as an intelligent and humorous journalist and critic who ardently searched for the truth.
Her Mississippi memoir, "Freedom Summer" (1965), based on her experience as a civil rights volunteer, was lauded for freshness and forcefulness.
Her other books are "A Room in Moscow" (1959), about a sojourn in the Soviet Union and "Living With War: A Belfast Year" (1987). "Un-American Activities," a memoir of her adolescence, is to be published in June by HarperCollins.
 
Youth in Hollywood and London
 Ms. Belfrage was born in Hollywood, the daughter of Cedric Belfrage and Molly Castle, Britons who were then correspondents for London newspapers. In "Un-American Activities" she wrote, "My mother was a mere English eccentric, but my father was a Red and so in trouble all the time."
After her family moved east, she attended Bronx High School of Science, Hunter College and, after moving to London when she was 18, the London School of Economics. In 1957, she worked for the Foreign Languages Publishing House in Moscow.
Her 1965 marriage to Bernard Pomerance, who wrote the play "The Elephant Man," ended in divorce in 1976.
She is survived by a daughter, Eve Pomerance of London; a son, Moby Pomerance of Manhattan; a brother, Nicholas, of London, and a sister, Anne Zribi of Paris.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sally Belfrage (David Hobson, 1992)

HEADLINE: FOOTBALL;
It's the Latest Waive: Bargaining for Players

BYLINE: By FRANK LITSKY 

 BODY:
Everyone in pro football knew that the National Football League's new odd couple -- unrestricted free agency and a salary cap -- would create weird situations.
But weird enough for teams to shed players because they could not afford them? 
 That is just what happened to the Washington Redskins and the Miami Dolphins and it will probably happen to many more teams before the free-agency period for this year ends July 15.
When the Redskins signed outside linebacker Ken Harvey of the Phoenix Cardinals for $11 million over four years and moved him to the strong side, Carl Banks became superfluos and was waived. That move was logical because it saved the Redskins the $1.5 million they would have had to pay Banks this season.
Then the Redskins waived wide receiver Tim McGee, who was scheduled to earn $1.3 million this season. While McGee was not a world-beater last season -- 39 receptions for 500 yards and 3 touchdowns -- he was still serviceable. And the Redskins need receivers because Ricky Sanders seems ready to defect to the San Diego Chargers, Art Monk is aging and Desmond Howard has been an overpaid bust.
But Norv Turner, the Redskins' new coach, thinks the 36-year-old Monk may have another year left. Turner also thinks the Redskins can sign Michael Timpson of the New England Patriots for much less than the $2 million a year Timpson wants (the Giants and Jets like Timpson, too).
The Redskins, like many other teams, coveted the two prize free-agent receivers -- Tim Brown of the Los Angeles Raiders and Anthony Miller of the Chargers. Both are transition players, and Brown seems headed for the Denver Broncos. He signed an $11 million offer sheet last Friday with Denver. The Raiders have seven days to match it. Miller will probably command between $2.5 million and $3 million a year, more than the Redskins are likely to spend for him because of their salary-cap squeeze.
By shedding McGee, the Redskins gained extra money. They picked up more when Jeff Bostic, their tough, willing center and guard for 15 years, retired at age 35. They spent some of that money when they signed tight end Ethan Horton, an unrestricted free agent from the Raiders, for $2.5 million over two years.
The Dolphins made two moves involving strong safeties. First, they signed Michael Stewart, an unrestricted free agent from the Los Angeles Rams. Then they dropped the transition-player designation from Louis Oliver, making him an unrestricted free agent free to play anywhere.
Stewart signed a three-year contract for $2.8 million, including a $600,000 signing bonus. Although Oliver is probably a better player, his salary this year would have been at least $1,697,000. Now he must find another team because Miami could not afford him.
"There will be plenty of interest in him," said Oliver's agent, Drew Rosenhaus.
Eddie Jones, the Dolphins' general manager, said it was simple economics.
"It was clear Louis would command a high price," Jones said, "and we had to plan with the realization that Louis might not be here."
By signing one safety and freeing another, the Dolphins saved $800,000. So if they now sign another free agent for that much, they will in effect have traded Oliver for Stewart and that new player.
"That's what it's coming down to," said Harvey Greene, a Dolphins' spokesman. "If you sign this guy, you may have to give up that guy."
That dilemma has contributed to the tentative signing pace for the 368 unrestricted and 99 restricted free agents. With this go-where-you-want-to-go period almost four weeks old, only 23 free agents have changed teams and 14 others have re-signed with their old teams.
"We're taking a wait-and-see attitude," said Carl Peterson, the president of the Kansas City Chiefs. So far, his team has signed no one and lost no one.
"We want to see which teams will put themselves into oblivion and which have money left to get players when the music stops," he said. "A few players will be upset that they won't be able to get the money they thought they would, but we've all got to live under the cap. Some people -- clubs, players and agents -- haven't planned for it.
"If the draft were right now, a half-dozen teams wouldn't have the money to pay one player. Most teams don't have more than 30 or 33 players signed now. We have 53, and two or three other teams do, too. And 53 is not 80, and you want to take 80 players to camp. Some teams say they will take less than 80 to camp. Good luck."
