Correction Appended

SECTION: Section C; Page 22; Column 1; Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 955 words

HEADLINE: Music Notes

BYLINE: By Allan Kozinn 

 BODY:

Helping With a Hall
Many of New York City's small performing organizations have complained increasingly in recent years that high rental fees have driven them out of the main concert halls. Some have moved their concerts to churches and community centers, some have found smaller, less expensive halls, and some have cut back on their activities. But now Lincoln Center is addressing this complaint with a new program that will subsidize performances at Alice Tully Hall. 
 The program, called the Lincoln Center Community Arts Project, is starting a pilot project this season in which $40,000 is to be distributed to six to eight groups. Each will receive a $5,000 grant, enough to cover the $4,040 hall rental fee and help defray some of the stage labor costs. Lincoln Center is also providing free marketing services, technical assistance and advice.
The first beneficiaries are to be ensembles that have performed at the hall in the past but have drifted away. So far only one performance is scheduled, a free concert by the New York Chamber Ensemble on March 30. Lincoln Center is also discussing presentations with the Caribbean Cultural Center and the Chinese-American Arts Council. No other organizations have been selected yet, a Lincoln Center spokesman said.
This season's performing groups were chosen from among the organizations that responded to a survey of past renters. Next season, the plan is to increase the number of groups to 10 and to start a more formal selection process. Performing groups will submit proposals, and a jury of Lincoln Center officials and arts professionals will make the selections.
The project is being underwritten by a grant from the New York Community Trust, an organization that distributes private bequests. Lincoln Center is also seeking foundation grants.
 
Direct Education
 Orchestras terrified by the prospect of dwindling audiences have said for years that the root of the problem has been the virtual disappearance of music education from public schools. The St. Louis Symphony Society, which manages the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra, has just made an unusually direct move into the education world. It has agreed to merge with the St. Louis Conservatory and School for the Arts (known as CASA) to form a joint venture called the St. Louis Symphony Community Music School. The merger takes effect in August and the initial budget has not yet been settled.
The school has 3,000 students, from pre-schoolers to adults. Its programs include instrumental instruction in both classical music and jazz. The school also has four youth orchestras, which have fed into the St. Louis Symphony's youth ensemble. Some of the St. Louis Symphony musicians teach at the school, and the orchestra has for years had a concert series in the conservatory's 800-seat hall. The school has satellite programs in city schools, an outreach project that the new venture hopes to expand.
Other orchestras have educational outreach programs and maintain connections with nearby conservatories. But the St. Louis project seems to be the first case of a major American orchestra having a school under its administrative umbrella. Besides the orchestra, the youth orchestra and now the school, the society manages the St. Louis Symphony Chorus and Powell Symphony Hall, the orchestra's home.
"The merger offers us a forum for our educational goals," said James F. Mann, the orchestra's general manager. "We want very much to make a commitment to education, but very often we would come up with ideas only to find that CASA was already doing them. By avoiding a duplication of effort, we can work more effectively."
 
Hemidemisemiquavers
 *Matthew Epstein, the general director of the Welsh National Opera since 1991, has resigned, saying that the company's financial situation made it impossible for him to continue. In a cordial letter to Lord Davies of Llandinam, the chairman of the innovative company, Mr. Epstein attributed the company's financial situation to reduced government support, a decline in ticket sales because of both the recession and high prices, and an unsuccessful fund-raising drive. Mr. Epstein, who also heads a division at Columbia Artists Management, had completed plans for the company's seasons through 1996. He said he would help find a successor.
*Elektra Nonesuch Records has taken another step in cornering the market in the most popular modern composers. Having already established relationships with Steve Reich, John Adams and Philip Glass, in which the composers oversee recordings of their works, the label has just signed an exclusive agreement with Henryk Gorecki. The company has been lucky for the composer: its 1991 recording of Mr. Gorecki's Symphony No. 3, with David Zinman, Dawn Upshaw and the London Sinfonietta, was a surprise hit in 1992 and 1993. The label has also issued recordings of his "Lerchenmusik" and two string quartets. Under the agreement, Mr. Gorecki will supervise recordings of his Symphony No. 2, "Old Polish Music," "Good Night," "Kleines Requiem fur eine Polka," Beatus Vir, Miserere, Concerto-Cantata for Flute and Orchestra, Two Sacred Songs, "Songs of Joy and Rhythm" and a collection of choral works.
*The Philadelphia Orchestra has added two new conductors to its staff. Andre Raphel Smith, the assistant conductor of the St. Louis Symphony, is moving east to take up the same position in Philadelphia. And Luis Biava, the Philadelphia Orchestra's principal second violinist, will be acting assistant conductor while keeping his playing job. Beginning next season, both conductors will direct nonsubscription performances and children's concerts and will be on hand for last-minute substitutions.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 16, 1994, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A brief report in the Music Notes column yesterday about the appointment of two conductors by the Philadelphia Orchestra misstated one title. At the beginning of the 1994-95 season, Luis Biava is to become a conductor in residence, not an acting assistant conductor.

HEADLINE: Facing Big-City Problems, L.I. Suburbs Try to Adapt

SERIES: Tarnished Haven -- First of two articles

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: EAST ISLIP, L.I.

 BODY:
The Long Island suburbs, which pioneered a new and better way to live in postwar America, are struggling with problems they never expected to reach their door. They have become a bellwether for the nation's older suburbs, trying to adapt to an uncertain and threatening future.
The Island's fiercely local brand of self-government grew up to serve bedroom communities of a like-minded middle class, almost entirely white, pursuing the good life. 
 Now its governments and politicians are finding themselves ill-equipped to deal with economic malaise, racial divisions, spreading poverty, declining population, rising crime -- and unrelenting pressure on governments to accomplish more with less.
Long Island has been geared since World War II to accommodate a growing population. But between 1985 and 1990, according to the latest Census, more than 310,000 people left the area, most of them joining a vast exodus from the New York region. During the same period, only 235,000 people moved to Nassau or Suffolk Counties -- a net loss of more than 75,000 people.
In this unfamiliar era of scarcity, suburban politicians are being forced into the continual balancing, and playing off, of competing constituencies that is routine in the older cities.
Where should tax money go? To sustain the schools and parks that once defined the suburbs, or to pay for the health and social services and courts and the police now needed to cope with afflictions once confined to cities?
Nassau and Suffolk Counties, with a total population of 2.6 million, have the highest rate of AIDS of any suburban area. Infant mortality among black babies, at 18.8 per thousand, is worse than in the South Bronx. Welfare caseloads increased 45 percent between 1989 and 1992.
The Long Island suburbs came to life after World War II as a bedroom community. Yet today, thousands of homeless Long Islanders lack a regular place to sleep.
The difference between the Long Island of today and the Long Island of yesteryear is the difference between Kenneth Euring and his parents.
At 47 years of age, Mr. Euring is about as old as the postwar boom that transformed the potato fields of Long Island into the nation's first modern suburbs.
Back in 1956, when Mr. Euring's parents chose to move to East Islip from Queens, Suffolk County was a haven of quiet streets, good schools and abundant parks for children. Passers-by said "good morning" to friends and strangers alike. Doors went unbolted at night.
But the Long Island that fulfilled the elder Eurings' dream of a better life is long since gone.
Today Mr. Euring cannot name most of his neighbors, who increasingly include renters. Many of the manufacturing jobs that fueled the postwar expansion have evaporated. They seem certain to grow scarcer with the impending acquisition of Grumman by a larger aerospace manufacturer, a move widely expected to result in more layoffs.
Mr. Euring, laid off from Grumman after 24 years, now works at Home Depot for less than half his former salary. His wife works two jobs; the family shops at food warehouses and scrimps on gas. Worried about crime, Mr. Euring made sure his two teen-age daughters learned how to shoot a pistol.
 
'We're Going Down, Down'
 "You do what you have to do to survive," Mr. Euring said. "We're going down, down."
The troubles facing Long Island and other postwar suburbs -- which originally provided a refuge from urban crowding for returning G.I.'s -- are not as great as those of cities, but the suburbs' resources are usually much more limited. If one measure of a great city has traditionally been its ability to extend opportunity to all, America's suburbs have been judged by their success in tailoring services to those who can pay for them.
Some suburbs, like those around Minneapolis, have begun to form political coalitions with the urban core, rather than competing with them, said David Rusk, a consultant to urban and suburban governments and author of "Cities Without Suburbs."
Here on Long Island, the language of civic life is of "tough decisions" and "hard choices" that will ultimately determine whether Long Island can adapt to a new age.
 
Decline
Problems Migrate On National Scope
 According to Eric Alexander of the Nassau-Suffolk Coalition for the Homeless, 40,000 people were homeless on Long Island in 1992, two-thirds of them living in emergency shelters or doubling up with relatives, and the rest sleeping in vacant buildings, abandoned cars and doorways. The number has grown by a third since 1987, he said, but it has not dropped with signs of economic recovery.
Katherine S. Newman, a professor of anthropology at Columbia University, likens the downturn on Long Island and the California suburbs, regions that lived on military contracts, to the decline of Rust Belt cities and towns a decade or two ago.
"They were faced with exactly these kinds of problems," she said. "I think Long Island is in deep, deep trouble."
Kenneth T. Jackson, a professor of history at Columbia and author of "Crabgrass Frontier: The Suburbanization of the United States," agreed. "Suburbs increasingly represent the problems of society as a whole," he said. "They're not really refuges anymore."
 
Still, Enviable Advantages
 To be sure, the suburbs are not New York City. New York's welfare caseload alone, at 1.1 million, nearly equals the entire population of Nassau County. In New York City, one in seven residents is on welfare; on Long Island, one in 38.
And Long Island retains some enviable advantages. Median incomes in Nassau and Suffolk, measured in the 1990 Census before the full impact of the recession, were $60,619 and $53,247 -- among the highest in the country. Its better schools are among the nation's best.
But in notable ways, the Long Island created after the war is eroding. Home foreclosures on the Island, so low during the 1980's that Suffolk County stopped tracking them, increased more than 500 percent to 6,375 last year from 962 in 1988. The high cost of housing, utilities and taxes on Long Island is hurting residents and forcing commercial manufacturers to turn away as well. Since 1989, Long Island has lost more than 110,000 jobs.
 
Government
Local Walls Keep Solutions Out
 It is far from clear whether the Long Island that grew up in an earlier, less demanding era can handle the problems that have come with maturity. Its fragmented political system, rooted in local control, at times seems stymied in dealing with islandwide or countywide issues. And its residents and politicians must decide how to divide dwindling resources among a broader array of competing demands.
"As the populations move out, the urban problems move out as well," Professor Jackson said. "Suburbs are not so much a place as a process."
Nassau County, for example, maintains 70 public tennis courts -- a traditional suburban amenity, the sort of "quality of life" factor that helped attract people in the first place. But can the county continue to pay for such amenities while facing the need to cut financing to the Nassau County Medical Center, which provides health care for many of the county's poorer residents?
Older residents, burdened with huge property tax bills, have exerted increasing pressure to cut school costs. But will such cuts threaten the quality of education -- a traditional drawing card of young families to the suburbs? Indeed, between 1980 and 1990, the share of children on Long Island who left the public school system for private schools increased by a third, to 23 percent from 17 percent.
The Nassau County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, recently complained that state and Federal mandates claimed 70 percent of the budget. He said he would seek private owners for the county's geriatric center and health clinics, and for the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum. The county also plans to sell the Nassau County Medical Center in Hempstead or transfer it to private management.
 
Spending on Poor Is Rare
 Hugh A. Wilson, director of the suburban studies center at Adelphi University, says that while Nassau County will match Federal or state funds, "very, very rarely" will it go it alone in spending money on the problems of the poor.
"That's the consensus here," Mr. Wilson said. "People left those problems in the city, and they don't want them following them out here. And if they do, they don't want to recognize it. They deny it."
Another complicating factor is the high degree of local control in government, which originally assured homeowners of a say over any changes in their immediate surroundings. The result has been to create a total of 1,037 different taxing authorities on Long Island, covering everything from schools to water to sidewalks.
That, in turn, has helped drive local taxes to the highest levels in the country and made Long Island too expensive for many young couples.
In addition to driving up the cost of government, the high degree of local control strips county government on Long Island of the power to impose solutions to countywide problems on individual towns. General problems typically become political footballs, some of which eventually land in the least powerful communities.
 
No One Is Responsible
 "Because decision-making is so diffuse, there's a lack of accountability, and not the kind of follow-through to implement decisions, so the public doesn't know who to praise or who to blame," said Patrick J. Halpin, a Democrat who served as Suffolk County Executive from 1987 to 1991. "It's always easier for politicians to do nothing, but a region like Long Island will pay a heavy price for the inaction of local politicians."
But so sacrosanct is the concept of home rule that when Mr. Halpin appointed Dr. Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board, to head a tax-relief commission, the panel's 1992 recommendations for streamlining government drew barely a flutter of interest.
And local interests remain powerful. When Canon U.S.A. wanted to move its North American headquarters from Lake Success to a larger plant near the horse farms of Brookville two years ago, homeowners on the wealthy North Shore blocked the move, though it would have saved about 1,500 white-collar jobs.
And while business leaders complain that the lack of affordable housing is a major deterrent to expanding or relocating on Long Island, middle-income towns seldom feel moved to allow subsidized housing.
Dr. Koppelman and others ask whether mature suburbs can even replenish themselves.
 
Island Is Beyond Its Means
 "If you were to empty Long Island of its 2.7 million people and told them all they could come back tomorrow morning at 9 A.M.," Dr. Koppelman said, "the overwhelming majority wouldn't be able to afford to live here." That means not only a population stretched to its credit limit, but also a growing insecurity and fear of any change that could upset the precarious balance.
Opposition to subsidized housing on Long Island has been stubborn. Many of its postwar residents were G.I.'s buying tract houses with low-interest Veterans Administration loans. Today, many of those same people oppose subsidized housing, fearing that it will depress housing values and draw minorities to their communities, said James M. Morgo, director of the Long Island Housing Partnership, a nonprofit group that builds subsidized housing. When such houses are built, they usually appear in depressed areas unlikely to attract middle-class workers.
John O'Connell, director of the Nassau County Health and Welfare Council, calls this the "bar the door" syndrome. "It's a mentality that says, 'I've got mine, the hell with you,' " Mr. O'Connell said.
Mr. O'Connell sees a shift in the attitudes of suburbs like Long Island. Once, he said, "it was the best instincts in people that drew them to Long Island: clean water, space for kids, good schools."
"Over 30 years, that has changed into a negative karma," he said -- "into, 'Cut my taxes, because I don't see the common good any more.' "
 
The Future
 Broken Contract With the Young

The hard choices facing Long Island, to one extent or another, are the choices of suburbs everywhere. And at times they seem to suggest the end of the postwar dream of an ever better life with each new generation.
"The social contract that's supposed to bind generations is coming under tremendous strains," said Professor Newman of Columbia.
John Juliano, 61, a real-estate agent for Levittown Equities, says that those now shopping for homes are typically better educated and harder working than their parents, but cannot afford the homes their parents' generation is trying to sell. Mr. Juliano, who worked as a milkman when he moved to Levittown in 1960, says that couples who now buy Levittown homes are older, white-collar parents, both working full-time.
Ebba and William Lehmann have retired in the Plainedge home they bought 40 years ago, when their street was but a dirt road. They would not dream of moving off Long Island. But she acknowledged that Long Island was beyond the reach of their sons, who are 42 and 40.
"We had much easier lives than our parents," said Ms. Lehmann, who is 68 years old, "and I don't think our kids are going to have as easy a life as we did. They rent, and they can't afford to assume the responsibilities we assumed at younger ages."
 
Working Through High School
 Richard Wesley, who has taught social studies at Massapequa High School for 26 years, sees successes and struggles in his classroom. Some families still prosper. Mr. Wesley had no difficulty finding students for a summer trip to Europe. But at the same time, nearly all the seniors at Massapequa High work part-time.
"There are a lot of families being held together by the barest thread," he said.
Planners here hope Long Island's pool of educated, productive workers will attract new businesses, but the high costs of energy, housing and transportation -- 97 percent of the freight moves by truck over congested highways -- drive up production costs. The new equation leaves little room for yesterday's skilled, blue-collar workers.
"The kinds of jobs people are talking about creating are low-wage manufacturing jobs, assembly-line jobs," Professor Newman said. "Even in high-tech industries, the jobs are low-paying."
More disturbing, she said, many of those leaving the Island blame the declining quality of life. That is a stinging rejection for suburbs that once lured growing families with good schools and safe, open spaces.
"The quality of life is sending people away," said one 29-year old businessman, who spoke at Kennedy International Airport as he waited for the plane to New Mexico, where he plans to move his Farmingdale sporting goods business next year. He did not want to be identified because his companion, a banking executive and the mother of their child, has not told her employer she will be leaving.
"When you are paying a lot in taxes and the roads are choked up and the quality of life problems are still there, you ask yourself, why am I here?" he said.

HEADLINE: Michigan Votes School Finance Plan

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 15

 BODY:
Michigan voters today approved a constitutional amendment to raise the state sales tax and cigarette tax to replace property taxes as the means of supporting the state's schools.
With 88 percent of the statewide vote counted, the amendment had 70 percent of the vote. 
 The measure on the ballot required people to vote yes or no on the plan, which raises the state sales tax to 6 percent from 4 percent as of May 1 and triples the tax on a pack of cigarettes to 75 cents from 25 cents.
The proposal also slightly decreases Michigan's flat-rate income tax, from 4.6 percent to 4.4 percent and limits property assessment increases to the inflation rate or a maximum of 5 percent a year.
 
One Tax or Another
 Voters had little choice but to raise taxes one way or another. The Michigan Legislature abolished most of the traditional financing of schools based on property taxes last July, and the public schools would not have had sufficient funds to operate had not some new revenue source been tapped.
Had the proposal been defeated, the Legislature required that a backup plan automatically take effect, increasing the state income tax to finance schools. The backup plan would have partly compensated for the loss of property tax by boosting Michigan's flat-rate income tax to 6 percent from 4.6 percent and increasing the cigarette tax by 15 cents a pack.
The vote followed a costly and bitter political battle, which began last July when the Legislature stunned Michigan by voting to abolish $7 billion in property tax revenues.
That money had been the mainstay of public school financing in Michigan for years, and the lawmakers canceled it with nothing to replace it.
 
Voters Given Last Word
 Lawmakers in both parties said that action came as a desperation move to force the issue after years of debate over how to finance education in the nation's eighth-largest state. The state had endured several crises when voters refused to raise local property taxes and school districts had to close, and there was widespread agreement that the traditional method of relying mainly on local property tax revenues was outdated and unfair. But there was profound disagreement about how to replace it.
After months of wrangling, the legislature agreed in December on a compromise in which the voters would have the final say about raising the 4 percent state sales tax.
That triggered a bitter and costly battle, in which many political and opinion leaders campaigned for the sales tax and cigarette tax plan, while the main teachers' union and the tobacco companies fought it.
Governor John Engler, a Republican who was the proposal's leading supporter, said his plan was "good for the schools and good for the state." The Governor, a conservative Republican, is up for re-election in November, and his chief Democratic opponents concede that Mr. Engler's re-election chances will be enhanced by the proposal's success.
 
Likened to Rates in Other States
 Mr. Engler argued that raising Michigan's sales tax would merely bring it in line with the rates in many other states, while raising the income tax would tend to hurt the state's ability to attract new businesses, especially in economically troubled Detroit.
That logic appealed to Detroit Mayor Dennis Archer, a Democrat who last week broke with many in his party and endorsed Mr. Engler's plan.
The Michigan Education Association, which represents 97,000 teachers in the state, has been vehement in its opposition. "Funding remains extremely unstable," under the proposal, Julius Maddox, president of the teachers' union, said last week.
"The income tax, unlike a sales tax, represents a much more dependable source of revenue for the schools," he added.

SECTION: Section B; Page 9; Column 1; National Desk; Education Page

LENGTH: 1534 words

HEADLINE: Sometimes a Company Must Become a School To Be a Good Business

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CLARKSDALE, Miss.

 BODY:
Delta Wire hardly looks like much.
A windowless factory building in a small town in the lost back stretches of the mud-rich Delta, the company is an oasis of industry in a land of cotton crops and scrubby fields. With only 120 employees, it is small by city standards -- minuscule next to its top competitors -- a humble place, where the offices are uncarpeted and the attitude is unpretentious. 
 In the Delta, though, the company is a beacon, a place where wages are good and jobs are stable for employees who run advanced machinery to make, among other things, wire for radial tires. It is also part lesson and part cautionary tale: To do business in rural Mississippi, the Delta Wire Corporation first had to educate its work force. Often, that meant "1 plus 1 is 2," said George F. Walker, the company's founder and president.
"We had a great supply of human talent, but no education," Mr. Walker said, reminiscing about the company's beginning in 1978. "We had adults come here who literally could not write their name. And we had to say to them, 'Now you are going to learn to read a micrometer. And now you are going to learn how to do statistical process control on a computer.' I had to hold their hands. I had to hold my own hand. It was awesome."
Delta Wire is now winning awards from major tire manufacturers for the quality of its products.
 
Difficult Transition
 Though making the transition from school to work poses problems for young people from Los Angeles to Brooklyn, it is most difficult in places like the Mississippi Delta, a stretch of flood plain between the Mississippi and Yazoo Rivers with there is little industry, low educational standards and entrenched poverty. Marshall Smith, an Under Secretary of Education, said preparing students for work is equally daunting in much of the South as well as in Appalachia and on Indian reservations across the country.
When President Clinton talks of education programs that address changing business needs, it is easy to conjure up images of high school students in lab coats concentrating on their computers screens as they develop into the skilled work force of the future. In some places -- like South Carolina, whose former Governor, Richard W. Riley, is now the Education Secretary -- those kinds of programs are already happening as a result of business initiatives, local school experiments and private financing.
But in the Mississippi Delta and other chronically depressed and traditionally agricultural areas, the transition from field to factories is extremely slow. Here, it is not the nuances of new technology that students need to learn, though they would also benefit from that, but reading, writing and arithmetic.
 
Congress Gets Involved
 The Federal Government is offering help. Legislation passed by Congress in January and supported by Education Secretary Riley and Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich would provide about $300 million in seed money to help some states improve their math and science courses, cooperate with local businesses and help students learn the language and work skills they will need in a competitive economy. The legislation -- two separate bills from the House and Senate -- will soon go to a conference committee, where differences will be resolved.
Formal education has never been a big part of life in the Delta, where it was historically denied slaves and sharecroppers. Mississippi put such a low priority on education for so long that until Gov. William F. Winter threw his administration behind advances in the educational system in 1982, there was no mandatory attendance and no provision for kindergarten. Even now, high school graduates often read at a fourth-grade level and understand only rudimentary math, according to state education officials.
Those students who do excel often leave the region, draining it of talent, potential entrepreneurs and future teachers. The migration has also helped set in motion a cycle of despair for those who live in poverty in rural Mississippi, including 36 percent of the state's school-age children, most of whom are black. Only one state, Louisiana, ranks behind Mississippi in the rural poverty rate for children, according to a study released by the General Accounting Office last month.
Overcoming those problems will take time, money, energy and good will.
At the Shelby Die Casting Company, a few miles to the south in Shelby, the best intentions have run against wall after wall of frustration. In a search for new employees, the company gave 25 high school seniors an eighth-grade math and reading test last year. Only eight scored 86 percent or higher, said Lois B. McMurchy, the company's training coordinator.
"You cannot get literate people," she said. "Forget other skills."
Like Delta Wire, Shelby Die Casting tried to start a program to help workers gain minimum skills. It has had mixed results. The problems with the local schools are so intractable, Ms. McMurchy said, that the company is thinking of closing the plant in Shelby and expanding its operations in Fayette, Ala., where "a high school degree is a high school degree."
The chasm between the classroom and the working world made a passionate reformist of Governor Winter soon after he took office in 1980. That year he watched 900 potential jobs slip away when a Chicago-based electronics company halted plans to build in Mississippi. The Governor winced at the company's reason: the state did not have enough educated workers or good enough schools. Instead, the company opened its new branch in South Carolina, where Governor Riley had already embarked on educational changes.
In Mississippi over the last decade, a group of programs, initiatives and experiments has helped ease the transition from school to work.
Delta Wire's story is one with a happy ending: jobs that pay well. "People will stay in school if they see a light at the end of the tunnel," Mr. Walker said. His factory, for many, has been that light.
In some cases the starting point is in classrooms where teachers are taught how to teach. One state-backed program pays math teachers $45 a session to give up their Saturdays and attend crash courses on how to teach geometry, trigonometry and calculus. Each Saturday session covers two weeks of math courses, said W. Ray Cleere, the Commissioner of the Mississippi Institutions of Higher Learning. Though basic, the training is crucial, he says. "We're just not quite ready for the wonderful world of computers," he said.
Down the road, in Itta Bena, a program called Career Beginnings offers mentors, introductions to the local community colleges, some practical training and a pool of volunteers to urge students on.
Run by Robert Moore, the director of the Mississippi Valley State University's Center for Economic Development, it helps 90 students each year to stay in school and plan for the future. That is precious few students out of the general population, but Mr. Moore shrugs at the question of size and says: "That's what we can handle. We hardly have a budget. At least it is a start."
Though the program does not help teen-agers train for specific jobs, it has placed almost 90 percent of its participants in two- or four-year college programs and prepares them for the workplace in everything from attitude to options.
 
Leaving for a Better Life
 Carolyn Sell, a 21-year-old junior at Mississippi State, was one of Career Beginnings' first students. Though she had a child while in high school, her mentor encouraged her to keep up with her studies. Now, when she finishes college, she will be the first person in her family to do so. She plans to work in Chicago, Georgia or Texas. But her departure, she hopes, will at least lead to something better than her mother's job, cutting catfish strips for the minimum wage.
"No one answer is enough," Mr. Cleere said. "Some people just need encouragement. Others need remedial work. We've got to work at all levels. We can't just wait until the next first grade gets to high school."
That fact has been all too clear to Janice Goree, who has coordinated Career Beginnings programs throughout the state.
"The Clinton program seems to open the door for addressing a number of problems," Ms. Goree said. "But some of our problems are relatively basic. We have kids who have never seen an elevator before. They are just not ready to go on to a business environment."
Driving his car in the gathering dark of the Delta, C. Thompson Wacaster, looked ahead with a mix of frustration and hope. "Right now there's just an incredible mishmash of stuff out there," said Mr. Wacaster, vice president for educational programs and research at the Phil Hardin Foundation, a nonprofit organization that channels money into educational programs and research. "There are tens and tens of programs just in Mississippi. Some work. Some don't. But we all share a sense of urgency."
Slapping the steering wheel and pointing with pride at a landscape awash in a vermilion and lavender sunset, he said Mississippi no longer has a choice. "We have so far to go," he said. "Communities are dying. They are dying right before our very eyes."

HEADLINE: EASTERN UTILITIES IN UNUSUAL PACT: A SMOG TRADEOFF

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
In the first deal of its kind across state lines, a New Jersey utility will clean up its generating stations so boilers in Connecticut can emit more smog-producing chemicals.
The deal will bring a small reduction in pollution regionwide and probably will cut smog in New York and New Jersey, but that is not the main goal. 
 It will change where the pollutants are emitted and at what time of year, reducing the damage, and it will help companies meet the reductions required by the Clean Air Act of 1990 at the lowest possible cost, proponents say.
The Clean Air Act authorized what amounts to a free market in pollution. It encouraged businesses to reduce their emissions more than the law required by giving them the right to sell their surplus savings -- in effect, rights to pollute -- to companies that found it cheaper to buy the rights than to cut their emissions themselves.
 
Trades for Sulfur Dioxide
 Similar trades have been made with sulfur dioxide, the chemical that causes acid rain, drawing criticism from environmentalists. But trades in smog-producing nitrogen oxides are not expected to attract such criticisms, in part because the deals must be approved by environmental officials in the states where the extra pollutants will be emitted.
In fact, a New Jersey utility is able to sell pollution rights to a Connecticut company because Connecticut is downwind of it. Fewer emissions in New Jersey benefit both New Jersey and New York without creating more smog in Connecticut.
The New Jersey utility, Public Service Electric and Gas, said today that it would cut its emissions of nitrogen oxides during the next five years by 2,400 more tons than the law requires, probably by adjusting a coal-fired plant in Jersey City, among other steps.
Northeast Utilities, which serves most of Connecticut and parts of Massachusetts and New Hampshire, will buy the rights to emit 500 of those tons, and pass them along to customers, like small factories or hospitals that operate boilers, that would find it extremely costly to comply with the Clean Air Act.
Both utilities called the sale an experiment, intended to create a market in which the rights to emit hundreds of thousands of tons will be traded every year.
"It's a toe in the water, a kick at the tires," said Eric B. Svenson, manager of regulatory support at Public Service Electric and Gas, based in Newark. The purpose, he said, is to encourage other potential buyers and sellers to come forward, "to encourage people to make reductions where it is most cost-effective to do so."
Trading in pollution credits, which is favored by economists and some environmentalists, seeks to achieve emissions reductions at the minimum cost by allowing the cleanup to be made wherever it is cheapest.
For example, to reduce nitrogen oxides by one ton it might be cheaper to have a utility switch a generating station from coal to natural gas than to have a university install a scrubbing system on a small boiler used to provide steam heat on campus. The utility estimates it can create the reduction for $1,000 a ton, and the university can buy it, avoiding its own cost, which could be hundreds of dollars a ton higher.
An auto body shop, which might have to build a painting booth to control emissions from wet paint, might face a cost of $15,000 or $20,000 to cut a ton of smog-producing chemicals, experts said.
The price for pollution credits, advocates hope, will be determined by trading among hundreds of buyers and sellers.
 
A Pollution Broker
 In this case, the pollution credits will be bought by a broker, the Clean Air Action Corporation of Tulsa, Okla., at cost. Clean Air Action will sell them at market price. The allowances Northeast Utilities is buying will be priced at whatever the market price eventually turns out to be.
Ben G. Henneke, president of Clean Air Action, said his company would retire 10 percent of the credits, so total nitrogen oxide output would be 140 tons lower over five years. In addition, he said, Clean Air Action will pay Public Service Electric and Gas to create the allowances in summer, when smog is a problem. But buyers would use them all year long. So some pollution would be shifted into winter, when smog is not an issue.
Since smog drifts across state lines, some states can achieve clean air only if upwind neighbors clean up. Mr. Henneke said that the only way states like Connecticut and Massachusetts could meet the standards, without "invading New Jersey or Pennsylvania," would be to approve deals like this with upwind states.
 
Directional Correctness
 Unlike trading in the right to emit chemicals that cause acid rain, the nitrogen-oxide trades are supposed to be "directionally correct." That means that the sellers must generally be upwind of the buyers. The effect of the trades, then, is to have the pollutants emitted further downwind, with fewer people to be exposed to ozone before it blows out to sea.
Officials not directly involved in the trade praised it. Langdon Marsh, Acting Commissioner of Environmental Conservation in New York, said that if companies in Connecticut bought 500 tons from New Jersey, that was 500 tons that did not blow over New York. Pointing to the interstate nature of smog, he noted that one of the monitoring stations that the Federal Environmental Protection Agency uses to determine New York's compliance is in Stratford, Conn.
 
A Regional Market
 At the Northeast States for Coordinated Air Use Management, an organization of top air pollution officials from New England, New York and New Jersey, Michael Bradley, the executive director, said, "It could be a catalyst to a regional market that would help quite substantially in reducing the ozone levels in the summertime."
Finding a way for the small companies to comply at low cost is essential, said William L. Stillinger, Northeast Utilities' director of technology and transmission planning, "if we're going to try to avoid businesses' shutting down and moving out of area."
The agreement in the announcement is simply a memorandum of understanding, partly because neither New Jersey nor Connecticut has completed writing the regulations under which such trades could take place.

HEADLINE: Employer-Paid Health Care Backed by House Panel, 6-5

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15

 BODY:
President Clinton won a victory today as a Congressional subcommittee voted 6 to 5 to support his proposal to require all employers to help buy health insurance for their employees.
In the year's first vote on health care, Democrats on the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health defeated a Republican proposal to eliminate the mandate on employers from any comprehensive bill intended to guarantee health insurance for all Americans. 
 Today's action, the first vote on such legislation in the 103d Congress, was not decisive. At least four other committees will vote on similar legislation. At this stage, any health care bill is a work in progress, whose provisions may be dropped, replaced or amended later in the legislative process.
The health subcommittee is often described as somewhat more liberal than the full House or the Senate, so today's close vote suggests that the struggle over the employer mandate will continue.
 
Daggers Are Flying
 The employer mandate is a central element of President Clinton's health plan and of the alternative proposed by Representative Pete Stark, the California Democrat who heads the subcommittee. Mr. Clinton and many other Democrats maintain that there is no feasible way to achieve universal coverage except by requiring employers to pay for most of the cost.
One Democrat, Representative Michael A. Andrews of Texas, joined the four Republicans on the subcommittee in opposing the employer mandate. The proposal to eliminate that part of the bill was offered by Representative Fred Grandy, Republican of Iowa, who said it was "a fundamental dividing line" between Democrats and Republicans. All six votes for the employer mandate were cast by Democrats.
Representative John Lewis, Democrat of Georgia, said Mr. Grandy's proposal was "a dagger in the heart of the bill," because it would eliminate the means to achieve and pay for universal coverage.
But Representative Bill Thomas of California, the ranking Republican on the subcommittee, retorted that the employer mandate was "a dagger at the heart of small business."
Moreover, Mr. Thomas asserted, "This is the mother of all entitlements, cradle-to-grave health insurance, paid for by business."
 
Threat of Veto
 Mr. Stark, a California Democrat, said President Clinton would veto the bill without an employer mandate. Mr. Stark, like Mr. Clinton, wants to require employers to pay at least 80 percent of health insurance premiums for workers. Under Mr. Stark's bill, as under the President's, all Americans would be entitled to a standard package of health benefits.
By identical votes of 6 to 5, the subcommittee today rejected several other Republican proposals. One, offered by Representative Jim McCrery, Republican of Louisiana, would have set a limit on tax breaks available to employers and employees who provide or receive health benefits exceeding those in the standard package.
Under current law, there is no limit on the tax deductions that employers may take for the cost of employee health benefits, and the insurance coverage is not counted as income for employees. Mr. McCrery would have limited such tax breaks to the amounts needed to pay for an average-cost insurance plan in a given region.
 
'Competitive Discipline'
 Mr. Andrews praised the proposal to limit tax breaks, saying it would "impose a new competitive discipline," forcing employers and employees to pay more attention to the costs and benefits of various insurance plans.
But Representative Sander M. Levin, Democrat of Michigan, opposed the idea of a tax cap, saying it would increase taxes for "hundreds of thousands of middle-income families" who now have benefits that exceed the minimum under Mr. Stark's bill.
Representative Jim McDermott, Democrat of Washington, said that aerospace workers in his district had given up pay raises to secure good health benefits. "Why should we force people to give up benefits that they fought for and that make up a good health care system?" he asked.
Many large employers now offer health benefits more generous than the minimum package described by Mr. Stark. He would require such employers to continue providing those additional benefits for at least five years.
By a vote of 6 to 5, the subcommittee rejected a Republican proposal to eliminate the five-year requirement.
 
Family Coverage
 Representative Nancy L. Johnson, a Connecticut Republican who wanted to eliminate the requirement, said: "This is an issue of equity among employers. Some employers have voluntarily provided generous health insurance for their workers. This would, in effect, penalize them for that."
But Mr. Stark said the five-year requirement was needed "to protect otherwise defenseless workers from employers who might see this bill as an opportunity to cut costs."
Mr. Stark's bill, as originally proposed, would have required employers to pay 80 percent of the premiums for their employees and the workers' children, but would not have required employers to contribute to the cost of coverage for spouses.
By a 6-to-4 vote, the subcommittee decided to require employers to pay 80 percent of the cost of "family coverage," including insurance for spouses if employees wanted it. Representative Gerald D. Kleczka, Democrat of Wisconsin, who offered this amendment, acknowledged that it would expand the employer mandate, making it more objectionable to Republicans and many small businesses.
Under Mr. Stark's original proposal, insurance coverage for a family might have been split in strange ways. A worker, for example, might get coverage through an employer, while the nonworking spouse would enroll in a new public program, to be known as Part C of Medicare.
Employers with more than 100 employees would generally have to offer private insurance under Mr. Stark's bill. Smaller companies could buy private coverage or could enroll employees in the new Medicare program.
Mr. McDermott, who favors a "single payer" program of national health insurance financed by the Government, offered an amendment that would let all Americans enroll in the proposed Part C of Medicare. Under his proposal, employers of any size could have bought coverage for their workers through the new Medicare program. The amendment failed on a tie vote, 5 to 5.
The bill being devised by the subcommittee is a mix of private and public health insurance. Mrs. Johnson said, "This mishmash is going to put the squeeze on businesses and industries that have got to grow" in a strong economy. "This plan will force some people in my district to go out of business," she predicted.
But Representative Benjamin L. Cardin, Democrat of Maryland, said, "There is no historical justification" for predicting such loss of jobs.
"When we pass legislation to expand the social safety net," he said, "it raises everyone's standard of living."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains on New Talk Of a German Rate Cut Soon

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Widening speculation that Germany might cut interest rates this week pushed the dollar higher yesterday against the mark and other European currencies.
Some traders said the German central bank would reduce rates at its meeting tomorrow in an effort to stimulate the economy. 
 Others mentioned the possibility of a cut in the key discount rate, which is now at 5.25 percent. Others say that the other key rate, the Lombard rate governing overnight lending, now at 6.75 percent, is likelier to come down.
Lower German interest rates generally affect the dollar favorably, as traders sell lower-yielding, mark-based investments.
In late New York trading, the dollar climbed to 1.6973 marks, from 1.6893 marks on Monday.
 
Statement by Kantor
 The dollar, however, slipped against the Japanese yen on a bleak American assessment of trade relations with Japan. The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, told a Congressional panel that economic ties with Japan were in "serious disrepair."
Currency dealers said the remark undermined hopes that the agreement last weekend to open the Tokyo-Nagoya cellular-telephone market to foreign makers would lead to an overall easing of trade tension.
"People listening to Kantor may have felt he was a little combative and that the trade war isn't quite over," said Andrew Gonzalez, a trader at the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank.
Before Mr. Kantor's statement, the dollar had reached an intraday high of 106.60 yen, spurred in part by the Federal Reserve Board's report that industrial output rose four-tenths of 1 percent in February, higher than expected. But in late trading, the dollar fell to 106.10 yen, from 106.16 yen on Monday.
Gold rose in New York after slipping in Europe. On the Commodity Exchange, the April gold contract gained 40 cents, to $387.60 an ounce.
The British pound slid to $1.4906 in New York, from $1.4970 on Monday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Monday's quotes, included: 1.4440 Swiss francs, up from 1.4350, 5.7725 French francs, up from 5.7410; $1.3637 (Canadian), up from $1.3601, and 1,673 Italian lire, up from 1,671.

HEADLINE: Philip Morris Tops List of Lobbying Spenders in New York

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 15

 BODY:
Philip Morris, fighting off a number of stringent anti-smoking measures, was last year's biggest spender on efforts to lobby members of the New York State Legislature, followed by a state teachers' group and New York City, according to a report released today.
In all, 1,142 organizations, from private corporations to public authorities, paid a record $38.5 million last year for lobbying efforts to influence state legislation, an 11 percent increase over 1992, the annual report from the New York Temporary State Commission on Lobbying said. 
 It was the 14th consecutive year of increased spending on lobbyists, who try to sway legislators in private meetings, mailings, dinners and receptions on behalf of clients. Groups spent a total of $22.1 million five years ago and only $5.7 million in 1978.
Philip Morris, which was not even among the top ten spenders in 1992, nearly tripled what it paid for lobbyists last year to a total of $623,637. The company hired seven private and two in-house lobbyists as the Legislature considered an increase in the cigarette excise tax and sweeping restrictions on smoking and tobacco advertising.
Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis, Democrat of Manhattan and the Legislature's chief sponsor of anti-smoking legislation, said the company's effort had mixed results. He said it was influential in reducing a proposed increase in the excise tax, which is now 56 cents a pack, and helped knock off two contentious measures in an anti-smoking bill.
But he said that the bill, which now would impose restrictions on smoking in schools, passed the Assembly last Monday and that the state in general is considered to have some of the nation's toughest laws against smoking.
"This is a very sophisticated industry, probably with more on the line than any other industry we deal with," Mr. Grannis said. "They are clearly battling against all reasonable odds. But their profits are so great that they justify the expenditures of these large sums of money."
Karen Daragon, a spokeswoman for Philip Morris, said the lobbying efforts were to insure that the company's voice was heard in Albany.
"We've been doing what we have always been doing, which is supporting issues which are important to our 11,000 employees and numerous consumers throughout the state," she said. "Certainly every other major business in the state is doing the same thing."
 
Familiar Faces
 Aside from Philip Morris, the list of top 10 spenders on lobbyists was virtually the same as last year. The second-highest spender was the New York State United Teachers, which spent $586,352 last year and was at the top of the list for 1992. The City of New York, which runs its own lobbying office in Albany, kept its spot as the third-highest spender, at $457,410.
The vast majority of the money spent on lobbyists represented the salaries of the state's 1,832 registered lobbyists and the cost of courting legislators in receptions, so-called "lobbying days," in the Capitol and at dinners and lunches.
Milton Mollen, the lobbying commission's chairman and a former New York City Deputy Mayor, said the amount of lobbying money in the report represented only about half of the total actually spent on lobbyists. Now lobbyists are only required to report efforts to influence pending legislation and rate-setting.
Not included, Mr. Mollen said, are lobbyists' efforts to encourage a legislator to introduce a bill -- or to prevent its introduction -- or when an organization seeks a state contract. The commission is seeking seven changes to expand the definition of lobbying and to increase the commission's reach. Four of the proposals are included in Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's package of proposed bills this year.
Besides their lobbying efforts, of course, many interest groups also spend thousands of dollars for campaign contributions to legislators.
Though Mr. Mollen speculated that the recession has in part driven the rise in reliance on lobbyists, Robert Malito, a lobbyist with Davidoff & Malito, said the issue is the increasing complexity of governmental regulations.

HEADLINE: Pentagon Turning Plowshares Into Swords

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
The press to develop an electric car has become a holy quest for environmentalists, who seek an antidote for smog, traffic noise and the nation's reliance on oil. But lately, this peacenik technology has found an unlikely patron: the Pentagon, which sees battlefield uses for electric-vehicle systems.
Although some environmentalists express misgivings about the Pentagon's patronage, in the last few months the military has been dispensing money to various civilian electric-car ventures, including a Georgia company at work on a computer-controlled battery charger; a Connecticut maker of fuel cells, and a Massachusetts company that has been converting gasoline cars to battery power and now wants to design an electric vehicle. 
 Where environmentalists see opportunities for quiet traffic and clean air, military strategists see the makings of scout vehicles that slip almost silently over enemy terrain and armored personnel carriers that have no exhaust pipes and so cannot be spotted by infrared detectors.
"At night, they can't see you, they can't hear you, they don't know you're there," said Maj. Richard C. Cope, a marine who is leading the military's charge into electric-vehicle research.
Major Cope is a project manager for the Pentagon's Advanced Research Projects Agency, or ARPA. (During the cold war it was called the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, widely known as Darpa.) Without fanfare ARPA has become one of the main sources of money for various technological pieces of the electric car, including electrochemical batteries; batteries powered by spinning flywheels; new types of charging systems; electronic controllers, and various other components.
From the beginning of 1993 to the end of 1995 ARPA expects to spend $68 million, with private industry adding more, for research into electric and hybrid vehicles.
This technology transfer can make for strange partners. Environmentalists tend to be "the same people who in the 1960's were protesting a war," said Sheila Lynch, who heads the Northeast Alternative Vehicle Consortium. But in peacetime, she said, if a big civilian project needs Government help, there are advantages to working with the military.
"No one can expedite a project faster than the Defense Department," she said, "because they have a battle attitude."
The warriors return the compliment. In many areas, Major Cope said, "the commercial guys are so far ahead of us" that he said he was happy to let private industry concentrate on components for the electric car-pool crowd.
"We can take the same motors, the same controllers, and put them in a Humvee," Major Cope said, using the military abbreviation for the "high-mobility multipurpose vehicle" that has replaced the jeep.
 
Quiet Military Patrons
 Little wonder, then, that the military has quietly become the main research patron for dozens of small civilian projects in important electric-vehicle technologies.
For example, $300,000 from ARPA helped Electronic Power Technology of Norcross, Ga., develop a computer-controlled battery charger. Last month at the Atlanta Motor Speedway, the battery charger helped set a world record for distance traveled by an electric vehicle in 24 hours. While the company hopes its charger will lead to electric "filling stations" for battery-powered cars, the Pentagon is thinking about electric fueling depots for a future Desert Storm.
Even as the spinoff of military technology into civilian products seems to be going the way of the fallout shelter, a pronounced trend has developed in the opposite direction -- from civilian workshop to military lab -- and it already has a name.
 
Process Is Called 'Spin-On'
 "They call it 'spin-on,' " said one Government scientist, Dr. Roger W. Werne of the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California, long a leading weapons laboratory that is now lining up joint, nonmilitary projects with private industry.
Meanwhile, the Army's Construction Engineering Research Laboratory in Champaign, Ill., is spending $18 million for a dozen fuel cells from the ONSI Corporation of South Windsor, Conn. The devices combine hydrogen and oxygen to make electricity, with water as a byproduct.
The Pentagon is installing one at Vandenberg Air Force Base in California to provide electricity for instruments that track missiles. Base commanders see fuel cells as one way to help comply with California's increasingly strict air-quality laws. Quiet and reliable, such cells could also provide electrical power for remote bases. On the civilian side, such fuel cells are being used for experimental pollution-free buses.
ARPA sponsors six regional consortiums, including the one headed by Ms. Lynch, that are made up of equipment manufacturers, electric utilities, government agencies and other groups interested in electric cars. Financing through these consortiums has made possible projects like the electric car.
Solectria Inc. of Wilmington, Mass., is at work on such a design, which may cost $1.3 million. ARPA is paying half. In such cases, funding that amounts to crumbs by military standards is whole loaves for struggling civilian enterprises.
Some environmentalists are wary, even if resigned to the trend. "It troubles me that any of our resources should be used for the purposes of preparing widespread destruction," said Barry Commoner, the director of the Center for the Biology of Natural Systems, at Queens College, part of the City University of New York. But if scientists and engineers avoided any work that had military uses, he said, "that would stop you from working on almost anything."
The military, in turn, sees little strategic danger of a battery-powered truck's falling into the wrong hands.
"Thinking of how potential adversaries of United States would be able to use this stuff militarily against us, the world has changed," said Lennie Siegel, director of the Pacific Studies Center, a public interest information center in Mountain View, Calif. "There is no one, who if you gave them a few key secrets, would become an adversary of the United States."
Indeed, there are important electric technologies that the military would love to see American private industry develop before anyone else in the world. Major Cope of ARPA cited energy storage, which could be mechanical, as in a flywheel, or electrochemical, as in a battery. The armed forces -- which in the past helped create photovoltaic cells that convert sunlight into electricity -- are interested in power-storage devices that might have scores of uses, including the operation of communications equipment in remote areas.
 
Power Flow a Goal
 Another goal is better and cheaper electronic components that can control the flow of power, permitting rapid start-up and shutdown.
Military scientists also expect better electrical storage and control to allow development of exotic weapons -- like magnetic shields that could be briefly switched on to bend the course of incoming rounds, deflecting them from their targets.
Or brief bursts of large amounts of power might be used to fire rounds from a gun at speeds of up to 7 kilometers a second, instead of the 1.5 kilometers a second that a conventional gun achieves, Major Cope said.
Another Federal source of money for civilian research and development is the Commerce Department's National Institute of Standards and Technology, but its budget of less than $200 million this year is not even half what ARPA receives.
The military agenda worries some environmentalists, like Richard E. Sclove, a technology policy specialist at the Loka Institute, an association of scholars and environmental activists in Amherst, Mass. "Why not go directly for the civilian technologies you want," he said, "when everyone is hoping for peace dividends, when there is some prospect of global demilitarization?"
Gregory A. Bischak, executive director of the National Commission for Economic Conversion and Disarmament, a nonprofit group in Washington, contends that channeling funds through the Pentagon can give civilian research and development a military bias.
"Every year the National Science Foundation has a long list of eligible and eminently qualified projects that are not funded, or underfunded," he said, as does the National Institutes of Health. But because they have no obvious potential military benefit, he said, they are not financed.
But most advocates of electric cars are happy to have the money, whatever the source and the motives.

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
A Meeting Fit for Detroit's Contrasts

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 15 Alas, Motor City.

 BODY:
Detroit has never been known as the Paris of the Midwest. Even at the best of times it was more of a monument to the oily, smoke-belching, spark-flying spirit of American competition than a natural home to the cultural subtleties of opera, architecture and fine art or a natural host to the worldly and elite. Hard hit now by streamlining in the automobile industry, by high crime and unemployment, it struggled to put its best face forward this week as host to the two-day jobs conference of the Group of Seven industrial nations. 
 "Ah, yes," sighed a visiting Frenchman late Sunday. "Detroit. I like it. Wonderful architecture. All this glass. But then," he shrugged and gave what the French call a moue, a slight pursing of the lips coupled with a disconsolate shrug of the shoulders, "the rest, it's like Pakistan."
While doing a radio interview this morning from his room on the 67th floor of the immense glass mountain that is the Renaissance Center, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich answered the question -- Why Detroit? -- with a wave of his hand toward the gray, still-icy Detroit River and the gray, gutted reaches of the once prosperous city just beyond.
Detroit, he said, was a fitting host to the Group of Seven conference, because it epitomizes the problems being discussed.
Several hours later, James Desler, an assistant to Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, chatted with Mr. Reich's press liaison, Mary Meagher. "You know," he said, stretching his arms lazily and gazing out across the river toward a low gray skyline on the far bank, "Detroit is actually quite pretty in the sunshine."
"Jim," corrected Ms. Meagher. "You are looking at Windsor. That's Canada."
Even the city's public relations materials could not completely avoid hinting of Detroit's problems. A brochure suggesting investment in the city has photographs taken in dim light and it hawks, among other attributes, a system set up to inventory vacant land and buildings, of which there is an unwelcome surplus.
On Monday, as visiting foreign ministers were chauffeured from the Fox Theater, where President Clinton gave his opening address, to Cobo Hall, where the conference ended this afternoon, they rolled, sirens blaring, down streets swept clean for their visit but filled with boarded-up storefronts and closed businesses with steel grates over the windows.
A delegate from Germany complained that when he went to look for a small gift for his wife he found the downtown weirdly empty and the Renaissance Center filled with Burger Kings and Taco Bells but few stores he cared to wander into.

 
 
High Tech Awes and Irritates
 Backstage, among the dozens of government workers who helped pull the conference together, there were several mild complaints. "Talk about a productivity conference," one man said. "Well, the computers they set up here all have Minesweeper and Solitaire on them. So here's this conference about increasing productivity, and the volunteers and staff are playing computer games."
He added that there had been such a proliferation of cellular telephones and walkie-talkies that "we have people standing around talking to each other on the phone who are, like, 20 feet away from each other."
"I think it's the information highway on overload, the information autobahn," he continued.
Another government worker used a quiet moment to send a fax to California to inquire about a conference scheduled for later this month. Within seconds, a response slid into the incoming basket.
"Wow!" she said. "This is incredible! If only the government could work like this."
Asked to elaborate, she gasped and said: "No, no, no, no. I'm a government worker. They'll fire me. But look, I mean this is really something. It's just what everyone has been saying, that the private sector is lean and mean. It's competitive. That's what we need. But the government, I can't imagine it. Oh, God. Don't quote me."

 
 
No Bonanza for Cab Drivers

At the ersatz public park set up inside Cobo Hall, where the trees were as plastic as the kites lodged coyly in their branches, police officers, government staff members and the members of the news media mingled all day over hot dogs, barbecue beef, bagels, egg sandwiches, baked beans, macaroni and half a dozen other classics of American cuisine. But the fake hot dogs used in one display were made in Italy. And the water served was Swedish. "Hmm. Not so good for a city trying to get back to 'Made in America,' " said Eric Andrus, a staff member of the United States Information Agency who helped coordinate news media arrangements.
Outside, where the trees were real and the sirens blared as ministers and secretaries moved around, taxi drivers groused that the jobs conference was making their lives more difficult.
On Thursday, Mayor Dennis W. Archer called the city's taxi drivers to a meeting in Cobo Hall. "He asked us to sell the city," said Gary McJennett, a 27-year-old driver who said he was banned from selling ice cream during the Pope's visit several years ago and has now been been forced from his usual taxi stand.
"Thursday afternoon they get us all together and tell us to really help out," he said. "Then they sold us out. I was at my place and some cop comes up and says, 'Get these blanking cabs out of here and don't come back until the G-7 is gone.' So, great. I can go up and down Woodward and pick up people going to the crack houses. But I'd rather make my money taking people back and forth to the airport."

 
 
Scenery Almost Steals Show
 Even the conference highlight had its distractions. When President Clinton made his welcoming address, he stood in a floodlight, center stage, in the 5,000-seat Fox Theater. Built in 1927 and refurbished by the owners of the Little Caesars pizza chain in 1988, it is, depending upon one's perspective, either a monument to the city's past glory or an homage to monumentally bad taste.
Usually home to music concerts, rock revivals and theatrical extravaganzas, the theater made a stunning, quite distracting, backdrop to the President's remarks. While Mr. Clinton spoke of jobs, international finance and changing economies, many an eye wandered across the gilt decorations crowding the walls and ceilings. Kitsch in the way that only America can be kitsch, gold and red and brilliant, even in the half light from the stage, the walls flaunted a wild gathering of lions, tigers, birds, cherubs and bare-breasted Shivas, who couldn't quite handle the lotus position and so crossed their feet rather awkwardly at the ankles.
High above the President, a huge elephant's head, gold with ivory tusks and a huge rhinestone-studded crown, kept a careful watch.
As the speech ended, a nattily dressed British representative headed out. Asked his opinion of the hall, he nodded and nodded and then gave that most British of responses: "Mmmmmmm. Yes. The theater."
Then he was gone, a figure vanishing in Motor City.

HEADLINE: Accent Is on Education as Global Jobs Talks End

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 15

 BODY:
Government officials from the United States and other leading industrial nations agreed today that the only way to create more good jobs in the face of rapid technological change was to upgrade education, particularly for those who are least skilled.
The final statement, read by Lloyd Bentsen, Secretary of the Treasury, at the close of the two-day international jobs seminar stressed this, along with more familiar themes, such as the importance of not adopting protectionist policies to guard shrinking job markets and of stimulating economies to insure growth. 
 The conference here was attended by finance, labor and economics ministers from France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Canada, Britain and the United States.
But the newest theme, and the one that was highlighted in the final statement, was how to get new jobs and preserve existing ones at a time when technology is making some jobs obsolete as quickly as it is producing new ones. Unless that issue is dealt with, many ministers said, workers in their countries will increasingly see technological innovation as an enemy and not a friend.
There was a consensus among the officials here that the rapid changes in technology, from robotics to the information highway, were revolutionizing the workplace to a degree most of them had not quite caught up with in their government programs. The result, particularly in Europe and the United States, has been a widening wage gap between skilled and unskilled workers, with more and more of the unskilled being out of work or poorly paid because of their low education levels.
While economists have remarked on this phenomenon for some time, the conference was the first time it was addressed as a global problem by Group of Seven policy makers.
Why is this problem more critical now than before? The ministers contended that the pace of technological change and the rate at which it was affecting the workplace had speeded up, with more educated workers benefiting, while more routine workers are being displaced.
For instance, a new set of computer-operated machine tools creates jobs for those with the appropriate education, like highly skilled engineers, designers and operators. But it may remove jobs for those trained to do only the manual, assembly-line work that can now be performed by those machines.
The same is true for advances in word processing, which have made routine typing and secretarial jobs less in demand, but have increased the demand for those who know how both to type and to operate specialized software.
 
'Lifelong Learning'
 "The cycles of innovation become shorter and shorter," said Norbert Blum, Germany's Minister of Labor and Social Affairs. "Therefore, we have lifelong learning. I think it is a false belief that well-trained and qualified people are not endangered by unemployment. In all our jobs we have to be very flexible, and we should be ready to retrain at any time. Retraining is the duty of management."
Indeed, if there was one thing that all the ministers here agreed upon, said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the chairwoman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, it was that the only way out of this predicament was improved education for all sectors of the population, so that the skill gap and the wage gap between the most educated segments of the population and the least educated would be narrowed.
She and Secretary of Labor Robert B. Reich said educational needs would be taken into account by the Clinton Administration as it devised its programs to aid people in moving from welfare to work, from one job to another and from school to work. Both of them also stressed the critical importance of getting the private sector in the United States to invest more in education, as the Germans and Japanese have done.
 
A Call for Changes
 "The income of the unskilled is falling in absolute and relative terms," Ms. Tyson said, "and that suggests that the only long-term solution, given the technological changes, is targeting programs on the unskilled, and revamping education and training with regard to the unskilled."
American officials said there were things to emulate in the German system, which features apprenticeship programs and the placing of young people from high school into skilled jobs.
The only Group of Seven country that has managed to balance higher education, advancing technology, improved productivity and low unemployment is Japan, American officials said. But even the spokesman for Japan's delegation, Seiichi Kondo, said that Japan, which has a long tradition of lifetime employment and a private industry that invests more than any other in education, was beginning to worry about how long it could keep its aging work force fully employed. The system that worked in the past "may not necessarily be the vehicle" for the future, Mr. Kondo said.
 
Some Crucial Differences

 
 In Japan, most college and high school graduates seem to leave school with skills that are complementary to the demands of a highly technologically advanced marketplace, American officials say. In the United States, only those with university degrees, or some specialized extra training beyond high school, acquire such skills, while those with just a high school degree or less do not.
Europe has the same gap, only its less-skilled workers are generally less willing to accept the lower-paying jobs that their American counterparts often do. In part, this is because Western Europe offers generous unemployment benefits. Therefore, outside of Germany, at the unskilled level, the Europeans have a big problem of unemployment, and not just a problem of low wages.
A paper delivered to the conference by the French Government noted, for example, that in France, "the mismatch between labor supply and demand is especially acute for unskilled workers."
The French paper added, "The solution to this problem implies a stronger link between the training system and the business sector," including "targeting 100 percent of the young people leaving school with professional training."
