HEADLINE: Whitman Seeks 2d Tax Cut, Aimed at Middle Class

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 15

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman produced her first state budget tonight with the promise of an additional tax cut aimed at the middle class. She proposed to wipe out several state agencies to help pay for it and appealed over the heads of the State Legislature for New Jerseyans to keep up the pressure for smaller government and lower taxes at all levels.
Her $15.4 billion budget, which is for the fiscal year beginning on July 1, was only precariously in balance with the help of an $800 million one-time source of savings. Governor Whitman said she would pay for $589 million in income tax cuts over 18 months by eliminating the Department of Higher Education and turning state campuses free to govern themselves. She called for closing the Office of Public Advocate and folding its public-defender functions into the Department of State, and for ending state ownership, and funds for, New Jersey's public television network. 
 "Not everyone will be happy with this budget," the Governor declared in a speech to the Legislature this evening. "You will hear complaints about particular cuts, questions about why I kept my promise to cut taxes. But tax cut or not tax cut, we would have to cut spending this year."
 
Minimizing the Pain
 The Governor has sought to minimize the pain by taking nibbles from each state division's budget instead of bites. Besides saving $7.38 million by eliminating the Department of Higher Education and laying off the state's $100,225-a-year Chancellor by July 1, the proposed budget would trim support for higher education by $11.5 million, or 1.7 percent, and require a 3.5 percent tuition increase, the smallest such increase, she said, in 10 years.
The state's subsidy to New Jersey Transit, the state-operated bus and rail commuter system, would be cut by $7 million, to $241 million, but would not require a corresponding fare increase under the proposed budget.
Elsewhere in the spending plan the Governor proposed savings as diverse as reducing street lighting on rural roads,, cutting state grants to New Jersey's private universities by 25 percent and closing 7 of the state's 39 armories.
"The Russians are not coming, except hopefully as tourists," she joked to laughter and applause in the well of the Assembly, where the Republican-dominated Legislature and a tumultuous crowd of supporters listened.
The Governor's proposed income tax cut for New Jersey's 3.6 million taxpayers, effective next Jan. 1, would provide a 10 percent rate reduction for up to $80,000 in annual earnings for joint filers, a 2.5 percent reduction for income between $80,000 and $150,000, and a one percent cut for incomes above that level.
For a family earning $50,000, the tax cut proposed this evening would produce a tax savings of $103 on top of the $51 a year provided by the 5 percent cut enacted on March 7. For a single filer earning $50,000, the new reduction would translate into a saving of $208.
The single filer's savings are greater than for a couple earning the same income because of the progressive nature of the tax code and because single payers tend to have fewer deductions than married couples.
Governor Whitman declared to loud applause that she would hold to her promise to seek an additional tax cut in next year's budget.
Tonight's speech and its accompanying spending plans are the culmination of a strategy adopted by Mrs. Whitman when she sought to energize her flagging Republican campaign for governor with a promise to cut state income taxes by 30 percent over her first three years in office. Derided at first, the tax cut pledge caught hold with voters in the closing weeks of the campaign and gave Mrs. Whitman a come-from-behind victory over Jim Florio, the Democratic incumbent.
This evening her speech was embellished with high notes of personal triumph: "I kept my promise," she said of her tax cut pledge. "I did it," she said of a plan reduce her State House staff.
The reaction has been jubilant from the Assembly's Republican majority, where tax-cut sentiment is running high.
In the Republican-controlled Senate, considered more liberal than the Assembly, the Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, praised the Governor's budget but emphasized that since the Senate is the budget-writing house, it will be up to it to conduct "careful reviews of the proposed budget."
Predictably, some of the state's traditional power centers were dismayed. The state teachers union, whose animosity to Mr. Florio helped defeat him, has already vowed to fight Mrs. Whitman's plan to change pension and health care financing plans and eliminate a 2 percent subsidy to public employee pensions.
State employee unions are already angry about proposed layoffs of 600 workers, a measure that Mrs. Whitman, during the campaign, had said she would seek to avoid.
 
'The Bottom Line'
 "Governor Whitman will probably win some praise from people on Main Street tonight," said Joseph V. Dorio, the Assembly's Democratic minority leader, "but the litany of speculative fiscal maneuvers in her budget may jeopardize New Jersey's standing in the month's to come. The bottom line on this budget shows a reduction in state aid to municipalities and schools while spreading the use of dubious one-shot budget gimmicks to the local government level."
Yet Mrs. Whitman is confident that she is part of a national movement of Republican governors who have seized on public frustration with rising taxes and unresponsive government have acted to drive state costs and bureaucracies to lower levels.
Tonight she spoke of New Jersey and its 7.7 million inhabitants as if it were a mini-nation responding to Ronald Reagan's supply-side stimulus. "The more money you have to spend," she said, addressing those watching her on television, "the more the economy will grow. You elected me to cut taxes and government spending in order to create jobs and stimulate economic growth. That's exactly what my tax cuts will do."
Yet she called for some spending increases that, she said, would produce savings later. These initiatives include a boot-camp program for first-time offenders, a privatized drug treatment center attached to the Hudson County Jail. Prisoners with drug habits would have to pass the treatment regimen before being released on parole, she said.
She also asked for more money to promote tourism and she proposed sharply increased spending for the Office of State Planning, which manages growth and development.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Rose Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15

 BODY:
Inflation remained subdued in February despite a surge in energy costs that drove the Producer Price Index up by five-tenths of 1 percent, the most since last spring, Government figures showed today.
Not counting energy, which has since declined, prices received by producers of finished goods were unchanged for the month and up less than 1 percent over the last year. 
 Separately, the Federal Reserve reported that severe weather inflicted less of a setback to industrial production than had been assumed, as output from the nation's factories, mines and utilities climbed four-tenths of 1 percent.
 
 
Busy Auto Sector
 The automotive sector was especially busy as factories turned out cars and light trucks at a sizzling annual pace of 13.6 million, a rate that exceeded plants' formal capacity.
"The economy struggled through the bad weather better than most people thought," Stuart G. Hoffman, the chief economist at the PNC Bank in Pittsburgh, said. Automobile output, he added, "basically maxed out," even surpassing a very strong pace of sales.
Still, the robust economy exhibited few signs of inflation; today's price report was regarded as unlikely to significantly accelerate the Fed's efforts to head off inflation pressures by raising interest rates. Bond traders greeted the price report warmly, and interest rates fell sharply. [Page D18.]

 
 
An Unsettling Note
 The main unsettling note was a jump of 2 percent in the price of raw materials other than food and energy, the fifth consecutive month of sizable increases in these "core" crude goods.
So far, higher prices for materials like iron and steel scrap have not been transmitted to later stages of production and thus constitute only a red flag, not an alarm siren, according to Donald E. Maude, an economist for Scotia McLeod in New York.
The five-tenths of 1 percent overall rise in the Producer Price Index's finished goods index, which matched that of last April, was only slightly more than had been expected and was combined with a significant slackening -- to a rise of just one-tenth of 1 percent -- when the erratic food and energy components were excluded.
Energy, which accounts for about 13 percent of the index, surged 2.8 percent last month, the Labor Department's report showed. The price of home heating oil soared 23.5 percent after falling slightly in January, and gasoline rose more than 6 percent for the second straight month. Residential gas rose 1.2 percent following a small January decline.
 
 
Food Prices Ease
 Food prices eased four-tenths of 1 percent, mainly the result of a 25 percent slide for fresh and dry vegetables.
Goods at the intermediate stage of production moved up four-tenths of 1 percent last month, the most since February 1993. But this also was mainly the result of energy, including an 18.1 percent surge for diesel fuel.
Once again, durable goods used in manufacturing, like hot rolled steel bars, gained in price, while nondurables like organic chemicals eased. Durables were up four-tenths of 1 percent, twice the January increase, while nondurables fell two-tenths of 1 percent for the second straight month.
The price of construction materials eased two-tenths of 1 percent as what appeared to be weather-related declines for softwood lumber, plywood, millwork and plastics more than offset sharp increases for nonferrous wire and cable and for gypsum products.
The index of crude prices fell 1.3 percent last month because of a broad-based drop for energy materials that was in sharp contrast to higher energy prices at the intermediate and finished stages of production, the report also showed. Prices rose for iron and steel scrap, wastepaper, aluminum base scrap, copper ores, raw cotton and leaf tobacco while lower prices were recorded for cattle hides and pulpwood logs.
 
 
Industrial Production
 The report on industrial production, which covers nearly one-third of the economy, showed a ninth consecutive monthly advance that came as a surprise to many analysts. Expectations had dimmed when the Government reported on March 4 that the average factory workweek had been chopped by 42 minutes last month, an extraordinarily big change.
But as it turned out, factory output climbed six-tenths of 1 percent last month, to 5.4 percent above the comparable month a year earlier. Production of durable goods, paced by cars, trucks, computers and related parts, jumped nine-tenths of 1 percent while output of nondurables moved up two-tenths of 1 percent.
Output from coal mines and oil and gas wells advanced eight-tenths of 1 percent, but utility production fell 1.3 percent following a 3.6 percent January burst.
American industry operated plants at 83.4 percent of capacity last month, up only slightly from the 83.3 percent to which January was revised but three-tenths of a point higher than the 83.1 percent rate initially reported for that month.
American plants making cars and light trucks ran at 100.2 percent of rated capacity last month, up from 92.6 percent in January and probably the fastest pace since this statistical series was started in 1977.

HEADLINE: Stocks Slip as Market Ignores Inflation Report

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
In a departure from recent trading sessions, the stock market closed mixed when the bond market went up yesterday. It is a parting of the ways that may be repeated today, when the Consumer Price Index, the best known gauge of inflation, is released.
The markets were perhaps of two minds about inflation. Before the stock market opened, the Producer Price Index for February was released, and its favorable news on inflation should have cheered both the stock and bond markets. 
 But after first rallying, all the main stock indexes fell sharply. The Dow Jones industrial average closed with a loss, while the Standard & Poor's 500 and Nasdaq composite indexes were basically unchanged.
 "This is just a nervous market that is unable to accept good inflation numbers at face value," said Alan R. Ackerman, a market strategist for Reich & Company. "Candidly, this is a good time to protect principal," and sell stocks, he said, "because the market is so nervous."
That the stock market did not follow the bond market was possibly a result of technical factors. Traders said that since some stock options expire on Friday, investors might have wanted to exercise them before the deadline, the triple-witching hour, when three sets of options and futures contracts simultaneously expire.
Also, computer-driven trading appeared to have speeded up a sharp price drop that began around 1:45 P.M.
But Harrison Roth, senior options strategist at Cowen & Company, cast doubt on those explanations, saying that witching hours have have had little effect on the market in recent years. "Options accelerate trends, but they do not create them," he said.
The Dow industrials dropped 13.39 points, to 3,849.59, and the broader S.& P. 500 fell 0.38 point, to 467.01. The Nasdaq index rose 0.72 point, to 793.52. The New York Stock Exchange Composite Index fell 0.02 point, to 258.99, on relatively heavy volume of 329.3 million shares. Advancing stocks led decliners, 1,138 to 1,000. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 0.07 point, to 468.13.
But bond prices rose and stayed up, restraining for a second day the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond, which brushed perilously close to 7 percent on Friday.
 
 
Good News on Core Rate
 At first, the bond market's reaction to the Labor Department's report on producer prices was puzzling because it was not immediately apparent that the news was good. The Producer Price Index rose five-tenths of 1 percent, more than Wall Street economists' expectations of four-tenths of 1 percent. But the core rate -- stripped of food and energy prices -- was up just one-tenth of 1 percent, or half that of expectations. Rising inflation reduces the value of fixed-income securities.
Four stocks dragged down the Dow industrials more than 12 points. They were: United Technologies, down 1 3/4, to 68; General Motors, down 1 1/4, to 61 1/2; McDonald's, down 1 1/4, to 60 1/2, and Boeing, down 1 1/8, to 46 3/4. Some investors might have been concerned about the possibility of a continued costly strike at two G.M. brake-parts plants.
Perrigo, a maker of generic cough and cold medicines sold under store brand names, was the most actively traded stock yesterday at 10 million shares. Retailers have cut back orders for its products, and shares of Perrigo fell 5, to 22 3/8.
The second-most-active stock was Catellus Development, a property developer and asset manager based in San Francisco. Its shares fell 3/8, to 7 1/4. Last week, the company announced a fourth-quarter loss of $13.2 million, quadruple its $3.44 million loss a year earlier.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Interest Rates DeclineOn New Inflation Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Interest rates fell sharply yesterday, as traders and investors greeted this week's first inflation report warmly. But the rebound in the market was only enough to offset Monday's sharp losses.
The positive tone in the market was established early in the session, following the Labor Department's release of February's Producer Price Index. The index showed an increase of five-tenths of 1 percent over all and one-tenth of 1 percent when food and energy were excluded. While slightly higher than analysts had expected, the index painted a fairly benign inflation picture. 
 Bond prices, which move in the opposite direction of interest rates, also received a lift from the Federal Reserve, when the central bank said yesterday morning that it was going to buy Treasury notes and bonds maturing on and after October 1994 to add cash to the banking system. The Fed action was intended to address a seasonal shortage of reserves that if left unanswered could cause short-term rates to move higher than current Fed policy warrants.
 
 
'Coupon Pass'
 The process is called a "coupon pass" and is something the Fed does a few times a year. The announcement itself did not surprise the bond market, since economists had been expecting the move for some time. Traders said the "coupon pass" also presented dealers with an opportunity to sell Treasury securities that had been piling up in inventory since a Feb. interest rate increase by the Fed.
However, when the Fed informed the dealers how much it would purchase, the dealers were disappointed by what they considered a lack of aggressive buying by the Fed. Bond prices as a result moved down off their highs of the day.
Near the close of the New York cash market, the 30-year bond was up 22/32 of a percentage point, to 921/32 for a yield of 6.89 percent, down from Monday's close of 6.95 percent. Intermediate and short-term maturities also enjoyed a rebound from Monday's selloff: the yield on a 3-year note fell to 5.33 percent from 5.36 percent, and the yield on a 10-year note fell to 6.44 percent from 6.51 percent.
 
 
'Where We Thought'
 Donald Fine, the chief market analyst at Chase Securities, said yesterday that "the February Producer Price Index for finished goods was basically pretty much where we thought it would be."
While the overall index was a little stronger than expected, the core was a little smaller than expectations and analysts said that was what the market responded to.
"I could never understand why so much is made of the core number, which excludes food and energy, major parts of the price indices," Mr. Fine said. In the Producer Price Index, food and energy account for 35 percent of the index; in the Consumer Price Index, they account for 25 percent.
"Petroleum, for example, an energy component, is also ingrained in other areas of the economy and not counted as energy," Mr. Fine continued. "But I suppose if you want to starve in a dark room and not travel, than maybe inflation excluding food and energy is acceptable."
Even as bond prices held on to modest gains across the curve, the upward momentum began to fizzle in the afternoon, as investors began to look toward the release today of the latest Consumer Price Index. Analysts at MMS International, a Wall Street research firm, said in a report that "some short positions were shaken out by the better-than-expected 0.1 percent core, as well as by the anticipation of the Fed's coupon pass."
 
 
Additional Data
 Other data released yesterday included the February industrial production and capacity utilization figures. Economists in a Reuters survey had expected the numbers to be unchanged for production and at 83 percent for capacity use. The Federal Reserve Board reported that February industrial production rose four-tenths of 1 percent and capacity use rose to 83.4 percent, its highest since 83.9 percent in June 1989.
Traders said the report temporarily caused prices of Treasury securities to sag slightly. According to some economists, the output and capacity use data showed manufacturing activity remained strong. MMS International analysts said it reinforced elements in the Atlanta Federal Reserve's regional index on Monday and the National Association of Purchasing Management index last month, both of which showed manufacturing activity picking up.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gasoline Prices Up Sharply; Data Show Dip in Supplies

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Gasoline futures rallied sharply yesterday as traders correctly bet that petroleum industry data would show a reduction in supplies.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, unleaded gasoline for April delivery rose 1.23 cents, to 46.11 cents a gallon. Other energy contracts also gained, with light crude for April delivery settling 34 cents higher at $14.83 a barrel; April home heating oil rising 1.27 cents, to 44.63 cents a gallon, and April natural gas rising 0.54 cent, to $2.104 for 1,000 cubic feet. 
 Investors in energy futures were speculating that the American Petroleum Institute's weekly inventory data, released after trading ended, would show that gasoline stockpiles were dwindling.
The report showed gasoline stocks had dropped 95,000 barrels in the latest week, with crude stocks slipping 5.284 million barrels.
The reduction could mean higher prices, particularly with the current high demand and with oil supplies backed up on an important trade route through the Bosporus in Turkey, said Tom Bentz, director of the energy division for Quantum Financial Services in New York.
About 100 ships stood at anchor yesterday because the Bosporus remained closed as an oil tanker continued to burn after a weekend collision with a freighter.
Investors also predicted that the stronger American economy would lead to increased seasonal demand for gasoline.
"We've seen outstanding demand this year for refined products, and all indications are that it will continue through another six months and well past that," said Peter Beutel, president of Cameron Hanover Inc. in Bronxville, N.Y.
On other commodity markets, corn and soybeans futures prices ended mostly lower after a relatively quiet trading session. Wheat futures prices advanced.
Wheat for delivery in March settled 1 cent lower, to $3.3175 a bushel, at the Chicago Board of Trade. March corn fell 3 cents, to $2.7725 a bushel; March oats were unchanged at $1.26 a bushel, and March soybeans were 1.5 cents lower at $6.865 a bushel.
Wheat futures gained on National Weather Service forecasts of normal-to-dry conditions in winter wheat growing areas, which are already dry. The losses in corn and soybeans futures were attributed mostly to technical movements after Monday's strong gains.
A report released after the trading session Monday showed lower-than-expected weekly soybean export shipments, and the weather service predicted normal to below-normal rain in the Midwest, which could allow a smooth start to planting of the new crop.
Prices of both corn and soybeans continue to be underpinned by tight stocks after last year's Midwest flooding.

HEADLINE: New Injury Pattern Linked to Air Bags

BYLINE: By SANDRA BLAKESLEE 

 BODY:
AIR bags and automatic seat-belt systems, while undoubtedly saving lives, are also transforming the kinds of injuries that people get in serious traffic accidents, emergency room physicians and Federal researchers say.
Crash victims in cars equipped with such devices tend to suffer crushed ankles, shattered legs and other trauma to their lower extremities, said Dr. Jeffrey Augenstein, a trauma surgeon who is the director of the Department of Transportation's crash study at the Ryder Trauma Center of Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami, Fla. They may also suffer internal injuries that would probably not be noticed at the scene of an accident, Dr. Augenstein added. 
 While such injuries may cause lifelong disabilities, he said, the victims would almost certainly have died were it not for the new safety devices.
 
Questions Remain
 There is no doubt that air bags are saving lives in front-end collisions, said George Parker, the associate administrator for research and development at the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration in Washington. But questions remain.
Now that airbags are coming into widespread use, Mr. Parker said, what are the consequences for drivers and passengers who get into accidents? Do the airbags themselves cause injuries? Why are there injuries when people wear seat belts as well as use airbags? And what is the nature of those injuries?
To find out, the agency is financing a five-year study at the Ryder Trauma Center, which treats most victims of catastrophic automobile accidents in the Miami area. Today, Dr. Augenstein will present a three-year progress report to officials of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, detailing the injuries suffered by 100 people treated at the center after head-on collisions.
 
Two Recommendations
 The administration has already issued two recommendations based on its continuing study of air-bag effectiveness, Mr. Parker said. One is that the police or paramedics at the scene of an accident lift the air bag to see if the steering wheel has been deformed. If so, the victim may have internal injuries and should be taken to a hospital for observation.
Second, rear-facing infant seats should not be placed in the front seat if the passenger side has an air bag. Such seats come too close to the air-bag mechanism, he said, and the force of inflation could harm the child. Front-facing child seats are safe, he added, but the back seat is the safest spot for young children in car seats.
Mr. Parker said that in 1992, the most recent year for which figures are available, 211,758 people were hospitalized nationwide because of crash injuries. Of these, 88,663, or 42 percent, had been wearing seat belts. An unknown fraction of them, Mr. Parker said, would also have been protected by air bags, which were first widely introduced in 1990-model cars.
 
Change in Injuries
 In the Miami study, 20 of the 100 victims were wearing seat belts and had driver-side air bags, Dr. Augenstein said. The bags protected their heads and torsos but, because of the force of the crash, their legs still came into contact with a hard part of the car. "We are beginning to see many very, very severe lower-extremity injuries, like ankle fractures, crushed feet" and broken femurs and hip bones, he said.
Drivers protected by air bags can also suffer internal injuries that are not apparent at the accident scene, Dr. Augenstein said. There may be no blood or broken bones, he said, but the driver's abdomen may still hit the steering wheel, especially if there are multiple impacts. Lacerations of the liver, bowel and spleen are not uncommon, Dr. Augenstein said. Such injuries may need surgery or careful observation in an intensive care unit.
Internal injuries are far more likely if the crash victim is not wearing seat belts, allowing the victim to slide up and over or around the air bag, Dr. Augenstein said. Air bags are not a substitute for for both shoulder and lap seat belt restraints, he said. In fact, air bags work best when both belts are used.
In the Miami study, 80 crash victims were riding in cars equipped with systems in which shoulder belts close automatically but lap belts must be buckled by hand. The injuries varied depending on the severity of the crash, Dr. Augenstein said, but every person who wore only the shoulder belt and failed to buckle the lap belt -- 7 of the 80 -- suffered liver lacerations. The absence of a lap belt lets the pelvis slide forward, he said, so that the automatic shoulder belt does not grab at the shoulder, but exerts maximum force at the right upper part of the abdomen, near the liver.
No one has been seriously harmed by the air bag itself, he said.
Automobile safety engineers are looking for ways to protect the lower body in severe crashes, Mr. Parker said. Some manufacturers are strengthening the car's lower level so that it does not crumple on impact, he said, but more research is needed.

HEADLINE: The Pub: A Center Of Ireland in Exile

BYLINE: By ELAINE LOUIE 

 BODY:
WHEN Giles Cooper was growing up in County Kerry, Ireland, he was so poor he slept with his only pair of shoes stuck under the bedposts, so that no one could steal them without lifting the bed and waking him up.
Now, Mr. Cooper is a contractor and no longer poor. Last Christmas, when he and two friends spent $200,000 to open Tom & Jerry's Bar and Restaurant on Elizabeth Street, on the edge of SoHo, Mr. Cooper was a happy man. From the exterior he may resemble Willie Nelson, down to the ponytail and the bandanna around his head, but in his heart, he will always be an Irishman. 
 "I always wanted to open a pub," Mr. Cooper said. The bar, with gleaming white walls inset with glass brick, is an Irish dream made real. On weekends, it is packed. And the people are not there for the food. There isn't any food -- yet.
To many of the Irish, whether in Ireland or in New York City, a pub is not just a bar, a place to grab a bottle of beer or a pint of Guinness stout, dark and bitter, yeasty and filling. In Ireland, a pub is the cultural epicenter, the place where people go at night. In New York, the pub serves much the same function, especially tomorrow, on St. Patrick's Day.
As Irish immigration to New York increases, so do the numbers of new pubs. Through much of the 1960's and 1970's, when the economy in Ireland was good, the United States drew few Irish immigrants. But since 1986, when United States immigration law changed, many young Irish men and women, most of them single and in their 20's, have been moving to America.
In 1992, 3,116 people from Ireland emigrated to New York City, and many of them settled in Queens, says Frank Vardy, a demographer at New York City's Department of City Planning. The favorite neighborhoods are Sunnyside and Woodside, where the Irish live side-by-side with Koreans, Chinese and Colombians. Other immigrants move to a Little Ireland along the Bronx-Yonkers border.
At pubs, people find gossip and jobs, boyfriends and girlfriends -- and sometimes husbands and wives. A pub is where there are dart games and seisiuns (pronounced se-SHOONS) -- informal gatherings for singing plaintive songs, whose roots are medieval ballads, accompanied by guitar, fiddle and bodhran (bow-RAWN), a drum.
"Your social life in Ireland is to go to to the bar," said Jimmy Tuohy, Mr. Cooper's partner in Tom & Jerry's. The third partner is Jo Janes, a former bartender and the daughter of a Presbyterian minister. ("I'm helping people sin, and he saves them," she said.)
Mr. Tuohy, who grew up in Ireland, said his native town, Kenmare, had 1,000 people and 30 bars.
Irish pubs in New York, with their fish and chips, beer and dart games, represent comfort. Some look much as they do in Ireland. At Fiona's on Katonah Avenue in the Bronx the Irishness begins with the architecture. There are carved dark wood arches and paneled walls, and an etched glass wall divides the bar and lounge area from a passageway that leads to the restrooms. In Ireland, the glass wall, always sandblasted and opaque, was traditionally used to divide the men from the women. The area where the women sat, and sometimes priests as well, was called the snug.
At Fiona's on a recent Thursday night, two women's dart teams, one from Fiona's, the other from the Hide-Out Bar, also in the Bronx, played for their league's championship.
Sometimes a dart missed the board and bounced off the Tiffany-style chandelier. Ping. Three hours and hundreds of darts later, the game was over.
The Hide-Out had won, and the women got rowdy.
The winners shook bottles of beer, covering the tops with their thumbs, and sprayed each other until their faces and blouses were soaked and sticky. Some of the women grabbed Patsy Kindelan, the Hide-Out's owner, and hoisted him onto their shoulders. He waved -- feebly.
Then the women from the Hide-Out did the glory run. They climbed up on the bar and ran up and down, shimmying and screaming for joy. As the women hollered, Danny Doohan, the owner of Fiona's, did what most Irish pub owners do, at the end of a game. He brought out shepherd's pie for the teams.
Across town, at Sidetrack's, a popular bar and restaurant in Sunnyside, there are no darts. "They're dangerous," said Andrew Breslin, Sidetrack's owner. "And it's a family restaurant."
Even without darts, Sidetrack's is Dermot G. Robinson's "local." "It's where you go regularly," said Mr. Robinson, a 35-year-old house painter who lives in Sunnyside. He is at Sidetrack's three times a week. If someone telephones for him and he isn't there, the staff takes a message.
Sidetrack's is Greta Wood's local, too.
"I come here Tuesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday for lunch and dinner," said Ms. Wood, 39, a building superintendent in Queens.
While agreeing that Irish social life is centered on pubs, the new immigrants resent the stereotype that portrays the Irish as heavy drinkers. And there is proof that they are right. In "Alcohol Use in Ireland," published last year by the Economic and Social Research Institute in Dublin, Denis Conniffe and Daniel McCoy report that in 1990, the alcohol consumption per adult was less than half that of France or Spain.
But when the Irish do drink, it's not necessarily Irish brands, like Harp lager or Guinness stout. At the pubs, they were drinking Molson, Amstel, Heineken, Coors, and vodka and Coke.
At the bar, Irishmen (but not Irishwomen) have their own etiquette about paying for drinks. When a man buys the first drink, he leaves the change, a stack of bills, on the bar, and when a friend comes by, he asks, "What will you have?" The bartender takes the money from the bar, returns the change, and not a word is said about the bill. At the end of the night, without any words being spoken about the crass subject of money, each person has bought his friends a round of drinks.
"It's a courtesy to buy a round of drinks," said Brendan Keenan, a 31-year-old instructor at the New York Restaurant School in Manhattan.
Ask an Irishman what he thinks about Irish food, and his answer is a joke. From Mr. Keenan: "Irish food is a six-pack of Guinness and a pint of potatoes." From John O'Callahan, who sells carpets and curtains in Queens: "Boil it dead. Cook it dead." After the jokes, comes the defense.
Probably no Irish chef will claim that Irish food ranks with French food. "The French live to eat," Mr. Keenan said, "and the Irish eat to live." But he would say that when the ingredients are farm- or river-fresh, and not overcooked, Irish food is simple yet tasty.
Still, concerned about Ireland's poor food image, the Irish Government began to put more money into cooking schools in 1963 and, later, to send Irish chefs to the Continent for cooking competitions. Now, at least four European-trained Irish chefs work at the Plaza, Regency and Waldorf-Astoria hotels in Manhattan. The St. Patrick's Day menu at the Waldorf-Astoria's Peacock Alley restaurant will feature a refined variation of the Irish stew. Conrad Gallagher, the sous-chef, will braise, not boil, the lamb shanks, and to the richly aromatic dish spiced with fresh thyme and rosemary, he will add fingerling potatoes and porcini.
When the Irish get homesick in New York, they crave an Irish breakfast: a platter of fried bacon (rashers), sausages (bangers), black pudding (a sausage made from pork blood) and white pudding (a white pork sausage), fried potatoes, fried tomatoes and triangles of toast.
At 1 in the afternoon, on a recent Saturday, the Irish Coffee Shop, a seven-month-old restaurant in Yonkers, was packed. Almost everyone was eating the Irish breakfast, a huge array priced at $6, enough food for two people. On weekends, the restaurant cooks 150 Irish breakfasts a day, and on weekdays, at least 50.
Patricia Kennedy, a 25-year-old nurse who lives in Yonkers, ordered the breakfast, without rashers.
"I ate too many rashers at home," Ms. Kennedy said.
How often was too many?
Nearly every day.
But the yearning for an Irish breakfast was still there.

HEADLINE: Standing Up to China

 BODY:
When dealing with China, it sometimes helps to see matters through Chinese eyes. As Beijing views it, a great power must always insist on being treated with due respect. To behave otherwise is to acknowledge inferiority and therefore to forfeit influence.
During Secretary of State Christopher's weekend visit to Beijing, Chinese leaders aggressively asserted what they see as the prerogatives of China. They deliberately humiliated America's highest-ranking diplomat by temporarily rounding up some of the country's most prominent dissidents, and by detaining several Western correspondents trying to report on the crackdown. 
 The purpose of the roundup was to prevent Mr. Christopher from hearing any independent views on the human rights issues he is required to evaluate before making a recommendation by June on renewing China's access to the most favorable American tariff schedules.
For the sake of a healthy U.S.-China relationship, Washington is now obliged to respond with equal firmness. To kowtow to Chinese bullying would be to repeat the mistakes of the Bush Administration, which squandered American influence by its consistent refusal to press human rights issues. That was what first provoked Congress to force annual showdowns over linking continuation of China's trade privileges to progress on human rights.
The Clinton Administration needs instead to be forthright about its continued determination to insist on human rights progress. It especially needs to dispel China's impression that it can exploit differences between various policy makers in the Administration, Congress and the business community. Such miscalculation can only increase the likelihood of a rupture both sides would prefer to avoid.
China, despite its pose of cool indifference, desperately needs the $20 billion hard currency surplus it earns from its trade with the U.S. to carry on with its ambitious economic development plans. And U.S. business frankly wants to maintain access to one of the world's largest and fastest-growing economies. For their part, human rights advocates recognize that China's continued economic growth and openness contribute to domestic pressures for more responsive, less dictatorial government.
Even so, the Clinton Administration has a clear right under international law, and an obligation under U.S. law, to link China's trade status to minimum human rights goals. The Administration has demanded nothing unreasonable or demeaning, for the most part asking only compliance with international agreements to which China already subscribes. Washington seeks an end to the export of goods produced by slave labor, freer emigration for relatives of exiles and detainees, humane and lawful treatment of prisoners, and respect for the cultural traditions of Tibet. On most of these issues it has not set rigid benchmarks but is looking for "overall significant progress."
The Administration can use the remaining two and a half months provided by last year's executive order to give China the greatest possible incentive to demonstrate progress. But Mr. Clinton must make clear that if Beijing continues to try to blow past the whole issue with deliberate human rights provocations, it will be making a very big mistake.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Black Summit Can't Exclude Nation of Islam

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People remains committed to our historic mandate to challenge racial exploitation, discrimination and bigotry. We will not be diverted by attempts to mischaracterize our efforts to convene African-American leadership to confront collectively the profound issues affecting African-American communities of the United States. 
 "The N.A.A.C.P.'s Mistake" (editorial, March 7) criticizes us for inviting Louis Farrakhan, the Nation of Islam leader, to a coming summit meeting of African-American leaders. But not to invite Mr. Farrakhan to participate in a critical dialogue with dozens of other national leaders would be a serious mistake.
An invitation to him or to other African-American leaders does not constitute an endorsement of the teachings or philosophies of the organizations they represent. We are not seeking to fabricate unity or consensus out of diversity, but we are convinced that diversity and dialogue are not mutually exclusive.
We believe that as the nation's oldest and largest civil rights organization, we have a responsibility to sponsor a summit meeting for African-American leaders on such issues as unemployment, alienation, drugs, violence, health care, education and lack of economic opportunity.
We are prepared to respect the integrity and independence of the organizations we invite to this summit, planned for the spring, and we expect reciprocity.
Dialogue and accord are taking place all over the world between longtime adversaries who recognize the need to work for a common interest. What's wrong with dialogue among parties with radically different perspectives right in the United States?
We all know that race relations were severely affected by the now infamous Kean College speech of Khalid Muhammad. The N.A.A.C.P. condemned his demagogic diatribe in the strongest terms, as throughout our 85-year history we have denounced all manifestations of racism, anti-Semitism and bigotry.
As we seek to forge new relationships, we also work to strengthen our relations with other groups and individuals in America's multiracial and multicultural mosaic. Just two weeks ago in New York, a leadership delegation of the N.A.A.C.P. held a productive meeting with leaders of the Anti-Defamation League. Moreover, the N.A.A.C.P. values the active participation in its affairs of its many white and Jewish members.
Yes, we are at a watershed moment in the war against prejudice in the United States. But we are also at a crossroads in the war against growing poverty, hopelessness and despair in urban and rural communities of America, the struggle against rising misery and degradation among millions of Americans.
Unemployment in the African-American community is twice the national average. Homelessness is rampant. Fratricide is claiming far too many young lives. Jails and prisons are overflowing with young African-American and Latino males.
Talking to one another will solve more common problems than throwing stones and shouting at one another.
 
BENJAMIN F. CHAVIS JR.
WILLIAM F. GIBSON
Baltimore, March 9, 1994
The writers are, respectively, executive director, N.A.A.C.P., and chairman of its national board of directors.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Cuts Cash Awards To Landlords for Homeless

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration has ordered drastic cuts in a program that has awarded landlords thousands of dollars in incentives for providing apartments to homeless families living in shelters.
Administration officials said the bonus program paid some landlords too much money. They said the reduction would not hurt the program in part because of recent increases in Federal rent subsidies. 
 The reduced payments, which the administration expects will save $18 million in state and city money, come on the heels of proposed budget cuts that would eliminate city financing for a program that creates housing for single homeless men and women. Housing advocates describe these programs as a central element of a successful effort that has movedthousands of homeless people from shelters to private housing.
Administration officials say neither cutback will affect the availability of permanent housing for the homeless, and they say that both will help the city economize as it is faces a budget gap of more than $2.3 billion.
But advocates for the homeless said they feared that the combined cuts could decimate more than 10 years of efforts to move the homeless from shelters to permanent housing. In the last decade, the two programs have produced more than 10,000 permanent apartments for the homeless.
The latest cut, which took effect Monday, reduces the bonuses that landlords receive for making their apartments available to shelter residents through the Emergency Assistance Rehousing Program, or E.A.R.P. Until Monday landlords had received a flat grant of $2,300 for every family member placed in new apartments. The new rate is a sliding scale, with a minimum of $1,000 per two-person family to a maximum bonus of $5,000 for families of eight or more.
Landlords who have apartments in the pipeline as of last Friday, and who have contracts with the New York City Housing Authority and tenant leases signed by June 30, will receive bonuses based on the higher schedule.
Joan Malin, the Commissioner of the city's Department of Homeless Services, said she felt that the new schedule of incentives would remove what she characterized as generous payments to landlords who place big families. "With the old schedule," Ms. Malin said, "there was no cap on the size of the bonus landlords could get. So a landlord could get $20,000 or more for each family accepted."
"There is no doubt that there is little housing available for large families," Ms. Malin said. "But there was a concern that for the top levels on the schedule, the payments were out of whack with the market."
She added that the administration does not believe the cuts in the cash bonuses will hurt the program, in part because recent increases in Federal rent subsidies will shift the incentive from the one-time bonus to the higher rents.
She said by raising the fair market rent levels, participating landlords would get higher rents and more landlords would qualify for the program. "It opens another band of the market to us," she said.
But several landlords said yesterday that they would probably stop participating because of the cuts in the bonuses.
"They have just destroyed the program," said Ira Kellman, a landlord who had not heard about the bonus cuts.
Mr. Kellman, who rents to about 30 E.A.R.P. tenants in Harlem, said the change in policy was a further disincentive for participation.
 
'It's Not Worthwhile'
 "After a point," Mr. Kellman said, who like other landlords complained about burdens of dealing with three agencies and the risk of seeing apartments stand empty while tenants were placed, "it's not worthwhile."
Mr. Kellman said that just this week he was considering offering 5 or 10 units that had recently become available in his complex to the city for tenants from the program. But he said he would need more information before making a decision.
In addition to the cuts in the bonus program, a provision in Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposed capital budget for the next three years would eliminate $89 million in city spending for the S.R.O. Loan Program, which helps nonprofit groups that develop single-room housing with support services for single homeless people. The Department of Housing Preservation and Development, which administers the program, hopes to make up the cut with Federal money.
 
Cuts Found Troubling
 Gretchen Buchenholtz, executive director of Association to Benefit Children, which operates Rosie and Harry's Place, a shelter in East Harlem, said she found the cuts in the bonus program "troubling and potentially short-sighted."
"If this move is going to reduce the number of apartments available to shelter residents," she said, "then more families will be stuck in shelters for a longer period of time, resulting in the long run a greater financial cost to the city and a greater human cost to the families."
The program was established in 1982 to help find private alternative housing for the homeless. But owners did not embrace it until 1986, when the State Legislature approved a bonus of $2,300 to landlords for each person in the household the first time a unit's lease was signed.
When the real-estate market was booming and few apartments were available, the payments encouraged landlords to renovate their properties to lease them to the homeless. To participate, landlords must sign 32-month leases and are paid fair-market rent through a combination of Federal rent subsidies and the tenant's public assistance income.
 
2 Programs Stepped Up
 After struggling through most of the 1980's with various ways to meet the needs of a growing population of homeless, the city stepped up both the bonus program and the S.R.O. Loan Program and saw them as an increasingly important component in its commitment to reduce the use of welfare hotels. Last year 2,300 shelter families found permanent homes as a result of the incentive program, and Ms. Malin said the agency's goal is to use it to find permanent homes for 2,700 families.
Since 1988 the S.R.O. program has developed 3,800 single-room apartments for homeless people.
Ms. Buchenholtz said she is most concerned about where the homeless families will go if the landlords abandon the program.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 17, 1994, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a New York City program that awards cash incentives to landlords who provide apartments for homeless families misstated the minimum payment in some editions. It is $1,000 for housing a two-member family, not $1,000 per person.

HEADLINE: The Whitewater Fallacy

BYLINE: By Ernest Dumas; Ernest Dumas is a columnist for The Arkansas Times.

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.

 BODY:
Reliable sources tell me that the word "incestuous" is coded into the computers of all news media people writing about Arkansas and Whitewater. Press the F1 key and a reflexive sentence will describe the illicit political and financial culture from which the President of the United States sprang.
So long have Arkansans endured the hillbilly caricature that defensiveness is part of their genetic code. They know why the incest metaphor seems so natural to Washington reporters, whose picture of Arkansas is of an ethical Dogpatch where savings-and-loan schemers bed their sisters and then get their idiot spawn appointed to the state regulatory agencies. 
 The coziness of Arkansas politics, government and finance has been a staple news theme since reporters came to Little Rock in the Presidential campaign and discovered what a small place it was. You could stroll down the sidewalk and see all sorts of local big fish. In a little plate-lunch cafe a block from campaign headquarters you could see bankers, Supreme Court Justices and what passed locally for big-time lawyers forking down meat loaf and tossing jolly ripostes across the tables.
Much of the reporting has focused on the connections of the staid old Rose Law Firm, where Hillary Rodham Clinton and three other Clinton Administration officials worked -- including Webster Hubbell, the now-departed Associate Attorney General.
The political-incest theory, in which the Rose firm plays a large part, might appear to be a reasonable explanation of why the fumbling White House would create a genuine crisis from a pathetic little investment fiasco and one of the smallest S. & L. belly-flops in the country -- in neither of which does the known record suggest any wrongdoing by the Clintons.
Or by anyone else in the government in Arkansas. And that is the trouble with the explanation. There is no doubt that Mr. Clinton hired cronies like Mr. Hubbell and that the White House sprang into a defensive crouch when questions began to be asked about the Clintons' financial dealings. But the idea that the wreck of Madison Guaranty Savings and Loan and the scheming of its erstwhile chief, James McDougal, were shielded by friendly state officials is a myth. Despite Mr. McDougal's support for Mr. Clinton, the government's demeanor toward him was anything but friendly.
A former aide to Senators John L. McClellan and J. William Fulbright, Mr. McDougal had been Governor Clinton's economic development adviser in his first term, in 1979 and 1980. He believed that hidebound Arkansas bankers -- who invested in U.S. securities rather than lending to local entrepreneurs who might have created jobs and growth -- were at the root of the state's woeful poverty.
When Mr. McDougal left the government and went into the banking and savings-and-loan business, he set out to prove his theory. Everyone (or at least every good Democrat) deserved a loan, whether needed or not; from that would flow abundance for all.
A couple of years later, with Mr. Clinton back in office, his Bank Commissioner, Marlin Jackson, drove up into the Ozark woods to tell the directors of Mr. McDougal's tiny bank to curb his free-wheeling lending outside its territory, specifically including loans to the Clintons for the Whitewater development project.
And it was Mr. Clinton's Securities Commissioner, Beverly Bassett Schaffer, who along with the Federal Home Loan Bank Board forced Mr. McDougal's removal from control of Madison Guaranty after an accounting firm's examination condemned its lending and investment practices in 1986. She petitioned for a Federal takeover of the company in 1987.
It is widely accepted that in 1985 Mrs. Schaffer approved an unprecedented issuance of preferred stock in after a plea from Hillary Clinton on Madison's behalf. But this "approval" was a little different from the way news accounts have painted it.
The Dallas regional office of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board had encouraged the troubled savings and loans in the region to recapitalize. Madison talked about issuing preferred stock, and a lawyer at the Rose firm wrote a memorandum asserting that state law did not bar such an issuance by a state-chartered savings and loan. The memo noted at the bottom that a copy had been sent to Hillary Rodham Clinton.
Mrs. Schaffer replied, in a now famous "Dear Hillary" letter, that preferred stock was not barred by state law. But an issuance would have had to be approved by Mrs. Schaffer, and Madison never proposed one -- either because it could not have withstood the disclosure requirements or because it could not have found buyers.
The caricature of an incestuous government seems to be based on Mr. Clinton's practice of hiring friends, some of whom turn out to be competent, others knaves. But no example comes to mind of a contrary policy anywhere in this country. That too many people know each other and have business and social relationships is an indictment of small cities everywhere. But the real difference is that in small places the little secrets are known, while in places like Washington, Chicago and New York they are unknowable.

HEADLINE: FIGURE SKATING;
Judge Accepts Harding Plea In Conspiracy

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

 BODY:
A 10-week whodunit that captured world attention for the unlikely backdrop of figure skating came to an inconclusive halt yesterday when Tonya Harding pleaded guilty to a single charge in the Jan. 6 assault on her rival, Nancy Kerrigan.
In a plea agreement in a Portland, Ore., District Court, Miss Harding admitted to conspiring to hinder prosecution of the case, a felony offense. But what the agreement did not include -- and now might never be known for certain -- is the full extent of her knowledge of the attack in Detroit, where Miss Kerrigan was struck on the knee with a collapsible metal baton. 
 Miss Harding acknowledged no further involvement beyond what she has already said -- that she learned of the attack only after it was committed and failed to tell authorities what she knew. She has consistently denied any role in the attack.
 
An Unanswered Question
 The conspiracy charge carries a maximum prison sentence of five years and a fine of $100,000. Under Oregon sentencing guidelines, however, she will not serve any prison time. She received a probation of three years, a fine of $100,000 and an order to perform 500 hours of community service.
While the unknowable might lack the scope and urgency of other celebrated but unresolved crimes, the extent of Miss Harding's role in the case had remained the single burning question. As such, it fed a growing fascination with a case that featured an unlikely brazen act, memorable characters and legal maneuvering, all amid the otherwise genteel world of sequins, lace and classical music on ice.
But if Miss Harding harbors any remaining secrets, she will no longer skate with them as an amateur. As an additional condition of the agreement, she must resign from the United States Figure Skating Association, a move that means she will be ineligible for the world championships next week in Japan.
By other terms of the agreement, Miss Harding agreed to contribute $50,000 to establish a fund for Special Olympics in Oregon, to reimburse the county $10,000 in legal expenses and to undergo a psychiatric examination.
Miss Harding's plea came at the end of a day on which several witnesses testified before a grand jury deciding whether Miss Harding or any of at least three others involved in the assault would be indicted. Among those appearing was her former husband, Jeff Gillooly, who had told Federal investigators that Miss Harding was involved in planning the attack.
 
Scheduled to Leave
 Miss Harding was scheduled to leave today for Japan in what was to be her final performance before she planned on turning professional. Thus, her competitive career will end with an eighth-place finish at the winter Olympics last month in Lillehammer, Norway, where Miss Kerrigan was second behind Oksana Baiul of Ukraine.
Jerry Lace, executive director of the skating association, said the organization's executive committee would meet today to decide whether to continue its disciplinary proceedings against Miss Harding. One of the possibilities, Mr. Lace said, is that Miss Harding could be stripped of the national championship she won in Detroit in January.
 Dressed in a black suit, Miss Harding stood somberly beside her lawyer, Robert C. Weaver Jr., as Judge Donald H. Londer of the Multnomah County District Court made certain she understood the agreement and all that it implied. Her only statement to the court after the 15-minute hearing was, "I would just like to say that I am really sorry I interfered," although it was not immediately clear whether she meant interfering with the case or Judge Londer's vacation.
He had cut short a trip to the Oregon coast to be in court.
Outside the courtroom, surrounded by reporters, Mr. Weaver said: "This ends the biggest part of what has been an unending nightmare for Tonya Harding for the last few months. She realized that she placed too much value on her goals and her career and not enough on herself. She's committed herself to get into a program she will examine why she has been involved in so many destructive relationships so that she can prevent them from happening again."
He added: "Tonya has to take care of Tonya now."
Throughout an investigation by Federal authorities and law enforcement agencies in Oregon and Michigan, Miss Harding maintained that she never knew more about the assault than what she learned several days after her Jan. 10 return to Portland from the national championships, which she won.
After initially denying she knew anything about the attack and sticking to her story for nearly nine hours in a Jan. 18 interview with the F.B.I., she changed her position in the next two hours to reveal she had learned that people close to her had been involved.
Those people included Mr. Gillooly, with whom she was living at the time. Mr. Gillooly had told the same Federal investigators in an earlier interview that Miss Harding was involved in planning the attack from the beginning, and that, in fact, it was her idea.
Mr. Gillooly, an unemployed former warehouse worker, pleaded guilty to a single count of racketeering on Feb. 1. The grand jury is still considering whether to indict three other men who have told authorities they played a role in the attack. They include Shane Stant of Phoenix, whom authorities say struck Miss Kerrigan; Derrick Smith, also of Phoenix, who confessed to driving the getaway car, and Shawn Eckart, the heavyset body guard and lifelong friend of Mr. Gillooly's who has told authorities he received $2,000 from Mr. Gillooly to pay the others to carry out the attack.
It is possible that Miss Harding could be called to testify if these men are indicted and the cases go to trial.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tonya Harding with her lawyer, Robert C. Weaver Jr., as she pleaded guilty yesterday in Portland, Ore., to a charge of hindering the prosecution. She was then sentenced to probation, a fine and community service. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Michigan Votes for Revolution In Financing Its Public Schools

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 16

 BODY:
In the nation's most dramatic shift in a century in the way public schools are financed, Michigan will begin using sales and other taxes, not property taxes, to pay for its 3,286 schools.
The experiment also includes provisions to begin equalizing spending by rich and poor districts throughout the state by giving each district a minimum of $4,200 a student, $1,000 more than the poorer districts now spend. The plan is being examined by several states; 28 are now mired in lawsuits about the inequities of financing from property taxes. 
 Approved by 70 percent of voters in a heavy turnout on Tuesday, the Michigan plan will end the state's 100-year reliance on property taxes, which here, as in other states, have galvanized property owners into a powerful political force trying to limit spending.
 
Conservative Impulse
 Backed by Gov. John M. Engler, a conservative Republican who faces re-election this fall, the plan was intended to help improve schools without increasing the burden on property owners. Less than 10 percent of school financing would come from property taxes, accomplishing Mr. Engler's initial goal, as well as equalizing expenditures in rich and poor school districts, a goal liberals have sought in many states for more than 20 years.
"It is a huge vote," Mr. Engler said by telephone today. "The property tax had been a terrible problem in the state because of the relentless increases for schools. We were approaching an educational meltdown, and it was the root of the inequities in the per pupil spending among districts."
Under the plan, which goes into effect on May 1, the state sales tax will increase to 6 percent from 4 percent, and cigarette taxes will triple, to 75 cents a pack. This will generate more than $2.1 billion a year, the State Treasury Office estimates. Property taxes will be reduced by about $1.9 billion.
 
Drawing Keen Interest
 Although school officials across the state as well as critics wonder whether sales tax receipts are too volatile to support public education in the future, the state's venture into uncharted terrain has drawn keen interest from other states. In the last month, the Wisconsin Legislature approved two competing proposals that would limit a school district's reliance on property taxes. Officials from Vermont, South Carolina, Rhode Island and New Hampshire have asked for detailed projections of the financing plan.
All told, 28 states are in court over the way they finance public education. In most cases, civil rights groups and coalitions of parents have alleged that state aid to supplement property taxes does not close the gap between rich schools and poor ones.
"The mere fact that Michigan has done this means that other states are going to think about it," said Steven D. Gold, director of the Center for the Study of the States in Albany, part of the State University of New York. "It's good for Michigan because property taxes were very high."
Under the plan, Michigan, which ranked eighth nationwide in property tax burden, will raise $1.8 billion to $2 billion from additional state sales taxes, replacing the same amount in property taxes. And the cigarette tax, which would raise the price to an average of $2.55 a pack, would add $350 million in the 1994-95 school year. As a result of the plan's passage, the state education budget in the next school year will increase about 6 percent, to $10.2 billion from $9.6 billion this year.
The gap between rich and poor is not as pronounced in Michigan as in some states facing court challenges. The poorest districts spend about $3,200 a student, and the richest, $10,000. In New York, for example, the richest district spends nearly $46,000 per student, while New York City averages $6,644 for each student.
The Michigan plan will narrow the gap between rich and poor by giving districts a minimum of $4,200 a student and limiting spending increases by wealthier districts.
School officials had mixed reactions today to the vote. Some said the new plan would do for now.
 
'The Best Option'
 "Although this is still not the complete answer to equitable, adequate and stable funding of the schools in our state, it does provide the best option at this time," said David L. Snead, superintendent of Detroit Public Schools, the nation's seventh-largest school system with 169,000 students.
But in the state's richest district -- Bloomfield Hills, just north of Detroit -- officials lamented the passage of the plan. The district spends $10,400 a student, but the new plan will limit increases in state financing to 1.5 percent a year or less and limit what districts themselves may spend.
"Our schools won't look too different for the next two years," said W. Robert Docking, the superintendent. "But eventually, the state revenue cap will catch up with the district."
And that, he said, could require the district to increase elementary class sizes or cut things like foreign language classes for elementary grades and the extended high school day that allows students to take seven classes instead of five or six.
"I am pleased that the lowest-financed schools will receive more assistance," he added. "That absolutely had to happen." But not, he said, at the expense of affluent school systems.
Had the plan been defeated, the Legislature had already approved one to replace property taxes with income taxes by raising them to 6 percent from 4.6 percent. The backup plan won the support of the Michigan Education Association, the 127,000-member teachers' union, which argued that sales tax receipts were too likely to be reduced by recession. Data over the last 20 years from the Michigan Department of Treasury indicated that the sales tax revenue has grown in each of the last 20 years except one.
But Governor Engler had vowed to reduce property taxes when first elected three years ago. In doing so, he seized on the simmering discontent that other politicians from across the political spectrum have tried to do.
 
Appeal in Both Partiesxx
 "Property taxes as a political issue doesn't play more in one party than another," said Chris Pipho, a school finance expert with the Education Commission of the States, a Denver-based nonprofit group that conducts education research for states. "Property taxes have a way of being a good issue for candidates of either party. When the public feels that property taxes are too high, politicians have to rise to that occasion."
After failing to win voters' support last year for a similar effort to revise school financing, Mr. Engler succeeded this year in presenting residents with what they saw as a palatable alternative -- the sales tax. Michigan's 4 percent sales tax was one of the lowest in the nation and even with the increase it will be near the national average.
The Governor campaigned heavily for the proposal. Even his Democratic opponents concede that his re-election bid was enhanced by the plan's lopsided victory.
Other states that have tried to move to a system of equal school district financing have found those efforts blocked by legislators from affluent districts who do not want to see a forced reduction in spending for their constituents' children.
But that did not happen in Michigan, State Senator John Kelly, a Democrat who represents the affluent Detroit suburb of Grosse Pointe, said on Wednesday. He attributed that to the affluent disctricts' being principally represented by Republicans loyal to Mr. Engler and a plan critical to his political future after winning an upset victory in 1990 by less than one percent of the vote.
"Besides, with the aging population, 70 percent of their voters do not have kids in the schools, and lowering the property tax was a much greater priority for them," said Mr. Kelly, adding that others care less since they have joined a growing trend and placed their children in private schools.
In the late 1970's, California property owners rebelled leading to the landmark Proposition 13, which limited property-tax increases. But even in that state, property taxes still supply about one-third of school financing, with the rest coming from state sales taxes, income taxes and other taxes.
In Michigan, the reluctance of property owners to pay for greater shares of public school cycle finally ruptured a year ago, when the public schools in Kalkaska, about 240 miles northwest of Detroit, shut down three months early after voters rejected three property tax increases.
In the Kalkaska public schools, which stand to benefit under the new plan, the outlook today was uncertain. With the guaranteed amount from the state, the district will see its per student spending rise to $4,200 next year from $3,800 this year, but the Superintendent of Schools, Doyle Disbrow, said today that he was uncertain whether Kalkaska would have enough money in coming years to pay for an increasing number of programs required by the state.
"I'm still concerned," Mr. Disbrow said. "The only thing I hope is that the Legislature with the Governor's help at least makes sure the funding is there for schools over the next few years."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. John Engler of Michigan, a Republican who faces re-election, backed the school finance plan, saying it would improve schools without increasing the burden on property owners. On Tuesday night, after learning that voters had approved the proposal, he attended a victory celebration with his wife, Michelle. (The Associated Press) (pg. A21)
