HEADLINE: Persistent Racial Segregation Mars Suburbs' Green Dream

SERIES: Tarnished Haven -- Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ROOSEVELT, L.I.

 BODY:
When Marshella Atkinson's parents decided to leave Brooklyn for Long Island, the enthusiasm of friends and teachers made her smile with anticipation.
Perhaps they pictured the swimming pools of nearby Levittown, or the shopping centers of Garden City, or the well-stocked library and spotless corridors of Plainview-Old Bethpage High School. Ms. Atkinson is not sure. 
 But four years later, the 16-year-old does know one thing: They could not have meant Roosevelt, where boarded-up houses dot the walk home from high school and people complain that their streets are last to be plowed by the Town of Hempstead, where Roosevelt is the most troubled section.
"I think they set it up so that when a black family moves here, it ends up in Roosevelt," said Ms. Atkinson, a junior at Roosevelt High School. She glanced at a hole in her classroom ceiling where tiles had been ripped away. Graffiti scarred the walls. "I thought it was going to be a dream place," she said.
Drawn by the promise of escape from inner-city congestion and violence, more and more families like the Atkinsons are moving to America's suburbs. Like the white middle class before them, they come for a home of their own, good schools, open spaces and relative safety, everything that the suburbs symbolize in the American narrative.
But segregation is not declining as black and Hispanic people move to the suburbs, according to John R. Logan, a sociologist at the State University of New York at Albany, who has studied segregation around 10 major cities. Nationally, 1 black person in 3 now lives in the suburbs, but even those with middle-class incomes usually end up in middle-class pockets of poorer neighborhoods.
Lily-white communities tend not to become integrated but to remain largely lily-white, with the addition of well-defined minority precincts. On Long Island, 95 percent of black residents are concentrated in 5 percent of the census tracts. According to census data, the average white person in Nassau County lives in a census tract in which only 8 percent of the residents are black or Hispanic. The average white child attends a school that is just 9 percent black.
In New York City, by contrast, the comparable figure is 18 percent on either score, or more than twice the degree of integration, said Dr. Andrew A. Beveridge, director of the Program of Applied Social Research at Queens College of the City University of New York, who analyzed the data.
Suffolk, slightly less segregated than Nassau, is more like suburbs around the country, Professor Beveridge said.
 
Laws Have No Effect
 "Both within cities and suburbs, Hispanics and blacks are segregated, and they're forced to locate in the least desirable communities," Professor Logan said. "And I see no evidence that any change in civil rights laws or fair housing legislation is having any effect."
Of course, some blacks choose to live in black neighborhoods. Others opted for integrated areas that white flight has since rendered mostly black. Still others can afford only the cheapest suburban housing. But a great many blacks complain they are never shown the full range of housing choices or are discouraged from buying in predominantly white communities.
Once they arrive, blacks find that the suburban landscape and the suburban way of life increase racial isolation: The tendency to restrict parks, libraries and other amenities to local residents; to rely on cars rather than on mass transit, and to emphasize home rule in government promote a segregated existence, no matter what the intent.
 
White Flight
Integration, Then Racial Isolation
 While the Long Island suburbs, in their postwar expansion, were providing the blueprint for an America of the automobile age, the plan accepted white prejudices of the day, typically restricting the emerging communities to "members of the Caucasian race."
Federal laws now bar discrimination, but mechanisms of segregation endure. James Thomas landed in the Suffolk County hamlet of Bellport after a thwarted attempt to buy a house in white Port Jefferson 33 years ago. Mr. Thomas's mailman, who was white, offered to sell Mr. Thomas his Cape Cod in Bellport for $10,500. "You have to take where you can get," the retired factory supervisor said.
For 20 years, Bellport remained a "solid, good community." But what he thought was steady integration turned out to be a white hemorrhage. A decade ago, Mr. Thomas realized that the people moving in were no longer working class or middle class but getting by on government aid. Bellport became as blighted as any city neighborhood, its streets lined with prostitutes and certain corners given over to drug dealing.
Mr. Thomas looked across the hedges at a house that had burned down several months before: a jungle of exposed wires and half-fallen floors. For him, the delay in razing the house, since removed, was sure proof of the Town of Brookhaven's disregard for blacks. "You can't tell me that this would be left to stand this way in a white neighborhood," he said.
 
Services Dwindle
 Whites who bought homes in the suburbs typically began a lifelong climb up the social and economic ladder. Many blacks are forced to watch their investment decline as whites flee, poorer minorities move in and services dwindle. Homeowners like Ed Larson of the North Amityville Taxpayers Association meet to enlist police against drug peddlers, prostitutes and street crime, problems that seldom preoccupy their white counterparts.
"If the American dream is to buy a house in the suburbs, send your kid to a good school and have some grass, yes, it's the American dream," said Hugh A. Wilson, director of the Institute for Suburban Studies at Adelphi University. "If it's also to do that in an integrated setting, then for blacks, it's not fulfilling the dream."
Some blacks complain that isolation feeds a quiet acceptance of racism. Alton Williams, first vice president of the Nassau County Guardians, which represents black police officers, said he was shocked to see a white supremacist flyer on another officer's bulletin board. It showed a smiling blond child with the caption "MISSING: A future for white children in America."
"The fear is that if people from the inner city come out to this pristine land, it will be ruined," said Melvin Boone, president of the Guardians. "And by saying 'people from the inner city,' who are they talking about?"
"They're talking about me," Mr. Williams replied.
Mr. Boone nodded. "And about me," he said.
 
Fragmented Power
Property Taxes Punish Blacks
 In Roosevelt, 70 of the 92 members of the volunteer fire department are black. But last week the New York State Attorney General disclosed that for 26 years blacks had been kept out of a fraternal group that provided insurance for Roosevelt firefighters. The group was ordered to open its doors and pay $53,000 in retroactive benefits.
While overt racism is not the norm, many experts say that political and institutional barriers work against minority residents.
For example, the tax system on Long Island appears to penalize minorities. According an analysis of Census data, blacks on Long Island and in many other suburbs pay higher rates of property taxes than homeowners in more affluent white communities. Poorer blacks in effect subsidize wealthier whites.
In Suffolk County, blacks pay 17.6 percent higher property taxes than whites on homes of comparable market value, while in Nassau the figure is 5.6 percent. The data, which compared homes bought by blacks and whites in the 1980's, may actually understate the disparity by not including property taxes for longtime homeowners.
Tax experts say the disparity reflects voter pressure that protects the status quo and deters governments from reassessing properties in a timely fashion. As real estate values in many white communities soared throughout the 1980's, homes were seldom reassessed. When growing numbers of minority families were funneled into suburban neighborhoods where values dropped as whites began to flee, their homes were not reassessed downward either.
Overtaxing minority communities contributes to the higher number of foreclosures in these areas, said George Peterson of the Urban Institute. Money that homeowners could have spent on upkeep goes instead to pay bloated tax bills, planning officials say. Roosevelt's residents, like Sheila Caballero, executive director of the I Am Corporation, a nonprofit group that works to build self-esteem among black youngsters, say the neighborhood has only become more run down with the years.
 
No Blacks Elected Countywide
 Neither Nassau nor Suffolk has ever elected a black to countywide office. Nassau is under a court order to overhaul its form of government for failing adequately to represent the county's minority residents, 14 percent of its population.
At the town level, officials are typically elected at large, making it difficult for black or Hispanic people to be elected or to win support for issues important to their neighborhoods.
Ms. Caballero, who has campaigned for a youth center in Roosevelt, says the Hempstead Town Board, which elected its first black member last year, is consistently more attuned to the wealthier voters of Garden City. "Everywhere we turn, we're in a box, and we can't figure out how to get out of that box," she said.
 
The Next Generation
Patchwork Quilt Of School Districts
 In the public schools, too, many minority residents say they are ill served by a patchwork of school districts that protects local control over enrollment, programs and curriculum. The combination replicates in suburbia the disparities that the New York State Department of Education recently said most glaringly divide school districts in white, middle class suburbs from minority, low-income urban districts.
Recently, Raymond Mattry, a program coordinator for I Am, took some Roosevelt students to Plainview-Old Bethpage High School, where the New York Civil Liberties Union had come for an anti-hate workshop. Akilah Watkins, a junior from Roosevelt, seemed shocked by the contrast between her own high school and Plainview, with its almost all-white student body.
At Roosevelt, library books from the 1930's describe the Treaty of Versailles as the last word in arms limitation. The football team works out in a cramped room lighted by a bare bulb, on equipment that Joseph Vito confesses he borrowed from his town's recreation center. ("I don't think they noticed it's gone," the gym teacher said, ducking his head in embarrassment.)
At Plainview, the science chairman, Saul Reine, shows off his newest addition: a dedicated computer network that he was able to buy despite budget tightening.
"If you walked into our high school, you'd be surprised," Ms. Watkins told the audience. "It isn't anything like this."
During a later tour of Plainview-Old Bethpage, Gail Weinstein, an assistant principal, described extra steps the school takes to help students succeed: a ninth period set aside for remedial help and teachers monitoring the halls, both of which are written into the teacher contract.
The library door was open, the tables were filled with students. In the weight room, where one wall was covered with mirrors, a custodian dropped to his knees upon seeing some chewing gum on the carpet. "Oh, terrible," he mumbled and scraped it clean.
"There's a misconception that affluent communities don't have problems," Mr. Reine said. "They do. It's just we have a safety net to catch the children, to help them when they fall."
At both schools, students said that segregation created a gap in their education. "We aren't exposed to people of a different race," Ms. Watkins said.
At Plainview-Old Bethpage, student officers were discussing several proposals at a recent meeting: establishing an anti-vandalism fund, sectioning off a lounge in the cafeteria, helping the environmental club.
None of the youths expressed any defeatism until the subject was race. The students said they missed contact with black and Hispanic people, but suggested such exposure should have begun in elementary school.
"I think it would be a good thing, but I can't see it happening," said Shari Glockner, student vice president. "I feel so sheltered in this community."

HEADLINE: States Moving to Ease Tax Burden

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
From Maine to California, nearly a score of states are moving to cut taxes, while several others are taking steps to shift levies sharply away from a reliance on local property taxes.
As a consequence, 1994 is shaping up as the first year since 1985 in which the total weight of taxes imposed by state governments is expected to ease, a report being published today says. 
 "The season for cutting state taxes is here," said Steven D. Gold, director of the Center for the Study of the States in Albany and author of the report. "I'm surprised. I thought there would be very few tax cuts this year, but it's pretty widespread."
Heading the parade is Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, who enacted the first stage and proposed the second in her pledge to cut New Jersey income tax rates by 30 percent over three years. If the entire plan is approved by the Legislature, it would represent the largest overall reduction in a state's taxes in the 1990's.
 
Few States Increasing Taxes
 But Governor Whitman is far from alone. Lower taxes in one form or another are on the agenda in almost half the states across the country.
In particular, several states in the Northeast -- New York, Connecticut, Massachusetts and Pennsylvania -- are worried about further losses of people and jobs. Those worries have prompted them to compete for business with New Jersey and lower-tax states in other regions by offering tax cuts that, while much smaller, are often directed at encouraging companies to create jobs.
New Jersey and New Mexico have adopted first installments on multiyear tax reduction programs, and 17 other states are considering plans to lower taxes. Only a handful of states, including Alaska, Hawaii and Vermont, are considering tax increases.
Reasons for tax cut proposals vary from state to state. But a common thread is the improving national economy, which has fattened state coffers across the country.
 
'The No. 1 Frustration'
 With the recession over almost everywhere except in California and parts of New England, many governors, including several seeking re-election this year, are in a position to offer at least modest tax reductions before the voters go to the polls in the fall. Even in California, Gov. Pete Wilson has proposed a $135 million package to reduce taxes for those with incomes under $40,000 and offer companies a $1,000 tax cut for each new job created.
Republicans are more likely to offer state tax reductions. Democrats are joining in to promise some tax relief to a constituency of mostly middle-class residents often hard-pressed to maintain their standard of living.
"We're in a semi-tax-revolt mode here in Wisconsin," said Walter J. Kunicki, speaker of the Democratic-controlled State Assembly. It recently approved the speaker's proposal to eliminate local property taxes to finance education. "Rising property taxes are the number one frustration, driving farmers off their farms, the elderly out of their homes and essentially basing the quality of education upon where you are born," Mr. Kunicki said.
In a broader context, Vic Fingerhut, a Democratic poll taker and political consultant, argued that the pressure to limit both taxes and state spending reflects a two-decades-long squeeze on the earnings of average workers.
 
Property Tax Out of Favor
 "Democrats have been forced to act more like Republicans because of the decline in real incomes," he said. "Families want to hold on to every penny they have and that makes it really tough for the public sector."
Frank Luntz, a Republican poll taker, said Democrats and Republican incumbents alike "want to be on the side of the taxpayer when they go into an election season, not the side of the tax collector."
Wisconsin's Democrats want to follow Michigan's lead and replace lost property tax revenues with other revenue sources. Oregon and Nebraska, among others, introduced property tax relief in recent years. South Carolina, Idaho and Vermont are considering measures that would either cut property taxes or partly replace them with other revenue.
"There is a very significant trend in many states away from the property tax," said Scott Mackey of the National Conference of State Legislatures in Denver. "Rightly or wrongly, it is perceived as particularly unfair."
 
Tax Breaks for Businesses
 An even more popular choice for tax reductions these days are state taxes on business.
"States increasingly feel they are in a very competitive marketplace for jobs," said Timothy J. Bartik, an economist at the W. E. Upjohn Institute for Employment Research in Kalamazoo, Mich. "Business today is much more footloose. That places very intense pressures on states to escalate the economic incentive war."
To be sure, the scale of the proposed state tax cuts for 1994 are comparatively modest. With no change in taxes, state revenues should reach about $390 billion in the coming fiscal year, according to Mr. Gold of the state study center. Over all, state tax changes enacted this year are likely to add up to less than $3 billion in reductions.
That compares with a net state tax increase of $1.1 billion last year and $1.4 billion in 1992. The recession years of 1990 and 1991 took a heavy toll of state budgets, prompting states to increase taxes by $9.2 billion in 1990 and $14.4 billion in 1991, the center's research shows. The figures do not take account of local taxes.
Still, state taxes rarely fall at all. The last year in which state taxes declined was in 1985, when a booming economy allowed lawmakers to cut taxes by a net $1.3 billion while still expanding government services.
Since the beginning of the 1960's, the only period other than 1985 in which taxes were reduced was from 1978 to 1979. Ignited by the Proposition 13 property tax revolt in California, some states sharply cut taxes, while others reined in spending and held back on tax increases.

HEADLINE: U.S. Cancels Talks With North Korea Over Atom Inspections

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
The United States today canceled high-level talks with North Korea scheduled for next week and stepped up planning for military exercises with South Korea because of the North's refusal to permit international monitors to complete their inspection of a key nuclear installation.
The action brought Washington full-circle in its long negotiations over efforts to stop North Korea's suspected program to develop nuclear weapons. 
 When North Korea allowed international inspectors to visit its sites two weeks ago, the Clinton Administration presented the move as a potential breakthrough. But then North Korea refused to allow monitors to take some samples from its plutonium reprocessing plant at Yongbyon. Now, even optimists in the Administration are beginning to lose hope that a diplomatic solution will be reached.
A South Korean official said there was only "a slim chance" that the North Koreans would relent and allow the inspections soon.
 
Energy Agency Meets Monday
 Representatives to the International Atomic Energy Agency, based in Vienna, plan to take up the inspection issue on Monday. Administration officials said the agency's board of governors was expected to issue a final demand that Pyongyang allow the inspectors to return to finish their work. If the North Koreans refuse, the board is likely to recommend that the matter be referred to the United Nations Security Council so it can consider imposing economic sanctions.
"This time the North went too far," an Administration official said. "There are no more carrots. We pushed the limit with our Feb. 25 agreement."
American and South Korean officials consulted today on holding the joint military exercise the two countries customarily conduct in the spring to rehearse the defense of South Korea. The exercise was suspended for this year on condition that the North Koreans allow the inspections to proceed and agree to an exchange of envoys with the South, neither of which has occurred.
A South Korean official, who asked not to be identified, noted that his Government had publicly committed itself to proceeding with the exercise if the North Koreans balked at allowing the inspections. He said his Government would have "no choice" but to go ahead with the exercise if the Atomic Energy Agency determined that North Korea would not yield on nuclear inspection, but added that the timing of the exercise remained a question.
 
Curbs on Scheduling
 The exercise is commonly held in the early part of the year before the onset of the planting season in South Korea so it does not interfere with farming. If it is not held soon, a State Department official said, Washington and Seoul will have to wait until the fall.
Washington, however, would have other ways to show its disapproval of the North Korean stance. Navy officials said two aircraft carriers were in the Northern Pacific. American ships could conduct exercises in the Sea of Japan as a signal that the United States has the means to enforce economic sanctions.
Providing details about the inspections, officials said the Atomic Energy Agency specified in advance what sort of monitoring it wanted to conduct at North Korea's seven officially disclosed nuclear sites. The North Koreans agreed to the plan.
Once the inspections were under way, however, the monitors encountered problems when they sought to take samples from the plutonium reprocessing plant at Yongbyon, 60 miles north of Pyongyang. The North Koreans allowed some samples to be taken but stopped the inspectors from taking others.
Adding to the suspicions, one of the seals that inspectors had placed on nuclear equipment in the reprocessing plant was discovered to have been broken. "There was an association between the broken seal and the need to take the sample," an Administration official said.
That raised the possibility that the North Koreans had used the plant to handle plutonium it had produced or had reprocessed plutonium from a secret supply of fuel rods that it had previously removed from the reactor.
Washington complained about the restrictions on the inspectors, hoping that they would be allowed to finish their work before they left North Korea. But the North refused.
While officials said the North Korea stance had led the Administration to cancel the high-level talks, which were scheduled to begin in Geneva on Monday, the State Department officially kept open the slimmest of hopes that the talks might yet proceed.
"It would appear that that meeting on Monday is now doubtful," said a State Department spokesman, Michael McCurry. "I don't see how it's going to happen."
The failure of diplomatic efforts would make economic sanctions the main means of compelling North Korea to submit its nuclear installations to proper inspection.
 
Asians Cool to Sanctions
 But Asian nations have always been reluctant to support sanctions for diplomatic and economic reasons, and this has reinforced the ambivalence in the Administration about taking forceful action to contain North Korean nuclear development efforts.
The support of China would be crucial because it is a member of the Security Council and has a long border with North Korea. But China has never been supportive of sanctions, and American relations with Beijing are strained.
Japan is also reluctant to support measures to cut off financial transfers to North Korea from Koreans living in Japan.
A South Korean official said it was important to "keep the dialogue open" between North and South Korea and noted that talks between the two sides on the exchange of envoys are scheduled to continue on Saturday.
Mr. McCurry said Secretary of State Warren Christopher was encouraged to pursue diplomacy during his recent trip to China and Japan. "I cannot say in either location there was enthusiasm about sanctions," he said.

HEADLINE: Los Angeles Is Taking Rapid Road to Recovery

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 16

 BODY:
Two months after it was jolted by one of the most powerful and costliest earthquakes to hit the United States, Los Angeles is making a fast recovery.
Southern California's economy, already showing signs of pulling out of recession, is getting a jump start from the $15 billion in reconstruction aid that has started flowing in: $11.5 billion in Federal and state money and $3.5 billion in insurance payments. In June, Californians will vote on a $2 billion bond issue for quake repairs. 
 The latest unemployment survey uncovered a significant post-quake dip in joblessness in Los Angeles in February, to 9.7 percent from 11 percent.
Nancy Bolton, who specializes in the California economy for the Business Forecasting Project at the University of California at Los Angeles, said, "It's a one-shot thing, not a permanent creation of jobs and markets, but every little bit helps when you've been through what Southern California has been through."
 
Segue Into Economic Pickup?
 While unemployment might start to rise again once the reconstruction winds down, the setback might not be particularly great, Ms. Bolton said, because the economy could be producing more jobs here by early summer.
Today, workers are rebuilding Angelenos' freeways with a headlong vengeance and are hammering dawn to dusk on crunched houses, offices and malls.
True, a few residents have fled, hastened by the hundreds of aftershocks that cause no new damage but are a reminder that the "big one" is still to come. Many people have lost jobs, homes and businesses and will not soon recover, if ever.
But for the most part, Los Angeles is picking itself up off the mat one more time after being floored earlier by recession, riots, fires and mud slides.
"I'm toughing it out, and I'm going to make it," said Laura D'Angelo, the owner of Kids At Heart, a children's novelty store in the Northridge area of the San Fernando Valley, the epicenter of the quake.
"I'm open for business even though the ceiling is still sagging and one wall is propped up," said Ms. D'Angelo, whose store was closed only six days. "I don't say things are good. Not yet. Sales are off at least 30 percent."
The quake, measuring 6.7 on the Richter scale, left 61 people dead, 9,000 injured and 25,000 homeless. It seriously damaged more than 30,000 houses, apartments and businesses, many beyond repair, and left perhaps 250,000 others with minor damage.
State disaster officials still do not know how many jobs and businesses have been permanently lost. Nor have they been able to compute lost wages and sales, though initial indications are that tourism, an economic pillar of the region, is holding up well. Gov. Pete Wilson has estimated the overall cost of the quake at more than $20 billion.
Despite such losses, the recovery effort is providing a much-needed economic boost, as often happens in disasters. It is creating jobs in construction and markets to offset some costs of the destruction.
More than 450,000 applications for disaster aid have been submitted to the Federal Emergency Management Agency, a national record in requests for recovery money, and the agency has so far handed out $870 million. After investigators uncovered a few early cases of fraud, officials said they had begun careful cross-checks for bogus applications.
The people who lost their homes in the quake have found new homes -- there was an 8 percent housing surplus at the time of the quake -- or they have moved in with friends or relatives. Frequently, it is a spare, uncomfortable and costly existence, but it is a step back toward normality.
 
'It's a Good Life'
 "Our house is in danger of collapsing, so we sleep in what's left of the garage," George Wolfus, a Northridge optometrist, said this week. "We lost all of our china, and so we're eating off paper plates. Eventually, we'll get it all back together. It's a good life."
But Mr. Wolfus has still not been able to repair and reopen his office.
"I can't take much more of this because I've got no cash flow," he said. "The damage is so bad that I may eventually have to move to a new building. But places are opening up everywhere as more repairs get done."
The progress is not difficult to track.
The yellow barrier tape that building inspectors strung around badly cracked structures is steadily coming down. Disappearing, too, are the plywood and plastic sheets nailed up to cover collapsed walls and smashed windows.
In the Los Angeles areas worst hit by the tremor -- the San Fernando Valley and Hollywood -- and in the adjacent city of Santa Monica, every street and shopping plaza is crowded with contractors' trucks loaded with lumber and brick.
"Before the quake, business was bad and I was doing maybe one job a month," said Joel Johnston of Johnston's Construction. "Now I'm doing two or three a week. Things are at a nice pace."
Lest anyone miss the recovery, many malls and stores have hung bright orange banners that proclaim "Open!" and "We're Back!"
While insurance will cover a good part of the quake damage -- 40 percent of the structures in the Los Angeles area are covered to some degree -- many property owners still face substantial repair bills. Quake insurance policies, which cost about $2 for each $1,000 of coverage, typically carry deductibles of 10 percent or more.
"My damage turns out to be just exactly the amount of my deductible -- $30,000," said Alan Holleb, a screenwriter whose $300,000 house in Santa Monica was badly cracked. "It's going to be a financial strain."
For the moment, Mr. Holleb is making do with his own patching work. He has been unable to find a contractor who is not booked with other quake recovery jobs.
Perhaps the most telling sign of recovery is the repair work on a half-dozen crippling breaks and 200 less serious cracks and strains in the region's 600 miles of freeways. The contractors, promised a big bonus for completing the job early, are well ahead of schedule.
State highway officials say the break in the Santa Monica Freeway, which runs west from downtown to the Pacific Ocean, will be repaired by May, a month early. The crumpled spans have been hauled off and the framework is up for pouring new concrete.
 
Road Work Ahead of Schedule
 "Normally a break like this would take a year to repair," said Jerry Baxter, district director for the California Transportation Department, "but we're going to get it done in just four months."
The rebuilding of the collapsed intersection of the Golden State and Antelope Valley freeways, north of Los Angeles near Santa Clarita, is proceeding more slowly. Because that intersection incorporates soaring overpasses, the reconstruction will not be complete until the end of the year.
In the meantime, how bad are traffic jams?
Ever resourceful when it comes to the automobile, Angelenos have found ways to work around most of the breaks, reducing to 20 minutes the average delay in commuting to work. In the days immediately after the quake, 90-minute delays were common.
Back then, in a burst of "telecommuting," many people began working out of their homes or neighborhood offices, communicating with their headquarters via computers. But the drivers quickly drifted back to their old commuting habits as traffic delays were reduced.
The widespread damage the quake inflicted on freeways has impelled state officials to speed up a lagging $1 billion program to strengthen highway bridges throughout California so that they will be less subject to tremors. No bridge that had already been strengthened was damaged on Jan. 17.
Computing the cost of repairing a damaged freeway or house has been difficult enough; figuring up the psychic damage is all but impossible.
"There's still a lot of anxiety and fear," said Dr. Patricia Mendoza, the director of a counseling program set up after the quake by the Los Angeles County Department of Mental Health.
At that time the project received more than 100 calls an hour. Two months later, it still gets as least 250 calls a day.
 
Pyschological Troubles
 "They're more intense and they take longer to handle now," Dr. Mendoza said. He said callers tell of sleep deprivation, an abiding emptiness after losing worldly possessions, suicidal impulses and hours spent worrying about the "big one," the giant earthquake that seismologists say is inevitable here because of geologic pressures building deep in rock stratas.
Jan Farquhar, a medical technician, has not requested counseling, but she said the quake had left her "a nervous wreck."
"Sometimes I wake up in the night just scared to death," Ms. Farquhar said. "I keep wondering when the next quake is going to hit."
She has decided not to wait around for it. "I've been thinking about moving to Georgia," she said, "and now I'm going to do it."
Though solid numbers are hard to come by, moving companies report a post-quake increase in moves to other states.
But earthquake experts say the migration will probably not last. They note that San Francisco, Tokyo and other cities hit by quakes initially experienced some flight but within a few months began to add population.
For those Angelenos who have decided to wait for the big one, there is a new niche store in the Glendale Galleria in San Fernando Valley, not far from the epicenter of the quake. It is called Be Ready Disaster Preparedness and offers everything from dried food to hard hats. It also sells pepper spray to chase off looters.

HEADLINE: Despite Foe, Burmese Junta Finds a Silver Lining

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: YANGON, Myanmar

 BODY:
The generals who run Myanmar in many ways hold a tighter grip on the country than at any time since their 1988 crackdown on the democracy movement, even as they ponder whether to open negotiations with the woman who has threatened to end the military's decades in power.
Their foe is Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the opposition leader and Nobel Peace Prize winner who is now in her fifth year under house arrest in the capital, Yangon. 
 While the junta has ruled out early talks with Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, military commanders have conceded that they may eventually want to open up some sort of dialogue with her. In February, she was permitted her first non-family foreign visitor since 1989, an American Congressman. The military's sudden willingness to consider talks with Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi has puzzled some diplomats and Burma scholars if only because the situation for the generals had otherwise seemed so promising.
 
Good News for the Junta
 Recently, there has been no shortage of encouraging news for the junta. The long-stagnant Burmese economy is growing, bolstered by the discovery of natural gas offshore and market reforms; the military has reached peace agreements with several ethnic rebel groups; the army has found a reliable arms supplier across the border in China, and the opposition movement once led by Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi has been all but crushed, its leaders either still in prison or too frightened to act.
"We do not like the army, but we cannot deny that it is in control," said a member of Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's political party, the National League for Democracy, which won a landslide victory in a national election in 1990 that was voided by the military. "Aung San Suu Kyi is the last hope of the people."
Diplomats are hoping that the decision to allow Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi to break her silence indicates a new pragmatism on the part of Myanmar's military leadership, particularly Lieut. Gen. Khin Nyunt, the steely-eyed director of military intelligence who appears to head the junta.
 
End of an Era
 "This may be the sign that the Ne Win era is over," said a diplomat, referring to Gen. Ne Win, the military leader whose isolationist policies during more than a quarter-century in power turned the country this resource-rich country into one of the poorest nations on earth. General Ne Win, who is in his 80's, is said to continue to play an important advisory role to the Government.
"Khin Nyunt and those around him may have decided that it is time for Burma to re-enter the world," another diplomat said, using the former name of Myanmar. "Not because they have to. Perhaps just because it is embarrassing for the generals to be such pariahs in the world."
Admired for his intelligence and feared for the security apparatus he leads, General Khin Nyunt seems to understand the dangers posed to his own position in the junta should he act unilaterally in dealing with Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi. He is not, therefore, moving quickly to accept the offer of talks with the democracy leader.
He emphasized in an interview on March 6 that the decision must be made by all of his colleagues in the Government, and that it would take time. "This is not a matter to be taken up lightly," he said.
Yet even as he dismissed Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi as a woman "who has no political background in this country" and whose loyalty to Myanmar was in question because she had lived abroad much of her life, he said that he had recently sent senior military officers "who report directly to me" to talk with her in hope of some sort of dialogue.
 
Seeks Better Relations With U.S.
 For the first time, he seemed to suggest reasons for the junta's willingness to make concessions to Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, including its desire for normal diplomatic and trade ties with the United States, which has led the international campaign to isolate Myanmar because of its dismal human rights record.
"Prior to 1988, relations between Myanmar and the United States were always very close," the general said. "And we want to go back to that relationship." The United States has cut off all aid to Myanmar and has refused to post an ambassador here for several years.
The junta, which calls itself the State Law and Order Restoration Council, formally took power in 1988, replacing what was then a civilian-led but military-dominated Government. The generals assumed total control of the Government in the midst of a bloody army crackdown on democracy demonstrations, in which soldiers are believed to have killed 2,000 to 5,000 followers of Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi.
From the day the junta took power, foreign governments and human rights groups have been blistering in their criticism. In February, a special human rights investigator for the United Nations, Yozu Yokota, asserted that "atrocities are being committed consistently and on a wide scale by the soldiers of the Myanmar Army."
In January, Amnesty International reported that while there had been "certain incremental improvements" in the human rights situation in Myanmar, torture and other abuses by the military were still common.
 
Central Planning Abandoned
 The junta has won praise for one of its policies -- its decision to abandon 30 years of central planning, known as the "Burmese Way to Socialism," and embrace the free market.
The result is most obvious in the streets of the major cities. Yangon, -- still better known to the outside world by its former name, Rangoon -- now pulsates with capitalist energy.
Market stalls are overflowing with imported goods, most of them from neighboring China and Thailand, and the city's streets, once empty, are crowded with new foreign cars. Private hotels and restaurants have opened. Because farmers are now free to sell at market prices, there were bumper crops last year, including a near-record rice harvest.
 
What Price Silence?
 "It's like China," said an engineering student at Yangon University, once the center for the democracy movement and today a virtual armed camp, with plainclothes military intelligence officers believed to be on every corner of the campus. The student looked repeatedly over his shoulder as he whispered to a stranger. "The Government is trying to buy our silence with a better economy," he said.
According to official statistics, the economy grew last year by 10.9 percent. While many foreign embassies believe the figure to be overstated, the true figure -- perhaps 4 to 5 percent -- is still impressive after several years in which the economy stagnated or shrank.
The economy is expected to be strengthened over the next several years by revenues from large deposits of natural gas recently detected offshore. A consortium that includes the French energy company Total is reported to have discovered at least five trillion cubic feet of natural gas in the Andaman Sea, worth billions of dollars.
Investors from several neighboring countries are looking more seriously at Myanmar. "Should you be interested in one person or in 42 million people?" the Minister for National Planning, Brig. Gen. David O. Abel, said when asked about Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi. "Investment is growing. Business people aren't interested in politics."

HEADLINE: As the Boss Goes, So Goes the Secretary: Is It Bias?

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN 

 BODY:
Women in professional jobs have workplace issues like the glass ceiling and the mommy track.
But now there is one for secretaries: rug-ranking. 
 "If the secretary's pay is based on her boss's status, not on the content of her job, that's rug-ranking -- treating her as a perk like the size of his office or the quality of the carpet on his floor," said N. Elizabeth Fried, a labor consultant based in Dublin, Ohio. "Secretaries are the only ones in the corporate world whose pay is directly linked to the boss. Instead of a career path of their own, most secretaries have had a hitch-your-wagon-to-a-star reward system."
Though women have advanced into many male-dominated fields, 3.5 million women work as secretaries, making secretarial work the largest job category for women nationwide, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Some managers see nothing wrong with paying secretaries on the basis of their boss's status. Those who work for high-level bosses generally have high-level responsibilities and access to confidential information, these managers say. They also point out that many people within a business rise and fall with their mentors, even where there is no direct link between their boss's status and their pay.
Rug-ranking bothers many advocates for women in the workplace, however; they find it altogether too reminiscent of the days when women were legally chattel and socially dependent. And banking on someone else's success can be just as perilous in the working world as in the domestic one: a private secretary displaced by her boss's demotion or retirement can be left in the lurch just as much as a homemaker is displaced by divorce or widowhood.
"It's just like the woman who marries the successful man and gets the better home," said Karen Nussbaum, director of the Women's Bureau of the Labor Department, and founder of 9 to 5, National Association of Working Women. "Women workers need to have objective standards on which they can rise, and their pay should be based on skill levels and job responsibilities."
Many large corporations have got the message. For a variety of reasons -- sensitivity to women's issues, fear of litigation, changing economics and reshaped secretarial duties -- they are quietly revising the way they pay secretaries, adopting compensation standards based more on job content.
Last year, Xerox began evaluating and paying secretaries based on the duties they perform, not on the level of manager to whom they report.
"The recommendations came from a team, made up mostly of secretaries, who studied the issue for a long time," said Tom Abbott, a Xerox spokesman. "Another thing they recommended was that they be called administrative assistants, which we now do."
 
New Roles for Secretaries
 Feminist concerns aside, rug-ranking may be on its way to extinction because most secretarial work itself is being transformed.
"The connection to an individual boss is becoming much less common," Ms. Nussbaum said. "With more bosses learning to do their own data entry, and downsizing, most secretaries now work for a half-dozen different bosses, far away in another room, or even in another building."
Ms. Fried, who has surveyed secretarial compensation periodically since 1988, has found a significant move away from rug-ranking since she began her questioning. In her 1993 survey of 478 companies, only 28.7 percent based secretarial pay solely on the level of the manager, compared with 46.9 percent in the 1988 survey.
"I think the whole issue of compensation in pink-collar positions is something corporations are looking at," said Paul Salvatore, an employment lawyer in New York. "Where there's an alleged inequity, employers know a plaintiff's lawyer will not be far behind."
 
Legal Challenges
 Rug-ranking has not often led to litigation, in part because the system has worked well for so many secretaries who stayed with one boss for many years, earning higher pay as the boss climbed the corporate ladder.
But in an era of corporate reorganizations and reduced workforces -- and at a time when voice mail and word-processors have made private secretaries a dwindling breed -- the system works less well.
And recently, in a few scattered cases across the country, rug-ranking has created legal headaches for corporations.
Elaine Truskoski, an executive secretary at ESPN, the television sports network based in Bristol, Conn., filed a legal complaint alleging sex discrimination after her boss was demoted in a corporate reorganization -- and so was she.
"It was ridiculous," said Ms. Truskoski, who had had a private office as secretary to an executive vice president, Allan B. Connal. "My job skills didn't change when he got demoted. And no one else in the department got dropped a grade because he was gone. It was like I was his personal property."
 
Complaint Withdrawn
 Ms. Truskoski, 46, filed a complaint with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, charging that because the rug-ranking system applied only to secretaries (all the ESPN secretaries were women), it was a form of sex discrimination.
She withdrew the complaint after ESPN promised to end the practice. But then ESPN put her to work photocopying all day, gave her 30 days to find a job within the company comparable to her old one -- though none were available -- and finally dismissed her.
Michael Soltys, a spokesman for ESPN, said that Ms. Truskoski had been offered three secretarial jobs at the same pay, but not as an executive secretary.
But Ms. Truskoski filed suit in Federal court, contending that the company was unfairly retaliating for her complaint about the pay system. Last spring, she won reinstatement to a secretarial job paying $30,000 a year and was awarded $115,000 to pay her legal bills.
Since then, a few other secretaries have made similar claims. Usually they involved a boss retiring and the secretary being displaced by the new boss's secretary.
"One of my clients has a case where an executive retired, and his replacement wanted to bring her own secretary with her," said Greg Rasin, a New York employment lawyer. "They offered the old secretary a position for a lower executive, and they didn't cut her salary, but they did red-circle it, so she wouldn't get a raise again soon. She has filed a complaint."
 
'An Ego Thing for Boss'
 Mr. Rasin said he was not asked for advice until after the fact, but he said he would not have advised the company to behave any differently.
"I don't think this is discrimination; I do think a person has the right to bring their own secretary," he said. "I don't see that this situation is so different from what happens when I.B.M. names a new chief executive officer and suddenly there's a lot of people in high levels resigning. It may not be as formal as with secretaries, but lots of people are linked to their bosses."
Still, some plaintiff lawyers who handle employment litigation say that even if rug-ranking is not found to be a form of sex discrimination, the practice may be vulnerable to class-action lawsuits based on the idea of comparable worth, namely that jobs of comparable difficulty should be paid comparably.
"I think it's mostly an ego thing for the boss: their name on the door, their rug on the floor, their secretary gets more," said Judith Vladeck, a New York employment lawyer. "It isn't really about paying secretaries for their work."

HEADLINE: Budget Wizardry in New Jersey

 BODY:
Popular, yes. Prudent, no. That describes Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's first budget.
She has delivered what she promised New Jersey voters. She is cutting taxes without at the same time cutting school and municipal aid in a way that forces property tax increases. But she works this wizardry with a large dose of gimmicks to cover a deficit that her tax cuts enlarged. 
 Mrs. Whitman won election on a promise to slash personal income taxes 30 percent. Even before tipping her hand on spending cuts, she persuaded the Legislature to approve an initial tax cut. Now, in her budget message, she seeks another.
For the year starting July 1, Governor Whitman outlined $15.5 billion of state spending, close to the current level -- a clear break from the past pattern of yearly increases, and no small accomplishment. In the details, she proposes to trim a little here and add a little there, still not revealing basic priorities.
She spoke of "remaking government" but proposed only to kill two agencies with small budgets, phase out support for public TV and sell two marinas. On some counts her ax was well aimed, like eliminating an outdated state subsidy to public employees.
Mrs. Whitman had also promised she would not cut municipal or school aid, so local jurisdictions would not be forced to raise property taxes. Her budget holds to this promise with imprudent gimmickry. It reduces state aid, though without injury to municipal or school budgets, because it would also reduce their annual contributions to their pension and health plans.
Since the Governor would not tinker with the pension plans themselves, this simply postpones contributions to another day -- and another governor. Meanwhile, local authorities say they must raise property taxes if state aid is not increased -- because they are already committed to paying higher salaries.
Mrs. Whitman also resorts to a bundle of one-shot revenues, of the sort she criticized in her campaign against Gov. Jim Florio. These are unspent deposits totaling $85 million in state trust funds -- for things like pollution prevention, recycling and relief for children with catastrophic illness. These will be a help in balancing this year's budget, but no help for the future. Indeed, they pose potential future problems if the state economy is in another recession when the money is needed.
Mrs. Whitman made her tax-cut promise late in last fall's campaign, when she was trailing. That promise now drives her budget. It is obviously popular. But she has yet to devise a long-term plan free of gimmicks.

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Poly Lobby

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: HONOLULU

 BODY:
The "poly lobby" the legion of psychological charlatans who claim their machines can unerringly detect lying -- suffered a severe setback when it was revealed that Aldrich Ames, the accused Russian mole, passed two polygraph exams.
The merchants of sweat at the F.B.I. moved quickly to protect their livelihood by putting out word that the machines worked -- but that incompetent C.I.A. polygraphers had read the results wrong. 
 The C.I.A. angrily disputes this leak from the poly lobby even as it reviews old cardiovascular charts of top officials. This leads to a Catch-22: Nobody can tell who's lying because each side knows how to beat the lie detector.
Washington's reliance on this device, which often wrongly accuses nervous truth-tellers and clears cool liars, may have led to the execution of 10 or more of our agents in Moscow.
Consider the possible fallout, if spymaster Kryuchkov followed the usual tradecraft: Before arresting our spies during the middle and late 80's, the K.G.B. fed false data for years to these doomed agents. No wonder C.I.A. analysts completely misread the size of the Soviet economy, which led them to egregiously mis-estimate the percentage going to armaments, and finally to the greatest intelligence fiasco of the cold war: failing to predict the likelihood of Soviet economic collapse.
I remember going out to Langley during the William Webster directorship for an on-the-record argument on this central subject; his deputy, Robert Gates, mightily resisted the appointment of a "team B" of eminent private economists to challenge the disinformation being swallowed by his analysts.
Now the C.I.A. is on a belated molehunt to find higher-ups who advanced Aldrich Ames's career. The world is turned upside down: Golitsyn is more credible, Nosenko less; Angleton was right and Colby tragically wrong; Yurchenko was not a real defector but a dangle. Among our best espionage writers, the legendary Epstein looks wiser than Wise.
As red-faced security teams retrace the feline steps, let us hope they remember the cost in agents' blood and agency failure of foolish reliance on the merchants of sweat.
Incredibly, however, the well-connected poly lobby has hornswoggled a group of Clintonites charged a year ago with a review of security procedures at C.I.A., N.S.A. and Defense. In its recent report, the section on polygraphs is an invitation to further undermine national security while diminishing personal freedom.
After accurately stating "there is no physiological response that is unique to deception," the report on "Redefining Security" then proceeds with exquisite evenhandedness.
Among the polygraph's "advantages": It scares those untrained in ways to beat the machine, sometimes eliciting admissions of guilt without the use of physical torture; it has been praised in a series of self-serving reports by the poly lobby; and it is supposedly "cost effective," saving "the considerable cost and time of conducting a background investigation." (Tell that last to the families of our dead agents.)
The poly's listed drawbacks: "Lack of scientific validity," found in Congressional studies in 1983 and 1991, and "unless the validity of the process can be demonstrated, there is nothing to prevent a practiced deceiver from passing a polygraph examination." More to the essence of American justice: "there will be occasions in which innocent people are falsely accused and guilty people avoid detection."
Then a sentence beginning "also" -- hastily added at the end, after the alleged mole was discovered -- piously decries "overreliance" on polygraphs when financial checks should be undertaken, "increasing the likelihood of spies being hired. . . ."
Does the Clinton panel urge curtailment of this abomination? Just the opposite. It calls for a new West Point for polygraphers; the further infection of the defense establishment with the moral standards of the espionage world; worst, research into "other methods of detecting deception" -- which means forcing brains into PET scans.
The Clintonites, influenced by the poly lobby, became so focused on mechanical defenses that they lost sight of the freedom America seeks to defend.

HEADLINE: Why Take the Half-Step of Clinton Health Plan?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In "Alliances for Progress" (Op-Ed, March 6), Prof. Paul Starr is on the money in pointing out that "with the rise of managed care, employers now choose which doctors and hospitals their workers and families use," calling this "an extraordinary usurpation: no one would tolerate an employer's dictating its employees' choice of schools or housing." 
 Professor Starr also notes that America's health care system is burdened by "staggering administrative costs" of 40 cents on the dollar. He then states that the health alliances in President Clinton's plan are the best way to fix both problems.
Yes, "the economies of joint purchasing" might "cut the high administrative costs that plague the insurance market." But by how much? And presenting consumers several managed care plans wouldn't give us what we want. Is it much of an improvement to let insurance companies, rather than employers, tell us what health care providers we can use, even with a choice of plans?
Look at it this way: Today I'm healthy. I don't know if I'll get sick next year, much less what specialists an illness may require. So my choice of a health plan will be like a shot in the dark, perhaps on a friend's recommendation, or maybe just because it's the least expensive. What happens if I become ill and am not favorably impressed with the plan's services? I'll be stuck with it until the next "open enrollment" to make a switch. And, if I've recovered by then, I will be no wiser in judging the merits of other plans competing in our mythical health care "free market."
It's odd that Mr. Starr reviews only Representative Jim Cooper's bill and a talked-about opening of Medicare to those younger than 65 as alternatives to the Clinton proposal. There is a better solution: the Wellstone-McDermott-Conyers single-payer bill (S. 491, H.R. 1200). Many experts, including the Congressional Budget Office, say it will save much more money than the President's plan. Better yet, instead of a choice of insurance plans (all containing financial barriers like co-payments and deductibles), it will give consumers what they really want: full freedom to choose their health care providers -- with no out-of-pocket expenses for medical services.
 
JOHN GLASEL
Tenafly, N.J., March 7, 1994

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Inflation Data Hurt Gold; Dollar Drifts a Little Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar drifted lower in light trading yesterday after showing little reaction to a Government report of low inflation. But the report on February's Consumer Price Index depressed the prices of gold and other precious metals.
The Labor Department reported that February consumer prices rose 0.3 percent, an annualized rate of 3.3 percent. The increase was in line with economists' expectations, and so the dollar showed almost no reaction after release of the much-anticipated report, traders said. 
 The consumer price survey followed Tuesday's Producer Price Index, a measure of inflation on the wholesale level. The producer price report showed an increase of five-tenths of 1 percent in February, but when food and energy were excluded, the gain was one-tenth of 1 percent.
"Certainly, the question is, where is the inflation?" Curtis Perkins, a currency trader at Chemical Bank, said.
Dealers had expected the dollar to rise if the reports showed greater-than-expected inflation. They reasoned that the Federal Reserve would respond to signs of inflation by pushing up short-term interest rates to cool economic activity.
The higher rates would make the dollar more valuable against other currencies. With that possibility less likely, the bond market rallied, pushing down the yield of the Treasury's 30-year bond to 6.80 percent from 6.89 percent on Tuesday.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted yesterday at 106.05 Japanese yen, down from 106.10 yen on Tuesday. It also fell to 1.6885 German marks from 1.6965 marks. The British pound advanced to $1.4945 from $1.49075.
At the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for April delivery fell $2, to $385.60 an ounce, while May silver fell 8.6 cents, to $5.402 an ounce. April platinum dropped $3, to $403.40 an ounce, on the New York Mercantile Exchange
The reports of low inflation led gold investors to ignore news that a strike at South Africa's richest mine had entered a third day. The mine's owner had said output could be affected if the strike went beyond four days. Peter Cardillo, director of research for Westfalia Investments in New York, predicted, "Given the fundamentals and present world economic situation, prices are going to remain in the doldrums unless something unforeseen happens."

HEADLINE: Congressional Economist Backs Arms Budget Plan

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
Congress's chief economist said today that the Pentagon's $1.2 trillion long-range budget was sufficient to pay for the troops and equipment the military says it needs to carry out its future fighting strategy.
The official, Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, told the House Armed Services Committee that the Defense Department might have overstated projected savings from base closings and underestimated environmental cleanup expenses and possible cost overruns on new weapons. But he said the budget office was "relatively sanguine" about the affordability of the plan. 
 Defense Secretary William J. Perry has said the Pentagon's budget through 1999 would be short by $20 billion, largely because inflation estimates are higher than originally projected. But Mr. Reischauer seemed to play down the shortage today, saying that even if the inflation estimates turned out to be true, they amounted to only about 2 percent of the long-range budget.
"By our judgment, the force structure and the budget are roughly consistent, although there is a lot of uncertainty," Mr. Reischauer said.
 
Importance of Endorsement
 The endorsement from Mr. Reischauer, who has challenged the military's budget projections in the past, is important because lawmakers from both parties, and even some of America's senior military commanders, have criticized the Pentagon's plan as unaffordable or unworkable.
Lawmakers listened somewhat skeptically to Mr. Reischauer's analysis. Some Republicans and conservative Democrats say the Administration is cutting too far, too fast for the military to meet its worst-case strategy of fighting two regional wars simultaneously.
"I am convinced that there are significant mismatches between the Clinton defense strategy and the Clinton defense program and budget," said Representative Floyd D. Spence, Republican of South Carolina.
Liberal Democrats contend that the Pentagon could cut more without undermining national security. "With real defense spending projected to remain above 80 percent of the cold war average, we must ask whether defense spending has really been cut as far as possible without undue military risk," said Representative Ronald V. Dellums, a California Democrat who heads the committee.
The Administration's plan cuts $100 billion from what the Bush Administration proposed to spend through 1999, but it backs the same two-war strategy.
Mr. Reischauer said the Pentagon could cut another $23 billion over five years and still meet the requirement to fight two wars.
The budget office focused most of its analysis on the Pentagon's assumptions, and the possible flaws in its approach. In addition to the potential shortfalls because of inflation, Mr. Reischauer said the Pentagon might have overestimated savings from base closings by as much as $10 billion over five years and underestimated environmental cleanup costs by $20 billion.
 
Other Possible Savings
 He also cited several areas where the Pentagon might reap further savings beyond what was included in the budget plan. The Administration might reduce the nation's strategic nuclear arsenal, resulting in additional savings of $8 billion over the five years, the budget office estimated. In addition, the Pentagon is overhauling the cumbersome system it uses to buy more than $50 billion a year in new weapons. New, more efficient techniques to clean up contaminated sites at military installations could yield more savings.
The budget office also endorsed the Pentagon's assumptions that the declining number of American troops, dropping to 1.4 million by 1999 from 1.7 million now, would be sufficient to fight the two-war strategy.

International
Critics of the North American Free Trade Agreement had warned it would push U.S. companies to move to Mexico. Yet in the four months since Congress approved the pact, the boldest acquisitions have been made by Mexican companies in the U.S. [Page D1.]
China has sought out international markets for its growing industries. It was just such a search that led to a deal with Johnston Tombigbee Furniture Manufacturing of Columbus, Miss. [D1.]

Higher charges for energy helped push consumer prices up three-tenths of 1 percent in February, the Government said. But most economists still believe that inflation remains at bay. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Publisher Pulls a Textbook In Furror on Sexual Content

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON

 BODY:
A publisher has decided not to sell a health textbook in Texas rather than make hundreds of revisions demanded by state officials after the book was criticized by anti-abortion groups and others for its discussion of condom use, homosexuality and other sexual issues.
The publisher, Holt, Rinehart and Winston Inc., of Austin, Tex., said it was pulling its 700-page high school health text out of the huge Texas textbook market not only because making scores of requested revisions was economically unfeasible but also because ethical issues were at stake. 
 "Some of the mandated revisions are in opposition to the fundamental philosophy of our program and are potentially injurious to the students of Texas," William A. Talkington, Holt's president wrote to Education Commissioner Lionel Meno. "We simply cannot produce a product that does not provide children with adequate instruction on life-threatening issues." The state released the letter on Tuesday.
The publisher's decision came after months of Texas Board of Education hearings in which family-planning, anti-abortion, gay-advocacy, fundamentalist Christian and other groups debated the merits of five health texts, written by Holt and four other publishers.
 
What Was Objectionable
 The board, which buys all textbooks for the state, last month requested a total of 400 revisions in the five texts, with the largest percentage of them for the Holt book, including the deletion of toll-free numbers for gay and lesbian groups and for teen-age suicide prevention groups.
The state wanted to see passages on homosexuality abridged, the addition of language describing Texas's sodomy laws and the deletion of a number of clinical illustrations, including a self-examination for testicular cancer and two comparing circumsised and uncircumsised penises.
"This underlines how hard it is getting to produce a textbook that appeals to a general audience and to satisfy all the pressure groups," said Gilbert T. Sewall, director of the American Textbook Council, a private group based in New York that reviews curriculum materials. "Especially in books dealing with health and sex education, highly opinionated, sometimes obsessive people come to the table -- from the homophobic to the libertine -- and publishers are increasingly inclined to retreat from subjects that bring so many marketing headaches."
Holt is the only publisher so far that has decided against making the revisions for Texas, which is planning to spend $7.5 million on the health texts. The other publishers appear to be seeking to comply with the state's requests, said Roger R. Rogalin, vice president of the Association of American Publishers, a trade organization.
 
'They Are Not Happy'
 "I know they are not happy, but they may stay in there," he said.
Textbook sales in Texas represent about 8 percent of the $2.2 billion national market for textbooks. The state is second only to California, which represents about 12 percent. Texas is also one of 22 states in which government committees must approve all texts sold in the state. Because Texas controls such a large market share, publishers often develop texts to meet the standards set by its 15-member Board of Education and then market them nationwide.
Peter Farwell, vice president of Harcourt General Inc, the corporation in Massachusetts that owns Holt, Rinehart and Winston, said yesterday that the changes would have made the book, titled "Holt Health," too expensive.
"When you look at the costs of making the changes, versus the potential sales, it wasn't feasible, especially because the changes made it a Texas-only book," Mr. Farwell said. "We created the book by talking to a lot of administrators and teachers involved in health education, who told us what they felt kids needed to know in order to deal with their health. The changes would have left out issues we feel are important."
Della May Moore, spokeswoman for the Texas Board of Education, said yesterday: "We regret that Holt has left the process, but we have a long cooperation with them and we're sure we'll be working with them again."
For a decade, Texas's official tastes in health education have swung wildly, Mr. Rogalin said. "The problem here is that the state asked for one thing and then changed their mind when the books were all done," he said. "And it was done for political reasons. This was another case in which factions of the religious right are getting more involved in boards of education all over the country."
 
'I Had No Choice'
 Monte S. Hasie, a board member and a stockbroker from Lubbock, was one of those who pressed for the deletions. He said he considered the Holt book unacceptable under any circumstances. He said, "I had no choice but to try to correct them."
Mr. Hasie said he was not opposed to sex education "done appropriately," but considered many passages and sexual illustrations in the Holt text too explicit.
"I didn't think this stuff should be part of the public schools," he said. "They were promoting homosexuality as an acceptable alternative life style and promoting sex as being O.K. if you use a condom. We were going to put Playboy and Penthouse out of business."
Rosemary D. Merriam, a spokeswoman for the Texas Family Planning Association, said that there were 49,000 teen-age pregnancies in the state, the second-highest number in the nation, and that the deletion of family planning information from textbooks could worsen the problem.
"We were upset because Holt's was a well-written book that doesn't talk down to children, and this means there will be less choice for Texas school districts on health education," she said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long-Term Rates Fall As Inflation Data Ease

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates on Treasury securities dropped sharply yesterday after back-to-back reports showed inflation rising at a restrained pace.
Late in the day the price of the Government's 30-year bond was up 11/16 , to 933/32 , for a yield of 6.80 percent, down from 6.89 percent on Tuesday. Short-term bills and intermediate notes also rallied, with three-month bill rates down to 3.51 percent, and six-month bill rates falling to 3.77 percent, both dropping by four basis points. 
 The yield on an intermediate-term three-year note fell five basis points, to 5.28 percent, while the closely followed 10-year note was down eight basis points, to 6.36 percent.
 
Another Report Coming
 But many traders said they believed it was too early to say whether the recent selloff in the bond market, which drove long-term rates to nearly 7 percent last week, was over.
One reason is that there is still another report on inflation, the Philadelphia Federal Reserve index of regional business activity, scheduled for today.
Although many analysts argue that the Philadelphia index is not a good barometer of price increases, it was the jump in the price components of this index last month that accelerated the slide in bond prices. That pushed the yield up through the 6.50 percent level.
The selloff began on Feb. 4, when the Federal Reserve raised its target for short-term interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point, to 3.25 percent, in an effort to head off any acceleration in inflation.
"Right now market sentiment is in a tug of war, with few new facts to back up the argument on either side," said Matthew Alexy, a government-securities trading specialist at CS First Boston.
 
Uncertainties Remain
 There are still uncertainties, he said, that must be addressed before determining if the selloff is over. One uncertainty is that the market is still unclear about the Fed's policy and whether the central bank will push up short-term interest rates a second time. The Fed's policy-making body meets on Tuesday.
And even if the inflation news remains good, traders and investors have to worry about the pace of economic growth, Mr. Alexy said. The severe winter weather and the California earthquake may be making the pace of growth at the beginning of the year appear slower than it is.
If the spring brings signs of faster growth, inflation worries will pick up again and there could be renewed selling.
But yesterday, after the report that the February Consumer Price Index was up a restrained three-tenths of a percent, investors bought Treasuries as quickly as they sold them when the concerns about inflation were at their peak.
The price index was what the market expected. The core rate, which excludes food and energy, was also up three-tenths of a percent. The energy component was up 1.6 percent, while home fuel oil prices rose 6 percent because of the cold winter.
 
Weather Distorts Data
 Nicocles L. Michas, vice president of research at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross Inc., said the consumer index, like the Producer Price Index on Tuesday, which rose five-tenths of a percent, showed modest price pressures. But he said he thought the market needed at least a month or two to get a handle on the rate of economic growth and potential buildup of inflation pressures. The winter weather, he said, had distorted much of the data from the first two months. "You have to establish a trend, and that may not show itself until at least April," he said.
Walter S. Frank, chief economist for IBC/Donoghue Inc., a company in Ashland, Mass., that provides research and analysis for retail and institutional investors, said he thought the producer and consumer indexes should help solidify the markets and calm them after a touch of hysteria.
"The data we're getting is close to reality, which is basically an uptick in inflation," Mr. Frank said. "That means that the more optimistic views in the market will be corrected. Except for temporary spikes, I don't see long-term interest rates much higher than they are right now, and perhaps lower by year end."
 
Housing Starts Slow
 The February housing data yesterday showed housing starts up 4.1 percent, to a 1.3 million annualized level, with January data revised to a drop of 22 percent, from a decline of 17.6 percent.
Some economists said they expected housing to rebound when the bad weather ended, but others were not so optimistic. They noted that the Government's report also showed that applications for building permits were down for the second consecutive month in February, falling 7.9 percent to a seasonally adjusted annualized rate of 1.25 million homes, after declining 8 percent in January.
The Treasury announced a planned $28 billion sale of new two- and five-year notes next Tuesday and Thursday, with the size of the sale unchanged from its last sale. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was being offered yesterday at a price to yield 4.97 percent, while the five-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.85 percent.
