HEADLINE: Trade Pact Is Spurring Mexican Deals in U.S.

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 16

 BODY:
During the heated debate last year over approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement, critics in the United States warned that the accord would encourage American employers to shift their resources south to Mexico.
Yet in the four months since Congress voted in favor of the agreement, the boldest acquisitions so far have been made by Mexican companies in the United States. 
 Since November, Mexicans have signed multimillion-dollar contracts to buy all or part of a major American bus manufacturer, one of the largest bakeries, and 39 Westin hotels spread across the United States. In some smaller deals in both countries, Mexicans and Americans have formed joint ventures, with the Mexicans retaining majority control. So far, the deals have not caused jobs to cross the border in either direction.
While the free-trade pact did not create financial incentives for Mexican companies to acquire businesses in the United States, it did create a psychological climate that has led some Mexican business owners to believe that they can compete on an equal footing with the Americans. In fact, the groundwork for the biggest projects was laid before the pact was signed, in anticipation that it would indeed take effect on Jan. 1. 1994.
"There probably were some people who thought it was going to be a 100 percent flow from the United States to Mexico," said Daniel Servitje, president of the cookie division of Grupo Industrial Bimbo, which is buying 50 percent of a Texas bakery and forming a joint venture to sell its products in the United States. "If they are surprised because Mexican companies have been aggressive, it's probably because they really haven't devoted much time to understanding our country."
The spate of deals in the wake of the trade agreement cannot compare with the powerful position that United States companies have held in Mexico since before the pact was signed. Companies like Ford and General Motors have operated here for generations, and control the domestic automotive market.
But the recent Mexican acquisitions have drawn attention to a new breed of Mexican businessmen, who say they are ready to compete in the international market. And they have quieted, at least temporarily, concerns that companies in the United States would flood over the border in search of $1-an-hour workers, even if some jobs have been relocated.
The cross-border deals have put the Mexican companies in a position to fight off American competition by moving first to expand their own reach. They are doing this as some American companies going into joint ventures gain access to Mexican industrial practices that they often do not understand or fully trust.
The bakery deal, for example, gives Bimbo (pronounced BEEM-bo), Mexico's largest baking company, a crack at the United States market, in which it has dabbled over the last year selling tortillas.
 
Learning Needed on Both Sides
 "What we felt," Mr. Servitje said, "was that as our two countries strengthened their relationship with Nafta, we, too, had to have a better understanding and knowledge of how the baking industry operates in the States." Mr. Servitje is likely to become a board member of the new joint venture.
Under the terms of the letter of intent signed by Bimbo and Mrs. Baird's Bakeries Inc. of Fort Worth, Bimbo will buy 50 percent of the family-owned company, and together they will form a joint venture in the United States called QFS Foods that will distribute a range of Bimbo bread and cake.
Mrs. Baird's does not intend to sell its products in Mexico for now, but Mr. Servitje said that could change.
The surprising financial strength of the Mexicans in making these acquisitions offers evidence that there is more money in the hands of business and industry here than anyone knew. It proves that Mexicans intend to be major players in the Nafta era.
But while their head start makes Mexican businessmen look smart now, some analysts here fear that American companies who accept a minority stake in order to get into the Mexican market may push for majority ownership once they have a foothold, relegating their Mexican partners to a junior role.
"Foreigners know that in the mid-term, two or three years hence, their technological expertise, their management expertise and their capacity to innovate are going to prevail," said Rogelio Ramirez de la O, an international consultant in Mexico City. "Eventually, that will give them a chance to dilute Mexican participation in the venture and give them control."
Mr. Servitje of Bimbo does not agree that American companies could wrest control from Mexicans in a few years, because, he says, the Mexican takeovers are based on business common sense.
"In this world of change, anything can go," Mr. Servitje conceded. "It all depends on how strong the company is and how clear are the intentions of its executives."
In another large Mexican-initiated deal, Consorcio Grupo Dina, which a few years ago was owned by the Mexican Government and lost $25 million a year, created one of the first companies to emerge after the approval of Nafta by buying Motor Coach Industries International of Phoenix, which has plants in the United States and Canada.
 
Valuable Technology
 The acquisition gives Dina a greatly expanded market while Mexico battles a domestic recession. It also gives the company access to more advanced technology, which will come in handy as it tries to fight competition from the bus division of Mercedes-Benz.
The recent deal for the Westin hotels may best exemplify the new Mexican corporate spirit. The $708 million transaction was made with a kind of business savvy Americans have not often associated with Mexican companies. Bernardo Dominguez, a 33-year-old entrepreneur in Mexico City, has signed a letter of intent to buy a company, with the help of Salomon Brothers and a group of United States and Mexican private investors. The hotel chain is much larger than his own three-resort property in Mexico.
The Westin chain was founded in the United States in 1930. It was sold in 1988 to the Aoki Corporation of Japan, from whom Mr. Dominguez is now buying the 39 hotels.
Such deals have shown how eager Mexican businessmen are to play in the big leagues.
"Now comes the real competition, when that Mexican entrepreneur who can put a few things together no longer has the Government standing in his way," said John P. McCray, an associate professor of strategic management at the University of Texas at San Antonio. "That Mexican works hard; he's got one hell of a lot of endurance, and a lot of family pride."
There is an impetus for the Mexican companies to move fast. The wave of confidence in the trade agreement's wake may not last long, with a presidential election coming in August, a less than fully resolved revolt in the southern state of Chiapas, and persistent talk of a devaluation of the peso -- something that could curb the ability to raise cash.
 
Diverging Views of Mexicans
 Mr. Ramirez, the consultant, commented: "Now they have the resources with which to finance growth over the next few years at a cheap exchange rate. In a sense, they are giving greater values to their own companies, so that when foreign investors come into Mexico in a serious way, the Mexican companies will be worth 50 to 100 percent more than if they had not gone into a joint venture now."
Mr. Ramirez believes that the Mexicans' position of strength will not last long. But Arturo Acevedo Aceves, chief of research at the Vector brokerage house in Mexico City, expects the acquisitions to continue for a while and perhaps gain strength as financial mergers take place, making lenders more sympathetic to Mexican needs.
Other big corporations from the United States made their moves before the trade agreement was signed. Last spring, Anheuser-Busch purchased an 18 per cent stake in Grupo Modelo, one of Mexico's largest brewing companies. Coca-Cola and Pepsi-Cola have bought into Mexican bottlers. And Bell Atlantic announced a billion-dollar purchase of part of the Mexican cellular telephone company Iusacell.
Since the American Congress approved the trade deal, some jobs have indeed moved south, as the pact's opponents predicted. Last Thursday, Nintendo of America relocated some assembly operations for its video games to two border plants in Mexico, laying off 136 workers in Seattle.

HEADLINE: Price Data Show Mild Inflation

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
Higher charges for energy helped push consumer prices up three-tenths of 1 percent in February, the Government said today. But most economists say they still believe that inflation remains at bay.
"There is little, if any, evidence that inflation is heating up," said Laurence H. Meyer, a consultant in St. Louis. But he added that the trend of progressively less inflation that marked most of the last decade had probably come to an end. 
 The reassuring news on inflation in February comes as the Federal Reserve prepares for a strategy session on interest rates next Tuesday.
 
Home Building Cool
 A separate Government report today showed that the pace at which builders broke ground for homes ticked up only slightly last month after collapse in January.
The cooling in home construction, which had been one of the strongest sectors of the economy in the second half of 1993, and the reduced nervousness about inflation helped the bond market advance, as long-term interest rates dropped sharply. [Page D16.]
Although housing starts were hurt by unusually severe weather in both months, industry specialists said it appeared that rising interest rates had also taken a toll on activity and that the near-boom conditions of 1993 were over. Rates on conventional mortgages have climbed to 7 5/8 percent this month, from a low point of 6 3/4 percent in October.
Unusually strong winter demand for energy was the dominating factor for the Consumer Price Index, as was the case on Tuesday, when the Labor Department reported an increase of five-tenths of 1 percent in inflation at the producer level in February. Excluding energy, consumer prices edged up just one-tenth of 1 percent for the second straight month. Producer prices were also almost flat, excluding energy.
The energy component, which accounts for 7 percent of the consumer's market basket and which had risen only once since April, jumped by 1.6 percent in February. But since then, oil prices have fallen.
While the Federal Reserve watches the price indexes, these gauges tend to look backward -- the consumer index's services component is an official lagging indicator -- and the central bank is seeking to head off revived inflation before it appears on the horizon.
Services rose four-tenths of 1 percent in price last month, and 3.3 percent for the three-month periods ending in November and February, the report showed.
 
0.9% Rise in New York
 The New York metropolitan area posted the largest price increase of any of the five big cities for which monthly price figures for February were included in today's report.
The rise in the New York area totaled nine-tenths of 1 percent, mainly because of a jump of 2.3 percent for shelter. Patrick C. Jackman, a department official, said the increase reflected an unusually large number of New Yorkers who moved and whose rent-regulated apartments were thus allowed to fetch higher rents.
Prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in Philadelphia and two-tenths of 1 percent in Chicago, while they were unchanged in Los Angeles and one-tenth of 1 percent lower in San Francisco.
Nationally, the heavily weighted housing component, accounting for 41 percent of the consumer index, rose an exceptionally big four-tenths of 1 percent last month. All household fuels rose, with heating oil up 7.2 percent.
Medical prices advanced three-tenths of 1 percent for the fourth straight month, bringing the 12-month inflation rate for this sector to less than 5 percent for the first time since the early 1970's.
Food prices eased three-tenths of 1 percent, the second consecutive decline, as fresh fruits and vegetables fell 3.4 percent.
 
Transportation Costs Up
 In contrast, transportation costs reversed course and climbed five-tenths of 1 percent on higher prices for gasoline, new cars and finance charges, partly offset by a rare decline for used cars.
The price of apparel, not yet reflecting the introduction of spring lines, eased slightly for the third consecutive month. Clothing prices are now also a bit lower than in February 1993.
With both food and energy excluded, so-called core prices moved up three-tenths of 1 percent last month, the same as the average for the final three months of last year.
Real average weekly earnings, the department also reported today, fell 1.5 percent last month as a result of a decline in hours worked and higher prices partly offset by a rise in hourly earnings.
The Commerce Department's tally of housing starts showed an annual rate in February of 1,309,000, up 4 percent. But this regained only a small part of the ground lost when starts plummeted by 22 percent in January, to a revised rate of 1,258,000.
David F. Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders, said activity lost to severe weather might not be made up now that mortgage rates had climbed nearly a percentage point from their lows.
"It seems pretty clear that the bottom of the interest rate cycle occurred last fall," Mr. Seiders said.
Housing starts rose in the Northeast and South last month, but declined in the West and Midwest.
Permits for future construction fell by 7.8 percent last month, to a rate of 1,251,000. Only the Northeast managed a gain, and it was a slim one from a very depressed pace.
Figures on shipments of mobile homes, which lag a month, showed producers delivering at a 316,000 annual rate in January, up 2.6 percent from December.

HEADLINE: For a Furniture Maker, a Taste of a Global Future

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: COLUMBUS, Miss.

 BODY:
It was August, when this part of the country sags under a slathering of humidity and heat. T. Scott Berry was up the road from here at a dealers show in Tupelo, displaying some of the furniture he makes. He was in the back of a warehouse, not doing much of anything, when he got a call from the desk. A man was there to see him.
"So I go out and there's this guy standing there," Mr. Berry recalled. "I almost threw him out, but I said, O.K., I'll talk to him." 
 Three months later, at the invitation of the Chinese man who came to call, Mr. Berry, a descendant of Arkansas mule traders and Mississippi furniture makers, was in Beijing trying to figure out how to work China into plans for his family company, the Johnston Tombigbee Furniture Manufacturing Company. He returned with a deal to have the Chinese make chairs for him; the first shipment will arrive next month.
 
Entering the Global Market
 "I was trying to move as fast as possible," said Mr. Berry, 40, a tousle-haired redhead who charges like a halfback through his vast factories, clambering over conveyor belts, scrutinizing racks of rough wood bedposts and calling out to many of his 1,000 employees by name. "It could be the future."
Here in Columbus, a town of 23,800 people, of white-columned antebellum mansions and a main street languorous in its pedestrian traffic, the global economy seems to intrude in a scattering of Japanese cars, a handful of Chinese restaurants and not much else. But for Johnston Tombigbee, the future probably lies as much in China -- in cities like Dalian, in what used to be Manchuria -- as it does in America's Southern heartland.
China, with Asia's fastest-growing economy, has aggressively sought out international markets for its growing industries, including furniture. Chinese business officials are diligently trolling the waters of trade shows, scrutinizing merchandise, buttonholing manufacturers, looking for deals. And furniture makers like Mr. Berry are often obliging in an effort to lower manufacturing costs and increase profitability.
Mr. Berry's new Chinese partner, a man named Yang Yijian, who he said preferred to be called James, quoted Johnston Tombigbee prices for the chairs that were two-thirds lower than what Mr. Berry pays in countries like Brazil.
"I said to myself, where is cheap labor and massive amounts of raw material?" Mr. Berry said. "I thought it was Brazil, but now it looks like it's China."
Although Taiwan has exported furniture to the United States for several years, China has made a big push only in the last year, according to Bruce Plantz, the executive editor of FDM Furniture Design and Manufacturing, a trade publication.
For the first nine months of 1993, furniture imports from China were worth $225 million, up 56 percent over the corresponding period of 1992. And combined imports from China, Malaysia, Indonesia, Singapore and the Philippines were up 52 percent from 1992, to $687 million. During 1993, the value of the United States wholesale residential furniture market was about $18 billion, according to Mr. Plantz.
For Johnston Tombigbee, the cheap labor and materials in China are the backbone of an expansion strategy. With reported sales of $40 million last year, Johnston Tombigbee ranks 139th among the top 300 makers of furniture in America, according to FDM. But Mr. Berry says he intended to move up the ladder by expanding into higher-end furniture, which he has started to make in Honduras and the Philippines, and by reducing the number of parts in other finished products to make them easier to produce in China.
"I see my furniture being made mostly of foreign-made parts," Mr. Berry said. "I would say that foreign countries like China will play a big part of it. With all the growing Government intervention in manufacturing, whether it's the E.P.A., OSHA, workers' comp, we'll get to the point where we'll be an assembler and packager. That's what will happen."
 
A Company's Revival
 Seven years ago, Johnston Tombigbee had all but collapsed, largely the result of family warfare and not a small bit of neglect and weak management, Mr. Berry said. He had quit the family business -- "I had all I could stand," he recalled -- and was wandering around Brazil, looking for someone to make some furniture he could sell in the United States. Then his wife called.
"I told him the company was going to be sold," Ruth Berry said, "and I told him to get home and fix it. It was worse than moribund."
Mr. Berry hurried back to Columbus and the shards of the family business.
The factories, including the original brick factory, were silent. There were no orders, no piles of lumber, not a piece of furniture. And 1,000 people were out of work. "It was pretty scary," Mr. Berry said, "but when you're 34, 35, you're bold." Boldness, in this case, meant three plans for the business, ranging from liquidation of remaining assets, to a partial restart of the factories coupled with some importing of furniture, to a complete start-up of all the factories.
"We did a full-blown massive restart," he said, "and that's where we are now."
Johnston Tombigbee is among the small, specialized furniture makers battling for the great American middle-class home market. The company, in its modest prime, specialized in wooden beds, dressers and side tables -- what is known in the trade as "promotional bedroom furniture."
While the company still produces wood furniture cheaply, China holds the promise of even lower costs. That is why Mr. Berry agreed to give the Chinese an opportunity to make what is known as a sled chair, about the simplest and cheapest wood chair made. It sells for about $50. With a padded fabric-covered seat and back held together by two square-shaped wooden frames, the bottoms of the squares mimic runners on a sled.
Mr. Berry recalled telling Yang Yijian during his visit to Tupelo that "when you get back, I'll fax you a print of the chair and send you a sample so you can make it."
"He quoted me an outstanding price on it, an unbelievable price," Mr. Berry said. "This chair costs me $12.50 from Brazil. James gave me a quote of $4.50."
Mr. Yang told Mr. Berry that he represented the Guangming Furniture Company in Dalian in northeast China. Within a month, the company had shipped some samples of a sled chair frame to Mr. Berry in Columbus. He sent back some of his bedposts and bought a ticket to Beijing.
"When I showed up at the Grand Hotel, they had these bedposts all made for me," Mr. Berry said. "It was pretty clear that they could absolutely do what I needed done."
While a good proportion of the furniture sold in the United States is made abroad, none of the sort of nine-piece ensembles that grace the bedrooms of middle America are manufactured there. "There are too many parts," Mr. Berry said. "So far it doesn't make any sense."
But with the prices Guangming is offering, Mr. Berry is redesigning his furniture to reduce the number of parts for pieces like dressers, and to make the parts interchangeable.
Mr. Berry still finds his relationship with Mr. Yang somewhat enigmatic. "I'm not sure who I'm dealing with with James Yang to a certain extent," he confessed. "But it was obvious to me that James was the kind of guy I could make a relationship with and the kind of guy I could do business with."
Next month, Mr. Yang will come here with a vice president from the Guangdong Development Bank, one of China's new lending institutions that is looking for investment deals with American companies. Mr. Berry said that while sled chairs and bedposts are a start, a deal with a Chinese bank to build a furniture factory in China is now a growing possibility.
Mr. Berry said he did not yet know the long-term implications of foreign manufacturing on his business or on the size of his work force. "We can't meet all our orders as is," he said.
Yet he is proceeding with caution. "I just put my toe in it with the sled chair," he said. "But now, I'm up to my knees, but cautiously, to see if any sharks are out there. But if this works, it's a gold mine."

HEADLINE: Stocks Mixed as Dow Falls on Late Selling

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
At last, stock traders believed good news about inflation yesterday. After some hesitation, most leading stock indicators followed the trend in the resurgent bond market and closed higher in active trading.
The exception was the Dow Jones industrial average, the most closely watched stock barometer, which had climbed steadily into positive territory by 2:30 P.M. But in the session's final seconds, the Dow dropped more than 13 points, probably because of high-speed computer trading. 
 At 4 P.M., the Dow appeared to have closed at 3,861.39, up 11.8 points, according to Bloomberg Financial Markets. But that did not reckon with a late deluge of sell orders. By the time the Big Board's Superdot computer system caught up, the Dow industrials had dropped 1.44 points to 3,848.15.
 
Huge Computer Program
 Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, estimated that a huge computer program involving as many as 6 million shares was executed close to or at the end of the session. Which Wall Street firm executed the program will not be known for weeks, when securities firms disclose trading records.
Philip H. Smyth, a market analyst at Birinyi, said such "market on close" sell programs are sometimes used near "witching hours." There will be one Friday, when three sets of futures and options expire.
Birinyi Associates has detected 18 other late declines in the Dow, probably resulting from computer trading, since January 1993. The largest occurred on June 18, 1993, when four such computer programs helped drag down the Dow some 25 points.
These programs often involve leading stocks in the Standard & Poor's 500, which overlap with most, if not all, of the 30 stocks in the Dow industrials, Mr. Smyth said. The programs are often favored by passive investors who want a portfolio that simply mirrors the broad market.
 
S.& P. 500 Rises 2.41
 The S.& P. 500 rose 2.41 points, to 469.42, and the smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 5.47 points, to 798.99. The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 1.35 points, to 260.34, on volume of 306.8 million shares. Advancing stocks outnumbered declining stocks, 1,346 to 803, on the Big Board. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 1.69 point, to 469.82.
Meanwhile, stock traders' counterparts in the bond market bid bond prices up and dragged yields down for the third time in four sessions. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond reached 6.80 percent, down 9 basis points, or hundredths of a point, from the previous day.
Both the Consumer Price Index, released yesterday, and the Producer Price Index, released on Tuesday, showed scant inflation. Rising inflation hurts both stocks and bonds.
The Federal Reserve Board is to meet next Tuesday to decide, among other things, its policy on interest rates, in effect, a referendum on inflation. This week's inflation data will be among the critical factors that the Fed governors will consider.
 
Interest Rates Drive Markets
 Interest rates on Government bonds have been the major factor driving both the stock and bond markets, said Martin D. Sass, a money manager. His M.D. Sass Investors Services Inc. manages $2.1 billion, apportioned as $600 million in stock, $1.4 billion in bonds and $100 million in cash.
His firm's researchers have concluded, after looking at 15 years of data, that every half-point rise or fall in the 10-year Government bond leads to a 200-point rise or fall in the Dow industrials.
So what will happen in today's session? Mr. Sass laughed and said: "I hate to make day-to-day projections. The stock market day-to-day is almost a random event."
The most active stock yesterday was Centex Telemanagement, with 12.5 million shares traded. It rose 5 5/8, to 10 1/2, after MFS Communications announced a tender offer of $9 a share. Centex manages phone services for corporations, and MFS offers local phone connections to corporations.
Telefonos de Mexico's American depository receipts were the second most actively traded stock yesterday at 10 million shares. Telmex, whose shares fell 1 3/8 on Tuesday, recovered yesterday, rising 7/8, to 61 3/4, possibly on bargain hunting.
